Madam, according as your Ladyship desired, By message craved, so is Lord Talbot come.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 4)
Even like a man new-haled from the rack, So fare my limbs with long imprisonment; And these gray locks, the pursuivants of death, Nestor-like aged in an age of care, Argue the end of Edmund Mortimer; These eyes, like lamps whose wasting oil is spent, Wax dim, as drawing to their exigent; Weak shoulders, overborne with burdening grief, And pithless arms, like to a withered vine That droops his sapless branches to the ground; Yet are these feet, whose strengthless stay is numb, Unable to support this lump of clay, Swift-winged with desire to get a grave, As witting no other comfort have.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 1)
Canst thou deny it? Did not Goodwife Keech, the butcher's wife, come in then and call me Gossip Quickly, coming in to borrow a mess of vinegar, telling us she had a good dish of prawns, whereby thou didst desire to eat some, whereby told thee they were ill for a green wound?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 42)
And didst thou not, when she was gone downstairs, desire me to be no more so familiarity with such poor people, saying that ere long they should call me madam?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 43)
say to you, do desire deliverance from these officers, being upon hasty employment in the King's affairs.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 57)

True.   Admit no other way to save his life-- As subscribe not that, nor any other-- But, in the loss of question, that you, his sister, Finding yourself desired of such a person Whose credit with the judge, or own great place, Could fetch your brother from the manacles Of the all-binding law, and that there were No earthly mean to save him but that either You must lay down the treasures of your body To this supposed, or else to let him suffer, What would you do?(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 35)

Wouldst thou aught with me?  Here's my son, sir, a poor boy--  Not a poor boy, sir, but the rich Jew's man, that would, sir, as my father shall specify--  He hath a great infection, sir, as one would say, to serve--  Indeed, the short and the long is, serve the Jew, and have a desire, as my father shall specify--  His master and he (saving your Worship's reverence) are scarce cater-cousins--  To be brief, the very truth is that the Jew, having done me wrong, doth cause me, as my father being, hope, an old man, shall frutify unto you--  have here a dish of doves that would bestow upon your Worship, and my suit is--  In very brief, the suit is impertinent to myself, as your Worship shall know by this honest old man, and though say it, though old man yet poor man, my father--  One speak for both.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 51)
desire no more delight Than to be under sail and gone tonight.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 29)
Now make your choice.   This first, of gold, who this inscription bears, "Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire"; The second, silver, which this promise carries, "Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves"; This third, dull lead, with warning all as blunt, "Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 1)
What if strayed no farther, but chose here? Let's see once more this saying graved in gold: "Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 14)
" Why, that's the lady! All the world desires her.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 15)
Ha, let me see: "Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 10)
" What many men desire--that "many" may be meant By the fool multitude that choose by show, Not learning more than the fond eye doth teach, Which pries not to th' interior, but like the martlet Builds in the weather on the outward wall, Even in the force and road of casualty.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 11)
will not choose what many men desire, Because will not jump with common spirits And rank me with the barbarous multitudes.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 12)

Why does the Prince love him so then?  Because their legs are both of a bigness, and he plays at quoits well, and eats conger and fennel, and drinks off candles' ends for flap-dragons, and rides the wild mare with the boys, and jumps upon joint stools, and swears with a good grace, and wears his boots very smooth like unto the sign of the Leg, and breeds no bate with telling of discreet stories, and such other gambol faculties he has that show a weak mind and an able body, for the which the Prince admits him; for the Prince himself is such another.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 117)
am old, am old.  love thee better than love e'er a scurvy young boy of them all.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 125)

do much wonder that one man, seeing how much another man is a fool when he dedicates his behaviors to love, will, after he hath laughed at such shallow follies in others, become the argument of his own scorn by falling in love--and such a man is Claudio.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 3)
will not be sworn but love may transform me to an oyster, but I'll take my oath on it, till he have made an oyster of me, he shall never make me such a fool.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 7)

ay.  Stalk on, stalk on; the fowl sits.--I did never think that lady would have loved any man.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 34)
Is 't possible? Sits the wind in that corner?  By my troth, my lord, cannot tell what to think of it, but that she loves him with an enraged affection, it is past the infinite of thought.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 36)

measure him," says she, "by my own spirit, for should flout him if he writ to me, yea, though love him, should.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 53)
Were it good, think you?  Hero thinks surely she will die, for she says she will die if he love her not, and she will die ere she make her love known, and she will die if he woo her rather than she will bate one breath of her accustomed crossness.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 64)
She doth well. If she should make tender of her love, 'tis very possible he'll scorn it, for the man, as you know all, hath a contemptible spirit.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 65)
Well, am sorry for your niece. Shall we go seek Benedick and tell him of her love?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 72)

Yet say he is in love.  There is no appearance of fancy in him, unless it be a fancy that he hath to strange disguises, as to be a Dutchman today, a Frenchman tomorrow, or in the shape of two countries at once, as a German from the waist downward, all slops, and a Spaniard from the hip upward, no doublet.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 12)

But all the charms of love, Salt Cleopatra, soften thy wanned lip!(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 10)
Worthily spoken, Maecenas.  Or, if you borrow one another's love for the instant, you may, when you hear no more words of Pompey, return it again.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 40)
Her love to both Would each to other and all loves to both Draw after her.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 53)
Let me have thy hand. Further this act of grace; and from this hour The heart of brothers govern in our loves And sway our great designs.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 59)
There's my hand.  sister bequeath you whom no brother Did ever love so dearly.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 60)
Let her live To join our kingdoms and our hearts; and never Fly off our loves again.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 61)
The poop was beaten gold, Purple the sails, and so perfumed that The winds were lovesick with them.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 81)
2        Give me some music--music, moody food Of us that trade in love.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 0)
Sir, never loved you much, but ha' praised you When you have well deserved ten times as much As have said you did.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 28)
think the policy of that purpose made more in the marriage than the love of the parties.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 47)
have seen a medicine That's able to breathe life into a stone, Quicken a rock, and make you dance canary With sprightly fire and motion, whose simple touch Is powerful to araise King Pippen, nay, To give great Charlemagne a pen in 's hand And write to her a love line.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 34)
More, more, a hundred of them.  Sir, am a poor friend of yours that loves you.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 1, Scene 15)
"  Make choice and see. Who shuns thy love shuns all his love in me.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 27)
Love make your fortunes twenty times above Her that so wishes, and her humble love.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 32)
cannot love her, nor will strive to do 't.   Thou wrong'st thyself if thou shouldst strive to choose.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 63)
--Here, take her hand, Proud, scornful boy, unworthy this good gift, That dost in vile misprision shackle up My love and her desert; that canst not dream We, poising us in her defective scale, Shall weigh thee to the beam; that wilt not know It is in us to plant thine honor where We please to have it grow.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 66)
As thou lov'st her Thy love's to me religious; else, does err.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 74)
The great prerogative and rite of love, Which as your due time claims, he does acknowledge But puts it off to a compelled restraint, Whose want and whose delay is strewed with sweets, Which they distill now in the curbed time To make the coming hour o'erflow with joy And pleasure drown the brim.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 3, Scene 15)
The brains of my Cupid's knocked out, and begin to love as an old man loves money, with no stomach.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 6)
Show me the place. love to cope him in these sullen fits, For then he's full of matter.(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 20)
Why, what make you here? Why are you virtuous? Why do people love you?(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 1)
Corin, that thou knew'st how do love her!   partly guess, for have loved ere now.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 8)
No, Corin, being old, thou canst not guess, Though in thy youth thou wast as true a lover As ever sighed upon a midnight pillow.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 9)
But if thy love were ever like to mine-- As sure think did never man love so-- How many actions most ridiculous Hast thou been drawn to by thy fantasy?(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 10)
Into a thousand that have forgotten.   thou didst then never love so heartily.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 11)
If thou rememb'rest not the slightest folly That ever love did make thee run into, Thou hast not loved.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 12)
Or if thou hast not sat as do now, Wearing thy hearer in thy mistress' praise, Thou hast not loved.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 13)
Or if thou hast not broke from company Abruptly, as my passion now makes me, Thou hast not loved.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 14)
And mine. remember when was in love broke my sword upon a stone and bid him take that for coming a-night to Jane Smile; and remember the kissing of her batler, and the cow's dugs that her pretty chopped hands had milked; and remember the wooing of a peascod instead of her, from whom took two cods and, giving her them again, said with weeping tears "Wear these for my sake.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 16)
" We that are true lovers run into strange capers.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 17)
But as all is mortal in nature, so is all nature in love mortal in folly.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 18)
And to you, gentle sir, and to you all.   prithee, shepherd, if that love or gold Can in this desert place buy entertainment, Bring us where we may rest ourselves and feed.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 25)
Song.   Under the greenwood tree Who loves to lie with me And turn his merry note Unto the sweet bird's throat, Come hither, come hither, come hither.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 0)
Come, warble, come.  Song.    Who doth ambition shun And loves to live i' th' sun, Seeking the food he eats And pleased with what he gets, Come hither, come hither, come hither.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 16)
There is an old poor man Who after me hath many a weary step Limped in pure love.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 45)

Good or bad?  Not according to the prayer of the people, for they love not Martius.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 1)
Nature teaches beasts to know their friends.  Pray you, who does the wolf love?(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 2)
Menenius, you are known well enough, too.  am known to be a humorous patrician and one that loves a cup of hot wine with not a drop of allaying Tiber in 't; said to be something imperfect in favoring the first complaint, hasty and tinder-like upon too trivial motion; one that converses more with the buttock of the night than with the forehead of the morning.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 18)
Honorable Menenius, my boy Martius approaches. For the love of Juno, let's go!(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 36)
'Tis thought That Martius shall be consul. have seen The dumb men throng to see him, and the blind To hear him speak; matrons flung gloves, Ladies and maids their scarves and handkerchiefs, Upon him as he passed; the nobles bended As to Jove's statue, and the Commons made shower and thunder with their caps and shouts.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 106)
That's a brave fellow, but he's vengeance proud and loves not the common people.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 2)
'Faith, there hath been many great men that have flattered the people who ne'er loved them; and there be many that they have loved they know not wherefore; so that, if they love they know not why, they hate upon no better a ground.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 3)
Therefore, for Coriolanus neither to care whether they love or hate him manifests the true knowledge he has in their disposition and, out of his noble carelessness, lets them plainly see 't.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 4)
If he did not care whether he had their love or no, he waved indifferently 'twixt doing them neither good nor harm; but he seeks their hate with greater devotion than they can render it him and leaves nothing undone that may fully discover him their opposite.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 5)
Now, to seem to affect the malice and displeasure of the people is as bad as that which he dislikes, to flatter them for their love.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 6)
He loves your people, But tie him not to be their bedfellow.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 20)
You soothed not, therefore hurt not; but your people, love them as they weigh.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 26)
You have not indeed loved the common people.  You should account me the more virtuous that have not been common in my love.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 37)
He has our voices, sir.   We pray the gods he may deserve your loves.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 66)
You should have said That as his worthy deeds did claim no less Than what he stood for, so his gracious nature Would think upon you for your voices, and Translate his malice towards you into love, Standing your friendly lord.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 79)
Did you perceive He did solicit you in free contempt When he did need your loves, and do you think That his contempt shall not be bruising to you When he hath power to crush?(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 82)
Enforce his pride And his old hate unto you. Besides, forget not With what contempt he wore the humble weed, How in his suit he scorned you; but your loves, Thinking upon his services, took from you Th' apprehension of his present portance, Which most gibingly, ungravely, he did fashion After the inveterate hate he bears you.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 89)
Still swear love you.   If you but said so, 'twere as deep with me.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 40)
In these feared hopes barely gratify your love; they failing, must die much your debtor.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 2)
Let there be no honor Where there is beauty, truth where semblance, love Where there's another man.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 42)
Ere learn love, I'll practice to obey.   How if your husband start some otherwhere?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 11)
Sister, you know he promised me a chain. Would that alone o' love he would detain, So he would keep fair quarter with his bed.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 49)
As you love strokes, so jest with me again. You know no Centaur?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 3)
Because that familiarly sometimes Do use you for my fool and chat with you, Your sauciness will jest upon my love And make a common of my serious hours.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 13)
Ah, do not tear away thyself from me! For know, my love, as easy mayst thou fall drop of water in the breaking gulf, And take unmingled thence that drop again Without addition or diminishing, As take from me thyself and not me too.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 52)
Shall, Antipholus, Even in the spring of love thy love-springs rot?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 1)
Shall love, in building, grow so ruinous? If you did wed my sister for her wealth, Then for her wealth's sake use her with more kindness.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 2)
Or if you like elsewhere, do it by stealth -- Muffle your false love with some show of blindness.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 3)
Alas, poor women, make us but believe, Being compact of credit, that you love us.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 10)
Let love, being light, be drowned if she sink.   What, are you mad that you do reason so?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 21)
As good to wink, sweet love, as look on night.   Why call you me "love"?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 24)
Thee will love, and with thee lead my life; Thou hast no husband yet, nor no wife.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 28)
Never was monarch better feared and loved Than is your Majesty.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 19)
Alas, your too much love and care of me Are heavy orisons 'gainst this poor wretch.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 29)
My Lord of Cambridge here, You know how apt our love was to accord To furnish him with all appurtenants Belonging to his honor, and this man Hath, for a few light crowns, lightly conspired And sworn unto the practices of France To kill us here in Hampton; to the which This knight, no less for bounty bound to us Than Cambridge is, hath likewise sworn.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 45)
--My love, give me thy lips. Look to my chattels and my movables.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 22)
Self-love, my liege, is not so vile a sin As self-neglecting.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 21)
Therefore in fierce tempest is he coming, In thunder and in earthquake like a Jove, That, if requiring fail, he will compel, And bids you, in the bowels of the Lord, Deliver up the crown and to take mercy On the poor souls for whom this hungry war Opens his vasty jaws, and on your head Turning the widows' tears, the orphans' cries, The dead men's blood, the prived maidens' groans, For husbands, fathers, and betrothed lovers That shall be swallowed in this controversy.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 25)
This duke as much They love and dote on, call him bounteous Buckingham, The mirror of all courtesy.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 20)
You few that loved me And dare be bold to weep for Buckingham, His noble friends and fellows, whom to leave Is only bitter to him, only dying, Go with me like good angels to my end, And as the long divorce of steel falls on me, Make of your prayers one sweet sacrifice, And lift my soul to heaven.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 30)
Ever beloved and loving may his rule be; And when old Time shall lead him to his end, Goodness and he fill up one monument!(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 38)
Yet thus far we are one in fortunes: both Fell by our servants, by those men we loved most-- most unnatural and faithless service.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 49)
Heaven has an end in all; yet, you that hear me, This from a dying man receive as certain: Where you are liberal of your loves and counsels Be sure you be not loose; for those you make friends And give your hearts to, when they once perceive The least rub in your fortunes, fall away Like water from you, never found again But where they mean to sink you.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 50)
And out of all these to restore the King, He counsels a divorce, a loss of her That like a jewel has hung twenty years About his neck, yet never lost her luster; Of her that loves him with that excellence That angels love good men with; even of her That, when the greatest stroke of fortune falls, Will bless the King.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 12)
For me, my lords, love him not nor fear him; there's my creed.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 19)
And once more in mine arms bid him welcome, And thank the holy conclave for their loves.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 43)
Your Grace must needs deserve all strangers' loves, You are so noble.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 45)
Where's Gardiner?   know your Majesty has always loved her So dear in heart not to deny her that woman of less place might ask by law: Scholars allowed freely to argue for her.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 48)
Or which of your friends Have not strove to love, although knew He were mine enemy?(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 17)
If, in the course And process of this time, you can report, And prove it too, against mine honor aught, My bond to wedlock or my love and duty Against your sacred person, in God's name Turn me away and let the foul'st contempt Shut door upon me, and so give me up To the sharp'st kind of justice.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 20)

Mad for thy love?  My lord, do not know, But truly do fear it.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 29)
Come, go with me. will go seek the King. This is the very ecstasy of love, Whose violent property fordoes itself And leads the will to desperate undertakings As oft as any passions under heaven That does afflict our natures.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 34)
Come, go we to the King. This must be known, which, being kept close, might move More grief to hide than hate to utter love.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 40)
will be faithful.  Doubt thou the stars are fire, Doubt that the sun doth move, Doubt truth to be a liar, But never doubt love.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 38)
dear Ophelia, am ill at these numbers. have not art to reckon my groans, but that love thee best, most best, believe it.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 39)
But how hath she received his love?  What do you think of me?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 42)
But what might you think, When had seen this hot love on the wing (As perceived it, must tell you that, Before my daughter told me), what might you, Or my dear Majesty your queen here, think, If had played the desk or table-book Or given my heart a winking, mute and dumb, Or looked upon this love with idle sight?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 44)
If he love her not, And be not from his reason fall'n thereon, Let me be no assistant for a state, But keep a farm and carters.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 53)
He is far gone. And truly, in my youth, suffered much extremity for love, very near this.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 64)
That you must teach me. But let me conjure you by the rights of our fellowship, by the consonancy of our youth, by the obligation of our ever-preserved love, and by what more dear a better proposer can charge you withal: be even and direct with me whether you were sent for or no.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 103)
What say you?  Nay, then, have an eye of you.--If you love me, hold not off.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 104)
The adventurous knight shall use his foil and target, the lover shall not sigh gratis, the humorous man shall end his part in peace, the clown shall make those laugh whose lungs are tickle o' th' sear, and the lady shall say her mind freely, or the blank verse shall halt for 't.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 114)

If he love Caesar, all that he can do Is to himself: take thought and die for Caesar.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 67)
Never fear that. If he be so resolved, can o'ersway him, for he loves to hear That unicorns may be betrayed with trees, And bears with glasses, elephants with holes, Lions with toils, and men with flatterers.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 73)
He loves me well, and have given him reasons. Send him but hither, and I'll fashion him.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 79)
And upon my knees charm you, by my once commended beauty, By all your vows of love, and that great vow Which did incorporate and make us one, That you unfold to me, your self, your half, Why you are heavy, and what men tonight Have had resort to you; for here have been Some six or seven who did hide their faces Even from darkness.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 100)
But for your private satisfaction, Because love you, will let you know.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 35)

give you welcome with a powerless hand But with a heart full of unstained love.(King John, Act 0, Scene 4)
Who would not do thee right?   Upon thy cheek lay this zealous kiss As seal to this indenture of my love: That to my home will no more return Till Angiers and the right thou hast in France, Together with that pale, that white-faced shore, Whose foot spurns back the ocean's roaring tides And coops from other lands her islanders, Even till that England, hedged in with the main, That water-walled bulwark, still secure And confident from foreign purposes, Even till that utmost corner of the West Salute thee for her king.(King John, Act 0, Scene 6)
take his mother's thanks, a widow's thanks, Till your strong hand shall help to give him strength To make a more requital to your love.(King John, Act 0, Scene 8)
England we love, and for that England's sake With burden of our armor here we sweat.(King John, Act 0, Scene 29)

With what?   With that which we lovers entitle "affected.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 88)

must employ him in a letter to my love.  Master, will you win your love with a French brawl?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 3)
How meanest thou? Brawling in French?  No, my complete master, but to jig off a tune at the tongue's end, canary to it with your feet, humor it with turning up your eyelids, sigh a note and sing a note, sometimes through the throat as if you swallowed love with singing love, sometimes through the nose as if you snuffed up love by smelling love; with your hat penthouse-like o'er the shop of your eyes, with your arms crossed on your thin-belly doublet like a rabbit on a spit; or your hands in your pocket like a man after the old painting; and keep not too long in one tune, but a snip and away.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 4)
"  Call'st thou my love "hobby-horse"?  No, master.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 8)
The hobby-horse is but a colt, and your love perhaps a hackney.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 9)
--But have you forgot your love?  Almost had.  Negligent student, learn her by heart.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 10)
man, if live; and this "by, in, and without," upon the instant: "by" heart you love her, because your heart cannot come by her; "in" heart you love her, because your heart is in love with her; and "out" of heart you love her, being out of heart that you cannot enjoy her.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 13)
Remuneration!   And forsooth in love! that have been love's whip, very beadle to a humorous sigh, critic, nay, a nightwatch constable, domineering pedant o'er the boy, Than whom no mortal so magnificent.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 82)
This wimpled, whining, purblind, wayward boy, This Signior Junior, giant dwarf, Dan Cupid, Regent of love rhymes, lord of folded arms, Th' anointed sovereign of sighs and groans, Liege of all loiterers and malcontents, Dread prince of plackets, king of codpieces, Sole imperator and great general Of trotting paritors--O my little heart!(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 83)
What? love, sue, seek a wife? woman, that is like a German clock, Still a-repairing, ever out of frame, And never going aright, being a watch, But being watched that it may still go right.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 85)
Nay, to be perjured, which is worst of all. And, among three, to love the worst of all, whitely wanton with a velvet brow, With two pitch-balls stuck in her face for eyes.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 86)
Well, will love, write, sigh, pray, sue, groan. Some men must love my lady, and some Joan.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 90)

could. Shall entreat thy love? will. What shalt thou exchange for rags?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 42)

do confess it and repent it, father.   'Tis meet so, daughter; but lest you do repent As that the sin hath brought you to this shame, Which sorrow is always toward ourselves, not heaven, Showing we would not spare heaven as we love it, But as we stand in fear--   do repent me as it is an evil, And take the shame with joy.(Measure for Measure, Act 2, Scene 11)
injurious love That respites me a life, whose very comfort Is still a dying horror.(Measure for Measure, Act 2, Scene 14)

something do excuse the thing hate For his advantage that dearly love.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 43)

There she lost a noble and renowned brother, in his love toward her ever most kind and natural; with him, the portion and sinew of her fortune, her marriage dowry; with both, her combinate husband, this well-seeming Angelo.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 87)
His unjust unkindness, that in all reason should have quenched her love, hath, like an impediment in the current, made it more violent and unruly.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 93)

The King doth keep his revels here tonight. Take heed the Queen come not within his sight, For Oberon is passing fell and wrath Because that she, as her attendant, hath lovely boy stolen from an Indian king; She never had so sweet a changeling.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 5)
But she perforce withholds the loved boy, Crowns him with flowers and makes him all her joy.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 7)
But know When thou hast stolen away from Fairyland And in the shape of Corin sat all day Playing on pipes of corn and versing love To amorous Phillida.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 21)
Why art thou here, Come from the farthest steep of India, But that, forsooth, the bouncing Amazon, Your buskined mistress and your warrior love, To Theseus must be wedded, and you come To give their bed joy and prosperity?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 22)
How canst thou thus for shame, Titania, Glance at my credit with Hippolyta, Knowing know thy love to Theseus?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 23)
certain aim he took At a fair vestal throned by the west, And loosed his love-shaft smartly from his bow As it should pierce a hundred thousand hearts.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 47)

love thee not; therefore pursue me not. Where is Lysander and fair Hermia?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 58)

And am sick when look not on you. sweet Athenian lady is in love With a disdainful youth.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 88)

pray thee, gentle mortal, sing again. Mine ear is much enamored of thy note, So is mine eye enthralled to thy shape, And thy fair virtue's force perforce doth move me On the first view to say, to swear, love thee.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 53)
And yet, to say the truth, reason and love keep little company together nowadays.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 55)
am a spirit of no common rate. The summer still doth tend upon my state, And do love thee.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 60)
Hop in his walks and gambol in his eyes; Feed him with apricocks and dewberries, With purple grapes, green figs, and mulberries; The honey-bags steal from the humble-bees, And for night-tapers crop their waxen thighs And light them at the fiery glowworms' eyes To have my love to bed and to arise; And pluck the wings from painted butterflies To fan the moonbeams from his sleeping eyes.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 65)
My mistress with a monster is in love. Near to her close and consecrated bower, While she was in her dull and sleeping hour, crew of patches, rude mechanicals, That work for bread upon Athenian stalls, Were met together to rehearse a play Intended for great Theseus' nuptial day.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 2)
When in that moment, so it came to pass, Titania waked and straightway loved an ass.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 9)

why rebuke you him that loves you so? Lay breath so bitter on your bitter foe!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 13)

Of thy misprision must perforce ensue Some true-love turned, and not a false turned true.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 34)

Look where thy love comes. Yonder is thy dear.      Dark night, that from the eye his function takes, The ear more quick of apprehension makes; Wherein it doth impair the seeing sense, It pays the hearing double recompense.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 74)
But why unkindly didst thou leave me so?   Why should he stay whom love doth press to go?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 76)
What love could press Lysander from my side?   Lysander's love, that would not let him bide, Fair Helena, who more engilds the night Than all yon fiery oes and eyes of light.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 77)
So we grew together Like to a double cherry, seeming parted, But yet an union in partition, Two lovely berries molded on one stem; So with two seeming bodies but one heart, Two of the first, like coats in heraldry, Due but to one, and crowned with one crest.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 84)
And will you rent our ancient love asunder, To join with men in scorning your poor friend?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 85)
Have you not set Lysander, as in scorn, To follow me and praise my eyes and face, And made your other love, Demetrius, Who even but now did spurn me with his foot, To call me goddess, nymph, divine and rare, Precious, celestial?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 88)
Wherefore speaks he this To her he hates? And wherefore doth Lysander Deny your love (so rich within his soul) And tender me, forsooth, affection, But by your setting on, by your consent?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 89)
What though be not so in grace as you, So hung upon with love, so fortunate, But miserable most, to love unloved?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 90)

But, my good lord, wot not by what power (But by some power it is) my love to Hermia, Melted as the snow, seems to me now As the remembrance of an idle gaud Which in my childhood did dote upon, And all the faith, the virtue of my heart, The object and the pleasure of mine eye, Is only Helena.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 62)
But, as in health, come to my natural taste, Now do wish it, love it, long for it, And will forevermore be true to it.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 64)

His hour is almost past.   And it is marvel he outdwells his hour, For lovers ever run before the clock.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 1)
ten times faster Venus' pigeons fly To seal love's bonds new-made than they are wont To keep obliged faith unforfeited.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 2)
Lorenzo, and thy love.   Lorenzo certain, and my love indeed, For who love so much?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 11)
But love is blind, and lovers cannot see The pretty follies that themselves commit, For if they could, Cupid himself would blush To see me thus transformed to a boy.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 16)
Why, 'tis an office of discovery, love, And should be obscured.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 19)
So are you, sweet, Even in the lovely garnish of a boy.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 20)
Now, by my hood, a gentle and no Jew!   Beshrew me but love her heartily, For she is wise, if can judge of her, And fair she is, if that mine eyes be true, And true she is, as she hath proved herself.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 23)
As much as deserve--why, that's the lady! do in birth deserve her, and in fortunes, In graces, and in qualities of breeding, But more than these, in love do deserve.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 13)

Here. What would my lord?   Madam, there is alighted at your gate young Venetian, one that comes before To signify th' approaching of his lord, From whom he bringeth sensible regreets; To wit (besides commends and courteous breath), Gifts of rich value; yet have not seen So likely an ambassador of love.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 38)
There's something tells me (but it is not love) would not lose you, and you know yourself Hate counsels not in such a quality.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 1)

None but that ugly treason of mistrust, Which makes me fear th' enjoying of my love.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 11)

Madam, you have bereft me of all words. Only my blood speaks to you in my veins, And there is such confusion in my powers As after some oration fairly spoke By a beloved prince there doth appear Among the buzzing pleased multitude, Where every something being blent together Turns to a wild of nothing, save of joy Expressed and not expressed.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 62)

First, must tell thee this: Desdemona is directly in love with him.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 86)
Mark me with what violence she first loved the Moor but for bragging and telling her fantastical lies.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 88)
And will she love him still for prating? Let not thy discreet heart think it.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 89)
When the blood is made dull with the act of sport, there should be, again to inflame it and to give satiety a fresh appetite, loveliness in favor, sympathy in years, manners, and beauties, all which the Moor is defective in.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 91)
If she had been blessed, she would never have loved the Moor.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 101)
Farewell.  Adieu.   That Cassio loves her, do well believe 't.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 115)
That she loves him, 'tis apt and of great credit.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 116)
Now, do love her too, Not out of absolute lust (though peradventure stand accountant for as great a sin) But partly led to diet my revenge For that do suspect the lusty Moor Hath leaped into my seat--the thought whereof Doth, like a poisonous mineral, gnaw my inwards, And nothing can or shall content my soul Till am evened with him, wife for wife, Or, failing so, yet that put the Moor At least into a jealousy so strong That judgment cannot cure.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 118)
Which thing to do, If this poor trash of Venice, whom trace For his quick hunting, stand the putting on, I'll have our Michael Cassio on the hip, Abuse him to the Moor in the rank garb (For fear Cassio with my nightcap too), Make the Moor thank me, love me, and reward me For making him egregiously an ass And practicing upon his peace and quiet Even to madness.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 119)
Come, my dear love, The purchase made, the fruits are to ensue; That profit's yet to come 'tween me and you.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 4)

An inviting eye, and yet methinks right modest.  And when she speaks, is it not an alarum to love?(Othello, Act 2, Scene 11)

do love Cassio well and would do much To cure him of this evil-- But hark!(Othello, Act 2, Scene 60)

She's framed as fruitful As the free elements. And then for her To win the Moor--were 't to renounce his baptism, All seals and symbols of redeemed sin-- His soul is so enfettered to her love That she may make, unmake, do what she list, Even as her appetite shall play the god With his weak function.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 146)
And I'll tell you, he hath a fair daughter, and tomorrow is her birthday; and there are princes and knights come from all parts of the world to joust and tourney for her love.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 42)

He loved me dearly, And for his sake wish the having of it, And that you'd guide me to your sovereign's court, Where with it may appear a gentleman.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 52)
He loves you well that holds his life of you.      Who is the second that presents himself?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 8)
Your presence glads our days. Honor we love, For who hates honor hates the gods above.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 8)
Here, with a cup that's stored unto the brim, As do you love, fill to your mistress' lips.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 20)
will not have excuse with saying this: "Loud music is too harsh for ladies' heads," Since they love men in arms as well as beds.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 39)
Princes, it is too late to talk of love, And that's the mark know you level at.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 46)
Your griefs? For what? Wrong not your prince you love.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 17)
If that you love Prince Pericles, forbear. Take your wish, leap into the seas, Where's hourly trouble for a minute's ease.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 22)
But if cannot win you to this love, Go search like nobles, like noble subjects, And in your search spend your adventurous worth, Whom if you find and win unto return, You shall like diamonds sit about his crown.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 24)
Then you love us, we you, and we'll clasp hands.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 26)
letter that she loves the knight of Tyre? 'Tis the King's subtlety to have my life.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 20)
-- seek not to entrap me, gracious lord, stranger and distressed gentleman That never aimed so high to love your daughter, But bent all offices to honor her.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 21)
By the gods, have not! Never did thought of mine levy offense; Nor never did my actions yet commence deed might gain her love or your displeasure.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 23)
No? Here comes my daughter. She can witness it.      Then as you are as virtuous as fair, Resolve your angry father if my tongue Did e'er solicit or my hand subscribe To any syllable that made love to you.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 27)
