-- Convey me to my bed, then to my grave. Love they to live that love and honor have.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 40)
He loves you, on my life, and holds you dear As Harry, Duke of Hereford, were he here.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 43)
Right, you say true: as Hereford's love, so his; As theirs, so mine; and all be as it is.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 44)
And we create, in absence of ourself, Our uncle York Lord Governor of England, For he is just and always loved us well.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 70)
Besides, our nearness to the King in love Is near the hate of those love not the King.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 51)
And that is the wavering commons, for their love Lies in their purses, and whoso empties them By so much fills their hearts with deadly hate.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 52)
thank thee, gentle Percy, and be sure count myself in nothing else so happy As in a soul rememb'ring my good friends; And as my fortune ripens with thy love, It shall be still thy true love's recompense.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 15)
Welcome, my lords. wot your love pursues banished traitor.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 20)
All my treasury Is yet but unfelt thanks, which, more enriched, Shall be your love and labor's recompense.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 21)
Swear your love.   By heaven, my soul is purged from grudging hate, And with my hand seal my true heart's love.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 4)
So prosper as swear perfect love.   And as love Hastings with my heart.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 6)
You have been factious one against the other.-- Wife, love Lord Hastings.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 8)
Dorset, embrace him.--Hastings, love Lord Marquess.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 11)
This interchange of love, here protest, Upon my part shall be inviolable.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 12)
Whenever Buckingham doth turn his hate Upon your Grace, but with all duteous love Doth cherish you and yours, God punish me With hate in those where expect most love.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 14)
When have most need to employ a friend, And most assured that he is a friend, Deep, hollow, treacherous, and full of guile Be he unto me: this do beg of God, When am cold in love to you or yours.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 15)
Happy indeed, as we have spent the day. Gloucester, we have done deeds of charity, Made peace of enmity, fair love of hate, Between these swelling, wrong-incensed peers.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 20)
'Tis death to me to be at enmity; hate it, and desire all good men's love.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 22)
Why, madam, have offered love for this, To be so flouted in this royal presence?(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 27)
Who spoke of brotherhood? Who spoke of love? Who told me how the poor soul did forsake The mighty Warwick and did fight for me?(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 40)
And so will   Peace, children, peace. The King doth love you well.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 6)
Grandam, we can, for my good uncle Gloucester Told me the King, provoked to it by the Queen, Devised impeachments to imprison him; And when my uncle told me so, he wept, And pitied me, and kindly kissed my cheek, Bade me rely on him as on my father, And he would love me dearly as a child.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 8)
You cloudy princes and heart-sorrowing peers That bear this heavy mutual load of moan, Now cheer each other in each other's love.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 45)
Cry but "Ay me," pronounce but "love" and "dove." Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word, One nickname for her purblind son and heir, Young Abraham Cupid, he that shot so trim When King Cophetua loved the beggar maid.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 0, Scene 5)
Blind is his love and best befits the dark.   If love be blind, love cannot hit the mark.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 0, Scene 13)
Cast it off. It is my lady. it is my love! that she knew she were!(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 3)
See how she leans her cheek upon her hand. that were a glove upon that hand, That might touch that cheek!(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 7)
Romeo, Romeo, wherefore art thou Romeo? Deny thy father and refuse thy name, Or, if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love, And I'll no longer be a Capulet.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 9)
take thee at thy word. Call me but love, and I'll be new baptized.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 16)
With love's light wings did o'erperch these walls, For stony limits cannot hold love out, And what love can do, that dares love attempt.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 23)
would not for the world they saw thee here.   have night's cloak to hide me from their eyes, And, but thou love me, let them find me here.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 27)
My life were better ended by their hate Than death prorogued, wanting of thy love.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 28)
By love, that first did prompt me to inquire. He lent me counsel, and lent him eyes.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 30)
But farewell compliment. Dost thou love me? know thou wilt say "Ay," And will take thy word.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 34)
Yet, if thou swear'st, Thou mayst prove false. At lovers' perjuries, They say, Jove laughs.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 35)
gentle Romeo, If thou dost love, pronounce it faithfully.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 36)
should have been more strange, must confess, But that thou overheard'st ere was ware My true-love passion.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 40)
Therefore pardon me, And not impute this yielding to light love, Which the dark night hath so discovered.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 41)
Lady, by yonder blessed moon vow, That tips with silver all these fruit-tree tops--   swear not by the moon, th' inconstant moon, That monthly changes in her circled orb, Lest that thy love prove likewise variable.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 42)
If my heart's dear love--   Well, do not swear. Although joy in thee, have no joy of this contract tonight.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 44)
" Sweet, good night. This bud of love, by summer's ripening breath, May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 46)
Th' exchange of thy love's faithful vow for mine.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 49)
Wouldst thou withdraw it? For what purpose, love?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 51)
My bounty is as boundless as the sea, My love as deep.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 53)
hear some noise within. Dear love, adieu.-- Anon, good nurse.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 55)
If that thy bent of love be honorable, Thy purpose marriage, send me word tomorrow, By one that I'll procure to come to thee, Where and what time thou wilt perform the rite, And all my fortunes at thy foot I'll lay And follow thee my lord throughout the world.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 59)
thousand times the worse to want thy light. Love goes toward love as schoolboys from their books, But love from love, toward school with heavy looks.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 63)
"   It is my soul that calls upon my name. How silver-sweet sound lovers' tongues by night, Like softest music to attending ears.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 66)
shall forget, to have thee still stand there, Rememb'ring how love thy company.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 70)
Then plainly know my heart's dear love is set On the fair daughter of rich Capulet.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 20)
Holy Saint Francis, what a change is here! Is Rosaline, that thou didst love so dear, So soon forsaken?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 23)
Young men's love then lies Not truly in their hearts, but in their eyes.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 24)
How much salt water thrown away in waste To season love, that of it doth not taste!(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 26)
And bad'st me bury love.  Not in a grave To lay one in, another out to have.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 32)
pray thee, chide me not. Her love now Doth grace for grace and love for love allow.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 33)
The other did not so.  she knew well Thy love did read by rote, that could not spell.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 34)
But come, young waverer, come, go with me. In one respect I'll thy assistant be, For this alliance may so happy prove To turn your households' rancor to pure love.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 35)
Alas, poor Romeo, he is already dead, stabbed with a white wench's black eye, run through the ear with a love-song, the very pin of his heart cleft with the blind bow-boy's butt shaft.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 5)
Laura to his lady was a kitchen wench (marry, she had a better love to berhyme her), Dido a dowdy, Cleopatra a gypsy, Helen and Hero hildings and harlots, Thisbe a gray eye or so, but not to the purpose.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 16)
Why, is not this better now than groaning for love?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 35)
For this driveling love is like a great natural that runs lolling up and down to hide his bauble in a hole.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 37)
gentleman, nurse, that loves to hear himself talk and will speak more in a minute than he will stand to in a month.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 59)
That fair for which love groaned for and would die, With tender Juliet matched, is now not fair.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 1)
Now Romeo is beloved and loves again, Alike bewitched by the charm of looks, But to his foe supposed he must complain, And she steal love's sweet bait from fearful hooks.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 2)
Being held a foe, he may not have access To breathe such vows as lovers use to swear, And she as much in love, her means much less To meet her new beloved anywhere.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 3)
Had she affections and warm youthful blood, She would be as swift in motion as a ball; My words would bandy her to my sweet love, And his to me.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 10)
faith, am sorry that thou art not well. Sweet, sweet, sweet nurse, tell me, what says my love?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 30)
Your love says, like an honest gentleman, and a courteous, and a kind, and a handsome, and, warrant, a virtuous--Where is your mother?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 31)
How oddly thou repliest: "Your love says, like an honest gentleman, Where is your mother?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 33)
Hie you to church. must another way, To fetch a ladder by the which your love Must climb a bird's nest soon when it is dark.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 39)
Do thou but close our hands with holy words, Then love-devouring death do what he dare, It is enough may but call her mine.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 5, Scene 2)
Therefore love moderately. Long love doth so. Too swift arrives as tardy as too slow.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 5, Scene 5)
lover may bestride the gossamers That idles in the wanton summer air, And yet not fall, so light is vanity.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 5, Scene 7)
They are but beggars that can count their worth, But my true love is grown to such excess cannot sum up sum of half my wealth.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 5, Scene 11)
Nay, now see She is your treasure, she must have a husband, must dance barefoot on her wedding day And, for your love to her, lead apes in hell.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 13)
Then tell me, if get your daughter's love, What dowry shall have with her to wife?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 48)
Ay, when the special thing is well obtained, That is, her love, for that is all in all.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 52)
Now, by the world, it is a lusty wench. love her ten times more than ere did.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 64)
tell you, 'tis incredible to believe How much she loves me.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 130)
the kindest Kate! She hung about my neck, and kiss on kiss She vied so fast, protesting oath on oath, That in a twink she won me to her love.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 131)
am your neighbor and was suitor first.   And am one that love Bianca more Than words can witness or your thoughts can guess.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 144)
Youngling, thou canst not love so dear as   Graybeard, thy love doth freeze.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 145)
will compound this strife. 'Tis deeds must win the prize, and he of both That can assure my daughter greatest dower Shall have my Bianca's love.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 148)
Conster them.  Hic ibat, as told you before, Simois, am Lucentio, hic est, son unto Vincentio of Pisa, Sigeia tellus, disguised thus to get your love, Hic steterat, and that "Lucentio" that comes a-wooing, Priami, is my man Tranio, regia, bearing my port, celsa senis, that we might beguile the old pantaloon.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 12)
Now for my life the knave doth court my love! Pedascule, I'll watch you better yet.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 18)
Yet read the gamut of Hortensio.    "Gamut am, the ground of all accord: re, to plead Hortensio's passion; mi, Bianca, take him for thy lord, fa ut, that loves with all affection; sol re, one clef, two notes have la mi, show pity or die.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 26)
But have cause to pry into this pedant. Methinks he looks as though he were in love.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 32)
Where is my lovely bride? How does my father? Gentles, methinks you frown.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 25)
But what a fool am to chat with you When should bid good morrow to my bride And seal the title with a lovely kiss!(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 37)
I'll after him, and see the event of this.    But, sir, to love concerneth us to add Her father's liking, which to bring to pass, As before imparted to your Worship, am to get a man (whate'er he be It skills not much, we'll fit him to our turn), And he shall be "Vincentio of Pisa," And make assurance here in Padua Of greater sums than have promised.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 39)
Now, if you love me, stay.  Grumio, my horse.  Ay, sir, they be ready; the oats have eaten the horses.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 67)
Sir, your glove.  Not mine. My gloves are on.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 0)
Tell me, do you know Madam Sylvia?  She that your Worship loves?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 7)
Why, how know you that am in love?  Marry, by these special marks: first, you have learned, like Sir Proteus, to wreathe your arms like a malcontent; to relish a love song like a robin redbreast; to walk alone like one that had the pestilence; to sigh like a schoolboy that had lost his to weep like a young wench that had buried her grandam; to fast like one that takes diet; to watch like one that fears robbing; to speak puling like a beggar at Hallowmas.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 8)
How long hath she been deformed?  Ever since you loved her.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 25)
have loved her ever since saw her, and still see her beautiful.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 26)
If you love her, you cannot see her.  Why?  Because love is blind.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 27)
What should see then?  Your own present folly and her passing deformity; for he, being in love, could not see to garter his hose, and you, being in love, cannot see to put on your hose.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 29)
Belike, boy, then you are in love, for last morning you could not see to wipe my shoes.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 30)
True, sir, was in love with my bed. thank you, you swinged me for my love, which makes me the bolder to chide you for yours.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 31)
Last night she enjoined me to write some lines to one she loves.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 33)
For often have you writ to her, and she, in modesty Or else for want of idle time, could not again reply, Or fearing else some messenger that might her mind discover, Herself hath taught her love himself to write unto her lover.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 67)
'Tis dinnertime.  have dined.  Ay, but hearken, sir, though the chameleon love can feed on the air, am one that am nourished by my victuals and would fain have meat.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 69)
Here is my hand for my true constancy. And when that hour o'erslips me in the day Wherein sigh not, Julia, for thy sake, The next ensuing hour some foul mischance Torment me for my love's forgetfulness.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 1, Scene 4)
Julia, farewell. What, gone without a word? Ay, so true love should do.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 1, Scene 6)
Ay, boy, it's for love.  Not of you.  Of my mistress, then.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 1)
Beshrew me, sir, but if he make this good, He is as worthy for an empress' love, As meet to be an emperor's counselor.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 25)
Why, lady, love hath twenty pair of eyes.   They say that Love hath not an eye at all.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 34)
To see such lovers, Thurio, as yourself. Upon a homely object, Love can wink.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 35)
And how thrives your love?   My tales of love were wont to weary you.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 51)
know you joy not in a love discourse.   Ay, Proteus, but that life is altered now.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 52)
have done penance for contemning Love, Whose high imperious thoughts have punished me With bitter fasts, with penitential groans, With nightly tears, and daily heartsore sighs, For in revenge of my contempt of love, Love hath chased sleep from my enthralled eyes And made them watchers of mine own heart's sorrow.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 53)
Now, no discourse except it be of love. Now can break my fast, dine, sup, and sleep Upon the very naked name of Love.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 55)
Call her divine.  will not flatter her.   flatter me, for love delights in praises.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 58)
Except my mistress.  Sweet, except not any, Except thou wilt except against my love.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 61)
Forgive me that do not dream on thee, Because thou seest me dote upon my love.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 66)
My foolish rival, that her father likes Only for his possessions are so huge, Is gone with her along, and must after, For love, thou know'st, is full of jealousy.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 67)
But she loves you?   Ay, and we are betrothed; nay more, our marriage hour, With all the cunning manner of our flight Determined of: how must climb her window, The ladder made of cords, and all the means Plotted and 'greed on for my happiness.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 68)
Will you make haste?  will. Even as one heat another heat expels, Or as one nail by strength drives out another, So the remembrance of my former love Is by a newer object quite forgotten.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 71)
She is fair, and so is Julia that love-- That did love, for now my love is thawed, Which like a waxen image 'gainst a fire Bears no impression of the thing it was.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 73)
Methinks my zeal to Valentine is cold, And that love him not as was wont.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 74)
but love his lady too too much, And that's the reason love him so little.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 75)
How shall dote on her with more advice That thus without advice begin to love her?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 76)
If can check my erring love, will; If not, to compass her I'll use my skill.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 78)
'Tis well that get it so. But, Lance, how sayst thou that my master is become a notable lover?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 15)
tell thee, my master is become a hot lover.  Why, tell thee, care not though he burn himself in love.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 18)
To leave my Julia, shall be forsworn. To love fair Sylvia, shall be forsworn.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 5, Scene 0)
Love bade me swear, and love bids me forswear. sweet-suggesting Love, if thou hast sinned, Teach me, thy tempted subject, to excuse it.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 5, Scene 2)
cannot leave to love, and yet do. But there leave to love where should love.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 5, Scene 5)
to myself am dearer than a friend, For love is still most precious in itself, And Sylvia--witness heaven that made her fair-- Shows Julia but a swarthy Ethiope.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 5, Scene 7)
will forget that Julia is alive, Rememb'ring that my love to her is dead; And Valentine I'll hold an enemy, Aiming at Sylvia as a sweeter friend.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 5, Scene 8)
Counsel, Lucetta. Gentle girl, assist me; And ev'n in kind love do conjure thee-- Who art the table wherein all my thoughts Are visibly charactered and engraved-- To lesson me and tell me some good mean How with my honor may undertake journey to my loving Proteus.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 0)
Didst thou but know the inly touch of love, Thou wouldst as soon go kindle fire with snow As seek to quench the fire of love with words.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 4)
do not seek to quench your love's hot fire, But qualify the fire's extreme rage, Lest it should burn above the bounds of reason.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 5)
Then let me go and hinder not my course. I'll be as patient as a gentle stream And make a pastime of each weary step Till the last step have brought me to my love, And there I'll rest as after much turmoil blessed soul doth in Elysium.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 8)
Why, then, your Ladyship must cut your hair.   No, girl, I'll knit it up in silken strings With twenty odd-conceited true-love knots.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 11)
thousand oaths, an ocean of his tears, And instances of infinite of love Warrant me welcome to my Proteus.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 23)
But truer stars did govern Proteus' birth. His words are bonds, his oaths are oracles, His love sincere, his thoughts immaculate, His tears pure messengers sent from his heart, His heart as far from fraud as heaven from Earth.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 25)
Only deserve my love by loving him. And presently go with me to my chamber To take a note of what stand in need of To furnish me upon my longing journey.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 27)
This love of theirs myself have often seen, Haply when they have judged me fast asleep, And oftentimes have purposed to forbid Sir Valentine her company and my court.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 6)
Know, noble lord, they have devised a mean How he her chamber-window will ascend And with a corded ladder fetch her down; For which the youthful lover now is gone, And this way comes he with it presently, Where, if it please you, you may intercept him.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 9)
But, good my lord, do it so cunningly That my discovery be not aimed at; For love of you, not hate unto my friend, Hath made me publisher of this pretense.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 10)
Cannot your Grace win her to fancy him?   No. Trust me, she is peevish, sullen, froward, Proud, disobedient, stubborn, lacking duty, Neither regarding that she is my child Nor fearing me as if were her father; And may say to thee, this pride of hers, Upon advice, hath drawn my love from her, And where thought the remnant of mine age Should have been cherished by her childlike duty, now am full resolved to take a wife And turn her out to who will take her in.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 19)
Send her another; never give her o'er, For scorn at first makes after-love the more.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 25)
If she do frown, 'tis not in hate of you, But rather to beget more love in you.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 26)
When would you use it? Pray sir, tell me that.   This very night; for love is like a child That longs for everything that he can come by.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 36)
But if thou linger in my territories Longer than swiftest expedition Will give thee time to leave our royal court, By heaven, my wrath shall far exceed the love ever bore my daughter or thyself.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 53)
Time is the nurse and breeder of all good. Here, if thou stay, thou canst not see thy love; Besides, thy staying will abridge thy life.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 81)
Hope is a lover's staff; walk hence with that And manage it against despairing thoughts.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 82)
Thy letters may be here, though thou art hence, Which, being writ to me, shall be delivered Even in the milk-white bosom of thy love.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 83)
The time now serves not to expostulate. Come, I'll convey thee through the city gate And, ere part with thee, confer at large Of all that may concern thy love affairs.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 84)
He lives not now that knows me to be in love, yet am in love, but a team of horse shall not pluck that from me, nor who 'tis love; and yet 'tis a woman, but what woman will not tell myself; and yet 'tis a milk-maid; yet 'tis not a maid, for she hath had gossips; yet 'tis a maid, for she is her master's maid and serves for wages.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 89)
Item, She hath no teeth.  care not for that neither, because love crusts.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 118)
Why didst not tell me sooner? Pox of your love letters!(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 132)
Sir Thurio, fear not but that she will love you Now Valentine is banished from her sight.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 0)
This weak impress of love is as a figure Trenched in ice, which with an hour's heat Dissolves to water and doth lose his form.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 2)
What might we do to make the girl forget The love of Valentine, and love Sir Thurio?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 12)
You have prevailed, my lord. If can do it By aught that can speak in his dispraise, She shall not long continue love to him.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 19)
But say this weed her love from Valentine, It follows not that she will love Sir Thurio.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 20)
Therefore, as you unwind her love from him, Lest it should ravel and be good to none, You must provide to bottom it on me, Which must be done by praising me as much As you in worth dispraise Sir Valentine.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 21)
Upon this warrant shall you have access Where you with Sylvia may confer at large-- For she is lumpish, heavy, melancholy, And, for your friend's sake, will be glad of you-- Where you may temper her by your persuasion To hate young Valentine and love my friend.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 23)
This, or else nothing, will inherit her.   This discipline shows thou hast been in love.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 30)
love and honor him But must not break my back to heal his finger.(Timon of Athens, Act 0, Scene 10)
do not always follow lover, elder brother, and woman; sometime the philosopher.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 54)
My loved lord, Though you hear now too late, yet now's a time.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 63)
Secure thy heart. If would broach the vessels of my love And try the argument of hearts by borrowing, Men and men's fortunes could frankly use As can bid thee speak.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 78)
Commend me to their loves, and am proud, say, that my occasions have found time to use 'em toward a supply of money.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 84)
am as able and as fit as thou To serve and to deserve my mistress' grace, And that my sword upon thee shall approve And plead my passions for Lavinia's love.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 9)
Clubs, clubs! These lovers will not keep the peace.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 10)
What, is Lavinia then become so loose Or Bassianus so degenerate That for her love such quarrels may be broached Without controlment, justice, or revenge?(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 21)
care not, knew she and all the world. love Lavinia more than all the world.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 23)
Or know you not in Rome How furious and impatient they be, And cannot brook competitors in love?(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 26)
Aaron, a thousand deaths Would propose to achieve her whom love.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 28)
She is a woman, therefore may be wooed; She is a woman, therefore may be won; She is Lavinia, therefore must be loved.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 30)
Take this of me: Lucrece was not more chaste Than this Lavinia, Bassianus' love.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 42)
My lords, a solemn hunting is in hand; There will the lovely Roman ladies troop.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 44)
Uncouple here, and let us make a bay And wake the Emperor and his lovely bride, And rouse the Prince, and ring a hunter's peal, That all the court may echo with the noise.(Titus Andronicus, Act 1, Scene 1)
My lovely Aaron, wherefore look'st thou sad, When everything doth make a gleeful boast?(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 3)
--I pray you, let us hence, And let her joy her raven-colored love.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 24)
Revenge it as you love your mother's life, Or be you not henceforth called my children.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 34)
Therefore away with her, and use her as you will; The worse to her, the better loved of me.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 58)
Now will hence to seek my lovely Moor, And let my spleenful sons this trull deflower.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 70)
Speak, gentle niece. What stern ungentle hands Hath lopped and hewed and made thy body bare Of her two branches, those sweet ornaments Whose circling shadows kings have sought to sleep in, And might not gain so great a happiness As half thy love?(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 8)
Fair Philomela, why she but lost her tongue, And in a tedious sampler sewed her mind; But, lovely niece, that mean is cut from thee.(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 14)
Titus Andronicus, my lord the Emperor Sends thee this word, that if thou love thy sons, Let Marcus, Lucius, or thyself, old Titus, Or any one of you, chop off your hand And send it to the King; he for the same Will send thee hither both thy sons alive, And that shall be the ransom for their fault.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 54)
And for our father's sake and mother's care, Now let me show a brother's love to thee.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 65)
Hie to the Goths and raise an army there. And if you love me, as think you do, Let's kiss and part, for we have much to do.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 109)
Farewell, proud Rome, till Lucius come again. He loves his pledges dearer than his life.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 111)
Draw thy sword. One stroke Shall free thee from the tribute which thou payest, And the King shall love thee.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 115)
Sometime am All wound with adders, who with cloven tongues Do hiss me into madness.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 3)
" She loved not the savor of tar nor of pitch, Yet a tailor might scratch her where'er she did itch.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 23)
Do you love me?   heaven, Earth, bear witness to this sound, And crown what profess with kind event If speak true; if hollowly, invert What best is boded me to mischief.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 28)
Beyond all limit of what else i' th' world, Do love, prize, honor you.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 29)
It were a bad recompense for your love to lay any of them on you.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 4)
If you will not murder me for my love, let me be your servant.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 17)
She loves me, sure! The cunning of her passion Invites me in this churlish messenger.(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 10)
If it be so, as 'tis, Poor lady, she were better love a dream.(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 12)
How will this fadge? My master loves her dearly, And poor monster, fond as much on him, And she, mistaken, seems to dote on me.(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 16)
What will become of this? As am man, My state is desperate for my master's love.(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 17)
If one knight give a--  Would you have a love song or a song of good life?(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 15)
love song, a love song.  Ay, ay, care not for good life.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 16)
Your truelove's coming, That can sing both high and low.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 18)
Trip no further, pretty sweeting. Journeys end in lovers meeting, Every wise man's son doth know.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 19)
Excellent good, i' faith!  Good, good.   What is love?(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 20)
Shall we do that?  An you love me, let's do 't. am dog at a catch.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 27)
the twelfth day of December--  For the love o' God, peace!(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 40)
The devil a puritan that he is, or anything constantly but a time-pleaser; an affectioned ass that cons state without book and utters it by great swaths; the best persuaded of himself, so crammed, as he thinks, with excellencies, that it is his grounds of faith that all that look on him love him.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 66)
What wilt thou do?  will drop in his way some obscure epistles of love, wherein by the color of his beard, the shape of his leg, the manner of his gait, the expressure of his eye, forehead, and complexion, he shall find himself most feelingly personated.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 68)
He shall think, by the letters that thou wilt drop, that they come from my niece, and that she's in love with him.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 71)
Come hither, boy. If ever thou shalt love, In the sweet pangs of it remember me, For such as am, all true lovers are, Unstaid and skittish in all motions else Save in the constant image of the creature That is beloved.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 6)
How dost thou like this tune?   It gives a very echo to the seat Where love is throned.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 7)
Thou dost speak masterly. My life upon 't, young though thou art, thine eye Hath stayed upon some favor that it loves.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 8)
think it well, my lord.   Then let thy love be younger than thyself, Or thy affection cannot hold the bent.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 15)
It is silly sooth, And dallies with the innocence of love Like the old age.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 20)
thousand thousand sighs to save, Lay me, where Sad true lover never find my grave To weep there.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 26)
Tell her my love, more noble than the world, Prizes not quantity of dirty lands.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 32)
But if she cannot love you, sir--   cannot be so answered.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 35)
Sooth, but you must. Say that some lady, as perhaps there is, Hath for your love as great a pang of heart As you have for Olivia.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 36)
You cannot love her; You tell her so. Must she not then be answered?(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 37)
There is no woman's sides Can bide the beating of so strong a passion As love doth give my heart; no woman's heart So big, to hold so much; they lack retention.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 38)
Alas, their love may be called appetite, No motion of the liver but the palate, That suffer surfeit, cloyment, and revolt; But mine is all as hungry as the sea, And can digest as much.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 39)
Make no compare Between that love a woman can bear me And that owe Olivia.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 40)
Ay, but know--  What dost thou know?   Too well what love women to men may owe.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 41)
In faith, they are as true of heart as we. My father had a daughter loved a man As it might be, perhaps, were a woman, should your Lordship.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 42)
And what's her history?   blank, my lord. She never told her love, But let concealment, like a worm i' th' bud, Feed on her damask cheek.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 43)
Was not this love indeed? We men may say more, swear more, but indeed Our shows are more than will; for still we prove Much in our vows but little in our love.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 45)
But died thy sister of her love, my boy?   am all the daughters of my father's house, And all the brothers, too--and yet know not.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 46)
Give her this jewel. Say My love can give no place, bide no denay.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 48)
Observe him, for the love of mockery, for know this letter will make a contemplative idiot of him.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 8)
Why that?  To the unknown beloved, this, and my good wishes--Her very phrases!(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 34)
Jove knows love, But who? Lips, do not move; No man must know.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 37)
do not now fool myself, to let imagination jade me; for every reason excites to this, that my lady loves me.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 67)
She did commend my yellow stockings of late, she did praise my leg being cross-gartered, and in this she manifests herself to my love and, with a kind of injunction, drives me to these habits of her liking.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 68)
Thou canst not choose but know who am. If thou entertain'st my love, let it appear in thy smiling; thy smiles become thee well.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 71)
And here being thus together, We are an endless mine to one another; We are one another's wife, ever begetting New births of love; we are father, friends, acquaintance; We are, in one another, families; am your heir, and you are mine.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 22)
Is there record of any two that loved Better than we do, Arcite?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 34)
Till our deaths it cannot.    And after death our spirits shall be led To those that love eternally.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 36)

love her as a woman, to enjoy her. So both may love.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 70)

Yes, love her, And, if the lives of all my name lay on it, must do so.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 75)
love her with my soul. If that will lose you, farewell, Palamon.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 76)
say again, love, and in loving her maintain am as worthy and as free a lover And have as just a title to her beauty As any Palamon or any living That is a man's son.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 77)
You may be.  Why then would you deal so cunningly, So strangely, so unlike a noble kinsman, To love alone?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 82)
Fie, sir! You play the child extremely. will love her; must, ought to do so, and dare, And all this justly.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 89)

And then am sure she would love me.--How now, keeper, Where's Arcite?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 104)
Arcite shall have a fortune, If he dare make himself a worthy lover, Yet in the field to strike a battle for her, And, if he lose her then, he's a cold coward.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 107)

love him beyond love and beyond reason Or wit or safety.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 5, Scene 3)

will not say pity me--'tis not a soldier-like phrase--but say love me.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 6)

He loves your wife; there's the short and the long.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 59)

love not the humor of bread and cheese. Adieu.  "The humor of it," quoth he?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 62)
Blessing on your heart for 't!  But pray thee, tell me this: has Ford's wife and Page's wife acquainted each other how they love me?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 44)
That were a trick indeed! But Mistress Page would desire you to send her your little page, of all loves.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 46)
Well, sir.  have long loved her and, protest to you, bestowed much on her, followed her with a doting observance, engrossed opportunities to meet her, fee'd every slight occasion that could but niggardly give me sight of her, not only bought many presents to give her, but have given largely to many to know what she would have given.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 81)
Briefly, have pursued her as love hath pursued me, which hath been on the wing of all occasions.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 82)
That have purchased at an infinite rate, and that hath taught me to say this: "Love like a shadow flies when substance love pursues, Pursuing that that flies, and flying what pursues.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 84)
Never.  Of what quality was your love, then?  Like a fair house built on another man's ground, so that have lost my edifice by mistaking the place where erected it.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 87)
By gar, love you, and shall procure-a you de good guest: de earl, de knight, de lords, de gentlemen, my patients.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 39)
Ay, be-gar, and de maid is love-a me! My nursh-a Quickly tell me so mush.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 30)

cannot. But love thee, none but thee; and thou deserv'st it.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 29)

--I love you better.   And why so, my lord?  Not for because Your brows are blacker--yet black brows, they say, Become some women best, so that there be not Too much hair there, but in a semicircle, Or a half-moon made with a pen.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 3)
This sessions, to our great grief we pronounce, Even pushes 'gainst our heart: the party tried The daughter of a king, our wife, and one Of us too much beloved.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 0)
For Polixenes, With whom am accused, do confess loved him as in honor he required, With such a kind of love as might become lady like me, with a love even such, So and no other, as yourself commanded, Which not to have done, think, had been in me Both disobedience and ingratitude To you and toward your friend, whose love had spoke, Even since it could speak, from an infant, freely That it was yours.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 15)

These are his substance, sinews, arms, and strength, With which he yoketh your rebellious necks, Razeth your cities, and subverts your towns, And in a moment makes them desolate.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 25)
Even like a man new-haled from the rack, So fare my limbs with long imprisonment; And these gray locks, the pursuivants of death, Nestor-like aged in an age of care, Argue the end of Edmund Mortimer; These eyes, like lamps whose wasting oil is spent, Wax dim, as drawing to their exigent; Weak shoulders, overborne with burdening grief, And pithless arms, like to a withered vine That droops his sapless branches to the ground; Yet are these feet, whose strengthless stay is numb, Unable to support this lump of clay, Swift-winged with desire to get a grave, As witting no other comfort have.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 1)
But that the tennis-court keeper knows better than for it is a low ebb of linen with thee when thou keepest not racket there, as thou hast not done a great while, because the rest of the low countries have made a shift to eat up thy holland; and God knows whether those that bawl out the ruins of thy linen shall inherit His kingdom; but the midwives say the children are not in the fault, whereupon the world increases and kindreds are mightily strengthened.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 8)

My love and fear glued many friends to thee; And now fall, thy tough commixtures melts, Impairing Henry, strength'ning misproud York; And whither fly the gnats but to the sun?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 2)

Go and tell him We come to speak with him; and you shall not sin If you do say we think him overproud And underhonest, in self-assumption greater Than in the note of judgment; and worthier than himself Here tend the savage strangeness he puts on, Disguise the holy strength of their command, And underwrite in an observing kind His humorous predominance--yea, watch His course and time, his ebbs and flows, as if The passage and whole carriage of this action Rode on his tide.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 51)

heavens, what stuff is here?  'Twas never merry world since, of two usuries, the merriest was put down, and the worser allowed by order of law a furred gown to keep him warm, and furred with fox and lambskins too, to signify that craft, being richer than innocency, stands for the facing.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 1)
His mother was a vot'ress of my order, And in the spiced Indian air by night Full often hath she gossiped by my side And sat with me on Neptune's yellow sands, Marking th' embarked traders on the flood, When we have laughed to see the sails conceive And grow big-bellied with the wanton wind; Which she, with pretty and with swimming gait, Following (her womb then rich with my young squire), Would imitate and sail upon the land To fetch me trifles and return again, As from a voyage, rich with merchandise.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 38)

Wouldst thou aught with me?  Here's my son, sir, a poor boy--  Not a poor boy, sir, but the rich Jew's man, that would, sir, as my father shall specify--  He hath a great infection, sir, as one would say, to serve--  Indeed, the short and the long is, serve the Jew, and have a desire, as my father shall specify--  His master and he (saving your Worship's reverence) are scarce cater-cousins--  To be brief, the very truth is that the Jew, having done me wrong, doth cause me, as my father being, hope, an old man, shall frutify unto you--  have here a dish of doves that would bestow upon your Worship, and my suit is--  In very brief, the suit is impertinent to myself, as your Worship shall know by this honest old man, and though say it, though old man yet poor man, my father--  One speak for both.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 51)
know thee well. Thou hast obtained thy suit. Shylock thy master spoke with me this day, And hath preferred thee, if it be preferment To leave a rich Jew's service, to become The follower of so poor a gentleman.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 53)
sinful thought! Never so rich a gem Was set in worse than gold.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 23)
my Christian ducats! Justice, the law, my ducats, and my daughter, sealed bag, two sealed bags of ducats, Of double ducats, stol'n from me by my daughter, And jewels--two stones, two rich and precious stones-- Stol'n by my daughter!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 7, Scene 6)
Marry, well remembered. reasoned with a Frenchman yesterday Who told me, in the Narrow Seas that part The French and English, there miscarried vessel of our country richly fraught.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 7, Scene 10)
Here. What would my lord?   Madam, there is alighted at your gate young Venetian, one that comes before To signify th' approaching of his lord, From whom he bringeth sensible regreets; To wit (besides commends and courteous breath), Gifts of rich value; yet have not seen So likely an ambassador of love.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 38)
Now, what news on the Rialto?  Why, yet it lives there unchecked that Antonio hath a ship of rich lading wracked on the Narrow Seas--the Goodwins, think they call the place--a very dangerous flat, and fatal, where the carcasses of many a tall ship lie buried, as they say, if my gossip Report be an honest woman of her word.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 0)
Though for myself alone would not be ambitious in my wish To wish myself much better, yet for you would be trebled twenty times myself, thousand times more fair, ten thousand times More rich, that only to stand high in your account might in virtues, beauties, livings, friends, Exceed account.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 57)

As much to him, else is his thanks too much. Say, Signior Gremio, what can you assure her?   First, as you know, my house within the city Is richly furnished with plate and gold, Basins and ewers to lave her dainty hands; My hangings all of Tyrian tapestry; In ivory coffers have stuffed my crowns, In cypress chests my arras counterpoints, Costly apparel, tents, and canopies, Fine linen, Turkey cushions bossed with pearl, Valance of Venice gold in needlework, Pewter and brass, and all things that belongs To house or housekeeping.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 149)
If may have your daughter to my wife, I'll leave her houses three or four as good, Within rich Pisa walls, as any one Old Signior Gremio has in Padua, Besides two thousand ducats by the year Of fruitful land, all which shall be her jointure.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 153)
Why, man, she is mine own, And as rich in having such a jewel As twenty seas if all their sand were pearl, The water nectar, and the rocks pure gold.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 65)
know it well, my lord, and sure the match Were rich and honorable.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 17)

Scape being drunk, for want of wine.   th' commonwealth would by contraries Execute all things, for no kind of traffic Would admit; no name of magistrate; Letters should not be known; riches, poverty, And use of service, none; contract, succession, Bourn, bound of land, tilth, vineyard, none; No use of metal, corn, or wine, or oil; No occupation; all men idle, all, And women too, but innocent and pure; No sovereignty--  Yet he would be king on 't.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 56)

frown the while, and perchance wind up my watch, or play with my--some rich jewel.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 22)
But, worthy Hector, She is a theme of honor and renown, spur to valiant and magnanimous deeds, Whose present courage may beat down our foes, And fame in time to come canonize us; For presume brave Hector would not lose So rich advantage of a promised glory As smiles upon the forehead of this action For the wide world's revenue.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 63)

dream itself is but a shadow.  Truly, and hold ambition of so airy and light a quality that it is but a shadow's shadow.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 92)
But 'tis a common proof That lowliness is young ambition's ladder, Whereto the climber-upward turns his face; But, when he once attains the upmost round, He then unto the ladder turns his back, Looks in the clouds, scorning the base degrees By which he did ascend.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 10)

And thought they Margaret was Hero?  Two of them did, the Prince and Claudio, but the devil my master knew she was Margaret; and partly by his oaths, which first possessed them, partly by the dark night, which did deceive them, but chiefly by my villainy, which did confirm any slander that Don John had made, away went Claudio enraged, swore he would meet her as he was appointed next morning at the temple, and there, before the whole congregation, shame her with what he saw o'ernight and send her home again without a husband.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 59)

Mad world, mad kings, mad composition! John, to stop Arthur's title in the whole, Hath willingly departed with a part; And France, whose armor conscience buckled on, Whom zeal and charity brought to the field As God's own soldier, rounded in the ear With that same purpose-changer, that sly devil, That broker that still breaks the pate of faith, That daily break-vow, he that wins of all, Of kings, of beggars, old men, young men, maids-- Who having no external thing to lose But the word "maid," cheats the poor maid of that-- That smooth-faced gentleman, tickling Commodity, Commodity, the bias of the world-- The world, who of itself is peised well, Made to run even upon even ground, Till this advantage, this vile-drawing bias, This sway of motion, this Commodity, Makes it take head from all indifferency, From all direction, purpose, course, intent.(King John, Act 0, Scene 192)

His mother was a vot'ress of my order, And in the spiced Indian air by night Full often hath she gossiped by my side And sat with me on Neptune's yellow sands, Marking th' embarked traders on the flood, When we have laughed to see the sails conceive And grow big-bellied with the wanton wind; Which she, with pretty and with swimming gait, Following (her womb then rich with my young squire), Would imitate and sail upon the land To fetch me trifles and return again, As from a voyage, rich with merchandise.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 38)

There is no appearance of fancy in him, unless it be a fancy that he hath to strange disguises, as to be a Dutchman today, a Frenchman tomorrow, or in the shape of two countries at once, as a German from the waist downward, all slops, and a Spaniard from the hip upward, no doublet.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 12)
--Why, what read you there That have so cowarded and chased your blood Out of appearance?(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 40)
Pray you, pass on. will not tarry; no, nor ever more Upon this business my appearance make In any of their courts.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 51)
And shamed life a hateful.   Ay, but to die, and go we know not where, To lie in cold obstruction and to rot, This sensible warm motion to become kneaded clod; and the delighted spirit To bathe in fiery floods, or to reside In thrilling region of thick-ribbed ice, To be imprisoned in the viewless winds And blown with restless violence round about The pendent world; or to be worse than worst Of those that lawless and incertain thought Imagine howling--'tis too horrible.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 47)
Mark me with what violence she first loved the Moor but for bragging and telling her fantastical lies.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 88)
Your officer Iago can inform you, While spare speech, which something now offends me, Of all that do know; nor know aught By me that's said or done amiss this night, Unless self-charity be sometimes a vice, And to defend ourselves it be a sin When violence assails us.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 87)
What means this scene of rude impatience?   To make an act of tragic violence.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 14)
Be certain what you do, sir, lest your justice Prove violence, in the which three great ones suffer: Yourself, your queen, your son.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 53)
But now the substance shall endure the like, And will chain these legs and arms of thine, That hast by tyranny these many years Wasted our country, slain our citizens, And sent our sons and husbands captivate.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 16)
Thy grave admonishments prevail with me. But yet methinks my father's execution Was nothing less than bloody tyranny.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 27)
So let high-sighted tyranny range on Till each man drop by lottery.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 46)
Insulting tyranny begins to jut Upon the innocent and aweless throne.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 24)
Even at thy teat thou hadst thy tyranny. Yet every mother breeds not sons alike.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 48)
Poor Bassianus here lies murdered.   Then all too late bring this fatal writ, The complot of this timeless tragedy, And wonder greatly that man's face can fold In pleasing smiles such murderous tyranny.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 99)
Thou kill'st my heart. Mine eyes are cloyed with view of tyranny; deed of death done on the innocent Becomes not Titus' brother.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 21)
I'll not call you tyrant; But this most cruel usage of your queen, Not able to produce more accusation Than your own weak-hinged fancy, something savors Of tyranny, and will ignoble make you, Yea, scandalous to the world.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 47)
But thus: if powers divine Behold our human actions, as they do, doubt not then but innocence shall make False accusation blush and tyranny Tremble at patience.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 6)
Thy tyranny, Together working with thy jealousies, Fancies too weak for boys, too green and idle For girls of nine, think what they have done, And then run mad indeed, stark mad, for all Thy bygone fooleries were but spices of it.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 52)
Give you a reason on compulsion? If reasons were as plentiful as blackberries, would give no man a reason upon compulsion,  I'll be no longer guilty of this sin.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 97)
His trespass yet lives guilty in thy blood, And, till thou be restored, thou art a yeoman.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 33)
In sight of God and us, your guilt is great. Receive the sentence of the law for sins Such as by God's book are adjudged to death.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 1)
Peter, thou hast prevailed in right!   Go, take hence that traitor from our sight; For by his death we do perceive his guilt.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 40)
But lest myself be guilty to self wrong, I'll stop mine ears against the mermaid's song.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 64)
But see, thy fault France hath in thee found out, nest of hollow bosoms, which he fills With treacherous crowns, and three corrupted men-- One, Richard, Earl of Cambridge, and the second, Henry, Lord Scroop of Masham, and the third, Sir Thomas Grey, knight, of Northumberland-- Have, for the gilt of France guilt indeed!(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 5)
You may guess quickly what.  Is he found guilty?(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 3)
The great duke Came to the bar, where to his accusations He pleaded still not guilty and alleged Many sharp reasons to defeat the law.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 6)
And so his peers upon this evidence Have found him guilty of high treason.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 10)
Be what they will, heartily forgive 'em. Yet let 'em look they glory not in mischief, Nor build their evils on the graves of great men, For then my guiltless blood must cry against 'em.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 28)
If the Duke be guiltless, 'Tis full of woe. Yet can give you inkling Of an ensuing evil, if it fall, Greater than this.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 56)
You, laying these slight sullies on my son, As 'twere a thing a little soiled i' th' working, Mark you, your party in converse, him you would sound, Having ever seen in the prenominate crimes The youth you breathe of guilty, be assured He closes with you in this consequence: "Good sir," or so, or "friend," or "gentleman," According to the phrase or the addition Of man and country--  Very good, my lord.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 15)
He would drown the stage with tears And cleave the general ear with horrid speech, Make mad the guilty and appall the free, Confound the ignorant and amaze indeed The very faculties of eyes and ears.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 199)
Fie upon 't! Foh! About, my brains!--Hum, have heard That guilty creatures sitting at a play Have, by the very cunning of the scene, Been struck so to the soul that presently They have proclaimed their malefactions; For murder, though it have no tongue, will speak With most miraculous organ.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 207)
Swear priests and cowards and men cautelous, Old feeble carrions, and such suffering souls That welcome wrongs; unto bad causes swear Such creatures as men doubt; but do not stain The even virtue of our enterprise, Nor th' insuppressive mettle of our spirits, To think that or our cause or our performance Did need an oath, when every drop of blood That every Roman bears, and nobly bears, Is guilty of a several bastardy If he do break the smallest particle Of any promise that hath passed from him.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 50)
And out of question so it is sometimes: Glory grows guilty of detested crimes, When for fame's sake, for praise, an outward part, We bend to that the working of the heart; As for praise alone now seek to spill The poor deer's blood, that my heart means no ill.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 15)
If he do bleed, I'll gild the faces of the grooms withal, For it must seem their guilt.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 31)
If it confess natural guiltiness such as is his, Let it not sound a thought upon your tongue Against my brother's life.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 61)
You spend your passion on a misprised mood. am not guilty of Lysander's blood, Nor is he dead, for aught that can tell.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 28)
But till come again, No bed shall e'er be guilty of my stay, Nor rest be interposer 'twixt us twain.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 119)
'Has had most favorable and happy speed! Tempests themselves, high seas, and howling winds, The guttered rocks and congregated sands (Traitors ensteeped to clog the guiltless keel), As having sense of beauty, do omit Their mortal natures, letting go safely by The divine Desdemona.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 26)
His hands were guilty of no kindred blood, But bloody with the enemies of his kin.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 57)
This is the fruits of rashness. Marked you not How that the guilty kindred of the Queen Looked pale when they did hear of Clarence' death?(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 49)
Let them not speak a word. The guilt is plain. For, by my soul, were there worse end than death, That end upon them should be executed.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 111)
--Away with her to prison. He who shall speak for her is afar off guilty But that he speaks.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 43)
You need not fear it, sir. This child was prisoner to the womb, and is By law and process of great nature thence Freed and enfranchised, not a party to The anger of the King, nor guilty of, If any be, the trespass of the Queen.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 27)
We can, my royal liege. He is not guilty of her coming hither.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 61)
Let us be cleared Of being tyrannous, since we so openly Proceed in justice, which shall have due course Even to the guilt or the purgation.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 1)
Since what am to say must be but that Which contradicts my accusation, and The testimony on my part no other But what comes from myself, it shall scarce boot me To say "Not guilty.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 4)
--Now, my masters, for a true face and good conscience.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 212)
Why that way?  To lose itself in a fog, where, being three parts melted away with rotten dews, the fourth would return for conscience' sake, to help to get thee a wife.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 9)
'Tis mine, and this will witness outwardly As strongly as the conscience does within To th' madding of her lord.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 19)
All the commons Hate him perniciously and, o' my conscience, Wish him ten fathom deep.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 19)
Yet heaven bear witness, And if have a conscience, let it sink me Even as the ax falls, if be not faithful!(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 25)
What's the cause?   It seems the marriage with his brother's wife Has crept too near his conscience.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 6)
No, his conscience Has crept too near another lady.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 7)
For, now he has cracked the league Between us and the Emperor, the Queen's great-nephew, He dives into the King's soul and there scatters Dangers, doubts, wringing of the conscience, Fears and despairs--and all these for his marriage.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 11)
My good Lord Cardinal? my Wolsey, The quiet of my wounded conscience, Thou art a cure fit for a king.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 34)
But, conscience, conscience! 'tis a tender place, and must leave her.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 64)
You, that have so fair parts of woman on you, Have too a woman's heart, which ever yet Affected eminence, wealth, sovereignty; Which, to say sooth, are blessings; and which gifts, Saving your mincing, the capacity Of your soft cheveril conscience would receive If you might please to stretch it.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 8)
Then mark th' inducement. Thus it came; give heed to 't: My conscience first received a tenderness, Scruple, and prick on certain speeches uttered By th' Bishop of Bayonne, then French ambassador, Who had been hither sent on the debating marriage 'twixt the Duke of Orleans and Our daughter Mary.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 62)
This respite shook The bosom of my conscience, entered me, Yea, with a spitting power, and made to tremble The region of my breast; which forced such way That many mazed considerings did throng And pressed in with this caution.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 64)
Thus hulling in The wild sea of my conscience, did steer Toward this remedy whereupon we are Now present here together.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 68)
That's to say, meant to rectify my conscience, which then did feel full sick, and yet not well, By all the reverend fathers of the land And doctors learned.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 69)
I'll have grounds More relative than this. The play's the thing Wherein I'll catch the conscience of the King.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 211)
Mad world, mad kings, mad composition! John, to stop Arthur's title in the whole, Hath willingly departed with a part; And France, whose armor conscience buckled on, Whom zeal and charity brought to the field As God's own soldier, rounded in the ear With that same purpose-changer, that sly devil, That broker that still breaks the pate of faith, That daily break-vow, he that wins of all, Of kings, of beggars, old men, young men, maids-- Who having no external thing to lose But the word "maid," cheats the poor maid of that-- That smooth-faced gentleman, tickling Commodity, Commodity, the bias of the world-- The world, who of itself is peised well, Made to run even upon even ground, Till this advantage, this vile-drawing bias, This sway of motion, this Commodity, Makes it take head from all indifferency, From all direction, purpose, course, intent.(King John, Act 0, Scene 192)
do; and bear the shame most patiently.   I'll teach you how you shall arraign your conscience, And try your penitence, if it be sound Or hollowly put on.(Measure for Measure, Act 2, Scene 7)
Certainly my conscience will serve me to run from this Jew my master.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 0)
" My conscience says "No. Take heed, honest Lancelet, take heed, honest Gobbo," or, as aforesaid, "honest Lancelet Gobbo, do not run; scorn running with thy heels.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 2)
" Well, my conscience, hanging about the neck of my heart, says very wisely to me "My honest friend Lancelet, being an honest man's son"--or rather, an honest woman's son, for indeed my father did something smack, something grow to--he had a kind of taste--well, my conscience says "Lancelet, budge not.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 5)
" "Budge," says the fiend. "Budge not," says my conscience.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 6)
" To be ruled by my conscience, should stay with the Jew my master, who (God bless the mark) is a kind of devil; and to run away from the Jew, should be ruled by the fiend, who (saving your reverence) is the devil himself.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 8)
Certainly the Jew is the very devil incarnation, and, in my conscience, my conscience is but a kind of hard conscience to offer to counsel me to stay with the Jew.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 9)
Both are my kinsmen. one is my sovereign, whom both my oath And duty bids defend; t' other again Is my kinsman, whom the King hath wronged, Whom conscience and my kindred bids to right.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 45)
Why dost thou weep? Canst thou the conscience lack To think shall lack friends?(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 77)
But, for your conscience?   Ay, sir, where lies that?(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 107)
Twenty consciences That stand 'twixt me and Milan, candied be they And melt ere they molest!(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 109)
Next, pitied him, And so would any young wench, o' my conscience, That ever dreamed, or vowed her maidenhead To a young handsome man.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 3, Scene 5)
'Tis my fault, Master Page. suffer for it.  You suffer for a pad conscience.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 91)
appeal To your own conscience, sir, before Polixenes Came to your court, how was in your grace, How merited to be so; since he came, With what encounter so uncurrent Have strained t' appear thus; if one jot beyond The bound of honor, or in act or will That way inclining, hardened be the hearts Of all that hear me, and my near'st of kin Cry fie upon my grave.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 11)

Thy luster thickens When he shines by. say again, thy spirit Is all afraid to govern thee near him; But he away, 'tis noble.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 2, Scene 13)

That's it. would have said the very same.  Why, your dolphin is not lustier.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 10)

Therefore my age is as a lusty winter, Frosty but kindly.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 20)

know thou canst, and therefore see thou do it. am possessed with an adulterate blot; My blood is mingled with the crime of lust; For if we two be one, and thou play false, do digest the poison of thy flesh, Being strumpeted by thy contagion.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 55)
And out of all these to restore the King, He counsels a divorce, a loss of her That like a jewel has hung twenty years About his neck, yet never lost her luster; Of her that loves him with that excellence That angels love good men with; even of her That, when the greatest stroke of fortune falls, Will bless the King.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 12)
Calphurnia here, my wife, stays me at home. She dreamt tonight she saw my statue, Which, like a fountain with an hundred spouts, Did run pure blood; and many lusty Romans Came smiling and did bathe their hands in it.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 36)
Our cannons' malice vainly shall be spent Against th' invulnerable clouds of heaven, And with a blessed and unvexed retire, With unbacked swords and helmets all unbruised, We will bear home that lusty blood again Which here we came to spout against your town, And leave your children, wives, and you in peace.(King John, Act 0, Scene 85)
Our colors do return in those same hands That did display them when we first marched forth, And like a jolly troop of huntsmen come Our lusty English, all with purpled hands, Dyed in the dying slaughter of their foes.(King John, Act 0, Scene 108)
If lusty love should go in quest of beauty, Where should he find it fairer than in Blanche?(King John, Act 0, Scene 144)
What cannoneer begot this lusty blood? He speaks plain cannon fire, and smoke, and bounce.(King John, Act 0, Scene 155)
The magnanimous and most illustrate King Cophetua set eye upon the pernicious and indubitate beggar Zenelophon; and he it was that might rightly say "Veni, vidi, vici," which to annothanize in the vulgar base and obscure vulgar!(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 32)
When a man's overlusty at legs, then he wears wooden netherstocks.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 4)
Lechery, by this hand! An index and obscure prologue to the history of lust and foul thoughts.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 104)
Now, do love her too, Not out of absolute lust (though peradventure stand accountant for as great a sin) But partly led to diet my revenge For that do suspect the lusty Moor Hath leaped into my seat--the thought whereof Doth, like a poisonous mineral, gnaw my inwards, And nothing can or shall content my soul Till am evened with him, wife for wife, Or, failing so, yet that put the Moor At least into a jealousy so strong That judgment cannot cure.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 118)
Three else of Cyprus, noble swelling spirits That hold their honors in a wary distance, The very elements of this warlike isle, Have tonight flustered with flowing cups; And they watch too.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 23)
For whiles this honest fool Plies Desdemona to repair his fortune, And she for him pleads strongly to the Moor, I'll pour this pestilence into his ear: That she repeals him for her body's lust; And by how much she strives to do him good, She shall undo her credit with the Moor.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 149)
Patience, good sir, Even for this charge.  Now mild may be thy life, For a more blusterous birth had never babe.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 13)
An he speak anything against me, I'll take him down, an he were lustier than he is, and twenty such jacks.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 60)
Now, by the world, it is a lusty wench. love her ten times more than ere did.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 64)

No, let them satisfy their lust on thee.   Away, for thou hast stayed us here too long!(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 65)

More than prince of cats. he's the courageous captain of compliments.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 7)
Why, brother Hector, We may not think the justness of each act Such and no other than event doth form it, Nor once deject the courage of our minds Because Cassandra's mad.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 40)
But, worthy Hector, She is a theme of honor and renown, spur to valiant and magnanimous deeds, Whose present courage may beat down our foes, And fame in time to come canonize us; For presume brave Hector would not lose So rich advantage of a promised glory As smiles upon the forehead of this action For the wide world's revenue.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 63)
I'll reconcile me to Polixenes, New woo my queen, recall the good Camillo, Whom proclaim a man of truth, of mercy; For, being transported by my jealousies To bloody thoughts and to revenge, chose Camillo for the minister to poison My friend Polixenes, which had been done But that the good mind of Camillo tardied My swift command, though with death and with Reward did threaten and encourage him, Not doing it and being done.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 45)

How meanest thou? Brawling in French?  No, my complete master, but to jig off a tune at the tongue's end, canary to it with your feet, humor it with turning up your eyelids, sigh a note and sing a note, sometimes through the throat as if you swallowed love with singing love, sometimes through the nose as if you snuffed up love by smelling love; with your hat penthouse-like o'er the shop of your eyes, with your arms crossed on your thin-belly doublet like a rabbit on a spit; or your hands in your pocket like a man after the old painting; and keep not too long in one tune, but a snip and away.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 4)
Not fair? Alack, for woe!   Yes, madam, fair.  Nay, never paint me now.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 8)
stonecutter or a painter could not have made him so ill, though they had been but two years o' th' trade.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 23)

Where are our friends and kindreds? But whether 'twas the coldness of the King, Who looked full gently on his warlike queen, That robbed my soldiers of their heated spleen, Or whether 'twas report of her success Or more than common fear of Clifford's rigor, Who thunders to his captives blood and death, cannot judge; but to conclude with truth, Their weapons like to lightning came and went; Our soldiers', like the night owl's lazy flight Or like an idle thresher with a flail, Fell gently down, as if they struck their friends.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 36)

Heaven has an end in all; yet, you that hear me, This from a dying man receive as certain: Where you are liberal of your loves and counsels Be sure you be not loose; for those you make friends And give your hearts to, when they once perceive The least rub in your fortunes, fall away Like water from you, never found again But where they mean to sink you.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 50)

Mad world, mad kings, mad composition! John, to stop Arthur's title in the whole, Hath willingly departed with a part; And France, whose armor conscience buckled on, Whom zeal and charity brought to the field As God's own soldier, rounded in the ear With that same purpose-changer, that sly devil, That broker that still breaks the pate of faith, That daily break-vow, he that wins of all, Of kings, of beggars, old men, young men, maids-- Who having no external thing to lose But the word "maid," cheats the poor maid of that-- That smooth-faced gentleman, tickling Commodity, Commodity, the bias of the world-- The world, who of itself is peised well, Made to run even upon even ground, Till this advantage, this vile-drawing bias, This sway of motion, this Commodity, Makes it take head from all indifferency, From all direction, purpose, course, intent.(King John, Act 0, Scene 192)
Since kings break faith upon Commodity, Gain, be my lord, for will worship thee!(King John, Act 0, Scene 197)

Silence!  Read the indictment.  Hermione, queen to the worthy Leontes, King of Sicilia, thou art here accused and arraigned of high treason, in committing adultery with Polixenes, King of Bohemia, and conspiring with Camillo to take away the life of our sovereign lord the King, thy royal husband; the pretense whereof being by circumstances partly laid open, thou, Hermione, contrary to the faith and allegiance of a true subject, didst counsel and aid them, for their better safety, to fly away by night.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 3)

What tidings with our cousin Buckingham?   Such as my heart doth tremble to unfold: sort of naughty persons, lewdly bent, Under the countenance and confederacy Of Lady Eleanor, the Protector's wife, The ringleader and head of all this rout, Have practiced dangerously against your state, Dealing with witches and with conjurers, Whom we have apprehended in the fact, Raising up wicked spirits from under ground, Demanding of King Henry's life and death And other of your Highness' Privy Council, As more at large your Grace shall understand.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 79)

Now all's his, When by and by the din of war gan pierce His ready sense; then straight his doubled spirit Requickened what in flesh was fatigate, And to the battle came he, where he did Run reeking o'er the lives of men as if 'Twere a perpetual spoil; and till we called Both field and city ours, he never stood To ease his breast with panting.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 42)

But if these-- As am sure they do--bear fire enough To kindle cowards and to steel with valor The melting spirits of women, then, countrymen, What need we any spur but our own cause To prick us to redress?(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 47)
Swear priests and cowards and men cautelous, Old feeble carrions, and such suffering souls That welcome wrongs; unto bad causes swear Such creatures as men doubt; but do not stain The even virtue of our enterprise, Nor th' insuppressive mettle of our spirits, To think that or our cause or our performance Did need an oath, when every drop of blood That every Roman bears, and nobly bears, Is guilty of a several bastardy If he do break the smallest particle Of any promise that hath passed from him.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 50)

Go after.  By no means what?   Persuade me to the murder of your Lordship, But that told him the revenging gods 'Gainst parricides did all the thunder bend, Spoke with how manifold and strong a bond The child was bound to th' father--sir, in fine, Seeing how loathly opposite stood To his unnatural purpose, in fell motion With his prepared sword he charges home My unprovided body, lanced mine arm; And when he saw my best alarumed spirits, Bold in the quarrel's right, roused to th' encounter, Or whether ghasted by the noise made, Full suddenly he fled.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 23)

And shamed life a hateful.   Ay, but to die, and go we know not where, To lie in cold obstruction and to rot, This sensible warm motion to become kneaded clod; and the delighted spirit To bathe in fiery floods, or to reside In thrilling region of thick-ribbed ice, To be imprisoned in the viewless winds And blown with restless violence round about The pendent world; or to be worse than worst Of those that lawless and incertain thought Imagine howling--'tis too horrible.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 47)

2        Come, now a roundel and a fairy song; Then, for the third part of a minute, hence-- Some to kill cankers in the muskrose buds, Some war with reremice for their leathern wings To make my small elves coats, and some keep back The clamorous owl that nightly hoots and wonders At our quaint spirits.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 0)
