Damned spirits all, That in crossways and floods have burial, Already to their wormy beds are gone.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 160)
But we are spirits of another sort. with the Morning's love have oft made sport And, like a forester, the groves may tread Even till the eastern gate, all fiery red, Opening on Neptune with fair blessed beams, Turns into yellow gold his salt-green streams.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 162)
Pray thee take pain To allay with some cold drops of modesty Thy skipping spirit, lest through thy wild behavior be misconstered in the place go to, And lose my hopes.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 70)
But adieu. These foolish drops do something drown my manly spirit.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 2, Scene 6)
All things that are, Are with more spirit chased than enjoyed.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 5)
The watery kingdom, whose ambitious head Spets in the face of heaven, is no bar To stop the foreign spirits, but they come As o'er a brook to see fair Portia.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 18)
will not choose what many men desire, Because will not jump with common spirits And rank me with the barbarous multitudes.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 12)
Like one of two contending in a prize That thinks he hath done well in people's eyes, Hearing applause and universal shout, Giddy in spirit, still gazing in a doubt Whether those peals of praise be his or no, So, thrice-fair lady, stand even so, As doubtful whether what see be true, Until confirmed, signed, ratified by you.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 55)
But the full sum of me Is sum of something, which, to term in gross, Is an unlessoned girl, unschooled, unpracticed; Happy in this, she is not yet so old But she may learn; happier than this, She is not bred so dull but she can learn; Happiest of all, is that her gentle spirit Commits itself to yours to be directed As from her lord, her governor, her king.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 58)
The dearest friend to me, the kindest man, The best conditioned and unwearied spirit In doing courtesies, and one in whom The ancient Roman honor more appears Than any that draws breath in Italy.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 106)
Great Jove, Othello guard, And swell his sail with thine own powerful breath, That he may bless this bay with his tall ship, Make love's quick pants in Desdemona's arms, Give renewed fire to our extincted spirits, And bring all Cyprus comfort!(Othello, Act 0, Scene 28)
Three else of Cyprus, noble swelling spirits That hold their honors in a wary distance, The very elements of this warlike isle, Have tonight flustered with flowing cups; And they watch too.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 23)
And discourse fustian with one's own shadow? thou invisible spirit of wine, if thou hast no name to be known by, let us call thee devil!(Othello, Act 2, Scene 119)
Death may usurp on nature many hours, And yet the fire of life kindle again The o'erpressed spirits.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 32)
'Twould anger him To raise a spirit in his mistress' circle Of some strange nature, letting it there stand Till she had laid it and conjured it down.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 0, Scene 9)
For shame, thou hilding of a devilish spirit! Why dost thou wrong her that did ne'er wrong thee?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 10)
Why, no, for she hath broke the lute to me. did but tell her she mistook her frets, And bowed her hand to teach her fingering, When, with a most impatient devilish spirit, " 'Frets' call you these?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 62)
pray you do. I'll attend her here--  And woo her with some spirit when she comes!(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 68)
see a woman may be made a fool If she had not a spirit to resist.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 74)
Valentine?  No.  Who then? His spirit?  Neither.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 64)
'Tis a spirit; sometime 't appears like a lord, sometime like a lawyer, sometime like a philosopher, with two stones more than 's artificial one.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 48)
He is very often like a knight, and generally in all shapes that man goes up and down in from fourscore to thirteen, this spirit walks in.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 49)
find Not myself disposed to sleep.  Nor My spirits are nimble.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 77)
Thus, sir: Although this lord of weak remembrance--this, Who shall be of as little memory When he is earthed--hath here almost persuaded-- For he's a spirit of persuasion, only Professes to persuade--the King his son's alive, 'Tis as impossible that he's undrowned As he that sleeps here swims.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 92)
His spirits hear me, And yet needs must curse. But they'll nor pinch, Fright me with urchin-shows, pitch me i' th' mire, Nor lead me like a firebrand in the dark Out of my way, unless he bid 'em.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 1)
Lo, now, lo! Here comes a spirit of his, and to torment me For bringing wood in slowly.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 4)
The spirit torments me.  This is some monster of the isle with four legs, who hath got, as take it, an ague.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 28)
Remember First to possess his books, for without them He's but a sot, as am, nor hath not One spirit to command.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 45)
peace, and the spirit of humors intimate reading aloud to him.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 31)
Thy fates open their hands. Let thy blood and spirit embrace them.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 57)
We are young and yet desire the ways of honor That liberty and common conversation, The poison of pure spirits, might like women Woo us to wander from.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 20)
Till our deaths it cannot.    And after death our spirits shall be led To those that love eternally.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 36)
There's not the meanest spirit on our party Without a heart to dare or sword to draw When Helen is defended, nor none so noble Whose life were ill bestowed or death unfamed Where Helen is the subject.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 52)
have a roisting challenge sent amongst The dull and factious nobles of the Greeks Will strike amazement to their drowsy spirits.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 65)
What spirit, what devil suggests this imagination?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 89)
Now from the oracle They will bring all, whose spiritual counsel had Shall stop or spur me.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 75)
He straight declined, drooped, took it deeply, Fastened and fixed the shame on 't in himself, Threw off his spirit, his appetite, his sleep, And downright languished.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 5)
-- Look to your babe, my lord; 'tis yours. Jove send her better guiding spirit.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 51)
--Come on, poor babe.  Some powerful spirit instruct the kites and ravens To be thy nurses!(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 77)
Welcome, Jack. Where hast thou been?  plague of all cowards, say, and a vengeance too!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 40)
That's a brave fellow, but he's vengeance proud and loves not the common people.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 2)
vengeance, vengeance! Me of my lawful pleasure she restrained And prayed me oft forbearance; did it with pudency so rosy the sweet view on 't Might well have warmed old Saturn, that thought her As chaste as unsunned snow.(Cymbeline, Act 4, Scene 3)
But as we often see against some storm silence in the heavens, the rack stand still, The bold winds speechless, and the orb below As hush as death, anon the dreadful thunder Doth rend the region; so, after Pyrrhus' pause, Aroused vengeance sets him new a-work, And never did the Cyclops' hammers fall On Mars's armor, forged for proof eterne, With less remorse than Pyrrhus' bleeding sword Now falls on Priam.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 175)
vengeance! Why, what an ass am This is most brave, That the son of a dear father murdered, Prompted to my revenge by heaven and hell, Must, like a whore, unpack my heart with words And fall a-cursing like a very drab, stallion!(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 206)
If it be true, all vengeance comes too short Which can pursue th' offender.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 37)
All the stored vengeances of heaven fall On her ingrateful top!(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 68)
No, Escanes, know this of me: Antiochus from incest lived not free, For which the most high gods not minding longer To withhold the vengeance that they had in store Due to this heinous capital offense, Even in the height and pride of all his glory, When he was seated in a chariot of An inestimable value, and his daughter with him, fire from heaven came and shriveled up Those bodies even to loathing, for they so stunk That all those eyes adored them, ere their fall, Scorn now their hand should give them burial.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 11)
vengeance on your crafty withered hide!-- Yet have faced it with a card of ten.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 168)
vengeance on 't, there 'tis! Now sir, this staff is my sister, for, look you, she is as white as a lily and as small as a wand.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 9)
This way, or not at all, stand you in hope. Come, come, our empress, with her sacred wit To villainy and vengeance consecrate, Will we acquaint withal what we intend, And she shall file our engines with advice That will not suffer you to square yourselves, But to your wishes' height advance you both.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 47)
And had you not by wondrous fortune come, This vengeance on me had they executed.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 33)
Banished the kingdom? 'Tis a benefit, mercy must thank 'em for; but banished The free enjoying of that face die for, 'twas a studied punishment, a death Beyond imagination--such a vengeance That, were old and wicked, all my sins Could never pluck upon me.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 0)
My mind misgives me. This fellow has a vengeance trick o' th' hip.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 34)
It was thought meet Paris should do some vengeance on the Greeks.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 22)
After this, the vengeance on the whole camp! Or rather, the Neapolitan bone-ache!(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 6)
Let him be Until a time may serve. For present vengeance, Take it on her.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 8)
--the Queen, the Queen, The sweet'st, dear'st creature's dead, and vengeance for 't Not dropped down yet.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 57)
Heigh-ho! An it be not four by the day, I'll be hanged.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 0)
Charles's Wain is over the new chimney, and yet our horse not packed.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 1)
--What, ostler!  Anon, anon.  prithee, Tom, beat Cut's saddle.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 2)
Put a few flocks in the point. Poor jade is wrung in the withers out of all cess.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 3)
Peas and beans are as dank here as a dog, and that is the next way to give poor jades the bots.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 4)
This house is turned upside down since Robin ostler died.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 5)
Poor fellow never joyed since the price of oats rose.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 6)
It was the death of him.  think this be the most villainous house in all London road for fleas.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 7)
am stung like a tench.  Like a tench? By the Mass, there is ne'er a king christen could be better bit than have been since the first cock.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 8)
Why, they will allow us ne'er a jordan, and then we leak in your chimney, and your chamber-lye breeds fleas like a loach.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 9)
What, ostler, come away and be hanged. Come away.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 10)
have a gammon of bacon and two races of ginger to be delivered as far as Charing Cross.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 11)
God's body, the turkeys in my pannier are quite starved.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 12)
--What, ostler! plague on thee! Hast thou never an eye in thy head?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 13)
Canst not hear? An 'twere not as good deed as drink to break the pate on thee, am a very villain.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 14)
Come, and be hanged. Hast no faith in thee?     Good morrow, carriers.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 15)
What's o'clock?  think it be two o'clock.  prithee, lend me thy lantern to see my gelding in the stable.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 16)
Nay, by God, soft. know a trick worth two of that, i' faith.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 17)
pray thee, lend me thine.  Ay, when, canst tell?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 18)
"Lend me thy lantern," quoth he. Marry, I'll see thee hanged first.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 19)
Sirrah carrier, what time do you mean to come to London?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 20)
Time enough to go to bed with a candle, warrant thee.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 21)
Come, neighbor Mugs, we'll call up the gentlemen.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 22)
They will along with company, for they have great charge.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 23)
What ho, chamberlain!     At hand, quoth pickpurse.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 24)
That's even as fair as "at hand, quoth the Chamberlain," for thou variest no more from picking of purses than giving direction doth from laboring: thou layest the plot how.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 25)
Good morrow, Master Gadshill. It holds current that told you yesternight: there's a franklin in the Wild of Kent hath brought three hundred marks with him in gold.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 26)
heard him tell it to one of his company last night at supper--a kind of auditor, one that hath abundance of charge too, God knows what.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 27)
They are up already and call for eggs and butter.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 28)
They will away presently.  Sirrah, if they meet not with Saint Nicholas' clerks, I'll give thee this neck.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 29)
No, I'll none of it. pray thee, keep that for the hangman, for know thou worshipest Saint Nicholas as truly as a man of falsehood may.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 30)
What talkest thou to me of the hangman? If hang, I'll make a fat pair of gallows, for if hang, old Sir John hangs with me, and thou knowest he is no starveling.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 31)
Tut, there are other Troyans that thou dream'st not of, the which for sport sake are content to do the profession some grace, that would, if matters should be looked into, for their own credit sake make all whole.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 32)
am joined with no foot-land-rakers, no long-staff sixpenny strikers, none of these mad mustachio purple-hued malt-worms, but with nobility and tranquillity, burgomasters and great oneyers, such as can hold in, such as will strike sooner than speak, and speak sooner than drink, and drink sooner than pray, and yet, zounds, lie, for they pray continually to their saint the commonwealth, or rather not pray to her but prey on her, for they ride up and down on her and make her their boots.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 33)
What, the commonwealth their boots? Will she hold out water in foul way?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 34)
She will, she will. Justice hath liquored her. We steal as in a castle, cocksure.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 35)
We have the receipt of fern seed; we walk invisible.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 36)
Nay, by my faith, think you are more beholding to the night than to fern seed for your walking invisible.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 37)
Give me thy hand. Thou shalt have a share in our purchase, as am a true man.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 38)
Nay, rather let me have it as you are a false thief.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 39)
Go to. Homo is a common name to all men. Bid the ostler bring my gelding out of the stable.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 0, Scene 40)
Come, shelter, shelter! have removed Falstaff's horse, and he frets like a gummed velvet.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 0)
Stand close.     Poins! Poins, and be hanged! Poins!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 1)
Peace, you fat-kidneyed rascal. What a brawling dost thou keep!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 2)
Where's Poins, Hal?  He is walked up to the top of the hill.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 3)
I'll go seek him.  am accursed to rob in that thief's company.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 4)
The rascal hath removed my horse and tied him know not where.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 5)
If travel but four foot by the square further afoot, shall break my wind.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 6)
Well, doubt not but to die a fair death for all this, if 'scape hanging for killing that rogue.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 7)
have forsworn his company hourly any time this two-and-twenty years, and yet am bewitched with the rogue's company.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 8)
If the rascal have not given me medicines to make me love him, I'll be hanged.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 9)
It could not be else: have drunk medicines.--Poins!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 10)
Hal! plague upon you both.--Bardolph! Peto!-- I'll starve ere I'll rob a foot further.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 11)
An 'twere not as good a deed as drink to turn true man and to leave these rogues, am the veriest varlet that ever chewed with a tooth.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 12)
Eight yards of uneven ground is threescore and ten miles afoot with me, and the stony-hearted villains know it well enough.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 13)
plague upon it when thieves cannot be true one to another!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 14)
Whew! plague upon you all!    Give me my horse, you rogues.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 15)
Give me my horse and be hanged!  Peace, you fat guts!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 16)
Lie down, lay thine ear close to the ground, and list if thou canst hear the tread of travelers.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 17)
Have you any levers to lift me up again being down?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 18)
'Sblood, I'll not bear my own flesh so far afoot again for all the coin in thy father's Exchequer.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 19)
What a plague mean you to colt me thus?  Thou liest.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 20)
Thou art not colted; thou art uncolted.  prithee, good Prince Hal, help me to my horse, good king's son.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 21)
Out, you rogue! Shall be your ostler?  Hang thyself in thine own heir-apparent garters!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 22)
If be ta'en, I'll peach for this. An have not ballads made on you all and sung to filthy tunes, let a cup of sack be my poison--when a jest is so forward, and afoot too!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 23)
hate it.     Stand.  So do, against my will.  'tis our setter.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 24)
know his voice.  What news?  Case you, case you. On with your vizards.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 25)
There's money of the King's coming down the hill.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 26)
'Tis going to the King's Exchequer.  You lie, you rogue.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 27)
'Tis going to the King's Tavern.  There's enough to make us all.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 28)
To be hanged.  Sirs, you four shall front them in the narrow lane.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 29)
Ned Poins and will walk lower. If they 'scape from your encounter, then they light on us.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 30)
How many be there of them?  Some eight or ten.  Zounds, will they not rob us?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 31)
What, a coward, Sir John Paunch?  Indeed, am not John of Gaunt, your grandfather, but yet no coward, Hal.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 32)
Well, we leave that to the proof.  Sirrah Jack, thy horse stands behind the hedge.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 33)
When thou need'st him, there thou shalt find him.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 34)
Farewell and stand fast.  Now cannot strike him, if should be hanged.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 35)
Ned, where are our disguises?  Here, hard by. Stand close.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 36)
Now, my masters, happy man be his dole, say Every man to his business.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 37)
Come, neighbor, the boy shall lead our horses down the hill.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 38)
We'll walk afoot awhile and ease our legs.  Stand!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 39)

Ah, whoreson caterpillars, bacon-fed knaves, they hate us youth.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 41)
Down with them! Fleece them!  we are undone, both we and ours forever!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 42)
Hang, you gorbellied knaves! Are you undone? No, you fat chuffs.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 43)
would your store were here. On, bacons, on! What, you knaves, young men must live.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 44)
You are grandjurors, are you? We'll jure you, faith.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 45)
The thieves have bound the true men. Now could thou and rob the thieves and go merrily to London, it would be argument for a week, laughter for a month, and a good jest forever.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 46)
Stand close, hear them coming.      Come, my masters, let us share, and then to horse before day.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 47)
An the Prince and Poins be not two arrant cowards, there's no equity stirring.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 48)
There's no more valor in that Poins than in a wild duck.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 49)
Your money!  Villains!     Got with much ease.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 50)
Now merrily to horse. The thieves are all scattered, and possessed with fear So strongly that they dare not meet each other.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 51)
Each takes his fellow for an officer. Away, good Ned.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 52)
Falstaff sweats to death, And lards the lean earth as he walks along.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 53)
Were 't not for laughing, should pity him.  How the fat rogue roared!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 1, Scene 54)
2       But, for mine own part, my lord, could be well contented to be there, in respect of the love bear your house.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 0)
He could be contented; why is he not, then? In respect of the love he bears our house--he shows in this he loves his own barn better than he loves our house.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 1)
Let me see some more. The purpose you undertake is dangerous.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 2)
Why, that's certain. 'Tis dangerous to take a cold, to sleep, to drink; but tell you, my Lord Fool, out of this nettle, danger, we pluck this flower, safety.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 3)
The purpose you undertake is dangerous, the friends you have named uncertain, the time itself unsorted, and your whole plot too light for the counterpoise of so great an opposition.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 4)
Say you so, say you so? say unto you again, you are a shallow, cowardly hind, and you lie.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 5)
What a lack-brain is this! By the Lord, our plot is a good plot as ever was laid, our friends true and constant--a good plot, good friends, and full of expectation; an excellent plot, very good friends.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 6)
What a frosty-spirited rogue is this! Why, my Lord of York commends the plot and the general course of the action.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 7)
Zounds, an were now by this rascal, could brain him with his lady's fan.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 8)
Is there not my father, my uncle, and myself, Lord Edmund Mortimer, my Lord of York, and Owen Glendower?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 9)
Is there not besides the Douglas? Have not all their letters to meet me in arms by the ninth of the next month, and are they not some of them set forward already?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 10)
What a pagan rascal is this--an infidel! Ha, you shall see now, in very sincerity of fear and cold heart, will he to the King and lay open all our proceedings.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 11)
could divide myself and go to buffets for moving such a dish of skim milk with so honorable an action!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 12)
Hang him, let him tell the King. We are prepared.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 13)
will set forward tonight.    How now, Kate? must leave you within these two hours.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 14)
my good lord, why are you thus alone? For what offense have this fortnight been banished woman from my Harry's bed?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 15)
Tell me, sweet lord, what is 't that takes from thee Thy stomach, pleasure, and thy golden sleep?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 16)
Why dost thou bend thine eyes upon the earth And start so often when thou sit'st alone?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 17)
Why hast thou lost the fresh blood in thy cheeks And given my treasures and my rights of thee To thick-eyed musing and curst melancholy?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 18)
In thy faint slumbers by thee have watched, And heard thee murmur tales of iron wars, Speak terms of manage to thy bounding steed, Cry "Courage!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 19)
To the field!" And thou hast talked Of sallies and retires, of trenches, tents, Of palisadoes, frontiers, parapets, Of basilisks, of cannon, culverin, Of prisoners' ransom, and of soldiers slain, And all the currents of a heady fight.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 20)
Thy spirit within thee hath been so at war, And thus hath so bestirred thee in thy sleep, That beads of sweat have stood upon thy brow Like bubbles in a late-disturbed stream, And in thy face strange motions have appeared, Such as we see when men restrain their breath On some great sudden hest.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 21)
what portents are these? Some heavy business hath my lord in hand, And must know it, else he loves me not.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 22)
What, ho!    Is Gilliams with the packet gone?  He is, my lord, an hour ago.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 23)
Hath Butler brought those horses from the sheriff?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 24)
One horse, my lord, he brought even now.   What horse?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 25)
roan, a crop-ear, is it not?   It is, my lord.  That roan shall be my throne.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 26)
Well, will back him straight. Esperance! Bid Butler lead him forth into the park.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 27)
But hear you, my lord.  What say'st thou, my lady?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 28)
What is it carries you away?  Why, my horse, my love, my horse.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 29)
Out, you mad-headed ape! weasel hath not such a deal of spleen As you are tossed with.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 30)
In faith, I'll know your business, Harry, that will.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 31)
fear my brother Mortimer doth stir About his title, and hath sent for you To line his enterprise; but if you go--   So far afoot, shall be weary, love.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 32)
Come, come, you paraquito, answer me Directly unto this question that ask.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 33)
In faith, I'll break thy little finger, Harry, An if thou wilt not tell me all things true.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 34)
Away! Away, you trifler. Love, love thee not. care not for thee, Kate.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 35)
This is no world To play with mammets and to tilt with lips.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 36)
We must have bloody noses and cracked crowns, And pass them current too.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 37)
--Gods me, my horse!-- What say'st thou, Kate? What wouldst thou have with me?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 38)
Do you not love me? Do you not indeed? Well, do not then, for since you love me not, will not love myself.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 39)
Do you not love me? Nay, tell me if you speak in jest or no.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 40)
Come, wilt thou see me ride? And when am a-horseback will swear love thee infinitely.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 41)
But hark you, Kate, must not have you henceforth question me Whither go, nor reason whereabout.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 42)
Whither must, must; and to conclude This evening must leave you, gentle Kate.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 43)
know you wise, but yet no farther wise Than Harry Percy's wife; constant you are, But yet a woman; and for secrecy No lady closer, for well believe Thou wilt not utter what thou dost not know, And so far will trust thee, gentle Kate.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 44)
How? So far?   Not an inch further. But hark you, Kate, Whither go, thither shall you go too.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 45)
Today will set forth, tomorrow you. Will this content you, Kate?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 2, Scene 46)
Ned, prithee, come out of that fat room and lend me thy hand to laugh a little.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 0)
Where hast been, Hal?  With three or four loggerheads amongst three or fourscore hogsheads.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 1)
have sounded the very bass string of humility. Sirrah, am sworn brother to a leash of drawers, and can call them all by their Christian names, as Tom, Dick, and Francis.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 2)
They take it already upon their salvation that though be but Prince of Wales, yet am the king of courtesy, and tell me flatly am no proud jack, like Falstaff, but a Corinthian, a lad of mettle, a good boy--by the Lord, so they call me--and when am king of England, shall command all the good lads in Eastcheap.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 3)
They call drinking deep "dyeing scarlet," and when you breathe in your watering, they cry "Hem!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 4)
" and bid you "Play it off!" To conclude, am so good a proficient in one quarter of an hour that can drink with any tinker in his own language during my life.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 5)
tell thee, Ned, thou hast lost much honor that thou wert not with me in this action; but, sweet Ned--to sweeten which name of Ned, give thee this pennyworth of sugar, clapped even now into my hand by an underskinker, one that never spake other English in his life than "Eight shillings and sixpence," and "You are welcome," with this shrill addition, "Anon, anon, sir.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 6)
--Score a pint of bastard in the Half-moon," or so.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 7)
But, Ned, to drive away the time till Falstaff come, prithee, do thou stand in some by-room while question my puny drawer to what end he gave me the sugar, and do thou never leave calling "Francis," that his tale to me may be nothing but "Anon.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 8)
" Step aside, and I'll show thee a precedent.  Francis!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 9)
Thou art perfect.  Francis!     Anon, anon, sir.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 10)
--Look down into the Pomgarnet, Ralph.  Come hither, Francis.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 11)
My lord?  How long hast thou to serve, Francis?  Forsooth, five years, and as much as to--  Francis!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 12)
Anon, anon, sir.  Five year! By 'r Lady, a long lease for the clinking of pewter!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 13)
But, Francis, darest thou be so valiant as to play the coward with thy indenture, and show it a fair pair of heels, and run from it?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 14)
Lord, sir, I'll be sworn upon all the books in England, could find in my heart--  Francis!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 15)
Anon, sir.  How old art thou, Francis?  Let me see.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 16)
About Michaelmas next, shall be--  Francis!  Anon, sir.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 17)
--Pray, stay a little, my lord.  Nay, but hark you, Francis, for the sugar thou gavest me--'twas a pennyworth, was 't not?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 18)
Lord, would it had been two!  will give thee for it a thousand pound.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 19)
Ask me when thou wilt, and thou shalt have it.  Francis!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 20)
Anon, anon.  Anon, Francis? No, Francis. But tomorrow, Francis; or, Francis, o' Thursday; or indeed, Francis, when thou wilt.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 21)
But, Francis--  My lord?  Wilt thou rob this leathern-jerkin, crystal-button, not-pated, agate-ring, puke-stocking, caddis-garter, smooth-tongue, Spanish-pouch--  Lord, sir, who do you mean?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 22)
Why then, your brown bastard is your only drink, for look you, Francis, your white canvas doublet will sully.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 23)
In Barbary, sir, it cannot come to so much.  What, sir?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 24)
Francis!  Away, you rogue! Dost thou not hear them call?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 25)
What, stand'st thou still and hear'st such a calling?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 26)
Look to the guests within. My lord, old Sir John with half a dozen more are at the door.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 27)
Shall let them in?  Let them alone awhile, and then open the door.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 28)
Poins!     Anon, anon, sir.  Sirrah, Falstaff and the rest of the thieves are at the door.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 29)
Shall we be merry?  As merry as crickets, my lad.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 30)
But hark you, what cunning match have you made with this jest of the drawer.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 31)
Come, what's the issue?  am now of all humors that have showed themselves humors since the old days of Goodman Adam to the pupil age of this present twelve o'clock at midnight.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 32)
What's o'clock, Francis?  Anon, anon, sir.  That ever this fellow should have fewer words than a parrot, and yet the son of a woman!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 33)
His industry is upstairs and downstairs, his eloquence the parcel of a reckoning.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 34)
am not yet of Percy's mind, the Hotspur of the north, he that kills me some six or seven dozen of Scots at a breakfast, washes his hands, and says to his wife "Fie upon this quiet life!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 35)
want work." my sweet Harry," says she, "how many hast thou killed today?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 36)
" "Give my roan horse a drench," says he, and answers "Some fourteen," an hour after.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 37)
trifle, a trifle." prithee, call in Falstaff. I'll play Percy, and that damned brawn shall play Dame Mortimer his wife.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 38)
"Rivo!" says the drunkard. Call in Ribs, call in Tallow.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 39)
Welcome, Jack. Where hast thou been?  plague of all cowards, say, and a vengeance too!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 40)
Marry and amen!--Give me a cup of sack, boy.--Ere lead this life long, I'll sew netherstocks and mend them, and foot them too.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 41)
plague of all cowards!--Give me a cup of sack, rogue!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 42)
--Is there no virtue extant?  Didst thou never see Titan kiss a dish of butter--pitiful-hearted Titan!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 43)
--that melted at the sweet tale of the sun's? If thou didst, then behold that compound.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 44)
You rogue, here's lime in this sack too.--There is nothing but roguery to be found in villainous man, yet a coward is worse than a cup of sack with lime in it.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 45)
villainous coward! Go thy ways, old Jack. Die when thou wilt.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 46)
If manhood, good manhood, be not forgot upon the face of the Earth, then am a shotten herring.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 47)
There lives not three good men unhanged in England, and one of them is fat and grows old, God help the while.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 48)
bad world, say. would were a weaver. could sing psalms, or anything.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 49)
plague of all cowards, say still.  How now, woolsack, what mutter you?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 50)
king's son! If do not beat thee out of thy kingdom with a dagger of lath, and drive all thy subjects afore thee like a flock of wild geese, I'll never wear hair on my face more.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 51)
You, Prince of Wales!  Why, you whoreson round man, what's the matter?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 52)
Are not you a coward? Answer me to that-- and Poins there?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 53)
Zounds, you fat paunch, an you call me coward, by the Lord, I'll stab thee.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 54)
call thee coward? I'll see thee damned ere call thee coward, but would give a thousand pound could run as fast as thou canst.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 55)
You are straight enough in the shoulders you care not who sees your back.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 56)
Call you that backing of your friends? plague upon such backing!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 57)
Give me them that will face me.--Give me a cup of sack.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 58)
--I am a rogue if drunk today.  villain, thy lips are scarce wiped since thou drunk'st last.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 59)
All is one for that.  plague of all cowards, still say  What's the matter?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 60)
What's the matter? There be four of us here have ta'en a thousand pound this day morning.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 61)
Where is it, Jack, where is it?  Where is it? Taken from us it is.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 62)
hundred upon poor four of us.  What, a hundred, man?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 63)
am a rogue if were not at half-sword with a dozen of them two hours together.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 64)
have 'scaped by miracle. am eight times thrust through the doublet, four through the hose, my buckler cut through and through, my sword hacked like a handsaw.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 65)
Ecce signum! never dealt better since was a man. All would not do.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 66)
plague of all cowards! Let them speak. If they speak more or less than truth, they are villains, and the sons of darkness.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 67)
Speak, sirs, how was it?  We four set upon some dozen.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 68)
Sixteen at least, my lord.  And bound them.  No, no, they were not bound.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 69)
You rogue, they were bound, every man of them, or am a Jew else, an Ebrew Jew.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 70)
As we were sharing, some six or seven fresh men set upon us.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 71)
And unbound the rest, and then come in the other.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 72)
What, fought you with them all?  All? know not what you call all, but if fought not with fifty of them am a bunch of radish.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 73)
If there were not two- or three-and-fifty upon poor old Jack, then am no two-legged creature.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 74)
Pray God you have not murdered some of them.  Nay, that's past praying for.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 75)
have peppered two of them. Two am sure have paid, two rogues in buckram suits.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 76)
tell thee what, Hal, if tell thee a lie, spit in my face, call me horse.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 77)
Thou knowest my old ward. Here lay, and thus bore my point.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 78)
Four rogues in buckram let drive at me.  What, four?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 79)
Thou said'st but two even now.  Four, Hal, told thee four.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 80)
Ay, ay, he said four.  These four came all afront, and mainly thrust at me.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 81)
made me no more ado, but took all their seven points in my target, thus.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 82)
Seven? Why there were but four even now.  In buckram?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 83)
Ay, four in buckram suits.  Seven by these hilts, or am a villain else.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 84)
Prithee, let him alone. We shall have more anon.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 85)
Dost thou hear me, Hal?  Ay, and mark thee too, Jack.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 86)
Do so, for it is worth the listening to. These nine in buckram that told thee of--  So, two more already.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 87)
Their points being broken--  Down fell their hose.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 88)
Began to give me ground, but followed me close, came in foot and hand, and, with a thought, seven of the eleven paid.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 89)
monstrous! Eleven buckram men grown out of two!  But as the devil would have it, three misbegotten knaves in Kendal green came at my back, and let drive at me, for it was so dark, Hal, that thou couldst not see thy hand.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 90)
These lies are like their father that begets them, gross as a mountain, open, palpable.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 91)
Why, thou claybrained guts, thou knotty-pated fool, thou whoreson, obscene, greasy tallow-catch--  What, art thou mad?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 92)
Art thou mad? Is not the truth the truth?  Why, how couldst thou know these men in Kendal green when it was so dark thou couldst not see thy hand?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 93)
Come, tell us your reason. What sayest thou to this?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 94)
Come, your reason, Jack, your reason.  What, upon compulsion?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 95)
Zounds, an were at the strappado or all the racks in the world, would not tell you on compulsion.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 96)
Give you a reason on compulsion? If reasons were as plentiful as blackberries, would give no man a reason upon compulsion,  I'll be no longer guilty of this sin.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 97)
This sanguine coward, this bed-presser, this horse-backbreaker, this huge hill of flesh--  'Sblood, you starveling, you elfskin, you dried neat's tongue, you bull's pizzle, you stockfish!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 98)
for breath to utter what is like thee! You tailor's yard, you sheath, you bowcase, you vile standing tuck--  Well, breathe awhile, and then to it again, and when thou hast tired thyself in base comparisons, hear me speak but this.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 99)
Mark, Jack.  We two saw you four set on four, and bound them and were masters of their wealth.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 100)
Mark now how a plain tale shall put you down. Then did we two set on you four and, with a word, outfaced you from your prize, and have it, yea, and can show it you here in the house.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 101)
And, Falstaff, you carried your guts away as nimbly, with as quick dexterity, and roared for mercy, and still run and roared, as ever heard bull-calf.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 102)
What a slave art thou to hack thy sword as thou hast done, and then say it was in fight!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 103)
What trick, what device, what starting-hole canst thou now find out to hide thee from this open and apparent shame?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 104)
Come, let's hear, Jack. What trick hast thou now?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 105)
By the Lord, knew you as well as he that made you.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 106)
Why, hear you, my masters, was it for me to kill the heir apparent?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 107)
Should turn upon the true prince? Why, thou knowest am as valiant as Hercules, but beware instinct.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 108)
The lion will not touch the true prince. Instinct is a great matter.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 109)
was now a coward on instinct. shall think the better of myself, and thee, during my life-- for a valiant lion, and thou for a true prince.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 110)
But, by the Lord, lads, am glad you have the money.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 111)
--Hostess, clap to the doors.--Watch tonight, pray tomorrow.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 112)
Gallants, lads, boys, hearts of gold, all the titles of good fellowship come to you.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 113)
What, shall we be merry? Shall we have a play extempore?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 114)
Content, and the argument shall be thy running away.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 115)
Ah, no more of that, Hal, an thou lovest me.     Jesu, my lord the Prince--  How now, my lady the hostess, what sayst thou to me?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 116)
Marry, my lord, there is a nobleman of the court at door would speak with you.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 117)
He says he comes from your father.  Give him as much as will make him a royal man and send him back again to my mother.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 118)
What manner of man is he?  An old man.  What doth Gravity out of his bed at midnight?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 119)
Shall give him his answer?  Prithee do, Jack.  Faith, and I'll send him packing.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 120)
Now, sirs.  By 'r Lady, you fought fair.--So did you, Peto.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 121)
--So did you, Bardolph.-- You are lions too. You ran away upon instinct.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 122)
You will not touch the true prince. No, fie!  Faith, ran when saw others run.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 123)
Faith, tell me now in earnest, how came Falstaff's sword so hacked?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 124)
Why, he hacked it with his dagger and said he would swear truth out of England but he would make you believe it was done in fight, and persuaded us to do the like.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 125)
Yea, and to tickle our noses with speargrass to make them bleed, and then to beslubber our garments with it, and swear it was the blood of true men.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 126)
did that did not this seven year before: blushed to hear his monstrous devices.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 127)
villain, thou stolest a cup of sack eighteen years ago, and wert taken with the manner, and ever since thou hast blushed extempore.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 128)
Thou hadst fire and sword on thy side, and yet thou ran'st away.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 129)
What instinct hadst thou for it?  My lord, do you see these meteors?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 130)
Do you behold these exhalations?  do.  What think you they portend?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 131)
Hot livers and cold purses.  Choler, my lord, if rightly taken.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 132)
No. If rightly taken, halter.    Here comes lean Jack.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 133)
Here comes bare-bone.-- How now, my sweet creature of bombast?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 134)
How long is 't ago, Jack, since thou sawest thine own knee?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 135)
My own knee? When was about thy years, Hal, was not an eagle's talon in the waist.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 136)
could have crept into any alderman's thumb-ring. plague of sighing and grief!(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 137)
It blows a man up like a bladder. There's villainous news abroad.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 138)
Here was Sir John Bracy from your father. You must to the court in the morning.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 139)
That same mad fellow of the north, Percy, and he of Wales that gave Amamon the bastinado, and made Lucifer cuckold, and swore the devil his true liegeman upon the cross of a Welsh hook--what a plague call you him?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 140)
Owen Glendower.  Owen, Owen, the same, and his son-in-law Mortimer, and old Northumberland, and that sprightly Scot of Scots, Douglas, that runs a-horseback up a hill perpendicular--  He that rides at high speed, and with his pistol kills a sparrow flying.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 141)
You have hit it.  So did he never the sparrow.  Well, that rascal hath good mettle in him.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 142)
He will not run.  Why, what a rascal art thou then to praise him so for running?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 143)
A-horseback, you cuckoo, but afoot he will not budge a foot.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 144)
Yes, Jack, upon instinct.  grant you, upon instinct.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 145)
Well, he is there too, and one Mordake, and a thousand blue-caps more.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 146)
Worcester is stolen away tonight. Thy father's beard is turned white with the news.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 147)
You may buy land now as cheap as stinking mackerel.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 148)
Why then, it is like if there come a hot June, and this civil buffeting hold, we shall buy maidenheads as they buy hobnails, by the hundreds.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 149)
By the Mass, thou sayest true. It is like we shall have good trading that way.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 150)
But tell me, Hal, art not thou horrible afeard? Thou being heir apparent, could the world pick thee out three such enemies again as that fiend Douglas, that spirit Percy, and that devil Glendower?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 151)
Art thou not horribly afraid? Doth not thy blood thrill at it?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 152)
Not a whit, i' faith. lack some of thy instinct.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 153)
Well, thou wilt be horribly chid tomorrow when thou comest to thy father.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 154)
If thou love me, practice an answer.  Do thou stand for my father and examine me upon the particulars of my life.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 155)
Shall Content.  This chair shall be my state, this dagger my scepter, and this cushion my crown.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 156)
Thy state is taken for a joined stool, thy golden scepter for a leaden dagger, and thy precious rich crown for a pitiful bald crown.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 157)
Well, an the fire of grace be not quite out of thee, now shalt thou be moved.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 158)
--Give me a cup of sack to make my eyes look red, that it may be thought have wept, for must speak in passion, and will do it in King Cambyses' vein.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 159)
Well, here is my leg.  And here is my speech.  Stand aside, nobility.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 160)
Jesu, this is excellent sport, i' faith!   Weep not, sweet queen, for trickling tears are vain.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 161)
the Father, how he holds his countenance!   For God's sake, lords, convey my tristful queen, For tears do stop the floodgates of her eyes.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 162)
Jesu, he doth it as like one of these harlotry players as ever see.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 163)
Peace, good pint-pot. Peace, good tickle-brain.-- Harry, do not only marvel where thou spendest thy time, but also how thou art accompanied.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 164)
For though the camomile, the more it is trodden on, the faster it grows, so youth, the more it is wasted, the sooner it wears.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 165)
That thou art my son have partly thy mother's word, partly my own opinion, but chiefly a villainous trick of thine eye and a foolish hanging of thy nether lip that doth warrant me.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 166)
If then thou be son to me, here lies the point: why, being son to me, art thou so pointed at?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 167)
Shall the blessed sun of heaven prove a micher and eat blackberries?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 168)
question not to be asked. Shall the son of England prove a thief and take purses?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 169)
question to be asked. There is a thing, Harry, which thou hast often heard of, and it is known to many in our land by the name of pitch.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 170)
This pitch, as ancient writers do report, doth defile; so doth the company thou keepest.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 171)
For, Harry, now do not speak to thee in drink, but in tears; not in pleasure, but in passion; not in words only, but in woes also.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 172)
And yet there is a virtuous man whom have often noted in thy company, but know not his name.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 173)
What manner of man, an it like your Majesty?  goodly portly man, i' faith, and a corpulent; of a cheerful look, a pleasing eye, and a most noble carriage, and, as think, his age some fifty, or, by 'r Lady, inclining to threescore; and now remember me, his name is Falstaff.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 174)
If that man should be lewdly given, he deceiveth me, for, Harry, see virtue in his looks.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 175)
If then the tree may be known by the fruit, as the fruit by the tree, then peremptorily speak it: there is virtue in that Falstaff; him keep with, the rest banish.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 176)
And tell me now, thou naughty varlet, tell me where hast thou been this month?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 177)
Dost thou speak like a king? Do thou stand for me, and I'll play my father.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 178)
Depose me? If thou dost it half so gravely, so majestically, both in word and matter, hang me up by the heels for a rabbit-sucker or a poulter's hare.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 179)
Well, here am set.  And here stand.--Judge, my masters.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 180)
Now, Harry, whence come you?  My noble lord, from Eastcheap.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 181)
The complaints hear of thee are grievous.  'Sblood, my lord, they are false.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 182)
--Nay, I'll tickle you for a young prince, i' faith.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 183)
Swearest thou? Ungracious boy, henceforth ne'er look on me.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 184)
Thou art violently carried away from grace. There is a devil haunts thee in the likeness of an old fat man.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 185)
tun of man is thy companion. Why dost thou converse with that trunk of humors, that bolting-hutch of beastliness, that swollen parcel of dropsies, that huge bombard of sack, that stuffed cloakbag of guts, that roasted Manningtree ox with the pudding in his belly, that reverend Vice, that gray iniquity, that father ruffian, that vanity in years?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 186)
Wherein is he good, but to taste sack and drink it?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 187)
Wherein neat and cleanly but to carve a capon and eat it?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 188)
Wherein cunning but in craft? Wherein crafty but in villainy?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 189)
Wherein villainous but in all things? Wherein worthy but in nothing?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 190)
would your Grace would take me with you. Whom means your Grace?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 191)
That villainous abominable misleader of youth, Falstaff, that old white-bearded Satan.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 192)
My lord, the man know.  know thou dost.  But to say know more harm in him than in myself were to say more than know.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 193)
That he is old, the more the pity; his white hairs do witness it.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 194)
But that he is, saving your reverence, a whoremaster, that utterly deny.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 195)
If sack and sugar be a fault, God help the wicked.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 196)
If to be old and merry be a sin, then many an old host that know is damned.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 197)
If to be fat be to be hated, then Pharaoh's lean kine are to be loved.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 198)
No, my good lord, banish Peto, banish Bardolph, banish Poins, but for sweet Jack Falstaff, kind Jack Falstaff, true Jack Falstaff, valiant Jack Falstaff, and therefore more valiant being as he is old Jack Falstaff, banish not him thy Harry's company, banish not him thy Harry's company.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 199)
Banish plump Jack, and banish all the world.  do, will.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 200)
loud knocking, and Bardolph, Hostess, and      my lord, my lord, the Sheriff with a most monstrous watch is at the door.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 201)
Out, you rogue.--Play out the play. have much to say in the behalf of that Falstaff.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 202)
Jesu, my lord, my lord--  Heigh, heigh, the devil rides upon a fiddlestick.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 203)
What's the matter?  The Sheriff and all the watch are at the door.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 204)
They are come to search the house. Shall let them in?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 205)
Dost thou hear, Hal? Never call a true piece of gold a counterfeit.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 206)
Thou art essentially made without seeming so.  And thou a natural coward without instinct.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 207)
deny your major. If you will deny the Sheriff, so; if not, let him enter.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 208)
If become not a cart as well as another man, a plague on my bringing up.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 209)
hope shall as soon be strangled with a halter as another.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 210)
Go hide thee behind the arras. The rest walk up above.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 211)
--Now, my masters, for a true face and good conscience.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 212)
Both which have had, but their date is out; and therefore I'll hide me.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 213)
Call in the Sheriff.       Now, Master Sheriff, what is your will with me?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 214)
First pardon me, my lord. hue and cry Hath followed certain men unto this house.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 215)
What men?   One of them is well known, my gracious lord.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 216)
gross fat man.  As fat as butter.   The man do assure you is not here, For myself at this time have employed him.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 217)
And, sheriff, will engage my word to thee That will by tomorrow dinner time Send him to answer thee or any man For anything he shall be charged withal.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 218)
And so let me entreat you leave the house.   will, my lord.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 219)
There are two gentlemen Have in this robbery lost three hundred marks.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 220)
It may be so. If he have robbed these men, He shall be answerable; and so farewell.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 221)
Good night, my noble lord.   think it is good morrow, is it not?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 222)
Indeed, my lord, think it be two o'clock.   This oily rascal is known as well as Paul's.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 223)
Go call him forth.  Falstaff!--Fast asleep behind the arras, and snorting like a horse.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 224)
Hark, how hard he fetches breath. Search his pockets.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 225)
What hast thou found?  Nothing but papers, my lord.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 226)
Let's see what they be. Read them.   Item, a capon,.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 227)
..2s. 2d. Item, sauce,...4d. Item, sack, two gallons,.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 228)
..5s. 8d. Item, anchovies and sack after supper,..(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 229)
.2s. 6d. Item, bread,...ob.  monstrous! But one halfpennyworth of bread to this intolerable deal of sack?(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 230)
What there is else, keep close. We'll read it at more advantage.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 231)
There let him sleep till day. I'll to the court in the morning.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 232)
We must all to the wars, and thy place shall be honorable.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 233)
I'll procure this fat rogue a charge of foot, and know his death will be a march of twelve score.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 234)
The money shall be paid back again with advantage.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 235)
Be with me betimes in the morning, and so good morrow, Peto.(Henry IV, Part I, Act 3, Scene 236)
Sirs, take your places and be vigilant. If any noise or soldier you perceive Near to the walls, by some apparent sign Let us have knowledge at the court of guard.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 0)
Sergeant, you shall. Thus are poor servitors, When others sleep upon their quiet beds, Constrained to watch in darkness, rain, and cold.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 1)
Lord Regent, and redoubted Burgundy, By whose approach the regions of Artois, Walloon, and Picardy are friends to us, This happy night the Frenchmen are secure, Having all day caroused and banqueted.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 2)
Embrace we then this opportunity, As fitting best to quittance their deceit Contrived by art and baleful sorcery.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 3)
Coward of France, how much he wrongs his fame, Despairing of his own arm's fortitude, To join with witches and the help of hell!(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 4)
Traitors have never other company. But what's that Pucelle whom they term so pure?(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 5)
maid, they say.  maid? And be so martial?   Pray God she prove not masculine ere long, If underneath the standard of the French She carry armor as she hath begun.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 6)
Well, let them practice and converse with spirits.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 7)
God is our fortress, in whose conquering name Let us resolve to scale their flinty bulwarks.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 8)
Ascend, brave Talbot. We will follow thee.   Not all together.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 9)
Better far, guess, That we do make our entrance several ways, That if it chance the one of us do fail, The other yet may rise against their force.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 10)
Agreed. I'll to yond corner.  And to this.   And here will Talbot mount, or make his grave.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 11)
Now, Salisbury, for thee and for the right Of English Henry, shall this night appear How much in duty am bound to both.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 12)
Arm, arm! The enemy doth make assault.         How now, my lords?(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 13)
What, all unready so?   Unready? Ay, and glad we scaped so well.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 14)
'Twas time, trow, to wake and leave our beds, Hearing alarums at our chamber doors.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 15)
Of all exploits since first followed arms Ne'er heard of a warlike enterprise More venturous or desperate than this.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 16)
think this Talbot be a fiend of hell.   If not of hell, the heavens sure favor him.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 17)
Here cometh Charles. marvel how he sped.      Tut, holy Joan was his defensive guard.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 18)
Is this thy cunning, thou deceitful dame? Didst thou at first, to flatter us withal, Make us partakers of a little gain That now our loss might be ten times so much?(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 19)
Wherefore is Charles impatient with his friend?(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 20)
At all times will you have my power alike? Sleeping or waking, must still prevail, Or will you blame and lay the fault on me?(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 21)
-- Improvident soldiers, had your watch been good, This sudden mischief never could have fall'n.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 22)
Duke of Alanson, this was your default, That, being captain of the watch tonight, Did look no better to that weighty charge.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 23)
Had all your quarters been as safely kept As that whereof had the government, We had not been thus shamefully surprised.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 24)
Mine was secure.  And so was mine, my lord.   And for myself, most part of all this night Within her quarter and mine own precinct was employed in passing to and fro About relieving of the sentinels.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 25)
Then how or which way should they first break in?(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 26)
Question, my lords, no further of the case, How or which way; 'tis sure they found some place But weakly guarded, where the breach was made.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 27)
And now there rests no other shift but this: To gather our soldiers, scattered and dispersed, And lay new platforms to endamage them.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 28)
Talbot, Talbot!" The French fly,     I'll be so bold to take what they have left.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 29)
The cry of "Talbot" serves me for a sword, For have loaden me with many spoils, Using no other weapon but his name.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 0, Scene 30)
The day begins to break and night is fled, Whose pitchy mantle over-veiled the Earth.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 1, Scene 0)
Here sound retreat and cease our hot pursuit.    Bring forth the body of old Salisbury, And here advance it in the marketplace, The middle center of this cursed town.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 1, Scene 1)
Now have paid my vow unto his soul: For every drop of blood was drawn from him There hath at least five Frenchmen died tonight.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 1, Scene 2)
And, that hereafter ages may behold What ruin happened in revenge of him, Within their chiefest temple I'll erect tomb wherein his corpse shall be interred, Upon the which, that everyone may read, Shall be engraved the sack of Orleance, The treacherous manner of his mournful death, And what a terror he had been to France.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 1, Scene 3)
But, lords, in all our bloody massacre, muse we met not with the Dauphin's grace, His new-come champion, virtuous Joan of Arc, Nor any of his false confederates.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 1, Scene 4)
'Tis thought, Lord Talbot, when the fight began, Roused on the sudden from their drowsy beds, They did amongst the troops of armed men Leap o'er the walls for refuge in the field.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 1, Scene 5)
Myself, as far as could well discern For smoke and dusky vapors of the night, Am sure scared the Dauphin and his trull, When arm-in-arm they both came swiftly running, Like to a pair of loving turtledoves That could not live asunder day or night.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 1, Scene 6)
After that things are set in order here, We'll follow them with all the power we have.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 1, Scene 7)
All hail, my lords. Which of this princely train Call you the warlike Talbot, for his acts So much applauded through the realm of France?(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 1, Scene 8)
Here is the Talbot. Who would speak with him?   The virtuous lady, Countess of Auvergne, With modesty admiring thy renown, By me entreats, great lord, thou wouldst vouchsafe To visit her poor castle where she lies, That she may boast she hath beheld the man Whose glory fills the world with loud report.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 1, Scene 9)
Is it even so? Nay, then, see our wars Will turn unto a peaceful comic sport, When ladies crave to be encountered with.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 1, Scene 10)
You may not, my lord, despise her gentle suit.   Ne'er trust me, then; for when a world of men Could not prevail with all their oratory, Yet hath a woman's kindness overruled.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 1, Scene 11)
-- And therefore tell her return great thanks, And in submission will attend on her.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 1, Scene 12)
-- Will not your Honors bear me company?   No, truly, 'tis more than manners will; And have heard it said unbidden guests Are often welcomest when they are gone.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 1, Scene 13)
Well then, alone, since there's no remedy, mean to prove this lady's courtesy.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 1, Scene 14)
-- Come hither, captain. You perceive my mind?   do, my lord, and mean accordingly.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 1, Scene 15)
Porter, remember what gave in charge, And when you have done so, bring the keys to me.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 0)
Madam, will.   The plot is laid. If all things fall out right, shall as famous be by this exploit As Scythian Tamyris by Cyrus' death.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 1)
Great is the rumor of this dreadful knight, And his achievements of no less account.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 2)
Fain would mine eyes be witness with mine ears To give their censure of these rare reports.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 3)
Madam, according as your Ladyship desired, By message craved, so is Lord Talbot come.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 4)
And he is welcome. What, is this the man?   Madam, it is.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 5)
Is this the scourge of France? Is this the Talbot, so much feared abroad That with his name the mothers still their babes?(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 6)
see report is fabulous and false. thought should have seen some Hercules, second Hector, for his grim aspect And large proportion of his strong-knit limbs.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 7)
Alas, this is a child, a silly dwarf! It cannot be this weak and writhled shrimp Should strike such terror to his enemies.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 8)
Madam, have been bold to trouble you. But since your Ladyship is not at leisure, I'll sort some other time to visit you.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 9)
What means he now? Go ask him whither he goes.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 10)
Stay, my Lord Talbot, for my lady craves To know the cause of your abrupt departure.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 11)
Marry, for that she's in a wrong belief, go to certify her Talbot's here.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 12)
If thou be he, then art thou prisoner.   Prisoner?(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 13)
To whom?  To me, bloodthirsty lord. And for that cause trained thee to my house.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 14)
Long time thy shadow hath been thrall to me, For in my gallery thy picture hangs.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 15)
But now the substance shall endure the like, And will chain these legs and arms of thine, That hast by tyranny these many years Wasted our country, slain our citizens, And sent our sons and husbands captivate.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 16)
Ha, ha, ha!   Laughest thou, wretch? Thy mirth shall turn to moan.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 17)
laugh to see your Ladyship so fond To think that you have aught but Talbot's shadow Whereon to practice your severity.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 18)
Why, art not thou the man?  am, indeed.  Then have substance too.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 19)
No, no, am but shadow of myself. You are deceived; my substance is not here, For what you see is but the smallest part And least proportion of humanity.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 20)
tell you, madam, were the whole frame here, It is of such a spacious lofty pitch Your roof were not sufficient to contain 't.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 21)
This is a riddling merchant for the nonce: He will be here and yet he is not here.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 22)
How can these contrarieties agree?   That will show you presently.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 23)
How say you, madam? Are you now persuaded That Talbot is but shadow of himself?(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 24)
These are his substance, sinews, arms, and strength, With which he yoketh your rebellious necks, Razeth your cities, and subverts your towns, And in a moment makes them desolate.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 25)
Victorious Talbot, pardon my abuse. find thou art no less than fame hath bruited, And more than may be gathered by thy shape.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 26)
Let my presumption not provoke thy wrath, For am sorry that with reverence did not entertain thee as thou art.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 27)
Be not dismayed, fair lady, nor misconster The mind of Talbot as you did mistake The outward composition of his body.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 28)
What you have done hath not offended me, Nor other satisfaction do crave But only, with your patience, that we may Taste of your wine and see what cates you have, For soldiers' stomachs always serve them well.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 29)
With all my heart, and think me honored To feast so great a warrior in my house.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 2, Scene 30)
William de la Pole the Earl of Suffolk,     Great lords and gentlemen, what means this silence?(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 0)
Dare no man answer in a case of truth?   Within the Temple Hall we were too loud; The garden here is more convenient.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 1)
Then say at once if maintained the truth, Or else was wrangling Somerset in th' error?(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 2)
Faith, have been a truant in the law And never yet could frame my will to it, And therefore frame the law unto my will.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 3)
Judge you, my Lord of Warwick, then, between us.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 4)
Between two hawks, which flies the higher pitch, Between two dogs, which hath the deeper mouth, Between two blades, which bears the better temper, Between two horses, which doth bear him best, Between two girls, which hath the merriest eye, have perhaps some shallow spirit of judgment; But in these nice sharp quillets of the law, Good faith, am no wiser than a daw.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 5)
Tut, tut, here is a mannerly forbearance! The truth appears so naked on my side That any purblind eye may find it out.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 6)
And on my side it is so well appareled, So clear, so shining, and so evident, That it will glimmer through a blind man's eye.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 7)
Since you are tongue-tied and so loath to speak, In dumb significants proclaim your thoughts: Let him that is a trueborn gentleman And stands upon the honor of his birth, If he suppose that have pleaded truth, From off this brier pluck a white rose with me.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 8)
Let him that is no coward nor no flatterer, But dare maintain the party of the truth, Pluck a red rose from off this thorn with me.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 9)
love no colors; and, without all color Of base insinuating flattery, pluck this white rose with Plantagenet.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 10)
pluck this red rose with young Somerset, And say withal think he held the right.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 11)
Stay, lords and gentlemen, and pluck no more Till you conclude that he upon whose side The fewest roses are cropped from the tree Shall yield the other in the right opinion.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 12)
Good Master Vernon, it is well objected: If have fewest, subscribe in silence.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 13)
And   Then for the truth and plainness of the case, pluck this pale and maiden blossom here, Giving my verdict on the white rose side.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 14)
Prick not your finger as you pluck it off, Lest, bleeding, you do paint the white rose red, And fall on my side so against your will.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 15)
If my lord, for my opinion bleed, Opinion shall be surgeon to my hurt And keep me on the side where still am.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 16)
Well, well, come on, who else?   Unless my study and my books be false, The argument you held was wrong in law, In sign whereof pluck a white rose too.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 17)
Now, Somerset, where is your argument?   Here in my scabbard, meditating that Shall dye your white rose in a bloody red.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 18)
Meantime your cheeks do counterfeit our roses, For pale they look with fear, as witnessing The truth on our side.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 19)
No, Plantagenet. 'Tis not for fear, but anger that thy cheeks Blush for pure shame to counterfeit our roses, And yet thy tongue will not confess thy error.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 20)
Hath not thy rose a canker, Somerset?   Hath not thy rose a thorn, Plantagenet?(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 21)
Ay, sharp and piercing, to maintain his truth, Whiles thy consuming canker eats his falsehood.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 22)
Well, I'll find friends to wear my bleeding roses That shall maintain what have said is true, Where false Plantagenet dare not be seen.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 23)
Now, by this maiden blossom in my hand, scorn thee and thy fashion, peevish boy.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 24)
Turn not thy scorns this way, Plantagenet.   Proud Pole, will, and scorn both him and thee.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 25)
I'll turn my part thereof into thy throat.   Away, away, good William de la Pole!(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 26)
We grace the yeoman by conversing with him.   Now, by God's will, thou wrong'st him, Somerset.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 27)
His grandfather was Lionel, Duke of Clarence, Third son to the third Edward, King of England.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 28)
Spring crestless yeomen from so deep a root?   He bears him on the place's privilege, Or durst not for his craven heart say thus.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 29)
By Him that made me, I'll maintain my words On any plot of ground in Christendom.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 30)
Was not thy father Richard, Earl of Cambridge, For treason executed in our late king's days?(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 31)
And, by his treason, stand'st not thou attainted, Corrupted, and exempt from ancient gentry?(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 32)
His trespass yet lives guilty in thy blood, And, till thou be restored, thou art a yeoman.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 33)
My father was attached, not attainted, Condemned to die for treason, but no traitor; And that I'll prove on better men than Somerset, Were growing time once ripened to my will.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 34)
For your partaker Pole and you yourself, I'll note you in my book of memory To scourge you for this apprehension.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 35)
Look to it well, and say you are well warned.   Ah, thou shalt find us ready for thee still, And know us by these colors for thy foes, For these my friends in spite of thee shall wear.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 36)
And, by my soul, this pale and angry rose, As cognizance of my blood-drinking hate, Will forever, and my faction, wear Until it wither with me to my grave Or flourish to the height of my degree.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 37)
Go forward, and be choked with thy ambition! And so farewell, until meet thee next.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 38)
Have with thee, Pole.--Farewell, ambitious Richard.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 39)
How am braved, and must perforce endure it!   This blot that they object against your house Shall be whipped out in the next parliament, Called for the truce of Winchester and Gloucester; And if thou be not then created York, will not live to be accounted Warwick.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 40)
Meantime, in signal of my love to thee, Against proud Somerset and William Pole Will upon thy party wear this rose.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 41)
And here prophesy: this brawl today, Grown to this faction in the Temple garden, Shall send, between the red rose and the white, thousand souls to death and deadly night.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 42)
Good Master Vernon, am bound to you, That you on my behalf would pluck a flower.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 43)
In your behalf still will wear the same.   And so will  Thanks, gentle sir.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 44)
Come, let us four to dinner. dare say This quarrel will drink blood another day.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 3, Scene 45)
Kind keepers of my weak decaying age, Let dying Mortimer here rest himself.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 0)
Even like a man new-haled from the rack, So fare my limbs with long imprisonment; And these gray locks, the pursuivants of death, Nestor-like aged in an age of care, Argue the end of Edmund Mortimer; These eyes, like lamps whose wasting oil is spent, Wax dim, as drawing to their exigent; Weak shoulders, overborne with burdening grief, And pithless arms, like to a withered vine That droops his sapless branches to the ground; Yet are these feet, whose strengthless stay is numb, Unable to support this lump of clay, Swift-winged with desire to get a grave, As witting no other comfort have.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 1)
But tell me, keeper, will my nephew come?   Richard Plantagenet, my lord, will come.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 2)
We sent unto the Temple, unto his chamber, And answer was returned that he will come.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 3)
Enough. My soul shall then be satisfied. Poor gentleman, his wrong doth equal mine.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 4)
