Since Henry Monmouth first began to reign, Before whose glory was great in arms, This loathsome sequestration have had; And even since then hath Richard been obscured, Deprived of honor and inheritance.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 5)
But now the arbitrator of despairs, Just Death, kind umpire of men's miseries, With sweet enlargement doth dismiss me hence.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 6)
would his troubles likewise were expired, That so he might recover what was lost.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 7)
My lord, your loving nephew now is come.   Richard Plantagenet, my friend, is he come?(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 8)
Ay, noble uncle, thus ignobly used, Your nephew, late despised Richard, comes.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 9)
Direct mine arms may embrace his neck And in his bosom spend my latter gasp.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 10)
tell me when my lips do touch his cheeks, That may kindly give one fainting kiss.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 11)
And now declare, sweet stem from York's great stock, Why didst thou say of late thou wert despised?(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 12)
First, lean thine aged back against mine arm, And in that ease I'll tell thee my disease.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 13)
This day, in argument upon a case, Some words there grew 'twixt Somerset and me, Among which terms he used his lavish tongue And did upbraid me with my father's death; Which obloquy set bars before my tongue, Else with the like had requited him.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 14)
Therefore, good uncle, for my father's sake, In honor of a true Plantagenet, And for alliance' sake, declare the cause My father, Earl of Cambridge, lost his head.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 15)
That cause, fair nephew, that imprisoned me And hath detained me all my flow'ring youth Within a loathsome dungeon, there to pine, Was cursed instrument of his decease.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 16)
Discover more at large what cause that was, For am ignorant and cannot guess.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 17)
will, if that my fading breath permit And death approach not ere my tale be done.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 18)
Henry the Fourth, grandfather to this king, Deposed his nephew Richard, Edward's son, The first begotten and the lawful heir Of Edward king, the third of that descent; During whose reign the Percies of the north, Finding his usurpation most unjust, Endeavored my advancement to the throne.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 19)
The reason moved these warlike lords to this Was, for that--young Richard thus removed, Leaving no heir begotten of his body-- was the next by birth and parentage; For by my mother derived am From Lionel, Duke of Clarence, third son To King Edward the Third; whereas he From John of Gaunt doth bring his pedigree, Being but fourth of that heroic line.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 20)
But mark: as in this haughty great attempt They labored to plant the rightful heir, lost my liberty and they their lives.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 21)
Long after this, when Henry the Fifth, Succeeding his father Bolingbroke, did reign, Thy father, Earl of Cambridge then, derived From famous Edmund Langley, Duke of York, Marrying my sister that thy mother was, Again, in pity of my hard distress, Levied an army, weening to redeem And have installed me in the diadem.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 22)
But, as the rest, so fell that noble earl And was beheaded.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 23)
Thus the Mortimers, In whom the title rested, were suppressed.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 24)
Of which, my lord, your Honor is the last.   True, and thou seest that no issue have And that my fainting words do warrant death.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 25)
Thou art my heir; the rest wish thee gather. But yet be wary in thy studious care.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 26)
Thy grave admonishments prevail with me. But yet methinks my father's execution Was nothing less than bloody tyranny.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 27)
With silence, nephew, be thou politic; Strong-fixed is the house of Lancaster, And, like a mountain, not to be removed.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 28)
But now thy uncle is removing hence, As princes do their courts when they are cloyed With long continuance in a settled place.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 29)
uncle, would some part of my young years Might but redeem the passage of your age.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 30)
Thou dost then wrong me, as that slaughterer doth Which giveth many wounds when one will kill.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 31)
Mourn not, except thou sorrow for my good; Only give order for my funeral.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 32)
And so farewell, and fair be all thy hopes, And prosperous be thy life in peace and war.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 33)
And peace, no war, befall thy parting soul. In prison hast thou spent a pilgrimage, And like a hermit overpassed thy days.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 34)
-- Well, will lock his counsel in my breast, And what do imagine, let that rest.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 35)
-- Keepers, convey him hence, and myself Will see his burial better than his life.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 36)
Here dies the dusky torch of Mortimer, Choked with ambition of the meaner sort.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 37)
And for those wrongs, those bitter injuries, Which Somerset hath offered to my house, doubt not but with honor to redress.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 38)
And therefore haste to the Parliament, Either to be restored to my blood, Or make mine ill th' advantage of my good.(Henry VI, Part 1, Act 4, Scene 39)
Master Fang, have you entered the action?  It is entered.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 0)
Where's your yeoman? Is 't a lusty yeoman? Will he stand to 't?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 1)
Sirrah! Where's Snare?  Lord, ay, good Master Snare.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 2)
Here, here.  Snare, we must arrest Sir John Falstaff.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 3)
Yea, good Master Snare, have entered him and all.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 4)
It may chance cost some of us our lives, for he will stab.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 5)
Alas the day, take heed of him. He stabbed me in mine own house, and that most beastly, in good faith.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 6)
He cares not what mischief he does. If his weapon be out, he will foin like any devil.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 7)
He will spare neither man, woman, nor child.  If can close with him, care not for his thrust.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 8)
No, nor neither. I'll be at your elbow.  An but fist him once, an he come but within my view--  am undone by his going.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 9)
warrant you, he's an infinitive thing upon my score.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 10)
Good Master Fang, hold him sure. Good Master Snare, let him not 'scape.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 11)
He comes continuantly to Pie Corner, saving your manhoods, to buy a saddle, and he is indited to dinner to the Lubber's Head in Lumbert Street, to Master Smooth's the silkman.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 12)
pray you, since my exion is entered, and my case so openly known to the world, let him be brought in to his answer.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 13)
hundred mark is a long one for a poor lone woman to bear, and have borne, and borne, and borne, and have been fubbed off, and fubbed off, and fubbed off from this day to that day, that it is a shame to be thought on.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 14)
There is no honesty in such dealing, unless a woman should be made an ass and a beast to bear every knave's wrong.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 15)
Yonder he comes, and that arrant malmsey-nose knave, Bardolph, with him.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 16)
Do your offices, do your offices, Master Fang and Master Snare, do me, do me, do me your offices.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 17)
How now, whose mare's dead? What's the matter?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 18)
Sir John, arrest you at the suit of Mistress Quickly.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 19)
Away, varlets!--Draw, Bardolph. Cut me off the villain's head.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 20)
Throw the quean in the channel.  Throw me in the channel?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 21)
I'll throw thee in the channel. Wilt thou, wilt thou, thou bastardly rogue?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 22)
--Murder, murder!--Ah, thou honeysuckle villain, wilt thou kill God's officers and the King's?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 23)
Ah, thou honeyseed rogue, thou art a honeyseed, a man-queller, and a woman-queller.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 24)
Keep them off, Bardolph.  rescue, a rescue!  Good people, bring a rescue or two.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 25)
--Thou wot, wot thou? Thou wot, wot ta? Do, do, thou rogue.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 26)
Do, thou hempseed.  Away, you scullion, you rampallian, you fustilarian!(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 27)
I'll tickle your catastrophe.      What is the matter?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 28)
Keep the peace here, ho!  Good my lord, be good to me.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 29)
beseech you stand to me.   How now, Sir John? What, are you brawling here?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 30)
Doth this become your place, your time, and business?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 31)
You should have been well on your way to York.-- Stand from him, fellow.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 32)
Wherefore hang'st thou upon him?  my most worshipful lord, an 't please your Grace, am a poor widow of Eastcheap, and he is arrested at my suit.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 33)
For what sum?  It is more than for some, my lord; it is for all have.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 34)
He hath eaten me out of house and home. He hath put all my substance into that fat belly of his.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 35)
But will have some of it out again, or will ride thee o' nights like the mare.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 36)
think am as like to ride the mare if have any vantage of ground to get up.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 37)
How comes this, Sir John? Fie, what man of good temper would endure this tempest of exclamation?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 38)
Are you not ashamed to enforce a poor widow to so rough a course to come by her own?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 39)
What is the gross sum that owe thee?  Marry, if thou wert an honest man, thyself and the money too.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 40)
Thou didst swear to me upon a parcel-gilt goblet, sitting in my Dolphin chamber at the round table by a sea-coal fire, upon Wednesday in Wheeson week, when the Prince broke thy head for liking his father to a singing-man of Windsor, thou didst swear to me then, as was washing thy wound, to marry me and make me my lady thy wife.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 41)
Canst thou deny it? Did not Goodwife Keech, the butcher's wife, come in then and call me Gossip Quickly, coming in to borrow a mess of vinegar, telling us she had a good dish of prawns, whereby thou didst desire to eat some, whereby told thee they were ill for a green wound?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 42)
And didst thou not, when she was gone downstairs, desire me to be no more so familiarity with such poor people, saying that ere long they should call me madam?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 43)
And didst thou not kiss me and bid me fetch thee thirty shillings?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 44)
put thee now to thy book-oath. Deny it if thou canst.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 45)
My lord, this is a poor mad soul, and she says up and down the town that her eldest son is like you.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 46)
She hath been in good case, and the truth is, poverty hath distracted her.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 47)
But, for these foolish officers, beseech you may have redress against them.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 48)
Sir John, Sir John, am well acquainted with your manner of wrenching the true cause the false way.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 49)
It is not a confident brow, nor the throng of words that come with such more than impudent sauciness from you, can thrust me from a level consideration.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 50)
You have, as it appears to me, practiced upon the easy-yielding spirit of this woman, and made her serve your uses both in purse and in person.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 51)
Yea, in truth, my lord.  Pray thee, peace.--Pay her the debt you owe her, and unpay the villainy you have done with her.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 52)
The one you may do with sterling money, and the other with current repentance.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 53)
My lord, will not undergo this sneap without reply.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 54)
You call honorable boldness "impudent sauciness." If a man will make curtsy and say nothing, he is virtuous.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 55)
No, my lord, my humble duty remembered, will not be your suitor.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 56)
say to you, do desire deliverance from these officers, being upon hasty employment in the King's affairs.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 57)
You speak as having power to do wrong; but answer in th' effect of your reputation, and satisfy the poor woman.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 58)
Come hither, hostess.      Now, Master Gower, what news?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 59)
The King, my lord, and Harry Prince of Wales Are near at hand.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 60)
The rest the paper tells.   As am a gentleman!  Faith, you said so before.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 61)
As am a gentleman. Come. No more words of it.  By this heavenly ground tread on, must be fain to pawn both my plate and the tapestry of my dining chambers.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 62)
Glasses, glasses, is the only drinking. And for thy walls, a pretty slight drollery, or the story of the Prodigal or the German hunting in waterwork is worth a thousand of these bed-hangers and these fly-bitten tapestries.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 63)
Let it be ten pound, if thou canst. Come, an 'twere not for thy humors, there's not a better wench in England.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 64)
Go wash thy face, and draw the action. Come, thou must not be in this humor with me.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 65)
Dost not know me? Come, come. know thou wast set on to this.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 66)
Pray thee, Sir John, let it be but twenty nobles.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 67)
faith, am loath to pawn my plate, so God save me, la.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 68)
Let it alone. I'll make other shift. You'll be a fool still.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 69)
Well, you shall have it, though pawn my gown. hope you'll come to supper.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 70)
You'll pay me all together?  Will live?  Go with her, with her.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 71)
Hook on, hook on.  Will you have Doll Tearsheet meet you at supper?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 72)
No more words. Let's have her.    have heard better news.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 73)
What's the news, my good lord?  Where lay the King tonight?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 74)
At Basingstoke, my lord.  hope, my lord, all's well.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 75)
What is the news, my lord?  Come all his forces back?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 76)
No. Fifteen hundred foot, five hundred horse Are marched up to my Lord of Lancaster Against Northumberland and the Archbishop.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 77)
Comes the King back from Wales, my noble lord?   You shall have letters of me presently.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 78)
Come. Go along with me, good Master Gower.  My lord!(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 79)
What's the matter?  Master Gower, shall entreat you with me to dinner?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 80)
must wait upon my good lord here. thank you, good Sir John.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 81)
Sir John, you loiter here too long, being you are to take soldiers up in counties as you go.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 82)
Will you sup with me, Master Gower?  What foolish master taught you these manners, Sir John?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 83)
Master Gower, if they become me not, he was a fool that taught them me.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 84)
--This is the right fencing grace, my lord: tap for tap, and so part fair.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 85)
Now the Lord lighten thee. Thou art a great fool.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 86)
Before God, am exceeding weary.  Is 't come to that?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 0)
had thought weariness durst not have attached one of so high blood.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 1)
Faith, it does me, though it discolors the complexion of my greatness to acknowledge it.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 2)
Doth it not show vilely in me to desire small beer?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 3)
Why, a prince should not be so loosely studied as to remember so weak a composition.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 4)
Belike then my appetite was not princely got, for, by my troth, do now remember the poor creature small beer.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 5)
But indeed these humble considerations make me out of love with my greatness.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 6)
What a disgrace is it to me to remember thy name, or to know thy face tomorrow, or to take note how many pair of silk stockings thou hast--with these, and those that were thy peach-colored ones--or to bear the inventory of thy shirts, as, one for superfluity and another for use.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 7)
But that the tennis-court keeper knows better than for it is a low ebb of linen with thee when thou keepest not racket there, as thou hast not done a great while, because the rest of the low countries have made a shift to eat up thy holland; and God knows whether those that bawl out the ruins of thy linen shall inherit His kingdom; but the midwives say the children are not in the fault, whereupon the world increases and kindreds are mightily strengthened.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 8)
How ill it follows, after you have labored so hard, you should talk so idly!(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 9)
Tell me, how many good young princes would do so, their fathers being so sick as yours at this time is?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 10)
Shall tell thee one thing, Poins?  Yes, faith, and let it be an excellent good thing.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 11)
It shall serve among wits of no higher breeding than thine.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 12)
Go to. stand the push of your one thing that you will tell.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 13)
Marry, tell thee it is not meet that should be sad, now my father is sick--albeit could tell to thee, as to one it pleases me, for fault of a better, to call my friend, could be sad, and sad indeed too.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 14)
Very hardly, upon such a subject.  By this hand, thou thinkest me as far in the devil's book as thou and Falstaff for obduracy and persistency.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 15)
Let the end try the man. But tell thee, my heart bleeds inwardly that my father is so sick; and keeping such vile company as thou art hath in reason taken from me all ostentation of sorrow.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 16)
The reason?  What wouldst thou think of me if should weep?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 17)
would think thee a most princely hypocrite.  It would be every man's thought, and thou art a blessed fellow to think as every man thinks.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 18)
Never a man's thought in the world keeps the roadway better than thine.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 19)
Every man would think me an hypocrite indeed. And what accites your most worshipful thought to think so?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 20)
Why, because you have been so lewd and so much engraffed to Falstaff.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 21)
And to thee.  By this light, am well spoke on. can hear it with mine own ears.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 22)
The worst that they can say of me is that am a second brother, and that am a proper fellow of my hands; and those two things, confess, cannot help.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 23)
By the Mass, here comes Bardolph.     And the boy that gave Falstaff.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 24)
He had him from me Christian, and look if the fat villain have not transformed him ape.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 25)
God save your Grace.  And yours, most noble Bardolph.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 26)
Come, you virtuous ass, you bashful fool, must you be blushing?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 27)
Wherefore blush you now? What a maidenly man-at-arms are you become!(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 28)
Is 't such a matter to get a pottle-pot's maidenhead?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 29)
He calls me e'en now, my lord, through a red lattice, and could discern no part of his face from the window.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 30)
At last spied his eyes, and methought he had made two holes in the ale-wife's new petticoat and so peeped through.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 31)
Has not the boy profited?  Away, you whoreson upright rabbit, away!(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 32)
Away, you rascally Althea's dream, away!  Instruct us, boy.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 33)
What dream, boy?  Marry, my lord, Althea dreamt she was delivered of a firebrand, and therefore call him her dream.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 34)
crown's worth of good interpretation. There 'tis, boy.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 35)
that this good blossom could be kept from cankers!(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 36)
Well, there is sixpence to preserve thee.   An you do not make him be hanged among you, the gallows shall have wrong.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 37)
And how doth thy master, Bardolph?  Well, my good lord.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 38)
He heard of your Grace's coming to town. There's a letter for you.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 39)
Delivered with good respect. And how doth the Martlemas your master?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 40)
In bodily health, sir.  Marry, the immortal part needs a physician, but that moves not him.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 41)
Though that be sick, it dies not.  do allow this wen to be as familiar with me as my dog, and he holds his place, for look you how he writes.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 42)
John Falstaff, knight. Every man must know that as oft as he has occasion to name himself, even like those that are kin to the King, for they never prick their finger but they say "There's some of the King's blood spilt.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 43)
" "How comes that?" says he that takes upon him not to conceive.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 44)
The answer is as ready as a borrower's cap: am the King's poor cousin, sir.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 45)
"  Nay, they will be kin to us, or they will fetch it from Japheth.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 46)
But to the letter:  Sir John Falstaff, knight, to the son of the King nearest his father, Harry Prince of Wales, greeting.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 47)
Why, this is a certificate.  Peace! will imitate the honorable Romans in brevity.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 48)
He sure means brevity in breath, short-winded.  commend me to thee, commend thee, and leave thee.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 49)
Be not too familiar with Poins, for he misuses thy favors so much that he swears thou art to marry his sister Nell.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 50)
Repent at idle times as thou mayst, and so farewell.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 51)
Thine by yea and no, which is as much as to say, as thou usest him, Jack Falstaff with my familiars, John with my brothers and sisters, and Sir John with all Europe.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 52)
My lord, I'll steep this letter in sack and make him eat it.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 53)
That's to make him eat twenty of his words. But do you use me thus, Ned?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 54)
Must marry your sister?  God send the wench no worse fortune!(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 55)
But never said so.  Well, thus we play the fools with the time, and the spirits of the wise sit in the clouds and mock us.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 56)
Is your master here in London?  Yea, my lord.  Where sups he?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 57)
Doth the old boar feed in the old frank?  At the old place, my lord, in Eastcheap.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 58)
What company?  Ephesians, my lord, of the old church.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 59)
Sup any women with him?  None, my lord, but old Mistress Quickly and Mistress Doll Tearsheet.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 60)
What pagan may that be?  proper gentlewoman, sir, and a kinswoman of my master's.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 61)
Even such kin as the parish heifers are to the town bull.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 62)
--Shall we steal upon them, Ned, at supper?  am your shadow, my lord.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 63)
I'll follow you.  Sirrah--you, boy--and Bardolph, no word to your master that am yet come to town.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 64)
There's for your silence.  have no tongue, sir.  And for mine, sir, will govern it.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 65)
Fare you well. Go. This Doll Tearsheet should be some road.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 66)
warrant you, as common as the way between Saint Albans and London.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 67)
How might we see Falstaff bestow himself tonight in his true colors, and not ourselves be seen?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 68)
Put on two leathern jerkins and aprons, and wait upon him at his table as drawers.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 69)
From a god to a bull: a heavy descension. It was Jove's case.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 70)
From a prince to a 'prentice: a low transformation that shall be mine, for in everything the purpose must weigh with the folly.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 71)
2         pray thee, loving wife and gentle daughter, Give even way unto my rough affairs.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 0)
Put not you on the visage of the times And be, like them, to Percy troublesome.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 1)
have given over. will speak no more. Do what you will; your wisdom be your guide.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 2)
Alas, sweet wife, my honor is at pawn, And, but my going, nothing can redeem it.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 3)
yet, for God's sake, go not to these wars. The time was, father, that you broke your word When you were more endeared to it than now, When your own Percy, when my heart's dear Harry, Threw many a northward look to see his father Bring up his powers; but he did long in vain.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 4)
Who then persuaded you to stay at home? There were two honors lost, yours and your son's.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 5)
For yours, the God of heaven brighten it. For his, it stuck upon him as the sun In the gray vault of heaven, and by his light Did all the chivalry of England move To do brave acts.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 6)
He was indeed the glass Wherein the noble youth did dress themselves.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 7)
He had no legs that practiced not his gait; And speaking thick, which nature made his blemish, Became the accents of the valiant; For those that could speak low and tardily Would turn their own perfection to abuse To seem like him.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 8)
So that in speech, in gait, In diet, in affections of delight, In military rules, humors of blood, He was the mark and glass, copy and book, That fashioned others.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 9)
And him--O wondrous him! miracle of men!--him did you leave, Second to none, unseconded by you, To look upon the hideous god of war In disadvantage, to abide a field Where nothing but the sound of Hotspur's name Did seem defensible.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 10)
So you left him. Never, never, do his ghost the wrong To hold your honor more precise and nice With others than with him.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 11)
Let them alone. The Marshal and the Archbishop are strong.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 12)
Had my sweet Harry had but half their numbers, Today might hanging on Hotspur's neck, Have talked of Monmouth's grave.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 13)
Beshrew your heart, Fair daughter, you do draw my spirits from me With new lamenting ancient oversights.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 14)
But must go and meet with danger there, Or it will seek me in another place And find me worse provided.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 15)
fly to Scotland Till that the nobles and the armed commons Have of their puissance made a little taste.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 16)
If they get ground and vantage of the King, Then join you with them like a rib of steel To make strength stronger; but, for all our loves, First let them try themselves.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 17)
So did your son; He was so suffered. So came a widow, And never shall have length of life enough To rain upon remembrance with mine eyes That it may grow and sprout as high as heaven For recordation to my noble husband.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 18)
Come, come, go in with me. 'Tis with my mind As with the tide swelled up unto his height, That makes a still-stand, running neither way.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 19)
Fain would go to meet the Archbishop, But many thousand reasons hold me back.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 20)
will resolve for Scotland. There am Till time and vantage crave my company.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 21)
What the devil hast thou brought there-- applejohns?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 0)
Thou knowest Sir John cannot endure an applejohn.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 1)
Mass, thou sayst true. The Prince once set a dish of applejohns before him and told him there were five more Sir Johns and, putting off his hat, said will now take my leave of these six dry, round, old, withered knights.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 2)
" It angered him to the heart. But he hath forgot that.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 3)
Why then, cover and set them down, and see if thou canst find out Sneak's noise.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 4)
Mistress Tearsheet would fain hear some music. Dispatch.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 5)
The room where they supped is too hot. They'll come in straight.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 6)
Sirrah, here will be the Prince and Master Poins anon, and they will put on two of our jerkins and aprons, and Sir John must not know of it.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 7)
Bardolph hath brought word.  By the Mass, here will be old utis.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 8)
It will be an excellent stratagem.  I'll see if can find out Sneak.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 9)
faith, sweetheart, methinks now you are in an excellent good temperality.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 10)
Your pulsidge beats as extraordinarily as heart would desire, and your color, warrant you, is as red as any rose, in good truth, la.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 11)
But, i' faith, you have drunk too much canaries, and that's a marvellous searching wine, and it perfumes the blood ere one can say "What's this?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 12)
" How do you now?  Better than was. Hem.  Why, that's well said.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 13)
good heart's worth gold. Lo, here comes Sir John.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 14)
When Arthur first in court-- Empty the jordan.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 15)
[Will exits.] And was a worthy king-- How now, Mistress Doll?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 16)
Sick of a calm, yea, good faith.  So is all her sect.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 17)
An they be once in a calm, they are sick.  pox damn you, you muddy rascal.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 18)
Is that all the comfort you give me?  You make fat rascals, Mistress Doll.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 19)
make them? Gluttony and diseases make them; make them not.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 20)
If the cook help to make the gluttony, you help to make the diseases, Doll.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 21)
We catch of you, Doll, we catch of you. Grant that, my poor virtue, grant that.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 22)
Yea, joy, our chains and our jewels.  Your brooches, pearls, and ouches--for to serve bravely is to come halting off, you know; to come off the breach with his pike bent bravely, and to surgery bravely, to venture upon the charged chambers bravely--  Hang yourself, you muddy conger, hang yourself!(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 23)
By my troth, this is the old fashion. You two never meet but you fall to some discord.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 24)
You are both, i' good truth, as rheumatic as two dry toasts.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 25)
You cannot one bear with another's confirmities. What the good-year!(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 26)
One must bear, and that must be you. You are the weaker vessel, as they say, the emptier vessel.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 27)
Can a weak empty vessel bear such a huge full hogshead?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 28)
There's a whole merchant's venture of Bordeaux stuff in him.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 29)
You have not seen a hulk better stuffed in the hold.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 30)
--Come, I'll be friends with thee, Jack. Thou art going to the wars, and whether shall ever see thee again or no, there is nobody cares.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 31)
Sir, Ancient Pistol's below and would speak with you.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 32)
Hang him, swaggering rascal! Let him not come hither.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 33)
It is the foul-mouthed'st rogue in England.  If he swagger, let him not come here.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 34)
No, by my faith, must live among my neighbors. I'll no swaggerers.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 35)
am in good name and fame with the very best. Shut the door.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 36)
There comes no swaggerers here. have not lived all this while to have swaggering now.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 37)
Shut the door, pray you.  Dost thou hear, hostess?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 38)
Pray you pacify yourself, Sir John. There comes no swaggerers here.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 39)
Dost thou hear? It is mine ancient.  Tilly-vally, Sir John, ne'er tell me.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 40)
And your ancient swaggerer comes not in my doors.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 41)
was before Master Tisick the debuty t' other day, and, as he said to me--'twas no longer ago than Wednesday last, i' good faith--"Neighbor Quickly," says he--Master Dumb, our minister, was by then-- "Neighbor Quickly," says he, "receive those that are civil, for," said he, "you are in an ill name.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 42)
" Now he said so, can tell whereupon. "For," says he, "you are an honest woman, and well thought on.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 43)

" There comes none here. You would bless you to hear what he said.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 45)
No, I'll no swaggerers.  He's no swaggerer, hostess, a tame cheater, i' faith.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 46)
You may stroke him as gently as a puppy greyhound.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 47)
He'll not swagger with a Barbary hen if her feathers turn back in any show of resistance.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 48)
-- Call him up, drawer.  "Cheater" call you him? will bar no honest man my house, nor no cheater, but do not love swaggering.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 49)

She is pistol-proof. Sir, you shall not hardly offend her.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 56)
Come, I'll drink no proofs nor no bullets. I'll drink no more than will do me good, for no man's pleasure,  Then, to you, Mistress Dorothy!(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 57)

know you, Mistress Dorothy.  Away, you cutpurse rascal, you filthy bung, away!(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 61)

Away, you bottle-ale rascal, you basket-hilt stale juggler, you.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 63)
Since when, pray you, sir? God's light, with two points on your shoulder?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 64)
Much!  God let me not live but will murder your ruff for this.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 65)
No more, Pistol. would not have you go off here.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 66)
Discharge yourself of our company, Pistol.  No, good Captain Pistol, not here, sweet captain!(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 67)
Captain? Thou abominable damned cheater, art thou not ashamed to be called captain?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 68)
An captains were of my mind, they would truncheon you out for taking their names upon you before you have earned them.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 69)
You a captain? You slave, for what? For tearing a poor whore's ruff in a bawdy house?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 70)
He a captain! Hang him, rogue. He lives upon mouldy stewed prunes and dried cakes.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 71)
captain? God's light, these villains will make the word as odious as the word "occupy," which was an excellent good word before it was ill sorted.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 72)
Therefore captains had need look to 't.  Pray thee go down, good ancient.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 73)
Hark thee hither, Mistress Doll.  Not tell thee what, Corporal Bardolph, could tear her.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 74)
I'll be revenged of her.  Pray thee go down.  I'll see her damned first to Pluto's damned lake, by this hand, to th' infernal deep with Erebus and tortures vile also.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 75)
Hold hook and line, say Down, down, dogs! Down, Fates!(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 76)

'Tis very late, i' faith. beseek you now, aggravate your choler.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 78)
These be good humors indeed. Shall pack-horses and hollow pampered jades of Asia, which cannot go but thirty mile a day, compare with Caesars and with cannibals and Troyant Greeks?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 79)
Nay, rather damn them with King Cerberus, and let the welkin roar.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 80)

Die men like dogs! Give crowns like pins! Have we not Hiren here?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 83)
my word, captain, there's none such here. What the good-year, do you think would deny her?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 84)

Sirrah, what humor's the Prince of?  good shallow young fellow, he would have made a good pantler; he would 'a chipped bread well.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 114)
They say Poins has a good wit.  He a good wit? Hang him, baboon.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 115)
His wit's as thick as Tewkesbury mustard. There's no more conceit in him than is in a mallet.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 116)
Why does the Prince love him so then?  Because their legs are both of a bigness, and he plays at quoits well, and eats conger and fennel, and drinks off candles' ends for flap-dragons, and rides the wild mare with the boys, and jumps upon joint stools, and swears with a good grace, and wears his boots very smooth like unto the sign of the Leg, and breeds no bate with telling of discreet stories, and such other gambol faculties he has that show a weak mind and an able body, for the which the Prince admits him; for the Prince himself is such another.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 117)
The weight of a hair will turn the scales between their avoirdupois.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 118)
Would not this nave of a wheel have his ears cut off?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 119)
Let's beat him before his whore.  Look whe'er the withered elder hath not his poll clawed like a parrot.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 120)
Is it not strange that desire should so many years outlive performance?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 121)
Kiss me, Doll.  Saturn and Venus this year in conjunction!(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 122)

dispraised him before the wicked, that the wicked might not fall in love with thee; in which doing, have done the part of a careful friend and a true subject, and thy father is to give me thanks for it.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 147)

Answer, thou dead elm, answer.  The fiend hath pricked down Bardolph irrecoverable, and his face is Lucifer's privy kitchen, where he doth nothing but roast malt-worms.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 151)
For the boy, there is a good angel about him, but the devil blinds him too.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 152)
For the women?  For one of them, she's in hell already and burns poor souls.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 153)
For th' other, owe her money, and whether she be damned for that know not.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 154)
No, warrant you.  No, think thou art not. think thou art quit for that.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 155)

All vitlars do so. What's a joint of mutton or two in a whole Lent?(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 157)
You, gentlewoman.  What says your Grace?  His grace says that which his flesh rebels against.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 158)
Who knocks so loud at door? Look to th' door there, Francis.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 159)
Peto, how now, what news?   The King your father is at Westminster, And there are twenty weak and wearied posts Come from the north, and as came along met and overtook a dozen captains, Bareheaded, sweating, knocking at the taverns And asking everyone for Sir John Falstaff.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 160)
By heaven, Poins, feel me much to blame So idly to profane the precious time When tempest of commotion, like the south Borne with black vapor, doth begin to melt And drop upon our bare unarmed heads.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 161)

cannot speak. If my heart be not ready to burst--well, sweet Jack, have a care of thyself.(Henry IV, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 170)

Lord Protector, Cardinal, and Suffolk, and     Believe me, lords, for flying at the brook saw not better sport these seven years' day.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 0)
Yet, by your leave, the wind was very high, And, ten to one, old Joan had not gone out.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 1)
But what a point, my lord, your falcon made, And what a pitch she flew above the rest!(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 2)
To see how God in all his creatures works! Yea, man and birds are fain of climbing high.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 3)
No marvel, an it like your Majesty, My Lord Protector's hawks do tower so well; They know their master loves to be aloft And bears his thoughts above his falcon's pitch.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 4)
My lord, 'tis but a base ignoble mind That mounts no higher than a bird can soar.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 5)
thought as much. He would be above the clouds.   Ay, my Lord Cardinal, how think you by that?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 6)
Were it not good your Grace could fly to heaven?   The treasury of everlasting joy.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 7)
Thy heaven is on Earth; thine eyes and thoughts Beat on a crown, the treasure of thy heart.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 8)
Pernicious Protector, dangerous peer, That smooth'st it so with king and commonweal!(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 9)
What, cardinal, is your priesthood grown peremptory?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 10)
Tantaene animis caelestibus irae? Churchmen so hot?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 11)
Good uncle, hide such malice. With such holiness, can you do it?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 12)
No malice, sir, no more than well becomes So good a quarrel and so bad a peer.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 13)
As who, my lord?  Why, as you, my lord, An 't like your lordly Lord Protectorship.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 14)
Why, Suffolk, England knows thine insolence.   And thy ambition, Gloucester.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 15)
prithee peace, Good queen, and whet not on these furious peers, For blessed are the peacemakers on Earth.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 16)
Let me be blessed for the peace make Against this proud Protector with my sword!(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 17)
Faith, holy uncle, would 't were come to that!  Marry, when thou dar'st!(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 18)
Make up no factious numbers for the matter. In thine own person answer thy abuse.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 19)
Ay, where thou dar'st not peep. An if thou dar'st, This evening, on the east side of the grove.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 20)
How now, my lords?  Believe me, cousin Gloucester, Had not your man put up the fowl so suddenly, We had had more sport.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 21)
Come with thy two-hand sword.   True, uncle.  Are you advised?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 22)
The east side of the grove.   am with you.  Why, how now, uncle Gloucester?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 23)
Talking of hawking; nothing else, my lord. Now, by God's mother, priest, I'll shave your crown for this, Or all my fence shall fail.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 24)
Medice, teipsum; Protector, see to 't well; protect yourself.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 25)
The winds grow high; so do your stomachs, lords.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 26)
How irksome is this music to my heart! When such strings jar, what hope of harmony?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 27)
pray, my lords, let me compound this strife.     What means this noise?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 28)
-- Fellow, what miracle dost thou proclaim?  miracle, a miracle!(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 29)
Come to the King, and tell him what miracle.   Forsooth, a blind man at Saint Alban's shrine Within this half hour hath received his sight, man that ne'er saw in his life before.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 30)
Now, God be praised, that to believing souls Gives light in darkness, comfort in despair.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 31)
bearing the man Simpcox between two in a chair,     Here comes the townsmen on procession To present your Highness with the man.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 32)
Great is his comfort in this earthly vale, Although by his sight his sin be multiplied.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 33)
Stand by, my masters.--Bring him near the King.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 34)
His Highness' pleasure is to talk with him.    Good fellow, tell us here the circumstance, That we for thee may glorify the Lord.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 35)
What, hast thou been long blind and now restored?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 36)
Born blind, an 't please your Grace.  Ay, indeed, was he.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 37)
What woman is this?  His wife, an 't like your Worship.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 38)
Hadst thou been his mother, thou couldst have better told.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 39)
Where wert thou born?   At Berwick in the North, an 't like your Grace.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 40)
Poor soul, God's goodness hath been great to thee.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 41)
Let never day nor night unhallowed pass, But still remember what the Lord hath done.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 42)
Tell me, good fellow, cam'st thou here by chance, Or of devotion to this holy shrine?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 43)
God knows, of pure devotion, being called hundred times and oftener in my sleep By good Saint Alban, who said "Simon, come, Come, offer at my shrine, and will help thee.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 44)
"   Most true, forsooth, and many time and oft Myself have heard a voice to call him so.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 45)
What, art thou lame?  Ay, God Almighty help me!  How cam'st thou so?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 46)
fall off of a tree.  plum tree, master.  How long hast thou been blind?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 47)
born so, master.  What, and wouldst climb a tree?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 48)
But that in all my life, when was a youth.  Too true, and bought his climbing very dear.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 49)
Mass, thou lov'dst plums well, that wouldst venture so.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 50)
Alas, good master, my wife desired some damsons, and made me climb, with danger of my life.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 51)
subtle knave, but yet it shall not serve.-- Let me see thine eyes.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 52)
Wink now. Now open them. In my opinion, yet thou seest not well.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 53)
Yes, master, clear as day, thank God and Saint Alban.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 54)
Sayst thou me so? What color is this cloak of?  Red, master, red as blood.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 55)
Why, that's well said. What color is my gown of?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 56)
Black, forsooth, coal-black as jet.   Why, then, thou know'st what color jet is of.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 57)
And yet, think, jet did he never see.   But cloaks and gowns, before this day, a many.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 58)
Never, before this day, in all his life.  Tell me, sirrah, what's my name?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 59)
Alas, master, know not.  What's his name?  know not.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 60)
Nor his?  No, indeed, master.  What's thine own name?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 61)
Sander Simpcox, an if it please you, master.  Then, Sander, sit there, the lying'st knave in Christendom.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 62)
If thou hadst been born blind, thou mightst as well have known all our names as thus to name the several colors we do wear.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 63)
Sight may distinguish of colors; but suddenly to nominate them all, it is impossible.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 64)
--My lords, Saint Alban here hath done a miracle; and would you not think his cunning to be great that could restore this cripple to his legs again?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 65)
master, that you could!  My masters of Saint Albans, have you not beadles in your town and things called whips?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 66)
Yes, my lord, if it please your Grace.  Then send for one presently.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 67)
Sirrah, go fetch the beadle hither straight.   Now fetch me a stool hither by and by.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 68)
Now, sirrah, if you mean to save yourself from whipping, leap me over this stool, and run away.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 69)
Alas, master, am not able to stand alone. You go about to torture me in vain.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 70)
Well, sir, we must have you find your legs.--Sirrah beadle, whip him till he leap over that same stool.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 71)
will, my lord.--Come on, sirrah, off with your doublet quickly.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 72)
Alas, master, what shall do? am not able to stand.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 73)
over the stool and runs away; and they follow    God, seest Thou this, and bearest so long?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 74)
It made me laugh to see the villain run.   Follow the knave, and take this drab away.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 75)
Alas, sir, we did it for pure need.   Let them be whipped through every market town Till they come to Berwick, from whence they came.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 76)
Duke Humphrey has done a miracle today.   True, made the lame to leap and fly away.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 77)
But you have done more miracles than You made in a day, my lord, whole towns to fly.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 78)
What tidings with our cousin Buckingham?   Such as my heart doth tremble to unfold: sort of naughty persons, lewdly bent, Under the countenance and confederacy Of Lady Eleanor, the Protector's wife, The ringleader and head of all this rout, Have practiced dangerously against your state, Dealing with witches and with conjurers, Whom we have apprehended in the fact, Raising up wicked spirits from under ground, Demanding of King Henry's life and death And other of your Highness' Privy Council, As more at large your Grace shall understand.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 79)
And so, my Lord Protector, by this means Your lady is forthcoming yet at London.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 80)
This news, think, hath turned your weapon's edge; 'Tis like, my lord, you will not keep your hour.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 81)
Ambitious churchman, leave to afflict my heart.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 82)
Sorrow and grief have vanquished all my powers, And, vanquished as am, yield to thee, Or to the meanest groom.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 83)
God, what mischiefs work the wicked ones, Heaping confusion on their own heads thereby!(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 84)
Gloucester, see here the tainture of thy nest, And look thyself be faultless, thou wert best.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 85)
Madam, for myself, to heaven do appeal How have loved my king and commonweal; And, for my wife, know not how it stands.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 86)
Sorry am to hear what have heard. Noble she is; but if she have forgot Honor and virtue, and conversed with such As, like to pitch, defile nobility, banish her my bed and company And give her as a prey to law and shame That hath dishonored Gloucester's honest name.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 87)
Well, for this night we will repose us here. Tomorrow toward London back again, To look into this business thoroughly, And call these foul offenders to their answers, And poise the cause in Justice' equal scales, Whose beam stands sure, whose rightful cause prevails.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 0, Scene 88)
Now, my good lords of Salisbury and Warwick, Our simple supper ended, give me leave, In this close walk, to satisfy myself In craving your opinion of my title, Which is infallible, to England's crown.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 0)
My lord, long to hear it at full.   Sweet York, begin; and if thy claim be good, The Nevilles are thy subjects to command.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 1)
Then thus: Edward the Third, my lords, had seven sons: The first, Edward the Black Prince, Prince of Wales; The second, William of Hatfield; and the third, Lionel, Duke of Clarence; next to whom Was John of Gaunt, the Duke of Lancaster; The fifth was Edmund Langley, Duke of York; The sixth was Thomas of Woodstock, Duke of Gloucester; William of Windsor was the seventh and last.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 2)
Edward the Black Prince died before his father And left behind him Richard, his only son, Who, after Edward the Third's death, reigned as king Till Henry Bolingbroke, Duke of Lancaster, The eldest son and heir of John of Gaunt, Crowned by the name of Henry the Fourth, Seized on the realm, deposed the rightful king, Sent his poor queen to France, from whence she came, And him to Pomfret; where, as all you know, Harmless Richard was murdered traitorously.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 3)
Father, the Duke hath told the truth. Thus got the house of Lancaster the crown.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 4)
Which now they hold by force and not by right; For Richard, the first son's heir, being dead, The issue of the next son should have reigned.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 5)
But William of Hatfield died without an heir.   The third son, Duke of Clarence, from whose line claim the crown, had issue, Philippa, a daughter, Who married Edmund Mortimer, Earl of March.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 6)
Edmund had issue, Roger, Earl of March; Roger had issue: Edmund, Anne, and Eleanor.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 7)
This Edmund, in the reign of Bolingbroke, As have read, laid claim unto the crown And, but for Owen Glendower, had been king, Who kept him in captivity till he died.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 8)
But to the rest.  His eldest sister, Anne, My mother, being heir unto the crown, Married Richard, Earl of Cambridge, who was son To Edmund Langley, Edward the Third's fifth son.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 9)
By her claim the kingdom. She was heir To Roger, Earl of March, who was the son Of Edmund Mortimer, who married Philippa, Sole daughter unto Lionel, Duke of Clarence.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 10)
So, if the issue of the elder son Succeed before the younger, am king.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 11)
What plain proceedings is more plain than this?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 12)
Henry doth claim the crown from John of Gaunt, The fourth son; York claims it from the third.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 13)
Till Lionel's issue fails, his should not reign. It fails not yet, but flourishes in thee And in thy sons, fair slips of such a stock.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 14)
Then, father Salisbury, kneel we together, And in this private plot be we the first That shall salute our rightful sovereign With honor of his birthright to the crown.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 15)
Long live our sovereign Richard, England's king!(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 16)
We thank you, lords.  But am not your king Till be crowned, and that my sword be stained With heart-blood of the house of Lancaster; And that's not suddenly to be performed, But with advice and silent secrecy.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 17)
Do you as do in these dangerous days: Wink at the Duke of Suffolk's insolence, At Beaufort's pride, at Somerset's ambition, At Buckingham, and all the crew of them, Till they have snared the shepherd of the flock, That virtuous prince, the good Duke Humphrey.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 18)
'Tis that they seek; and they, in seeking that, Shall find their deaths, if York can prophesy.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 19)
My lord, break we off. We know your mind at full.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 20)
My heart assures me that the Earl of Warwick Shall one day make the Duke of York a king.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 21)
And, Neville, this do assure myself: Richard shall live to make the Earl of Warwick The greatest man in England but the King.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 1, Scene 22)
(Queen Margaret, Gloucester, York, Salisbury, Suffolk, and Others) with Guard, to banish the Duchess of Gloucester, who is accompanied by Margery Jourdain,     Stand forth, Dame Eleanor Cobham, Gloucester's wife.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 0)
In sight of God and us, your guilt is great. Receive the sentence of the law for sins Such as by God's book are adjudged to death.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 1)
You four, from hence to prison back again; From thence unto the place of execution: The witch in Smithfield shall be burnt to ashes, And you three shall be strangled on the gallows.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 2)
You, madam, for you are more nobly born, Despoiled of your honor in your life, Shall, after three days' open penance done, Live in your country here in banishment With Sir John Stanley in the Isle of Man.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 3)
Welcome is banishment. Welcome were my death.   Eleanor, the law, thou seest, hath judged thee.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 4)
cannot justify whom the law condemns.  Mine eyes are full of tears, my heart of grief.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 5)
Ah, Humphrey, this dishonor in thine age Will bring thy head with sorrow to the ground.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 6)
-- beseech your Majesty give me leave to go; Sorrow would solace, and mine age would ease.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 7)
Stay, Humphrey, Duke of Gloucester. Ere thou go, Give up thy staff.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 8)
Henry will to himself Protector be; and God shall be my hope, My stay, my guide, and lantern to my feet.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 9)
And go in peace, Humphrey, no less beloved Than when thou wert Protector to thy king.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 10)
see no reason why a king of years Should be to be protected like a child.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 11)
God and King Henry govern England's realm!-- Give up your staff, sir, and the King his realm.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 12)
My staff?--Here, noble Henry, is my staff.  As willingly do the same resign As e'er thy father Henry made it mine; And even as willingly at thy feet leave it As others would ambitiously receive it.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 13)
Farewell, good king. When am dead and gone, May honorable peace attend thy throne.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 14)
Why, now is Henry king and Margaret queen, And Humphrey, Duke of Gloucester, scarce himself, That bears so shrewd a maim.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 15)
Two pulls at once: His lady banished and a limb lopped off.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 16)
This staff of honor raught, there let it stand Where it best fits to be, in Henry's hand.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 17)
Thus droops this lofty pine and hangs his sprays; Thus Eleanor's pride dies in her youngest days.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 18)
Lords, let him go.--Please it your Majesty, This is the day appointed for the combat, And ready are the appellant and defendant-- The armorer and his man--to enter the lists, So please your Highness to behold the fight.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 19)
Ay, good my lord, for purposely therefor Left the court to see this quarrel tried.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 20)
God's name, see the lists and all things fit. Here let them end it, and God defend the right!(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 21)
never saw a fellow worse bestead Or more afraid to fight than is the appellant, The servant of this armorer, my lords.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 22)
Neighbors, drinking to him so much that he is drunk; and he enters with a Drum before him and his staff with a sandbag fastened to it; and at the other door his man Peter, with a Drum and sandbag, and Prentices    Here, neighbor Horner, drink to you in a cup of sack; and fear not, neighbor, you shall do well enough.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 23)
And here, neighbor, here's a cup of charneco.  And here's a pot of good double beer, neighbor.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 24)
Drink, and fear not your man.  Let it come, i' faith, and I'll pledge you all.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 25)
And a fig for Peter!  Here, Peter, drink to thee, and be not afraid.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 26)
Be merry, Peter, and fear not thy master. Fight for credit of the prentices.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 27)
thank you all. Drink, and pray for me, pray you, for think have taken my last draft in this world.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 28)
Here, Robin, an if die, give thee my apron.--And, Will, thou shalt have my hammer.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 29)
-- And here, Tom, take all the money that have. Lord, bless me, pray God, for am never able to deal with my master.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 30)
He hath learnt so much fence already.  Come, leave your drinking, and fall to blows.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 31)
Sirrah, what's thy name?  Peter, forsooth.  Peter?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 32)
What more?  Thump.  Thump? Then see thou thump thy master well.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 33)
Masters, am come hither, as it were, upon my man's instigation, to prove him a knave and myself an honest man; and touching the Duke of York, will take my death never meant him any ill, nor the King, nor the Queen.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 34)
--And therefore, Peter, have at thee with a downright blow!(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 35)
Dispatch. This knave's tongue begins to double. Sound, trumpets.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 36)
Alarum to the combatants!    Hold, Peter, hold! confess, confess treason.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 37)
Take away his weapon.--Fellow, thank God and the good wine in thy master's way.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 38)
God, have overcome mine enemies in this presence?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 39)
Peter, thou hast prevailed in right!   Go, take hence that traitor from our sight; For by his death we do perceive his guilt.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 40)
And God in justice hath revealed to us The truth and innocence of this poor fellow, Which he had thought to have murdered wrongfully.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 2, Scene 41)
2         Thus sometimes hath the brightest day a cloud, And after summer evermore succeeds Barren winter, with his wrathful nipping cold; So cares and joys abound, as seasons fleet.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 0)
Sirs, what's o'clock?  Ten, my lord.   Ten is the hour that was appointed me To watch the coming of my punished duchess.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 1)
Uneath may she endure the flinty streets, To tread them with her tender-feeling feet.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 2)
Sweet Nell, ill can thy noble mind abrook The abject people gazing on thy face With envious looks laughing at thy shame, That erst did follow thy proud chariot wheels When thou didst ride in triumph through the streets.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 3)
But, soft! think she comes, and I'll prepare My tearstained eyes to see her miseries.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 4)
white sheet, with papers pinned to her back and a taper burning in her hand, with Sir John Stanley,     So please your Grace, we'll take her from the Sheriff.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 5)
No, stir not for your lives. Let her pass by.   Come you, my lord, to see my open shame?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 6)
Now thou dost penance too. Look how they gaze! See how the giddy multitude do point, And nod their heads, and throw their eyes on thee.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 7)
Ah, Gloucester, hide thee from their hateful looks, And, in thy closet pent up, rue my shame, And ban thine enemies, both mine and thine.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 8)
Be patient, gentle Nell. Forget this grief.   Ah, Gloucester, teach me to forget myself!(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 9)
For whilst think am thy married wife And thou a prince, Protector of this land, Methinks should not thus be led along, Mailed up in shame, with papers on my back, And followed with a rabble that rejoice To see my tears and hear my deep-fet groans.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 10)
The ruthless flint doth cut my tender feet, And when start, the envious people laugh And bid me be advised how tread.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 11)
Ah, Humphrey, can bear this shameful yoke? Trowest thou that e'er I'll look upon the world Or count them happy that enjoys the sun?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 12)
No, dark shall be my light, and night my day. To think upon my pomp shall be my hell.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 13)
Sometimes I'll say am Duke Humphrey's wife And he a prince and ruler of the land; Yet so he ruled and such a prince he was As he stood by whilst his forlorn duchess, Was made a wonder and a pointing-stock To every idle rascal follower.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 14)
But be thou mild, and blush not at my shame, Nor stir at nothing till the ax of death Hang over thee, as, sure, it shortly will.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 15)
For Suffolk, he that can do all in all With her that hateth thee and hates us all, And York and impious Beaufort, that false priest, Have all limed bushes to betray thy wings; And fly thou how thou canst, they'll tangle thee.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 16)
But fear not thou until thy foot be snared, Nor never seek prevention of thy foes.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 17)
Ah, Nell, forbear. Thou aimest all awry. must offend before be attainted; And had twenty times so many foes, And each of them had twenty times their power, All these could not procure me any scathe So long as am loyal, true, and crimeless.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 18)
Wouldst have me rescue thee from this reproach? Why, yet thy scandal were not wiped away, But in danger for the breach of law.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 19)
Thy greatest help is quiet, gentle Nell. pray thee, sort thy heart to patience; These few days' wonder will be quickly worn.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 20)
summon your Grace to his Majesty's Parliament Holden at Bury the first of this next month.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 21)
And my consent ne'er asked herein before? This is close dealing.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 22)
Well, will be there.  My Nell, take my leave.--And, master sheriff, Let not her penance exceed the King's commission.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 23)
An 't please your Grace, here my commission stays, And Sir John Stanley is appointed now To take her with him to the Isle of Man.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 24)
Must you, Sir John, protect my lady here?   So am given in charge, may 't please your Grace.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 25)
Entreat her not the worse in that pray You use her well.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 26)
The world may laugh again, And may live to do you kindness, if You do it her.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 27)
And so, Sir John, farewell.   What, gone, my lord, and bid me not farewell?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 28)
Witness my tears. cannot stay to speak.    Art thou gone too?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 29)
All comfort go with thee, For none abides with me.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 30)
My joy is death-- Death, at whose name oft have been afeard, Because wished this world's eternity.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 31)
-- Stanley, prithee, go, and take me hence. care not whither, for beg no favor; Only convey me where thou art commanded.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 32)
Why, madam, that is to the Isle of Man, There to be used according to your state.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 33)
That's bad enough, for am but reproach. And shall then, be used reproachfully?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 34)
Like to a duchess and Duke Humphrey's lady; According to that state you shall be used.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 35)
Sheriff, farewell, and better than fare, Although thou hast been conduct of my shame.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 36)
It is my office; and, madam, pardon me.   Ay, ay, farewell.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 37)
Thy office is discharged.  Come, Stanley, shall we go?(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 38)
Madam, your penance done, throw off this sheet, And go we to attire you for our journey.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 39)
My shame will not be shifted with my sheet. No, it will hang upon my richest robes And show itself, attire me how can.(Henry VI, Part 2, Act 3, Scene 40)
march. Enter Edward, Richard, and their power,     wonder how our princely father scaped, Or whether he be scaped away or no From Clifford's and Northumberland's pursuit.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 0)
Had he been ta'en, we should have heard the news; Had he been slain, we should have heard the news; Or had he scaped, methinks we should have heard The happy tidings of his good escape.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 1)
How fares my brother? Why is he so sad?   cannot joy until be resolved Where our right valiant father is become.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 2)
saw him in the battle range about And watched him how he singled Clifford forth.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 3)
Methought he bore him in the thickest troop As doth a lion in a herd of neat, Or as a bear encompassed round with dogs, Who having pinched a few and made them cry, The rest stand all aloof and bark at him; So fared our father with his enemies; So fled his enemies my warlike father.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 4)
Methinks 'tis prize enough to be his son. See how the morning opes her golden gates And takes her farewell of the glorious sun.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 5)
How well resembles it the prime of youth, Trimmed like a younker, prancing to his love!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 6)
Dazzle mine eyes, or do see three suns?   Three glorious suns, each one a perfect sun, Not separated with the racking clouds But severed in a pale clear-shining sky.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 7)
See, see, they join, embrace, and seem to kiss, As if they vowed some league inviolable.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 8)
Now are they but one lamp, one light, one sun; In this, the heaven figures some event.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 9)
'Tis wondrous strange, the like yet never heard of.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 10)
think it cites us, brother, to the field, That we, the sons of brave Plantagenet, Each one already blazing by our meeds, Should notwithstanding join our lights together And overshine the earth, as this the world.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 11)
Whate'er it bodes, henceforward will bear Upon my target three fair shining suns.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 12)
Nay, bear three daughters: by your leave speak it, You love the breeder better than the male.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 13)
But what art thou whose heavy looks foretell Some dreadful story hanging on thy tongue?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 14)
Ah, one that was a woeful looker-on Whenas the noble Duke of York was slain, Your princely father and my loving lord.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 15)
speak no more, for have heard too much!   Say how he died, for will hear it all.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 16)
Environed he was with many foes, And stood against them, as the hope of Troy Against the Greeks that would have entered Troy.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 17)
But Hercules himself must yield to odds; And many strokes, though with a little axe, Hews down and fells the hardest-timbered oak.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 18)
By many hands your father was subdued, But only slaughtered by the ireful arm Of unrelenting Clifford and the Queen, Who crowned the gracious duke in high despite, Laughed in his face; and when with grief he wept, The ruthless queen gave him to dry his cheeks napkin steeped in the harmless blood Of sweet young Rutland, by rough Clifford slain.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 19)
And after many scorns, many foul taunts, They took his head and on the gates of York They set the same, and there it doth remain, The saddest spectacle that e'er viewed.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 20)
Sweet Duke of York, our prop to lean upon, Now thou art gone, we have no staff, no stay.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 21)
Clifford, boist'rous Clifford, thou hast slain The flower of Europe for his chivalry; And treacherously hast thou vanquished him, For hand to hand he would have vanquished thee.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 22)
Now my soul's palace is become a prison; Ah, would she break from hence, that this my body Might in the ground be closed up in rest, For never henceforth shall joy again.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 23)
Never, never, shall see more joy!   cannot weep, for all my body's moisture Scarce serves to quench my furnace-burning heart; Nor can my tongue unload my heart's great burden, For selfsame wind that should speak withal Is kindling coals that fires all my breast And burns me up with flames that tears would quench.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 24)
To weep is to make less the depth of grief: Tears, then, for babes; blows and revenge for me.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 25)
Richard, bear thy name. I'll venge thy death Or die renowned by attempting it.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 26)
His name that valiant duke hath left with thee; His dukedom and his chair with me is left.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 27)
Nay, if thou be that princely eagle's bird, Show thy descent by gazing 'gainst the sun; For "chair" and "dukedom," "throne" and "kingdom" say; Either that is thine or else thou wert not his.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 28)
How now, fair lords? What fare, what news abroad?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 29)
Great lord of Warwick, if we should recount Our baleful news, and at each word's deliverance Stab poniards in our flesh till all were told, The words would add more anguish than the wounds.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 30)
valiant lord, the Duke of York is slain.   Warwick, Warwick, that Plantagenet Which held thee dearly as his soul's redemption Is by the stern Lord Clifford done to death.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 31)
Ten days ago drowned these news in tears. And now to add more measure to your woes, come to tell you things sith then befall'n.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 32)
After the bloody fray at Wakefield fought, Where your brave father breathed his latest gasp, Tidings, as swiftly as the posts could run, Were brought me of your loss and his depart.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 33)
then in London, keeper of the King, Mustered my soldiers, gathered flocks of friends, Marched toward Saint Albans to intercept the Queen, Bearing the King in my behalf along; For by my scouts was advertised That she was coming with a full intent To dash our late decree in Parliament Touching King Henry's oath and your succession.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 34)
Short tale to make, we at Saint Albans met, Our battles joined, and both sides fiercely fought.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 35)
But whether 'twas the coldness of the King, Who looked full gently on his warlike queen, That robbed my soldiers of their heated spleen, Or whether 'twas report of her success Or more than common fear of Clifford's rigor, Who thunders to his captives blood and death, cannot judge; but to conclude with truth, Their weapons like to lightning came and went; Our soldiers', like the night owl's lazy flight Or like an idle thresher with a flail, Fell gently down, as if they struck their friends.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 36)
cheered them up with justice of our cause, With promise of high pay and great rewards, But all in vain; they had no heart to fight, And we, in them, no hope to win the day, So that we fled: the King unto the Queen; Lord George your brother, Norfolk, and myself In haste, posthaste, are come to join with you; For in the Marches here we heard you were, Making another head to fight again.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 37)
Where is the Duke of Norfolk, gentle Warwick? And when came George from Burgundy to England?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 38)
Some six miles off the Duke is with the soldiers, And, for your brother, he was lately sent From your kind aunt, Duchess of Burgundy, With aid of soldiers to this needful war.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 39)
'Twas odds, belike, when valiant Warwick fled. Oft have heard his praises in pursuit, But ne'er till now his scandal of retire.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 40)
Nor now my scandal, Richard, dost thou hear? For thou shalt know this strong right hand of mine Can pluck the diadem from faint Henry's head And wring the awful scepter from his fist, Were he as famous and as bold in war As he is famed for mildness, peace, and prayer.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 41)
know it well, Lord Warwick; blame me not. 'Tis love bear thy glories make me speak.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 42)
But in this troublous time, what's to be done? Shall we go throw away our coats of steel And wrap our bodies in black mourning gowns, Numb'ring our Ave Marys with our beads?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 43)
Or shall we on the helmets of our foes Tell our devotion with revengeful arms?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 44)
If for the last, say "Ay," and to it, lords.   Why, therefore Warwick came to seek you out, And therefore comes my brother Montague.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 45)
Attend me, lords: the proud insulting queen, With Clifford and the haught Northumberland And of their feather many more proud birds, Have wrought the easy-melting king like wax.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 46)
He swore consent to your succession, His oath enrolled in the Parliament.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 47)
And now to London all the crew are gone To frustrate both his oath and what beside May make against the house of Lancaster.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 48)
Their power, think, is thirty thousand strong. Now, if the help of Norfolk and myself, With all the friends that thou, brave Earl of March, Amongst the loving Welshmen canst procure, Will but amount to five and twenty thousand, Why, via, to London will we march, And once again bestride our foaming steeds, And once again cry "Charge!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 49)
" upon our foes, But never once again turn back and fly.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 50)
Ay, now methinks hear great Warwick speak. Ne'er may he live to see a sunshine day That cries "Retire!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 51)
" if Warwick bid him stay.   Lord Warwick, on thy shoulder will lean, And when thou fail'st--as God forbid the hour!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 52)
-- Must Edward fall, which peril heaven forfend.
