No longer Earl of March, but Duke of York; The next degree is England's royal throne: For King of England shalt thou be proclaimed In every borough as we pass along, And he that throws not up his cap for joy Shall for the fault make forfeit of his head.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 53)
King Edward, valiant Richard, Montague, Stay we no longer dreaming of renown, But sound the trumpets and about our task.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 54)
Then, Clifford, were thy heart as hard as steel, As thou hast shown it flinty by thy deeds, come to pierce it or to give thee mine.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 55)
Then strike up drums! God and Saint George for us!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 56)
How now, what news?   The Duke of Norfolk sends you word by me, The Queen is coming with a puissant host, And craves your company for speedy counsel.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 57)
Why, then it sorts. Brave warriors, let's away!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 0, Scene 58)
Clifford, Northumberland, and young Prince Edward, all wearing the red rose with Drum and Trumpets,     Welcome, my lord, to this brave town of York.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 0)
Yonder's the head of that arch-enemy That sought to be encompassed with your crown.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 1)
Doth not the object cheer your heart, my lord?   Ay, as the rocks cheer them that fear their wrack!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 2)
To see this sight, it irks my very soul. Withhold revenge, dear God!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 3)
'Tis not my fault, Nor wittingly have infringed my vow.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 4)
My gracious liege, this too much lenity And harmful pity must be laid aside.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 5)
To whom do lions cast their gentle looks? Not to the beast that would usurp their den.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 6)
Whose hand is that the forest bear doth lick? Not his that spoils her young before her face.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 7)
Who scapes the lurking serpent's mortal sting? Not he that sets his foot upon her back.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 8)
The smallest worm will turn, being trodden on, And doves will peck in safeguard of their brood.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 9)
Ambitious York did level at thy crown, Thou smiling while he knit his angry brows.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 10)
He, but a duke, would have his son a king And raise his issue like a loving sire; Thou being a king, blest with a goodly son, Didst yield consent to disinherit him, Which argued thee a most unloving father.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 11)
Unreasonable creatures feed their young; And though man's face be fearful to their eyes, Yet in protection of their tender ones, Who hath not seen them, even with those wings Which sometime they have used with fearful flight, Make war with him that climbed unto their nest, Offering their own lives in their young's defense?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 12)
For shame, my liege, make them your precedent. Were it not pity that this goodly boy Should lose his birthright by his father's fault, And long hereafter say unto his child "What my great-grandfather and grandsire got, My careless father fondly gave away"?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 13)
Ah, what a shame were this! Look on the boy, And let his manly face, which promiseth Successful fortune, steel thy melting heart To hold thine own and leave thine own with him.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 14)
Full well hath Clifford played the orator, Inferring arguments of mighty force.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 15)
But, Clifford, tell me, didst thou never hear That things ill got had ever bad success?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 16)
And happy always was it for that son Whose father for his hoarding went to hell?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 17)
I'll leave my son my virtuous deeds behind, And would my father had left me no more; For all the rest is held at such a rate As brings a thousandfold more care to keep Than in possession any jot of pleasure.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 18)
Ah, cousin York, would thy best friends did know How it doth grieve me that thy head is here.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 19)
My lord, cheer up your spirits; our foes are nigh, And this soft courage makes your followers faint.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 20)
You promised knighthood to our forward son. Unsheathe your sword and dub him presently.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 21)
-- Edward, kneel down.   Edward Plantagenet, arise a knight, And learn this lesson: draw thy sword in right.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 22)
My gracious father, by your kingly leave, I'll draw it as apparent to the crown And in that quarrel use it to the death.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 23)
Why, that is spoken like a toward prince.      Royal commanders, be in readiness, For with a band of thirty thousand men Comes Warwick backing of the Duke of York, And in the towns as they do march along Proclaims him king, and many fly to him.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 24)
Deraign your battle, for they are at hand.   would your Highness would depart the field.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 25)
The Queen hath best success when you are absent.   Ay, good my lord, and leave us to our fortune.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 26)
Why, that's my fortune too; therefore I'll stay.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 27)
Be it with resolution, then, to fight.   My royal father, cheer these noble lords And hearten those that fight in your defense.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 28)
Unsheathe your sword, good father; cry "Saint George!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 29)
"   George, Norfolk, Montague, and Soldiers,     Now, perjured Henry, wilt thou kneel for grace And set thy diadem upon my head, Or bide the mortal fortune of the field?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 30)
Go rate thy minions, proud insulting boy. Becomes it thee to be thus bold in terms Before thy sovereign and thy lawful king?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 31)
am his king, and he should bow his knee. was adopted heir by his consent.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 32)
Since when, his oath is broke; for, as hear, You that are king, though he do wear the crown, Have caused him, by new act of Parliament, To blot out me and put his own son in.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 33)
And reason too: Who should succeed the father but the son?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 34)
Are you there, butcher? cannot speak!   Ay, crookback, here stand to answer thee, Or any he, the proudest of thy sort.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 35)
'Twas you that killed young Rutland, was it not?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 36)
Ay, and old York, and yet not satisfied.   For God's sake, lords, give signal to the fight!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 37)
What sayst thou, Henry? Wilt thou yield the crown?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 38)
Why, how now, long-tongued Warwick, dare you speak?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 39)
When you and met at Saint Albans last, Your legs did better service than your hands.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 40)
Then 'twas my turn to fly, and now 'tis thine.   You said so much before, and yet you fled.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 41)
'Twas not your valor, Clifford, drove me thence.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 42)
No, nor your manhood that durst make you stay.   Northumberland, hold thee reverently.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 43)
-- Break off the parley, for scarce can refrain The execution of my big-swoll'n heart Upon that Clifford, that cruel child-killer.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 44)
slew thy father; call'st thou him a child?   Ay, like a dastard and a treacherous coward, As thou didst kill our tender brother Rutland.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 45)
But ere sunset I'll make thee curse the deed.   Have done with words, my lords, and hear me speak.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 46)
Defy them, then, or else hold close thy lips.   prithee, give no limits to my tongue.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 47)
am a king and privileged to speak.   My liege, the wound that bred this meeting here Cannot be cured by words; therefore, be still.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 48)
Then, executioner, unsheathe thy sword. By Him that made us all, am resolved That Clifford's manhood lies upon his tongue.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 49)
Say, Henry, shall have my right or no? thousand men have broke their fasts today That ne'er shall dine unless thou yield the crown.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 50)
If thou deny, their blood upon thy head, For York in justice puts his armor on.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 51)
If that be right which Warwick says is right, There is no wrong, but everything is right.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 52)
Whoever got thee, there thy mother stands, For well wot thou hast thy mother's tongue.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 53)
But thou art neither like thy sire nor dam, But like a foul misshapen stigmatic, Marked by the Destinies to be avoided, As venom toads or lizards' dreadful stings.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 54)
Iron of Naples, hid with English gilt, Whose father bears the title of a king, As if a channel should be called the sea, Sham'st thou not, knowing whence thou art extraught, To let thy tongue detect thy baseborn heart?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 55)
wisp of straw were worth a thousand crowns To make this shameless callet know herself.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 56)
-- Helen of Greece was fairer far than thou, Although thy husband may be Menelaus; And ne'er was Agamemnon's brother wronged By that false woman as this king by thee.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 57)
His father reveled in the heart of France, And tamed the King, and made the Dauphin stoop; And had he matched according to his state, He might have kept that glory to this day.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 58)
But when he took a beggar to his bed And graced thy poor sire with his bridal day, Even then that sunshine brewed a shower for him That washed his father's fortunes forth of France And heaped sedition on his crown at home.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 59)
For what hath broached this tumult but thy pride?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 60)
Hadst thou been meek, our title still had slept, And we, in pity of the gentle king, Had slipped our claim until another age.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 61)
But when we saw our sunshine made thy spring, And that thy summer bred us no increase, We set the axe to thy usurping root; And though the edge hath something hit ourselves, Yet know thou, since we have begun to strike, We'll never leave till we have hewn thee down Or bathed thy growing with our heated bloods.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 62)
And in this resolution, defy thee, Not willing any longer conference, Since thou denied'st the gentle king to speak.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 63)
-- Sound, trumpets! Let our bloody colors wave; And either victory or else a grave!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 64)
Stay, Edward!   No, wrangling woman, we'll no longer stay.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 65)
These words will cost ten thousand lives this day.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 1, Scene 66)
Forspent with toil, as runners with a race, lay me down a little while to breathe, For strokes received and many blows repaid Have robbed my strong-knit sinews of their strength; And spite of spite, needs must rest awhile.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 2, Scene 0)
Smile, gentle heaven, or strike, ungentle death, For this world frowns and Edward's sun is clouded.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 2, Scene 1)
How now, my lord, what hap? What hope of good?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 2, Scene 2)
Our hap is loss, our hope but sad despair; Our ranks are broke, and ruin follows us.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 2, Scene 3)
What counsel give you? Whither shall we fly?   Bootless is flight; they follow us with wings, And weak we are and cannot shun pursuit.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 2, Scene 4)
Ah, Warwick, why hast thou withdrawn thyself?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 2, Scene 5)
Thy brother's blood the thirsty earth hath drunk, Broached with the steely point of Clifford's lance, And in the very pangs of death he cried, Like to a dismal clangor heard from far, "Warwick, revenge!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 2, Scene 6)
Brother, revenge my death!" So, underneath the belly of their steeds, That stained their fetlocks in his smoking blood, The noble gentleman gave up the ghost.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 2, Scene 7)
Then let the earth be drunken with our blood! I'll kill my horse because will not fly.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 2, Scene 8)
Why stand we like soft-hearted women here, Wailing our losses whiles the foe doth rage, And look upon, as if the tragedy Were played in jest by counterfeiting actors?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 2, Scene 9)
Here on my knee vow to God above I'll never pause again, never stand still, Till either death hath closed these eyes of mine Or Fortune given me measure of revenge.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 2, Scene 10)
Warwick, do bend my knee with thine, And in this vow do chain my soul to thine  And, ere my knee rise from the Earth's cold face, throw my hands, mine eyes, my heart to Thee, Thou setter up and plucker down of kings, Beseeching Thee, if with Thy will it stands That to my foes this body must be prey, Yet that Thy brazen gates of heaven may ope And give sweet passage to my sinful soul.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 2, Scene 11)
Now, lords, take leave until we meet again, Where'er it be, in heaven or in Earth.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 2, Scene 12)
Brother, give me thy hand.--And, gentle Warwick, Let me embrace thee in my weary arms.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 2, Scene 13)
that did never weep now melt with woe That winter should cut off our springtime so.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 2, Scene 14)
Away, away! Once more, sweet lords, farewell.   Yet let us all together to our troops And give them leave to fly that will not stay, And call them pillars that will stand to us; And, if we thrive, promise them such rewards As victors wear at the Olympian Games.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 2, Scene 15)
This may plant courage in their quailing breasts, For yet is hope of life and victory.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 2, Scene 16)
2         Now, Clifford, have singled thee alone. Suppose this arm is for the Duke of York, And this for Rutland, both bound to revenge, Wert thou environed with a brazen wall.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 3, Scene 0)
Now, Richard, am with thee here alone. This is the hand that stabbed thy father York, And this the hand that slew thy brother Rutland, And here's the heart that triumphs in their death And cheers these hands that slew thy sire and brother To execute the like upon thyself.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 3, Scene 1)
And so, have at thee!      Nay, Warwick, single out some other chase, For myself will hunt this wolf to death.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 3, Scene 2)
This battle fares like to the morning's war, When dying clouds contend with growing light, What time the shepherd, blowing of his nails, Can neither call it perfect day nor night.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 0)
Now sways it this way, like a mighty sea Forced by the tide to combat with the wind; Now sways it that way, like the selfsame sea Forced to retire by fury of the wind.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 1)
Sometime the flood prevails, and then the wind; Now one the better, then another best, Both tugging to be victors, breast to breast, Yet neither conqueror nor conquered.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 2)
So is the equal poise of this fell war. Here on this molehill will sit me down.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 3)
To whom God will, there be the victory; For Margaret my queen and Clifford too Have chid me from the battle, swearing both They prosper best of all when am thence.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 4)
Would were dead, if God's good will were so, For what is in this world but grief and woe?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 5)
God! Methinks it were a happy life To be no better than a homely swain, To sit upon a hill as do now, To carve out dials quaintly, point by point, Thereby to see the minutes how they run: How many makes the hour full complete, How many hours brings about the day, How many days will finish up the year, How many years a mortal man may live.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 6)
When this is known, then to divide the times: So many hours must tend my flock, So many hours must take my rest, So many hours must contemplate, So many hours must sport myself, So many days my ewes have been with young, So many weeks ere the poor fools will ean, So many years ere shall shear the fleece; So minutes, hours, days, months, and years, Passed over to the end they were created, Would bring white hairs unto a quiet grave.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 7)
Ah, what a life were this! How sweet, how lovely!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 8)
Gives not the hawthorn bush a sweeter shade To shepherds looking on their silly sheep Than doth a rich embroidered canopy To kings that fear their subjects' treachery?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 9)
yes, it doth, a thousandfold it doth. And to conclude, the shepherd's homely curds, His cold thin drink out of his leather bottle, His wonted sleep under a fresh tree's shade, All which secure and sweetly he enjoys, Is far beyond a prince's delicates-- His viands sparkling in a golden cup, His body couched in a curious bed-- When care, mistrust, and treason waits on him.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 10)
Ill blows the wind that profits nobody. This man, whom hand to hand slew in fight, May be possessed with some store of crowns, And that haply take them from him now, May yet ere night yield both my life and them To some man else, as this dead man doth me.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 11)
Who's this? God! It is my father's face, Whom in this conflict unwares have killed.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 12)
heavy times, begetting such events! From London by the King was pressed forth.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 13)
My father, being the Earl of Warwick's man, Came on the part of York, pressed by his master.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 14)
And who at his hands received my life, Have by my hands of life bereaved him.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 15)
Pardon me, God, knew not what did; And pardon, father, for knew not thee.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 16)
My tears shall wipe away these bloody marks, And no more words till they have flowed their fill.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 17)
piteous spectacle! bloody times! Whiles lions war and battle for their dens, Poor harmless lambs abide their enmity.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 18)
Weep, wretched man. I'll aid thee tear for tear, And let our hearts and eyes, like civil war, Be blind with tears and break, o'ercharged with grief.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 19)
Thou that so stoutly hath resisted me, Give me thy gold, if thou hast any gold, For have bought it with an hundred blows.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 20)
But let me see: is this our foeman's face? Ah, no, no, no, it is mine only son!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 21)
Ah, boy, if any life be left in thee, Throw up thine eye!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 22)
See, see, what showers arise, Blown with the windy tempest of my heart Upon thy wounds, that kills mine eye and heart!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 23)
pity God this miserable age! What stratagems, how fell, how butcherly, Erroneous, mutinous, and unnatural This deadly quarrel daily doth beget!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 24)
boy, thy father gave thee life too soon, And hath bereft thee of thy life too late!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 25)
Woe above woe, grief more than common grief! that my death would stay these ruthful deeds!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 26)
pity, pity, gentle heaven, pity! The red rose and the white are on his face, The fatal colors of our striving houses; The one his purple blood right well resembles, The other his pale cheeks methinks presenteth.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 27)
Wither one rose and let the other flourish; If you contend, a thousand lives must wither.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 28)
How will my mother for a father's death Take on with me and ne'er be satisfied!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 29)
How will my wife for slaughter of my son Shed seas of tears and ne'er be satisfied!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 30)
How will the country for these woeful chances Misthink the King and not be satisfied!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 31)
Was ever son so rued a father's death?   Was ever father so bemoaned his son?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 32)
Was ever king so grieved for subjects' woe? Much is your sorrow, mine ten times so much.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 33)
I'll bear thee hence, where may weep my fill.    These arms of mine shall be thy winding-sheet; My heart, sweet boy, shall be thy sepulcher, For from my heart thine image ne'er shall go.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 34)
My sighing breast shall be thy funeral bell; And so obsequious will thy father be E'en for the loss of thee, having no more, As Priam was for all his valiant sons.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 35)
I'll bear thee hence, and let them fight that will, For have murdered where should not kill.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 36)
Sad-hearted men, much overgone with care, Here sits a king more woeful than you are.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 37)
Fly, father, fly, for all your friends are fled, And Warwick rages like a chafed bull.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 38)
Away, for Death doth hold us in pursuit.   Mount you, my lord; towards Berwick post amain.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 39)
Edward and Richard, like a brace of greyhounds Having the fearful flying hare in sight, With fiery eyes sparkling for very wrath And bloody steel grasped in their ireful hands, Are at our backs, and therefore hence amain.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 40)
Away, for Vengeance comes along with them. Nay, stay not to expostulate, make speed; Or else come after; I'll away before.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 41)
Nay, take me with thee, good sweet Exeter; Not that fear to stay, but love to go Whither the Queen intends.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 4, Scene 42)
loud alarum. Enter Clifford,     Here burns my candle out; ay, here it dies, Which whiles it lasted gave King Henry light.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 0)
Lancaster, fear thy overthrow More than my body's parting with my soul!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 1)
My love and fear glued many friends to thee; And now fall, thy tough commixtures melts, Impairing Henry, strength'ning misproud York; And whither fly the gnats but to the sun?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 2)
And who shines now but Henry's enemies? Phoebus, hadst thou never given consent That Phaeton should check thy fiery steeds, Thy burning car never had scorched the Earth!(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 3)
And Henry, hadst thou swayed as kings should do, Or as thy father and his father did, Giving no ground unto the house of York, They never then had sprung like summer flies; and ten thousand in this luckless realm Had left no mourning widows for our death, And thou this day hadst kept thy chair in peace.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 4)
For what doth cherish weeds but gentle air? And what makes robbers bold but too much lenity?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 5)
Bootless are plaints, and cureless are my wounds; No way to fly, no strength to hold out flight.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 6)
The foe is merciless and will not pity, For at their hands have deserved no pity.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 7)
The air hath got into my deadly wounds, And much effuse of blood doth make me faint.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 8)
Come, York and Richard, Warwick and the rest. stabbed your fathers' bosoms; split my breast.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 9)
Richard, and Soldiers, Montague, and George,     Now breathe we, lords.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 10)
Good fortune bids us pause And smooth the frowns of war with peaceful looks.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 11)
Some troops pursue the bloody-minded queen That led calm Henry, though he were a king, As doth a sail filled with a fretting gust Command an argosy to stem the waves.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 12)
But think you, lords, that Clifford fled with them?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 13)
No, 'tis impossible he should escape, For, though before his face speak the words, Your brother Richard marked him for the grave, And wheresoe'er he is, he's surely dead.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 14)
Whose soul is that which takes her heavy leave?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 15)
deadly groan, like life and death's departing.   See who it is; and, now the battle's ended, If friend or foe, let him be gently used.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 16)
Revoke that doom of mercy, for 'tis Clifford, Who not contented that he lopped the branch In hewing Rutland when his leaves put forth, But set his murd'ring knife unto the root From whence that tender spray did sweetly spring, mean our princely father, Duke of York.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 17)
From off the gates of York fetch down the head, Your father's head, which Clifford placed there; Instead whereof let this supply the room.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 18)
Measure for measure must be answered.   Bring forth that fatal screech owl to our house That nothing sung but death to us and ours; Now death shall stop his dismal threat'ning sound, And his ill-boding tongue no more shall speak.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 19)
think his understanding is bereft.-- Speak, Clifford, dost thou know who speaks to thee?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 20)
-- Dark cloudy death o'ershades his beams of life, And he nor sees nor hears us what we say.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 21)
would he did--and so, perhaps, he doth! 'Tis but his policy to counterfeit, Because he would avoid such bitter taunts Which in the time of death he gave our father.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 22)
If so thou think'st, vex him with eager words.   Clifford, ask mercy and obtain no grace.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 23)
Clifford, repent in bootless penitence.   Clifford, devise excuses for thy faults.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 24)
While we devise fell tortures for thy faults.   Thou didst love York, and am son to York.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 25)
Thou pitied'st Rutland; will pity thee.   Where's Captain Margaret to fence you now?(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 26)
They mock thee, Clifford; swear as thou wast wont.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 27)
What, not an oath? Nay, then, the world goes hard When Clifford cannot spare his friends an oath.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 28)
know by that he's dead; and, by my soul, If this right hand would buy but two hours' life That in all despite might rail at him, This hand should chop it off, and with the issuing blood Stifle the villain whose unstaunched thirst York and young Rutland could not satisfy.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 29)
Ay, but he's dead. Off with the traitor's head, And rear it in the place your father's stands.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 30)
And now to London with triumphant march, There to be crowned England's royal king, From whence shall Warwick cut the sea to France And ask the Lady Bona for thy queen; So shalt thou sinew both these lands together, And having France thy friend, thou shalt not dread The scattered foe that hopes to rise again; For though they cannot greatly sting to hurt, Yet look to have them buzz to offend thine ears.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 31)
First will see the coronation, And then to Brittany I'll cross the sea To effect this marriage, so it please my lord.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 32)
Even as thou wilt, sweet Warwick, let it be; For in thy shoulder do build my seat, And never will undertake the thing Wherein thy counsel and consent is wanting.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 33)
-- Richard, will create thee Duke of Gloucester, And George, of Clarence.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 34)
Warwick as ourself Shall do and undo as him pleaseth best.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 35)
Let me be Duke of Clarence, George of Gloucester, For Gloucester's dukedom is too ominous.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 36)
Tut, that's a foolish observation. Richard, be Duke of Gloucester.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 37)
Now to London, To see these honors in possession.(Henry VI, Part 3, Act 5, Scene 38)
Was not Count John here at supper?  saw him not.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 0)
How tartly that gentleman looks! never can see him but am heartburned an hour after.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 1)
He is of a very melancholy disposition.  He were an excellent man that were made just in the midway between him and Benedick.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 2)
The one is too like an image and says nothing, and the other too like my lady's eldest son, evermore tattling.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 3)
Then half Signior Benedick's tongue in Count John's mouth, and half Count John's melancholy in Signior Benedick's face--  With a good leg and a good foot, uncle, and money enough in his purse, such a man would win any woman in the world if he could get her goodwill.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 4)
By my troth, niece, thou wilt never get thee a husband if thou be so shrewd of thy tongue.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 5)
In faith, she's too curst.  Too curst is more than curst.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 6)
shall lessen God's sending that way, for it is said "God sends a curst cow short horns," but to a cow too curst, he sends none.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 7)
So, by being too curst, God will send you no horns.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 8)
Just, if He send me no husband, for the which blessing am at Him upon my knees every morning and evening.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 9)
Lord, could not endure a husband with a beard on his face.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 10)
had rather lie in the woolen!  You may light on a husband that hath no beard.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 11)
What should do with him? Dress him in my apparel and make him my waiting gentlewoman?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 12)
He that hath a beard is more than a youth, and he that hath no beard is less than a man; and he that is more than a youth is not for me, and he that is less than a man, am not for him.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 13)
Therefore will even take sixpence in earnest of the bearherd, and lead his apes into hell.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 14)
Well then, go you into hell?  No, but to the gate, and there will the devil meet me like an old cuckold with horns on his head, and say "Get you to heaven, Beatrice, get you to heaven; here's no place for you maids.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 15)
" So deliver up my apes and away to Saint Peter; for the heavens, he shows me where the bachelors sit, and there live we as merry as the day is long.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 16)
Well, niece, trust you will be ruled by your father.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 17)
Yes, faith, it is my cousin's duty to make curtsy and say "Father, as it please you.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 18)
" But yet for all that, cousin, let him be a handsome fellow, or else make another curtsy and say "Father, as it please me.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 19)
"  Well, niece, hope to see you one day fitted with a husband.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 20)
Not till God make men of some other metal than earth.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 21)
Would it not grieve a woman to be overmastered with a piece of valiant dust?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 22)
To make an account of her life to a clod of wayward marl?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 23)
No, uncle, I'll none. Adam's sons are my brethren, and truly hold it a sin to match in my kindred.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 24)
Daughter, remember what told you. If the Prince do solicit you in that kind, you know your answer.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 25)
The fault will be in the music, cousin, if you be not wooed in good time.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 26)
If the Prince be too important, tell him there is measure in everything, and so dance out the answer.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 27)
For hear me, Hero, wooing, wedding, and repenting is as a Scotch jig, a measure, and a cinquepace.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 28)
The first suit is hot and hasty like a Scotch jig, and full as fantastical; the wedding, mannerly modest as a measure, full of state and ancientry; and then comes repentance, and with his bad legs falls into the cinquepace faster and faster till he sink into his grave.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 29)
Cousin, you apprehend passing shrewdly.  have a good eye, uncle; can see a church by daylight.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 30)
The revelers are entering, brother. Make good room.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 31)
Benedick, Signior Antonio, and Balthasar, all in    Lady, will you walk a bout with your friend?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 32)
So you walk softly, and look sweetly, and say nothing, am yours for the walk, and especially when walk away.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 33)
With me in your company?  may say so when please.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 34)
And when please you to say so?  When like your favor, for God defend the lute should be like the case.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 35)
My visor is Philemon's roof; within the house is Jove.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 36)
Why, then, your visor should be thatched.  Speak low if you speak love.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 37)
Well, would you did like me.  So would not for your own sake, for have many ill qualities.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 38)
Which is one?  say my prayers aloud.  love you the better; the hearers may cry "Amen.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 39)
"  God match me with a good dancer.    Amen.  And God keep him out of my sight when the dance is done.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 40)
Answer, clerk.  No more words. The clerk is answered.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 41)
know you well enough. You are Signior Antonio.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 42)
At a word, am not.  know you by the waggling of your head.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 43)
To tell you true, counterfeit him.  You could never do him so ill-well unless you were the very man.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 44)
Here's his dry hand up and down. You are he, you are he.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 45)
At a word, am not.  Come, come, do you think do not know you by your excellent wit?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 46)
Can virtue hide itself? Go to, mum, you are he. Graces will appear, and there's an end.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 47)
Will you not tell me who told you so?  No, you shall pardon me.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 48)
Nor will you not tell me who you are?  Not now.  That was disdainful, and that had my good wit out of The Hundred Merry Tales!(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 49)
Well, this was Signior Benedick that said so.  What's he?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 50)
am sure you know him well enough.  Not believe me.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 51)
Did he never make you laugh?  pray you, what is he?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 52)
Why, he is the Prince's jester, a very dull fool; only his gift is in devising impossible slanders.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 53)
None but libertines delight in him, and the commendation is not in his wit but in his villainy, for he both pleases men and angers them, and then they laugh at him and beat him.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 54)
am sure he is in the fleet.I would he had boarded me.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 55)
When know the gentleman, I'll tell him what you say.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 56)
Do, do. He'll but break a comparison or two on me, which peradventure not marked or not laughed at strikes him into melancholy, and then there's a partridge wing saved, for the fool will eat no supper that night.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 57)
We must follow the leaders.  In every good thing.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 58)
Nay, if they lead to any ill, will leave them at the next turning.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 59)
Sure my brother is amorous on Hero, and hath withdrawn her father to break with him about it.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 60)
The ladies follow her, and but one visor remains.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 61)
And that is Claudio. know him by his bearing.  Are not you Signior Benedick?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 62)
You know me well. am he.  Signior, you are very near my brother in his love.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 63)
He is enamored on Hero. pray you dissuade him from her.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 64)
She is no equal for his birth. You may do the part of an honest man in it.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 65)
How know you he loves her?  heard him swear his affection.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 66)
So did too, and he swore he would marry her tonight.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 67)
Come, let us to the banquet.    Thus answer in name of Benedick, But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 68)
'Tis certain so. The Prince woos for himself. Friendship is constant in all other things Save in the office and affairs of love.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 69)
Therefore all hearts in love use their own tongues.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 70)
Let every eye negotiate for itself And trust no agent, for beauty is a witch Against whose charms faith melteth into blood.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 71)
This is an accident of hourly proof, Which mistrusted not.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 72)
Farewell therefore, Hero.     Count Claudio?  Yea, the same.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 73)
Come, will you go with me?  Whither?  Even to the next willow, about your own business, county.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 74)
What fashion will you wear the garland of? About your neck like an usurer's chain?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 75)
Or under your arm like a lieutenant's scarf? You must wear it one way, for the Prince hath got your Hero.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 76)
wish him joy of her.  Why, that's spoken like an honest drover; so they sell bullocks.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 77)
But did you think the Prince would have served you thus?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 78)
pray you, leave me.  Ho, now you strike like the blind man.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 79)
'Twas the boy that stole your meat, and you'll beat the post.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 80)
If it will not be, I'll leave you.  Alas, poor hurt fowl, now will he creep into sedges.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 81)
But that my Lady Beatrice should know me, and not know me!(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 82)
The Prince's fool! Ha, it may be go under that title because am merry.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 83)
Yea, but so am apt to do myself wrong. am not so reputed!(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 84)
It is the base, though bitter, disposition of Beatrice that puts the world into her person and so gives me out.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 85)
Well, I'll be revenged as may.     Now, signior, where's the Count?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 86)
Did you see him?  Troth, my lord, have played the part of Lady Fame.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 87)
found him here as melancholy as a lodge in a warren.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 88)
told him, and think told him true, that your Grace had got the goodwill of this young lady, and offered him my company to a willow tree, either to make him a garland, as being forsaken, or to bind him up a rod, as being worthy to be whipped.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 89)
To be whipped? What's his fault?  The flat transgression of a schoolboy who, being overjoyed with finding a bird's nest, shows it his companion, and he steals it.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 90)
Wilt thou make a trust a transgression? The transgression is in the stealer.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 91)
Yet it had not been amiss the rod had been made, and the garland too, for the garland he might have worn himself, and the rod he might have bestowed on you, who, as take it, have stolen his bird's nest.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 92)
will but teach them to sing and restore them to the owner.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 93)
If their singing answer your saying, by my faith, you say honestly.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 94)
The Lady Beatrice hath a quarrel to you. The gentleman that danced with her told her she is much wronged by you.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 95)
she misused me past the endurance of a block! An oak but with one green leaf on it would have answered her.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 96)
My very visor began to assume life and scold with her.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 97)
She told me, not thinking had been myself, that was the Prince's jester, that was duller than a great thaw, huddling jest upon jest with such impossible conveyance upon me that stood like a man at a mark with a whole army shooting at me.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 98)
She speaks poniards, and every word stabs. If her breath were as terrible as her terminations, there were no living near her; she would infect to the North Star.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 99)
would not marry her though she were endowed with all that Adam had left him before he transgressed.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 100)
She would have made Hercules have turned spit, yea, and have cleft his club to make the fire, too.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 101)
Come, talk not of her. You shall find her the infernal Ate in good apparel.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 102)
would to God some scholar would conjure her, for certainly, while she is here, a man may live as quiet in hell as in a sanctuary, and people sin upon purpose because they would go thither.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 103)
So indeed all disquiet, horror, and perturbation follows her.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 104)
Look, here she comes.  Will your Grace command me any service to the world's end?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 105)
will go on the slightest errand now to the Antipodes that you can devise to send me on.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 106)
will fetch you a toothpicker now from the furthest inch of Asia, bring you the length of Prester John's foot, fetch you a hair off the great Cham's beard, do you any embassage to the Pygmies, rather than hold three words' conference with this harpy.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 107)
You have no employment for me?  None but to desire your good company.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 108)
God, sir, here's a dish love not! cannot endure my Lady Tongue.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 109)
Come, lady, come, you have lost the heart of Signior Benedick.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 110)
Indeed, my lord, he lent it me awhile, and gave him use for it, a double heart for his single one.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 111)
Marry, once before he won it of me with false dice.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 112)
Therefore your Grace may well say have lost it.  You have put him down, lady, you have put him down.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 113)
So would not he should do me, my lord, lest should prove the mother of fools.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 114)
have brought Count Claudio, whom you sent me to seek.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 115)
Why, how now, count, wherefore are you sad?  Not sad, my lord.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 116)
How then, sick?  Neither, my lord.  The Count is neither sad, nor sick, nor merry, nor well, but civil count, civil as an orange, and something of that jealous complexion.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 117)
faith, lady, think your blazon to be true, though I'll be sworn, if he be so, his conceit is false.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 118)
--Here, Claudio, have wooed in thy name, and fair Hero is won.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 119)
have broke with her father and his goodwill obtained.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 120)
Name the day of marriage, and God give thee joy.  Count, take of me my daughter, and with her my fortunes.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 121)
His Grace hath made the match, and all grace say "Amen" to it.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 122)
Speak, count, 'tis your cue.  Silence is the perfectest herald of joy.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 123)
were but little happy if could say how much.--Lady, as you are mine, am yours.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 124)
give away myself for you and dote upon the exchange.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 125)
Speak, cousin, or, if you cannot, stop his mouth with a kiss and let not him speak neither.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 126)
In faith, lady, you have a merry heart.  Yea, my lord.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 127)
thank it, poor fool, it keeps on the windy side of care.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 128)
My cousin tells him in his ear that he is in her heart.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 129)
And so she doth, cousin.  Good Lord for alliance!(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 130)
Thus goes everyone to the world but and am sunburnt.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 131)
may sit in a corner and cry "Heigh-ho for a husband!(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 132)
"  Lady Beatrice, will get you one.  would rather have one of your father's getting.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 133)
Hath your Grace ne'er a brother like you? Your father got excellent husbands, if a maid could come by them.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 134)
Will you have me, lady?  No, my lord, unless might have another for working days.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 135)
Your Grace is too costly to wear every day. But beseech your Grace pardon me.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 136)
was born to speak all mirth and no matter.  Your silence most offends me, and to be merry best becomes you, for out o' question you were born in a merry hour.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 137)
No, sure, my lord, my mother cried, but then there was a star danced, and under that was born.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 138)
--Cousins, God give you joy!  Niece, will you look to those things told you of?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 139)
cry you mercy, uncle.--By your Grace's pardon.  By my troth, a pleasant-spirited lady.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 140)
There's little of the melancholy element in her, my lord.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 141)
She is never sad but when she sleeps, and not ever sad then, for have heard my daughter say she hath often dreamt of unhappiness and waked herself with laughing.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 142)
She cannot endure to hear tell of a husband.  by no means.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 143)
She mocks all her wooers out of suit.  She were an excellent wife for Benedick.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 144)
Lord, my lord, if they were but a week married, they would talk themselves mad.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 145)
County Claudio, when mean you to go to church?  Tomorrow, my lord.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 146)
Time goes on crutches till love have all his rites.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 147)
Not till Monday, my dear son, which is hence a just sevennight, and a time too brief, too, to have all things answer my mind.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 148)
Come, you shake the head at so long a breathing, but warrant thee, Claudio, the time shall not go dully by us.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 149)
will in the interim undertake one of Hercules' labors, which is to bring Signior Benedick and the Lady Beatrice into a mountain of affection, th' one with th' other.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 150)
would fain have it a match, and doubt not but to fashion it, if you three will but minister such assistance as shall give you direction.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 151)
My lord, am for you, though it cost me ten nights' watchings.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 152)
And my lord.  And you too, gentle Hero?  will do any modest office, my lord, to help my cousin to a good husband.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 153)
And Benedick is not the unhopefullest husband that know.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 154)
Thus far can praise him: he is of a noble strain, of approved valor, and confirmed honesty.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 155)
will teach you how to humor your cousin that she shall fall in love with Benedick.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 156)
-- And with your two helps, will so practice on Benedick that, in despite of his quick wit and his queasy stomach, he shall fall in love with Beatrice.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 157)
If we can do this, Cupid is no longer an archer; his glory shall be ours, for we are the only love gods.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 0, Scene 158)
It is so. The Count Claudio shall marry the daughter of Leonato.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 1, Scene 0)
Yea, my lord, but can cross it.  Any bar, any cross, any impediment will be med'cinable to me.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 1, Scene 1)
am sick in displeasure to him, and whatsoever comes athwart his affection ranges evenly with mine.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 1, Scene 2)
How canst thou cross this marriage?  Not honestly, my lord, but so covertly that no dishonesty shall appear in me.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 1, Scene 3)
Show me briefly how.  think told your Lordship a year since, how much am in the favor of Margaret, the waiting gentlewoman to Hero.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 1, Scene 4)
remember.  can, at any unseasonable instant of the night, appoint her to look out at her lady's chamber window.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 1, Scene 5)
What life is in that to be the death of this marriage?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 1, Scene 6)
The poison of that lies in you to temper. Go you to the Prince your brother; spare not to tell him that he hath wronged his honor in marrying the renowned Claudio, whose estimation do you mightily hold up, to a contaminated stale, such a one as Hero.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 1, Scene 7)
What proof shall make of that?  Proof enough to misuse the Prince, to vex Claudio, to undo Hero, and kill Leonato.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 1, Scene 8)
Look you for any other issue?  Only to despite them will endeavor anything.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 1, Scene 9)
Go then, find me a meet hour to draw Don Pedro and the Count Claudio alone.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 1, Scene 10)
Tell them that you know that Hero loves me; intend a kind of zeal both to the Prince and Claudio, as in love of your brother's honor, who hath made this match, and his friend's reputation, who is thus like to be cozened with the semblance of a maid, that you have discovered thus.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 1, Scene 11)
They will scarcely believe this without trial. Offer them instances, which shall bear no less likelihood than to see me at her chamber window, hear me call Margaret "Hero," hear Margaret term me "Claudio," and bring them to see this the very night before the intended wedding, for in the meantime will so fashion the matter that Hero shall be absent, and there shall appear such seeming truth of Hero's disloyalty that jealousy shall be called assurance and all the preparation overthrown.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 1, Scene 12)
Grow this to what adverse issue it can, will put it in practice.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 1, Scene 13)
Be cunning in the working this, and thy fee is a thousand ducats.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 1, Scene 14)
Be you constant in the accusation, and my cunning shall not shame me.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 1, Scene 15)
2       Boy!     Signior?  In my chamber window lies a book.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 0)
Bring it hither to me in the orchard.  am here already, sir.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 1)
know that, but would have thee hence and here again.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 2)
do much wonder that one man, seeing how much another man is a fool when he dedicates his behaviors to love, will, after he hath laughed at such shallow follies in others, become the argument of his own scorn by falling in love--and such a man is Claudio.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 3)
have known when there was no music with him but the drum and the fife, and now had he rather hear the tabor and the pipe; have known when he would have walked ten mile afoot to see a good armor, and now will he lie ten nights awake carving the fashion of a new doublet.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 4)
He was wont to speak plain and to the purpose, like an honest man and a soldier, and now is he turned orthography; his words are a very fantastical banquet, just so many strange dishes.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 5)
May be so converted and see with these eyes? cannot tell; think not.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 6)
will not be sworn but love may transform me to an oyster, but I'll take my oath on it, till he have made an oyster of me, he shall never make me such a fool.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 7)
One woman is fair, yet am well; another is wise, yet am well; another virtuous, yet am well; but till all graces be in one woman, one woman shall not come in my grace.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 8)
Rich she shall be, that's certain; wise, or I'll none; virtuous, or I'll never cheapen her; fair, or I'll never look on her; mild, or come not near me; noble, or not for an angel; of good discourse, an excellent musician, and her hair shall be of what color it please God.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 9)
Ha! The Prince and Monsieur Love! will hide me in the arbor.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 10)
Come, shall we hear this music?   Yea, my good lord.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 11)
How still the evening is, As hushed on purpose to grace harmony!(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 12)
See you where Benedick hath hid himself?   very well my lord.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 13)
The music ended, We'll fit the kid-fox with a pennyworth.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 14)
Come, Balthasar, we'll hear that song again.   good my lord, tax not so bad a voice To slander music any more than once.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 15)
It is the witness still of excellency To put a strange face on his own perfection.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 16)
pray thee, sing, and let me woo no more.   Because you talk of wooing, will sing, Since many a wooer doth commence his suit To her he thinks not worthy, yet he woos, Yet will he swear he loves.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 17)
Nay, pray thee, come, Or if thou wilt hold longer argument, Do it in notes.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 18)
Note this before my notes: There's not a note of mine that's worth the noting.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 19)
Why, these are very crotchets that he speaks! Note notes, forsooth, and nothing.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 20)
Now, divine air! Now is his soul ravished. Is it not strange that sheeps' guts should hale souls out of men's bodies?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 21)
Well, a horn for my money, when all's done.   Sigh no more, ladies, sigh no more, Men were deceivers ever, One foot in sea and one on shore, To one thing constant never.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 22)
Then sigh not so, but let them go, And be you blithe and bonny, Converting all your sounds of woe Into Hey, nonny nonny.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 23)
Sing no more ditties, sing no mo, Of dumps so dull and heavy.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 24)
The fraud of men was ever so, Since summer first was leavy.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 25)
Then sigh not so, but let them go, And be you blithe and bonny, Converting all your sounds of woe Into Hey, nonny nonny.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 26)
By my troth, a good song.  And an ill singer, my lord.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 27)
Ha, no, no, faith, thou sing'st well enough for a shift.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 28)
An he had been a dog that should have howled thus, they would have hanged him.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 29)
And pray God his bad voice bode no mischief. had as lief have heard the night raven, come what plague could have come after it.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 30)
Yea, marry, dost thou hear, Balthasar? pray thee get us some excellent music, for tomorrow night we would have it at the Lady Hero's chamber window.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 31)
The best can, my lord.  Do so. Farewell. Come hither, Leonato.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 32)
What was it you told me of today, that your niece Beatrice was in love with Signior Benedick?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 33)
ay.  Stalk on, stalk on; the fowl sits.--I did never think that lady would have loved any man.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 34)
No, nor neither, but most wonderful that she should so dote on Signior Benedick, whom she hath in all outward behaviors seemed ever to abhor.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 35)
Is 't possible? Sits the wind in that corner?  By my troth, my lord, cannot tell what to think of it, but that she loves him with an enraged affection, it is past the infinite of thought.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 36)
Maybe she doth but counterfeit.  Faith, like enough.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 37)
God! Counterfeit? There was never counterfeit of passion came so near the life of passion as she discovers it.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 38)
Why, what effects of passion shows she?  Bait the hook well; this fish will bite.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 39)
What effects, my lord? She will sit you--you heard my daughter tell you how.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 40)
She did indeed.  How, how pray you? You amaze me.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 41)
would have thought her spirit had been invincible against all assaults of affection.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 42)
would have sworn it had, my lord, especially against Benedick.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 43)
should think this a gull but that the white-bearded fellow speaks it.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 44)
Knavery cannot, sure, hide himself in such reverence.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 45)
He hath ta'en th' infection. Hold it up.  Hath she made her affection known to Benedick?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 46)
No, and swears she never will. That's her torment.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 47)
'Tis true indeed, so your daughter says. "Shall says she, "that have so oft encountered him with scorn, write to him that love him?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 48)
"  This says she now when she is beginning to write to him, for she'll be up twenty times a night, and there will she sit in her smock till she have writ a sheet of paper.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 49)
My daughter tells us all.  Now you talk of a sheet of paper, remember a pretty jest your daughter told us of.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 50)
when she had writ it and was reading it over, she found "Benedick" and "Beatrice" between the sheet?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 51)
That.  she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence, railed at herself that she should be so immodest to write to one that she knew would flout her.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 52)
measure him," says she, "by my own spirit, for should flout him if he writ to me, yea, though love him, should.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 53)
"  Then down upon her knees she falls, weeps, sobs, beats her heart, tears her hair, prays, curses: sweet Benedick, God give me patience!(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 54)
"  She doth indeed, my daughter says so, and the ecstasy hath so much overborne her that my daughter is sometimes afeared she will do a desperate outrage to herself.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 55)
It is very true.  It were good that Benedick knew of it by some other, if she will not discover it.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 56)
To what end? He would make but a sport of it and torment the poor lady worse.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 57)
An he should, it were an alms to hang him. She's an excellent sweet lady, and, out of all suspicion, she is virtuous.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 58)
And she is exceeding wise.  In everything but in loving Benedick.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 59)
my lord, wisdom and blood combating in so tender a body, we have ten proofs to one that blood hath the victory.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 60)
am sorry for her, as have just cause, being her uncle and her guardian.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 61)
would she had bestowed this dotage on me. would have daffed all other respects and made her half myself.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 62)
pray you tell Benedick of it, and hear what he will say.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 63)
Were it good, think you?  Hero thinks surely she will die, for she says she will die if he love her not, and she will die ere she make her love known, and she will die if he woo her rather than she will bate one breath of her accustomed crossness.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 64)
She doth well. If she should make tender of her love, 'tis very possible he'll scorn it, for the man, as you know all, hath a contemptible spirit.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 65)
He is a very proper man.  He hath indeed a good outward happiness.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 66)
Before God, and in my mind, very wise.  He doth indeed show some sparks that are like wit.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 67)
And take him to be valiant.  As Hector, assure you, and in the managing of quarrels you may say he is wise, for either he avoids them with great discretion or undertakes them with a most Christianlike fear.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 68)
If he do fear God, he must necessarily keep peace.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 69)
If he break the peace, he ought to enter into a quarrel with fear and trembling.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 70)
And so will he do, for the man doth fear God, howsoever it seems not in him by some large jests he will make.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 71)
Well, am sorry for your niece. Shall we go seek Benedick and tell him of her love?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 72)
Never tell him, my lord, let her wear it out with good counsel.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 73)
Nay, that's impossible; she may wear her heart out first.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 74)
Well, we will hear further of it by your daughter.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 75)
Let it cool the while. love Benedick well, and could wish he would modestly examine himself to see how much he is unworthy so good a lady.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 76)
My lord, will you walk? Dinner is ready.   If he do not dote on her upon this, will never trust my expectation.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 77)
Let there be the same net spread for her, and that must your daughter and her gentlewomen carry.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 78)
The sport will be when they hold one an opinion of another's dotage, and no such matter.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 79)
That's the scene that would see, which will be merely a dumb show.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 80)
Let us send her to call him in to dinner.   This can be no trick.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 81)
The conference was sadly borne; they have the truth of this from Hero; they seem to pity the lady.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 82)
It seems her affections have their full bent. Love me?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 83)
Why, it must be requited! hear how am censured. They say will bear myself proudly if perceive the love come from her.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 84)
They say, too, that she will rather die than give any sign of affection.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 85)
did never think to marry. must not seem proud. Happy are they that hear their detractions and can put them to mending.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 86)
They say the lady is fair; 'tis a truth, can bear them witness.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 87)
And virtuous; 'tis so, cannot reprove it. And wise, but for loving me; by my troth, it is no addition to her wit, nor no great argument of her folly, for will be horribly in love with her!(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 88)
may chance have some odd quirks and remnants of wit broken on me because have railed so long against marriage, but doth not the appetite alter?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 89)
man loves the meat in his youth that he cannot endure in his age.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 90)
Shall quips and sentences and these paper bullets of the brain awe a man from the career of his humor?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 91)
No! The world must be peopled. When said would die a bachelor, did not think should live till were married.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 92)
Here comes Beatrice. By this day, she's a fair lady.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 93)
do spy some marks of love in her.     Against my will, am sent to bid you come in to dinner.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 94)
Fair Beatrice, thank you for your pains.  took no more pains for those thanks than you take pains to thank me.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 95)
If it had been painful, would not have come.  You take pleasure then in the message?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 96)
Yea, just so much as you may take upon a knife's point and choke a daw withal.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 97)
You have no stomach, signior. Fare you well.  Ha!(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 98)
"Against my will am sent to bid you come in to dinner.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 99)
" There's a double meaning in that. took no more pains for those thanks than you took pains to thank me.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 100)
" That's as much as to say "Any pains that take for you is as easy as thanks.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 101)
" If do not take pity of her, am a villain; if do not love her, am a Jew.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 2, Scene 102)
Good Margaret, run thee to the parlor. There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice Proposing with the Prince and Claudio.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 0)
Whisper her ear and tell her and Ursula Walk in the orchard, and our whole discourse Is all of her.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 1)
Say that thou overheardst us, And bid her steal into the pleached bower Where honeysuckles ripened by the sun Forbid the sun to enter, like favorites, Made proud by princes, that advance their pride Against that power that bred it.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 2)
There will she hide her To listen our propose. This is thy office.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 3)
Bear thee well in it, and leave us alone.   I'll make her come, warrant you, presently.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 4)
Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come, As we do trace this alley up and down, Our talk must only be of Benedick.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 5)
When do name him, let it be thy part To praise him more than ever man did merit.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 6)
My talk to thee must be how Benedick Is sick in love with Beatrice.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 7)
Of this matter Is little Cupid's crafty arrow made, That only wounds by hearsay.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 8)
Now begin, For look where Beatrice like a lapwing runs Close by the ground, to hear our conference.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 9)
The pleasant'st angling is to see the fish Cut with her golden oars the silver stream And greedily devour the treacherous bait.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 10)
So angle we for Beatrice, who even now Is couched in the woodbine coverture.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 11)
Fear you not my part of the dialogue.   Then go we near her, that her ear lose nothing Of the false sweet bait that we lay for it.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 12)
--  No, truly, Ursula, she is too disdainful. know her spirits are as coy and wild As haggards of the rock.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 13)
But are you sure That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 14)
So says the Prince and my new-trothed lord.   And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 15)
They did entreat me to acquaint her of it, But persuaded them, if they loved Benedick, To wish him wrestle with affection And never to let Beatrice know of it.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 16)
Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman Deserve as full as fortunate a bed As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 17)
god of love! know he doth deserve As much as may be yielded to a man, But Nature never framed a woman's heart Of prouder stuff than that of Beatrice.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 18)
Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes, Misprizing what they look on, and her wit Values itself so highly that to her All matter else seems weak.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 19)
She cannot love, Nor take no shape nor project of affection, She is so self-endeared.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 20)
Sure, think so, And therefore certainly it were not good She knew his love, lest she'll make sport at it.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 21)
Why, you speak truth. never yet saw man, How wise, how noble, young, how rarely featured, But she would spell him backward.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 22)
If fair-faced, She would swear the gentleman should be her sister; If black, why, Nature, drawing of an antic, Made a foul blot; if tall, a lance ill-headed; If low, an agate very vilely cut; If speaking, why, a vane blown with all winds; If silent, why, a block moved with none.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 23)
So turns she every man the wrong side out, And never gives to truth and virtue that Which simpleness and merit purchaseth.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 24)
Sure, sure, such carping is not commendable.   No, not to be so odd and from all fashions As Beatrice is cannot be commendable.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 25)
But who dare tell her so? If should speak, She would mock me into air.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 26)
she would laugh me Out of myself, press me to death with wit.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 27)
Therefore let Benedick, like covered fire, Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 28)
It were a better death than die with mocks, Which is as bad as die with tickling.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 29)
Yet tell her of it. Hear what she will say.   No, rather will go to Benedick And counsel him to fight against his passion; And truly I'll devise some honest slanders To stain my cousin with.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 30)
One doth not know How much an ill word may empoison liking.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 31)
do not do your cousin such a wrong! She cannot be so much without true judgment, Having so swift and excellent a wit As she is prized to have, as to refuse So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 32)
He is the only man of Italy, Always excepted my dear Claudio.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 33)
pray you be not angry with me, madam, Speaking my fancy: Signior Benedick, For shape, for bearing, argument, and valor, Goes foremost in report through Italy.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 34)
Indeed, he hath an excellent good name.   His excellence did earn it ere he had it.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 35)
When are you married, madam?   Why, every day, tomorrow.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 36)
Come, go in. I'll show thee some attires and have thy counsel Which is the best to furnish me tomorrow.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 37)
She's limed, warrant you. We have caught her, madam.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 38)
If it prove so, then loving goes by haps; Some Cupid kills with arrows, some with traps.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 39)
What fire is in mine ears? Can this be true? Stand condemned for pride and scorn so much?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 40)
Contempt, farewell, and maiden pride, adieu! No glory lives behind the back of such.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 41)
And Benedick, love on; will requite thee, Taming my wild heart to thy loving hand.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 42)
If thou dost love, my kindness shall incite thee To bind our loves up in a holy band.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 43)
For others say thou dost deserve, and Believe it better than reportingly.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 17, Scene 44)
do but stay till your marriage be consummate, and then go toward Aragon.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 0)
I'll bring you thither, my lord, if you'll vouchsafe me.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 1)
Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new gloss of your marriage as to show a child his new coat and forbid him to wear it.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 2)
will only be bold with Benedick for his company, for from the crown of his head to the sole of his foot he is all mirth.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 3)
He hath twice or thrice cut Cupid's bowstring, and the little hangman dare not shoot at him.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 4)
He hath a heart as sound as a bell, and his tongue is the clapper, for what his heart thinks, his tongue speaks.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 5)
Gallants, am not as have been.  So say Methinks you are sadder.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 6)
hope he be in love.  Hang him, truant! There's no true drop of blood in him to be truly touched with love.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 7)
If he be sad, he wants money.  have the toothache.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 8)
Draw it.  Hang it!  You must hang it first, and draw it afterwards.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 9)
What, sigh for the toothache?  Where is but a humor or a worm.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 10)
Well, everyone can master a grief but he that has it.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 11)
Yet say he is in love.  There is no appearance of fancy in him, unless it be a fancy that he hath to strange disguises, as to be a Dutchman today, a Frenchman tomorrow, or in the shape of two countries at once, as a German from the waist downward, all slops, and a Spaniard from the hip upward, no doublet.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 12)
Unless he have a fancy to this foolery, as it appears he hath, he is no fool for fancy, as you would have it appear he is.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 13)
If he be not in love with some woman, there is no believing old signs.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 14)
He brushes his hat o' mornings. What should that bode?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 15)
Hath any man seen him at the barber's?  No, but the barber's man hath been seen with him, and the old ornament of his cheek hath already stuffed tennis balls.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 16)
Indeed he looks younger than he did, by the loss of a beard.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 17)
Nay, he rubs himself with civet. Can you smell him out by that?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 18)
That's as much as to say, the sweet youth's in love.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 19)
The greatest note of it is his melancholy.  And when was he wont to wash his face?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 20)
Yea, or to paint himself? For the which hear what they say of him.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 21)
Nay, but his jesting spirit, which is now crept into a lute string and now governed by stops--  Indeed, that tells a heavy tale for him.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 22)
Conclude, conclude, he is in love.  Nay, but know who loves him.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 23)
That would know, too. warrant, one that knows him not.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 24)
Yes, and his ill conditions; and, in despite of all, dies for him.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 25)
She shall be buried with her face upwards.  Yet is this no charm for the toothache.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 26)
-- Old signior, walk aside with me. have studied eight or nine wise words to speak to you, which these hobby-horses must not hear.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 27)
For my life, to break with him about Beatrice!  'Tis even so.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 28)
Hero and Margaret have by this played their parts with Beatrice, and then the two bears will not bite one another when they meet.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 29)
My lord and brother, God save you.  Good e'en, brother.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 30)
If your leisure served, would speak with you.  In private?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 31)
If it please you. Yet Count Claudio may hear, for what would speak of concerns him.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 32)
What's the matter?  Means your Lordship to be married tomorrow?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 33)
You know he does.  know not that, when he knows what know.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 34)
If there be any impediment, pray you discover it.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 35)
You may think love you not. Let that appear hereafter, and aim better at me by that now will manifest.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 36)
For my brother, think he holds you well, and in dearness of heart hath holp to effect your ensuing marriage--surely suit ill spent and labor ill bestowed.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 37)
Why, what's the matter?  came hither to tell you; and, circumstances shortened, for she has been too long a-talking of, the lady is disloyal.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 38)
Who, Hero?  Even she: Leonato's Hero, your Hero, every man's Hero.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 39)
Disloyal?  The word is too good to paint out her wickedness.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 40)
could say she were worse. Think you of a worse title, and will fit her to it.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 41)
Wonder not till further warrant. Go but with me tonight, you shall see her chamber window entered, even the night before her wedding day.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 42)
If you love her then, tomorrow wed her. But it would better fit your honor to change your mind.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 43)
May this be so?  will not think it.  If you dare not trust that you see, confess not that you know.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 44)
If you will follow me, will show you enough, and when you have seen more and heard more, proceed accordingly.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 45)
