If see anything tonight why should not marry her, tomorrow in the congregation, where should wed, there will shame her.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 46)
And as wooed for thee to obtain her, will join with thee to disgrace her.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 47)
will disparage her no farther till you are my witnesses.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 48)
Bear it coldly but till midnight, and let the issue show itself.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 49)
day untowardly turned!  mischief strangely thwarting!(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 50)
plague right well prevented! So will you say when you have seen the sequel.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 18, Scene 51)
3        Are you good men and true?  Yea, or else it were pity but they should suffer salvation, body and soul.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 0)
Nay, that were a punishment too good for them if they should have any allegiance in them, being chosen for the Prince's watch.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 1)
Well, give them their charge, neighbor Dogberry.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 2)
First, who think you the most desartless man to be constable?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 3)
Hugh Oatcake, sir, or George Seacoal, for they can write and read.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 4)
Come hither, neighbor Seacoal. God hath blessed you with a good name.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 5)
To be a well-favored man is the gift of fortune, but to write and read comes by nature.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 6)
Both which, master constable--  You have. knew it would be your answer.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 7)
Well, for your favor, sir, why, give God thanks, and make no boast of it, and for your writing and reading, let that appear when there is no need of such vanity.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 8)
You are thought here to be the most senseless and fit man for the constable of the watch; therefore bear you the lantern.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 9)
This is your charge: you shall comprehend all vagrom men; you are to bid any man stand, in the Prince's name.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 10)
How if he will not stand?  Why, then, take no note of him, but let him go, and presently call the rest of the watch together and thank God you are rid of a knave.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 11)
If he will not stand when he is bidden, he is none of the Prince's subjects.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 12)
True, and they are to meddle with none but the Prince's subjects.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 13)
--You shall also make no noise in the streets; for, for the watch to babble and to talk is most tolerable and not to be endured.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 14)
We will rather sleep than talk. We know what belongs to a watch.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 15)
Why, you speak like an ancient and most quiet watchman, for cannot see how sleeping should offend; only have a care that your bills be not stolen.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 16)
Well, you are to call at all the alehouses and bid those that are drunk get them to bed.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 17)
How if they will not?  Why then, let them alone till they are sober.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 18)
If they make you not then the better answer, you may say they are not the men you took them for.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 19)
Well, sir.  If you meet a thief, you may suspect him, by virtue of your office, to be no true man, and for such kind of men, the less you meddle or make with them, why, the more is for your honesty.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 20)
If we know him to be a thief, shall we not lay hands on him?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 21)
Truly, by your office you may, but think they that touch pitch will be defiled.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 22)
The most peaceable way for you, if you do take a thief, is to let him show himself what he is and steal out of your company.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 23)
You have been always called a merciful man, partner.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 24)
Truly, would not hang a dog by my will, much more a man who hath any honesty in him.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 25)
If you hear a child cry in the night, you must call to the nurse and bid her still it.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 26)
How if the nurse be asleep and will not hear us?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 27)
Why, then depart in peace, and let the child wake her with crying, for the ewe that will not hear her lamb when it baas will never answer a calf when he bleats.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 28)
'Tis very true.  This is the end of the charge. You, constable, are to present the Prince's own person.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 29)
If you meet the Prince in the night, you may stay him.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 30)
Nay, by 'r Lady, that think he cannot.  Five shillings to one on 't, with any man that knows the statutes, he may stay him--marry, not without the Prince be willing, for indeed the watch ought to offend no man, and it is an offense to stay a man against his will.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 31)
By 'r Lady, think it be so.  Ha, ah ha!--Well, masters, goodnight.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 32)
An there be any matter of weight chances, call up me.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 33)
Keep your fellows' counsels and your own, and goodnight.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 34)
--Come, neighbor.   Well, masters, we hear our charge.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 35)
Let us go sit here upon the church bench till two, and then all to bed.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 36)
One word more, honest neighbors. pray you watch about Signior Leonato's door, for the wedding being there tomorrow, there is a great coil tonight.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 37)
Adieu, be vigitant, beseech you.      What, Conrade!(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 38)
Peace, stir not.  Conrade, say!  Here, man, am at thy elbow.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 39)
Mass, and my elbow itched, thought there would a scab follow.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 40)
will owe thee an answer for that. And now forward with thy tale.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 41)
Stand thee close, then, under this penthouse, for it drizzles rain, and will, like a true drunkard, utter all to thee.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 42)
Some treason, masters. Yet stand close.  Therefore know, have earned of Don John a thousand ducats.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 43)
Is it possible that any villainy should be so dear?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 44)
Thou shouldst rather ask if it were possible any villainy should be so rich.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 45)
For when rich villains have need of poor ones, poor ones may make what price they will.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 46)
wonder at it.  That shows thou art unconfirmed. Thou knowest that the fashion of a doublet, or a hat, or a cloak, is nothing to a man.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 47)
Yes, it is apparel.  mean the fashion.  Yes, the fashion is the fashion.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 48)
Tush, may as well say the fool's the fool. But seest thou not what a deformed thief this fashion is?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 49)
know that Deformed. He has been a vile thief this seven year.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 50)
He goes up and down like a gentleman. remember his name.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 51)
Didst thou not hear somebody?  No, 'twas the vane on the house.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 52)
Seest thou not, say, what a deformed thief this fashion is, how giddily he turns about all the hot bloods between fourteen and five-and-thirty, sometimes fashioning them like Pharaoh's soldiers in the reechy painting, sometimes like god Bel's priests in the old church window, sometimes like the shaven Hercules in the smirched worm-eaten tapestry, where his codpiece seems as massy as his club?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 53)
All this see, and see that the fashion wears out more apparel than the man.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 54)
But art not thou thyself giddy with the fashion too, that thou hast shifted out of thy tale into telling me of the fashion?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 55)
Not so, neither. But know that have tonight wooed Margaret, the Lady Hero's gentlewoman, by the name of Hero.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 56)
She leans me out at her mistress' chamber window, bids me a thousand times goodnight.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 57)
tell this tale vilely. should first tell thee how the Prince, Claudio, and my master, planted and placed and possessed by my master Don John, saw afar off in the orchard this amiable amiable encounter.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 58)
And thought they Margaret was Hero?  Two of them did, the Prince and Claudio, but the devil my master knew she was Margaret; and partly by his oaths, which first possessed them, partly by the dark night, which did deceive them, but chiefly by my villainy, which did confirm any slander that Don John had made, away went Claudio enraged, swore he would meet her as he was appointed next morning at the temple, and there, before the whole congregation, shame her with what he saw o'ernight and send her home again without a husband.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 59)
We charge you in the Prince's name stand!  Call up the right Master Constable.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 60)
We have here recovered the most dangerous piece of lechery that ever was known in the commonwealth.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 61)
And one Deformed is one of them. know him; he wears a lock.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 62)
Masters, masters--  You'll be made bring Deformed forth, warrant you.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 63)
Masters, never speak, we charge you, let us obey you to go with us.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 64)
We are like to prove a goodly commodity, being taken up of these men's bills.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 65)
commodity in question, warrant you.-- Come, we'll obey you.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 19, Scene 66)
Good Ursula, wake my cousin Beatrice and desire her to rise.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 0)
will, lady.  And bid her come hither.  Well.  Troth, think your other rebato were better.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 1)
No, pray thee, good Meg, I'll wear this.  By my troth, 's not so good, and warrant your cousin will say so.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 2)
My cousin's a fool, and thou art another. I'll wear none but this.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 3)
like the new tire within excellently, if the hair were a thought browner; and your gown's a most rare fashion, i' faith.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 4)
saw the Duchess of Milan's gown that they praise so.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 5)
that exceeds, they say.  By my troth, 's but a nightgown in respect of yours--cloth o' gold, and cuts, and laced with silver, set with pearls, down sleeves, side sleeves, and skirts round underborne with a bluish tinsel.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 6)
But for a fine, quaint, graceful, and excellent fashion, yours is worth ten on 't.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 7)
God give me joy to wear it, for my heart is exceeding heavy.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 8)
'Twill be heavier soon by the weight of a man.  Fie upon thee!(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 9)
Art not ashamed?  Of what, lady? Of speaking honorably?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 10)
Is not marriage honorable in a beggar? Is not your lord honorable without marriage?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 11)
think you would have me say "Saving your reverence, a husband.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 12)
" An bad thinking do not wrest true speaking, I'll offend nobody.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 13)
Is there any harm in "the heavier for a husband"?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 14)
None, think, an it be the right husband and the right wife.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 15)
Otherwise, 'tis light and not heavy. Ask my lady Beatrice else.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 16)
Here she comes.     Good morrow, coz.  Good morrow, sweet Hero.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 17)
Why, how now? Do you speak in the sick tune?  am out of all other tune, methinks.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 18)
Clap 's into "Light o' love." That goes without a burden.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 19)
Do you sing it, and I'll dance it.  You light o' love with your heels!(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 20)
Then, if your husband have stables enough, you'll see he shall lack no barns.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 21)
illegitimate construction! scorn that with my heels.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 22)
'Tis almost five o'clock, cousin. 'Tis time you were ready.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 23)
By my troth, am exceeding ill. Heigh-ho!  For a hawk, a horse, or a husband?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 24)
For the letter that begins them all,  Well, an you be not turned Turk, there's no more sailing by the star.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 25)
What means the fool, trow?  Nothing, but God send everyone their heart's desire.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 26)
These gloves the Count sent me, they are an excellent perfume.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 27)
am stuffed, cousin. cannot smell.  maid, and stuffed!(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 28)
There's goodly catching of cold.  God help me, God help me!(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 29)
How long have you professed apprehension?  Ever since you left it.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 30)
Doth not my wit become me rarely?  It is not seen enough; you should wear it in your cap.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 31)
By my troth, am sick.  Get you some of this distilled carduus benedictus and lay it to your heart.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 32)
It is the only thing for a qualm.  There thou prick'st her with a thistle.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 33)
Benedictus! Why benedictus? You have some moral in this benedictus?(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 34)
Moral? No, by my troth, have no moral meaning; meant plain holy thistle.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 35)
You may think perchance that think you are in love.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 36)
Nay, by 'r Lady, am not such a fool to think what list, nor list not to think what can, nor indeed cannot think, if would think my heart out of thinking, that you are in love or that you will be in love or that you can be in love.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 37)
Yet Benedick was such another, and now is he become a man.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 38)
He swore he would never marry, and yet now, in despite of his heart, he eats his meat without grudging.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 39)
And how you may be converted know not, but methinks you look with your eyes as other women do.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 40)
What pace is this that thy tongue keeps?  Not a false gallop.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 41)
Madam, withdraw. The Prince, the Count, Signior Benedick, Don John, and all the gallants of the town are come to fetch you to church.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 42)
Help to dress me, good coz, good Meg, good Ursula.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 20, Scene 43)
What would you with me, honest neighbor?  Marry, sir, would have some confidence with you that decerns you nearly.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 0)
Brief, pray you, for you see it is a busy time with me.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 1)
Marry, this it is, sir.  Yes, in truth, it is, sir.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 2)
What is it, my good friends?  Goodman Verges, sir, speaks a little off the matter.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 3)
An old man, sir, and his wits are not so blunt as, God help, would desire they were, but, in faith, honest as the skin between his brows.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 4)
Yes, thank God am as honest as any man living that is an old man and no honester than  Comparisons are odorous.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 5)
Palabras, neighbor Verges.  Neighbors, you are tedious.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 6)
It pleases your Worship to say so, but we are the poor duke's officers.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 7)
But truly, for mine own part, if were as tedious as a king, could find in my heart to bestow it all of your Worship.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 8)
All thy tediousness on me, ah?  Yea, an 'twere a thousand pound more than 'tis, for hear as good exclamation on your Worship as of any man in the city, and though be but a poor man, am glad to hear it.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 9)
And so am  would fain know what you have to say.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 10)
Marry, sir, our watch tonight, excepting your Worship's presence, ha' ta'en a couple of as arrant knaves as any in Messina.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 11)
good old man, sir. He will be talking. As they say, "When the age is in, the wit is out.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 12)
" God help us, it is a world to see!--Well said, i' faith, neighbor Verges.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 13)
--Well, God's a good man. An two men ride of a horse, one must ride behind.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 14)
An honest soul, i' faith, sir, by my troth he is, as ever broke bread, but God is to be worshiped, all men are not alike, alas, good neighbor.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 15)
Indeed, neighbor, he comes too short of you.  Gifts that God gives.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 16)
must leave you.  One word, sir. Our watch, sir, have indeed comprehended two aspicious persons, and we would have them this morning examined before your Worship.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 17)
Take their examination yourself and bring it me.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 18)
am now in great haste, as it may appear unto you.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 19)
It shall be suffigance.  Drink some wine ere you go.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 20)
Fare you well.     My lord, they stay for you to give your daughter to her husband.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 21)
I'll wait upon them. am ready.   Go, good partner, go, get you to Francis Seacoal.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 22)
Bid him bring his pen and inkhorn to the jail. We are now to examination these men.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 23)
And we must do it wisely.  We will spare for no wit, warrant you.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 24)
Here's that shall drive some of them to a noncome.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 25)
Only get the learned writer to set down our excommunication and meet me at the jail.(Much Ado About Nothing, Act 21, Scene 26)
If the great gods be just, they shall assist The deeds of justest men.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 0)
Know, worthy Pompey, That what they do delay they not deny.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 1)
Whiles we are suitors to their throne, decays The thing we sue for.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 2)
We, ignorant of ourselves, Beg often our own harms, which the wise powers Deny us for our good; so find we profit By losing of our prayers.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 3)
shall do well. The people love me, and the sea is mine; My powers are crescent, and my auguring hope Says it will come to th' full.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 4)
Mark Antony In Egypt sits at dinner, and will make No wars without doors.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 5)
Caesar gets money where He loses hearts. Lepidus flatters both, Of both is flattered; but he neither loves, Nor either cares for him.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 6)
Caesar and Lepidus Are in the field. mighty strength they carry.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 7)
Where have you this? 'Tis false.  From Silvius, sir.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 8)
He dreams. know they are in Rome together, Looking for Antony.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 9)
But all the charms of love, Salt Cleopatra, soften thy wanned lip!(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 10)
Let witchcraft join with beauty, lust with both; Tie up the libertine in a field of feasts; Keep his brain fuming.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 11)
Epicurean cooks Sharpen with cloyless sauce his appetite, That sleep and feeding may prorogue his honor Even till a Lethe'd dullness--    How now, Varrius?(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 12)
This is most certain that shall deliver: Mark Antony is every hour in Rome Expected.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 13)
Since he went from Egypt 'tis space for farther travel.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 14)
could have given less matter better ear.--Menas, did not think This amorous surfeiter would have donned his helm For such a petty war.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 15)
His soldiership Is twice the other twain. But let us rear The higher our opinion, that our stirring Can from the lap of Egypt's widow pluck The ne'er lust-wearied Antony.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 16)
cannot hope Caesar and Antony shall well greet together.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 17)
His wife that's dead did trespasses to Caesar; His brother warred upon him, although think Not moved by Antony.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 18)
know not, Menas, How lesser enmities may give way to greater.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 19)
Were 't not that we stand up against them all, 'Twere pregnant they should square between themselves, For they have entertained cause enough To draw their swords.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 20)
But how the fear of us May cement their divisions and bind up The petty difference, we yet not know.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 21)
Be 't as our gods will have 't. It only stands Our lives upon to use our strongest hands.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 0, Scene 22)
Good Enobarbus, 'tis a worthy deed, And shall become you well, to entreat your captain To soft and gentle speech.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 0)
shall entreat him To answer like himself. If Caesar move him, Let Antony look over Caesar's head And speak as loud as Mars.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 1)
By Jupiter, Were the wearer of Antonio's beard, would not shave 't today.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 2)
'Tis not a time for private stomaching.  Every time serves for the matter that is then born in 't.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 3)
But small to greater matters must give way.  Not if the small come first.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 4)
Your speech is passion; but pray you stir No embers up.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 5)
Here comes the noble Antony.     And yonder Caesar.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 6)
If we compose well here, to Parthia. Hark, Ventidius.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 7)
do not know, Maecenas. Ask Agrippa.  Noble friends, That which combined us was most great, and let not leaner action rend us.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 8)
What's amiss, May it be gently heard. When we debate Our trivial difference loud, we do commit Murder in healing wounds.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 9)
Then, noble partners, The rather for earnestly beseech, Touch you the sourest points with sweetest terms, Nor curstness grow to th' matter.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 10)
'Tis spoken well. Were we before our armies, and to fight, should do thus.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 11)
Welcome to Rome.  Thank you.  Sit.  Sit, sir.  Nay, then.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 12)
learn you take things ill which are not so, Or, being, concern you not.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 13)
must be laughed at If or for nothing or a little, Should say myself offended, and with you Chiefly i' th' world; more laughed at, that should Once name you derogately when to sound your name It not concerned me.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 14)
My being in Egypt, Caesar, what was 't to you?   No more than my residing here at Rome Might be to you in Egypt.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 15)
Yet if you there Did practice on my state, your being in Egypt Might be my question.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 16)
How intend you, practiced?   You may be pleased to catch at mine intent By what did here befall me.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 17)
Your wife and brother Made wars upon me, and their contestation Was theme for you; you were the word of war.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 18)
You do mistake your business. My brother never Did urge me in his act.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 19)
did inquire it, And have my learning from some true reports That drew their swords with you.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 20)
Did he not rather Discredit my authority with yours, And make the wars alike against my stomach, Having alike your cause?(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 21)
Of this my letters Before did satisfy you. If you'll patch a quarrel, As matter whole you have to make it with, It must not be with this.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 22)
You praise yourself By laying defects of judgment to me; but You patched up your excuses.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 23)
Not so, not so. know you could not lack--I am certain on 't-- Very necessity of this thought, that Your partner in the cause 'gainst which he fought, Could not with graceful eyes attend those wars Which fronted mine own peace.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 24)
As for my wife, would you had her spirit in such another.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 25)
The third o' th' world is yours, which with a snaffle You may pace easy, but not such a wife.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 26)
Would we had all such wives, that the men might go to wars with the women!(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 27)
So much uncurbable, her garboils, Caesar, Made out of her impatience--which not wanted Shrewdness of policy too--I grieving grant Did you too much disquiet.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 28)
For that you must But say could not help it.  wrote to you When rioting in Alexandria; you Did pocket up my letters, and with taunts Did gibe my missive out of audience.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 29)
Sir, He fell upon me ere admitted, then; Three kings had newly feasted, and did want Of what was i' th' morning.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 30)
But next day told him of myself, which was as much As to have asked him pardon.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 31)
Let this fellow Be nothing of our strife; if we contend, Out of our question wipe him.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 32)
You have broken The article of your oath, which you shall never Have tongue to charge me with.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 33)
Soft, Caesar!  No, Lepidus, let him speak. The honor is sacred which he talks on now, Supposing that lacked it.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 34)
--But on, Caesar: The article of my oath?   To lend me arms and aid when required them, The which you both denied.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 35)
Neglected, rather; And then when poisoned hours had bound me up From mine own knowledge.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 36)
As nearly as may I'll play the penitent to you. But mine honesty Shall not make poor my greatness, nor my power Work without it.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 37)
Truth is that Fulvia, To have me out of Egypt, made wars here, For which myself, the ignorant motive, do So far ask pardon as befits mine honor To stoop in such a case.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 38)
'Tis noble spoken.   If it might please you to enforce no further The griefs between you, to forget them quite Were to remember that the present need Speaks to atone you.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 39)
Worthily spoken, Maecenas.  Or, if you borrow one another's love for the instant, you may, when you hear no more words of Pompey, return it again.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 40)
You shall have time to wrangle in when you have nothing else to do.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 41)
Thou art a soldier only. Speak no more.  That truth should be silent had almost forgot.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 42)
You wrong this presence; therefore speak no more.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 43)
Go to, then. Your considerate stone.   do not much dislike the matter, but The manner of his speech; for 't cannot be We shall remain in friendship, our conditions So diff'ring in their acts.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 44)
Yet if knew What hoop should hold us staunch, from edge to edge th' world would pursue it.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 45)
Give me leave, Caesar.  Speak, Agrippa.   Thou hast a sister by the mother's side, Admired Octavia.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 46)
Great Mark Antony Is now a widower.  Say not so, Agrippa.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 47)
If Cleopatra heard you, your reproof Were well deserved of rashness.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 48)
am not married, Caesar. Let me hear Agrippa further speak.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 49)
To hold you in perpetual amity, To make you brothers, and to knit your hearts With an unslipping knot, take Antony Octavia to his wife, whose beauty claims No worse a husband than the best of men; Whose virtue and whose general graces speak That which none else can utter.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 50)
By this marriage All little jealousies, which now seem great, And all great fears, which now import their dangers, Would then be nothing.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 51)
Truths would be tales, Where now half-tales be truths.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 52)
Her love to both Would each to other and all loves to both Draw after her.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 53)
Pardon what have spoke, For 'tis a studied, not a present thought, By duty ruminated.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 54)
Will Caesar speak?   Not till he hears how Antony is touched With what is spoke already.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 55)
What power is in Agrippa, If would say "Agrippa, be it so," To make this good?(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 56)
The power of Caesar, and His power unto Octavia.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 57)
May never To this good purpose, that so fairly shows, Dream of impediment.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 58)
Let me have thy hand. Further this act of grace; and from this hour The heart of brothers govern in our loves And sway our great designs.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 59)
There's my hand.  sister bequeath you whom no brother Did ever love so dearly.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 60)
Let her live To join our kingdoms and our hearts; and never Fly off our loves again.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 61)
Happily, amen!   did not think to draw my sword 'gainst Pompey, For he hath laid strange courtesies and great Of late upon me.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 62)
must thank him only, Lest my remembrance suffer ill report; At heel of that, defy him.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 63)
Time calls upon 's. Of us must Pompey presently be sought, Or else he seeks out us.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 64)
Where lies he?  About the Mount Misena.  What is his strength by land?(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 65)
Great and increasing; But by sea he is an absolute master.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 66)
So is the fame. Would we had spoke together. Haste we for it.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 67)
Yet, ere we put ourselves in arms, dispatch we The business we have talked of.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 68)
With most gladness, And do invite you to my sister's view, Whither straight I'll lead you.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 69)
Let us, Lepidus, not lack your company.   Noble Antony, not sickness should detain me.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 70)
Welcome from Egypt, sir.  Half the heart of Caesar, worthy Maecenas!(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 71)
--My honorable friend Agrippa!  Good Enobarbus!  We have cause to be glad that matters are so well digested.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 72)
You stayed well by 't in Egypt.  Ay, sir, we did sleep day out of countenance and made the night light with drinking.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 73)
Eight wild boars roasted whole at a breakfast, and but twelve persons there.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 74)
Is this true?  This was but as a fly by an eagle.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 75)
We had much more monstrous matter of feast, which worthily deserved noting.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 76)
She's a most triumphant lady, if report be square to her.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 77)
When she first met Mark Antony, she pursed up his heart upon the river of Cydnus.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 78)
There she appeared indeed, or my reporter devised well for her.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 79)
will tell you. The barge she sat in like a burnished throne Burned on the water.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 80)
The poop was beaten gold, Purple the sails, and so perfumed that The winds were lovesick with them.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 81)
The oars were silver, Which to the tune of flutes kept stroke, and made The water which they beat to follow faster, As amorous of their strokes.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 82)
For her own person, It beggared all description: she did lie In her pavilion--cloth-of-gold, of tissue-- O'erpicturing that Venus where we see The fancy outwork nature.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 83)
On each side her Stood pretty dimpled boys, like smiling Cupids, With divers-colored fans, whose wind did seem To glow the delicate cheeks which they did cool, And what they undid did.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 84)
rare for Antony!   Her gentlewomen, like the Nereides, So many mermaids, tended her i' th' eyes, And made their bends adornings.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 85)
At the helm seeming mermaid steers. The silken tackle Swell with the touches of those flower-soft hands That yarely frame the office.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 86)
From the barge strange invisible perfume hits the sense Of the adjacent wharfs.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 87)
The city cast Her people out upon her; and Antony, Enthroned i' th' market-place, did sit alone, Whistling to th' air, which but for vacancy Had gone to gaze on Cleopatra too And made a gap in nature.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 88)
Rare Egyptian!   Upon her landing, Antony sent to her, Invited her to supper.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 89)
She replied It should be better he became her guest, Which she entreated.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 90)
Our courteous Antony, Whom ne'er the word of "No" woman heard speak, Being barbered ten times o'er, goes to the feast, And for his ordinary pays his heart For what his eyes eat only.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 91)
Royal wench! She made great Caesar lay his sword to bed; He ploughed her, and she cropped.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 92)
saw her once Hop forty paces through the public street, And having lost her breath, she spoke and panted, That she did make defect perfection, And breathless pour breath forth.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 93)
Now Antony must leave her utterly.  Never. He will not.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 94)
Age cannot wither her, nor custom stale Her infinite variety.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 95)
Other women cloy The appetites they feed, but she makes hungry Where most she satisfies.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 96)
For vilest things Become themselves in her, that the holy priests Bless her when she is riggish.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 97)
If beauty, wisdom, modesty can settle The heart of Antony, Octavia is blessed lottery to him.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 98)
Let us go. Good Enobarbus, make yourself my guest Whilst you abide here.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 1, Scene 99)
The world and my great office will sometimes Divide me from your bosom.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 2, Scene 0)
All which time Before the gods my knee shall bow my prayers To them for you.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 2, Scene 1)
Goodnight, sir.--My Octavia, Read not my blemishes in the world's report.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 2, Scene 2)
have not kept my square, but that to come Shall all be done by th' rule.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 2, Scene 3)
Good night, dear lady.-- Good night, sir.  Goodnight.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 2, Scene 4)
Now, sirrah, you do wish yourself in Egypt?  Would had never come from thence, nor you thither.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 2, Scene 5)
If you can, your reason?  see it in my motion, have it not in my tongue.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 2, Scene 6)
But yet hie you to Egypt again.   Say to me, whose fortunes shall rise higher, Caesar's or mine?(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 2, Scene 7)
Caesar's. Therefore, Antony, stay not by his side.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 2, Scene 8)
Thy daemon--that thy spirit which keeps thee--is Noble, courageous, high, unmatchable, Where Caesar's is not.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 2, Scene 9)
But near him, thy angel Becomes afeard, as being o'erpowered.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 2, Scene 10)
Therefore Make space enough between you.  Speak this no more.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 2, Scene 11)
To none but thee; no more but when to thee. If thou dost play with him at any game, Thou art sure to lose; and of that natural luck He beats thee 'gainst the odds.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 2, Scene 12)
Thy luster thickens When he shines by. say again, thy spirit Is all afraid to govern thee near him; But he away, 'tis noble.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 2, Scene 13)
Get thee gone. Say to Ventidius would speak with him.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 2, Scene 14)
He shall to Parthia. Be it art or hap, He hath spoken true.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 2, Scene 15)
The very dice obey him, And in our sports my better cunning faints Under his chance.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 2, Scene 16)
If we draw lots, he speeds; His cocks do win the battle still of mine When it is all to naught, and his quails ever Beat mine, inhooped, at odds.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 2, Scene 17)
will to Egypt. And though make this marriage for my peace, th' East my pleasure lies.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 2, Scene 18)
come, Ventidius. You must to Parthia; your commission's ready.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 2, Scene 19)
Trouble yourselves no further. Pray you hasten Your generals after.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 3, Scene 0)
Sir, Mark Antony Will e'en but kiss Octavia, and we'll follow.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 3, Scene 1)
Till shall see you in your soldiers' dress, Which will become you both, farewell.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 3, Scene 2)
We shall, As conceive the journey, be at the Mount Before you, Lepidus.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 3, Scene 3)
Your way is shorter; My purposes do draw me much about.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 3, Scene 4)
You'll win two days upon me.  Sir, good success.  Farewell.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 3, Scene 5)
2        Give me some music--music, moody food Of us that trade in love.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 0)
The music, ho!      Let it alone. Let's to billiards.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 1)
Come, Charmian.   My arm is sore. Best play with Mardian.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 2)
As well a woman with an eunuch played As with a woman.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 3)
--Come, you'll play with me, sir?  As well as can, madam.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 4)
And when good will is showed, though 't come too short, The actor may plead pardon.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 5)
I'll none now. Give me mine angle; we'll to th' river.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 6)
There, My music playing far off, will betray Tawny-finned fishes.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 7)
My bended hook shall pierce Their slimy jaws, and as draw them up I'll think them every one an Antony And say "Aha!(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 8)
You're caught."  'Twas merry when You wagered on your angling; when your diver Did hang a salt fish on his hook, which he With fervency drew up.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 9)
That time?--O, times!-- laughed him out of patience; and that night laughed him into patience; and next morn, Ere the ninth hour, drunk him to his bed, Then put my tires and mantles on him, whilst wore his sword Philippan.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 10)
from Italy! Ram thou thy fruitful tidings in mine ears, That long time have been barren.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 11)
Madam, madam--   Antonio's dead! If thou say so, villain, Thou kill'st thy mistress.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 12)
But well and free, If thou so yield him, there is gold, and here My bluest veins to kiss, a hand that kings Have lipped and trembled kissing.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 13)
First, madam, he is well.   Why, there's more gold.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 14)
But sirrah, mark, we use To say the dead are well.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 15)
Bring it to that, The gold give thee will melt and pour Down thy ill-uttering throat.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 16)
Good madam, hear me.  Well, go to, will. But there's no goodness in thy face--if Antony Be free and healthful, so tart a favor To trumpet such good tidings!(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 17)
If not well, Thou shouldst come like a Fury crowned with snakes, Not like a formal man.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 18)
Will 't please you hear me?   have a mind to strike thee ere thou speak'st Yet if thou say Antony lives, is well, Or friends with Caesar or not captive to him, I'll set thee in a shower of gold and hail Rich pearls upon thee.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 19)
Madam, he's well.  Well said.   And friends with Caesar.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 20)
Th' art an honest man.   Caesar and he are greater friends than ever.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 21)
Make thee a fortune from me.  But yet, madam--   do not like "But yet.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 22)
" It does allay The good precedence. Fie upon "But yet.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 23)
" "But yet" is as a jailer to bring forth Some monstrous malefactor.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 24)
Prithee, friend, Pour out the pack of matter to mine ear, The good and bad together: he's friends with Caesar, In state of health, thou say'st, and, thou say'st, free.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 25)
Free, madam, no. made no such report. He's bound unto Octavia.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 26)
For what good turn?   For the best turn i' th' bed.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 27)
am pale, Charmian.   Madam, he's married to Octavia.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 28)
The most infectious pestilence upon thee!   Good madam, patience!(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 29)
What say you? Hence, horrible villain, or I'll spurn thine eyes Like balls before me!(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 30)
I'll unhair thy head!  Thou shalt be whipped with wire and stewed in brine, Smarting in ling'ring pickle.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 31)
Gracious madam, that do bring the news made not the match.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 32)
Say 'tis not so, a province will give thee And make thy fortunes proud.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 33)
The blow thou hadst Shall make thy peace for moving me to rage, And will boot thee with what gift beside Thy modesty can beg.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 34)
He's married, madam.   Rogue, thou hast lived too long.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 35)
Nay then, I'll run. What mean you, madam? have made no fault.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 36)
Good madam, keep yourself within yourself. The man is innocent.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 37)
Some innocents 'scape not the thunderbolt. Melt Egypt into Nile, and kindly creatures Turn all to serpents!(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 38)
Call the slave again. Though am mad, will not bite him.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 39)
Call!   He is afeard to come.  will not hurt him.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 40)
These hands do lack nobility that they strike meaner than myself, since myself Have given myself the cause.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 41)
Come hither, sir. Though it be honest, it is never good To bring bad news.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 42)
Give to a gracious message An host of tongues, but let ill tidings tell Themselves when they be felt.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 43)
have done my duty.  Is he married? cannot hate thee worser than do If thou again say "yes.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 44)
"  He's married, madam.   The gods confound thee! Dost thou hold there still?(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 45)
Should lie, madam?  would thou didst, So half my Egypt were submerged and made cistern for scaled snakes!(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 46)
Go, get thee hence. Hadst thou Narcissus in thy face, to me Thou wouldst appear most ugly.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 47)
He is married?   crave your Highness' pardon.  He is married?(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 48)
Take no offense that would not offend you. To punish me for what you make me do Seems much unequal.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 49)
He's married to Octavia.   that his fault should make a knave of thee That art not what th' art sure of!(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 50)
Get thee hence. The merchandise which thou hast brought from Rome Are all too dear for me.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 51)
Lie they upon thy hand, And be undone by 'em!  Good your Highness, patience.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 52)
In praising Antony, have dispraised Caesar.  Many times, madam.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 53)
am paid for 't now. Lead me from hence; faint. Iras, Charmian!(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 54)
'Tis no matter.-- Go to the fellow, good Alexas. Bid him Report the feature of Octavia, her years, Her inclination; let him not leave out The color of her hair.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 55)
Bring me word quickly.  Let him forever go--let him not, Charmian.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 56)
Though he be painted one way like a Gorgon, The other way 's a Mars.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 57)
Bid you Alexas Bring me word how tall she is.--Pity me, Charmian, But do not speak to me.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 4, Scene 58)
with Drum and Trumpet; at another Caesar, Lepidus, Antony, Enobarbus, Maecenas, and Agrippa,     Your hostages have, so have you mine, And we shall talk before we fight.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 0)
Most meet That first we come to words, and therefore have we Our written purposes before us sent, Which if thou hast considered, let us know If 'twill tie up thy discontented sword And carry back to Sicily much tall youth That else must perish here.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 1)
To you all three, The senators alone of this great world, Chief factors for the gods: do not know Wherefore my father should revengers want, Having a son and friends, since Julius Caesar, Who at Philippi the good Brutus ghosted, There saw you laboring for him.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 2)
What was 't That moved pale Cassius to conspire? And what Made the all-honored, honest, Roman Brutus, With the armed rest, courtiers of beauteous freedom, To drench the Capitol, but that they would Have one man but a man?(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 3)
And that is it Hath made me rig my navy, at whose burden The angered ocean foams, with which meant To scourge th' ingratitude that despiteful Rome Cast on my noble father.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 4)
Take your time.   Thou canst not fear us, Pompey, with thy sails.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 5)
We'll speak with thee at sea. At land thou know'st How much we do o'ercount thee.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 6)
At land indeed Thou dost o'ercount me of my father's house; But since the cuckoo builds not for himself, Remain in 't as thou mayst.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 7)
Be pleased to tell us-- For this is from the present--how you take The offers we have sent you.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 8)
There's the point.   Which do not be entreated to, but weigh What it is worth embraced.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 9)
And what may follow To try a larger fortune.  You have made me offer Of Sicily, Sardinia; and must Rid all the sea of pirates; then to send Measures of wheat to Rome.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 10)
This 'greed upon, To part with unhacked edges and bear back Our targes undinted.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 11)
That's our offer.  Know then came before you here a man prepared To take this offer.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 12)
But Mark Antony Put me to some impatience.--Though lose The praise of it by telling, you must know When Caesar and your brother were at blows, Your mother came to Sicily and did find Her welcome friendly.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 13)
have heard it, Pompey, And am well studied for a liberal thanks, Which do owe you.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 14)
Let me have your hand.  did not think, sir, to have met you here.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 15)
The beds i' th' East are soft; and thanks to you, That called me timelier than my purpose hither, For have gained by 't.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 16)
Since saw you last, There's a change upon you.  Well, know not What counts harsh Fortune casts upon my face, But in my bosom shall she never come To make my heart her vassal.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 17)
Well met here.   hope so, Lepidus. Thus we are agreed.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 18)
crave our composition may be written And sealed between us.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 19)
That's the next to do.   We'll feast each other ere we part, and let's Draw lots who shall begin.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 20)
That will Pompey.   No, Antony, take the lot. But, first or last, Your fine Egyptian cookery shall have The fame.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 21)
have heard that Julius Caesar Grew fat with feasting there.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 22)
You have heard much.  have fair meanings, sir.  And fair words to them.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 23)
Then so much have heard. And have heard Apollodorus carried--   No more of that.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 24)
He did so.  What, pray you?   certain queen to Caesar in a mattress.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 25)
know thee now. How far'st thou, soldier?  Well, And well am like to do, for perceive Four feasts are toward.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 26)
Let me shake thy hand. never hated thee. have seen thee fight When have envied thy behavior.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 27)
Sir, never loved you much, but ha' praised you When you have well deserved ten times as much As have said you did.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 28)
Enjoy thy plainness; It nothing ill becomes thee.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 29)
-- Aboard my galley invite you all. Will you lead, lords?(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 30)
Show 's the way, sir.  Come.   Thy father, Pompey, would ne'er have made this treaty.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 31)
--You and have known, sir.  At sea, think.  We have, sir.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 32)
You have done well by water.  And you by land.  will praise any man that will praise me, though it cannot be denied what have done by land.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 33)
Nor what have done by water.  Yes, something you can deny for your own safety: you have been a great thief by sea.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 34)
And you by land.  There deny my land service. But give me your hand, Menas.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 35)
If our eyes had authority, here they might take two thieves kissing.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 36)
All men's faces are true, whatsome'er their hands are.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 37)
But there is never a fair woman has a true face.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 38)
No slander. They steal hearts.  We came hither to fight with you.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 39)
For my part, am sorry it is turned to a drinking.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 40)
Pompey doth this day laugh away his fortune.  If he do, sure he cannot weep 't back again.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 41)
You've said, sir. We looked not for Mark Antony here.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 42)
Pray you, is he married to Cleopatra?  Caesar's sister is called Octavia.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 43)
True, sir. She was the wife of Caius Marcellus.  But she is now the wife of Marcus Antonius.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 44)
Pray you, sir?  'Tis true.  Then is Caesar and he forever knit together.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 45)
If were bound to divine of this unity, would not prophesy so.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 46)
think the policy of that purpose made more in the marriage than the love of the parties.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 47)
think so, too. But you shall find the band that seems to tie their friendship together will be the very strangler of their amity.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 48)
Octavia is of a holy, cold, and still conversation.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 49)
Who would not have his wife so?  Not he that himself is not so, which is Mark Antony.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 50)
He will to his Egyptian dish again. Then shall the sighs of Octavia blow the fire up in Caesar, and, as said before, that which is the strength of their amity shall prove the immediate author of their variance.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 51)
Antony will use his affection where it is. He married but his occasion here.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 52)
And thus it may be. Come, sir, will you aboard? have a health for you.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 53)
shall take it, sir. We have used our throats in Egypt.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 5, Scene 54)
Here they'll be, man. Some o' their plants are ill-rooted already.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 0)
The least wind i' th' world will blow them down.  Lepidus is high-colored.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 1)
They have made him drink alms-drink.  As they pinch one another by the disposition, he cries out "No more," reconciles them to his entreaty and himself to th' drink.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 2)
But it raises the greater war between him and his discretion.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 3)
Why, this it is to have a name in great men's fellowship.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 4)
had as lief have a reed that will do me no service as a partisan could not heave.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 5)
To be called into a huge sphere, and not to be seen to move in 't, are the holes where eyes should be, which pitifully disaster the cheeks.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 6)
sennet sounded. Enter Caesar, Antony, Pompey, Lepidus, Agrippa, Maecenas, Enobarbus, Menas, with     Thus do they, sir: they take the flow o' th' Nile By certain scales i' th' Pyramid; they know By th' height, the lowness, or the mean if dearth Or foison follow.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 7)
The higher Nilus swells, The more it promises. As it ebbs, the seedsman Upon the slime and ooze scatters his grain, And shortly comes to harvest.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 8)
You've strange serpents there?  Ay, Lepidus.  Your serpent of Egypt is bred now of your mud by the operation of your sun; so is your crocodile.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 9)
They are so.   Sit, and some wine. health to Lepidus!(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 10)
am not so well as should be, but I'll ne'er out.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 11)
Not till you have slept. fear me you'll be in till then.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 12)
Nay, certainly, have heard the Ptolemies' pyramises are very goodly things.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 13)
Without contradiction have heard that.   Pompey, a word.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 14)
Say in mine ear what is 't.   Forsake thy seat, do beseech thee, captain, And hear me speak a word.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 15)
Forbear me till anon.--This wine for Lepidus!  What manner o' thing is your crocodile?(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 16)
It is shaped, sir, like itself, and it is as broad as it hath breadth.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 17)
It is just so high as it is, and moves with it own organs.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 18)
It lives by that which nourisheth it, and the elements once out of it, it transmigrates.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 19)
What color is it of?  Of it own color too.  'Tis a strange serpent.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 20)
'Tis so, and the tears of it are wet.  Will this description satisfy him?(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 21)
With the health that Pompey gives him, else he is a very epicure.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 22)
Go hang, sir, hang! Tell me of that? Away! Do as bid you.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 23)
--Where's this cup called for?   If for the sake of merit thou wilt hear me, Rise from thy stool.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 24)
think th' art mad!  The matter?   have ever held my cap off to thy fortunes.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 25)
Thou hast served me with much faith. What's else to say?(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 26)
-- Be jolly, lords.  These quicksands, Lepidus, Keep off them, for you sink.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 27)
Wilt thou be lord of all the world?  What sayst thou?(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 28)
Wilt thou be lord of the whole world? That's twice.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 29)
How should that be?  But entertain it, And though thou think me poor, am the man Will give thee all the world.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 30)
Hast thou drunk well?   No, Pompey, have kept me from the cup.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 31)
Thou art, if thou dar'st be, the earthly Jove. Whate'er the ocean pales or sky inclips Is thine, if thou wilt ha 't.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 32)
Show me which way.   These three world-sharers, these competitors, Are in thy vessel.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 33)
Let me cut the cable, And when we are put off, fall to their throats.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 34)
All there is thine.  Ah, this thou shouldst have done And not have spoke on 't!(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 35)
In me 'tis villainy; In thee 't had been good service.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 36)
Thou must know 'Tis not my profit that does lead mine honor; Mine honor, it.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 37)
Repent that e'er thy tongue Hath so betrayed thine act.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 38)
Being done unknown, should have found it afterwards well done, But must condemn it now.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 39)
Desist and drink.  For this I'll never follow thy palled fortunes more.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 40)
Who seeks and will not take when once 'tis offered Shall never find it more.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 41)
This health to Lepidus!   Bear him ashore.--I'll pledge it for him, Pompey.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 42)
Here's to thee, Menas.  Enobarbus, welcome.  Fill till the cup be hid.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 43)
There's a strong fellow, Menas.  Why?  He bears The third part of the world, man.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 44)
Seest not?   The third part, then, is drunk. Would it were all, That it might go on wheels.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 45)
Drink thou. Increase the reels.  Come.   This is not yet an Alexandrian feast.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 46)
It ripens towards it. Strike the vessels, ho! Here's to Caesar.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 47)
could well forbear 't. It's monstrous labor when wash my brain And it grows fouler.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 48)
Be a child o' th' time.  Possess it, I'll make answer.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 49)
But had rather fast from all, four days, Than drink so much in one.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 50)
Ha, my brave emperor, Shall we dance now the Egyptian bacchanals And celebrate our drink?(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 51)
Let's ha 't, good soldier.  Come, let's all take hands Till that the conquering wine hath steeped our sense In soft and delicate Lethe.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 52)
All take hands. Make battery to our ears with the loud music, The while I'll place you; then the boy shall sing.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 53)
The holding every man shall beat as loud As his strong sides can volley.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 54)
The Song.  Come, thou monarch of the vine, Plumpy Bacchus, with pink eyne.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 55)
In thy vats our cares be drowned. With thy grapes our hairs be crowned.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 56)
Cup us till the world go round, Cup us till the world go round.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 57)
What would you more?--Pompey, goodnight.-- Good brother, Let me request you off.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 58)
Our graver business Frowns at this levity.--Gentle lords, let's part.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 59)
You see we have burnt our cheeks. Strong Enobarb Is weaker than the wine, and mine own tongue Splits what it speaks.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 60)
The wild disguise hath almost Anticked us all. What needs more words?(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 61)
Goodnight. Good Antony, your hand.  I'll try you on the shore.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 62)
And shall, sir. Give 's your hand.   Antony, you have my father's house.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 63)
But what? We are friends! Come down into the boat.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 64)
Take heed you fall not.  Menas, I'll not on shore.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 65)
No, to my cabin. These drums, these trumpets, flutes!(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 66)
What! Let Neptune hear we bid a loud farewell To these great fellows.(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 67)
Sound and be hanged. Sound out!  Hoo, says 'a! There's my cap!(Antony and Cleopatra, Act 6, Scene 68)
young Lords, taking leave for the Florentine war;     Farewell, young lords.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 0)
These warlike principles Do not throw from you.--And you, my lords, farewell.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 1)
Share the advice betwixt you. If both gain all, The gift doth stretch itself as 'tis received And is enough for both.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 2)
'Tis our hope, sir, After well-entered soldiers, to return And find your Grace in health.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 3)
No, no, it cannot be. And yet my heart Will not confess he owes the malady That doth my life besiege.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 4)
Farewell, young lords. Whether live or die, be you the sons Of worthy Frenchmen.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 5)
Let higher Italy-- Those bated that inherit but the fall Of the last monarchy--see that you come Not to woo honor but to wed it.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 6)
When The bravest questant shrinks, find what you seek, That fame may cry you loud.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 7)
say farewell.   Health at your bidding serve your Majesty!(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 8)
Those girls of Italy, take heed of them. They say our French lack language to deny If they demand.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 9)
Beware of being captives Before you serve.  Our hearts receive your warnings.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 10)
Farewell.--Come hither to me.     my sweet lord, that you will stay behind us!(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 11)
'Tis not his fault, the spark.  'tis brave wars.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 12)
Most admirable. have seen those wars.   am commanded here and kept a coil With "Too young," and "The next year," and "'Tis too early.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 13)
"   An thy mind stand to 't, boy, steal away bravely.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 14)
shall stay here the forehorse to a smock, Creaking my shoes on the plain masonry Till honor be bought up, and no sword worn But one to dance with.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 15)
By heaven, I'll steal away!   There's honor in the theft.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 16)
Commit it, count.   am your accessory. And so, farewell.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 17)
grow to you, and our parting is a tortured body.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 18)
Farewell, captain.  Sweet Monsieur Parolles.  Noble heroes, my sword and yours are kin.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 19)
Good sparks and lustrous, a word, good metals. You shall find in the regiment of the Spinii one Captain Spurio with his cicatrice, an emblem of war, here on his sinister cheek.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 20)
It was this very sword entrenched it. Say to him live, and observe his reports for me.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 21)
We shall, noble captain.  Mars dote on you for his novices.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 22)
What will you do?  Stay the King.  Use a more spacious ceremony to the noble lords.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 23)
You have restrained yourself within the list of too cold an adieu.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 24)
Be more expressive to them, for they wear themselves in the cap of the time; there do muster true gait; eat, speak, and move under the influence of the most received star, and, though the devil lead the measure, such are to be followed.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 25)
After them, and take a more dilated farewell.  And will do so.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 26)
Worthy fellows, and like to prove most sinewy swordmen.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 27)
Pardon, my lord, for me and for my tidings.  I'll fee thee to stand up.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 28)
Then here's a man stands that has brought his pardon.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 29)
would you had kneeled, my lord, to ask me mercy, And that at my bidding you could so stand up.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 30)
would had, so had broke thy pate And asked thee mercy for 't.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 31)
Good faith, across. But, my good lord, 'tis thus: will you be cured Of your infirmity?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 32)
No.  will you eat No grapes, my royal fox? Yes, but you will My noble grapes, an if my royal fox Could reach them.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 33)
have seen a medicine That's able to breathe life into a stone, Quicken a rock, and make you dance canary With sprightly fire and motion, whose simple touch Is powerful to araise King Pippen, nay, To give great Charlemagne a pen in 's hand And write to her a love line.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 34)
What "her" is this?   Why, Doctor She. My lord, there's one arrived, If you will see her.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 35)
Now, by my faith and honor, If seriously may convey my thoughts In this my light deliverance, have spoke With one that in her sex, her years, profession, Wisdom, and constancy hath amazed me more Than dare blame my weakness.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 36)
Will you see her-- For that is her demand--and know her business?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 37)
That done, laugh well at me.  Now, good Lafew, Bring in the admiration, that we with thee May spend our wonder too, or take off thine By wond'ring how thou took'st it.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 38)
Nay, I'll fit you, And not be all day neither.    Thus he his special nothing ever prologues.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 39)
Nay, come your ways.  This haste hath wings indeed.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 40)
Nay, come your ways. This is his Majesty. Say your mind to him.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 41)
traitor you do look like, but such traitors His Majesty seldom fears.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 42)
am Cressid's uncle That dare leave two together. Fare you well.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 43)
Now, fair one, does your business follow us?  Ay, my good lord, Gerard de Narbon was my father, In what he did profess well found.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 44)
knew him.   The rather will spare my praises towards him.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 45)
Knowing him is enough. On 's bed of death Many receipts he gave me, chiefly one Which, as the dearest issue of his practice, And of his old experience th' only darling, He bade me store up as a triple eye, Safer than mine own two, more dear.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 46)
have so, And hearing your high Majesty is touched With that malignant cause wherein the honor Of my dear father's gift stands chief in power, come to tender it and my appliance With all bound humbleness.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 47)
We thank you, maiden, But may not be so credulous of cure, When our most learned doctors leave us and The congregated college have concluded That laboring art can never ransom nature From her inaidible estate.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 48)
say we must not So stain our judgment or corrupt our hope To prostitute our past-cure malady To empirics, or to dissever so Our great self and our credit to esteem senseless help when help past sense we deem.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 49)
My duty, then, shall pay me for my pains. will no more enforce mine office on you, Humbly entreating from your royal thoughts modest one to bear me back again.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 50)
cannot give thee less, to be called grateful. Thou thought'st to help me, and such thanks give As one near death to those that wish him live.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 51)
But what at full know, thou know'st no part, knowing all my peril, thou no art.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 52)
What can do can do no hurt to try Since you set up your rest 'gainst remedy.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 53)
He that of greatest works is finisher Oft does them by the weakest minister.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 54)
So holy writ in babes hath judgment shown When judges have been babes.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 55)
Great floods have flown From simple sources, and great seas have dried When miracles have by the great'st been denied.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 56)
Oft expectation fails, and most oft there Where most it promises, and oft it hits Where hope is coldest and despair most shifts.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 57)
must not hear thee. Fare thee well, kind maid. Thy pains, not used, must by thyself be paid.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 58)
Proffers not took reap thanks for their reward.   Inspired merit so by breath is barred.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 59)
It is not so with Him that all things knows As 'tis with us that square our guess by shows; But most it is presumption in us when The help of heaven we count the act of men.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 60)
Dear sir, to my endeavors give consent. Of heaven, not me, make an experiment.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 61)
am not an impostor that proclaim Myself against the level of mine aim, But know think and think know most sure My art is not past power nor you past cure.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 62)
Art thou so confident? Within what space Hop'st thou my cure?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 63)
The greatest grace lending grace, Ere twice the horses of the sun shall bring Their fiery torcher his diurnal ring; Ere twice in murk and occidental damp Moist Hesperus hath quenched her sleepy lamp; Or four and twenty times the pilot's glass Hath told the thievish minutes, how they pass, What is infirm from your sound parts shall fly, Health shall live free, and sickness freely die.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 64)
Upon thy certainty and confidence What dar'st thou venture?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 65)
Tax of impudence, strumpet's boldness, a divulged shame; Traduced by odious ballads, my maiden's name Seared otherwise; nay, worse of worst, extended With vilest torture let my life be ended.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 66)
Methinks in thee some blessed spirit doth speak His powerful sound within an organ weak, And what impossibility would slay In common sense, sense saves another way.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 67)
Thy life is dear, for all that life can rate Worth name of life in thee hath estimate: Youth, beauty, wisdom, courage, all That happiness and prime can happy call.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 68)
Thou this to hazard needs must intimate Skill infinite or monstrous desperate.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 69)
Sweet practicer, thy physic will try, That ministers thine own death if die.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 70)
If break time or flinch in property Of what spoke, unpitied let me die, And well deserved.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 71)
Not helping, death's my fee. But if help, what do you promise me?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 72)
Make thy demand.  But will you make it even?   Ay, by my scepter and my hopes of heaven.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 73)
Then shalt thou give me with thy kingly hand What husband in thy power will command.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 74)
Exempted be from me the arrogance To choose from forth the royal blood of France, My low and humble name to propagate With any branch or image of thy state; But such a one, thy vassal, whom know Is free for me to ask, thee to bestow.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 75)
Here is my hand. The premises observed, Thy will by my performance shall be served.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 76)
So make the choice of thy own time, for Thy resolved patient, on thee still rely.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 77)
More should question thee, and more must, Though more to know could not be more to trust: From whence thou cam'st, how tended on; but rest Unquestioned welcome and undoubted blessed.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 78)
-- Give me some help here, ho!--If thou proceed As high as word, my deed shall match thy deed.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 0, Scene 79)
Come on, sir. shall now put you to the height of your breeding.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 1, Scene 0)
will show myself highly fed and lowly taught. know my business is but to the court.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 1, Scene 1)
"To the court"? Why, what place make you special when you put off that with such contempt?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 1, Scene 2)
"But to the court"?  Truly, madam, if God have lent a man any manners, he may easily put it off at court.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 1, Scene 3)
He that cannot make a leg, put off 's cap, kiss his hand, and say nothing, has neither leg, hands, lip, nor cap; and indeed such a fellow, to say precisely, were not for the court.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 1, Scene 4)
But, for me, have an answer will serve all men.  Marry, that's a bountiful answer that fits all questions.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 1, Scene 5)
It is like a barber's chair that fits all buttocks: the pin-buttock, the quatch-buttock, the brawn-buttock, or any buttock.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 1, Scene 6)
Will your answer serve fit to all questions?  As fit as ten groats is for the hand of an attorney, as your French crown for your taffety punk, as Tib's rush for Tom's forefinger, as a pancake for Shrove Tuesday, a morris for May Day, as the nail to his hole, the cuckold to his horn, as a scolding quean to a wrangling knave, as the nun's lip to the friar's mouth, nay, as the pudding to his skin.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 1, Scene 7)
Have you, say, an answer of such fitness for all questions?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 1, Scene 8)
From below your duke to beneath your constable, it will fit any question.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 1, Scene 9)
It must be an answer of most monstrous size that must fit all demands.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 1, Scene 10)
But a trifle neither, in good faith, if the learned should speak truth of it.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 1, Scene 11)
Here it is, and all that belongs to 't. Ask me if am a courtier; it shall do you no harm to learn.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 1, Scene 12)
To be young again, if we could! will be a fool in question, hoping to be the wiser by your answer.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 1, Scene 13)
pray you, sir, are you a courtier?  Lord, sir!--There's a simple putting off.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 1, Scene 14)

2       They say miracles are past, and we have our philosophical persons to make modern and familiar things supernatural and causeless.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 0)
Hence is it that we make trifles of terrors, ensconcing ourselves into seeming knowledge when we should submit ourselves to an unknown fear.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 1)
Why, 'tis the rarest argument of wonder that hath shot out in our latter times.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 2)
And so 'tis.  To be relinquished of the artists--  So say, both of Galen and Paracelsus.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 3)
Of all the learned and authentic fellows--  Right, so say.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 4)
That gave him out incurable--  Why, there 'tis. So say too.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 5)
Not to be helped.  Right, as 'twere a man assured of a--  Uncertain life and sure death.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 6)
Just. You say well. So would have said.  may truly say it is a novelty to the world.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 7)
It is indeed. If you will have it in showing, you shall read it in what-do-you-call there.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 8)
showing of a heavenly effect in an earthly actor.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 9)
That's it. would have said the very same.  Why, your dolphin is not lustier.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 10)
'Fore me, speak in respect--  Nay, 'tis strange, 'tis very strange; that is the brief and the tedious of it; and he's of a most facinorous spirit that will not acknowledge it to be the--  Very hand of heaven.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 11)
Ay, so say.  In a most weak--  And debile minister.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 12)
Great power, great transcendence, which should indeed give us a further use to be made than alone the recov'ry of the King, as to be--  Generally thankful.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 13)
would have said it. You say well. Here comes the King.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 14)
Lustig, as the Dutchman says. I'll like a maid the better whilst have a tooth in my head.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 15)
