Why, he's able to lead her a coranto.  Mort du vinaigre!(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 16)
Is not this Helen?  'Fore God, think so.   Go, call before me all the lords in court.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 17)
Sit, my preserver, by thy patient's side, And with this healthful hand, whose banished sense Thou hast repealed, a second time receive The confirmation of my promised gift, Which but attends thy naming.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 18)
Fair maid, send forth thine eye. This youthful parcel Of noble bachelors stand at my bestowing, O'er whom both sovereign power and father's voice have to use.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 19)
Thy frank election make. Thou hast power to choose, and they none to forsake.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 20)
To each of you one fair and virtuous mistress Fall when Love please!(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 21)
Marry, to each but one.   I'd give bay Curtal and his furniture My mouth no more were broken than these boys' And writ as little beard.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 22)
Peruse them well. Not one of those but had a noble father.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 23)
Gentlemen, Heaven hath through me restored the King to health.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 24)
We understand it and thank heaven for you.   am a simple maid, and therein wealthiest That protest simply am a maid.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 25)
-- Please it your Majesty, have done already. The blushes in my cheeks thus whisper me: "We blush that thou shouldst choose; but, be refused, Let the white death sit on thy cheek forever; We'll ne'er come there again.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 26)
"  Make choice and see. Who shuns thy love shuns all his love in me.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 27)
Now, Dian, from thy altar do fly, And to imperial Love, that god most high, Do my sighs stream.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 28)
Sir, will you hear my suit?   And grant it.  Thanks, sir.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 29)
All the rest is mute.  had rather be in this choice than throw ambs-ace for my life.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 30)
The honor, sir, that flames in your fair eyes Before speak too threat'ningly replies.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 31)
Love make your fortunes twenty times above Her that so wishes, and her humble love.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 32)
No better, if you please.  My wish receive, Which great Love grant, and so take my leave.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 33)
Do all they deny her? An they were sons of mine, I'd have them whipped, or would send them to th' Turk to make eunuchs of.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 34)
Be not afraid that your hand should take. I'll never do you wrong, for your own sake.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 35)
Blessing upon your vows, and in your bed Find fairer fortune if you ever wed.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 36)
These boys are boys of ice; they'll none have her.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 37)
Sure they are bastards to the English; the French ne'er got 'em.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 38)
You are too young, too happy, and too good To make yourself a son out of my blood.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 39)
Fair one, think not so.  There's one grape yet. am sure thy father drunk wine.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 40)
But if thou be'st not an ass, am a youth of fourteen; have known thee already.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 41)
dare not say take you, but give Me and my service ever whilst live Into your guiding power.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 42)
--This is the man.   Why then, young Bertram, take her.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 43)
She's thy wife.   My wife, my liege? shall beseech your Highness In such a business give me leave to use The help of mine own eyes.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 44)
Know'st thou not, Bertram, What she has done for me?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 45)
Yes, my good lord, But never hope to know why should marry her.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 46)
Thou know'st she has raised me from my sickly bed.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 47)
But follows it, my lord, to bring me down Must answer for your raising?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 48)
know her well; She had her breeding at my father's charge.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 49)
poor physician's daughter my wife? Disdain Rather corrupt me ever!(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 50)
'Tis only title thou disdain'st in her, the which can build up.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 51)
Strange is it that our bloods, Of color, weight, and heat, poured all together, Would quite confound distinction, yet stands off In differences so mighty.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 52)
If she be All that is virtuous, save what thou dislik'st-- poor physician's daughter"--thou dislik'st Of virtue for the name.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 53)
But do not so. From lowest place whence virtuous things proceed, The place is dignified by th' doer's deed.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 54)
Where great additions swell 's, and virtue none, It is a dropsied honor.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 55)
Good alone Is good, without a name; vileness is so; The property by what it is should go, Not by the title.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 56)
She is young, wise, fair; In these to nature she's immediate heir, And these breed honor.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 57)
That is honor's scorn Which challenges itself as honor's born And is not like the sire.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 58)
Honors thrive When rather from our acts we them derive Than our foregoers.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 59)
The mere word's a slave Debauched on every tomb, on every grave lying trophy, and as oft is dumb Where dust and damned oblivion is the tomb Of honored bones indeed.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 60)
What should be said? If thou canst like this creature as a maid, can create the rest.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 61)
Virtue and she Is her own dower, honor and wealth from me.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 62)
cannot love her, nor will strive to do 't.   Thou wrong'st thyself if thou shouldst strive to choose.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 63)
That you are well restored, my lord, I'm glad. Let the rest go.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 64)
My honor's at the stake, which to defeat must produce my power.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 65)
--Here, take her hand, Proud, scornful boy, unworthy this good gift, That dost in vile misprision shackle up My love and her desert; that canst not dream We, poising us in her defective scale, Shall weigh thee to the beam; that wilt not know It is in us to plant thine honor where We please to have it grow.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 66)
Check thy contempt; Obey our will, which travails in thy good.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 67)
Believe not thy disdain, but presently Do thine own fortunes that obedient right Which both thy duty owes and our power claims, Or will throw thee from my care forever Into the staggers and the careless lapse Of youth and ignorance, both my revenge and hate Loosing upon thee in the name of justice Without all terms of pity.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 68)
Speak. Thine answer.   Pardon, my gracious lord, for submit My fancy to your eyes.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 69)
When consider What great creation and what dole of honor Flies where you bid it, find that she which late Was in my nobler thoughts most base is now The praised of the King, who, so ennobled, Is as 'twere born so.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 70)
Take her by the hand, And tell her she is thine, to whom promise counterpoise, if not to thy estate, balance more replete.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 71)
take her hand.   Good fortune and the favor of the King Smile upon this contract, whose ceremony Shall seem expedient on the now-born brief And be performed tonight.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 72)
The solemn feast Shall more attend upon the coming space, Expecting absent friends.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 73)
As thou lov'st her Thy love's to me religious; else, does err.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 74)
Do you hear, monsieur? word with you.  Your pleasure, sir.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 75)
Your lord and master did well to make his recantation.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 76)
"Recantation"? My "lord"? My "master"?  Ay. Is it not a language speak?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 77)
most harsh one, and not to be understood without bloody succeeding.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 78)
My "master"?  Are you companion to the Count Rossillion?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 79)
To any count, to all counts, to what is man.  To what is count's man.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 80)
Count's master is of another style.  You are too old, sir; let it satisfy you, you are too old.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 81)
must tell thee, sirrah, write man, to which title age cannot bring thee.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 82)
What dare too well do, dare not do.  did think thee, for two ordinaries, to be a pretty wise fellow; thou didst make tolerable vent of thy travel; it might pass.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 83)
Yet the scarves and the bannerets about thee did manifoldly dissuade me from believing thee a vessel of too great a burden.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 84)
have now found thee. When lose thee again, care not.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 85)
Yet art thou good for nothing but taking up, and that thou 'rt scarce worth.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 86)
Hadst thou not the privilege of antiquity upon thee--  Do not plunge thyself too far in anger lest thou hasten thy trial, which if--Lord have mercy on thee for a hen!(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 87)
So, my good window of lattice, fare thee well; thy casement need not open, for look through thee.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 88)
Give me thy hand.  My lord, you give me most egregious indignity.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 89)
Ay, with all my heart, and thou art worthy of it.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 90)
have not, my lord, deserved it.  Yes, good faith, ev'ry dram of it, and will not bate thee a scruple.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 91)
Well, shall be wiser.  Ev'n as soon as thou canst, for thou hast to pull at a smack o' th' contrary.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 92)
If ever thou be'st bound in thy scarf and beaten, thou shalt find what it is to be proud of thy bondage.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 93)
have a desire to hold my acquaintance with thee, or rather my knowledge, that may say in the default "He is a man know.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 94)
"  My lord, you do me most insupportable vexation.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 95)
would it were hell pains for thy sake, and my poor doing eternal; for doing am past, as will by thee in what motion age will give me leave.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 96)
Well, thou hast a son shall take this disgrace off me.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 97)
Scurvy, old, filthy, scurvy lord! Well, must be patient; there is no fettering of authority.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 98)
I'll beat him, by my life, if can meet him with any convenience, an he were double and double a lord.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 99)
I'll have no more pity of his age than would have of--I'll beat him, an if could but meet him again.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 100)
Sirrah, your lord and master's married. There's news for you: you have a new mistress.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 101)
most unfeignedly beseech your Lordship to make some reservation of your wrongs.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 102)
He is my good lord; whom serve above is my master.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 103)
Who? God?  Ay, sir.  The devil it is that's thy master.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 104)
Why dost thou garter up thy arms o' this fashion?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 105)
Dost make hose of thy sleeves? Do other servants so?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 106)
Thou wert best set thy lower part where thy nose stands.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 107)
By mine honor, if were but two hours younger, I'd beat thee.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 108)
Methink'st thou art a general offense, and every man should beat thee.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 109)
think thou wast created for men to breathe themselves upon thee.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 110)
This is hard and undeserved measure, my lord.  Go to, sir.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 111)
You were beaten in Italy for picking a kernel out of a pomegranate.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 112)
You are a vagabond, and no true traveler. You are more saucy with lords and honorable personages than the commission of your birth and virtue gives you heraldry.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 113)
You are not worth another word; else I'd call you knave.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 114)
leave you.  Good, very good! It is so, then. Good, very good.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 115)
Let it be concealed awhile.      Undone, and forfeited to cares forever!(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 116)
What's the matter, sweetheart?   Although before the solemn priest have sworn, will not bed her.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 117)
What, what, sweetheart?   my Parolles, they have married me!(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 118)
I'll to the Tuscan wars and never bed her.  France is a dog-hole, and it no more merits the tread of a man's foot.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 119)
To th' wars!  There's letters from my mother. What th' import is know not yet.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 120)
Ay, that would be known. To th' wars, my boy, to th' wars!(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 121)
He wears his honor in a box unseen That hugs his kicky-wicky here at home, Spending his manly marrow in her arms Which should sustain the bound and high curvet Of Mars's fiery steed.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 122)
To other regions! France is a stable, we that dwell in 't jades.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 123)
Therefore, to th' war!   It shall be so. I'll send her to my house, Acquaint my mother with my hate to her And wherefore am fled, write to the King That which durst not speak.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 124)
His present gift Shall furnish me to those Italian fields Where noble fellows strike.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 125)
Wars is no strife To the dark house and the detested wife.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 126)
Will this capriccio hold in thee? Art sure?   Go with me to my chamber, and advise me.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 127)
I'll send her straight away. Tomorrow I'll to the wars, she to her single sorrow.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 128)
Why, these balls bound; there's noise in it. 'Tis hard.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 129)
young man married is a man that's marred. Therefore away, and leave her bravely.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 130)
Go. The King has done you wrong, but hush, 'tis so.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 2, Scene 131)
My mother greets me kindly. Is she well?  She is not well, but yet she has her health.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 3, Scene 0)
She's very merry, but yet she is not well. But, thanks be given, she's very well and wants nothing i' th' world, but yet she is not well.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 3, Scene 1)
If she be very well, what does she ail that she's not very well?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 3, Scene 2)
Truly, she's very well indeed, but for two things.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 3, Scene 3)
What two things?  One, that she's not in heaven, whither God send her quickly; the other, that she's in Earth, from whence God send her quickly.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 3, Scene 4)
Bless you, my fortunate lady.  hope, sir, have your good will to have mine own good fortunes.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 3, Scene 5)
You had my prayers to lead them on, and to keep them on have them still.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 3, Scene 6)
--O my knave, how does my old lady?  So that you had her wrinkles and her money, would she did as you say.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 3, Scene 7)
Why, say nothing.  Marry, you are the wiser man, for many a man's tongue shakes out his master's undoing.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 3, Scene 8)
To say nothing, to do nothing, to know nothing, and to have nothing is to be a great part of your title, which is within a very little of nothing.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 3, Scene 9)
Away. Thou 'rt a knave.  You should have said, sir, "Before a knave, thou 'rt a knave"; that's "Before me, thou 'rt a knave.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 3, Scene 10)
" This had been truth, sir.  Go to. Thou art a witty fool.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 3, Scene 11)
have found thee.  Did you find me in yourself, sir, or were you taught to find me?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 3, Scene 12)
...  The search, sir, was profitable, and much fool may you find in you, even to the world's pleasure and the increase of laughter.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 3, Scene 13)
good knave, i' faith, and well fed. Madam, my lord will go away tonight; very serious business calls on him.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 3, Scene 14)
The great prerogative and rite of love, Which as your due time claims, he does acknowledge But puts it off to a compelled restraint, Whose want and whose delay is strewed with sweets, Which they distill now in the curbed time To make the coming hour o'erflow with joy And pleasure drown the brim.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 3, Scene 15)
What's his will else?   That you will take your instant leave o' th' King And make this haste as your own good proceeding, Strengthened with what apology you think May make it probable need.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 3, Scene 16)
What more commands he?   That, having this obtained, you presently Attend his further pleasure.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 3, Scene 17)
In everything wait upon his will.  shall report it so.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 3, Scene 18)
But hope your Lordship thinks not him a soldier.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 0)
Yes, my lord, and of very valiant approof.  You have it from his own deliverance.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 1)
And by other warranted testimony.  Then my dial goes not true.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 2)
took this lark for a bunting.  do assure you, my lord, he is very great in knowledge and accordingly valiant.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 3)
have then sinned against his experience and transgressed against his valor, and my state that way is dangerous since cannot yet find in my heart to repent.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 4)
Here he comes. pray you make us friends. will pursue the amity.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 5)
These things shall be done, sir.  Pray you, sir, who's his tailor?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 6)
Sir?  know him well. Ay, sir, he, sir, 's a good workman, a very good tailor.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 7)
Is she gone to the King?  She is.  Will she away tonight?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 8)
As you'll have her.   have writ my letters, casketed my treasure, Given order for our horses, and tonight, When should take possession of the bride, End ere do begin.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 9)
good traveler is something at the latter end of a dinner, but one that lies three thirds, and uses a known truth to pass a thousand nothings with, should be once heard and thrice beaten.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 10)
-- God save you, captain.  Is there any unkindness between my lord and you, monsieur?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 11)
know not how have deserved to run into my lord's displeasure.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 12)
You have made shift to run into 't, boots and spurs and all, like him that leapt into the custard; and out of it you'll run again rather than suffer question for your residence.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 13)
It may be you have mistaken him, my lord.  And shall do so ever, though took him at 's prayers.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 14)
Fare you well, my lord, and believe this of me: there can be no kernel in this light nut.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 15)
The soul of this man is his clothes. Trust him not in matter of heavy consequence.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 16)
have kept of them tame and know their natures.--Farewell, monsieur.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 17)
have spoken better of you than you have or will to deserve at my hand, but we must do good against evil.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 18)
An idle lord, swear.  think not so.  Why, do you not know him?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 19)
Yes, do know him well, and common speech Gives him a worthy pass.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 20)
Here comes my clog.   have, sir, as was commanded from you, Spoke with the King and have procured his leave For present parting.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 21)
Only he desires Some private speech with you.  shall obey his will.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 22)
You must not marvel, Helen, at my course, Which holds not color with the time, nor does The ministration and required office On my particular.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 23)
Prepared was not For such a business; therefore am found So much unsettled.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 24)
This drives me to entreat you That presently you take your way for home, And rather muse than ask why entreat you; For my respects are better than they seem, And my appointments have in them a need Greater than shows itself at the first view To you that know them not.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 25)
This to my mother. 'Twill be two days ere shall see you, so leave you to your wisdom.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 26)
Sir, can nothing say But that am your most obedient servant--   Come, come, no more of that.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 27)
And ever shall With true observance seek to eke out that Wherein toward me my homely stars have failed To equal my great fortune.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 28)
Let that go. My haste is very great. Farewell. Hie home.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 29)
Pray, sir, your pardon.  Well, what would you say?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 30)
am not worthy of the wealth owe, Nor dare say 'tis mine--and yet it is-- But, like a timorous thief, most fain would steal What law does vouch mine own.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 31)
What would you have?   Something, and scarce so much; nothing, indeed.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 32)
would not tell you what would, my lord. Faith, yes: Strangers and foes do sunder and not kiss.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 33)
pray you stay not, but in haste to horse.   shall not break your bidding, good my lord.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 34)
-- Where are my other men?--Monsieur, farewell.    Go thou toward home, where will never come Whilst can shake my sword or hear the drum.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 4, Scene 35)
So that from point to point now have you heard The fundamental reasons of this war, Whose great decision hath much blood let forth And more thirsts after.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 23, Scene 0)
Holy seems the quarrel Upon your Grace's part, black and fearful On the opposer.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 23, Scene 1)
Therefore we marvel much our cousin France Would in so just a business shut his bosom Against our borrowing prayers.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 23, Scene 2)
Good my lord, The reasons of our state cannot yield But like a common and an outward man That the great figure of a council frames By self-unable motion; therefore dare not Say what think of it, since have found Myself in my incertain grounds to fail As often as guessed.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 23, Scene 3)
Be it his pleasure.   But am sure the younger of our nation, That surfeit on their ease, will day by day Come here for physic.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 23, Scene 4)
Welcome shall they be, And all the honors that can fly from us Shall on them settle.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 23, Scene 5)
You know your places well. When better fall, for your avails they fell.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 23, Scene 6)
It hath happened all as would have had it, save that he comes not along with her.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 0)
By my troth, take my young lord to be a very melancholy man.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 1)
By what observance, pray you?  Why, he will look upon his boot and sing, mend the ruff and sing, ask questions and sing, pick his teeth and sing.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 2)
know a man that had this trick of melancholy sold a goodly manor for a song.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 3)
Let me see what he writes and when he means to come.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 4)
have no mind to Isbel since was at court. Our old lings and our Isbels o' th' country are nothing like your old ling and your Isbels o' th' court.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 5)
The brains of my Cupid's knocked out, and begin to love as an old man loves money, with no stomach.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 6)
What have we here?  E'en that you have there.  have sent you a daughter-in-law.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 7)
She hath recovered the King and undone me. have wedded her, not bedded her, and sworn to make the "not" eternal.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 8)
You shall hear am run away. Know it before the report come.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 9)
If there be breadth enough in the world, will hold a long distance.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 10)
My duty to you. Your unfortunate son, Bertram. This is not well, rash and unbridled boy: To fly the favors of so good a king, To pluck his indignation on thy head By the misprizing of a maid too virtuous For the contempt of empire.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 11)
madam, yonder is heavy news within, between two soldiers and my young lady.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 12)
What is the matter?  Nay, there is some comfort in the news, some comfort.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 13)
Your son will not be killed so soon as thought he would.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 14)
Why should he be killed?  So say madam, if he run away, as hear he does.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 15)
The danger is in standing to 't; that's the loss of men, though it be the getting of children.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 16)
Here they come will tell you more. For my part, only hear your son was run away.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 17)
Save you, good madam.   Madam, my lord is gone, forever gone.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 18)
Do not say so.   Think upon patience, pray you.--Gentlemen, have felt so many quirks of joy and grief That the first face of neither on the start Can woman me unto 't.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 19)
Where is my son, pray you?   Madam, he's gone to serve the Duke of Florence.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 20)
We met him thitherward, for thence we came, And, after some dispatch in hand at court, Thither we bend again.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 21)
Look on his letter, madam; here's my passport. When thou canst get the ring upon my finger, which never shall come off, and show me a child begotten of thy body that am father to, then call me husband.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 22)
But in such a "then" write a "never." This is a dreadful sentence.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 23)
Brought you this letter, gentlemen?  Ay, madam, And for the contents' sake are sorry for our pains.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 24)
prithee, lady, have a better cheer. If thou engrossest all the griefs are thine, Thou robb'st me of a moiety.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 25)
He was my son, But do wash his name out of my blood, And thou art all my child.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 26)
--Towards Florence is he?  Ay, madam.  And to be a soldier?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 27)
Such is his noble purpose, and, believe 't, The Duke will lay upon him all the honor That good convenience claims.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 28)
Return you thither?   Ay, madam, with the swiftest wing of speed.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 29)
Till have no wife have nothing in France. 'Tis bitter.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 30)
Find you that there?  Ay, madam.   'Tis but the boldness of his hand, haply, Which his heart was not consenting to.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 31)
Nothing in France until he have no wife! There's nothing here that is too good for him But only she, and she deserves a lord That twenty such rude boys might tend upon And call her hourly mistress.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 32)
Who was with him?   servant only, and a gentleman Which have sometime known.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 33)
Parolles was it not?  Ay, my good lady, he.   very tainted fellow, and full of wickedness.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 34)
My son corrupts a well-derived nature With his inducement.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 35)
Indeed, good lady, The fellow has a deal of that too much Which holds him much to have.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 36)
You're welcome, gentlemen. will entreat you when you see my son To tell him that his sword can never win The honor that he loses.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 37)
More I'll entreat you Written to bear along.  We serve you, madam, In that and all your worthiest affairs.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 38)
Not so, but as we change our courtesies. Will you draw near?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 39)
"Till have no wife have nothing in France." Nothing in France until he has no wife.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 40)
Thou shalt have none, Rossillion, none in France.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 41)
Then hast thou all again. Poor lord, is 't That chase thee from thy country and expose Those tender limbs of thine to the event Of the none-sparing war?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 42)
And is it That drive thee from the sportive court, where thou Wast shot at with fair eyes, to be the mark Of smoky muskets?(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 43)
you leaden messengers That ride upon the violent speed of fire, Fly with false aim; move the still-'pearing air That sings with piercing; do not touch my lord.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 44)
Whoever shoots at him, set him there; Whoever charges on his forward breast, am the caitiff that do hold him to 't; And though kill him not, am the cause His death was so effected.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 45)
Better 'twere met the ravin lion when he roared With sharp constraint of hunger; better 'twere That all the miseries which nature owes Were mine at once.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 46)
No, come thou home, Rossillion, Whence honor but of danger wins a scar, As oft it loses all.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 47)
will be gone. My being here it is that holds thee hence.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 48)
Shall stay here to do 't? No, no, although The air of paradise did fan the house And angels officed all.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 49)
will be gone, That pitiful rumor may report my flight To consolate thine ear.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 50)
Come, night; end, day; For with the dark, poor thief, I'll steal away.(All's Well That Ends Well, Act 24, Scene 51)
Now, my co-mates and brothers in exile, Hath not old custom made this life more sweet Than that of painted pomp?(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 0)
Are not these woods More free from peril than the envious court?(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 1)
Here feel we not the penalty of Adam, The seasons' difference, as the icy fang And churlish chiding of the winter's wind, Which when it bites and blows upon my body Even till shrink with cold, smile and say "This is no flattery.(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 2)
These are counselors That feelingly persuade me what am.(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 3)
" Sweet are the uses of adversity, Which, like the toad, ugly and venomous, Wears yet a precious jewel in his head.(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 4)
And this our life, exempt from public haunt, Finds tongues in trees, books in the running brooks, Sermons in stones, and good in everything.(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 5)
would not change it. Happy is your Grace, That can translate the stubbornness of fortune Into so quiet and so sweet a style.(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 6)
Come, shall we go and kill us venison? And yet it irks me the poor dappled fools, Being native burghers of this desert city, Should in their own confines with forked heads Have their round haunches gored.(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 7)
Indeed, my lord, The melancholy Jaques grieves at that, And in that kind swears you do more usurp Than doth your brother that hath banished you.(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 8)
Today my Lord of Amiens and myself Did steal behind him as he lay along Under an oak, whose antique root peeps out Upon the brook that brawls along this wood; To the which place a poor sequestered stag That from the hunter's aim had ta'en a hurt Did come to languish.(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 9)
And indeed, my lord, The wretched animal heaved forth such groans That their discharge did stretch his leathern coat Almost to bursting, and the big round tears Coursed one another down his innocent nose In piteous chase.(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 10)
And thus the hairy fool, Much marked of the melancholy Jaques, Stood on th' extremest verge of the swift brook, Augmenting it with tears.(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 11)
But what said Jaques? Did he not moralize this spectacle?(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 12)
yes, into a thousand similes. First, for his weeping into the needless stream: "Poor deer," quoth he, "thou mak'st a testament As worldlings do, giving thy sum of more To that which had too much.(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 13)
" Then, being there alone, Left and abandoned of his velvet friends: "'Tis right," quoth he.(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 14)
"Thus misery doth part The flux of company." Anon a careless herd, Full of the pasture, jumps along by him And never stays to greet him.(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 15)
"Ay," quoth Jaques, "Sweep on, you fat and greasy citizens.(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 16)
'Tis just the fashion. Wherefore do you look Upon that poor and broken bankrupt there?(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 17)
" Thus most invectively he pierceth through The body of country, city, court, Yea, and of this our life, swearing that we Are mere usurpers, tyrants, and what's worse, To fright the animals and to kill them up In their assigned and native dwelling place.(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 18)
And did you leave him in this contemplation?   We did, my lord, weeping and commenting Upon the sobbing deer.(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 19)
Show me the place. love to cope him in these sullen fits, For then he's full of matter.(As You Like It, Act 0, Scene 20)
Can it be possible that no man saw them? It cannot be.(As You Like It, Act 1, Scene 0)
Some villains of my court Are of consent and sufferance in this.(As You Like It, Act 1, Scene 1)
cannot hear of any that did see her. The ladies her attendants of her chamber Saw her abed, and in the morning early They found the bed untreasured of their mistress.(As You Like It, Act 1, Scene 2)
My lord, the roinish clown at whom so oft Your Grace was wont to laugh is also missing.(As You Like It, Act 1, Scene 3)
Hisperia, the Princess' gentlewoman, Confesses that she secretly o'erheard Your daughter and her cousin much commend The parts and graces of the wrestler That did but lately foil the sinewy Charles, And she believes wherever they are gone That youth is surely in their company.(As You Like It, Act 1, Scene 4)
Send to his brother. Fetch that gallant hither.(As You Like It, Act 1, Scene 5)
If he be absent, bring his brother to me. I'll make him find him.(As You Like It, Act 1, Scene 6)
Do this suddenly, And let not search and inquisition quail To bring again these foolish runaways.(As You Like It, Act 1, Scene 7)
2       Who's there?   What, my young master, my gentle master, my sweet master, you memory Of old Sir Rowland!(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 0)
Why, what make you here? Why are you virtuous? Why do people love you?(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 1)
And wherefore are you gentle, strong, and valiant?(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 2)
Why would you be so fond to overcome The bonny prizer of the humorous duke?(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 3)
Your praise is come too swiftly home before you. Know you not, master, to some kind of men Their graces serve them but as enemies?(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 4)
No more do yours. Your virtues, gentle master, Are sanctified and holy traitors to you.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 5)
what a world is this when what is comely Envenoms him that bears it!(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 6)
Why, what's the matter?  unhappy youth, Come not within these doors.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 7)
Within this roof The enemy of all your graces lives.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 8)
Your brother--no, no brother--yet the son-- Yet not the son, will not call him son-- Of him was about to call his father, Hath heard your praises, and this night he means To burn the lodging where you use to lie, And you within it.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 9)
If he fail of that, He will have other means to cut you off.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 10)
overheard him and his practices. This is no place, this house is but a butchery.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 11)
Abhor it, fear it, do not enter it.   Why, whither, Adam, wouldst thou have me go?(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 12)
No matter whither, so you come not here.   What, wouldst thou have me go and beg my food, Or with a base and boist'rous sword enforce thievish living on the common road?(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 13)
This must do, or know not what to do; Yet this will not do, do how can.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 14)
rather will subject me to the malice Of a diverted blood and bloody brother.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 15)
But do not so. have five hundred crowns, The thrifty hire saved under your father, Which did store to be my foster nurse When service should in my old limbs lie lame, And unregarded age in corners thrown.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 16)
Take that, and He that doth the ravens feed, Yea, providently caters for the sparrow, Be comfort to my age.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 17)
Here is the gold. All this give you. Let me be your servant.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 18)
Though look old, yet am strong and lusty, For in my youth never did apply Hot and rebellious liquors in my blood, Nor did not with unbashful forehead woo The means of weakness and debility.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 19)
Therefore my age is as a lusty winter, Frosty but kindly.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 20)
Let me go with you. I'll do the service of a younger man In all your business and necessities.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 21)
good old man, how well in thee appears The constant service of the antique world, When service sweat for duty, not for meed.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 22)
Thou art not for the fashion of these times, Where none will sweat but for promotion, And having that do choke their service up Even with the having.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 23)
It is not so with thee. But, poor old man, thou prun'st a rotten tree That cannot so much as a blossom yield In lieu of all thy pains and husbandry.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 24)
But come thy ways. We'll go along together, And ere we have thy youthful wages spent, We'll light upon some settled low content.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 25)
Master, go on, and will follow thee To the last gasp with truth and loyalty.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 26)
From seventeen years till now almost fourscore Here lived but now live here no more.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 27)
At seventeen years, many their fortunes seek, But at fourscore, it is too late a week.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 28)
Yet fortune cannot recompense me better Than to die well, and not my master's debtor.(As You Like It, Act 2, Scene 29)
Jupiter, how weary are my spirits!  care not for my spirits, if my legs were not weary.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 0)
could find in my heart to disgrace my man's apparel and to cry like a woman, but must comfort the weaker vessel, as doublet and hose ought to show itself courageous to petticoat.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 1)
Therefore courage, good Aliena.  pray you bear with me.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 2)
cannot go no further.  For my part, had rather bear with you than bear you.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 3)
Yet should bear no cross if did bear you, for think you have no money in your purse.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 4)
Well, this is the Forest of Arden.  Ay, now am in Arden, the more fool When was at home was in a better place, but travelers must be content.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 5)
Ay, be so, good Touchstone.    Look you who comes here, a young man and an old in solemn talk.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 6)
That is the way to make her scorn you still.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 7)
Corin, that thou knew'st how do love her!   partly guess, for have loved ere now.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 8)
No, Corin, being old, thou canst not guess, Though in thy youth thou wast as true a lover As ever sighed upon a midnight pillow.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 9)
But if thy love were ever like to mine-- As sure think did never man love so-- How many actions most ridiculous Hast thou been drawn to by thy fantasy?(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 10)
Into a thousand that have forgotten.   thou didst then never love so heartily.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 11)
If thou rememb'rest not the slightest folly That ever love did make thee run into, Thou hast not loved.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 12)
Or if thou hast not sat as do now, Wearing thy hearer in thy mistress' praise, Thou hast not loved.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 13)
Or if thou hast not broke from company Abruptly, as my passion now makes me, Thou hast not loved.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 14)
Phoebe, Phoebe, Phoebe!   Alas, poor shepherd, searching of thy wound, have by hard adventure found mine own.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 15)
And mine. remember when was in love broke my sword upon a stone and bid him take that for coming a-night to Jane Smile; and remember the kissing of her batler, and the cow's dugs that her pretty chopped hands had milked; and remember the wooing of a peascod instead of her, from whom took two cods and, giving her them again, said with weeping tears "Wear these for my sake.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 16)
" We that are true lovers run into strange capers.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 17)
But as all is mortal in nature, so is all nature in love mortal in folly.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 18)
Thou speak'st wiser than thou art ware of.  Nay, shall ne'er be ware of mine own wit till break my shins against it.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 19)
Jove, Jove, this shepherd's passion Is much upon my fashion.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 20)
And mine, but it grows something stale with me.  pray you, one of you question yond man, if he for gold will give us any food.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 21)
faint almost to death.  Holla, you clown!  Peace, fool.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 22)
He's not thy kinsman.  Who calls?  Your betters, sir.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 23)
Else are they very wretched.   Peace, say. Good even toyou, friend.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 24)
And to you, gentle sir, and to you all.   prithee, shepherd, if that love or gold Can in this desert place buy entertainment, Bring us where we may rest ourselves and feed.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 25)
Here's a young maid with travel much oppressed, And faints for succor.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 26)
Fair sir, pity her And wish for her sake more than for mine own My fortunes were more able to relieve her.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 27)
But am shepherd to another man And do not shear the fleeces that graze.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 28)
My master is of churlish disposition And little recks to find the way to heaven By doing deeds of hospitality.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 29)
Besides, his cote, his flocks, and bounds of feed Are now on sale, and at our sheepcote now, By reason of his absence, there is nothing That you will feed on.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 30)
But what is, come see, And in my voice most welcome shall you be.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 31)
What is he that shall buy his flock and pasture?(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 32)
That young swain that you saw here but erewhile, That little cares for buying anything.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 33)
pray thee, if it stand with honesty, Buy thou the cottage, pasture, and the flock, And thou shalt have to pay for it of us.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 34)
And we will mend thy wages. like this place, And willingly could waste my time in it.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 35)
Assuredly the thing is to be sold. Go with me. If you like upon report The soil, the profit, and this kind of life, will your very faithful feeder be And buy it with your gold right suddenly.(As You Like It, Act 3, Scene 36)
Song.   Under the greenwood tree Who loves to lie with me And turn his merry note Unto the sweet bird's throat, Come hither, come hither, come hither.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 0)
Here shall he see No enemy But winter and rough weather.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 1)
More, more, prithee, more.  It will make you melancholy, Monsieur Jaques.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 2)
thank it. More, prithee, more. can suck melancholy out of a song as a weasel sucks eggs.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 3)
More, prithee, more.  My voice is ragged. know cannot please you.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 4)
do not desire you to please me. do desire you to sing.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 5)
Come, more, another stanzo. Call you 'em "stanzos"?(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 6)
What you will, Monsieur Jaques.  Nay, care not for their names.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 7)
They owe me nothing. Will you sing?  More at your request than to please myself.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 8)
Well then, if ever thank any man, I'll thank you.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 9)
But that they call "compliment" is like th' encounter of two dog-apes.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 10)
And when a man thanks me heartily, methinks have given him a penny and he renders me the beggarly thanks.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 11)
Come, sing. And you that will not, hold your tongues.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 12)
Well, I'll end the song.--Sirs, cover the while; the Duke will drink under this tree.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 13)
--He hath been all this day to look you.  And have been all this day to avoid him.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 14)
He is too disputable for my company. think of as many matters as he, but give heaven thanks and make no boast of them.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 15)
Come, warble, come.  Song.    Who doth ambition shun And loves to live i' th' sun, Seeking the food he eats And pleased with what he gets, Come hither, come hither, come hither.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 16)
Here shall he see No enemy But winter and rough weather.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 17)
I'll give you a verse to this note that made yesterday in despite of my invention.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 18)
And I'll sing it.  Thus it goes: If it do come to pass That any man turn ass, Leaving his wealth and ease stubborn will to please, Ducdame, ducdame, ducdame.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 19)
Here shall he see Gross fools as he, An if he will come to me.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 20)
What's that "ducdame"?  'Tis a Greek invocation to call fools into a circle.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 21)
I'll go sleep if can. If cannot, I'll rail against all the first-born of Egypt.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 22)
And I'll go seek the Duke. His banquet is prepared.(As You Like It, Act 4, Scene 23)
Dear master, can go no further. die for food. Here lie down and measure out my grave.(As You Like It, Act 5, Scene 0)
Farewell, kind master.  Why, how now, Adam? No greater heart in thee?(As You Like It, Act 5, Scene 1)
Live a little, comfort a little, cheer thyself a little.(As You Like It, Act 5, Scene 2)
If this uncouth forest yield anything savage, will either be food for it or bring it for food to thee.(As You Like It, Act 5, Scene 3)
Thy conceit is nearer death than thy powers. For my sake, be comfortable.(As You Like It, Act 5, Scene 4)
Hold death awhile at the arm's end. will here be with thee presently, and if bring thee not something to eat, will give thee leave to die.(As You Like It, Act 5, Scene 5)
But if thou diest before come, thou art a mocker of my labor.(As You Like It, Act 5, Scene 6)
Well said. Thou look'st cheerly, and I'll be with thee quickly.(As You Like It, Act 5, Scene 7)
Yet thou liest in the bleak air. Come, will bear thee to some shelter, and thou shalt not die for lack of a dinner if there live anything in this desert.(As You Like It, Act 5, Scene 8)
think he be transformed into a beast, For can nowhere find him like a man.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 0)
My lord, he is but even now gone hence. Here was he merry, hearing of a song.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 1)
If he, compact of jars, grow musical, We shall have shortly discord in the spheres.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 2)
Go seek him. Tell him would speak with him.      He saves my labor by his own approach.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 3)
Why, how now, monsieur? What a life is this That your poor friends must woo your company?(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 4)
What, you look merrily.   fool, a fool, met a fool i' th' forest, motley fool.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 5)
miserable world! As do live by food, met a fool, Who laid him down and basked him in the sun And railed on Lady Fortune in good terms, In good set terms, and yet a motley fool.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 6)
"Good morrow, fool," quoth "No, sir," quoth he, "Call me not 'fool' till heaven hath sent me fortune.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 7)
" And then he drew a dial from his poke And, looking on it with lack-luster eye, Says very wisely "It is ten o'clock.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 8)
Thus we may see," quoth he, "how the world wags. 'Tis but an hour ago since it was nine, And after one hour more 'twill be eleven.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 9)
And so from hour to hour we ripe and ripe, And then from hour to hour we rot and rot, And thereby hangs a tale.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 10)
" When did hear The motley fool thus moral on the time, My lungs began to crow like chanticleer That fools should be so deep-contemplative, And did laugh sans intermission An hour by his dial.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 11)
noble fool! worthy fool! Motley's the only wear.  What fool is this?(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 12)
worthy fool!--One that hath been a courtier, And says "If ladies be but young and fair, They have the gift to know it.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 13)
" And in his brain, Which is as dry as the remainder biscuit After a voyage, he hath strange places crammed With observation, the which he vents In mangled forms.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 14)
that were a fool! am ambitious for a motley coat.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 15)
Thou shalt have one.  It is my only suit, Provided that you weed your better judgments Of all opinion that grows rank in them That am wise.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 16)
must have liberty Withal, as large a charter as the wind, To blow on whom please, for so fools have.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 17)
And they that are most galled with my folly, They most must laugh.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 18)
And why, sir, must they so? The "why" is plain as way to parish church: He that a fool doth very wisely hit Doth very foolishly, although he smart, Not to seem senseless of the bob.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 19)
If not, The wise man's folly is anatomized Even by the squand'ring glances of the fool.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 20)
Invest me in my motley. Give me leave To speak my mind, and will through and through Cleanse the foul body of th' infected world, If they will patiently receive my medicine.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 21)
Fie on thee! can tell what thou wouldst do.   What, for a counter, would do but good?(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 22)
Most mischievous foul sin in chiding sin; For thou thyself hast been a libertine, As sensual as the brutish sting itself, And all th' embossed sores and headed evils That thou with license of free foot hast caught Wouldst thou disgorge into the general world.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 23)
Why, who cries out on pride That can therein tax any private party?(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 24)
Doth it not flow as hugely as the sea Till that the weary very means do ebb?(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 25)
What woman in the city do name When that say the city-woman bears The cost of princes on unworthy shoulders?(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 26)
Who can come in and say that mean her, When such a one as she such is her neighbor?(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 27)
Or what is he of basest function That says his bravery is not on my cost, Thinking that mean him, but therein suits His folly to the mettle of my speech?(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 28)
There then. How then, what then? Let me see wherein My tongue hath wronged him.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 29)
If it do him right, Then he hath wronged himself.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 30)
If he be free, Why then my taxing like a wild goose flies Unclaimed of any man.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 31)
But who comes here?  Forbear, and eat no more.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 32)
Why, have eat none yet.   Nor shalt not till necessity be served.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 33)
Of what kind should this cock come of?   Art thou thus boldened, man, by thy distress, Or else a rude despiser of good manners, That in civility thou seem'st so empty?(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 34)
You touched my vein at first. The thorny point Of bare distress hath ta'en from me the show Of smooth civility, yet am inland bred And know some nurture.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 35)
But forbear, say. He dies that touches any of this fruit Till and my affairs are answered.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 36)
An you will not be answered with reason, must die.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 37)
What would you have? Your gentleness shall force More than your force move us to gentleness.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 38)
almost die for food, and let me have it.   Sit down and feed, and welcome to our table.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 39)
Speak you so gently? Pardon me, pray you. thought that all things had been savage here, And therefore put on the countenance Of stern commandment.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 40)
But whate'er you are That in this desert inaccessible, Under the shade of melancholy boughs, Lose and neglect the creeping hours of time, If ever you have looked on better days, If ever been where bells have knolled to church, If ever sat at any good man's feast, If ever from your eyelids wiped a tear And know what 'tis to pity and be pitied, Let gentleness my strong enforcement be, In the which hope blush and hide my sword.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 41)
True is it that we have seen better days, And have with holy bell been knolled to church, And sat at good men's feasts and wiped our eyes Of drops that sacred pity hath engendered.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 42)
And therefore sit you down in gentleness, And take upon command what help we have That to your wanting may be ministered.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 43)
Then but forbear your food a little while Whiles, like a doe, go to find my fawn And give it food.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 44)
There is an old poor man Who after me hath many a weary step Limped in pure love.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 45)
Till he be first sufficed, Oppressed with two weak evils, age and hunger, will not touch a bit.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 46)
Go find him out, And we will nothing waste till you return.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 47)
thank you; and be blessed for your good comfort.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 48)
Thou seest we are not all alone unhappy. This wide and universal theater Presents more woeful pageants than the scene Wherein we play in.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 49)
All the world's a stage, And all the men and women merely players.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 50)
They have their exits and their entrances, And one man in his time plays many parts, His acts being seven ages.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 51)
At first the infant, Mewling and puking in the nurse's arms.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 52)
Then the whining schoolboy with his satchel And shining morning face, creeping like snail Unwillingly to school.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 53)
And then the lover, Sighing like furnace, with a woeful ballad Made to his mistress' eyebrow.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 54)
Then a soldier, Full of strange oaths and bearded like the pard, Jealous in honor, sudden and quick in quarrel, Seeking the bubble reputation Even in the cannon's mouth.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 55)
And then the justice, In fair round belly with good capon lined, With eyes severe and beard of formal cut, Full of wise saws and modern instances; And so he plays his part.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 56)
The sixth age shifts Into the lean and slippered pantaloon With spectacles on nose and pouch on side, His youthful hose, well saved, a world too wide For his shrunk shank, and his big manly voice, Turning again toward childish treble, pipes And whistles in his sound.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 57)
Last scene of all, That ends this strange eventful history, Is second childishness and mere oblivion, Sans teeth, sans eyes, sans taste, sans everything.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 58)
Welcome. Set down your venerable burden, And let him feed.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 59)
thank you most for him.  So had you need.-- scarce can speak to thank you for myself.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 60)
Welcome. Fall to. will not trouble you As yet to question you about your fortunes.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 61)
-- Give us some music, and, good cousin, sing.      Song.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 62)
Blow, blow, thou winter wind. Thou art not so unkind As man's ingratitude.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 63)
Thy tooth is not so keen, Because thou art not seen, Although thy breath be rude.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 64)
Heigh-ho, sing heigh-ho, unto the green holly. Most friendship is feigning, most loving mere folly.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 65)
Then heigh-ho, the holly. This life is most jolly.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 66)
Freeze, freeze, thou bitter sky, That dost not bite so nigh As benefits forgot.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 67)
Though thou the waters warp, Thy sting is not so sharp As friend remembered not.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 68)
Heigh-ho, sing heigh-ho, unto the green holly. Most friendship is feigning, most loving mere folly.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 69)
Then heigh-ho, the holly. This life is most jolly.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 70)
If that you were the good Sir Rowland's son, As you have whispered faithfully you were, And as mine eye doth his effigies witness Most truly limned and living in your face, Be truly welcome hither.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 71)
am the duke That loved your father. The residue of your fortune Go to my cave and tell me.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 72)
--Good old man, Thou art right welcome as thy master is.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 73)
Support him by the arm. [To Orlando.] Give me your hand, And let me all your fortunes understand.(As You Like It, Act 6, Scene 74)
The augurer tells me we shall have news tonight.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 0)
Good or bad?  Not according to the prayer of the people, for they love not Martius.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 1)
Nature teaches beasts to know their friends.  Pray you, who does the wolf love?(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 2)
The lamb.  Ay, to devour him, as the hungry plebeians would the noble Martius.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 3)
He's a lamb indeed, that baas like a bear.  He's a bear indeed, that lives like a lamb.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 4)
You two are old men; tell me one thing that shall ask you.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 5)
Well, sir.  In what enormity is Martius poor in, that you two have not in abundance?(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 6)
He's poor in no one fault, but stored with all.  Especially in pride.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 7)
And topping all others in boasting.  This is strange now.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 8)
Do you two know how you are censured here in the city, mean of us o' th' right-hand file, do you?(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 9)
Why, how are we censured?  Because you talk of pride now, will you not be angry?(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 10)
Well, well, sir, well?  Why, 'tis no great matter; for a very little thief of occasion will rob you of a great deal of patience.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 11)
Give your dispositions the reins, and be angry at your pleasures, at the least, if you take it as a pleasure to you in being so.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 12)
You blame Martius for being proud.  We do it not alone, sir.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 13)
know you can do very little alone, for your helps are many, or else your actions would grow wondrous single.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 14)
Your abilities are too infantlike for doing much alone.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 15)
You talk of pride. that you could turn your eyes toward the napes of your necks and make but an interior survey of your good selves!(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 16)
that you could!  What then, sir?  Why, then you should discover a brace of unmeriting, proud, violent, testy magistrates, alias fools, as any in Rome.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 17)
Menenius, you are known well enough, too.  am known to be a humorous patrician and one that loves a cup of hot wine with not a drop of allaying Tiber in 't; said to be something imperfect in favoring the first complaint, hasty and tinder-like upon too trivial motion; one that converses more with the buttock of the night than with the forehead of the morning.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 18)
What think utter, and spend my malice in my breath.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 19)
Meeting two such wealsmen as you are--I cannot call you Lycurguses--if the drink you give me touch my palate adversely, make a crooked face at it.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 20)
cannot say your Worships have delivered the matter well when find the ass in compound with the major part of your syllables.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 21)
And though must be content to bear with those that say you are reverend grave men, yet they lie deadly that tell you have good faces.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 22)
If you see this in the map of my microcosm, follows it that am known well enough too?(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 23)
What harm can your bisson conspectuities glean out of this character, if be known well enough, too?(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 24)
Come, sir, come; we know you well enough.  You know neither me, yourselves, nor anything.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 25)
You are ambitious for poor knaves' caps and legs.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 26)
You wear out a good wholesome forenoon in hearing a cause between an orange-wife and a faucet-seller, and then rejourn the controversy of threepence to a second day of audience.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 27)
When you are hearing a matter between party and party, if you chance to be pinched with the colic, you make faces like mummers, set up the bloody flag against all patience, and, in roaring for a chamber pot, dismiss the controversy bleeding, the more entangled by your hearing.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 28)
All the peace you make in their cause is calling both the parties knaves.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 29)
You are a pair of strange ones.  Come, come. You are well understood to be a perfecter giber for the table than a necessary bencher in the Capitol.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 30)
Our very priests must become mockers if they shall encounter such ridiculous subjects as you are.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 31)
When you speak best unto the purpose, it is not worth the wagging of your beards, and your beards deserve not so honorable a grave as to stuff a botcher's cushion or to be entombed in an ass's packsaddle.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 32)
Yet you must be saying Martius is proud, who, in a cheap estimation, is worth all your predecessors since Deucalion, though peradventure some of the best of 'em were hereditary hangmen.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 33)
Good e'en to your Worships. More of your conversation would infect my brain, being the herdsmen of the beastly plebeians.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 34)
will be bold to take my leave of you.     How now, my as fair as noble ladies--and the moon, were she earthly, no nobler--whither do you follow your eyes so fast?(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 35)
Honorable Menenius, my boy Martius approaches. For the love of Juno, let's go!(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 36)
Ha? Martius coming home?  Ay, worthy Menenius, and with most prosperous approbation.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 37)
Take my cap, Jupiter, and thank thee! Hoo! Martius coming home?(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 38)
Nay, 'tis true.  Look, here's a letter from him.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 39)
The state hath another, his wife another, and think there's one at home for you.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 40)
will make my very house reel tonight. letter for me?(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 41)
Yes, certain, there's a letter for you; saw 't.  letter for me?(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 42)
It gives me an estate of seven years' health, in which time will make a lip at the physician.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 43)
The most sovereign prescription in Galen is but empiricutic and, to this preservative, of no better report than a horse drench.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 44)
Is he not wounded? He was wont to come home wounded.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 45)
no, no, no!  he is wounded, thank the gods for 't.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 46)
So do too, if it be not too much. Brings he victory in his pocket, the wounds become him.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 47)
On 's brows, Menenius. He comes the third time home with the oaken garland.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 48)
Has he disciplined Aufidius soundly?  Titus Lartius writes they fought together, but Aufidius got off.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 49)
And 'twas time for him too, I'll warrant him that.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 50)
An he had stayed by him, would not have been so 'fidiused for all the chests in Corioles and the gold that's in them.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 51)
Is the Senate possessed of this?  Good ladies, let's go.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 52)
--Yes, yes, yes. The Senate has letters from the General, wherein he gives my son the whole name of the war.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 53)
He hath in this action outdone his former deeds doubly.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 54)
In troth, there's wondrous things spoke of him.  Wondrous?(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 55)
Ay, warrant you, and not without his true purchasing.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 56)
The gods grant them true.  True? Pow waw!  True?(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 57)
I'll be sworn they are true. Where is he wounded?(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 58)
God save your good Worships! Martius is coming home; he has more cause to be proud.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 59)
--Where is he wounded?  th' shoulder and i' th' left arm.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 60)
There will be large cicatrices to show the people when he shall stand for his place.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 61)
He received in the repulse of Tarquin seven hurts i' th' body.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 62)
One i' th' neck and two i' th' thigh--there's nine that know.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 63)
He had, before this last expedition, twenty-five wounds upon him.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 64)
Now it's twenty-seven. Every gash was an Hark, the trumpets!(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 65)
These are the ushers of Martius: before him he carries noise, and behind him he leaves tears.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 66)
Death, that dark spirit, in 's nervy arm doth lie, Which, being advanced, declines, and then men die.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 67)
them Coriolanus crowned with an oaken garland, with     Know, Rome, that all alone Martius did fight Within Corioles' gates, where he hath won, With fame, a name to Martius Caius; these In honor follows "Coriolanus.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 68)
" Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus.    Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus!(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 69)
No more of this. It does offend my heart. Pray now, no more.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 70)
Look, sir, your mother.   You have, know, petitioned all the gods For my prosperity.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 71)
Nay, my good soldier, up.  My gentle Martius, worthy Caius, and By deed-achieving honor newly named-- What is it?(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 72)
Coriolanus must call thee? But, thy wife--  My gracious silence, hail.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 73)
Wouldst thou have laughed had come coffined home, That weep'st to see me triumph?(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 74)
Ah, my dear, Such eyes the widows in Corioles wear And mothers that lack sons.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 75)
Now the gods crown thee!   And live you yet?  my sweet lady, pardon.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 76)
know not where to turn. welcome home!-- And, welcome, general.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 77)
--And you're welcome all.   hundred thousand welcomes!(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 78)
could weep, And could laugh; am light and heavy. Welcome.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 79)
curse begin at very root on 's heart That is not glad to see thee!(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 80)
You are three That Rome should dote on; yet, by the faith of men, We have some old crab trees here at home that will not Be grafted to your relish.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 81)
Yet welcome, warriors! We call a nettle but a nettle, and The faults of fools but folly.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 82)
Ever right.  Menenius ever, ever.   Give way there, and go on!(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 83)
Your hand and yours. Ere in our own house do shade my head, The good patricians must be visited, From whom have received not only greetings, But with them change of honors.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 84)
have lived To see inherited my very wishes And the buildings of my fancy.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 85)
Only There's one thing wanting, which doubt not but Our Rome will cast upon thee.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 86)
Know, good mother, had rather be their servant in my way Than sway with them in theirs.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 87)
On, to the Capitol.        All tongues speak of him, and the bleared sights Are spectacled to see him.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 88)
Your prattling nurse Into a rapture lets her baby cry While she chats him.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 89)
The kitchen malkin pins Her richest lockram 'bout her reechy neck, Clamb'ring the walls to eye him.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 90)
Stalls, bulks, windows Are smothered up, leads filled, and ridges horsed With variable complexions, all agreeing In earnestness to see him.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 91)
Seld-shown flamens Do press among the popular throngs and puff To win a vulgar station.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 92)
Our veiled dames Commit the war of white and damask in Their nicely-gauded cheeks to th' wanton spoil Of Phoebus' burning kisses.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 93)
Such a pother, As if that whatsoever god who leads him Were slyly crept into his human powers And gave him graceful posture.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 94)
On the sudden warrant him consul.  Then our office may, During his power, go sleep.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 95)
He cannot temp'rately transport his honors From where he should begin and end, but will Lose those he hath won.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 96)
In that there's comfort.  Doubt not The commoners, for whom we stand, but they Upon their ancient malice will forget With the least cause these his new honors--which That he will give them make as little question As he is proud to do 't.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 97)
heard him swear, Were he to stand for consul, never would he Appear i' th' marketplace nor on him put The napless vesture of humility, Nor showing, as the manner is, his wounds To th' people, beg their stinking breaths.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 98)
'Tis right.   It was his word. he would miss it rather Than carry it but by the suit of the gentry to him And the desire of the nobles.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 99)
wish no better Than have him hold that purpose and to put it In execution.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 100)
'Tis most like he will.   It shall be to him then as our good wills, sure destruction.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 101)
So it must fall out To him, or our authority's for an end.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 102)
We must suggest the people in what hatred He still hath held them; that to 's power he would Have made them mules, silenced their pleaders, and Dispropertied their freedoms; holding them In human action and capacity Of no more soul nor fitness for the world Than camels in their war, who have their provand Only for bearing burdens, and sore blows For sinking under them.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 103)
This, as you say, suggested At some time when his soaring insolence Shall touch the people--which time shall not want If he be put upon 't, and that's as easy As to set dogs on sheep--will be his fire To kindle their dry stubble, and their blaze Shall darken him forever.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 104)
What's the matter?   You are sent for to the Capitol.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 105)
'Tis thought That Martius shall be consul. have seen The dumb men throng to see him, and the blind To hear him speak; matrons flung gloves, Ladies and maids their scarves and handkerchiefs, Upon him as he passed; the nobles bended As to Jove's statue, and the Commons made shower and thunder with their caps and shouts.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 106)
never saw the like.  Let's to the Capitol, And carry with us ears and eyes for th' time, But hearts for the event.(Coriolanus, Act 0, Scene 107)
Come, come. They are almost here. How many stand for consulships?(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 0)
Three, they say; but 'tis thought of everyone Coriolanus will carry it.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 1)
That's a brave fellow, but he's vengeance proud and loves not the common people.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 2)
'Faith, there hath been many great men that have flattered the people who ne'er loved them; and there be many that they have loved they know not wherefore; so that, if they love they know not why, they hate upon no better a ground.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 3)
Therefore, for Coriolanus neither to care whether they love or hate him manifests the true knowledge he has in their disposition and, out of his noble carelessness, lets them plainly see 't.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 4)
If he did not care whether he had their love or no, he waved indifferently 'twixt doing them neither good nor harm; but he seeks their hate with greater devotion than they can render it him and leaves nothing undone that may fully discover him their opposite.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 5)
Now, to seem to affect the malice and displeasure of the people is as bad as that which he dislikes, to flatter them for their love.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 6)
He hath deserved worthily of his country, and his ascent is not by such easy degrees as those who, having been supple and courteous to the people, bonneted, without any further deed to have them at all into their estimation and report; but he hath so planted his honors in their eyes and his actions in their hearts that for their tongues to be silent and not confess so much were a kind of ingrateful injury.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 7)
To report otherwise were a malice that, giving itself the lie, would pluck reproof and rebuke from every ear that heard it.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 8)
No more of him; he's a worthy man. Make way. They are coming.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 9)
sennet. Enter the Patricians and the Tribunes of the people, Lictors before them; Coriolanus, Menenius, Cominius the consul.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 10)
The Patricians sit. Sicinius and Brutus take their places by themselves.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 11)
Having determined of the Volsces and To send for Titus Lartius, it remains, As the main point of this our after-meeting, To gratify his noble service that Hath thus stood for his country.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 12)
Therefore please you, Most reverend and grave elders, to desire The present consul and last general In our well-found successes to report little of that worthy work performed By Martius Caius Coriolanus, whom We met here both to thank and to remember With honors like himself.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 13)
Speak, good Cominius. Leave nothing out for length, and make us think Rather our state's defective for requital, Than we to stretch it out.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 14)
Masters o' th' people, We do request your kindest ears and, after, Your loving motion toward the common body To yield what passes here.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 15)
We are convented Upon a pleasing treaty and have hearts Inclinable to honor and advance The theme of our assembly.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 16)
Which the rather We shall be blest to do if he remember kinder value of the people than He hath hereto prized them at.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 17)
That's off, that's off! would you rather had been silent.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 18)
Please you To hear Cominius speak?  Most willingly, But yet my caution was more pertinent Than the rebuke you give it.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 19)
He loves your people, But tie him not to be their bedfellow.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 20)
-- Worthy Cominius, speak.  Nay, keep your place.   Sit, Coriolanus.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 21)
Never shame to hear What you have nobly done.  Your Honors, pardon.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 22)
had rather have my wounds to heal again Than hear say how got them.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 23)
Sir, hope My words disbenched you not?  No, sir.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 24)
Yet oft, When blows have made me stay, fled from words.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 25)
You soothed not, therefore hurt not; but your people, love them as they weigh.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 26)
