Pray now, sit down.   had rather have one scratch my head i' th' sun When the alarum were struck than idly sit To hear my nothings monstered.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 27)
Masters of the people, Your multiplying spawn how can he flatter-- That's thousand to one good one--when you now see He had rather venture all his limbs for honor Than one on 's ears to hear it.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 28)
--Proceed, Cominius.   shall lack voice. The deeds of Coriolanus Should not be uttered feebly.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 29)
It is held That valor is the chiefest virtue and Most dignifies the haver; if it be, The man speak of cannot in the world Be singly counterpoised.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 30)
At sixteen years, When Tarquin made a head for Rome, he fought Beyond the mark of others.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 31)
Our then dictator, Whom with all praise point at, saw him fight When with his Amazonian chin he drove The bristled lips before him.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 32)
He bestrid An o'erpressed Roman and i' th' Consul's view Slew three opposers.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 33)
Tarquin's self he met And struck him on his knee.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 34)
In that day's feats, When he might act the woman in the scene, He proved best man i' th' field and for his meed Was brow-bound with the oak.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 35)
His pupil age Man-entered thus, he waxed like a sea, And in the brunt of seventeen battles since He lurched all swords of the garland.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 36)
For this last, Before and in Corioles, let me say, cannot speak him home.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 37)
He stopped the flyers And by his rare example made the coward Turn terror into sport.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 38)
As weeds before vessel under sail, so men obeyed And fell below his stem.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 39)
His sword, Death's stamp, Where it did mark, it took; from face to foot He was a thing of blood, whose every motion Was timed with dying cries.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 40)
Alone he entered The mortal gate o' th' city, which he painted With shunless destiny; aidless came off And with a sudden reinforcement struck Corioles like a planet.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 41)
Now all's his, When by and by the din of war gan pierce His ready sense; then straight his doubled spirit Requickened what in flesh was fatigate, And to the battle came he, where he did Run reeking o'er the lives of men as if 'Twere a perpetual spoil; and till we called Both field and city ours, he never stood To ease his breast with panting.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 42)
Worthy man!   He cannot but with measure fit the honors Which we devise him.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 43)
Our spoils he kicked at And looked upon things precious as they were The common muck of the world.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 44)
He covets less Than misery itself would give, rewards His deeds with doing them, and is content To spend the time to end it.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 45)
He's right noble. Let him be called for.  Call Coriolanus.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 46)
He doth appear.      The Senate, Coriolanus, are well pleased To make thee consul.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 47)
do owe them still My life and services.  It then remains That you do speak to the people.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 48)
do beseech you, Let me o'erleap that custom, for cannot Put on the gown, stand naked, and entreat them For my wounds' sake to give their suffrage.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 49)
Please you That may pass this doing.  Sir, the people Must have their voices; neither will they bate One jot of ceremony.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 50)
Put them not to 't. Pray you, go fit you to the custom, and Take to you, as your predecessors have, Your honor with your form.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 51)
It is a part That shall blush in acting, and might well Be taken from the people.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 52)
Mark you that?   To brag unto them "Thus did, and thus!(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 53)
" Show them th' unaching scars, which should hide, As if had received them for the hire Of their breath only!(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 54)
Do not stand upon 't.-- We recommend to you, tribunes of the people, Our purpose to them, and to our noble consul Wish we all joy and honor.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 55)
To Coriolanus come all joy and honor!     You see how he intends to use the people.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 56)
May they perceive 's intent! He will require them As if he did contemn what he requested Should be in them to give.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 57)
Come, we'll inform them Of our proceedings here.(Coriolanus, Act 1, Scene 58)
Once, if he do require our voices, we ought not to deny him.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 0)
We may, sir, if we will.  We have power in ourselves to do it, but it is a power that we have no power to do; for, if he show us his wounds and tell us his deeds, we are to put our tongues into those wounds and speak for them.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 1)
So, if he tell us his noble deeds, we must also tell him our noble acceptance of them.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 2)
Ingratitude is monstrous, and for the multitude to be ingrateful were to make a monster of the multitude, of the which, we being members, should bring ourselves to be monstrous members.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 3)
And to make us no better thought of, a little help will serve; for once we stood up about the corn, he himself stuck not to call us the many-headed multitude.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 4)
We have been called so of many; not that our heads are some brown, some black, some abram, some bald, but that our wits are so diversely colored; and truly think if all our wits were to issue out of one skull, they would fly east, west, north, south, and their consent of one direct way should be at once to all the points o' th' compass.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 5)
Think you so? Which way do you judge my wit would fly?(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 6)
Nay, your wit will not so soon out as another man's will; 'tis strongly wedged up in a blockhead.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 7)
But if it were at liberty, 'twould sure southward.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 8)
Why that way?  To lose itself in a fog, where, being three parts melted away with rotten dews, the fourth would return for conscience' sake, to help to get thee a wife.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 9)
You are never without your tricks. You may, you may.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 10)
Are you all resolved to give your voices? But that's no matter; the greater part carries it.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 11)
say, if he would incline to the people, there was never a worthier man.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 12)
Here he comes, and in the gown of humility. Mark his behavior.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 13)
We are not to stay all together, but to come by him where he stands, by ones, by twos, and by threes.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 14)
He's to make his requests by particulars, wherein every one of us has a single honor in giving him our own voices with our own tongues.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 15)
Therefore follow me, and I'll direct you how you shall go by him.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 16)
Content, content.   sir, you are not right. Have you not known The worthiest men have done 't?(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 17)
What must say? pray, sir?"--plague upon 't! cannot bring My tongue to such a pace.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 18)
"Look, sir, my wounds! got them in my country's service when Some certain of your brethren roared and ran From th' noise of our own drums.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 19)
"  me, the gods! You must not speak of that. You must desire them To think upon you.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 20)
Think upon me? Hang 'em! would they would forget me, like the virtues Which our divines lose by 'em.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 21)
You'll mar all. I'll leave you. Pray you, speak to 'em, pray you, In wholesome manner.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 22)
Bid them wash their faces And keep their teeth clean.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 23)
So, here comes a brace.-- You know the cause, sir, of my standing here.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 24)
We do, sir. Tell us what hath brought you to 't.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 25)
Mine own desert.  Your own desert?  Ay, but not mine own desire.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 26)
How, not your own desire?  No, sir, 'twas never my desire yet to trouble the poor with begging.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 27)
You must think if we give you anything, we hope to gain by you.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 28)
Well then, pray, your price o' th' consulship?  The price is to ask it kindly.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 29)
Kindly, sir, pray, let me ha 't. have wounds to show you, which shall be yours in private.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 30)
--Your good voice, sir. What say you?  You shall ha 't, worthy sir.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 31)
match, sir. There's in all two worthy voices begged.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 32)
have your alms. Adieu.  But this is something odd.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 33)
An 'twere to give again--but 'tis no matter.     Pray you now, if it may stand with the tune of your voices that may be consul, have here the customary gown.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 34)
You have deserved nobly of your country, and you have not deserved nobly.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 35)
Your enigma?  You have been a scourge to her enemies; you have been a rod to her friends.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 36)
You have not indeed loved the common people.  You should account me the more virtuous that have not been common in my love.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 37)
will, sir, flatter my sworn brother, the people, to earn a dearer estimation of them; 'tis a condition they account gentle.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 38)
And since the wisdom of their choice is rather to have my hat than my heart, will practice the insinuating nod and be off to them most counterfeitly.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 39)
That is, sir, will counterfeit the bewitchment of some popular man and give it bountiful to the desirers.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 40)
Therefore, beseech you, may be consul.  We hope to find you our friend, and therefore give you our voices heartily.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 41)
You have received many wounds for your country.  will not seal your knowledge with showing them.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 42)
will make much of your voices and so trouble you no farther.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 43)
The gods give you joy, sir, heartily.   Most sweet voices!(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 44)
Better it is to die, better to starve, Than crave the hire which first we do deserve.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 45)
Why in this woolvish toge should stand here To beg of Hob and Dick that does appear Their needless vouches?(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 46)
Custom calls me to 't. What custom wills, in all things should we do 't?(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 47)
The dust on antique time would lie unswept And mountainous error be too highly heaped For truth to o'erpeer.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 48)
Rather than fool it so, Let the high office and the honor go To one that would do thus.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 49)
am half through; The one part suffered, the other will do.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 50)
Here come more voices.-- Your voices! For your voices have fought; Watched for your voices; for your voices bear Of wounds two dozen odd.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 51)
Battles thrice six have seen and heard of; for your voices have Done many things, some less, some more.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 52)
Your voices! Indeed, would be consul.  He has done nobly, and cannot go without any honest man's voice.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 53)
Therefore let him be consul. The gods give him joy, and make him good friend to the people!(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 54)
Amen, amen. God save thee, noble consul.   Worthy voices!(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 55)
You have stood your limitation, and the Tribunes Endue you with the people's voice.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 56)
Remains That in th' official marks invested, you Anon do meet the Senate.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 57)
Is this done?   The custom of request you have discharged.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 58)
The people do admit you, and are summoned To meet anon upon your approbation.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 59)
Where? At the Senate House?  There, Coriolanus.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 60)
May change these garments?  You may, sir.   That I'll straight do and, knowing myself again, Repair to th' Senate House.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 61)
I'll keep you company.--Will you along?   We stay here for the people.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 62)
Fare you well.  He has it now; and by his looks, methinks, 'Tis warm at 's heart.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 63)
With a proud heart he wore His humble weeds. Will you dismiss the people?(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 64)
How now, my masters, have you chose this man?(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 65)
He has our voices, sir.   We pray the gods he may deserve your loves.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 66)
Amen, sir. To my poor unworthy notice, He mocked us when he begged our voices.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 67)
Certainly, he flouted us downright.   No, 'tis his kind of speech.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 68)
He did not mock us.   Not one amongst us, save yourself, but says He used us scornfully.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 69)
He should have showed us His marks of merit, wounds received for 's country.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 70)
Why, so he did, am sure.  No, no. No man saw 'em.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 71)
He said he had wounds, which he could show in private, And with his hat, thus waving it in scorn, would be consul," says he.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 72)
"Aged custom, But by your voices, will not so permit me; Your voices therefore.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 73)
" When we granted that, Here was thank you for your voices.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 74)
Thank you. Your most sweet voices! Now you have left your voices, have no further with you.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 75)
" Was not this mockery?   Why either were you ignorant to see 't Or, seeing it, of such childish friendliness To yield your voices?(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 76)
Could you not have told him As you were lessoned?(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 77)
When he had no power, But was a petty servant to the state, He was your enemy, ever spake against Your liberties and the charters that you bear th' body of the weal; and, now arriving place of potency and sway o' th' state, If he should still malignantly remain Fast foe to th' plebeii, your voices might Be curses to yourselves.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 78)
You should have said That as his worthy deeds did claim no less Than what he stood for, so his gracious nature Would think upon you for your voices, and Translate his malice towards you into love, Standing your friendly lord.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 79)
Thus to have said, As you were fore-advised, had touched his spirit And tried his inclination; from him plucked Either his gracious promise, which you might, As cause had called you up, have held him to; Or else it would have galled his surly nature, Which easily endures not article Tying him to aught.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 80)
So putting him to rage, You should have ta'en th' advantage of his choler And passed him unelected.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 81)
Did you perceive He did solicit you in free contempt When he did need your loves, and do you think That his contempt shall not be bruising to you When he hath power to crush?(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 82)
Why, had your bodies No heart among you? Or had you tongues to cry Against the rectorship of judgment?(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 83)
Have you ere now denied the asker? And now Again, of him that did not ask but mock, Bestow your sued-for tongues?(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 84)
He's not confirmed. We may deny him yet.  And will deny him.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 85)
I'll have five hundred voices of that sound.   twice five hundred, and their friends to piece 'em.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 86)
Get you hence instantly, and tell those friends They have chose a consul that will from them take Their liberties, make them of no more voice Than dogs that are as often beat for barking As therefor kept to do so.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 87)
Let them assemble And, on a safer judgment, all revoke Your ignorant election.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 88)
Enforce his pride And his old hate unto you. Besides, forget not With what contempt he wore the humble weed, How in his suit he scorned you; but your loves, Thinking upon his services, took from you Th' apprehension of his present portance, Which most gibingly, ungravely, he did fashion After the inveterate hate he bears you.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 89)
Lay fault on us, your tribunes, that we labored, No impediment between, but that you must Cast your election on him.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 90)
Say you chose him More after our commandment than as guided By your own true affections, and that your minds, Preoccupied with what you rather must do Than what you should, made you against the grain To voice him consul.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 91)
Lay the fault on us.   Ay, spare us not. Say we read lectures to you, How youngly he began to serve his country, How long continued, and what stock he springs of, The noble house o' th' Martians, from whence came That Ancus Martius, Numa's daughter's son, Who after great Hostilius here was king, Of the same house Publius and Quintus were, That our best water brought by conduits hither; And Censorinus, that was so surnamed, And nobly named so, twice being censor, Was his great ancestor.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 92)
One thus descended, That hath besides well in his person wrought To be set high in place, we did commend To your remembrances; but you have found, Scaling his present bearing with his past, That he's your fixed enemy, and revoke Your sudden approbation.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 93)
Say you ne'er had done 't-- Harp on that still--but by our putting on.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 94)
And presently, when you have drawn your number, Repair to th' Capitol.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 95)
We will so. Almost all Repent in their election.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 96)
Let them go on. This mutiny were better put in hazard Than stay, past doubt, for greater.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 97)
If, as his nature is, he fall in rage With their refusal, both observe and answer The vantage of his anger.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 98)
To th' Capitol, come. We will be there before the stream o' th' people, And this shall seem, as partly 'tis, their own, Which we have goaded onward.(Coriolanus, Act 2, Scene 99)
Was there ever man had such luck? When kissed the jack, upon an upcast to be hit away?(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 0)
had a hundred pound on 't. And then a whoreson jackanapes must take me up for swearing, as if borrowed mine oaths of him and might not spend them at my pleasure.(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 1)
What got he by that? You have broke his pate with your bowl.(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 2)
If his wit had been like him that broke it, it would have run all out.(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 3)
When a gentleman is disposed to swear, it is not for any standers-by to curtail his oaths, ha?(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 4)
No, my lord,  nor crop the ears of them.  Whoreson dog!(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 5)
gave him satisfaction. Would he had been one of my rank.(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 6)
To have smelled like a fool.  am not vexed more at anything in th' Earth.(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 7)
pox on 't! had rather not be so noble as am. They dare not fight with me because of the Queen my mother.(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 8)
Every jack-slave hath his bellyful of fighting, and must go up and down like a cock that nobody can match.(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 9)
You are cock and capon too, and you crow cock with your comb on.(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 10)
Sayest thou?  It is not fit your Lordship should undertake every companion that you give offense to.(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 11)
No, know that, but it is fit should commit offense to my inferiors.(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 12)
Ay, it is fit for your Lordship only.  Why, so say.(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 13)
Did you hear of a stranger that's come to court tonight?(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 14)
stranger, and not know on 't?  He's a strange fellow himself and knows it not.(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 15)
There's an Italian come, and 'tis thought one of Leonatus' friends.(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 16)
Leonatus? banished rascal; and he's another, whatsoever he be.(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 17)
Who told you of this stranger?  One of your Lordship's pages.(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 18)
Is it fit went to look upon him? Is there no derogation in 't?(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 19)
You cannot derogate, my lord.  Not easily, think.(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 20)
You are a fool granted; therefore your issues, being foolish, do not derogate.(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 21)
Come, I'll go see this Italian. What have lost today at bowls I'll win tonight of him.(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 22)
Come, go.  I'll attend your Lordship.  That such a crafty devil as is his mother Should yield the world this ass!(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 23)
woman that Bears all down with her brain, and this her son Cannot take two from twenty, for his heart, And leave eighteen.(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 24)
Alas, poor princess, Thou divine Imogen, what thou endur'st, Betwixt a father by thy stepdame governed, mother hourly coining plots, a wooer More hateful than the foul expulsion is Of thy dear husband, than that horrid act Of the divorce he'd make!(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 25)
The heavens hold firm The walls of thy dear honor, keep unshaked That temple, thy fair mind, that thou mayst stand enjoy thy banished lord and this great land.(Cymbeline, Act 0, Scene 26)
trunk is brought in. Enter Imogen, reading, in her     Who's there?(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 0)
My woman Helen?  Please you, madam.   What hour is it?(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 1)
Almost midnight, madam.   have read three hours then.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 2)
Mine eyes are weak.  Fold down the leaf where have left.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 3)
To bed. Take not away the taper; leave it burning.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 4)
And if thou canst awake by four o' th' clock, prithee, call me.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 5)
Sleep hath seized me wholly. To your protection commend me, gods.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 6)
From fairies and the tempters of the night Guard me, beseech you.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 7)
The crickets sing, and man's o'erlabored sense Repairs itself by rest.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 8)
Our Tarquin thus Did softly press the rushes ere he wakened The chastity he wounded.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 9)
--Cytherea, How bravely thou becom'st thy bed, fresh lily, And whiter than the sheets.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 10)
--That might touch! But kiss, one kiss! Rubies unparagoned, How dearly they do 't.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 11)
'Tis her breathing that Perfumes the chamber thus.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 12)
The flame o' th' taper Bows toward her and would underpeep her lids To see th' enclosed lights, now canopied Under these windows, white and azure-laced With blue of heaven's own tinct.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 13)
But my design: To note the chamber. will write all down.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 14)
Such and such pictures; there the window; such Th' adornment of her bed; the arras, figures, Why, such and such; and the contents o' th' story.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 15)
Ah, but some natural notes about her body Above ten thousand meaner movables Would testify t' enrich mine inventory.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 16)
sleep, thou ape of death, lie dull upon her, And be her sense but as a monument Thus in a chapel lying.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 17)
Come off, come off; As slippery as the Gordian knot was hard.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 18)
'Tis mine, and this will witness outwardly As strongly as the conscience does within To th' madding of her lord.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 19)
On her left breast mole cinque-spotted, like the crimson drops th' bottom of a cowslip.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 20)
Here's a voucher Stronger than ever law could make.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 21)
This secret Will force him think have picked the lock and ta'en The treasure of her honor.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 22)
No more. To what end? Why should write this down that's riveted, Screwed to my memory?(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 23)
She hath been reading late The tale of Tereus; here the leaf's turned down Where Philomel gave up.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 24)
have enough. To th' trunk again, and shut the spring of it.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 25)
Swift, swift, you dragons of the night, that dawning May bare the raven's eye.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 26)
lodge in fear. Though this a heavenly angel, hell is here.(Cymbeline, Act 1, Scene 27)
Your Lordship is the most patient man in loss, the most coldest that ever turned up ace.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 0)
It would make any man cold to lose.  But not every man patient after the noble temper of your Lordship.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 1)
You are most hot and furious when you win.  Winning will put any man into courage.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 2)
If could get this foolish Imogen, should have gold enough.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 3)
It's almost morning, is 't not?  Day, my lord.  would this music would come.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 4)
am advised to give her music a-mornings; they say it will penetrate.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 5)
Come on, tune. If you can penetrate her with your fingering, so.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 6)
We'll try with tongue, too. If none will do, let her remain, but I'll never give o'er.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 7)
First, a very excellent good-conceited thing; after, a wonderful sweet air, with admirable rich words to it, and then let her consider.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 8)
Song.  Hark, hark, the lark at heaven's gate sings, And Phoebus gins arise, His steeds to water at those springs On chaliced flowers that lies; And winking Mary-buds begin To ope their golden eyes.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 9)
With everything that pretty is, My lady sweet, arise, Arise, arise.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 10)
So, get you gone. If this penetrate, will consider your music the better.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 11)
If it do not, it is a vice in her ears which horsehairs and calves' guts, nor the voice of unpaved eunuch to boot, can never amend.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 12)
Here comes the King.  am glad was up so late, for that's the reason was up so early.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 13)
He cannot choose but take this service have done fatherly.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 14)
--Good morrow to your Majesty and to my gracious mother.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 15)
Attend you here the door of our stern daughter?(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 16)
Will she not forth?  have assailed her with musics, but she vouchsafes no notice.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 17)
The exile of her minion is too new; She hath not yet forgot him.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 18)
Some more time Must wear the print of his remembrance on 't, And then she's yours.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 19)
You are most bound to th' King, Who lets go by no vantages that may Prefer you to his daughter.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 20)
Frame yourself To orderly solicits and be friended With aptness of the season.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 21)
Make denials Increase your services. So seem as if You were inspired to do those duties which You tender to her; that you in all obey her, Save when command to your dismission tends, And therein you are senseless.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 22)
Senseless? Not so.      So like you, sir, ambassadors from Rome; The one is Caius Lucius.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 23)
worthy fellow, Albeit he comes on angry purpose now.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 24)
But that's no fault of his. We must receive him According to the honor of his sender, And towards himself, his goodness forespent on us, We must extend our notice.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 25)
--Our dear son, When you have given good morning to your mistress, Attend the Queen and us.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 26)
We shall have need employ you towards this Roman.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 27)
--Come, our queen.     If she be up, I'll speak with her; if not, Let her lie still and dream.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 28)
By your leave, ho!-- know her women are about her.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 29)
What If do line one of their hands? 'Tis gold Which buys admittance--oft it doth--yea, and makes Diana's rangers false themselves, yield up Their deer to th' stand o' th' stealer; and 'tis gold Which makes the true man killed and saves the thief, Nay, sometime hangs both thief and true man.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 30)
What Can it not do and undo? will make One of her women lawyer to me, for yet not understand the case myself.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 31)
By your leave.      Who's there that knocks?  gentleman.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 32)
No more?   Yes, and a gentlewoman's son.  That's more Than some whose tailors are as dear as yours Can justly boast of.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 33)
What's your Lordship's pleasure?   Your lady's person.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 34)
Is she ready?  Ay, To keep her chamber.  There is gold for you.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 35)
Sell me your good report.   How, my good name? Or to report of you What shall think is good?(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 36)
The Princess.    Good morrow, fairest sister. Your sweet hand.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 37)
Good morrow, sir. You lay out too much pains For purchasing but trouble.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 38)
The thanks give Is telling you that am poor of thanks And scarce can spare them.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 39)
Still swear love you.   If you but said so, 'twere as deep with me.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 40)
If you swear still, your recompense is still That regard it not.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 41)
This is no answer.   But that you shall not say yield being silent, would not speak.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 42)
pray you, spare me. Faith, shall unfold equal discourtesy To your best kindness.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 43)
One of your great knowing Should learn, being taught, forbearance.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 44)
To leave you in your madness 'twere my sin. will not.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 45)
Fools are not mad folks.  Do you call me fool?  As am mad, do.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 46)
If you'll be patient, I'll no more be mad. That cures us both.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 47)
am much sorry, sir, You put me to forget a lady's manners By being so verbal; and learn now for all That which know my heart, do here pronounce, By th' very truth of it, care not for you, And am so near the lack of charity To accuse myself hate you--which had rather You felt than make 't my boast.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 48)
You sin against Obedience, which you owe your father.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 49)
For The contract you pretend with that base wretch-- One bred of alms and fostered with cold dishes, With scraps o' th' court--it is no contract, none; And though it be allowed in meaner parties-- Yet who than he more mean?(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 50)
--to knit their souls, On whom there is no more dependency But brats and beggary, in self-figured knot; Yet you are curbed from that enlargement by The consequence o' th' crown, and must not foil The precious note of it with a base slave, hilding for a livery, a squire's cloth, pantler--not so eminent.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 51)
Profane fellow, Wert thou the son of Jupiter and no more But what thou art besides, thou wert too base To be his groom.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 52)
Thou wert dignified enough, Even to the point of envy, if 'twere made Comparative for your virtues to be styled The under-hangman of his kingdom and hated For being preferred so well.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 53)
The south fog rot him!   He never can meet more mischance than come To be but named of thee.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 54)
His mean'st garment That ever hath but clipped his body is dearer In my respect than all the hairs above thee, Were they all made such men.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 55)
--How now, Pisanio!     "His garment"? Now the devil--   To Dorothy, my woman, hie thee presently.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 56)
"His garment"?  am sprighted with a fool, Frighted and angered worse.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 57)
Go bid my woman Search for a jewel that too casually Hath left mine arm.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 58)
It was thy master's. Shrew me If would lose it for a revenue Of any king's in Europe.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 59)
do think saw 't this morning. Confident am Last night 'twas on mine arm; kissed it.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 60)
hope it be not gone to tell my lord That kiss aught but he.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 61)
'Twill not be lost.   hope so. Go and search.  You have abused me.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 62)
"His meanest garment"?  Ay, said so, sir. If you will make 't an action, call witness to 't.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 63)
will inform your father.  Your mother too. She's my good lady and will conceive, hope, But the worst of me.(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 64)
So leave you, sir, To th' worst of discontent.   I'll be revenged!(Cymbeline, Act 2, Scene 65)
Fear it not, sir. would were so sure To win the King as am bold her honor Will remain hers.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 0)
What means do you make to him?   Not any, but abide the change of time, Quake in the present winter's state, and wish That warmer days would come.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 1)
In these feared hopes barely gratify your love; they failing, must die much your debtor.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 2)
Your very goodness and your company O'erpays all can do.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 3)
By this, your king Hath heard of great Augustus. Caius Lucius Will do 's commission throughly.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 4)
And think He'll grant the tribute, send th' arrearages, Or look upon our Romans, whose remembrance Is yet fresh in their grief.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 5)
do believe, Statist though am none nor like to be, That this will prove a war; and you shall hear The legion now in Gallia sooner landed In our not-fearing Britain than have tidings Of any penny tribute paid.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 6)
Our countrymen Are men more ordered than when Julius Caesar Smiled at their lack of skill but found their courage Worthy his frowning at.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 7)
Their discipline, Now winged with their courages, will make known To their approvers they are people such That mend upon the world.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 8)
See, Iachimo!   The swiftest harts have posted you by land, And winds of all the corners kissed your sails To make your vessel nimble.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 9)
Welcome, sir.   hope the briefness of your answer made The speediness of your return.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 10)
Your lady Is one of the fairest that have looked upon.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 11)
And therewithal the best, or let her beauty Look thorough a casement to allure false hearts And be false with them.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 12)
Here are letters for you.   Their tenor good, trust.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 13)
'Tis very like.    Was Caius Lucius in the Briton court When you were there?(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 14)
He was expected then, but not approached.  All is well yet.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 15)
Sparkles this stone as it was wont, or is 't not Too dull for your good wearing?(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 16)
If have lost it, should have lost the worth of it in gold.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 17)
I'll make a journey twice as far t' enjoy second night of such sweet shortness which Was mine in Britain, for the ring is won.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 18)
The stone's too hard to come by.  Not a whit, Your lady being so easy.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 19)
Make not, sir, Your loss your sport. hope you know that we Must not continue friends.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 20)
Good sir, we must, If you keep covenant. Had not brought The knowledge of your mistress home, grant We were to question farther; but now Profess myself the winner of her honor, Together with your ring, and not the wronger Of her or you, having proceeded but By both your wills.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 21)
If you can make 't apparent That you have tasted her in bed, my hand And ring is yours.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 22)
If not, the foul opinion You had of her pure honor gains or loses Your sword or mine, or masterless leave both To who shall find them.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 23)
Sir, my circumstances, Being so near the truth as will make them, Must first induce you to believe; whose strength will confirm with oath, which doubt not You'll give me leave to spare when you shall find You need it not.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 24)
Proceed.  First, her bedchamber-- Where confess slept not, but profess Had that was well worth watching--it was hanged With tapestry of silk and silver, the story Proud Cleopatra when she met her Roman And Cydnus swelled above the banks, or for The press of boats or pride.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 25)
piece of work So bravely done, so rich, that it did strive In workmanship and value, which wondered Could be so rarely and exactly wrought Since the true life on 't was--  This is true, And this you might have heard of here, by me Or by some other.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 26)
More particulars Must justify my knowledge.  So they must, Or do your honor injury.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 27)
The chimney Is south the chamber, and the chimney-piece Chaste Dian bathing.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 28)
Never saw figures So likely to report themselves; the cutter Was as another Nature, dumb, outwent her, Motion and breath left out.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 29)
This is a thing Which you might from relation likewise reap, Being, as it is, much spoke of.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 30)
The roof o' th' chamber With golden cherubins is fretted.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 31)
Her andirons-- had forgot them--were two winking Cupids Of silver, each on one foot standing, nicely Depending on their brands.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 32)
This is her honor? Let it be granted you have seen all this--and praise Be given to your remembrance--the description Of what is in her chamber nothing saves The wager you have laid.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 33)
Then if you can Be pale, beg but leave to air this jewel.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 34)
See--  And now 'tis up again. It must be married To that your diamond.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 35)
I'll keep them.  Jove! Once more let me behold it.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 36)
Is it that Which left with her?  Sir, thank her, that.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 37)
She stripped it from her arm. see her yet. Her pretty action did outsell her gift And yet enriched it too.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 38)
She gave it me And said she prized it once.  Maybe she plucked it off To send it me.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 39)
She writes so to you, doth she?   no, no, no, 'tis true.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 40)
Here, take this too.  It is a basilisk unto mine eye, Kills me to look on 't.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 41)
Let there be no honor Where there is beauty, truth where semblance, love Where there's another man.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 42)
The vows of women Of no more bondage be to where they are made Than they are to their virtues, which is nothing.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 43)
above measure false!  Have patience, sir, And take your ring again.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 44)
'Tis not yet won. It may be probable she lost it; or Who knows if one her women, being corrupted, Hath stol'n it from her.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 45)
Very true, And so hope he came by 't.--Back, my ring!(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 46)
Render to me some corporal sign about her More evident than this, for this was stol'n.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 47)
By Jupiter, had it from her arm.   Hark you, he swears!(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 48)
By Jupiter he swears. 'Tis true--nay, keep the ring--'tis true.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 49)
am sure She would not lose it. Her attendants are All sworn and honorable.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 50)
They induced to steal it? And by a stranger? No, he hath enjoyed her.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 51)
The cognizance of her incontinency Is this. She hath bought the name of whore thus dearly.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 52)
There, take thy hire, and all the fiends of hell Divide themselves between you!(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 53)
Sir, be patient. This is not strong enough to be believed Of one persuaded well of.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 54)
Never talk on 't. She hath been colted by him.  If you seek For further satisfying, under her breast, Worthy the pressing, lies a mole, right proud Of that most delicate lodging.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 55)
By my life, kissed it, and it gave me present hunger To feed again, though full.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 56)
You do remember This stain upon her?  Ay, and it doth confirm Another stain as big as hell can hold, Were there no more but it.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 57)
Will you hear more?  Spare your arithmetic; Never count the turns.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 58)
Once, and a million!  I'll be sworn--  No swearing.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 59)
If you will swear you have not done 't, you lie, And will kill thee if thou dost deny Thou 'st made me cuckold.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 60)
I'll deny nothing.   that had her here, to tear her limb-meal!(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 61)
will go there and do 't i' th' court, before Her father.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 62)
I'll do something.  Quite beside The government of patience.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 63)
You have won. Let's follow him and pervert the present wrath He hath against himself.(Cymbeline, Act 3, Scene 64)
Is there no way for men to be, but women Must be half-workers?(Cymbeline, Act 4, Scene 0)
We are all bastards, And that most venerable man which Did call my father was know not where When was stamped.(Cymbeline, Act 4, Scene 1)
Some coiner with his tools Made me a counterfeit; yet my mother seemed The Dian of that time; so doth my wife The nonpareil of this.(Cymbeline, Act 4, Scene 2)
vengeance, vengeance! Me of my lawful pleasure she restrained And prayed me oft forbearance; did it with pudency so rosy the sweet view on 't Might well have warmed old Saturn, that thought her As chaste as unsunned snow.(Cymbeline, Act 4, Scene 3)
all the devils! This yellow Iachimo in an hour, was 't not?(Cymbeline, Act 4, Scene 4)
Or less? At first? Perchance he spoke not, but, Like a full-acorned boar, a German one, Cried and mounted; found no opposition But what he looked for should oppose and she Should from encounter guard.(Cymbeline, Act 4, Scene 5)
Could find out The woman's part in me--for there's no motion That tends to vice in man but affirm It is the woman's part: be it lying, note it, The woman's; flattering, hers; deceiving, hers; Lust and rank thoughts, hers, hers; revenges, hers; Ambitions, covetings, change of prides, disdain, Nice longing, slanders, mutability, All faults that have a name, nay, that hell knows, Why, hers, in part or all, but rather all.(Cymbeline, Act 4, Scene 6)
For even to vice They are not constant, but are changing still One vice but of a minute old for one Not half so old as that.(Cymbeline, Act 4, Scene 7)
I'll write against them, Detest them, curse them.(Cymbeline, Act 4, Scene 8)
Yet 'tis greater skill In a true hate to pray they have their will; The very devils cannot plague them better.(Cymbeline, Act 4, Scene 9)
Neither my husband nor the slave returned That in such haste sent to seek his master?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 0)
Sure, Luciana, it is two o'clock.   Perhaps some merchant hath invited him, And from the mart he's somewhere gone to dinner.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 1)
Good sister, let us dine, and never fret. man is master of his liberty; Time is their master, and when they see time They'll go or come.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 2)
If so, be patient, sister.   Why should their liberty than ours be more?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 3)
Because their business still lies out o' door.   Look when serve him so, he takes it ill.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 4)
know he is the bridle of your will.   There's none but asses will be bridled so.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 5)
Why, headstrong liberty is lashed with woe. There's nothing situate under heaven's eye But hath his bound in earth, in sea, in sky.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 6)
The beasts, the fishes, and the winged fowls Are their males' subjects and at their controls.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 7)
Man, more divine, the master of all these, Lord of the wide world and wild wat'ry seas, Endued with intellectual sense and souls, Of more preeminence than fish and fowls, Are masters to their females, and their lords.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 8)
Then let your will attend on their accords.   This servitude makes you to keep unwed.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 9)
Not this, but troubles of the marriage bed.   But, were you wedded, you would bear some sway.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 10)
Ere learn love, I'll practice to obey.   How if your husband start some otherwhere?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 11)
Till he come home again, would forbear.   Patience unmoved!(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 12)
No marvel though she pause; They can be meek that have no other cause.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 13)
wretched soul bruised with adversity We bid be quiet when we hear it cry, But were we burdened with like weight of pain, As much or more we should ourselves complain.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 14)
So thou, that hast no unkind mate to grieve thee, With urging helpless patience would relieve me; But if thou live to see like right bereft, This fool-begged patience in thee will be left.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 15)
Well, will marry one day, but to try. Here comes your man.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 16)
Now is your husband nigh.      Say, is your tardy master now at hand?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 17)
Nay, he's at two hands with me, and that my two ears can witness.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 18)
Say, didst thou speak with him? Know'st thou his mind?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 19)
Ay, ay, he told his mind upon mine ear. Beshrew his hand, scarce could understand it.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 20)
Spake he so doubtfully thou couldst not feel his meaning?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 21)
Nay, he struck so plainly could too well feel his blows, and withal so doubtfully that could scarce understand them.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 22)
But say, prithee, is he coming home? It seems he hath great care to please his wife.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 23)
Why, mistress, sure my master is horn mad.   Horn mad, thou villain?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 24)
mean not cuckold mad, But sure he is stark mad. When desired him to come home to dinner, He asked me for a thousand marks in gold.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 25)
"'Tis dinnertime," quoth "My gold," quoth he. "Your meat doth burn," quoth "My gold," quoth he.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 26)
"Will you come?" quoth "My gold," quoth he. "Where is the thousand marks gave thee, villain?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 27)
" "The pig," quoth "is burned." "My gold," quoth he.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 28)
"My mistress, sir," quoth "Hang up thy mistress! know not thy mistress.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 29)
Out on thy mistress!"  Quoth who?  Quoth my master.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 30)
know," quoth he, "no house, no wife, no mistress.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 31)
" So that my errand, due unto my tongue, thank him, bare home upon my shoulders, For, in conclusion, he did beat me there.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 32)
Go back again, thou slave, and fetch him home.   Go back again and be new beaten home?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 33)
For God's sake, send some other messenger.   Back, slave, or will break thy pate across.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 34)
And he will bless that cross with other beating.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 35)
Between you, shall have a holy head.   Hence, prating peasant.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 36)
Fetch thy master home.   Am so round with you as you with me, That like a football you do spurn me thus?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 37)
You spurn me hence, and he will spurn me hither. If last in this service, you must case me in leather.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 38)
Fie, how impatience loureth in your face.   His company must do his minions grace, Whilst at home starve for a merry look.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 39)
Hath homely age th' alluring beauty took From my poor cheek?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 40)
Then he hath wasted it. Are my discourses dull? Barren my wit?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 41)
If voluble and sharp discourse be marred, Unkindness blunts it more than marble hard.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 42)
Do their gay vestments his affections bait? That's not my fault; he's master of my state.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 43)
What ruins are in me that can be found By him not ruined?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 44)
Then is he the ground Of my defeatures. My decayed fair sunny look of his would soon repair.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 45)
But, too unruly deer, he breaks the pale And feeds from home.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 46)
Poor am but his stale.   Self-harming jealousy, fie, beat it hence.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 47)
Unfeeling fools can with such wrongs dispense. know his eye doth homage otherwhere, Or else what lets it but he would be here?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 48)
Sister, you know he promised me a chain. Would that alone o' love he would detain, So he would keep fair quarter with his bed.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 49)
see the jewel best enameled Will lose his beauty.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 50)
Yet the gold bides still That others touch, and often touching will Wear gold; yet no man that hath a name By falsehood and corruption doth it shame.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 51)
Since that my beauty cannot please his eye, I'll weep what's left away, and weeping die.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 0, Scene 52)
2        The gold gave to Dromio is laid up Safe at the Centaur, and the heedful slave Is wandered forth in care to seek me out.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 0)
By computation and mine host's report, could not speak with Dromio since at first sent him from the mart.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 1)
See, here he comes.    How now, sir? Is your merry humor altered?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 2)
As you love strokes, so jest with me again. You know no Centaur?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 3)
You received no gold? Your mistress sent to have me home to dinner?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 4)
My house was at the Phoenix? Wast thou mad, That thus so madly thou didst answer me?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 5)
What answer, sir? When spake such a word?   Even now, even here, not half an hour since.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 6)
did not see you since you sent me hence, Home to the Centaur with the gold you gave me.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 7)
Villain, thou didst deny the gold's receipt And told'st me of a mistress and a dinner, For which hope thou felt'st was displeased.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 8)
am glad to see you in this merry vein. What means this jest, pray you, master, tell me?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 9)
Yea, dost thou jeer and flout me in the teeth? Think'st thou jest?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 10)
Hold, take thou that and that.    Hold, sir, for God's sake!(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 11)
Now your jest is earnest. Upon what bargain do you give it me?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 12)
Because that familiarly sometimes Do use you for my fool and chat with you, Your sauciness will jest upon my love And make a common of my serious hours.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 13)
When the sun shines, let foolish gnats make sport, But creep in crannies when he hides his beams.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 14)
If you will jest with me, know my aspect, And fashion your demeanor to my looks, Or will beat this method in your sconce.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 15)
"Sconce" call you it? So you would leave battering, had rather have it a "head.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 16)
" An you use these blows long, must get a sconce for my head and ensconce it too, or else shall seek my wit in my shoulders.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 17)
But pray, sir, why am beaten?  Dost thou not know?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 18)
Nothing, sir, but that am beaten.  Shall tell you why?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 19)
Ay, sir, and wherefore, for they say every why hath a wherefore.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 20)
"Why" first: for flouting me; and then "wherefore": for urging it the second time to me.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 21)
Was there ever any man thus beaten out of season, When in the "why" and the "wherefore" is neither rhyme nor reason?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 22)
Well, sir, thank you.  Thank me, sir, for what?  Marry, sir, for this something that you gave me for nothing.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 23)
I'll make you amends next, to give you nothing for something.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 24)
But say, sir, is it dinnertime?  No, sir, think the meat wants that have.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 25)
In good time, sir, what's that?  Basting.  Well, sir, then 'twill be dry.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 26)
If it be, sir, pray you eat none of it.  Your reason?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 27)
Lest it make you choleric and purchase me another dry basting.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 28)
Well, sir, learn to jest in good time. There's a time for all things.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 29)
durst have denied that before you were so choleric.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 30)
By what rule, sir?  Marry, sir, by a rule as plain as the plain bald pate of Father Time himself.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 31)
Let's hear it.  There's no time for a man to recover his hair that grows bald by nature.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 32)
May he not do it by fine and recovery?  Yes, to pay a fine for a periwig, and recover the lost hair of another man.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 33)
Why is Time such a niggard of hair, being, as it is, so plentiful an excrement?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 34)
Because it is a blessing that he bestows on beasts, and what he hath scanted men in hair, he hath given them in wit.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 35)
Why, but there's many a man hath more hair than wit.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 36)
Not a man of those but he hath the wit to lose his hair.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 37)
Why, thou didst conclude hairy men plain dealers without wit.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 38)
The plainer dealer, the sooner lost. Yet he loseth it in a kind of jollity.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 39)
For what reason?  For two, and sound ones too.  Nay, not sound, pray you.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 40)
Sure ones, then.  Nay, not sure, in a thing falsing.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 41)
Certain ones, then.  Name them.  The one, to save the money that he spends in tiring; the other, that at dinner they should not drop in his porridge.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 42)
You would all this time have proved there is no time for all things.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 43)
Marry, and did, sir: namely, e'en no time to recover hair lost by nature.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 44)
But your reason was not substantial why there is no time to recover.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 45)
Thus mend it: Time himself is bald and therefore, to the world's end, will have bald followers.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 46)
knew 'twould be a bald conclusion. But soft, who wafts us yonder?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 47)
Ay, ay, Antipholus, look strange and frown. Some other mistress hath thy sweet aspects.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 48)
am not Adriana, nor thy wife. The time was once when thou unurged wouldst vow That never words were music to thine ear, That never object pleasing in thine eye, That never touch well welcome to thy hand, That never meat sweet-savored in thy taste, Unless spake, or looked, or touched, or carved to thee.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 49)
How comes it now, my husband, how comes it That thou art then estranged from thyself?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 50)
"Thyself" call it, being strange to me, That, undividable, incorporate, Am better than thy dear self's better part.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 51)
Ah, do not tear away thyself from me! For know, my love, as easy mayst thou fall drop of water in the breaking gulf, And take unmingled thence that drop again Without addition or diminishing, As take from me thyself and not me too.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 52)
How dearly would it touch thee to the quick, Shouldst thou but hear were licentious And that this body, consecrate to thee, By ruffian lust should be contaminate!(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 53)
Wouldst thou not spit at me, and spurn at me, And hurl the name of husband in my face, And tear the stained skin off my harlot brow, And from my false hand cut the wedding ring, And break it with a deep-divorcing vow?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 54)
know thou canst, and therefore see thou do it. am possessed with an adulterate blot; My blood is mingled with the crime of lust; For if we two be one, and thou play false, do digest the poison of thy flesh, Being strumpeted by thy contagion.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 55)
Keep then fair league and truce with thy true bed, live distained, thou undishonored.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 56)
Plead you to me, fair dame? know you not. In Ephesus am but two hours old, As strange unto your town as to your talk, Who, every word by all my wit being scanned, Wants wit in all one word to understand.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 57)
Fie, brother, how the world is changed with you!(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 58)
When were you wont to use my sister thus? She sent for you by Dromio home to dinner.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 59)
By Dromio?  By me?   By thee; and this thou didst return from him: That he did buffet thee and, in his blows, Denied my house for his, me for his wife.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 60)
Did you converse, sir, with this gentlewoman? What is the course and drift of your compact?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 61)
sir? never saw her till this time.   Villain, thou liest, for even her very words Didst thou deliver to me on the mart.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 62)
never spake with her in all my life.   How can she thus then call us by our names-- Unless it be by inspiration?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 63)
How ill agrees it with your gravity To counterfeit thus grossly with your slave, Abetting him to thwart me in my mood.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 64)
Be it my wrong you are from me exempt, But wrong not that wrong with a more contempt.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 65)
Come, will fasten on this sleeve of thine.  Thou art an elm, my husband, a vine, Whose weakness, married to thy stronger state, Makes me with thy strength to communicate.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 66)
If aught possess thee from me, it is dross, Usurping ivy, brier, or idle moss, Who, all for want of pruning, with intrusion Infect thy sap and live on thy confusion.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 67)
To me she speaks; she moves me for her theme. What, was married to her in my dream?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 68)
Or sleep now and think hear all this? What error drives our eyes and ears amiss?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 69)
Until know this sure uncertainty I'll entertain the offered fallacy.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 70)
Dromio, go bid the servants spread for dinner.   for my beads!(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 71)
cross me for a sinner.  This is the fairy land. spite of spites!(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 72)
We talk with goblins, owls, and sprites. If we obey them not, this will ensue: They'll suck our breath, or pinch us black and blue.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 73)
Why prat'st thou to thyself and answer'st not? Dromio--thou, Dromio--thou snail, thou slug, thou sot.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 74)
am transformed, master, am not?   think thou art in mind, and so am   Nay, master, both in mind and in my shape.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 75)
Thou hast thine own form.  No, am an ape.   If thou art changed to aught, 'tis to an ass.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 76)
'Tis true. She rides me, and long for grass. 'Tis so.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 77)
am an ass; else it could never be But should know her as well as she knows me.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 78)
Come, come, no longer will be a fool, To put the finger in the eye and weep Whilst man and master laughs my woes to scorn.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 79)
Come, sir, to dinner.--Dromio, keep the gate.-- Husband, I'll dine above with you today, And shrive you of a thousand idle pranks.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 80)
Sirrah, if any ask you for your master, Say he dines forth, and let no creature enter.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 81)
-- Come, sister.--Dromio, play the porter well.   Am in Earth, in heaven, or in hell?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 82)
Sleeping or waking, mad or well-advised? Known unto these, and to myself disguised!(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 83)
I'll say as they say, and persever so, And in this mist at all adventures go.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 84)
Master, shall be porter at the gate?   Ay, and let none enter, lest break your pate.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 1, Scene 85)
Good Signior Angelo, you must excuse us all; My wife is shrewish when keep not hours.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 0)
Say that lingered with you at your shop To see the making of her carcanet, And that tomorrow you will bring it home.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 1)
But here's a villain that would face me down He met me on the mart, and that beat him And charged him with a thousand marks in gold, And that did deny my wife and house.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 2)
-- Thou drunkard, thou, what didst thou mean by this?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 3)
Say what you will, sir, but know what know. That you beat me at the mart have your hand to show; If the skin were parchment and the blows you gave were ink, Your own handwriting would tell you what think.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 4)
think thou art an ass.  Marry, so it doth appear By the wrongs suffer and the blows bear.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 5)
should kick being kicked and, being at that pass, You would keep from my heels and beware of an ass.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 6)
You're sad, Signior Balthasar. Pray God our cheer May answer my goodwill and your good welcome here.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 7)
hold your dainties cheap, sir, and your welcome dear.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 8)
Signior Balthasar, either at flesh or fish table full of welcome makes scarce one dainty dish.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 9)
Good meat, sir, is common; that every churl affords.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 10)
And welcome more common, for that's nothing but words.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 11)
Small cheer and great welcome makes a merry feast.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 12)
Ay, to a niggardly host and more sparing guest.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 13)
But though my cates be mean, take them in good part.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 14)
Better cheer may you have, but not with better heart.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 15)
But soft! My door is locked.  Go, bid them let us in.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 16)
Maud, Bridget, Marian, Ciceley, Gillian, Ginn!   Mome, malt-horse, capon, coxcomb, idiot, patch!(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 17)
Either get thee from the door or sit down at the hatch.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 18)
Dost thou conjure for wenches, that thou call'st for such store When one is one too many?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 19)
Go, get thee from the door.   What patch is made our porter?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 20)
My master stays in the street.   Let him walk from whence he came, lest he catch cold on 's feet.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 21)
Who talks within there? Ho, open the door.   Right, sir, I'll tell you when an you'll tell me wherefore.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 22)
Wherefore? For my dinner. have not dined today.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 23)
Nor today here you must not. Come again when you may.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 24)
What art thou that keep'st me out from the house owe?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 25)
The porter for this time, sir, and my name is Dromio.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 26)
villain, thou hast stolen both mine office and my name!(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 27)
The one ne'er got me credit, the other mickle blame.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 28)
If thou hadst been Dromio today in my place, Thou wouldst have changed thy face for a name, or thy name for an ass.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 29)
What a coil is there, Dromio! Who are those at the gate?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 30)
Let my master in, Luce.  Faith, no, he comes too late, And so tell your master.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 31)
Lord, must laugh. Have at you with a proverb: shall set in my staff?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 32)
Have at you with another: that's--When, can you tell?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 33)
If thy name be called "Luce," Luce, thou hast answered him well.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 34)
Do you hear, you minion? You'll let us in, hope?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 35)
thought to have asked you.  And you said no.   So, come help.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 36)
Well struck! There was blow for blow.   Thou baggage, let me in.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 37)
Can you tell for whose sake?   Master, knock the door hard.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 38)
Let him knock till it ache.   You'll cry for this, minion, if beat the door down.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 39)
What needs all that, and a pair of stocks in the town?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 40)
Who is that at the door that keeps all this noise?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 41)
By my troth, your town is troubled with unruly boys.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 42)
Are you there, wife? You might have come before.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 43)
Your wife, sir knave? Go, get you from the door.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 44)
If you went in pain, master, this knave would go sore.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 45)
Here is neither cheer, sir, nor welcome. We would fain have either.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 46)
In debating which was best, we shall part with neither.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 47)
They stand at the door, master. Bid them welcome hither.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 48)
There is something in the wind, that we cannot get in.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 49)
You would say so, master, if your garments were thin.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 50)
Your cake here is warm within; you stand here in the cold.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 51)
It would make a man mad as a buck to be so bought and sold.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 52)
Go, fetch me something. I'll break ope the gate.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 53)
Break any breaking here, and I'll break your knave's pate.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 54)
man may break a word with you, sir, and words are but wind, Ay, and break it in your face, so he break it not behind.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 55)
It seems thou want'st breaking. Out upon thee, hind!(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 56)
Here's too much "Out upon thee!" pray thee, let me in.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 57)
Ay, when fowls have no feathers and fish have no fin.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 58)
Well, I'll break in. Go, borrow me a crow.   crow without feather?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 59)
Master, mean you so? For a fish without a fin, there's a fowl without a feather.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 60)
-- If a crow help us in, sirrah, we'll pluck a crow together.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 61)
Go, get thee gone. Fetch me an iron crow.   Have patience, sir.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 62)
let it not be so. Herein you war against your reputation, And draw within the compass of suspect Th' unviolated honor of your wife.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 63)
Once this: your long experience of her wisdom, Her sober virtue, years, and modesty Plead on her part some cause to you unknown.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 64)
And doubt not, sir, but she will well excuse Why at this time the doors are made against you.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 65)
Be ruled by me; depart in patience, And let us to the Tiger all to dinner, And about evening come yourself alone To know the reason of this strange restraint.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 66)
If by strong hand you offer to break in Now in the stirring passage of the day, vulgar comment will be made of it; And that supposed by the common rout Against your yet ungalled estimation That may with foul intrusion enter in And dwell upon your grave when you are dead; For slander lives upon succession, Forever housed where it gets possession.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 67)
You have prevailed. will depart in quiet And, in despite of mirth, mean to be merry.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 68)
know a wench of excellent discourse, Pretty and witty, wild and yet, too, gentle.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 69)
There will we dine. This woman that mean, My wife--but, protest, without desert-- Hath oftentimes upbraided me withal; To her will we to dinner.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 70)
Get you home And fetch the chain; by this, know, 'tis made.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 71)
Bring it, pray you, to the Porpentine, For there's the house.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 72)
That chain will bestow-- Be it for nothing but to spite my wife-- Upon mine hostess there.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 73)
Good sir, make haste. Since mine own doors refuse to entertain me, I'll knock elsewhere, to see if they'll disdain me.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 74)
I'll meet you at that place some hour hence.   Do so.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 11, Scene 75)
3        And may it be that you have quite forgot husband's office?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 0)
Shall, Antipholus, Even in the spring of love thy love-springs rot?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 1)
Shall love, in building, grow so ruinous? If you did wed my sister for her wealth, Then for her wealth's sake use her with more kindness.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 2)
Or if you like elsewhere, do it by stealth -- Muffle your false love with some show of blindness.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 3)
Let not my sister read it in your eye; Be not thy tongue thy own shame's orator; Look sweet, speak fair, become disloyalty; Apparel vice like virtue's harbinger.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 4)
Bear a fair presence, though your heart be tainted.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 5)
Teach sin the carriage of a holy saint. Be secret-false.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 6)
What need she be acquainted? What simple thief brags of his own attaint?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 7)
'Tis double wrong to truant with your bed And let her read it in thy looks at board.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 8)
Shame hath a bastard fame, well managed; Ill deeds is doubled with an evil word.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 9)
Alas, poor women, make us but believe, Being compact of credit, that you love us.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 10)
Though others have the arm, show us the sleeve; We in your motion turn, and you may move us.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 11)
Then, gentle brother, get you in again. Comfort my sister, cheer her, call her wife.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 12)
'Tis holy sport to be a little vain When the sweet breath of flattery conquers strife.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 13)
Sweet mistress--what your name is else know not, Nor by what wonder you do hit of mine-- Less in your knowledge and your grace you show not Than our Earth's wonder, more than Earth divine.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 14)
Teach me, dear creature, how to think and speak. Lay open to my earthy gross conceit, Smothered in errors, feeble, shallow, weak, The folded meaning of your words' deceit.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 15)
Against my soul's pure truth why labor you To make it wander in an unknown field?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 16)
Are you a god? Would you create me new? Transform me, then, and to your power I'll yield.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 17)
But if that am then well know Your weeping sister is no wife of mine, Nor to her bed no homage do owe.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 18)
Far more, far more, to you do decline. train me not, sweet mermaid, with thy note To drown me in thy sister's flood of tears.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 19)
Sing, Siren, for thyself, and will dote. Spread o'er the silver waves thy golden hairs, And as a bed I'll take them and there lie, And in that glorious supposition think He gains by death that hath such means to die.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 20)
Let love, being light, be drowned if she sink.   What, are you mad that you do reason so?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 21)
Not mad, but mated--how, do not know.   It is a fault that springeth from your eye.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 22)
For gazing on your beams, fair sun, being by.   Gaze when you should, and that will clear your sight.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 23)
As good to wink, sweet love, as look on night.   Why call you me "love"?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 24)
Call my sister so.   Thy sister's sister.  That's my sister.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 25)
No, It is thyself, mine own self's better part, Mine eye's clear eye, my dear heart's dearer heart, My food, my fortune, and my sweet hope's aim, My sole Earth's heaven, and my heaven's claim.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 26)
All this my sister is, or else should be.   Call thyself "sister," sweet, for am thee.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 27)
Thee will love, and with thee lead my life; Thou hast no husband yet, nor no wife.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 28)
Give me thy hand.  soft, sir. Hold you still. I'll fetch my sister to get her goodwill.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 29)
Why, how now, Dromio. Where runn'st thou so fast?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 30)
Do you know me, sir? Am Dromio? Am your man? Am myself?(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 31)
Thou art Dromio, thou art my man, thou art thyself.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 32)
am an ass, am a woman's man, and besides myself.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 33)
What woman's man? And how besides thyself?  Marry, sir, besides myself am due to a woman, one that claims me, one that haunts me, one that will have me.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 34)
What claim lays she to thee?  Marry, sir, such claim as you would lay to your horse, and she would have me as a beast; not that being a beast she would have me, but that she, being a very beastly creature, lays claim to me.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 35)
What is she?  very reverend body, ay, such a one as a man may not speak of without he say "sir-reverence.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 36)
" have but lean luck in the match, and yet is she a wondrous fat marriage.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 37)
How dost thou mean a "fat marriage"?  Marry, sir, she's the kitchen wench, and all grease, and know not what use to put her to but to make a lamp of her and run from her by her own light.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 38)
warrant her rags and the tallow in them will burn a Poland winter.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 39)
If she lives till doomsday, she'll burn a week longer than the whole world.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 40)
What complexion is she of?  Swart like my shoe, but her face nothing like so clean kept.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 41)
For why? She sweats. man may go overshoes in the grime of it.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 42)
That's a fault that water will mend.  No, sir, 'tis in grain; Noah's flood could not do it.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 43)
What's her name?  Nell, sir, but her name and three quarters--that's an ell and three quarters-- will not measure her from hip to hip.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 44)
Then she bears some breadth?  No longer from head to foot than from hip to hip.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 45)
She is spherical, like a globe. could find out countries in her.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 46)
In what part of her body stands Ireland?  Marry, sir, in her buttocks.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 47)
found it out by the bogs.  Where Scotland?  found it by the barrenness, hard in the palm of the hand.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 48)
Where France?  In her forehead, armed and reverted, making war against her heir.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 49)
Where England?  looked for the chalky cliffs, but could find no whiteness in them.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 50)
But guess it stood in her chin, by the salt rheum that ran between France and it.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 51)
Where Spain?  Faith, saw it not, but felt it hot in her breath.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 52)
Where America, the Indies?  sir, upon her nose, all o'erembellished with rubies, carbuncles, sapphires, declining their rich aspect to the hot breath of Spain, who sent whole armadas of carracks to be ballast at her nose.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 53)
Where stood Belgia, the Netherlands?  sir, did not look so low.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 54)
To conclude: this drudge or diviner laid claim to me, called me Dromio, swore was assured to her, told me what privy marks had about me, as the mark of my shoulder, the mole in my neck, the great wart on my left arm, that amazed, ran from her as a witch.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 55)
And, think, if my breast had not been made of faith, and my heart of steel, She had transformed me to a curtal dog and made me turn i' th' wheel.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 56)
Go, hie thee presently. Post to the road. An if the wind blow any way from shore, will not harbor in this town tonight.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 57)
If any bark put forth, come to the mart, Where will walk till thou return to me.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 58)
If everyone knows us, and we know none, 'Tis time, think, to trudge, pack, and be gone.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 59)
As from a bear a man would run for life, So fly from her that would be my wife.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 60)
There's none but witches do inhabit here, And therefore 'tis high time that were hence.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 61)
She that doth call me husband, even my soul Doth for a wife abhor.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 62)
