But her fair sister, Possessed with such a gentle sovereign grace, Of such enchanting presence and discourse, Hath almost made me traitor to myself.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 63)
But lest myself be guilty to self wrong, I'll stop mine ears against the mermaid's song.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 64)
Master Antipholus.  Ay, that's my name.   know it well, sir.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 65)
Lo, here's the chain. thought to have ta'en you at the Porpentine; The chain unfinished made me stay thus long.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 66)
What is your will that shall do with this?   What please yourself, sir.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 67)
have made it for you.   Made it for me, sir? bespoke it not.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 68)
Not once, nor twice, but twenty times you have.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 69)
Go home with it, and please your wife withal, And soon at supper time I'll visit you And then receive my money for the chain.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 70)
pray you, sir, receive the money now, For fear you ne'er see chain nor money more.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 71)
You are a merry man, sir. Fare you well.   What should think of this cannot tell, But this think: there's no man is so vain That would refuse so fair an offered chain.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 72)
see a man here needs not live by shifts When in the streets he meets such golden gifts.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 73)
I'll to the mart, and there for Dromio stay. If any ship put out, then straight away.(The Comedy of Errors, Act 12, Scene 74)
Well met, Corporal Nym.  Good morrow, Lieutenant Bardolph.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 0)
What, are Ancient Pistol and you friends yet?  For my part, care not.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 1)
say little, but when time shall serve, there shall be smiles; but that shall be as it may.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 2)
dare not fight, but will wink and hold out mine iron.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 3)
It is a simple one, but what though? It will toast cheese, and it will endure cold as another man's sword will, and there's an end.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 4)
will bestow a breakfast to make you friends, and we'll be all three sworn brothers to France.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 5)
Let 't be so, good Corporal Nym.  Faith, will live so long as may, that's the certain of it; and when cannot live any longer, will do as may.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 6)
That is my rest, that is the rendezvous of it.  It is certain, corporal, that he is married to Nell Quickly, and certainly she did you wrong, for you were troth-plight to her.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 7)
cannot tell. Things must be as they may. Men may sleep, and they may have their throats about them at that time, and some say knives have edges.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 8)
It must be as it may. Though patience be a tired mare, yet she will plod.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 9)
There must be conclusions. Well, cannot tell.     Here comes Ancient Pistol and his wife.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 10)
Good corporal, be patient here.--How now, mine host Pistol?(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 11)
Base tyke, call'st thou me host? Now, by this hand, swear scorn the term, nor shall my Nell keep lodgers.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 12)
No, by my troth, not long; for we cannot lodge and board a dozen or fourteen gentlewomen that live honestly by the prick of their needles but it will be thought we keep a bawdy house straight.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 13)
well-a-day, Lady! If he be not hewn now, we shall see willful adultery and murder committed.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 14)
Good lieutenant, good corporal, offer nothing here.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 15)
Pish!  Pish for thee, Iceland dog, thou prick-eared cur of Iceland!(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 16)
Good Corporal Nym, show thy valor, and put up your sword.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 17)
Will you shog off?  would have you solus.  "Solus, egregious dog?(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 18)
viper vile, the solus in thy most marvelous face, the solus in thy teeth and in thy throat and in thy hateful lungs, yea, in thy maw, perdy, and, which is worse, within thy nasty mouth!(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 19)
do retort the solus in thy bowels, for can take, and Pistol's cock is up, and flashing fire will follow.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 20)
am not Barbason, you cannot conjure me. have an humor to knock you indifferently well.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 21)
If you grow foul with me, Pistol, will scour you with my rapier, as may, in fair terms.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 22)
If you would walk off, would prick your guts a little in good terms, as may, and that's the humor of it.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 23)
braggart vile and damned furious wight, The grave doth gape, and doting death is near.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 24)
Therefore exhale.  Hear me, hear me what say: he that strikes the first stroke, I'll run him up to the hilts, as am a soldier.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 25)
An oath of mickle might, and fury shall abate.   Give me thy fist, thy forefoot to me give.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 26)
Thy spirits are most tall.  will cut thy throat one time or other in fair terms, that is the humor of it.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 27)
Couple a gorge, that is the word. defy thee again.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 28)
hound of Crete, think'st thou my spouse to get? No, to the spital go, and from the powd'ring tub of infamy fetch forth the lazar kite of Cressid's kind, Doll Tearsheet she by name, and her espouse.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 29)
have, and will hold, the quondam Quickly for the only she: and pauca, there's enough too!(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 30)
Go to.     Mine host Pistol, you must come to my master, and your hostess.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 31)
He is very sick and would to bed.--Good Bardolph, put thy face between his sheets, and do the office of a warming-pan.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 32)
Faith, he's very ill.  Away, you rogue!  By my troth, he'll yield the crow a pudding one of these days.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 33)
The King has killed his heart. Good husband, come home presently.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 34)
Come, shall make you two friends? We must to France together.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 35)
Why the devil should we keep knives to cut one another's throats?(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 36)
Let floods o'erswell and fiends for food howl on!(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 37)
You'll pay me the eight shillings won of you at betting?(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 38)
Base is the slave that pays.  That now will have, that's the humor of it.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 39)
As manhood shall compound. Push home.   By this sword, he that makes the first thrust, I'll kill him.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 40)
By this sword, will.  "Sword" is an oath, and oaths must have their course.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 41)
Corporal Nym, an thou wilt be friends, be friends; an thou wilt not, why then be enemies with me too.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 42)
Prithee, put up.  noble shalt thou have, and present pay, and liquor likewise will give to thee, and friendship shall combine, and brotherhood.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 43)
I'll live by Nym, and Nym shall live by me. Is not this just?(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 44)
For shall sutler be unto the camp, and profits will accrue.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 45)
Give me thy hand.  shall have my noble?  In cash, most justly paid.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 46)
Well, then, that's the humor of 't.      As ever you come of women, come in quickly to Sir John.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 47)
Ah, poor heart, he is so shaked of a burning quotidian-tertian that it is most lamentable to behold.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 48)
Sweet men, come to him.  The King hath run bad humors on the knight, that's the even of it.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 49)
Nym, thou hast spoke the right. His heart is fracted and corroborate.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 50)
The King is a good king, but it must be as it may; he passes some humors and careers.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 51)
Let us condole the knight, for, lambkins, we will live.(Henry V, Act 0, Scene 52)
2        Now all the youth of England are on fire, And silken dalliance in the wardrobe lies; Now thrive the armorers, and honor's thought Reigns solely in the breast of every man.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 0)
They sell the pasture now to buy the horse, Following the mirror of all Christian kings With winged heels, as English Mercurys.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 1)
For now sits Expectation in the air And hides a sword, from hilts unto the point, With crowns imperial, crowns, and coronets Promised to Harry and his followers.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 2)
The French, advised by good intelligence Of this most dreadful preparation, Shake in their fear, and with pale policy Seek to divert the English purposes.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 3)
England, model to thy inward greatness, Like little body with a mighty heart, What might'st thou do, that honor would thee do, Were all thy children kind and natural!(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 4)
But see, thy fault France hath in thee found out, nest of hollow bosoms, which he fills With treacherous crowns, and three corrupted men-- One, Richard, Earl of Cambridge, and the second, Henry, Lord Scroop of Masham, and the third, Sir Thomas Grey, knight, of Northumberland-- Have, for the gilt of France guilt indeed!(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 5)
), Confirmed conspiracy with fearful France, And by their hands this grace of kings must die, If hell and treason hold their promises, Ere he take ship for France, and in Southampton.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 6)
Linger your patience on, and we'll digest Th' abuse of distance, force a play.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 7)
The sum is paid, the traitors are agreed, The King is set from London, and the scene Is now transported, gentles, to Southampton.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 8)
There is the playhouse now, there must you sit, And thence to France shall we convey you safe And bring you back, charming the narrow seas To give you gentle pass; for, if we may, We'll not offend one stomach with our play.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 9)
But, till the King come forth, and not till then, Unto Southampton do we shift our scene.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 10)
'Fore God, his Grace is bold to trust these traitors.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 11)
They shall be apprehended by and by.   How smooth and even they do bear themselves, As if allegiance in their bosoms sat Crowned with faith and constant loyalty.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 12)
The King hath note of all that they intend, By interception which they dream not of.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 13)
Nay, but the man that was his bedfellow, Whom he hath dulled and cloyed with gracious favors-- That he should, for a foreign purse, so sell His sovereign's life to death and treachery!(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 14)
Now sits the wind fair, and we will aboard.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 15)
-- My Lord of Cambridge, and my kind Lord of Masham, And you, my gentle knight, give me your thoughts.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 16)
Think you not that the powers we bear with us Will cut their passage through the force of France, Doing the execution and the act For which we have in head assembled them?(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 17)
No doubt, my liege, if each man do his best.   doubt not that, since we are well persuaded We carry not a heart with us from hence That grows not in a fair consent with ours, Nor leave not one behind that doth not wish Success and conquest to attend on us.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 18)
Never was monarch better feared and loved Than is your Majesty.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 19)
There's not, think, a subject That sits in heart-grief and uneasiness Under the sweet shade of your government.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 20)
True. Those that were your father's enemies Have steeped their galls in honey, and do serve you With hearts create of duty and of zeal.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 21)
We therefore have great cause of thankfulness, And shall forget the office of our hand Sooner than quittance of desert and merit According to the weight and worthiness.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 22)
So service shall with steeled sinews toil, And labor shall refresh itself with hope To do your Grace incessant services.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 23)
We judge no less.--Uncle of Exeter, Enlarge the man committed yesterday That railed against our person.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 24)
We consider It was excess of wine that set him on, And on his more advice we pardon him.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 25)
That's mercy, but too much security. Let him be punished, sovereign, lest example Breed, by his sufferance, more of such a kind.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 26)
let us yet be merciful.   So may your Highness, and yet punish too.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 27)
Sir, you show great mercy if you give him life After the taste of much correction.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 28)
Alas, your too much love and care of me Are heavy orisons 'gainst this poor wretch.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 29)
If little faults proceeding on distemper Shall not be winked at, how shall we stretch our eye When capital crimes, chewed, swallowed, and digested, Appear before us?(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 30)
We'll yet enlarge that man, Though Cambridge, Scroop, and Grey, in their dear care And tender preservation of our person, Would have him punished.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 31)
And now to our French causes. Who are the late commissioners?(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 32)
one, my lord. Your Highness bade me ask for it today.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 33)
So did you me, my liege.  And my royal sovereign.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 34)
Then Richard, Earl of Cambridge, there is yours-- There yours, Lord Scroop of Masham.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 35)
--And, sir knight, Grey of Northumberland, this same is yours.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 36)
-- Read them, and know know your worthiness.-- My Lord of Westmoreland and uncle Exeter, We will aboard tonight.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 37)
--Why how now, gentlemen? What see you in those papers, that you lose So much complexion?(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 38)
--Look you, how they change. Their cheeks are paper.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 39)
--Why, what read you there That have so cowarded and chased your blood Out of appearance?(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 40)
do confess my fault, And do submit me to your Highness' mercy.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 41)
To which we all appeal.   The mercy that was quick in us but late By your own counsel is suppressed and killed.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 42)
You must not dare, for shame, to talk of mercy, For your own reasons turn into your bosoms As dogs upon their masters, worrying you.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 43)
-- See you, my princes and my noble peers, These English monsters.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 44)
My Lord of Cambridge here, You know how apt our love was to accord To furnish him with all appurtenants Belonging to his honor, and this man Hath, for a few light crowns, lightly conspired And sworn unto the practices of France To kill us here in Hampton; to the which This knight, no less for bounty bound to us Than Cambridge is, hath likewise sworn.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 45)
--But What shall say to thee, Lord Scroop, thou cruel, Ingrateful, savage, and inhuman creature?(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 46)
Thou that didst bear the key of all my counsels, That knew'st the very bottom of my soul, That almost mightst have coined me into gold, Wouldst thou have practiced on me for thy use-- May it be possible that foreign hire Could out of thee extract one spark of evil That might annoy my finger?(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 47)
'Tis so strange That, though the truth of it stands off as gross As black and white, my eye will scarcely see it.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 48)
Treason and murder ever kept together, As two yoke-devils sworn to either's purpose, Working so grossly in a natural cause That admiration did not whoop at them.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 49)
But thou, 'gainst all proportion, didst bring in Wonder to wait on treason and on murder, And whatsoever cunning fiend it was That wrought upon thee so preposterously Hath got the voice in hell for excellence.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 50)
All other devils that suggest by treasons Do botch and bungle up damnation With patches, colors, and with forms being fetched From glist'ring semblances of piety; But he that tempered thee bade thee stand up, Gave thee no instance why thou shouldst do treason, Unless to dub thee with the name of traitor.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 51)
If that same demon that hath gulled thee thus Should with his lion gait walk the whole world, He might return to vasty Tartar back And tell the legions can never win soul so easy as that Englishman's.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 52)
" how hast thou with jealousy infected The sweetness of affiance!(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 53)
Show men dutiful? Why, so didst thou. Seem they grave and learned?(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 54)
Why, so didst thou. Come they of noble family? Why, so didst thou.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 55)
Seem they religious? Why, so didst thou. Or are they spare in diet, Free from gross passion or of mirth or anger, Constant in spirit, not swerving with the blood, Garnished and decked in modest complement, Not working with the eye without the ear, And but in purged judgment trusting neither?(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 56)
Such and so finely bolted didst thou seem. And thus thy fall hath left a kind of blot To mark the full-fraught man and best endued With some suspicion.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 57)
will weep for thee, For this revolt of thine methinks is like Another fall of man.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 58)
--Their faults are open. Arrest them to the answer of the law, And God acquit them of their practices.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 59)
arrest thee of high treason, by the name of Richard, Earl of Cambridge.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 60)
-- arrest thee of high treason, by the name of Henry, Lord Scroop of Masham.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 61)
-- arrest thee of high treason, by the name of Thomas Grey, knight, of Northumberland.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 62)
Our purposes God justly hath discovered, And repent my fault more than my death, Which beseech your Highness to forgive, Although my body pay the price of it.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 63)
For me, the gold of France did not seduce, Although did admit it as a motive The sooner to effect what intended; But God be thanked for prevention, Which in sufferance heartily will rejoice, Beseeching God and you to pardon me.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 64)
Never did faithful subject more rejoice At the discovery of most dangerous treason Than do at this hour joy o'er myself, Prevented from a damned enterprise.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 65)
My fault, but not my body, pardon, sovereign.   God quit you in His mercy.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 66)
Hear your sentence: You have conspired against our royal person, Joined with an enemy proclaimed, and from his coffers Received the golden earnest of our death, Wherein you would have sold your king to slaughter, His princes and his peers to servitude, His subjects to oppression and contempt, And his whole kingdom into desolation.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 67)
Touching our person, seek we no revenge, But we our kingdom's safety must so tender, Whose ruin you have sought, that to her laws We do deliver you.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 68)
Get you therefore hence, Poor miserable wretches, to your death, The taste whereof God of His mercy give You patience to endure, and true repentance Of all your dear offenses.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 69)
--Bear them hence.  Now, lords, for France, the enterprise whereof Shall be to you as us, like glorious.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 70)
We doubt not of a fair and lucky war, Since God so graciously hath brought to light This dangerous treason lurking in our way To hinder our beginnings.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 71)
We doubt not now But every rub is smoothed on our way.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 72)
Then forth, dear countrymen. Let us deliver Our puissance into the hand of God, Putting it straight in expedition.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 73)
Cheerly to sea. The signs of war advance. No king of England if not king of France.(Henry V, Act 1, Scene 74)
Prithee, honey-sweet husband, let me bring thee to Staines.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 0)
No; for my manly heart doth earn.--Bardolph, be blithe.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 1)
--Nym, rouse thy vaunting veins.-- Boy, bristle thy courage up.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 2)
For Falstaff, he is dead, and we must earn therefore.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 3)
Would were with him, wheresome'er he is, either in heaven or in hell.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 4)
Nay, sure, he's not in hell! He's in Arthur's bosom, if ever man went to Arthur's bosom.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 5)
He made a finer end, and went away an it had been any christom child.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 6)
He parted ev'n just between twelve and one, ev'n at the turning o' th' tide; for after saw him fumble with the sheets and play with flowers and smile upon his finger's end, knew there was but one way, for his nose was as sharp as a pen and he talked of green fields.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 7)
"How now, Sir John?" quoth "What, man, be o' good cheer!(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 8)
" So he cried out "God, God, God!" three or four times.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 9)
Now to comfort him, bid him he should not think of God; hoped there was no need to trouble himself with any such thoughts yet.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 10)
So he bade me lay more clothes on his feet. put my hand into the bed and felt them, and they were as cold as any stone.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 11)
Then felt to his knees, and so upward and upward, and all was as cold as any stone.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 12)
They say he cried out of sack.  Ay, that he did.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 13)
And of women.  Nay, that he did not.  Yes, that he did, and said they were devils incarnate.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 14)
He could never abide carnation. 'Twas a color he never liked.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 15)
He said once, the devil would have him about women.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 16)
He did in some sort, indeed, handle women, but then he was rheumatic and talked of the Whore of Babylon.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 17)
Do you not remember he saw a flea stick upon Bardolph's nose, and he said it was a black soul burning in hell?(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 18)
Well, the fuel is gone that maintained that fire.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 19)
That's all the riches got in his service.  Shall we shog?(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 20)
The King will be gone from Southampton.  Come, let's away.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 21)
--My love, give me thy lips. Look to my chattels and my movables.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 22)
Let senses rule. The word is "Pitch and pay." Trust none, for oaths are straws, men's faiths are wafer-cakes, and Holdfast is the only dog, my duck.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 23)
Therefore, Caveto be thy counselor. Go, clear thy crystals.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 24)
--Yoke-fellows in arms, let us to France, like horse-leeches, my boys, to suck, to suck, the very blood to suck.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 25)
And that's but unwholesome food, they say.  Touch her soft mouth, and march.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 26)
Farewell, hostess.  cannot kiss, that is the humor of it.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 27)
But adieu.  Let huswifery appear. Keep close, thee command.(Henry V, Act 2, Scene 28)
Thus comes the English with full power upon us, And more than carefully it us concerns To answer royally in our defenses.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 0)
Therefore the Dukes of Berri and of Brittany, Of Brabant and of Orleans, shall make forth, And you, Prince Dauphin, with all swift dispatch, To line and new-repair our towns of war With men of courage and with means defendant.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 1)
For England his approaches makes as fierce As waters to the sucking of a gulf.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 2)
It fits us then to be as provident As fear may teach us out of late examples Left by the fatal and neglected English Upon our fields.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 3)
My most redoubted father, It is most meet we arm us 'gainst the foe, For peace itself should not so dull a kingdom, Though war nor no known quarrel were in question But that defenses, musters, preparations Should be maintained, assembled, and collected As were a war in expectation.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 4)
Therefore say 'tis meet we all go forth To view the sick and feeble parts of France.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 5)
And let us do it with no show of fear, No, with no more than if we heard that England Were busied with a Whitsun morris-dance.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 6)
For, my good liege, she is so idly kinged, Her scepter so fantastically borne By a vain, giddy, shallow, humorous youth, That fear attends her not.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 7)
peace, Prince Dauphin! You are too much mistaken in this king.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 8)
Question your Grace the late ambassadors With what great state he heard their embassy, How well supplied with noble councillors, How modest in exception, and withal How terrible in constant resolution, And you shall find his vanities forespent Were but the outside of the Roman Brutus, Covering discretion with a coat of folly, As gardeners do with ordure hide those roots That shall first spring and be most delicate.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 9)
Well, 'tis not so, my Lord High Constable. But though we think it so, it is no matter.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 10)
In cases of defense, 'tis best to weigh The enemy more mighty than he seems.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 11)
So the proportions of defense are filled, Which of a weak and niggardly projection Doth, like a miser, spoil his coat with scanting little cloth.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 12)
Think we King Harry strong, And, princes, look you strongly arm to meet him.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 13)
The kindred of him hath been fleshed upon us, And he is bred out of that bloody strain That haunted us in our familiar paths.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 14)
Witness our too-much-memorable shame When Cressy battle fatally was struck And all our princes captived by the hand Of that black name, Edward, Black Prince of Wales, Whiles that his mountain sire, on mountain standing Up in the air, crowned with the golden sun, Saw his heroical seed and smiled to see him Mangle the work of nature and deface The patterns that by God and by French fathers Had twenty years been made.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 15)
This is a stem Of that victorious stock, and let us fear The native mightiness and fate of him.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 16)
Ambassadors from Harry King of England Do crave admittance to your Majesty.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 17)
We'll give them present audience. Go, and bring them.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 18)
You see this chase is hotly followed, friends.   Turn head and stop pursuit, for coward dogs Most spend their mouths when what they seem to threaten Runs far before them.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 19)
Good my sovereign, Take up the English short, and let them know Of what a monarchy you are the head.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 20)
Self-love, my liege, is not so vile a sin As self-neglecting.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 21)
From our brother of England?   From him, and thus he greets your Majesty: He wills you, in the name of God almighty, That you divest yourself and lay apart The borrowed glories that, by gift of heaven, By law of nature and of nations, 'longs To him and to his heirs--namely, the crown And all wide-stretched honors that pertain By custom and the ordinance of times Unto the crown of France.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 22)
That you may know 'Tis no sinister nor no awkward claim Picked from the wormholes of long-vanished days Nor from the dust of old oblivion raked, He sends you this most memorable line,  In every branch truly demonstrative, Willing you overlook this pedigree, And when you find him evenly derived From his most famed of famous ancestors, Edward the Third, he bids you then resign Your crown and kingdom, indirectly held From him, the native and true challenger.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 23)
Or else what follows?   Bloody constraint, for if you hide the crown Even in your hearts, there will he rake for it.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 24)
Therefore in fierce tempest is he coming, In thunder and in earthquake like a Jove, That, if requiring fail, he will compel, And bids you, in the bowels of the Lord, Deliver up the crown and to take mercy On the poor souls for whom this hungry war Opens his vasty jaws, and on your head Turning the widows' tears, the orphans' cries, The dead men's blood, the prived maidens' groans, For husbands, fathers, and betrothed lovers That shall be swallowed in this controversy.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 25)
This is his claim, his threat'ning, and my message-- Unless the Dauphin be in presence here, To whom expressly bring greeting too.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 26)
For us, we will consider of this further. Tomorrow shall you bear our full intent Back to our brother of England.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 27)
For the Dauphin, stand here for him. What to him from England?(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 28)
Scorn and defiance, slight regard, contempt, And anything that may not misbecome The mighty sender, doth he prize you at.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 29)
Thus says my king: an if your father's Highness Do not, in grant of all demands at large, Sweeten the bitter mock you sent his Majesty, He'll call you to so hot an answer of it That caves and womby vaultages of France Shall chide your trespass and return your mock In second accent of his ordinance.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 30)
Say, if my father render fair return, It is against my will, for desire Nothing but odds with England.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 31)
To that end, As matching to his youth and vanity, did present him with the Paris balls.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 32)
He'll make your Paris Louvre shake for it, Were it the mistress court of mighty Europe.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 33)
And be assured you'll find a difference, As we his subjects have in wonder found, Between the promise of his greener days And these he masters now.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 34)
Now he weighs time Even to the utmost grain. That you shall read In your own losses, if he stay in France.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 35)
Tomorrow shall you know our mind at full.    Dispatch us with all speed, lest that our king Come here himself to question our delay, For he is footed in this land already.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 36)
You shall be soon dispatched with fair conditions.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 37)
night is but small breath and little pause To answer matters of this consequence.(Henry V, Act 3, Scene 38)
Whither away so fast?  God save you. E'en to the Hall to hear what shall become Of the great Duke of Buckingham.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 0)
I'll save you That labor, sir. All's now done but the ceremony Of bringing back the prisoner.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 1)
Were you there?   Yes, indeed was  Pray speak what has happened.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 2)
You may guess quickly what.  Is he found guilty?(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 3)
Yes, truly, is he, and condemned upon 't.   am sorry for 't.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 4)
So are a number more.  But pray, how passed it?   I'll tell you in a little.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 5)
The great duke Came to the bar, where to his accusations He pleaded still not guilty and alleged Many sharp reasons to defeat the law.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 6)
The King's attorney on the contrary Urged on the examinations, proofs, confessions Of divers witnesses, which the Duke desired To him brought viva voce to his face; At which appeared against him his surveyor, Sir Gilbert Peck his chancellor, and John Car, Confessor to him, with that devil monk, Hopkins, that made this mischief.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 7)
That was he That fed him with his prophecies?  The same.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 8)
All these accused him strongly, which he fain Would have flung from him, but indeed he could not.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 9)
And so his peers upon this evidence Have found him guilty of high treason.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 10)
Much He spoke, and learnedly, for life, but all Was either pitied in him or forgotten.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 11)
After all this, how did he bear himself?   When he was brought again to th' bar to hear His knell rung out, his judgment, he was stirred With such an agony he sweat extremely And something spoke in choler, ill and hasty.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 12)
But he fell to himself again, and sweetly In all the rest showed a most noble patience.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 13)
do not think he fears death.  Sure he does not; He never was so womanish.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 14)
The cause He may a little grieve at.  Certainly The Cardinal is the end of this.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 15)
'Tis likely, By all conjectures; first, Kildare's attainder, Then Deputy of Ireland, who, removed, Earl Surrey was sent thither, and in haste too, Lest he should help his father.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 16)
That trick of state Was a deep envious one.  At his return No doubt he will requite it.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 17)
This is noted, And generally: whoever the King favors, The Card'nal instantly will find employment, And far enough from court too.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 18)
All the commons Hate him perniciously and, o' my conscience, Wish him ten fathom deep.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 19)
This duke as much They love and dote on, call him bounteous Buckingham, The mirror of all courtesy.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 20)
Stay there, sir, And see the noble ruined man you speak of.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 21)
him, the ax with the edge towards him, Halberds on each side, accompanied with Sir Thomas Lovell, Sir Nicholas     Let's stand close and behold him.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 22)
All good people, You that thus far have come to pity me, Hear what say, and then go home and lose me.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 23)
have this day received a traitor's judgment, And by that name must die.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 24)
Yet heaven bear witness, And if have a conscience, let it sink me Even as the ax falls, if be not faithful!(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 25)
The law bear no malice for my death; has done, upon the premises, but justice.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 26)
But those that sought it could wish more Christian.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 27)
Be what they will, heartily forgive 'em. Yet let 'em look they glory not in mischief, Nor build their evils on the graves of great men, For then my guiltless blood must cry against 'em.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 28)
For further life in this world ne'er hope, Nor will sue, although the King have mercies More than dare make faults.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 29)
You few that loved me And dare be bold to weep for Buckingham, His noble friends and fellows, whom to leave Is only bitter to him, only dying, Go with me like good angels to my end, And as the long divorce of steel falls on me, Make of your prayers one sweet sacrifice, And lift my soul to heaven.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 30)
--Lead on, a' God's name.   do beseech your Grace, for charity, If ever any malice in your heart Were hid against me, now to forgive me frankly.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 31)
Sir Thomas Lovell, as free forgive you As would be forgiven.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 32)
forgive all. There cannot be those numberless offenses 'Gainst me that cannot take peace with.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 33)
No black envy Shall make my grave. Commend me to his Grace.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 34)
And if he speak of Buckingham, pray tell him You met him half in heaven.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 35)
My vows and prayers Yet are the King's and, till my soul forsake, Shall cry for blessings on him.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 36)
May he live Longer than have time to tell his years.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 37)
Ever beloved and loving may his rule be; And when old Time shall lead him to his end, Goodness and he fill up one monument!(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 38)
To th' waterside must conduct your Grace, Then give my charge up to Sir Nicholas Vaux, Who undertakes you to your end.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 39)
Prepare there! The Duke is coming. See the barge be ready, And fit it with such furniture as suits The greatness of his person.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 40)
Nay, Sir Nicholas, Let it alone. My state now will but mock me.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 41)
When came hither, was Lord High Constable And Duke of Buckingham; now, poor Edward Bohun.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 42)
Yet am richer than my base accusers, That never knew what truth meant.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 43)
now seal it, And with that blood will make 'em one day groan for 't.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 44)
My noble father, Henry of Buckingham, Who first raised head against usurping Richard, Flying for succor to his servant Banister, Being distressed, was by that wretch betrayed, And, without trial, fell.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 45)
God's peace be with him. Henry the Seventh, succeeding, truly pitying My father's loss, like a most royal prince Restored me to my honors and out of ruins Made my name once more noble.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 46)
Now his son, Henry the Eighth, life, honor, name, and all That made me happy at one stroke has taken Forever from the world.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 47)
had my trial, And must needs say a noble one, which makes me little happier than my wretched father.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 48)
Yet thus far we are one in fortunes: both Fell by our servants, by those men we loved most-- most unnatural and faithless service.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 49)
Heaven has an end in all; yet, you that hear me, This from a dying man receive as certain: Where you are liberal of your loves and counsels Be sure you be not loose; for those you make friends And give your hearts to, when they once perceive The least rub in your fortunes, fall away Like water from you, never found again But where they mean to sink you.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 50)
All good people, Pray for me. must now forsake you.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 51)
The last hour Of my long weary life is come upon me.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 52)
Farewell. And when you would say something that is sad, Speak how fell.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 53)
have done; and God forgive me.    this is full of pity, sir!(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 54)
It calls, fear, too many curses on their heads That were the authors.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 55)
If the Duke be guiltless, 'Tis full of woe. Yet can give you inkling Of an ensuing evil, if it fall, Greater than this.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 56)
Good angels keep it from us! What may it be? You do not doubt my faith, sir?(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 57)
This secret is so weighty 'twill require strong faith to conceal it.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 58)
Let me have it. do not talk much.  am confident; You shall, sir.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 59)
Did you not of late days hear buzzing of a separation Between the King and Katherine?(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 60)
Yes, but it held not; For when the King once heard it, out of anger He sent command to the Lord Mayor straight To stop the rumor and allay those tongues That durst disperse it.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 61)
But that slander, sir, Is found a truth now, for it grows again Fresher than e'er it was, and held for certain The King will venture at it.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 62)
Either the Cardinal, Or some about him near, have, out of malice To the good queen, possessed him with a scruple That will undo her.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 63)
To confirm this too, Cardinal Campeius is arrived, and lately, As all think, for this business.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 64)
'Tis the Cardinal; And merely to revenge him on the Emperor For not bestowing on him at his asking The archbishopric of Toledo this is purposed.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 65)
think you have hit the mark. But is 't not cruel That she should feel the smart of this?(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 66)
The Cardinal Will have his will, and she must fall.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 67)
'Tis woeful. We are too open here to argue this.(Henry VIII, Act 0, Scene 68)
My lord, the horses your Lordship sent for, with all the care had saw well chosen, ridden, and furnished.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 0)
They were young and handsome and of the best breed in the north.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 1)
When they were ready to set out for London, a man of my Lord Cardinal's, by commission and main power, took 'em from me with this reason: his master would be served before a subject, if not before the King, which stopped our mouths, sir.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 2)
fear he will indeed; well, let him have them. He will have all, think.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 3)
Well met, my Lord Chamberlain.  Good day to both your Graces.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 4)
How is the King employed?  left him private, Full of sad thoughts and troubles.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 5)
What's the cause?   It seems the marriage with his brother's wife Has crept too near his conscience.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 6)
No, his conscience Has crept too near another lady.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 7)
'Tis so; This is the Cardinal's doing. The king-cardinal, That blind priest, like the eldest son of Fortune, Turns what he list.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 8)
The King will know him one day.   Pray God he do!(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 9)
He'll never know himself else.   How holily he works in all his business, And with what zeal!(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 10)
For, now he has cracked the league Between us and the Emperor, the Queen's great-nephew, He dives into the King's soul and there scatters Dangers, doubts, wringing of the conscience, Fears and despairs--and all these for his marriage.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 11)
And out of all these to restore the King, He counsels a divorce, a loss of her That like a jewel has hung twenty years About his neck, yet never lost her luster; Of her that loves him with that excellence That angels love good men with; even of her That, when the greatest stroke of fortune falls, Will bless the King.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 12)
And is not this course pious?   Heaven keep me from such counsel!(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 13)
'Tis most true: These news are everywhere, every tongue speaks 'em, And every true heart weeps for 't.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 14)
All that dare Look into these affairs see this main end, The French king's sister.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 15)
Heaven will one day open The King's eyes, that so long have slept upon This bold bad man.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 16)
And free us from his slavery.  We had need pray, And heartily, for our deliverance, Or this imperious man will work us all From princes into pages.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 17)
All men's honors Lie like one lump before him, to be fashioned Into what pitch he please.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 18)
For me, my lords, love him not nor fear him; there's my creed.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 19)
As am made without him, so I'll stand, If the King please.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 20)
His curses and his blessings Touch me alike: they're breath not believe in.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 21)
knew him and know him; so leave him To him that made him proud, the Pope.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 22)
Let's in, And with some other business put the King From these sad thoughts that work too much upon him.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 23)
-- My lord, you'll bear us company?  Excuse me; The King has sent me otherwhere.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 24)
Besides, You'll find a most unfit time to disturb him.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 25)
Health to your Lordships.  Thanks, my good Lord Chamberlain.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 26)
How sad he looks! Sure he is much afflicted.   Who's there?(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 27)
Ha?  Pray God he be not angry.   Who's there, say?(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 28)
How dare you thrust yourselves Into my private meditations?(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 29)
Who am ha?   gracious king that pardons all offenses Malice ne'er meant.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 30)
Our breach of duty this way Is business of estate, in which we come To know your royal pleasure.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 31)
You are too bold. Go to; I'll make you know your times of business.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 32)
Is this an hour for temporal affairs, ha?    Who's there?(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 33)
My good Lord Cardinal? my Wolsey, The quiet of my wounded conscience, Thou art a cure fit for a king.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 34)
You're welcome, Most learned reverend sir, into our kingdom.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 35)
Use us and it.--My good lord, have great care be not found a talker.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 36)
Sir, you cannot. would your Grace would give us but an hour Of private conference.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 37)
We are busy. Go.   This priest has no pride in him?(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 38)
Not to speak of. would not be so sick, though for his place.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 39)
But this cannot continue.  If it do, I'll venture one have-at-him.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 40)
another.    Your Grace has given a precedent of wisdom Above all princes in committing freely Your scruple to the voice of Christendom.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 41)
Who can be angry now? What envy reach you? The Spaniard, tied by blood and favor to her, Must now confess, if they have any goodness, The trial just and noble; all the clerks-- mean the learned ones in Christian kingdoms-- Have their free voices; Rome, the nurse of judgment, Invited by your noble self, hath sent One general tongue unto us, this good man, This just and learned priest, Cardinal Campeius, Whom once more present unto your Highness.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 42)
And once more in mine arms bid him welcome, And thank the holy conclave for their loves.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 43)
They have sent me such a man would have wished for.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 44)
Your Grace must needs deserve all strangers' loves, You are so noble.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 45)
To your Highness' hand tender my commission--by whose virtue, The court of Rome commanding, you, my Lord Cardinal of York, are joined with me their servant In the unpartial judging of this business.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 46)
Two equal men. The Queen shall be acquainted Forthwith for what you come.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 47)
Where's Gardiner?   know your Majesty has always loved her So dear in heart not to deny her that woman of less place might ask by law: Scholars allowed freely to argue for her.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 48)
Ay, and the best she shall have, and my favor To him that does best.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 49)
God forbid else. Cardinal, Prithee call Gardiner to me, my new secretary.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 50)
find him a fit fellow.      Give me your hand. Much joy and favor to you.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 51)
You are the King's now.  But to be commanded Forever by your Grace, whose hand has raised me.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 52)
Come hither, Gardiner.    My lord of York, was not one Doctor Pace In this man's place before him?(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 53)
Yes, he was.   Was he not held a learned man?  Yes, surely.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 54)
Believe me, there's an ill opinion spread, then, Even of yourself, Lord Cardinal.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 55)
How? Of me?   They will not stick to say you envied him And, fearing he would rise--he was so virtuous-- Kept him a foreign man still, which so grieved him That he ran mad and died.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 56)
Heav'n's peace be with him! That's Christian care enough.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 57)
For living murmurers, There's places of rebuke. He was a fool, For he would needs be virtuous.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 58)
That good fellow If command him follows my appointment.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 59)
will have none so near else. Learn this, brother: We live not to be griped by meaner persons.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 60)
Deliver this with modesty to th' Queen.  The most convenient place that can think of For such receipt of learning is Blackfriars.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 61)
There you shall meet about this weighty business.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 62)
My Wolsey, see it furnished. my lord, Would it not grieve an able man to leave So sweet a bedfellow?(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 63)
But, conscience, conscience! 'tis a tender place, and must leave her.(Henry VIII, Act 1, Scene 64)
Not for that neither. Here's the pang that pinches: His Highness having lived so long with her, and she So good a lady that no tongue could ever Pronounce dishonor of her--by my life, She never knew harm-doing!(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 0)
--O, now, after So many courses of the sun enthroned, Still growing in a majesty and pomp, the which To leave a thousandfold more bitter than 'Tis sweet at first t' acquire--after this process, To give her the avaunt!(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 1)
It is a pity Would move a monster.  Hearts of most hard temper Melt and lament for her.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 2)
God's will! Much better She ne'er had known pomp; though 't be temporal, Yet if that quarrel, Fortune, do divorce It from the bearer, 'tis a sufferance panging As soul and body's severing.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 3)
Alas, poor lady, She's a stranger now again!  So much the more Must pity drop upon her.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 4)
Verily, swear, 'tis better to be lowly born And range with humble livers in content Than to be perked up in a glist'ring grief And wear a golden sorrow.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 5)
Our content Is our best having.  By my troth and maidenhead, would not be a queen.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 6)
Beshrew me, would, And venture maidenhead for 't; and so would you, For all this spice of your hypocrisy.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 7)
You, that have so fair parts of woman on you, Have too a woman's heart, which ever yet Affected eminence, wealth, sovereignty; Which, to say sooth, are blessings; and which gifts, Saving your mincing, the capacity Of your soft cheveril conscience would receive If you might please to stretch it.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 8)
Nay, good troth.   Yes, troth, and troth. You would not be a queen?(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 9)
No, not for all the riches under heaven.   'Tis strange.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 10)
threepence bowed would hire me, Old as am, to queen it.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 11)
But pray you, What think you of a duchess? Have you limbs To bear that load of title?(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 12)
No, in truth.   Then you are weakly made. Pluck off a little.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 13)
would not be a young count in your way For more than blushing comes to.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 14)
If your back Cannot vouchsafe this burden, 'tis too weak Ever to get a boy.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 15)
How you do talk! swear again, would not be a queen For all the world.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 16)
In faith, for little England You'd venture an emballing.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 17)
myself Would for Carnarvanshire, although there longed No more to th' crown but that.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 18)
Lo, who comes here?      Good morrow, ladies. What were 't worth to know The secret of your conference?(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 19)
My good lord, Not your demand; it values not your asking.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 20)
Our mistress' sorrows we were pitying.   It was a gentle business, and becoming The action of good women.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 21)
There is hope All will be well.  Now, pray God, amen!(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 22)
You bear a gentle mind, and heav'nly blessings Follow such creatures.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 23)
That you may, fair lady, Perceive speak sincerely, and high note's Ta'en of your many virtues, the King's Majesty Commends his good opinion of you to you, and Does purpose honor to you no less flowing Than Marchioness of Pembroke, to which title thousand pound a year annual support Out of his grace he adds.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 24)
do not know What kind of my obedience should tender.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 25)
More than my all is nothing, nor my prayers Are not words duly hallowed, nor my wishes More worth than empty vanities.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 26)
Yet prayers and wishes Are all can return. 'Beseech your Lordship, Vouchsafe to speak my thanks and my obedience, As from a blushing handmaid, to his Highness, Whose health and royalty pray for.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 27)
Lady, shall not fail t' approve the fair conceit The King hath of you.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 28)
have perused her well. Beauty and honor in her are so mingled That they have caught the King.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 29)
And who knows yet But from this lady may proceed a gem To lighten all this isle?(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 30)
--I'll to the King And say spoke with you.  My honored lord.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 31)
Why, this it is! See, see! have been begging sixteen years in court, Am yet a courtier beggarly, nor could Come pat betwixt too early and too late For any suit of pounds; and you--O, fate!(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 32)
-- very fresh fish here--fie, fie, fie upon This compelled fortune!(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 33)
--have your mouth filled up Before you open it.  This is strange to me.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 34)
How tastes it? Is it bitter? Forty pence, no. There was a lady once--'tis an old story-- That would not be a queen, that would she not, For all the mud in Egypt.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 35)
Have you heard it?   Come, you are pleasant.  With your theme, could O'ermount the lark.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 36)
The Marchioness of Pembroke? thousand pounds a year for pure respect?(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 37)
No other obligation? By my life, That promises more thousands; honor's train Is longer than his foreskirt.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 38)
By this time know your back will bear a duchess. Say, Are you not stronger than you were?(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 39)
Good lady, Make yourself mirth with your particular fancy, And leave me out on 't.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 40)
Would had no being If this salute my blood a jot.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 41)
It faints me To think what follows. The Queen is comfortless and we forgetful In our long absence.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 42)
Pray do not deliver What here you've heard to her.(Henry VIII, Act 2, Scene 43)
2     short silver wands; next them, two Scribes, in the habit of doctors; after them, the Bishop of Canterbury alone; after him, the Bishops of Lincoln, Ely, Rochester, and Saint Asaph; next them, with some small distance, follows a Gentleman bearing the purse with the great seal, and a cardinal's hat.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 0)
Then two Priests, bearing each a silver cross; then a Gentleman Usher bare-headed, accompanied with a Sergeant-at-Arms, bearing a silver mace; then two Gentlemen, bearing two great silver pillars.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 1)
After them, side by side, the two Cardinals, and two Noblemen with the sword and mace.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 2)
The King takes place under the cloth of state. The two Cardinals sit under him as judges.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 3)
The Queen takes place some distance from the King.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 4)
The Bishops place themselves on each side the court, in manner of a consistory; below them the Scribes.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 5)
The Lords sit next the Bishops. The rest of the Attendants including a Crier and the Queen's Gentleman Usher     Whilst our commission from Rome is read, Let silence be commanded.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 6)
What's the need? It hath already publicly been read, And on all sides th' authority allowed.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 7)
You may then spare that time.  Be 't so. Proceed.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 8)
Say "Henry King of England, come into the court.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 9)
"  Henry King of England, come into the court.  Here.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 10)
Say "Katherine Queen of England, come into the court.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 11)
"  Katherine Queen of England, come into the court.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 12)
chair, goes about the court, comes to the King,    Sir, desire you do me right and justice, And to bestow your pity on me; for am a most poor woman and a stranger, Born out of your dominions, having here No judge indifferent nor no more assurance Of equal friendship and proceeding.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 13)
Alas, sir, In what have offended you? What cause Hath my behavior given to your displeasure That thus you should proceed to put me off And take your good grace from me?(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 14)
Heaven witness have been to you a true and humble wife, At all times to your will conformable, Ever in fear to kindle your dislike, Yea, subject to your countenance, glad or sorry As saw it inclined.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 15)
When was the hour ever contradicted your desire, Or made it not mine too?(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 16)
Or which of your friends Have not strove to love, although knew He were mine enemy?(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 17)
What friend of mine That had to him derived your anger did Continue in my liking?(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 18)
Nay, gave notice He was from thence discharged? Sir, call to mind That have been your wife in this obedience Upward of twenty years, and have been blessed With many children by you.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 19)
If, in the course And process of this time, you can report, And prove it too, against mine honor aught, My bond to wedlock or my love and duty Against your sacred person, in God's name Turn me away and let the foul'st contempt Shut door upon me, and so give me up To the sharp'st kind of justice.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 20)
Please you, sir, The King your father was reputed for prince most prudent, of an excellent And unmatched wit and judgment.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 21)
Ferdinand, My father, King of Spain, was reckoned one The wisest prince that there had reigned by many year before.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 22)
It is not to be questioned That they had gathered a wise council to them Of every realm, that did debate this business, Who deemed our marriage lawful.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 23)
Wherefore humbly Beseech you, sir, to spare me till may Be by my friends in Spain advised, whose counsel will implore.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 24)
If not, i' th' name of God, Your pleasure be fulfilled.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 25)
You have here, lady, And of your choice, these reverend fathers, men Of singular integrity and learning, Yea, the elect o' th' land, who are assembled To plead your cause.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 26)
It shall be therefore bootless That longer you desire the court, as well For your own quiet as to rectify What is unsettled in the King.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 27)
His Grace Hath spoken well and justly. Therefore, madam, It's fit this royal session do proceed And that without delay their arguments Be now produced and heard.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 28)
Lord Cardinal, To you speak.  Your pleasure, madam.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 29)
Sir, am about to weep; but thinking that We are a queen, or long have dreamed so, certain The daughter of a king, my drops of tears I'll turn to sparks of fire.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 30)
Be patient yet.   will, when you are humble; nay, before, Or God will punish me.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 31)
do believe, Induced by potent circumstances, that You are mine enemy, and make my challenge You shall not be my judge; for it is you Have blown this coal betwixt my lord and me-- Which God's dew quench!(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 32)
Therefore say again, utterly abhor, yea, from my soul Refuse you for my judge, whom, yet once more, hold my most malicious foe and think not At all a friend to truth.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 33)
do profess You speak not like yourself, who ever yet Have stood to charity and displayed th' effects Of disposition gentle and of wisdom O'ertopping woman's power.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 34)
Madam, you do me wrong. have no spleen against you, nor injustice For you or any.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 35)
How far have proceeded, Or how far further shall, is warranted By a commission from the Consistory, Yea, the whole Consistory of Rome.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 36)
You charge me That "have blown this coal." do deny it.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 37)
The King is present. If it be known to him That gainsay my deed, how may he wound, And worthily, my falsehood, yea, as much As you have done my truth.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 38)
If he know That am free of your report, he knows am not of your wrong.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 39)
Therefore in him It lies to cure me, and the cure is to Remove these thoughts from you, the which before His Highness shall speak in, do beseech You, gracious madam, to unthink your speaking And to say so no more.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 40)
My lord, my lord, am a simple woman, much too weak oppose your cunning.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 41)
You're meek and humble-mouthed; You sign your place and calling, in full seeming, With meekness and humility, but your heart Is crammed with arrogancy, spleen, and pride.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 42)
You have by fortune and his Highness' favors Gone slightly o'er low steps, and now are mounted Where powers are your retainers, and your words, Domestics to you, serve your will as 't please Yourself pronounce their office.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 43)
must tell you, You tender more your person's honor than Your high profession spiritual, that again do refuse you for my judge, and here, Before you all, appeal unto the Pope To bring my whole cause 'fore his Holiness, And to be judged by him.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 44)
The Queen is obstinate, Stubborn to justice, apt to accuse it, and Disdainful to be tried by 't.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 45)
'Tis not well. She's going away.  Call her again.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 46)
Katherine, Queen of England, come into the court.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 47)
Madam, you are called back.   What need you note it?(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 48)
Pray you, keep your way. When you are called, return.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 49)
Now, the Lord help! They vex me past my patience.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 50)
Pray you, pass on. will not tarry; no, nor ever more Upon this business my appearance make In any of their courts.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 51)
Go thy ways, Kate. That man i' th' world who shall report he has better wife, let him in naught be trusted, For speaking false in that.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 52)
Thou art, alone-- If thy rare qualities, sweet gentleness, Thy meekness saintlike, wifelike government, Obeying in commanding, and thy parts Sovereign and pious else, could speak thee out-- The queen of earthly queens.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 53)
She's noble born, And like her true nobility she has Carried herself towards me.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 54)
Most gracious sir, In humblest manner require your Highness That it shall please you to declare in hearing Of all these ears--for where am robbed and bound, There must be unloosed, although not there At once and fully satisfied--whether ever Did broach this business to your Highness, or Laid any scruple in your way which might Induce you to the question on 't, or ever Have to you, but with thanks to God for such royal lady, spake one the least word that might Be to the prejudice of her present state, Or touch of her good person?(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 55)
My Lord Cardinal, do excuse you; yea, upon mine honor, free you from 't.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 56)
You are not to be taught That you have many enemies that know not Why they are so but, like to village curs, Bark when their fellows do.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 57)
By some of these The Queen is put in anger. You're excused.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 58)
But will you be more justified? You ever Have wished the sleeping of this business, never desired It to be stirred, but oft have hindered, oft, The passages made toward it.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 59)
On my honor speak my good Lord Cardinal to this point And thus far clear him.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 60)
Now, what moved me to 't, will be bold with time and your attention.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 61)
Then mark th' inducement. Thus it came; give heed to 't: My conscience first received a tenderness, Scruple, and prick on certain speeches uttered By th' Bishop of Bayonne, then French ambassador, Who had been hither sent on the debating marriage 'twixt the Duke of Orleans and Our daughter Mary.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 62)
th' progress of this business, Ere a determinate resolution, he, mean the Bishop, did require a respite Wherein he might the King his lord advertise Whether our daughter were legitimate, Respecting this our marriage with the dowager, Sometime our brother's wife.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 63)
This respite shook The bosom of my conscience, entered me, Yea, with a spitting power, and made to tremble The region of my breast; which forced such way That many mazed considerings did throng And pressed in with this caution.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 64)
First, methought stood not in the smile of heaven, who had Commanded nature that my lady's womb, If it conceived a male child by me, should Do no more offices of life to 't than The grave does to th' dead, for her male issue Or died where they were made, or shortly after This world had aired them.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 65)
Hence took a thought This was a judgment on me, that my kingdom, Well worthy the best heir o' th' world, should not Be gladded in 't by me.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 66)
Then follows that weighed the danger which my realms stood in By this my issue's fail, and that gave to me Many a groaning throe.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 67)
Thus hulling in The wild sea of my conscience, did steer Toward this remedy whereupon we are Now present here together.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 68)
That's to say, meant to rectify my conscience, which then did feel full sick, and yet not well, By all the reverend fathers of the land And doctors learned.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 69)
First, began in private With you, my Lord of Lincoln.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 70)
You remember How under my oppression did reek When first moved you.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 71)
Very well, my liege.   have spoke long. Be pleased yourself to say How far you satisfied me.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 72)
So please your Highness, The question did at first so stagger me, Bearing a state of mighty moment in 't And consequence of dread, that committed The daring'st counsel which had to doubt, And did entreat your Highness to this course Which you are running here.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 73)
then moved you, My Lord of Canterbury, and got your leave To make this present summons.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 74)
Unsolicited left no reverend person in this court, But by particular consent proceeded Under your hands and seals.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 75)
Therefore go on, For no dislike i' th' world against the person Of the good queen, but the sharp thorny points Of my alleged reasons drives this forward.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 76)
Prove but our marriage lawful, by my life And kingly dignity, we are contented To wear our mortal state to come with her, Katherine our queen, before the primest creature That's paragoned o' th' world.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 77)
So please your Highness, The Queen being absent, 'tis a needful fitness That we adjourn this court till further day.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 78)
Meanwhile must be an earnest motion Made to the Queen to call back her appeal She intends unto his Holiness.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 79)
may perceive These cardinals trifle with me. abhor This dilatory sloth and tricks of Rome.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 80)
My learned and well-beloved servant Cranmer, Prithee return.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 81)
With thy approach, know, My comfort comes along.--Break up the court.(Henry VIII, Act 3, Scene 82)
Give him this money and these notes, Reynaldo.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 0)
will, my lord.   You shall do marvelous wisely, good Reynaldo, Before you visit him, to make inquire Of his behavior.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 1)
My lord, did intend it.   Marry, well said, very well said.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 2)
Look you, sir, Inquire me first what Danskers are in Paris; And how, and who, what means, and where they keep, What company, at what expense; and finding By this encompassment and drift of question That they do know my son, come you more nearer Than your particular demands will touch it.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 3)
Take you, as 'twere, some distant knowledge of him, As thus: know his father and his friends And, in part, him.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 4)
" Do you mark this, Reynaldo?  Ay, very well, my lord.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 5)
"And, in part, him, but," you may say, "not well.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 6)
But if 't be he mean, he's very wild, Addicted so and so.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 7)
" And there put on him What forgeries you please--marry, none so rank As may dishonor him, take heed of that, But, sir, such wanton, wild, and usual slips As are companions noted and most known To youth and liberty.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 8)
As gaming, my lord.  Ay, or drinking, fencing, swearing, Quarreling, drabbing--you may go so far.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 9)
My lord, that would dishonor him.   Faith, no, as you may season it in the charge.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 10)
You must not put another scandal on him That he is open to incontinency; That's not my meaning.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 11)
But breathe his faults so quaintly That they may seem the taints of liberty, The flash and outbreak of a fiery mind, savageness in unreclaimed blood, Of general assault.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 12)
But, my good lord--  Wherefore should you do this?(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 13)
Ay, my lord, would know that.  Marry, sir, here's my drift, And believe it is a fetch of wit.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 14)
You, laying these slight sullies on my son, As 'twere a thing a little soiled i' th' working, Mark you, your party in converse, him you would sound, Having ever seen in the prenominate crimes The youth you breathe of guilty, be assured He closes with you in this consequence: "Good sir," or so, or "friend," or "gentleman," According to the phrase or the addition Of man and country--  Very good, my lord.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 15)
And then, sir, does he this, he does--what was about to say?(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 16)
By the Mass, was about to say something. Where did leave?(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 17)
At "closes in the consequence," at "friend, or so," and "gentleman.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 18)
"   At "closes in the consequence"--ay, marry-- He closes thus: know the gentleman.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 19)
saw him yesterday," or "th' other day" (Or then, or then, with such or such), "and as you say, There was he gaming, there o'ertook in 's rouse, There falling out at tennis"; or perchance saw him enter such a house of sale"-- Videlicet, a brothel--or so forth.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 20)
See you now Your bait of falsehood take this carp of truth; And thus do we of wisdom and of reach, With windlasses and with assays of bias, By indirections find directions out.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 21)
So by my former lecture and advice Shall you my son.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 22)
You have me, have you not?   My lord, have.  God be wi' you.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 23)
Fare you well.  Good my lord.   Observe his inclination in yourself.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 24)
shall, my lord.  And let him ply his music.  Well, my lord.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 25)
Farewell.    How now, Ophelia, what's the matter?(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 26)
my lord, my lord, have been so affrighted!  With what, i' th' name of God?(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 27)
My lord, as was sewing in my closet, Lord Hamlet, with his doublet all unbraced, No hat upon his head, his stockings fouled, Ungartered, and down-gyved to his ankle, Pale as his shirt, his knees knocking each other, And with a look so piteous in purport As if he had been loosed out of hell To speak of horrors--he comes before me.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 28)
Mad for thy love?  My lord, do not know, But truly do fear it.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 29)
What said he?   He took me by the wrist and held me hard.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 30)
Then goes he to the length of all his arm, And, with his other hand thus o'er his brow, He falls to such perusal of my face As he would draw it.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 31)
Long stayed he so. At last, a little shaking of mine arm, And thrice his head thus waving up and down, He raised a sigh so piteous and profound As it did seem to shatter all his bulk And end his being.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 32)
That done, he lets me go, And, with his head over his shoulder turned, He seemed to find his way without his eyes, For out o' doors he went without their helps And to the last bended their light on me.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 33)
Come, go with me. will go seek the King. This is the very ecstasy of love, Whose violent property fordoes itself And leads the will to desperate undertakings As oft as any passions under heaven That does afflict our natures.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 34)
am sorry. What, have you given him any hard words of late?(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 35)
No, my good lord, but as you did command did repel his letters and denied His access to me.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 36)
That hath made him mad. am sorry that with better heed and judgment had not coted him.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 37)
feared he did but trifle And meant to wrack thee.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 38)
But beshrew my jealousy! By heaven, it is as proper to our age To cast beyond ourselves in our opinions As it is common for the younger sort To lack discretion.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 39)
Come, go we to the King. This must be known, which, being kept close, might move More grief to hide than hate to utter love.(Hamlet, Act 0, Scene 40)
Welcome, dear Rosencrantz and Guildenstern. Moreover that we much did long to see you, The need we have to use you did provoke Our hasty sending.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 0)
Something have you heard Of Hamlet's transformation, so call it, Sith nor th' exterior nor the inward man Resembles that it was.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 1)
What it should be, More than his father's death, that thus hath put him So much from th' understanding of himself cannot dream of.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 2)
entreat you both That, being of so young days brought up with him And sith so neighbored to his youth and havior, That you vouchsafe your rest here in our court Some little time, so by your companies To draw him on to pleasures, and to gather So much as from occasion you may glean, Whether aught to us unknown afflicts him thus That, opened, lies within our remedy.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 3)
Good gentlemen, he hath much talked of you, And sure am two men there is not living To whom he more adheres.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 4)
If it will please you To show us so much gentry and goodwill As to expend your time with us awhile For the supply and profit of our hope, Your visitation shall receive such thanks As fits a king's remembrance.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 5)
Both your Majesties Might, by the sovereign power you have of us, Put your dread pleasures more into command Than to entreaty.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 6)
But we both obey, And here give up ourselves in the full bent To lay our service freely at your feet, To be commanded.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 7)
Thanks, Rosencrantz and gentle Guildenstern.   Thanks, Guildenstern and gentle Rosencrantz.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 8)
And beseech you instantly to visit My too much changed son.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 9)
--Go, some of you, And bring these gentlemen where Hamlet is.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 10)
Heavens make our presence and our practices Pleasant and helpful to him!(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 11)
Ay, amen!        Th' ambassadors from Norway, my good lord, Are joyfully returned.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 12)
Thou still hast been the father of good news.   Have my lord?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 13)
assure my good liege hold my duty as hold my soul, Both to my God and to my gracious king, And do think, or else this brain of mine Hunts not the trail of policy so sure As it hath used to do, that have found The very cause of Hamlet's lunacy.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 14)
speak of that! That do long to hear.   Give first admittance to th' ambassadors.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 15)
My news shall be the fruit to that great feast.   Thyself do grace to them and bring them in.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 16)
He tells me, my dear Gertrude, he hath found The head and source of all your son's distemper.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 17)
doubt it is no other but the main-- His father's death and our o'erhasty marriage.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 18)
Well, we shall sift him.     Welcome, my good friends.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 19)
Say, Voltemand, what from our brother Norway?   Most fair return of greetings and desires.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 20)
Upon our first, he sent out to suppress His nephew's levies, which to him appeared To be a preparation 'gainst the Polack, But, better looked into, he truly found It was against your Highness.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 21)
Whereat, grieved That so his sickness, age, and impotence Was falsely borne in hand, sends out arrests On Fortinbras, which he, in brief, obeys, Receives rebuke from Norway, and, in fine, Makes vow before his uncle never more To give th' assay of arms against your Majesty.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 22)
Whereon old Norway, overcome with joy, Gives him three-score thousand crowns in annual fee And his commission to employ those soldiers, So levied as before, against the Polack, With an entreaty, herein further shown,  That it might please you to give quiet pass Through your dominions for this enterprise, On such regards of safety and allowance As therein are set down.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 23)
It likes us well, And, at our more considered time, we'll read, Answer, and think upon this business.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 24)
Meantime, we thank you for your well-took labor. Go to your rest.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 25)
At night we'll feast together. Most welcome home!(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 26)
This business is well ended. My liege, and madam, to expostulate What majesty should be, what duty is, Why day is day, night night, and time is time Were nothing but to waste night, day, and time.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 27)
Therefore, since brevity is the soul of wit, And tediousness the limbs and outward flourishes, will be brief.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 28)
Your noble son is mad. "Mad" call it, for, to define true madness, What is 't but to be nothing else but mad?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 29)
But let that go.  More matter with less art.   Madam, swear use no art at all.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 30)
That he's mad, 'tis true; 'tis true 'tis pity, And pity 'tis 'tis true--a foolish figure, But farewell it, for will use no art.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 31)
Mad let us grant him then, and now remains That we find out the cause of this effect, Or, rather say, the cause of this defect, For this effect defective comes by cause.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 32)
Thus it remains, and the remainder thus. Perpend.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 33)
have a daughter (have while she is mine) Who, in her duty and obedience, mark, Hath given me this.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 34)
Now gather and surmise. To the celestial, and my soul's idol, the most beautified Ophelia-- That's an ill phrase, a vile phrase; "beautified" is a vile phrase.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 35)
But you shall hear. Thus: In her excellent white bosom, these, etc.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 36)
--  Came this from Hamlet to her?   Good madam, stay awhile.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 37)
will be faithful.  Doubt thou the stars are fire, Doubt that the sun doth move, Doubt truth to be a liar, But never doubt love.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 38)
dear Ophelia, am ill at these numbers. have not art to reckon my groans, but that love thee best, most best, believe it.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 39)
Adieu. Thine evermore, most dear lady, whilst this machine is to him, Hamlet.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 40)
This, in obedience, hath my daughter shown me, And more above, hath his solicitings, As they fell out by time, by means, and place, All given to mine ear.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 41)
But how hath she received his love?  What do you think of me?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 42)
As of a man faithful and honorable.   would fain prove so.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 43)
