But what might you think, When had seen this hot love on the wing (As perceived it, must tell you that, Before my daughter told me), what might you, Or my dear Majesty your queen here, think, If had played the desk or table-book Or given my heart a winking, mute and dumb, Or looked upon this love with idle sight?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 44)
What might you think? No, went round to work, And my young mistress thus did bespeak: "Lord Hamlet is a prince, out of thy star.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 45)
This must not be." And then prescripts gave her, That she should lock herself from his resort, Admit no messengers, receive no tokens; Which done, she took the fruits of my advice, And he, repelled (a short tale to make), Fell into a sadness, then into a fast, Thence to a watch, thence into a weakness, Thence to a lightness, and, by this declension, Into the madness wherein now he raves And all we mourn for.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 46)
Do you think 'tis this?  It may be, very like.   Hath there been such a time would fain know that) That have positively said "'Tis so," When it proved otherwise?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 47)
Not that know.   Take this from this, if this be otherwise.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 48)
If circumstances lead me, will find Where truth is hid, though it were hid, indeed, Within the center.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 49)
How may we try it further?   You know sometimes he walks four hours together Here in the lobby.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 50)
So he does indeed.   At such a time I'll loose my daughter to him.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 51)
Be you and behind an arras then. Mark the encounter.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 52)
If he love her not, And be not from his reason fall'n thereon, Let me be no assistant for a state, But keep a farm and carters.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 53)
We will try it.      But look where sadly the poor wretch comes reading.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 54)
Away, do beseech you both, away. I'll board him presently.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 55)
give me leave.  How does my good Lord Hamlet?  Well, God-a-mercy.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 56)
Do you know me, my lord?  Excellent well. You are a fishmonger.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 57)
Not my lord.  Then would you were so honest a man.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 58)
Honest, my lord?  Ay, sir. To be honest, as this world goes, is to be one man picked out of ten thousand.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 59)
That's very true, my lord.  For if the sun breed maggots in a dead dog, being a good kissing carrion--Have you a daughter?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 60)
have, my lord.  Let her not walk i' th' sun. Conception is a blessing, but, as your daughter may conceive, friend, look to 't.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 61)
How say you by that? Still harping on my daughter.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 62)
Yet he knew me not at first; he said was a fishmonger.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 63)
He is far gone. And truly, in my youth, suffered much extremity for love, very near this.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 64)
I'll speak to him again.--What do you read, my lord?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 65)
Words, words, words.  What is the matter, my lord?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 66)
Between who?  mean the matter that you read, my lord.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 67)
Slanders, sir; for the satirical rogue says here that old men have gray beards, that their faces are wrinkled, their eyes purging thick amber and plum-tree gum, and that they have a plentiful lack of wit, together with most weak hams; all which, sir, though most powerfully and potently believe, yet hold it not honesty to have it thus set down; for yourself, sir, shall grow old as am, if, like a crab, you could go backward.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 68)
Though this be madness, yet there is method in 't.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 69)
--Will you walk out of the air, my lord?  Into my grave?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 70)
Indeed, that's out of the air.  How pregnant sometimes his replies are!(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 71)
happiness that often madness hits on, which reason and sanity could not so prosperously be delivered of.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 72)
will leave him and suddenly contrive the means of meeting between him and my daughter.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 73)
--My lord, will take my leave of you.  You cannot, sir, take from me anything that will more willingly part withal--except my life, except my life, except my life.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 74)
Fare you well, my lord.  These tedious old fools.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 75)
You go to seek the Lord Hamlet. There he is.  God save you, sir.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 76)
My honored lord.  My most dear lord.  My excellent good friends!(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 77)
How dost thou, Guildenstern? Ah, Rosencrantz! Good lads, how do you both?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 78)
As the indifferent children of the earth.   Happy in that we are not overhappy.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 79)
On Fortune's cap, we are not the very button.  Nor the soles of her shoe?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 80)
Neither, my lord.  Then you live about her waist, or in the middle of her favors?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 81)
Faith, her privates we.  In the secret parts of Fortune?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 82)
most true! She is a strumpet. What news?  None, my lord, but that the world's grown honest.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 83)
Then is doomsday near. But your news is not true.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 84)
Let me question more in particular. What have you, my good friends, deserved at the hands of Fortune that she sends you to prison hither?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 85)
Prison, my lord?  Denmark's a prison.  Then is the world one.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 86)
goodly one, in which there are many confines, wards, and dungeons, Denmark being one o' th' worst.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 87)
We think not so, my lord.  Why, then, 'tis none to you, for there is nothing either good or bad but thinking makes it so.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 88)
To me, it is a prison.  Why, then, your ambition makes it one.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 89)
'Tis too narrow for your mind.  God, could be bounded in a nutshell and count myself a king of infinite space, were it not that have bad dreams.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 90)
Which dreams, indeed, are ambition, for the very substance of the ambitious is merely the shadow of a dream.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 91)
dream itself is but a shadow.  Truly, and hold ambition of so airy and light a quality that it is but a shadow's shadow.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 92)
Then are our beggars bodies, and our monarchs and outstretched heroes the beggars' shadows.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 93)
Shall we to th' court? For, by my fay, cannot reason.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 94)
We'll wait upon you.  No such matter. will not sort you with the rest of my servants, for, to speak to you like an honest man, am most dreadfully attended.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 95)
But, in the beaten way of friendship, what make you at Elsinore?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 96)
To visit you, my lord, no other occasion.  Beggar that am, am even poor in thanks; but thank you, and sure, dear friends, my thanks are too dear a halfpenny.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 97)
Were you not sent for? Is it your own inclining? Is it a free visitation?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 98)
Come, come, deal justly with me. Come, come; nay, speak.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 99)
What should we say, my lord?  Anything but to th' purpose.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 100)
You were sent for, and there is a kind of confession in your looks which your modesties have not craft enough to color.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 101)
know the good king and queen have sent for you.  To what end, my lord?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 102)
That you must teach me. But let me conjure you by the rights of our fellowship, by the consonancy of our youth, by the obligation of our ever-preserved love, and by what more dear a better proposer can charge you withal: be even and direct with me whether you were sent for or no.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 103)
What say you?  Nay, then, have an eye of you.--If you love me, hold not off.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 104)
My lord, we were sent for.  will tell you why; so shall my anticipation prevent your discovery, and your secrecy to the King and Queen molt no feather.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 105)
have of late, but wherefore know not, lost all my mirth, forgone all custom of exercises, and, indeed, it goes so heavily with my disposition that this goodly frame, the Earth, seems to me a sterile promontory; this most excellent canopy, the air, look you, this brave o'erhanging firmament, this majestical roof, fretted with golden fire--why, it appeareth nothing to me but a foul and pestilent congregation of vapors.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 106)
What a piece of work is a man, how noble in reason, how infinite in faculties, in form and moving how express and admirable; in action how like an angel, in apprehension how like a god: the beauty of the world, the paragon of animals--and yet, to me, what is this quintessence of dust?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 107)
Man delights not me, no, nor women neither, though by your smiling you seem to say so.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 108)
My lord, there was no such stuff in my thoughts.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 109)
Why did you laugh, then, when said "man delights not me"?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 110)
To think, my lord, if you delight not in man, what Lenten entertainment the players shall receive from you.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 111)
We coted them on the way, and hither are they coming to offer you service.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 112)
He that plays the king shall be welcome--his Majesty shall have tribute on me.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 113)
The adventurous knight shall use his foil and target, the lover shall not sigh gratis, the humorous man shall end his part in peace, the clown shall make those laugh whose lungs are tickle o' th' sear, and the lady shall say her mind freely, or the blank verse shall halt for 't.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 114)
What players are they?  Even those you were wont to take such delight in, the tragedians of the city.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 115)
How chances it they travel? Their residence, both in reputation and profit, was better both ways.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 116)
think their inhibition comes by the means of the late innovation.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 117)
Do they hold the same estimation they did when was in the city?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 118)
Are they so followed?  No, indeed are they not.  How comes it?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 119)
Do they grow rusty?  Nay, their endeavor keeps in the wonted pace.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 120)
But there is, sir, an aerie of children, little eyases, that cry out on the top of question and are most tyrannically clapped for 't.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 121)
These are now the fashion and so berattle the common stages (so they call them) that many wearing rapiers are afraid of goose quills and dare scarce come thither.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 122)
What, are they children? Who maintains 'em? How are they escoted?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 123)
Will they pursue the quality no longer than they can sing?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 124)
Will they not say afterwards, if they should grow themselves to common players (as it is most like, if their means are no better), their writers do them wrong to make them exclaim against their own succession?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 125)
Faith, there has been much to-do on both sides, and the nation holds it no sin to tar them to controversy.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 126)
There was for a while no money bid for argument unless the poet and the player went to cuffs in the question.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 127)
Is 't possible?  there has been much throwing about of brains.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 128)
Do the boys carry it away?  Ay, that they do, my lord--Hercules and his load too.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 129)
It is not very strange; for my uncle is King of Denmark, and those that would make mouths at him while my father lived give twenty, forty, fifty, a hundred ducats apiece for his picture in little.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 130)
'Sblood, there is something in this more than natural, if philosophy could find it out.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 131)
There are the players.  Gentlemen, you are welcome to Elsinore.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 132)
Your hands, come then. Th' appurtenance of welcome is fashion and ceremony.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 133)
Let me comply with you in this garb, lest my extent to the players, which, tell you, must show fairly outwards, should more appear like entertainment than yours.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 134)
You are welcome. But my uncle-father and aunt-mother are deceived.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 135)
In what, my dear lord?  am but mad north-north-west.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 136)
When the wind is southerly, know a hawk from a handsaw.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 137)
Well be with you, gentlemen.  Hark you, Guildenstern, and you too--at each ear a hearer!(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 138)
That great baby you see there is not yet out of his swaddling clouts.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 139)
Haply he is the second time come to them, for they say an old man is twice a child.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 140)
will prophesy he comes to tell me of the players; mark it.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 141)
--You say right, sir, a Monday morning, 'twas then indeed.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 142)
My lord, have news to tell you.  My lord, have news to tell you: when Roscius was an actor in Rome--  The actors are come hither, my lord.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 143)
Buzz, buzz.  Upon my honor--  Then came each actor on his ass.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 144)
The best actors in the world, either for tragedy, comedy, history, pastoral, pastoral-comical, historical-pastoral, tragical-historical, tragical-comical-historical-pastoral, scene individable, or poem unlimited.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 145)
Seneca cannot be too heavy, nor Plautus too light.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 146)
For the law of writ and the liberty, these are the only men.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 147)
Jephthah, judge of Israel, what a treasure hadst thou!(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 148)
What a treasure had he, my lord?  Why, One fair daughter, and no more, The which he loved passing well.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 149)
Still on my daughter.  Am not i' th' right, old Jephthah?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 150)
If you call me "Jephthah," my lord: have a daughter that love passing well.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 151)
Nay, that follows not.  What follows then, my lord?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 152)
Why, As by lot, God wot and then, you know, It came to pass, as most like it was-- the first row of the pious chanson will show you more, for look where my abridgment comes.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 153)
You are welcome, masters; welcome all.--I am glad to see thee well.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 154)
--Welcome, good friends.--O my old friend! Why, thy face is valanced since saw thee last.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 155)
Com'st thou to beard me in Denmark?--What, my young lady and mistress!(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 156)
By 'r Lady, your Ladyship is nearer to heaven than when saw you last, by the altitude of a chopine.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 157)
Pray God your voice, like a piece of uncurrent gold, be not cracked within the ring.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 158)
Masters, you are all welcome. We'll e'en to 't like French falconers, fly at anything we see.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 159)
We'll have a speech straight. Come, give us a taste of your quality.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 160)
Come, a passionate speech.  What speech, my good lord?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 161)
heard thee speak me a speech once, but it was never acted, or, if it was, not above once; for the play, remember, pleased not the million: 'twas caviary to the general.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 162)
But it was (as received it, and others whose judgments in such matters cried in the top of mine) an excellent play, well digested in the scenes, set down with as much modesty as cunning.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 163)
remember one said there were no sallets in the lines to make the matter savory, nor no matter in the phrase that might indict the author of affection, but called it an honest method, as wholesome as sweet and, by very much, more handsome than fine.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 164)
One speech in 't chiefly loved. 'Twas Aeneas' tale to Dido, and thereabout of it especially when he speaks of Priam's slaughter.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 165)
If it live in your memory, begin at this line--let me see, let me see: The rugged Pyrrhus, like th' Hyrcanian beast-- 'tis not so; it begins with Pyrrhus: The rugged Pyrrhus, he whose sable arms, Black as his purpose, did the night resemble When he lay couched in th' ominous horse, Hath now this dread and black complexion smeared With heraldry more dismal.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 166)
Head to foot, Now is he total gules, horridly tricked With blood of fathers, mothers, daughters, sons, Baked and impasted with the parching streets, That lend a tyrannous and a damned light To their lord's murder.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 167)
Roasted in wrath and fire, And thus o'ersized with coagulate gore, With eyes like carbuncles, the hellish Pyrrhus Old grandsire Priam seeks.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 168)
So, proceed you.  'Fore God, my lord, well spoken, with good accent and good discretion.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 169)
Anon he finds him Striking too short at Greeks. His antique sword, Rebellious to his arm, lies where it falls, Repugnant to command.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 170)
Unequal matched, Pyrrhus at Priam drives, in rage strikes wide; But with the whiff and wind of his fell sword Th' unnerved father falls.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 171)
Then senseless Ilium, Seeming to feel this blow, with flaming top Stoops to his base, and with a hideous crash Takes prisoner Pyrrhus' ear.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 172)
For lo, his sword, Which was declining on the milky head Of reverend Priam, seemed i' th' air to stick.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 173)
So as a painted tyrant Pyrrhus stood And, like a neutral to his will and matter, Did nothing.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 174)
But as we often see against some storm silence in the heavens, the rack stand still, The bold winds speechless, and the orb below As hush as death, anon the dreadful thunder Doth rend the region; so, after Pyrrhus' pause, Aroused vengeance sets him new a-work, And never did the Cyclops' hammers fall On Mars's armor, forged for proof eterne, With less remorse than Pyrrhus' bleeding sword Now falls on Priam.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 175)
Out, out, thou strumpet Fortune! All you gods In general synod take away her power, Break all the spokes and fellies from her wheel, And bowl the round nave down the hill of heaven As low as to the fiends!(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 176)
This is too long.  It shall to the barber's with your beard.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 177)
-- Prithee say on. He's for a jig or a tale of bawdry, or he sleeps.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 178)
Say on; come to Hecuba.   But who, ah woe, had seen the mobled queen--  "The mobled queen"?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 179)
That's good. "Mobled queen" is good.   Run barefoot up and down, threat'ning the flames With bisson rheum, a clout upon that head Where late the diadem stood, and for a robe, About her lank and all o'erteemed loins blanket, in the alarm of fear caught up-- Who this had seen, with tongue in venom steeped, 'Gainst Fortune's state would treason have pronounced.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 180)
But if the gods themselves did see her then When she saw Pyrrhus make malicious sport In mincing with his sword her husband's limbs, The instant burst of clamor that she made (Unless things mortal move them not at all) Would have made milch the burning eyes of heaven And passion in the gods.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 181)
Look whe'er he has not turned his color and has tears in 's eyes.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 182)
Prithee, no more.  'Tis well. I'll have thee speak out the rest of this soon.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 183)
--Good my lord, will you see the players well bestowed?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 184)
Do you hear, let them be well used, for they are the abstract and brief chronicles of the time.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 185)
After your death you were better have a bad epitaph than their ill report while you live.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 186)
My lord, will use them according to their desert.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 187)
God's bodykins, man, much better! Use every man after his desert and who shall 'scape whipping?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 188)
Use them after your own honor and dignity. The less they deserve, the more merit is in your bounty.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 189)
Take them in.  Come, sirs.  Follow him, friends. We'll hear a play tomorrow.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 190)
Dost thou hear me, old friend? Can you play "The Murder of Gonzago"?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 191)
Ay, my lord.  We'll ha 't tomorrow night. You could, for a need, study a speech of some dozen or sixteen lines, which would set down and insert in 't, could you not?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 192)
Ay, my lord.  Very well. Follow that lord--and look you mock him not.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 193)
My good friends, I'll leave you till night. You are welcome to Elsinore.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 194)
Good my lord.   Ay, so, good-bye to you.  Now am alone.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 195)
what a rogue and peasant slave am Is it not monstrous that this player here, But in a fiction, in a dream of passion, Could force his soul so to his own conceit That from her working all his visage wanned, Tears in his eyes, distraction in his aspect, broken voice, and his whole function suiting With forms to his conceit--and all for nothing!(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 196)
For Hecuba! What's Hecuba to him, or he to Hecuba, That he should weep for her?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 197)
What would he do Had he the motive and the cue for passion That have?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 198)
He would drown the stage with tears And cleave the general ear with horrid speech, Make mad the guilty and appall the free, Confound the ignorant and amaze indeed The very faculties of eyes and ears.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 199)
Yet dull and muddy-mettled rascal, peak Like John-a-dreams, unpregnant of my cause, And can say nothing--no, not for a king Upon whose property and most dear life damned defeat was made.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 200)
Am a coward? Who calls me "villain"? breaks my pate across?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 201)
Plucks off my beard and blows it in my face? Tweaks me by the nose?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 202)
gives me the lie i' th' throat As deep as to the lungs?(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 203)
Who does me this? Ha! 'Swounds, should take it! For it cannot be But am pigeon-livered and lack gall To make oppression bitter, or ere this should have fatted all the region kites With this slave's offal.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 204)
Bloody, bawdy villain! Remorseless, treacherous, lecherous, kindless villain!(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 205)
vengeance! Why, what an ass am This is most brave, That the son of a dear father murdered, Prompted to my revenge by heaven and hell, Must, like a whore, unpack my heart with words And fall a-cursing like a very drab, stallion!(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 206)
Fie upon 't! Foh! About, my brains!--Hum, have heard That guilty creatures sitting at a play Have, by the very cunning of the scene, Been struck so to the soul that presently They have proclaimed their malefactions; For murder, though it have no tongue, will speak With most miraculous organ.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 207)
I'll have these players Play something like the murder of my father Before mine uncle.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 208)
I'll observe his looks; I'll tent him to the quick.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 209)
If he do blench, know my course. The spirit that have seen May be a devil, and the devil hath power assume a pleasing shape; yea, and perhaps, Out of my weakness and my melancholy, As he is very potent with such spirits, Abuses me to damn me.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 210)
I'll have grounds More relative than this. The play's the thing Wherein I'll catch the conscience of the King.(Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 211)
What, Lucius, ho!-- cannot by the progress of the stars Give guess how near to day.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 0)
--Lucius, say!-- would it were my fault to sleep so soundly.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 1)
-- When, Lucius, when? Awake, say! What, Lucius!     Called you, my lord?(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 2)
Get me a taper in my study, Lucius. When it is lighted, come and call me here.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 3)
will, my lord.   It must be by his death. And for my part know no personal cause to spurn at him, But for the general.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 4)
He would be crowned: How that might change his nature, there's the question.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 5)
It is the bright day that brings forth the adder, And that craves wary walking.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 6)
Crown him that, And then grant we put a sting in him That at his will he may do danger with.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 7)
Th' abuse of greatness is when it disjoins Remorse from power.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 8)
And, to speak truth of Caesar, have not known when his affections swayed More than his reason.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 9)
But 'tis a common proof That lowliness is young ambition's ladder, Whereto the climber-upward turns his face; But, when he once attains the upmost round, He then unto the ladder turns his back, Looks in the clouds, scorning the base degrees By which he did ascend.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 10)
So Caesar may. Then, lest he may, prevent. And since the quarrel Will bear no color for the thing he is, Fashion it thus: that what he is, augmented, Would run to these and these extremities.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 11)
And therefore think him as a serpent's egg, Which, hatched, would, as his kind, grow mischievous, And kill him in the shell.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 12)
The taper burneth in your closet, sir. Searching the window for a flint, found This paper, thus sealed up, and am sure It did not lie there when went to bed.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 13)
Get you to bed again. It is not day. Is not tomorrow, boy, the ides of March?(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 14)
know not, sir.   Look in the calendar, and bring me word.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 15)
will, sir.   The exhalations, whizzing in the air, Give so much light that may read by them.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 16)
Brutus, thou sleep'st. Awake, and see thyself! Shall Rome, etc.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 17)
Speak, strike, redress! "Brutus, thou sleep'st. Awake.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 18)
" Such instigations have been often dropped Where have took them up.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 19)
"Shall Rome, etc." Thus must piece it out: Shall Rome stand under one man's awe?(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 20)
What, Rome? My ancestors did from the streets of Rome The Tarquin drive when he was called a king.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 21)
"Speak, strike, redress!" Am entreated To speak and strike?(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 22)
Rome, make thee promise, If the redress will follow, thou receivest Thy full petition at the hand of Brutus.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 23)
Sir, March is wasted fifteen days.    'Tis good.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 24)
Go to the gate; somebody knocks.  Since Cassius first did whet me against Caesar, have not slept.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 25)
Between the acting of a dreadful thing And the first motion, all the interim is Like a phantasma or a hideous dream.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 26)
The genius and the mortal instruments Are then in council, and the state of man, Like to a little kingdom, suffers then The nature of an insurrection.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 27)
Sir, 'tis your brother Cassius at the door, Who doth desire to see you.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 28)
Is he alone?   No, sir. There are more with him.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 29)
Do you know them?   No, sir. Their hats are plucked about their ears, And half their faces buried in their cloaks, That by no means may discover them By any mark of favor.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 30)
Let 'em enter. They are the faction. conspiracy, Sham'st thou to show thy dang'rous brow by night, When evils are most free?(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 31)
then, by day Where wilt thou find a cavern dark enough To mask thy monstrous visage?(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 32)
Seek none, conspiracy. Hide it in smiles and affability; For if thou path, thy native semblance on, Not Erebus itself were dim enough To hide thee from prevention.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 33)
think we are too bold upon your rest. Good morrow, Brutus.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 34)
Do we trouble you?   have been up this hour, awake all night.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 35)
Know these men that come along with you?   Yes, every man of them; and no man here But honors you, and every one doth wish You had but that opinion of yourself Which every noble Roman bears of you.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 36)
This is Trebonius.  He is welcome hither.   This, Decius Brutus.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 37)
He is welcome too.   This, Casca; this, Cinna; and this, Metellus Cimber.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 38)
They are all welcome. What watchful cares do interpose themselves Betwixt your eyes and night?(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 39)
Shall entreat a word?    Here lies the east; doth not the day break here?(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 40)
No.   pardon, sir, it doth; and yon gray lines That fret the clouds are messengers of day.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 41)
You shall confess that you are both deceived. Here, as point my sword, the sun arises, Which is a great way growing on the south, Weighing the youthful season of the year.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 42)
Some two months hence, up higher toward the north He first presents his fire, and the high east Stands, as the Capitol, directly here.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 43)
Give me your hands all over, one by one.   And let us swear our resolution.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 44)
No, not an oath. If not the face of men, The sufferance of our souls, the time's abuse-- If these be motives weak, break off betimes, And every man hence to his idle bed.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 45)
So let high-sighted tyranny range on Till each man drop by lottery.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 46)
But if these-- As am sure they do--bear fire enough To kindle cowards and to steel with valor The melting spirits of women, then, countrymen, What need we any spur but our own cause To prick us to redress?(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 47)
What other bond Than secret Romans that have spoke the word And will not palter?(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 48)
And what other oath Than honesty to honesty engaged That this shall be or we will fall for it?(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 49)
Swear priests and cowards and men cautelous, Old feeble carrions, and such suffering souls That welcome wrongs; unto bad causes swear Such creatures as men doubt; but do not stain The even virtue of our enterprise, Nor th' insuppressive mettle of our spirits, To think that or our cause or our performance Did need an oath, when every drop of blood That every Roman bears, and nobly bears, Is guilty of a several bastardy If he do break the smallest particle Of any promise that hath passed from him.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 50)
But what of Cicero? Shall we sound him? think he will stand very strong with us.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 51)
Let us not leave him out.  No, by no means.   let us have him, for his silver hairs Will purchase us a good opinion And buy men's voices to commend our deeds.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 52)
It shall be said his judgment ruled our hands. Our youths and wildness shall no whit appear, But all be buried in his gravity.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 53)
name him not! Let us not break with him, For he will never follow anything That other men begin.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 54)
Then leave him out.  Indeed, he is not fit.   Shall no man else be touched, but only Caesar?(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 55)
Decius, well urged. think it is not meet Mark Antony, so well beloved of Caesar, Should outlive Caesar.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 56)
We shall find of him shrewd contriver; and, you know, his means, If he improve them, may well stretch so far As to annoy us all; which to prevent, Let Antony and Caesar fall together.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 57)
Our course will seem too bloody, Caius Cassius, To cut the head off and then hack the limbs, Like wrath in death and envy afterwards; For Antony is but a limb of Caesar.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 58)
Let's be sacrificers, but not butchers, Caius. We all stand up against the spirit of Caesar, And in the spirit of men there is no blood.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 59)
that we then could come by Caesar's spirit And not dismember Caesar!(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 60)
But, alas, Caesar must bleed for it. And, gentle friends, Let's kill him boldly, but not wrathfully.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 61)
Let's carve him as a dish fit for the gods, Not hew him as a carcass fit for hounds.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 62)
And let our hearts, as subtle masters do, Stir up their servants to an act of rage And after seem to chide 'em.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 63)
This shall make Our purpose necessary and not envious; Which so appearing to the common eyes, We shall be called purgers, not murderers.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 64)
And for Mark Antony, think not of him, For he can do no more than Caesar's arm When Caesar's head is off.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 65)
Yet fear him, For in the engrafted love he bears to Caesar--   Alas, good Cassius, do not think of him.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 66)
If he love Caesar, all that he can do Is to himself: take thought and die for Caesar.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 67)
And that were much he should, for he is given To sports, to wildness, and much company.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 68)
There is no fear in him. Let him not die, For he will live and laugh at this hereafter.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 69)
Peace, count the clock.  The clock hath stricken three.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 70)
'Tis time to part.  But it is doubtful yet Whether Caesar will come forth today or no, For he is superstitious grown of late, Quite from the main opinion he held once Of fantasy, of dreams, and ceremonies.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 71)
It may be these apparent prodigies, The unaccustomed terror of this night, And the persuasion of his augurers May hold him from the Capitol today.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 72)
Never fear that. If he be so resolved, can o'ersway him, for he loves to hear That unicorns may be betrayed with trees, And bears with glasses, elephants with holes, Lions with toils, and men with flatterers.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 73)
But when tell him he hates flatterers, He says he does, being then most flattered.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 74)
Let me work, For can give his humor the true bent, And will bring him to the Capitol.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 75)
Nay, we will all of us be there to fetch him.   By the eighth hour, is that the uttermost?(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 76)
Be that the uttermost, and fail not then.   Caius Ligarius doth bear Caesar hard, Who rated him for speaking well of Pompey.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 77)
wonder none of you have thought of him.   Now, good Metellus, go along by him.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 78)
He loves me well, and have given him reasons. Send him but hither, and I'll fashion him.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 79)
The morning comes upon 's. We'll leave you, Brutus.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 80)
And, friends, disperse yourselves, but all remember What you have said, and show yourselves true Romans.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 81)
Good gentlemen, look fresh and merrily. Let not our looks put on our purposes, But bear it, as our Roman actors do, With untired spirits and formal constancy.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 82)
And so good morrow to you every one.  Boy! Lucius!(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 83)
--Fast asleep? It is no matter. Enjoy the honey-heavy dew of slumber.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 84)
Thou hast no figures nor no fantasies Which busy care draws in the brains of men.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 85)
Therefore thou sleep'st so sound.     Brutus, my lord.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 86)
Portia! What mean you? Wherefore rise you now? It is not for your health thus to commit Your weak condition to the raw cold morning.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 87)
Nor for yours neither. You've ungently, Brutus, Stole from my bed.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 88)
And yesternight at supper You suddenly arose and walked about, Musing and sighing, with your arms across, And when asked you what the matter was, You stared upon me with ungentle looks.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 89)
urged you further; then you scratched your head And too impatiently stamped with your foot.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 90)
Yet insisted; yet you answered not, But with an angry wafture of your hand Gave sign for me to leave you.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 91)
So did, Fearing to strengthen that impatience Which seemed too much enkindled, and withal Hoping it was but an effect of humor, Which sometime hath his hour with every man.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 92)
It will not let you eat nor talk nor sleep, And could it work so much upon your shape As it hath much prevailed on your condition, should not know you Brutus.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 93)
Dear my lord, Make me acquainted with your cause of grief.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 94)
am not well in health, and that is all.   Brutus is wise and, were he not in health, He would embrace the means to come by it.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 95)
Why so do. Good Portia, go to bed.   Is Brutus sick?(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 96)
And is it physical To walk unbraced and suck up the humors Of the dank morning?(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 97)
What, is Brutus sick, And will he steal out of his wholesome bed To dare the vile contagion of the night And tempt the rheumy and unpurged air To add unto his sickness?(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 98)
No, my Brutus, You have some sick offense within your mind, Which by the right and virtue of my place ought to know of.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 99)
And upon my knees charm you, by my once commended beauty, By all your vows of love, and that great vow Which did incorporate and make us one, That you unfold to me, your self, your half, Why you are heavy, and what men tonight Have had resort to you; for here have been Some six or seven who did hide their faces Even from darkness.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 100)
Kneel not, gentle Portia.    should not need, if you were gentle Brutus.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 101)
Within the bond of marriage, tell me, Brutus, Is it excepted should know no secrets That appertain to you?(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 102)
Am your self But, as it were, in sort or limitation, To keep with you at meals, comfort your bed, And talk to you sometimes?(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 103)
Dwell but in the suburbs Of your good pleasure? If it be no more, Portia is Brutus' harlot, not his wife.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 104)
You are my true and honorable wife, As dear to me as are the ruddy drops That visit my sad heart.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 105)
If this were true, then should know this secret.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 106)
grant am a woman, but withal woman that Lord Brutus took to wife.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 107)
grant am a woman, but withal woman well-reputed, Cato's daughter.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 108)
Think you am no stronger than my sex, Being so fathered and so husbanded?(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 109)
Tell me your counsels; will not disclose 'em. have made strong proof of my constancy, Giving myself a voluntary wound Here, in the thigh.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 110)
Can bear that with patience, And not my husband's secrets?(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 111)
you gods, Render me worthy of this noble wife! Hark, hark, one knocks.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 112)
Portia, go in awhile, And by and by thy bosom shall partake The secrets of my heart.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 113)
All my engagements will construe to thee, All the charactery of my sad brows.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 114)
Leave me with haste. Lucius, who 's that knocks?      Here is a sick man that would speak with you.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 115)
Caius Ligarius, that Metellus spoke of.-- Boy, stand aside.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 116)
Caius Ligarius, how?   Vouchsafe good morrow from a feeble tongue.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 117)
what a time have you chose out, brave Caius, To wear a kerchief!(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 118)
Would you were not sick!   am not sick, if Brutus have in hand Any exploit worthy the name of honor.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 119)
Such an exploit have in hand, Ligarius, Had you a healthful ear to hear of it.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 120)
By all the gods that Romans bow before, here discard my sickness.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 121)
Soul of Rome, Brave son derived from honorable loins, Thou like an exorcist hast conjured up My mortified spirit.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 122)
Now bid me run, And will strive with things impossible, Yea, get the better of them.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 123)
What's to do?   piece of work that will make sick men whole.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 124)
But are not some whole that we must make sick?   That must we also.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 125)
What it is, my Caius, shall unfold to thee as we are going To whom it must be done.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 126)
Set on your foot, And with a heart new-fired follow you To do know not what; but it sufficeth That Brutus leads me on.(Julius Caesar, Act 0, Scene 127)
Nor heaven nor Earth have been at peace tonight.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 0)
Thrice hath Calphurnia in her sleep cried out "Help ho, they murder Caesar!(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 1)
"--Who's within?     My lord.   Go bid the priests do present sacrifice, And bring me their opinions of success.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 2)
will, my lord.      What mean you, Caesar? Think you to walk forth?(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 3)
You shall not stir out of your house today.   Caesar shall forth.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 4)
The things that threatened me Ne'er looked but on my back.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 5)
When they shall see The face of Caesar, they are vanished.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 6)
Caesar, never stood on ceremonies, Yet now they fright me.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 7)
There is one within, Besides the things that we have heard and seen, Recounts most horrid sights seen by the watch.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 8)
lioness hath whelped in the streets, And graves have yawned and yielded up their dead.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 9)
Fierce fiery warriors fought upon the clouds In ranks and squadrons and right form of war, Which drizzled blood upon the Capitol.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 10)
The noise of battle hurtled in the air, Horses did neigh, and dying men did groan, And ghosts did shriek and squeal about the streets.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 11)
Caesar, these things are beyond all use, And do fear them.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 12)
What can be avoided Whose end is purposed by the mighty gods?(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 13)
Yet Caesar shall go forth, for these predictions Are to the world in general as to Caesar.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 14)
When beggars die there are no comets seen; The heavens themselves blaze forth the death of princes.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 15)
Cowards die many times before their deaths; The valiant never taste of death but once.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 16)
Of all the wonders that yet have heard, It seems to me most strange that men should fear, Seeing that death, a necessary end, Will come when it will come.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 17)
What say the augurers?   They would not have you to stir forth today.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 18)
Plucking the entrails of an offering forth, They could not find a heart within the beast.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 19)
The gods do this in shame of cowardice. Caesar should be a beast without a heart If he should stay at home today for fear.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 20)
No, Caesar shall not. Danger knows full well That Caesar is more dangerous than he.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 21)
We are two lions littered in one day, And the elder and more terrible.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 22)
And Caesar shall go forth.  Alas, my lord, Your wisdom is consumed in confidence.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 23)
Do not go forth today. Call it my fear That keeps you in the house, and not your own.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 24)
We'll send Mark Antony to the Senate House, And he shall say you are not well today.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 25)
Let me, upon my knee, prevail in this.   Mark Antony shall say am not well, And for thy humor will stay at home.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 26)
Here's Decius Brutus; he shall tell them so.   Caesar, all hail!(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 27)
Good morrow, worthy Caesar. come to fetch you to the Senate House.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 28)
And you are come in very happy time To bear my greeting to the Senators And tell them that will not come today.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 29)
Cannot is false, and that dare not, falser. will not come today.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 30)
Tell them so, Decius.   Say he is sick.  Shall Caesar send a lie?(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 31)
Have in conquest stretched mine arm so far, To be afeard to tell graybeards the truth?(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 32)
Decius, go tell them Caesar will not come.   Most mighty Caesar, let me know some cause, Lest be laughed at when tell them so.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 33)
The cause is in my will. will not come. That is enough to satisfy the Senate.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 34)
But for your private satisfaction, Because love you, will let you know.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 35)
Calphurnia here, my wife, stays me at home. She dreamt tonight she saw my statue, Which, like a fountain with an hundred spouts, Did run pure blood; and many lusty Romans Came smiling and did bathe their hands in it.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 36)
And these does she apply for warnings and portents And evils imminent, and on her knee Hath begged that will stay at home today.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 37)
This dream is all amiss interpreted. It was a vision fair and fortunate.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 38)
Your statue spouting blood in many pipes, In which so many smiling Romans bathed, Signifies that from you great Rome shall suck Reviving blood, and that great men shall press For tinctures, stains, relics, and cognizance.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 39)
This by Calphurnia's dream is signified.   And this way have you well expounded it.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 40)
have, when you have heard what can say. And know it now: the Senate have concluded To give this day a crown to mighty Caesar.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 41)
If you shall send them word you will not come, Their minds may change.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 42)
Besides, it were a mock Apt to be rendered, for someone to say "Break up the Senate till another time, When Caesar's wife shall meet with better dreams.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 43)
" If Caesar hide himself, shall they not whisper "Lo, Caesar is afraid"?(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 44)
Pardon me, Caesar, for my dear dear love To your proceeding bids me tell you this, And reason to my love is liable.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 45)
How foolish do your fears seem now, Calphurnia!(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 46)
am ashamed did yield to them. Give me my robe, for will go.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 47)
And look where Publius is come to fetch me.   Good morrow, Caesar.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 48)
Welcome, Publius.-- What, Brutus, are you stirred so early too?(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 49)
-- Good morrow, Casca.--Caius Ligarius, Caesar was ne'er so much your enemy As that same ague which hath made you lean.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 50)
-- What is 't o'clock?  Caesar, 'tis strucken eight.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 51)
thank you for your pains and courtesy.    See, Antony that revels long a-nights Is notwithstanding up.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 52)
--Good morrow, Antony.  So to most noble Caesar.  Bid them prepare within.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 53)
-- am to blame to be thus waited for. Now, Cinna.--Now, Metellus.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 54)
--What, Trebonius, have an hour's talk in store for you.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 55)
Remember that you call on me today; Be near me that may remember you.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 56)
Caesar, will.  And so near will be That your best friends shall wish had been further.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 57)
Good friends, go in and taste some wine with me, And we, like friends, will straightway go together.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 58)
That every like is not the same, Caesar, The heart of Brutus earns to think upon.(Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 59)
2       Caesar, beware of Brutus, take heed of Cassius, come not near Casca, have an eye to Cinna, trust not Trebonius, mark well Metellus Cimber.(Julius Caesar, Act 2, Scene 0)
Decius Brutus loves thee not. Thou hast wronged Caius Ligarius.(Julius Caesar, Act 2, Scene 1)
There is but one mind in all these men, and it is bent against Caesar.(Julius Caesar, Act 2, Scene 2)
If thou beest not immortal, look about you. Security gives way to conspiracy.(Julius Caesar, Act 2, Scene 3)
The mighty gods defend thee! Thy lover, Artemidorus Here will stand till Caesar pass along, And as a suitor will give him this.(Julius Caesar, Act 2, Scene 4)
My heart laments that virtue cannot live Out of the teeth of emulation.(Julius Caesar, Act 2, Scene 5)
If thou read this, Caesar, thou mayest live; If not, the Fates with traitors do contrive.(Julius Caesar, Act 2, Scene 6)
prithee, boy, run to the Senate House. Stay not to answer me, but get thee gone.(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 0)
Why dost thou stay?  To know my errand, madam.   would have had thee there and here again Ere can tell thee what thou shouldst do there.(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 1)
constancy, be strong upon my side; Set a huge mountain 'tween my heart and tongue.(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 2)
have a man's mind but a woman's might. How hard it is for women to keep counsel!(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 3)
-- Art thou here yet?  Madam, what should do? Run to the Capitol, and nothing else?(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 4)
And so return to you, and nothing else?   Yes, bring me word, boy, if thy lord look well, For he went sickly forth.(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 5)
And take good note What Caesar doth, what suitors press to him.(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 6)
Hark, boy, what noise is that?  hear none, madam.(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 7)
Prithee, listen well. heard a bustling rumor like a fray, And the wind brings it from the Capitol.(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 8)
Sooth, madam, hear nothing.      Come hither, fellow.(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 9)
Which way hast thou been?  At mine own house, good lady.(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 10)
What is 't o'clock?  About the ninth hour, lady.(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 11)
Is Caesar yet gone to the Capitol?   Madam, not yet.(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 12)
go to take my stand To see him pass on to the Capitol.(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 13)
Thou hast some suit to Caesar, hast thou not?   That have, lady.(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 14)
If it will please Caesar To be so good to Caesar as to hear me, shall beseech him to befriend himself.(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 15)
Why, know'st thou any harm's intended towards him?(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 16)
None that know will be, much that fear may chance.(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 17)
Good morrow to you.--Here the street is narrow. The throng that follows Caesar at the heels, Of senators, of praetors, common suitors, Will crowd a feeble man almost to death.(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 18)
I'll get me to a place more void, and there Speak to great Caesar as he comes along.(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 19)
must go in.  Ay me, how weak a thing The heart of woman is!(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 20)
Brutus, The heavens speed thee in thine enterprise!(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 21)
Sure the boy heard me.  Brutus hath a suit That Caesar will not grant.(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 22)
grow faint.-- Run, Lucius, and commend me to my lord.(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 23)
Say am merry. Come to me again And bring me word what he doth say to thee.(Julius Caesar, Act 3, Scene 24)
2     King of France, Louis the Dauphin, Constance, Arthur, and Attendants; at the other side, with Forces, Austria,     Before Angiers well met, brave Austria.(King John, Act 0, Scene 0)
-- Arthur, that great forerunner of thy blood, Richard, that robbed the lion of his heart And fought the holy wars in Palestine, By this brave duke came early to his grave.(King John, Act 0, Scene 1)
And, for amends to his posterity, At our importance hither is he come To spread his colors, boy, in thy behalf, And to rebuke the usurpation Of thy unnatural uncle, English John.(King John, Act 0, Scene 2)
Embrace him, love him, give him welcome hither.   God shall forgive you Coeur de Lion's death The rather that you give his offspring life, Shadowing their right under your wings of war.(King John, Act 0, Scene 3)
give you welcome with a powerless hand But with a heart full of unstained love.(King John, Act 0, Scene 4)
Welcome before the gates of Angiers, duke.   noble boy.(King John, Act 0, Scene 5)
Who would not do thee right?   Upon thy cheek lay this zealous kiss As seal to this indenture of my love: That to my home will no more return Till Angiers and the right thou hast in France, Together with that pale, that white-faced shore, Whose foot spurns back the ocean's roaring tides And coops from other lands her islanders, Even till that England, hedged in with the main, That water-walled bulwark, still secure And confident from foreign purposes, Even till that utmost corner of the West Salute thee for her king.(King John, Act 0, Scene 6)
Till then, fair boy, Will not think of home, but follow arms.(King John, Act 0, Scene 7)
take his mother's thanks, a widow's thanks, Till your strong hand shall help to give him strength To make a more requital to your love.(King John, Act 0, Scene 8)
The peace of heaven is theirs that lift their swords In such a just and charitable war.(King John, Act 0, Scene 9)
Well, then, to work. Our cannon shall be bent Against the brows of this resisting town.(King John, Act 0, Scene 10)
Call for our chiefest men of discipline To cull the plots of best advantages.(King John, Act 0, Scene 11)
We'll lay before this town our royal bones, Wade to the marketplace in Frenchmen's blood, But we will make it subject to this boy.(King John, Act 0, Scene 12)
Stay for an answer to your embassy, Lest unadvised you stain your swords with blood.(King John, Act 0, Scene 13)
My lord Chatillion may from England bring That right in peace which here we urge in war, And then we shall repent each drop of blood That hot rash haste so indirectly shed.(King John, Act 0, Scene 14)
wonder, lady! Lo, upon thy wish Our messenger Chatillion is arrived.(King John, Act 0, Scene 15)
-- What England says say briefly, gentle lord. We coldly pause for thee.(King John, Act 0, Scene 16)
Chatillion, speak.   Then turn your forces from this paltry siege And stir them up against a mightier task.(King John, Act 0, Scene 17)
England, impatient of your just demands, Hath put himself in arms.(King John, Act 0, Scene 18)
The adverse winds, Whose leisure have stayed, have given him time To land his legions all as soon as His marches are expedient to this town, His forces strong, his soldiers confident.(King John, Act 0, Scene 19)
With him along is come the Mother Queen, An Ate stirring him to blood and strife; With her her niece, the Lady Blanche of Spain; With them a bastard of the King's deceased.(King John, Act 0, Scene 20)
And all th' unsettled humors of the land-- Rash, inconsiderate, fiery voluntaries, With ladies' faces and fierce dragons' spleens-- Have sold their fortunes at their native homes, Bearing their birthrights proudly on their backs, To make a hazard of new fortunes here.(King John, Act 0, Scene 21)
In brief, a braver choice of dauntless spirits Than now the English bottoms have waft o'er Did never float upon the swelling tide To do offense and scathe in Christendom.(King John, Act 0, Scene 22)
The interruption of their churlish drums Cuts off more circumstance.(King John, Act 0, Scene 23)
They are at hand, To parley or to fight, therefore prepare.(King John, Act 0, Scene 24)
How much unlooked-for is this expedition.   By how much unexpected, by so much We must awake endeavor for defense, For courage mounteth with occasion.(King John, Act 0, Scene 25)
Let them be welcome, then. We are prepared.       Peace be to France, if France in peace permit Our just and lineal entrance to our own.(King John, Act 0, Scene 26)
If not, bleed France, and peace ascend to heaven, Whiles we, God's wrathful agent, do correct Their proud contempt that beats his peace to heaven.(King John, Act 0, Scene 27)
Peace be to England, if that war return From France to England, there to live in peace.(King John, Act 0, Scene 28)
England we love, and for that England's sake With burden of our armor here we sweat.(King John, Act 0, Scene 29)
This toil of ours should be a work of thine; But thou from loving England art so far That thou hast underwrought his lawful king, Cut off the sequence of posterity, Outfaced infant state, and done a rape Upon the maiden virtue of the crown.(King John, Act 0, Scene 30)
Look here upon thy brother Geoffrey's face.  These eyes, these brows, were molded out of his; This little abstract doth contain that large Which died in Geoffrey, and the hand of time Shall draw this brief into as huge a volume.(King John, Act 0, Scene 31)
That Geoffrey was thy elder brother born, And this his son.(King John, Act 0, Scene 32)
England was Geoffrey's right, And this is Geoffrey's.(King John, Act 0, Scene 33)
In the name of God, How comes it then that thou art called a king, When living blood doth in these temples beat Which owe the crown that thou o'ermasterest?(King John, Act 0, Scene 34)
From whom hast thou this great commission, France, To draw my answer from thy articles?(King John, Act 0, Scene 35)
From that supernal judge that stirs good thoughts In any breast of strong authority To look into the blots and stains of right.(King John, Act 0, Scene 36)
That judge hath made me guardian to this boy, Under whose warrant impeach thy wrong, And by whose help mean to chastise it.(King John, Act 0, Scene 37)
Alack, thou dost usurp authority.   Excuse it is to beat usurping down.(King John, Act 0, Scene 38)
Who is it thou dost call usurper, France?   Let me make answer: thy usurping son.(King John, Act 0, Scene 39)
Out, insolent! Thy bastard shall be king That thou mayst be a queen and check the world.(King John, Act 0, Scene 40)
My bed was ever to thy son as true As thine was to thy husband, and this boy Liker in feature to his father Geoffrey Than thou and John, in manners being as like As rain to water or devil to his dam.(King John, Act 0, Scene 41)
My boy a bastard? By my soul, think His father never was so true begot.(King John, Act 0, Scene 42)
It cannot be, an if thou wert his mother.   There's a good mother, boy, that blots thy father.(King John, Act 0, Scene 43)
There's a good grandam, boy, that would blot thee.(King John, Act 0, Scene 44)
Peace!  Hear the crier!  What the devil art thou?(King John, Act 0, Scene 45)
One that will play the devil, sir, with you, An he may catch your hide and you alone.(King John, Act 0, Scene 46)
You are the hare of whom the proverb goes, Whose valor plucks dead lions by the beard.(King John, Act 0, Scene 47)
I'll smoke your skin-coat an catch you right. Sirrah, look to 't.(King John, Act 0, Scene 48)
faith, will, i' faith!   well did he become that lion's robe That did disrobe the lion of that robe.(King John, Act 0, Scene 49)
It lies as sightly on the back of him As great Alcides' shoes upon an ass.(King John, Act 0, Scene 50)
-- But, ass, I'll take that burden from your back Or lay on that shall make your shoulders crack.(King John, Act 0, Scene 51)
What cracker is this same that deafs our ears With this abundance of superfluous breath?(King John, Act 0, Scene 52)
Louis, determine what we shall do straight.   Women and fools, break off your conference.(King John, Act 0, Scene 53)
-- King John, this is the very sum of all: England and Ireland, Anjou, Touraine, Maine, In right of Arthur do claim of thee.(King John, Act 0, Scene 54)
Wilt thou resign them and lay down thy arms?   My life as soon!(King John, Act 0, Scene 55)
do defy thee, France.-- Arthur of Brittany, yield thee to my hand, And out of my dear love I'll give thee more Than e'er the coward hand of France can win.(King John, Act 0, Scene 56)
Submit thee, boy.  Come to thy grandam, child.   Do, child, go to it grandam, child.(King John, Act 0, Scene 57)
Give grandam kingdom, and it grandam will Give it a plum, a cherry, and a fig.(King John, Act 0, Scene 58)
There's a good grandam.  Good my mother, peace. would that were low laid in my grave.(King John, Act 0, Scene 59)
am not worth this coil that's made for me.   His mother shames him so, poor boy, he weeps.(King John, Act 0, Scene 60)
Now shame upon you whe'er she does or no! His grandam's wrongs, and not his mother's shames, Draws those heaven-moving pearls from his poor eyes, Which heaven shall take in nature of a fee.(King John, Act 0, Scene 61)
Ay, with these crystal beads heaven shall be bribed To do him justice and revenge on you.(King John, Act 0, Scene 62)
Thou monstrous slanderer of heaven and Earth!   Thou monstrous injurer of heaven and Earth, Call not me slanderer.(King John, Act 0, Scene 63)
Thou and thine usurp The dominations, royalties, and rights Of this oppressed boy.(King John, Act 0, Scene 64)
This is thy eldest son's son, Infortunate in nothing but in thee.(King John, Act 0, Scene 65)
Thy sins are visited in this poor child. The canon of the law is laid on him, Being but the second generation Removed from thy sin-conceiving womb.(King John, Act 0, Scene 66)
Bedlam, have done.  have but this to say, That he is not only plagued for her sin, But God hath made her sin and her the plague On this removed issue, plagued for her, And with her plague; her sin his injury, Her injury the beadle to her sin, All punished in the person of this child And all for her.(King John, Act 0, Scene 67)
plague upon her!   Thou unadvised scold, can produce will that bars the title of thy son.(King John, Act 0, Scene 68)
Ay, who doubts that? will--a wicked will, woman's will, a cankered grandam's will.(King John, Act 0, Scene 69)
Peace, lady. Pause, or be more temperate. It ill beseems this presence to cry aim To these ill-tuned repetitions.(King John, Act 0, Scene 70)
-- Some trumpet summon hither to the walls These men of Angiers.(King John, Act 0, Scene 71)
Let us hear them speak Whose title they admit, Arthur's or John's.(King John, Act 0, Scene 72)
Who is it that hath warned us to the walls?(King John, Act 0, Scene 73)
'Tis France, for England.  England, for itself.(King John, Act 0, Scene 74)
You men of Angiers, and my loving subjects--   You loving men of Angiers, Arthur's subjects, Our trumpet called you to this gentle parle--   For our advantage.(King John, Act 0, Scene 75)
Therefore hear us first. These flags of France that are advanced here Before the eye and prospect of your town, Have hither marched to your endamagement.(King John, Act 0, Scene 76)
The cannons have their bowels full of wrath, And ready mounted are they to spit forth Their iron indignation 'gainst your walls.(King John, Act 0, Scene 77)
All preparation for a bloody siege And merciless proceeding by these French Confronts your city's eyes, your winking gates, And, but for our approach, those sleeping stones, That as a waist doth girdle you about, By the compulsion of their ordinance By this time from their fixed beds of lime Had been dishabited, and wide havoc made For bloody power to rush upon your peace.(King John, Act 0, Scene 78)
But on the sight of us your lawful king, Who painfully with much expedient march Have brought a countercheck before your gates To save unscratched your city's threatened cheeks, Behold, the French, amazed, vouchsafe a parle.(King John, Act 0, Scene 79)
And now, instead of bullets wrapped in fire To make a shaking fever in your walls, They shoot but calm words folded up in smoke To make a faithless error in your ears, Which trust accordingly, kind citizens, And let us in.(King John, Act 0, Scene 80)
Your king, whose labored spirits Forwearied in this action of swift speed, Craves harborage within your city walls.(King John, Act 0, Scene 81)
When have said, make answer to us both.  Lo, in this right hand, whose protection Is most divinely vowed upon the right Of him it holds, stands young Plantagenet, Son to the elder brother of this man, And king o'er him and all that he enjoys.(King John, Act 0, Scene 82)
For this downtrodden equity we tread In warlike march these greens before your town, Being no further enemy to you Than the constraint of hospitable zeal In the relief of this oppressed child Religiously provokes.(King John, Act 0, Scene 83)
Be pleased then To pay that duty which you truly owe To him that owes it, namely, this young prince, And then our arms, like to a muzzled bear Save in aspect, hath all offense sealed up.(King John, Act 0, Scene 84)
Our cannons' malice vainly shall be spent Against th' invulnerable clouds of heaven, And with a blessed and unvexed retire, With unbacked swords and helmets all unbruised, We will bear home that lusty blood again Which here we came to spout against your town, And leave your children, wives, and you in peace.(King John, Act 0, Scene 85)
But if you fondly pass our proffered offer, 'Tis not the roundure of your old-faced walls Can hide you from our messengers of war, Though all these English and their discipline Were harbored in their rude circumference.(King John, Act 0, Scene 86)
Then tell us, shall your city call us lord In that behalf which we have challenged it?(King John, Act 0, Scene 87)
Or shall we give the signal to our rage And stalk in blood to our possession?(King John, Act 0, Scene 88)
In brief, we are the King of England's subjects.(King John, Act 0, Scene 89)
For him, and in his right, we hold this town.   Acknowledge then the King and let me in.(King John, Act 0, Scene 90)
That can we not. But he that proves the King, To him will we prove loyal.(King John, Act 0, Scene 91)
Till that time Have we rammed up our gates against the world.(King John, Act 0, Scene 92)
Doth not the crown of England prove the King? And if not that, bring you witnesses, Twice fifteen thousand hearts of England's breed--  Bastards and else.(King John, Act 0, Scene 93)
To verify our title with their lives.   As many and as wellborn bloods as those--  Some bastards too.(King John, Act 0, Scene 94)
Stand in his face to contradict his claim.   Till you compound whose right is worthiest, We for the worthiest hold the right from both.(King John, Act 0, Scene 95)
Then God forgive the sin of all those souls That to their everlasting residence, Before the dew of evening fall, shall fleet In dreadful trial of our kingdom's king.(King John, Act 0, Scene 96)
Amen, amen.--Mount, chevaliers! To arms!   Saint George, that swinged the dragon and e'er since Sits on 's horseback at mine hostess' door, Teach us some fence!(King John, Act 0, Scene 97)
Sirrah, were at home At your den, sirrah, with your lioness, would set an ox head to your lion's hide And make a monster of you.(King John, Act 0, Scene 98)
Peace! No more.   tremble, for you hear the lion roar.(King John, Act 0, Scene 99)
Up higher to the plain, where we'll set forth In best appointment all our regiments.(King John, Act 0, Scene 100)
Speed, then, to take advantage of the field.   It shall be so, and at the other hill Command the rest to stand.(King John, Act 0, Scene 101)
God and our right!        You men of Angiers, open wide your gates, And let young Arthur, Duke of Brittany, in, Who by the hand of France this day hath made Much work for tears in many an English mother, Whose sons lie scattered on the bleeding ground.(King John, Act 0, Scene 102)
Many a widow's husband groveling lies Coldly embracing the discolored earth, And victory with little loss doth play Upon the dancing banners of the French, Who are at hand, triumphantly displayed, To enter conquerors and to proclaim Arthur of Brittany England's king and yours.(King John, Act 0, Scene 103)
Rejoice, you men of Angiers, ring your bells!(King John, Act 0, Scene 104)
King John, your king and England's, doth approach, Commander of this hot malicious day.(King John, Act 0, Scene 105)
Their armors, that marched hence so silver bright, Hither return all gilt with Frenchmen's blood.(King John, Act 0, Scene 106)
There stuck no plume in any English crest That is removed by a staff of France.(King John, Act 0, Scene 107)
Our colors do return in those same hands That did display them when we first marched forth, And like a jolly troop of huntsmen come Our lusty English, all with purpled hands, Dyed in the dying slaughter of their foes.(King John, Act 0, Scene 108)
Open your gates, and give the victors way.   Heralds, from off our towers we might behold From first to last the onset and retire Of both your armies, whose equality By our best eyes cannot be censured.(King John, Act 0, Scene 109)
Blood hath bought blood, and blows have answered blows, Strength matched with strength, and power confronted power.(King John, Act 0, Scene 110)
Both are alike, and both alike we like. One must prove greatest.(King John, Act 0, Scene 111)
While they weigh so even, We hold our town for neither, yet for both.(King John, Act 0, Scene 112)
Bastard, Queen Eleanor, Blanche, and Salisbury;     France, hast thou yet more blood to cast away?(King John, Act 0, Scene 113)
Say, shall the current of our right roam on, Whose passage, vexed with thy impediment, Shall leave his native channel and o'erswell With course disturbed even thy confining shores, Unless thou let his silver water keep peaceful progress to the ocean?(King John, Act 0, Scene 114)
England, thou hast not saved one drop of blood In this hot trial more than we of France, Rather lost more.(King John, Act 0, Scene 115)
And by this hand swear That sways the earth this climate overlooks, Before we will lay down our just-borne arms, We'll put thee down, 'gainst whom these arms we bear, Or add a royal number to the dead, Gracing the scroll that tells of this war's loss With slaughter coupled to the name of kings.(King John, Act 0, Scene 116)
Ha, majesty! How high thy glory towers When the rich blood of kings is set on fire!(King John, Act 0, Scene 117)
now doth Death line his dead chaps with steel, The swords of soldiers are his teeth, his fangs, And now he feasts, mousing the flesh of men In undetermined differences of kings.(King John, Act 0, Scene 118)
Why stand these royal fronts amazed thus? Cry havoc, kings!(King John, Act 0, Scene 119)
Back to the stained field, You equal potents, fiery-kindled spirits.(King John, Act 0, Scene 120)
Then let confusion of one part confirm The other's peace.(King John, Act 0, Scene 121)
Till then, blows, blood, and death!   Whose party do the townsmen yet admit?(King John, Act 0, Scene 122)
Speak, citizens, for England. Who's your king?   The King of England, when we know the King.(King John, Act 0, Scene 123)
Know him in us, that here hold up his right.   In us, that are our own great deputy And bear possession of our person here, Lord of our presence, Angiers, and of you.(King John, Act 0, Scene 124)
greater power than we denies all this, And till it be undoubted, we do lock Our former scruple in our strong-barred gates, Kings of our fear, until our fears resolved Be by some certain king purged and deposed.(King John, Act 0, Scene 125)
By heaven, these scroyles of Angiers flout you, kings, And stand securely on their battlements As in a theater, whence they gape and point At your industrious scenes and acts of death.(King John, Act 0, Scene 126)
Your royal presences, be ruled by me: Do like the mutines of Jerusalem, Be friends awhile, and both conjointly bend Your sharpest deeds of malice on this town.(King John, Act 0, Scene 127)
By east and west let France and England mount Their battering cannon charged to the mouths, Till their soul-fearing clamors have brawled down The flinty ribs of this contemptuous city.(King John, Act 0, Scene 128)
I'd play incessantly upon these jades, Even till unfenced desolation Leave them as naked as the vulgar air.(King John, Act 0, Scene 129)
That done, dissever your united strengths And part your mingled colors once again; Turn face to face and bloody point to point.(King John, Act 0, Scene 130)
Then in a moment Fortune shall cull forth Out of one side her happy minion, To whom in favor she shall give the day And kiss him with a glorious victory.(King John, Act 0, Scene 131)
How like you this wild counsel, mighty states? Smacks it not something of the policy?(King John, Act 0, Scene 132)
Now by the sky that hangs above our heads, like it well.(King John, Act 0, Scene 133)
France, shall we knit our powers And lay this Angiers even with the ground, Then after fight who shall be king of it?(King John, Act 0, Scene 134)
An if thou hast the mettle of a king, Being wronged as we are by this peevish town, Turn thou the mouth of thy artillery, As we will ours, against these saucy walls, And when that we have dashed them to the ground, Why, then, defy each other and pell-mell Make work upon ourselves, for heaven or hell.(King John, Act 0, Scene 135)
Let it be so. Say, where will you assault?   We from the west will send destruction Into this city's bosom.(King John, Act 0, Scene 136)
from the north.  Our thunder from the south Shall rain their drift of bullets on this town.(King John, Act 0, Scene 137)
prudent discipline! From north to south, Austria and France shoot in each other's mouth.(King John, Act 0, Scene 138)
I'll stir them to it. -- Come, away, away!   Hear us, great kings.(King John, Act 0, Scene 139)
Vouchsafe awhile to stay, And shall show you peace and fair-faced league, Win you this city without stroke or wound, Rescue those breathing lives to die in beds That here come sacrifices for the field.(King John, Act 0, Scene 140)
Persever not, but hear me, mighty kings.   Speak on with favor.(King John, Act 0, Scene 141)
We are bent to hear.   That daughter there of Spain, the Lady Blanche, Is near to England.(King John, Act 0, Scene 142)
Look upon the years Of Louis the Dauphin and that lovely maid.(King John, Act 0, Scene 143)
If lusty love should go in quest of beauty, Where should he find it fairer than in Blanche?(King John, Act 0, Scene 144)
If zealous love should go in search of virtue, Where should he find it purer than in Blanche?(King John, Act 0, Scene 145)
If love ambitious sought a match of birth, Whose veins bound richer blood than Lady Blanche?(King John, Act 0, Scene 146)
Such as she is, in beauty, virtue, birth, Is the young Dauphin every way complete.(King John, Act 0, Scene 147)
If not complete of, say he is not she, And she again wants nothing, to name want, If want it be not that she is not he.(King John, Act 0, Scene 148)
He is the half part of a blessed man, Left to be finished by such as she, And she a fair divided excellence, Whose fullness of perfection lies in him.(King John, Act 0, Scene 149)
two such silver currents when they join Do glorify the banks that bound them in, And two such shores to two such streams made one, Two such controlling bounds shall you be, kings, To these two princes, if you marry them.(King John, Act 0, Scene 150)
This union shall do more than battery can To our fast-closed gates, for at this match, With swifter spleen than powder can enforce, The mouth of passage shall we fling wide ope And give you entrance.(King John, Act 0, Scene 151)
But without this match, The sea enraged is not half so deaf, Lions more confident, mountains and rocks More free from motion, no, not Death himself In mortal fury half so peremptory As we to keep this city.(King John, Act 0, Scene 152)
Here's a stay That shakes the rotten carcass of old Death Out of his rags!(King John, Act 0, Scene 153)
Here's a large mouth indeed That spits forth death and mountains, rocks and seas; Talks as familiarly of roaring lions As maids of thirteen do of puppy dogs.(King John, Act 0, Scene 154)
What cannoneer begot this lusty blood? He speaks plain cannon fire, and smoke, and bounce.(King John, Act 0, Scene 155)
He gives the bastinado with his tongue. Our ears are cudgeled.(King John, Act 0, Scene 156)
Not a word of his But buffets better than a fist of France.(King John, Act 0, Scene 157)
Zounds, was never so bethumped with words Since first called my brother's father Dad.(King John, Act 0, Scene 158)
Son, list to this conjunction; make this match.(King John, Act 0, Scene 159)
Give with our niece a dowry large enough, For by this knot thou shalt so surely tie Thy now unsured assurance to the crown That yon green boy shall have no sun to ripe The bloom that promiseth a mighty fruit.(King John, Act 0, Scene 160)
see a yielding in the looks of France. Mark how they whisper.(King John, Act 0, Scene 161)
Urge them while their souls Are capable of this ambition, Lest zeal, now melted by the windy breath Of soft petitions, pity, and remorse, Cool and congeal again to what it was.(King John, Act 0, Scene 162)
Why answer not the double majesties This friendly treaty of our threatened town?(King John, Act 0, Scene 163)
Speak England first, that hath been forward first To speak unto this city.(King John, Act 0, Scene 164)
What say you?   If that the Dauphin there, thy princely son, Can in this book of beauty read love," Her dowry shall weigh equal with a queen.(King John, Act 0, Scene 165)
For Anjou and fair Touraine, Maine, Poitiers, And all that we upon this side the sea-- Except this city now by us besieged-- Find liable to our crown and dignity, Shall gild her bridal bed and make her rich In titles, honors, and promotions, As she in beauty, education, blood, Holds hand with any princess of the world.(King John, Act 0, Scene 166)
What sayst thou, boy? Look in the lady's face.   do, my lord, and in her eye find wonder or a wondrous miracle, The shadow of myself formed in her eye, Which, being but the shadow of your son, Becomes a sun and makes your son a shadow.(King John, Act 0, Scene 167)
do protest never loved myself Till now infixed beheld myself Drawn in the flattering table of her eye.(King John, Act 0, Scene 168)
"Drawn in the flattering table of her eye"? Hanged in the frowning wrinkle of her brow And quartered in her heart!(King John, Act 0, Scene 169)
He doth espy Himself love's traitor. This is pity now, That hanged and drawn and quartered there should be In such a love so vile a lout as he.(King John, Act 0, Scene 170)
My uncle's will in this respect is mine. If he see aught in you that makes him like, That anything he sees which moves his liking can with ease translate it to my will.(King John, Act 0, Scene 171)
Or if you will, to speak more properly, will enforce it eas'ly to my love.(King John, Act 0, Scene 172)
Further will not flatter you, my lord, That all see in you is worthy love, Than this: that nothing do see in you, Though churlish thoughts themselves should be your judge, That can find should merit any hate.(King John, Act 0, Scene 173)
What say these young ones? What say you, my niece?(King John, Act 0, Scene 174)
That she is bound in honor still to do What you in wisdom still vouchsafe to say.(King John, Act 0, Scene 175)
Speak then, Prince Dauphin. Can you love this lady?(King John, Act 0, Scene 176)
Nay, ask me if can refrain from love, For do love her most unfeignedly.(King John, Act 0, Scene 177)
