Then do give Volquessen, Touraine, Maine, Poitiers and Anjou, these five provinces With her to thee, and this addition more: Full thirty thousand marks of English coin.(King John, Act 0, Scene 178)
-- Philip of France, if thou be pleased withal, Command thy son and daughter to join hands.(King John, Act 0, Scene 179)
It likes us well.--Young princes, close your hands.(King John, Act 0, Scene 180)
And your lips too, for am well assured That did so when was first assured.(King John, Act 0, Scene 181)
Now, citizens of Angiers, ope your gates. Let in that amity which you have made, For at Saint Mary's Chapel presently The rites of marriage shall be solemnized.(King John, Act 0, Scene 182)
-- Is not the Lady Constance in this troop? know she is not, for this match made up Her presence would have interrupted much.(King John, Act 0, Scene 183)
Where is she and her son? Tell me, who knows.   She is sad and passionate at your Highness' tent.(King John, Act 0, Scene 184)
And by my faith, this league that we have made Will give her sadness very little cure.(King John, Act 0, Scene 185)
-- Brother of England, how may we content This widow lady?(King John, Act 0, Scene 186)
In her right we came, Which we, God knows, have turned another way To our own vantage.(King John, Act 0, Scene 187)
We will heal up all, For we'll create young Arthur Duke of Brittany And Earl of Richmond, and this rich, fair town We make him lord of.(King John, Act 0, Scene 188)
--Call the Lady Constance. Some speedy messenger bid her repair To our solemnity.(King John, Act 0, Scene 189)
trust we shall, If not fill up the measure of her will, Yet in some measure satisfy her so That we shall stop her exclamation.(King John, Act 0, Scene 190)
Go we as well as haste will suffer us To this unlooked-for, unprepared pomp.(King John, Act 0, Scene 191)
Mad world, mad kings, mad composition! John, to stop Arthur's title in the whole, Hath willingly departed with a part; And France, whose armor conscience buckled on, Whom zeal and charity brought to the field As God's own soldier, rounded in the ear With that same purpose-changer, that sly devil, That broker that still breaks the pate of faith, That daily break-vow, he that wins of all, Of kings, of beggars, old men, young men, maids-- Who having no external thing to lose But the word "maid," cheats the poor maid of that-- That smooth-faced gentleman, tickling Commodity, Commodity, the bias of the world-- The world, who of itself is peised well, Made to run even upon even ground, Till this advantage, this vile-drawing bias, This sway of motion, this Commodity, Makes it take head from all indifferency, From all direction, purpose, course, intent.(King John, Act 0, Scene 192)
And this same bias, this Commodity, This bawd, this broker, this all-changing word, Clapped on the outward eye of fickle France, Hath drawn him from his own determined aid, From a resolved and honorable war To a most base and vile-concluded peace.(King John, Act 0, Scene 193)
And why rail on this Commodity? But for because he hath not wooed me yet.(King John, Act 0, Scene 194)
Not that have the power to clutch my hand When his fair angels would salute my palm, But for my hand, as unattempted yet, Like a poor beggar raileth on the rich.(King John, Act 0, Scene 195)
Well, whiles am a beggar, will rail And say there is no sin but to be rich; And being rich, my virtue then shall be To say there is no vice but beggary.(King John, Act 0, Scene 196)
Since kings break faith upon Commodity, Gain, be my lord, for will worship thee!(King John, Act 0, Scene 197)
Ladies (Rosaline, Maria, and Katherine), Boyet     Now, madam, summon up your dearest spirits.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 0)
Consider who the King your father sends, To whom he sends, and what's his embassy.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 1)
Yourself, held precious in the world's esteem, To parley with the sole inheritor Of all perfections that a man may owe, Matchless Navarre; the plea of no less weight Than Aquitaine, a dowry for a queen.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 2)
Be now as prodigal of all dear grace As nature was in making graces dear When she did starve the general world besides And prodigally gave them all to you.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 3)
Good Lord Boyet, my beauty, though but mean, Needs not the painted flourish of your praise.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 4)
Beauty is bought by judgment of the eye, Not uttered by base sale of chapmen's tongues.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 5)
am less proud to hear you tell my worth Than you much willing to be counted wise In spending your wit in the praise of mine.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 6)
But now to task the tasker: good Boyet, You are not ignorant all-telling fame Doth noise abroad Navarre hath made a vow, Till painful study shall outwear three years, No woman may approach his silent court.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 7)
Therefore to 's seemeth it a needful course, Before we enter his forbidden gates, To know his pleasure, and in that behalf, Bold of your worthiness, we single you As our best-moving fair solicitor.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 8)
Tell him the daughter of the King of France On serious business craving quick dispatch, Importunes personal conference with his Grace.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 9)
Haste, signify so much, while we attend, Like humble-visaged suitors, his high will.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 10)
Proud of employment, willingly go.   All pride is willing pride, and yours is so.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 11)
Who are the votaries, my loving lords, That are vow-fellows with this virtuous duke?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 12)
Lord Longaville is one.  Know you the man?   know him, madam.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 13)
At a marriage feast Between Lord Perigort and the beauteous heir Of Jaques Falconbridge, solemnized In Normandy, saw this Longaville.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 14)
man of sovereign parts he is esteemed, Well fitted in arts, glorious in arms.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 15)
Nothing becomes him ill that he would well. The only soil of his fair virtue's gloss, If virtue's gloss will stain with any soil, Is a sharp wit matched with too blunt a will, Whose edge hath power to cut, whose will still wills It should none spare that come within his power.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 16)
Some merry mocking lord, belike. Is 't so?   They say so most that most his humors know.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 17)
Such short-lived wits do wither as they grow. Who are the rest?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 18)
The young Dumaine, a well-accomplished youth, Of all that virtue love for virtue loved.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 19)
Most power to do most harm, least knowing ill; For he hath wit to make an ill shape good, And shape to win grace though he had no wit.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 20)
saw him at the Duke Alanson's once, And much too little of that good saw Is my report to his great worthiness.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 21)
Another of these students at that time Was there with him, if have heard a truth.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 22)
Berowne they call him, but a merrier man, Within the limit of becoming mirth, never spent an hour's talk withal.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 23)
His eye begets occasion for his wit, For every object that the one doth catch The other turns to a mirth-moving jest, Which his fair tongue, conceit's expositor, Delivers in such apt and gracious words That aged ears play truant at his tales, And younger hearings are quite ravished, So sweet and voluble is his discourse.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 24)
God bless my ladies, are they all in love, That every one her own hath garnished With such bedecking ornaments of praise?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 25)
Here comes Boyet.     Now, what admittance, lord?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 26)
Navarre had notice of your fair approach, And he and his competitors in oath Were all addressed to meet you, gentle lady, Before came.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 27)
Marry, thus much have learned: He rather means to lodge you in the field, Like one that comes here to besiege his court, Than seek a dispensation for his oath To let you enter his unpeopled house.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 28)
Here comes Navarre.  Fair Princess, welcome to the court of Navarre.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 29)
"Fair" give you back again, and "welcome" have not yet.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 30)
The roof of this court is too high to be yours, and welcome to the wide fields too base to be mine.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 31)
You shall be welcome, madam, to my court.   will be welcome, then.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 32)
Conduct me thither.   Hear me, dear lady. have sworn an oath.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 33)
Our Lady help my lord! He'll be forsworn.   Not for the world, fair madam, by my will.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 34)
Why, will shall break it, will and nothing else.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 35)
Your Ladyship is ignorant what it is.   Were my lord so, his ignorance were wise, Where now his knowledge must prove ignorance.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 36)
hear your Grace hath sworn out housekeeping. 'Tis deadly sin to keep that oath, my lord, And sin to break it.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 37)
But pardon me, am too sudden bold. To teach a teacher ill beseemeth me.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 38)
Vouchsafe to read the purpose of my coming, And suddenly resolve me in my suit.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 39)
Madam, will, if suddenly may.   You will the sooner that were away, For you'll prove perjured if you make me stay.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 40)
Did not dance with you in Brabant once?   Did not dance with you in Brabant once?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 41)
know you did.  How needless was it then To ask the question.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 42)
You must not be so quick.   'Tis long of you that spur me with such questions.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 43)
Your wit's too hot, it speeds too fast; 'twill tire.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 44)
Not till it leave the rider in the mire.   What time o' day?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 45)
The hour that fools should ask.  Now fair befall your mask.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 46)
Fair fall the face it covers.  And send you many lovers.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 47)
Amen, so you be none.  Nay, then, will be gone.   Madam, your father here doth intimate The payment of a hundred thousand crowns, Being but the one half of an entire sum Disbursed by my father in his wars.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 48)
But say that he or we, as neither have, Received that sum, yet there remains unpaid hundred thousand more, in surety of the which One part of Aquitaine is bound to us, Although not valued to the money's worth.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 49)
If then the King your father will restore But that one half which is unsatisfied, We will give up our right in Aquitaine, And hold fair friendship with his Majesty.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 50)
But that, it seems, he little purposeth; For here he doth demand to have repaid hundred thousand crowns, and not demands, On payment of a hundred thousand crowns, To have his title live in Aquitaine-- Which we much rather had depart withal, And have the money by our father lent, Than Aquitaine, so gelded as it is.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 51)
Dear Princess, were not his requests so far From reason's yielding, your fair self should make yielding 'gainst some reason in my breast, And go well satisfied to France again.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 52)
You do the King my father too much wrong, And wrong the reputation of your name, In so unseeming to confess receipt Of that which hath so faithfully been paid.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 53)
do protest never heard of it; And if you prove it, I'll repay it back Or yield up Aquitaine.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 54)
We arrest your word.-- Boyet, you can produce acquittances For such a sum from special officers Of Charles his father.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 55)
Satisfy me so.   So please your Grace, the packet is not come Where that and other specialties are bound.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 56)
Tomorrow you shall have a sight of them.   It shall suffice me; at which interview All liberal reason will yield unto.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 57)
Meantime receive such welcome at my hand As honor (without breach of honor) may Make tender of to thy true worthiness.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 58)
You may not come, fair princess, within my gates, But here without you shall be so received As you shall deem yourself lodged in my heart, Though so denied fair harbor in my house.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 59)
Your own good thoughts excuse me, and farewell. Tomorrow shall we visit you again.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 60)
Sweet health and fair desires consort your Grace.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 61)
Thy own wish wish thee in every place.    Lady, will commend you to my own heart.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 62)
Pray you, do my commendations. would be glad to see it.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 63)
would you heard it groan.  Is the fool sick?  Sick at the heart.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 64)
Alack, let it blood.  Would that do it good?  My physic says "ay.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 65)
"  Will you prick 't with your eye?  No point, with my knife.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 66)
Now God save thy life.  And yours from long living.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 67)
cannot stay thanksgiving.      Sir, pray you, a word.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 68)
What lady is that same?   The heir of Alanson, Katherine her name.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 69)
gallant lady, monsieur. Fare you well.      beseech you, a word.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 70)
What is she in the white?   woman sometimes, an you saw her in the light.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 71)
Perchance light in the light. desire her name.   She hath but one for herself; to desire that were a shame.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 72)
Pray you, sir, whose daughter?  Her mother's, have heard.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 73)
God's blessing on your beard!  Good sir, be not offended.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 74)
She is an heir of Falconbridge.  Nay, my choler is ended.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 75)
She is a most sweet lady.  Not unlike, sir, that may be.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 76)
What's her name in the cap?  Rosaline, by good hap.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 77)
Is she wedded or no?  To her will, sir, or so.  You are welcome, sir.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 78)
Adieu.  Farewell to me, sir, and welcome to you.    That last is Berowne, the merry madcap lord.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 79)
Not a word with him but a jest.  And every jest but a word.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 80)
It was well done of you to take him at his word.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 81)
was as willing to grapple as he was to board.   Two hot sheeps, marry.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 82)
And wherefore not ships? No sheep, sweet lamb, unless we feed on your lips.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 83)
You sheep and pasture. Shall that finish the jest?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 84)
So you grant pasture for me.  Not so, gentle beast, My lips are no common, though several they be.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 85)
Belonging to whom?  To my fortunes and me.   Good wits will be jangling; but, gentles, agree, This civil war of wits were much better used On Navarre and his bookmen, for here 'tis abused.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 86)
If my observation, which very seldom lies, By the heart's still rhetoric, disclosed wi' th' eyes, Deceive me not now, Navarre is infected.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 87)
With what?   With that which we lovers entitle "affected.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 88)
"  Your reason?   Why, all his behaviors did make their retire To the court of his eye, peeping thorough desire.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 89)
His heart like an agate with your print impressed, Proud with his form, in his eye pride expressed.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 90)
His tongue, all impatient to speak and not see, Did stumble with haste in his eyesight to be; All senses to that sense did make their repair, To feel only looking on fairest of fair.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 91)
Methought all his senses were locked in his eye, As jewels in crystal for some prince to buy, Who, tend'ring their own worth from where they were glassed, Did point you to buy them along as you passed.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 92)
His face's own margent did quote such amazes That all eyes saw his eyes enchanted with gazes.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 93)
I'll give you Aquitaine, and all that is his, An you give him for my sake but one loving kiss.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 94)
Come, to our pavilion. Boyet is disposed.   But to speak that in words which his eye hath disclosed.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 95)
only have made a mouth of his eye By adding a tongue which know will not lie.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 96)
Thou art an old lovemonger and speakest skillfully.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 97)
He is Cupid's grandfather, and learns news of him.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 98)
Then was Venus like her mother, for her father is but grim.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 99)
Do you hear, my mad wenches?  No.  What then, do you see?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 100)
Ay, our way to be gone.  You are too hard for me.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 0, Scene 101)
3       Warble, child, make passionate my sense of hearing.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 0)
Concolinel.  Sweet air. Go, tenderness of years.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 1)
Take this key, give enlargement to the swain, bring him festinately hither.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 2)
must employ him in a letter to my love.  Master, will you win your love with a French brawl?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 3)
How meanest thou? Brawling in French?  No, my complete master, but to jig off a tune at the tongue's end, canary to it with your feet, humor it with turning up your eyelids, sigh a note and sing a note, sometimes through the throat as if you swallowed love with singing love, sometimes through the nose as if you snuffed up love by smelling love; with your hat penthouse-like o'er the shop of your eyes, with your arms crossed on your thin-belly doublet like a rabbit on a spit; or your hands in your pocket like a man after the old painting; and keep not too long in one tune, but a snip and away.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 4)
These are compliments, these are humors; these betray nice wenches that would be betrayed without these, and make them men of note--do you note me?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 5)
--that most are affected to these.  How hast thou purchased this experience?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 6)
By my penny of observation.  But but  "The hobby-horse is forgot.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 7)
"  Call'st thou my love "hobby-horse"?  No, master.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 8)
The hobby-horse is but a colt, and your love perhaps a hackney.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 9)
--But have you forgot your love?  Almost had.  Negligent student, learn her by heart.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 10)
By heart and in heart, boy.  And out of heart, master.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 11)
All those three will prove.  What wilt thou prove?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 12)
man, if live; and this "by, in, and without," upon the instant: "by" heart you love her, because your heart cannot come by her; "in" heart you love her, because your heart is in love with her; and "out" of heart you love her, being out of heart that you cannot enjoy her.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 13)
am all these three.  And three times as much more,  and yet nothing at all.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 14)
Fetch hither the swain. He must carry me a letter.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 15)
message well sympathized--a horse to be ambassador for an ass.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 16)
Ha? Ha? What sayest thou?  Marry, sir, you must send the ass upon the horse, for he is very slow-gaited.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 17)
But go.  The way is but short. Away!  As swift as lead, sir.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 18)
Thy meaning, pretty ingenious? Is not lead a metal heavy, dull, and slow?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 19)
Minime, honest master, or rather, master, no.   say lead is slow.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 20)
You are too swift, sir, to say so. Is that lead slow which is fired from a gun?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 21)
Sweet smoke of rhetoric! He reputes me a cannon, and the bullet, that's he.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 22)
-- shoot thee at the swain.  Thump, then, and flee.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 23)
most acute juvenal, voluble and free of grace.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 24)
By thy favor, sweet welkin, must sigh in thy face.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 25)
Most rude melancholy, valor gives thee place. My herald is returned.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 26)
wonder, master! Here's a costard broken in a shin.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 27)
Some enigma, some riddle. Come, thy l'envoi begin.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 28)
No egma, no riddle, no l'envoi, no salve in the mail, sir.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 29)
sir, plantain, a plain plantain! No l'envoi, no l'envoi, no salve, sir, but a plantain.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 30)
By virtue, thou enforcest laughter; thy silly thought, my spleen.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 31)
The heaving of my lungs provokes me to ridiculous smiling.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 32)
pardon me, my stars! Doth the inconsiderate take salve for l'envoi, and the word l'envoi for a salve?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 33)
Do the wise think them other? Is not l'envoi a salve?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 34)
No, page, it is an epilogue or discourse to make plain Some obscure precedence that hath tofore been sain.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 35)
will example it: The fox, the ape, and the humble-bee Were still at odds, being but three.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 36)
There's the moral. Now the l'envoi.  will add the l'envoi.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 37)
Say the moral again.   The fox, the ape, and the humble-bee Were still at odds, being but three.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 38)
Until the goose came out of door And stayed the odds by adding four.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 39)
Now will begin your moral, and do you follow with my l'envoi.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 40)
The fox, the ape, and the humble-bee Were still at odds, being but three.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 41)
Until the goose came out of door, Staying the odds by adding four.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 42)
good l'envoi, ending in the goose. Would you desire more?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 43)
The boy hath sold him a bargain--a goose, that's flat.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 44)
-- Sir, your pennyworth is good, an your goose be fat.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 45)
To sell a bargain well is as cunning as fast and loose.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 46)
Let me see: a fat l'envoi--ay, that's a fat goose.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 47)
Come hither, come hither. How did this argument begin?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 48)
By saying that a costard was broken in a shin. Then called you for the l'envoi.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 49)
True, and for a plantain. Thus came your argument in.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 50)
Then the boy's fat l'envoi, the goose that you bought; and he ended the market.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 51)
But tell me, how was there a costard broken in a shin?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 52)
will tell you sensibly.  Thou hast no feeling of it, Mote.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 53)
will speak that l'envoi. Costard, running out, that was safely within, Fell over the threshold and broke my shin.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 54)
We will talk no more of this matter.  Till there be more matter in the shin.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 55)
Sirrah Costard, will enfranchise thee.  marry me to one Frances!(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 56)
smell some l'envoi, some goose, in this.  By my sweet soul, mean, setting thee at liberty, enfreedoming thy person.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 57)
Thou wert immured, restrained, captivated, bound.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 58)
True, true; and now you will be my purgation, and let me loose.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 59)
give thee thy liberty, set thee from durance, and, in lieu thereof, impose on thee nothing but this: bear this significant to the country maid Jaquenetta.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 60)
There is remuneration for the best ward of mine honor is rewarding my dependents.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 61)
--Mote, follow.  Like the sequel, Signior Costard, adieu.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 62)
My sweet ounce of man's flesh, my incony Jew! Now will look to his remuneration.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 63)
"Remuneration"! that's the Latin word for three farthings.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 64)
Three farthings--remuneration. "What's the price of this inkle?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 65)
" "One penny." "No, I'll give you a remuneration." Why, it carries it!(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 66)
Remuneration. Why, it is a fairer name than "French crown.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 67)
" will never buy and sell out of this word.     My good knave Costard, exceedingly well met.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 68)
Pray you, sir, how much carnation ribbon may a man buy for a remuneration?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 69)
What is a remuneration?  Marry, sir, halfpenny farthing.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 70)
Why then, three farthing worth of silk.  thank your Worship.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 71)
God be wi' you.   Stay, slave, must employ thee. As thou wilt win my favor, good my knave, Do one thing for me that shall entreat.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 72)
When would you have it done, sir?  This afternoon.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 73)
Well, will do it, sir. Fare you well.  Thou knowest not what it is.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 74)
shall know, sir, when have done it.  Why, villain, thou must know first.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 75)
will come to your Worship tomorrow morning.  It must be done this afternoon.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 76)
Hark, slave, it is but this: The Princess comes to hunt here in the park, And in her train there is a gentle lady.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 77)
When tongues speak sweetly, then they name her name, And Rosaline they call her.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 78)
Ask for her, And to her white hand see thou do commend This sealed-up counsel.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 79)
There's thy guerdon. Go.  Gardon.  sweet gardon! Better than remuneration, a 'levenpence farthing better!(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 80)
Most sweet gardon. will do it, sir, in print. Gardon!(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 81)
Remuneration!   And forsooth in love! that have been love's whip, very beadle to a humorous sigh, critic, nay, a nightwatch constable, domineering pedant o'er the boy, Than whom no mortal so magnificent.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 82)
This wimpled, whining, purblind, wayward boy, This Signior Junior, giant dwarf, Dan Cupid, Regent of love rhymes, lord of folded arms, Th' anointed sovereign of sighs and groans, Liege of all loiterers and malcontents, Dread prince of plackets, king of codpieces, Sole imperator and great general Of trotting paritors--O my little heart!(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 83)
And to be a corporal of his field And wear his colors like a tumbler's hoop!(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 84)
What? love, sue, seek a wife? woman, that is like a German clock, Still a-repairing, ever out of frame, And never going aright, being a watch, But being watched that it may still go right.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 85)
Nay, to be perjured, which is worst of all. And, among three, to love the worst of all, whitely wanton with a velvet brow, With two pitch-balls stuck in her face for eyes.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 86)
Ay, and by heaven, one that will do the deed Though Argus were her eunuch and her guard.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 87)
And to sigh for her, to watch for her, To pray for her!(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 88)
Go to. It is a plague That Cupid will impose for my neglect Of his almighty dreadful little might.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 89)
Well, will love, write, sigh, pray, sue, groan. Some men must love my lady, and some Joan.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 9, Scene 90)
4         Was that the King that spurred his horse so hard Against the steep uprising of the hill?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 0)
know not, but think it was not he.   Whoe'er he was, he showed a mounting mind.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 1)
-- Well, lords, today we shall have our dispatch. Or Saturday we will return to France.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 2)
-- Then, forester, my friend, where is the bush That we must stand and play the murderer in?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 3)
Hereby, upon the edge of yonder coppice, stand where you may make the fairest shoot.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 4)
thank my beauty, am fair that shoot, And thereupon thou speakst "the fairest shoot.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 5)
"   Pardon me, madam, for meant not so.   What, what?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 6)
First praise me, and again say no? short-lived pride.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 7)
Not fair? Alack, for woe!   Yes, madam, fair.  Nay, never paint me now.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 8)
Where fair is not, praise cannot mend the brow. Here, good my glass, take this for telling true.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 9)
Fair payment for foul words is more than due.   Nothing but fair is that which you inherit.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 10)
See, see, my beauty will be saved by merit. heresy in fair, fit for these days!(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 11)
giving hand, though foul, shall have fair praise.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 12)
But come, the bow.  Now mercy goes to kill, And shooting well is then accounted ill.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 13)
Thus will save my credit in the shoot: Not wounding, pity would not let me do 't; If wounding, then it was to show my skill, That more for praise than purpose meant to kill.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 14)
And out of question so it is sometimes: Glory grows guilty of detested crimes, When for fame's sake, for praise, an outward part, We bend to that the working of the heart; As for praise alone now seek to spill The poor deer's blood, that my heart means no ill.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 15)
Do not curst wives hold that self sovereignty Only for praise' sake when they strive to be Lords o'er their lords?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 16)
Only for praise; and praise we may afford To any lady that subdues a lord.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 17)
Here comes a member of the commonwealth.  God dig-you-den all!(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 18)
Pray you, which is the head lady?  Thou shalt know her, fellow, by the rest that have no heads.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 19)
Which is the greatest lady, the highest?  The thickest and the tallest.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 20)
The thickest and the tallest: it is so, truth is truth.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 21)
An your waist, mistress, were as slender as my wit, One o' these maids' girdles for your waist should be fit.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 22)
Are not you the chief woman? You are the thickest here.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 23)
What's your will, sir? What's your will?  have a letter from Monsieur Berowne to one Lady Rosaline.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 24)
thy letter, thy letter! He's a good friend of mine.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 25)
Stand aside, good bearer.--Boyet, you can carve. Break up this capon.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 26)
am bound to serve. This letter is mistook; it importeth none here.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 27)
It is writ to Jaquenetta.  We will read it, swear.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 28)
Break the neck of the wax, and everyone give ear.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 29)
By heaven, that thou art fair is most infallible, true that thou art beauteous, truth itself that thou art lovely.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 30)
More fairer than fair, beautiful than beauteous, truer than truth itself, have commiseration on thy heroical vassal.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 31)
The magnanimous and most illustrate King Cophetua set eye upon the pernicious and indubitate beggar Zenelophon; and he it was that might rightly say "Veni, vidi, vici," which to annothanize in the vulgar base and obscure vulgar!(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 32)
) videlicet, "He came, see, and overcame": He came, one; see, two; overcame, three.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 33)
Who came? The King. Why did he come? To see. Why did he see?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 34)
To overcome. To whom came he? To the beggar. What saw he?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 35)
The beggar. Who overcame he? The beggar. The conclusion is victory.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 36)
On whose side? The King's. The captive is enriched.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 37)
On whose side? The beggar's. The catastrophe is a nuptial.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 38)
On whose side? The King's--no, on both in one, or one in both.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 39)
am the King, for so stands the comparison; thou the beggar, for so witnesseth thy lowliness.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 40)
Shall command thy love? may. Shall enforce thy love?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 41)
could. Shall entreat thy love? will. What shalt thou exchange for rags?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 42)
Robes. For tittles? Titles. For thyself? Me. Thus expecting thy reply, profane my lips on thy foot, my eyes on thy picture, and my heart on thy every part.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 43)
Thine, in the dearest design of industry, Don Adriano de Armado.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 44)
Thus dost thou hear the Nemean lion roar 'Gainst thee, thou lamb, that standest as his prey.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 45)
Submissive fall his princely feet before, And he from forage will incline to play.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 46)
But if thou strive, poor soul, what art thou then?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 47)
Food for his rage, repasture for his den.   What plume of feathers is he that indited this letter?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 48)
What vane? What weathercock? Did you ever hear better?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 49)
am much deceived but remember the style.   Else your memory is bad, going o'er it erewhile.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 50)
This Armado is a Spaniard that keeps here in court, phantasime, a Monarcho, and one that makes sport To the Prince and his bookmates.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 51)
Thou, fellow, a word. Who gave thee this letter?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 52)
told you: my lord.   To whom shouldst thou give it?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 53)
From my lord to my lady.  From which lord to which lady?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 54)
From my Lord Berowne, a good master of mine, To a lady of France that he called Rosaline.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 55)
Thou hast mistaken his letter. Come, lords, away.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 56)
Here, sweet, put up this; 'twill be thine another day.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 57)
Forester exit. Boyet, Rosaline, Maria,    Who is the shooter?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 58)
Who is the shooter?  Shall teach you to know?   Ay, my continent of beauty.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 59)
Why, she that bears the bow. Finely put off.   My lady goes to kill horns, but if thou marry, Hang me by the neck if horns that year miscarry.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 60)
Finely put on.   Well, then, am the shooter.  And who is your deer?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 61)
If we choose by the horns, yourself come not near.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 62)
Finely put on, indeed.   You still wrangle with her, Boyet, and she strikes at the brow.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 63)
But she herself is hit lower. Have hit her now?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 64)
Shall come upon thee with an old saying, that was a man when King Pippen of France was a little boy, as touching the hit it?(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 65)
So may answer thee with one as old, that was a woman when Queen Guinover of Britain was a little wench, as touching the hit it.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 66)
Thou canst not hit it, hit it, hit it, Thou canst not hit it, my good man.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 67)
An cannot, cannot, cannot, An cannot, another can.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 68)
By my troth, most pleasant. How both did fit it!(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 69)
mark marvelous well shot, for they both did hit it.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 70)
mark! mark but that mark. mark," says my lady. Let the mark have a prick in 't to mete at, if it may be.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 71)
Wide o' the bow hand! faith, your hand is out.   Indeed, he must shoot nearer, or he'll ne'er hit the clout.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 72)
An if my hand be out, then belike your hand is in.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 73)
Then will she get the upshoot by cleaving the pin.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 74)
Come, come, you talk greasily. Your lips grow foul.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 75)
She's too hard for you at pricks, sir. Challenge her to bowl.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 76)
fear too much rubbing. Good night, my good owl.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 77)
By my soul, a swain, a most simple clown. Lord, Lord, how the ladies and have put him down.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 78)
my troth, most sweet jests, most incony vulgar wit, When it comes so smoothly off, so obscenely, as it were, so fit.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 79)
Armado o' th' one side, a most dainty man! To see him walk before a lady and to bear her fan.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 80)
To see him kiss his hand, and how most sweetly he will swear.(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 81)
And his page o' t' other side, that handful of wit!(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 82)
Ah heavens, it is a most pathetical nit.  Sola, sola!(Love's Labor's Lost, Act 18, Scene 83)
Save thee, Curan.  And you, sir. have been with your father and given him notice that the Duke of Cornwall and Regan his duchess will be here with him this night.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 0)
How comes that?  Nay, know not. You have heard of the news abroad?(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 1)
--I mean the whispered ones, for they are yet but ear-kissing arguments.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 2)
Not Pray you, what are they?  Have you heard of no likely wars toward 'twixt the dukes of Cornwall and Albany?(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 3)
Not a word.  You may do, then, in time. Fare you well, sir.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 4)
The Duke be here tonight? The better, best. This weaves itself perforce into my business.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 5)
My father hath set guard to take my brother, And have one thing of a queasy question Which must act.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 6)
Briefness and fortune work!-- Brother, a word. Descend.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 7)
Brother, say!    My father watches. sir, fly this place!(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 8)
Intelligence is given where you are hid. You have now the good advantage of the night.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 9)
Have you not spoken 'gainst the Duke of Cornwall?(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 10)
He's coming hither, now, i' th' night, i' th' haste, And Regan with him.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 11)
Have you nothing said Upon his party 'gainst the Duke of Albany?(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 12)
Advise yourself.  am sure on 't, not a word.   hear my father coming.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 13)
Pardon me. In cunning must draw my sword upon you.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 14)
Draw. Seem to defend yourself. Now, quit you well.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 15)
Yield! Come before my father! Light, hoa, here! Fly, brother.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 16)
--Torches, torches! --So, farewell. Some blood drawn on me would beget opinion Of my more fierce endeavor.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 17)
have seen drunkards Do more than this in sport. Father, father!(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 18)
Stop, stop! No help?     Now, Edmund, where's the villain?(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 19)
Here stood he in the dark, his sharp sword out, Mumbling of wicked charms, conjuring the moon To stand auspicious mistress.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 20)
But where is he?   Look, sir, bleed.  Where is the villain, Edmund?(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 21)
Fled this way, sir, when by no means he could--   Pursue him, ho!(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 22)
Go after.  By no means what?   Persuade me to the murder of your Lordship, But that told him the revenging gods 'Gainst parricides did all the thunder bend, Spoke with how manifold and strong a bond The child was bound to th' father--sir, in fine, Seeing how loathly opposite stood To his unnatural purpose, in fell motion With his prepared sword he charges home My unprovided body, lanced mine arm; And when he saw my best alarumed spirits, Bold in the quarrel's right, roused to th' encounter, Or whether ghasted by the noise made, Full suddenly he fled.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 23)
Let him fly far! Not in this land shall he remain uncaught, And found--dispatch.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 24)
The noble duke my master, My worthy arch and patron, comes tonight.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 25)
By his authority will proclaim it That he which finds him shall deserve our thanks, Bringing the murderous coward to the stake; He that conceals him, death.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 26)
When dissuaded him from his intent And found him pight to do it, with curst speech threatened to discover him.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 27)
He replied "Thou unpossessing bastard, dost thou think If would stand against thee, would the reposal Of any trust, virtue, or worth in thee Make thy words faithed?(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 28)
No. What should deny-- As this would, though thou didst produce My very character--I'd turn it all To thy suggestion, plot, and damned practice.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 29)
And thou must make a dullard of the world If they not thought the profits of my death Were very pregnant and potential spurs To make thee seek it.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 30)
"  strange and fastened villain! Would he deny his letter, said he?(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 31)
never got him. Hark, the Duke's trumpets. know not why he comes.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 32)
All ports I'll bar. The villain shall not 'scape.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 33)
The Duke must grant me that. Besides, his picture will send far and near, that all the kingdom May have due note of him.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 34)
And of my land, Loyal and natural boy, I'll work the means To make thee capable.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 35)
How now, my noble friend? Since came hither, Which can call but now, have heard strange news.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 36)
If it be true, all vengeance comes too short Which can pursue th' offender.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 37)
How dost, my lord?   madam, my old heart is cracked; it's cracked.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 38)
What, did my father's godson seek your life? He whom my father named, your Edgar?(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 39)
lady, lady, shame would have it hid!   Was he not companion with the riotous knights That tended upon my father?(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 40)
know not, madam. 'Tis too bad, too bad.   Yes, madam, he was of that consort.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 41)
No marvel, then, though he were ill affected. 'Tis they have put him on the old man's death, To have th' expense and waste of his revenues.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 42)
have this present evening from my sister Been well informed of them, and with such cautions That if they come to sojourn at my house I'll not be there.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 43)
Nor assure thee, Regan.-- Edmund, hear that you have shown your father childlike office.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 44)
It was my duty, sir.   He did bewray his practice, and received This hurt you see striving to apprehend him.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 45)
Is he pursued?  Ay, my good lord.   If he be taken, he shall never more Be feared of doing harm.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 46)
Make your own purpose, How in my strength you please.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 47)
--For you, Edmund, Whose virtue and obedience doth this instant So much commend itself, you shall be ours.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 48)
Natures of such deep trust we shall much need. You we first seize on.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 49)
shall serve you, sir, Truly, however else.  For him thank your Grace.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 50)
You know not why we came to visit you--   Thus out of season, threading dark-eyed night.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 51)
Occasions, noble Gloucester, of some poise, Wherein we must have use of your advice.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 52)
Our father he hath writ, so hath our sister, Of differences, which best thought it fit To answer from our home.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 53)
The several messengers From hence attend dispatch.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 54)
Our good old friend, Lay comforts to your bosom and bestow Your needful counsel to our businesses, Which craves the instant use.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 55)
serve you, madam. Your Graces are right welcome.(King Lear, Act 0, Scene 56)
Good dawning to thee, friend. Art of this house?(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 0)
Ay.  Where may we set our horses?  th' mire.  Prithee, if thou lov'st me, tell me.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 1)
love thee not.  Why then, care not for thee.  If had thee in Lipsbury pinfold, would make thee care for me.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 2)
Why dost thou use me thus? know thee not.  Fellow, know thee.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 3)
What dost thou know me for?  knave, a rascal, an eater of broken meats; a base, proud, shallow, beggarly, three-suited, hundred-pound, filthy worsted-stocking knave; a lily-livered, action-taking, whoreson, glass-gazing, superserviceable, finical rogue; one-trunk-inheriting slave; one that wouldst be a bawd in way of good service, and art nothing but the composition of a knave, beggar, coward, pander, and the son and heir of a mongrel bitch; one whom will beat into clamorous whining if thou deny'st the least syllable of thy addition.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 4)
Why, what a monstrous fellow art thou thus to rail on one that is neither known of thee nor knows thee!(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 5)
What a brazen-faced varlet art thou to deny thou knowest me!(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 6)
Is it two days ago since tripped up thy heels and beat thee before the King?(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 7)
Draw, you rogue, for though it be night, yet the moon shines.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 8)
I'll make a sop o' th' moonshine of you, you whoreson, cullionly barbermonger.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 9)
Draw!  Away! have nothing to do with thee.  Draw, you rascal!(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 10)
You come with letters against the King and take Vanity the puppet's part against the royalty of her father.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 11)
Draw, you rogue, or I'll so carbonado your shanks!(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 12)
Draw, you rascal! Come your ways.  Help, ho! Murder!(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 13)
Help!  Strike, you slave! Stand, rogue! Stand, you neat slave!(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 14)
Strike!  Help, ho! Murder, murder!      How now, what's the matter?(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 15)
Part!  With you, goodman boy, if you please. Come, I'll flesh you.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 16)
Come on, young master.   Weapons? Arms? What's the matter here?(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 17)
Keep peace, upon your lives! He dies that strikes again.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 18)
What is the matter?   The messengers from our sister and the King.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 19)
What is your difference? Speak.  am scarce in breath, my lord.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 20)
No marvel, you have so bestirred your valor. You cowardly rascal, nature disclaims in thee; a tailor made thee.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 21)
Thou art a strange fellow. tailor make a man?  tailor, sir.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 22)
stonecutter or a painter could not have made him so ill, though they had been but two years o' th' trade.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 23)
Speak yet, how grew your quarrel?  This ancient ruffian, sir, whose life have spared at suit of his gray beard--  Thou whoreson zed, thou unnecessary letter!(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 24)
--My lord, if you will give me leave, will tread this unbolted villain into mortar and daub the wall of a jakes with him.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 25)
--Spare my gray beard, you wagtail?  Peace, sirrah!(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 26)
You beastly knave, know you no reverence?   Yes, sir, but anger hath a privilege.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 27)
Why art thou angry?   That such a slave as this should wear a sword, Who wears no honesty.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 28)
Such smiling rogues as these, Like rats, oft bite the holy cords atwain Which are too intrinse t' unloose; smooth every passion That in the natures of their lords rebel-- Being oil to fire, snow to the colder moods-- Renege, affirm, and turn their halcyon beaks With every gale and vary of their masters, Knowing naught, like dogs, but following.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 29)
-- plague upon your epileptic visage! Smile you my speeches, as were a fool?(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 30)
Goose, if had you upon Sarum plain, I'd drive you cackling home to Camelot.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 31)
What, art thou mad, old fellow?  How fell you out?(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 32)
Say that.   No contraries hold more antipathy Than and such a knave.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 33)
Why dost thou call him "knave"? What is his fault?(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 34)
His countenance likes me not.   No more, perchance, does mine, nor his, nor hers.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 35)
Sir, 'tis my occupation to be plain: have seen better faces in my time Than stands on any shoulder that see Before me at this instant.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 36)
This is some fellow Who, having been praised for bluntness, doth affect saucy roughness and constrains the garb Quite from his nature.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 37)
He cannot flatter, he. An honest mind and plain, he must speak truth!(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 38)
An they will take it, so; if not, he's plain. These kind of knaves know, which in this plainness Harbor more craft and more corrupter ends Than twenty silly-ducking observants That stretch their duties nicely.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 39)
Sir, in good faith, in sincere verity, Under th' allowance of your great aspect, Whose influence, like the wreath of radiant fire On flick'ring Phoebus' front--  What mean'st by this?(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 40)
To go out of my dialect, which you discommend so much.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 41)
know, sir, am no flatterer. He that beguiled you in a plain accent was a plain knave, which for my part will not be, though should win your displeasure to entreat me to 't.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 42)
What was th' offense you gave him?  never gave him any.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 43)
It pleased the King his master very late To strike at me, upon his misconstruction; When he, compact, and flattering his displeasure, Tripped me behind; being down, insulted, railed, And put upon him such a deal of man That worthied him, got praises of the King For him attempting who was self-subdued; And in the fleshment of this dread exploit, Drew on me here again.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 44)
None of these rogues and cowards But Ajax is their fool.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 45)
Fetch forth the stocks.-- You stubborn ancient knave, you reverent braggart, We'll teach you.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 46)
Sir, am too old to learn. Call not your stocks for me.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 47)
serve the King, On whose employment was sent to you.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 48)
You shall do small respect, show too bold malice Against the grace and person of my master, Stocking his messenger.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 49)
Fetch forth the stocks.--As have life and honor, There shall he sit till noon.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 50)
Till noon? Till night, my lord, and all night, too.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 51)
Why, madam, if were your father's dog, You should not use me so.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 52)
Sir, being his knave, will.   This is a fellow of the selfsame color Our sister speaks of.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 53)
--Come, bring away the stocks.    Let me beseech your Grace not to do so.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 54)
His fault is much, and the good king his master Will check him for 't.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 55)
Your purposed low correction Is such as basest and contemned'st wretches For pilf'rings and most common trespasses Are punished with.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 56)
The King must take it ill That he, so slightly valued in his messenger, Should have him thus restrained.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 57)
I'll answer that.   My sister may receive it much more worse To have her gentleman abused, assaulted For following her affairs.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 58)
--Put in his legs.   Come, my good lord, away.    am sorry for thee, friend.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 59)
'Tis the Duke's pleasure, Whose disposition all the world well knows Will not be rubbed nor stopped.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 60)
I'll entreat for thee.   Pray, do not, sir. have watched and traveled hard.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 61)
Some time shall sleep out; the rest I'll whistle.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 62)
good man's fortune may grow out at heels. Give you good morrow.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 63)
The Duke's to blame in this. 'Twill be ill taken.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 64)
Good king, that must approve the common saw, Thou out of heaven's benediction com'st To the warm sun.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 65)
Approach, thou beacon to this under globe, That by thy comfortable beams may Peruse this letter.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 66)
Nothing almost sees miracles But misery. know 'tis from Cordelia, Who hath most fortunately been informed Of my obscured course, and shall find time From this enormous state, seeking to give Losses their remedies.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 67)
All weary and o'erwatched, Take vantage, heavy eyes, not to behold This shameful lodging.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 68)
Fortune, good night. Smile once more; turn thy wheel.(King Lear, Act 1, Scene 69)
heard myself proclaimed, And by the happy hollow of a tree Escaped the hunt.(King Lear, Act 2, Scene 0)
No port is free; no place That guard and most unusual vigilance Does not attend my taking.(King Lear, Act 2, Scene 1)
Whiles may 'scape, will preserve myself, and am bethought To take the basest and most poorest shape That ever penury in contempt of man Brought near to beast.(King Lear, Act 2, Scene 2)
My face I'll grime with filth, Blanket my loins, elf all my hairs in knots, And with presented nakedness outface The winds and persecutions of the sky.(King Lear, Act 2, Scene 3)
The country gives me proof and precedent Of Bedlam beggars who with roaring voices Strike in their numbed and mortified arms Pins, wooden pricks, nails, sprigs of rosemary, And, with this horrible object, from low farms, Poor pelting villages, sheepcotes, and mills, Sometime with lunatic bans, sometime with prayers, Enforce their charity.(King Lear, Act 2, Scene 4)
"Poor Turlygod! Poor Tom!" That's something yet. "Edgar" nothing am.(King Lear, Act 2, Scene 5)
'Tis strange that they should so depart from home And not send back my messenger.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 0)
As learned, The night before there was no purpose in them Of this remove.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 1)
Hail to thee, noble master.  Ha? Mak'st thou this shame thy pastime?(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 2)
No, my lord.  Ha, ha, he wears cruel garters. Horses are tied by the heads, dogs and bears by th' neck, monkeys by th' loins, and men by th' legs.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 3)
When a man's overlusty at legs, then he wears wooden netherstocks.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 4)
What's he that hath so much thy place mistook To set thee here?(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 5)
It is both he and she, Your son and daughter.  No.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 6)
Yes.  No, say.  say yea.  By Jupiter, swear no.  KENTBy Juno, swear ay.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 7)
They durst not do 't. They could not, would not do 't.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 8)
'Tis worse than murder To do upon respect such violent outrage.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 9)
Resolve me with all modest haste which way Thou might'st deserve or they impose this usage, Coming from us.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 10)
My lord, when at their home did commend your Highness' letters to them, Ere was risen from the place that showed My duty kneeling, came there a reeking post, Stewed in his haste, half breathless, panting forth From Goneril his mistress salutations; Delivered letters, spite of intermission, Which presently they read; on whose contents They summoned up their meiny, straight took horse, Commanded me to follow and attend The leisure of their answer, gave me cold looks; And meeting here the other messenger, Whose welcome, perceived, had poisoned mine, Being the very fellow which of late Displayed so saucily against your Highness, Having more man than wit about me, drew.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 11)
He raised the house with loud and coward cries. Your son and daughter found this trespass worth The shame which here it suffers.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 12)
Winter's not gone yet if the wild geese fly that way.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 13)
Fathers that wear rags Do make their children blind, But fathers that bear bags Shall see their children kind.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 14)
Fortune, that arrant whore, Ne'er turns the key to th' poor.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 15)
But, for all this, thou shalt have as many dolors for thy daughters as thou canst tell in a year.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 16)
how this mother swells up toward my heart! Hysterica passio, down, thou climbing sorrow!(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 17)
Thy element's below.--Where is this daughter?  With the Earl, sir, here within.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 18)
Follow me not. Stay here.   Made you no more offense but what you speak of?(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 19)
None. How chance the King comes with so small a number?(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 20)
An thou hadst been set i' th' stocks for that question, thou 'dst well deserved it.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 21)
Why, Fool?  We'll set thee to school to an ant to teach thee there's no laboring i' th' winter.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 22)
All that follow their noses are led by their eyes but blind men, and there's not a nose among twenty but can smell him that's stinking.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 23)
Let go thy hold when a great wheel runs down a hill lest it break thy neck with following; but the great one that goes upward, let him draw thee after.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 24)
When a wise man gives thee better counsel, give me mine again.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 25)
would have none but knaves follow it, since a Fool gives it.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 26)
That sir which serves and seeks for gain, And follows but for form, Will pack when it begins to rain And leave thee in the storm.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 27)
But will tarry; the Fool will stay, And let the wise man fly.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 28)
The knave turns fool that runs away; The Fool no knave, perdie.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 29)
Where learned you this, Fool?  Not i' th' stocks, fool.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 30)
Deny to speak with me? They are sick? They are weary?(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 31)
They have traveled all the night? Mere fetches, The images of revolt and flying off.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 32)
Fetch me a better answer.  My dear lord, You know the fiery quality of the Duke, How unremovable and fixed he is In his own course.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 33)
Vengeance, plague, death, confusion! "Fiery"? What "quality"?(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 34)
Why Gloucester, Gloucester, I'd speak with the Duke of Cornwall and his wife.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 35)
Well, my good lord, have informed them so.   "Informed them"?(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 36)
Dost thou understand me, man?  Ay, my good lord.   The King would speak with Cornwall.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 37)
The dear father Would with his daughter speak, commands, tends service.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 38)
Are they "informed" of this? My breath and blood!(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 39)
"Fiery"? The "fiery" duke? Tell the hot duke that-- No, but not yet.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 40)
Maybe he is not well. Infirmity doth still neglect all office Whereto our health is bound.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 41)
We are not ourselves When nature, being oppressed, commands the mind To suffer with the body.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 42)
I'll forbear, And am fallen out with my more headier will, To take the indisposed and sickly fit For the sound man.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 43)
Death on my state! Wherefore Should he sit here?(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 44)
This act persuades me That this remotion of the Duke and her Is practice only.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 45)
Give me my servant forth. Go tell the Duke and 's wife I'd speak with them.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 46)
Now, presently, bid them come forth and hear me, Or at their chamber door I'll beat the drum Till it cry sleep to death.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 47)
would have all well betwixt you.    me, my heart, my rising heart!(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 48)
But down!  Cry to it, nuncle, as the cockney did to the eels when she put 'em i' th' paste alive.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 49)
She knapped 'em o' th' coxcombs with a stick and cried "Down, wantons, down!(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 50)
" 'Twas her brother that in pure kindness to his horse buttered his hay.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 51)
Good morrow to you both.  Hail to your Grace.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 52)
am glad to see your Highness.   Regan, think you are.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 53)
know what reason have to think so: if thou shouldst not be glad, would divorce me from thy mother's tomb, Sepulch'ring an adult'ress.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 54)
are you free? Some other time for that.--Beloved Regan, Thy sister's naught.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 55)
Regan, she hath tied Sharp-toothed unkindness, like a vulture, here.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 56)
can scarce speak to thee. Thou 'lt not believe With how depraved a quality--O Regan!(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 57)
pray you, sir, take patience. have hope You less know how to value her desert Than she to scant her duty.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 58)
Say? How is that?   cannot think my sister in the least Would fail her obligation.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 59)
If, sir, perchance She have restrained the riots of your followers, 'Tis on such ground and to such wholesome end As clears her from all blame.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 60)
My curses on her.  sir, you are old. Nature in you stands on the very verge Of his confine.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 61)
You should be ruled and led By some discretion that discerns your state Better than you yourself.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 62)
Therefore, pray you That to our sister you do make return.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 63)
Say you have wronged her.  Ask her forgiveness? Do you but mark how this becomes the house:  "Dear daughter, confess that am old.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 64)
Age is unnecessary. On my knees beg That you'll vouchsafe me raiment, bed, and food.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 65)
"   Good sir, no more. These are unsightly tricks.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 66)
Return you to my sister.  Never, Regan. She hath abated me of half my train, Looked black upon me, struck me with her tongue Most serpentlike upon the very heart.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 67)
All the stored vengeances of heaven fall On her ingrateful top!(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 68)
Strike her young bones, You taking airs, with lameness!(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 69)
Fie, sir, fie!   You nimble lightnings, dart your blinding flames Into her scornful eyes!(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 70)
Infect her beauty, You fen-sucked fogs drawn by the powerful sun To fall and blister!(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 71)
the blest gods! So will you wish on me When the rash mood is on.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 72)
No, Regan, thou shalt never have my curse. Thy tender-hefted nature shall not give Thee o'er to harshness.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 73)
Her eyes are fierce, but thine Do comfort and not burn.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 74)
'Tis not in thee To grudge my pleasures, to cut off my train, To bandy hasty words, to scant my sizes, And, in conclusion, to oppose the bolt Against my coming in.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 75)
Thou better know'st The offices of nature, bond of childhood, Effects of courtesy, dues of gratitude.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 76)
Thy half o' th' kingdom hast thou not forgot, Wherein thee endowed.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 77)
Good sir, to th' purpose.    Who put my man i' th' stocks?(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 78)
What trumpet's that?   know 't--my sister's. This approves her letter, That she would soon be here.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 79)
Is your lady come?   This is a slave whose easy-borrowed pride Dwells in the fickle grace of her he follows.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 80)
-- Out, varlet, from my sight!  What means your Grace?(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 81)
Who stocked my servant? Regan, have good hope Thou didst not know on 't.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 82)
Who comes here? heavens, If you do love old men, if your sweet sway Allow obedience, if you yourselves are old, Make it your cause.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 83)
Send down and take my part. Art not ashamed to look upon this beard?(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 84)
Regan, will you take her by the hand?   Why not by th' hand, sir?(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 85)
How have offended? All's not offense that indiscretion finds And dotage terms so.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 86)
sides, you are too tough! Will you yet hold?--How came my man i' th' stocks?(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 87)
set him there, sir, but his own disorders Deserved much less advancement.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 88)
You? Did you?   pray you, father, being weak, seem so.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 89)
If till the expiration of your month You will return and sojourn with my sister, Dismissing half your train, come then to me.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 90)
am now from home and out of that provision Which shall be needful for your entertainment.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 91)
Return to her? And fifty men dismissed? No! Rather abjure all roofs, and choose To wage against the enmity o' th' air, To be a comrade with the wolf and owl, Necessity's sharp pinch.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 92)
Return with her? Why the hot-blooded France, that dowerless took Our youngest born--I could as well be brought To knee his throne and, squire-like, pension beg To keep base life afoot.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 93)
Return with her? Persuade me rather to be slave and sumpter To this detested groom.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 94)
At your choice, sir.   prithee, daughter, do not make me mad.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 95)
will not trouble thee, my child. Farewell. We'll no more meet, no more see one another.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 96)
But yet thou art my flesh, my blood, my daughter, Or, rather, a disease that's in my flesh, Which must needs call mine.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 97)
Thou art a boil, plague-sore or embossed carbuncle In my corrupted blood.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 98)
But I'll not chide thee. Let shame come when it will; do not call it.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 99)
do not bid the thunder-bearer shoot, Nor tell tales of thee to high-judging Jove.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 100)
Mend when thou canst. Be better at thy leisure. can be patient.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 101)
can stay with Regan, and my hundred knights.  Not altogether so.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 102)
looked not for you yet, nor am provided For your fit welcome.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 103)
Give ear, sir, to my sister, For those that mingle reason with your passion Must be content to think you old, and so-- But she knows what she does.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 104)
Is this well spoken?   dare avouch it, sir. What, fifty followers?(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 105)
Is it not well? What should you need of more? Yea, or so many, sith that both charge and danger Speak 'gainst so great a number?(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 106)
How in one house Should many people under two commands Hold amity?(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 107)
'Tis hard, almost impossible.   Why might not you, my lord, receive attendance From those that she calls servants, or from mine?(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 108)
Why not, my lord? If then they chanced to slack you, We could control them.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 109)
If you will come to me (For now spy a danger), entreat you To bring but five-and-twenty.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 110)
To no more Will give place or notice.  gave you all--  And in good time you gave it.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 111)
Made you my guardians, my depositaries, But kept a reservation to be followed With such a number.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 112)
What, must come to you With five-and-twenty? Regan, said you so?(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 113)
And speak 't again, my lord. No more with me.   Those wicked creatures yet do look well-favored When others are more wicked.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 114)
Not being the worst Stands in some rank of praise.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 115)
I'll go with thee. Thy fifty yet doth double five-and-twenty, And thou art twice her love.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 116)
Hear me, my lord. What need you five-and-twenty, ten, or five, To follow in a house where twice so many Have a command to tend you?(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 117)
What need one?   reason not the need! Our basest beggars Are in the poorest thing superfluous.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 118)
Allow not nature more than nature needs, Man's life is cheap as beast's.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 119)
Thou art a lady; If only to go warm were gorgeous, Why, nature needs not what thou gorgeous wear'st, Which scarcely keeps thee warm.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 120)
But, for true need-- You heavens, give me that patience, patience need!(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 121)
You see me here, you gods, a poor old man As full of grief as age, wretched in both.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 122)
If it be you that stirs these daughters' hearts Against their father, fool me not so much To bear it tamely.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 123)
Touch me with noble anger, And let not women's weapons, water drops, Stain my man's cheeks.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 124)
--No, you unnatural hags, will have such revenges on you both That all the world shall--I will do such things-- What they are yet know not, but they shall be The terrors of the Earth!(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 125)
You think I'll weep. No, I'll not weep. have full cause of weeping, but this heart  Shall break into a hundred thousand flaws Or ere I'll weep.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 126)
--O Fool, shall go mad!    Let us withdraw. 'Twill be a storm.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 127)
This house is little. The old man and 's people Cannot be well bestowed.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 128)
'Tis his own blame hath put himself from rest, And must needs taste his folly.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 129)
For his particular, I'll receive him gladly, But not one follower.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 130)
So am purposed. Where is my lord of Gloucester?(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 131)
Followed the old man forth.    He is returned.  The King is in high rage.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 132)
Whither is he going?   He calls to horse, but will know not whither.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 133)
'Tis best to give him way. He leads himself.   My lord, entreat him by no means to stay.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 134)
Alack, the night comes on, and the high winds Do sorely ruffle.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 135)
For many miles about There's scarce a bush.  sir, to willful men The injuries that they themselves procure Must be their schoolmasters.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 136)
Shut up your doors. He is attended with a desperate train, And what they may incense him to, being apt To have his ear abused, wisdom bids fear.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 137)
Shut up your doors, my lord. 'Tis a wild night.(King Lear, Act 3, Scene 138)
How goes the night, boy?   The moon is down. have not heard the clock.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 0)
And she goes down at twelve.  take 't 'tis later, sir.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 1)
Hold, take my sword. There's husbandry in heaven; Their candles are all out.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 2)
Take thee that too. heavy summons lies like lead upon me, And yet would not sleep.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 3)
Merciful powers, Restrain in me the cursed thoughts that nature Gives way to in repose.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 4)
Give me my sword.--Who's there?  friend.   What, sir, not yet at rest?(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 5)
The King's abed. He hath been in unusual pleasure, and Sent forth great largess to your offices.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 6)
This diamond he greets your wife withal, By the name of most kind hostess, and shut up In measureless content.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 7)
Being unprepared, Our will became the servant to defect, Which else should free have wrought.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 8)
All's well. dreamt last night of the three Weird Sisters.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 9)
To you they have showed some truth.  think not of them.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 10)
Yet, when we can entreat an hour to serve, We would spend it in some words upon that business, If you would grant the time.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 11)
At your kind'st leisure.   If you shall cleave to my consent, when 'tis, It shall make honor for you.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 12)
So lose none In seeking to augment it, but still keep My bosom franchised and allegiance clear, shall be counseled.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 13)
Good repose the while.  Thanks, sir. The like to you.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 14)
Go bid thy mistress, when my drink is ready, She strike upon the bell.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 15)
Get thee to bed.  Is this a dagger which see before me, The handle toward my hand?(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 16)
Come, let me clutch thee. have thee not, and yet see thee still.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 17)
Art thou not, fatal vision, sensible To feeling as to sight?(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 18)
Or art thou but dagger of the mind, a false creation Proceeding from the heat-oppressed brain?(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 19)
see thee yet, in form as palpable As this which now draw.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 20)
Thou marshal'st me the way that was going, And such an instrument was to use.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 21)
Mine eyes are made the fools o' th' other senses Or else worth all the rest.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 22)
see thee still, And, on thy blade and dudgeon, gouts of blood, Which was not so before.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 23)
There's no such thing. It is the bloody business which informs Thus to mine eyes.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 24)
Now o'er the one-half world Nature seems dead, and wicked dreams abuse The curtained sleep.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 25)
Witchcraft celebrates Pale Hecate's off'rings, and withered murder, Alarumed by his sentinel, the wolf, Whose howl's his watch, thus with his stealthy pace, With Tarquin's ravishing strides, towards his design Moves like a ghost.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 26)
Thou sure and firm-set earth, Hear not my steps, which way they walk, for fear Thy very stones prate of my whereabouts And take the present horror from the time, Which now suits with it.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 27)
Whiles threat, he lives. Words to the heat of deeds too cold breath gives.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 28)
go, and it is done. The bell invites me. Hear it not, Duncan, for it is a knell That summons thee to heaven or to hell.(Macbeth, Act 0, Scene 29)
That which hath made them drunk hath made me bold.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 0)
What hath quenched them hath given me fire. Hark!(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 1)
--Peace. It was the owl that shrieked, the fatal bellman, Which gives the stern'st good-night.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 2)
He is about it. The doors are open, and the surfeited grooms Do mock their charge with snores.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 3)
have drugged their possets, That death and nature do contend about them Whether they live or die.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 4)
Who's there? what, ho!   Alack, am afraid they have awaked, And 'tis not done.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 5)
Th' attempt and not the deed Confounds us. Hark!--I laid their daggers ready; He could not miss 'em.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 6)
Had he not resembled My father as he slept, had done 't.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 7)
My husband?   have done the deed. Didst thou not hear a noise?(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 8)
heard the owl scream and the crickets cry. Did not you speak?(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 9)
When?  Now.  As descended?  Ay.  Hark!--Who lies i' th' second chamber?(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 10)
Donalbain.  This is a sorry sight.   foolish thought, to say a sorry sight.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 11)
There's one did laugh in 's sleep, and one cried "Murder!(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 12)
" That they did wake each other. stood and heard them.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 13)
But they did say their prayers and addressed them Again to sleep.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 14)
There are two lodged together.   One cried "God bless us" and "Amen" the other, As they had seen me with these hangman's hands, List'ning their fear.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 15)
could not say "Amen" When they did say "God bless us.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 16)
"  Consider it not so deeply.   But wherefore could not pronounce "Amen"?(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 17)
had most need of blessing, and "Amen" Stuck in my throat.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 18)
These deeds must not be thought After these ways; so, it will make us mad.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 19)
Methought heard a voice cry "Sleep no more! Macbeth does murder sleep"--the innocent sleep, Sleep that knits up the raveled sleave of care, The death of each day's life, sore labor's bath, Balm of hurt minds, great nature's second course, Chief nourisher in life's feast.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 20)
What do you mean?   Still it cried "Sleep no more!(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 21)
" to all the house. "Glamis hath murdered sleep, and therefore Cawdor Shall sleep no more.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 22)
Macbeth shall sleep no more."   Who was it that thus cried?(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 23)
Why, worthy thane, You do unbend your noble strength to think So brainsickly of things.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 24)
Go get some water And wash this filthy witness from your hand.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 25)
-- Why did you bring these daggers from the place?(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 26)
They must lie there. Go, carry them and smear The sleepy grooms with blood.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 27)
I'll go no more. am afraid to think what have done.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 28)
Look on 't again dare not.  Infirm of purpose! Give me the daggers.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 29)
