The sleeping and the dead Are but as pictures. 'Tis the eye of childhood That fears a painted devil.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 30)
If he do bleed, I'll gild the faces of the grooms withal, For it must seem their guilt.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 31)
Whence is that knocking? How is 't with me when every noise appalls me?(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 32)
What hands are here! Ha, they pluck out mine eyes.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 33)
Will all great Neptune's ocean wash this blood Clean from my hand?(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 34)
No, this my hand will rather The multitudinous seas incarnadine, Making the green one red.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 35)
My hands are of your color, but shame To wear a heart so white.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 36)
hear a knocking At the south entry. Retire we to our chamber.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 37)
little water clears us of this deed. How easy is it, then!(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 38)
Your constancy Hath left you unattended. Hark, more knocking.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 39)
Get on your nightgown, lest occasion call us And show us to be watchers.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 40)
Be not lost So poorly in your thoughts.   To know my deed 'twere best not know myself.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 41)
Wake Duncan with thy knocking. would thou couldst.(Macbeth, Act 1, Scene 42)
Here's a knocking indeed! If a man were porter of hell gate, he should have old turning the key.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 0)
Knock, knock, knock! Who's there, i' th' name of Beelzebub?(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 1)
Here's a farmer that hanged himself on th' expectation of plenty.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 2)
Come in time! Have napkins enough about you; here you'll sweat for 't.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 3)
Knock, knock! Who's there, in th' other devil's name?(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 4)
Faith, here's an equivocator that could swear in both the scales against either scale, who committed treason enough for God's sake yet could not equivocate to heaven.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 5)
come in, equivocator.  Knock, knock, knock! Who's there?(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 6)
Faith, here's an English tailor come hither for stealing out of a French hose.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 7)
Come in, tailor. Here you may roast your goose.  Knock, knock!(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 8)
Never at quiet.--What are you?--But this place is too cold for hell.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 9)
I'll devil-porter it no further. had thought to have let in some of all professions that go the primrose way to th' everlasting bonfire.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 10)
Anon, anon!    pray you, remember the porter.   Was it so late, friend, ere you went to bed That you do lie so late?(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 11)
Faith, sir, we were carousing till the second cock, and drink, sir, is a great provoker of three things.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 12)
What three things does drink especially provoke?(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 13)
Marry, sir, nose-painting, sleep, and urine. Lechery, sir, it provokes and unprovokes.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 14)
It provokes the desire, but it takes away the performance.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 15)
Therefore much drink may be said to be an equivocator with lechery.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 16)
It makes him, and it mars him; it sets him on, and it takes him off; it persuades him and disheartens him; makes him stand to and not stand to; in conclusion, equivocates him in a sleep and, giving him the lie, leaves him.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 17)
believe drink gave thee the lie last night.  That it did, sir, i' th' very throat on me; but requited him for his lie, and, think, being too strong for him, though he took up my legs sometime, yet made a shift to cast him.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 18)
Is thy master stirring?    Our knocking has awaked him.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 19)
Here he comes.    Good morrow, noble sir.  Good morrow, both.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 20)
Is the King stirring, worthy thane?  Not yet.   He did command me to call timely on him.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 21)
have almost slipped the hour.  I'll bring you to him.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 22)
know this is a joyful trouble to you, But yet 'tis one.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 23)
The labor we delight in physics pain. This is the door.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 24)
I'll make so bold to call, For 'tis my limited service.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 25)
Goes the King hence today?  He does. He did appoint so.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 26)
The night has been unruly. Where we lay, Our chimneys were blown down and, as they say, Lamentings heard i' th' air, strange screams of death, And prophesying, with accents terrible, Of dire combustion and confused events New hatched to th' woeful time.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 27)
The obscure bird Clamored the livelong night. Some say the Earth Was feverous and did shake.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 28)
'Twas a rough night.   My young remembrance cannot parallel fellow to it.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 29)
horror, horror, horror! Tongue nor heart cannot conceive nor name thee!(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 30)
What's the matter?   Confusion now hath made his masterpiece.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 31)
Most sacrilegious murder hath broke ope The Lord's anointed temple and stole thence The life o' th' building.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 32)
What is 't you say? The life?  Mean you his Majesty?(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 33)
Approach the chamber and destroy your sight With a new Gorgon.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 34)
Do not bid me speak. See and then speak yourselves.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 35)
Awake, awake! Ring the alarum bell.--Murder and treason!(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 36)
Banquo and Donalbain, Malcolm, awake! Shake off this downy sleep, death's counterfeit, And look on death itself.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 37)
Up, up, and see The great doom's image. Malcolm, Banquo, As from your graves rise up and walk like sprites To countenance this horror.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 38)
--Ring the bell.      What's the business, That such a hideous trumpet calls to parley The sleepers of the house?(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 39)
Speak, speak!  gentle lady, 'Tis not for you to hear what can speak.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 40)
The repetition in a woman's ear Would murder as it fell.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 41)
Banquo, Banquo, Our royal master's murdered.  Woe, alas!(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 42)
What, in our house?  Too cruel anywhere.-- Dear Duff, prithee, contradict thyself And say it is not so.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 43)
Had but died an hour before this chance, had lived a blessed time; for from this instant There's nothing serious in mortality.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 44)
All is but toys. Renown and grace is dead. The wine of life is drawn, and the mere lees Is left this vault to brag of.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 45)
What is amiss?  You are, and do not know 't. The spring, the head, the fountain of your blood Is stopped; the very source of it is stopped.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 46)
Your royal father's murdered.  by whom?   Those of his chamber, as it seemed, had done 't.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 47)
Their hands and faces were all badged with blood.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 48)
So were their daggers, which unwiped we found Upon their pillows.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 49)
They stared and were distracted. No man's life was to be trusted with them.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 50)
yet do repent me of my fury, That did kill them.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 51)
Wherefore did you so?   Who can be wise, amazed, temp'rate, and furious, Loyal, and neutral, in a moment?(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 52)
No man. Th' expedition of my violent love Outrun the pauser, reason.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 53)
Here lay Duncan, His silver skin laced with his golden blood, And his gashed stabs looked like a breach in nature For ruin's wasteful entrance; there the murderers, Steeped in the colors of their trade, their daggers Unmannerly breeched with gore.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 54)
Who could refrain That had a heart to love, and in that heart Courage to make 's love known?(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 55)
Help me hence, ho!   Look to the lady.  Why do we hold our tongues, That most may claim this argument for ours?(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 56)
What should be spoken here, where our fate, Hid in an auger hole, may rush and seize us?(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 57)
Let's away. Our tears are not yet brewed.   Nor our strong sorrow upon the foot of motion.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 58)
Look to the lady.  And when we have our naked frailties hid, That suffer in exposure, let us meet And question this most bloody piece of work To know it further.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 59)
Fears and scruples shake us. In the great hand of God stand, and thence Against the undivulged pretense fight Of treasonous malice.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 60)
And so do  So all.   Let's briefly put on manly readiness And meet i' th' hall together.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 61)
Well contented.    What will you do? Let's not consort with them.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 62)
To show an unfelt sorrow is an office Which the false man does easy.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 63)
I'll to England.   To Ireland Our separated fortune Shall keep us both the safer.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 64)
Where we are, There's daggers in men's smiles. The near in blood, The nearer bloody.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 65)
This murderous shaft that's shot Hath not yet lighted, and our safest way Is to avoid the aim.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 66)
Therefore to horse, And let us not be dainty of leave-taking But shift away.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 67)
There's warrant in that theft Which steals itself when there's no mercy left.(Macbeth, Act 2, Scene 68)
Threescore and ten can remember well, Within the volume of which time have seen Hours dreadful and things strange, but this sore night Hath trifled former knowings.(Macbeth, Act 3, Scene 0)
Ha, good father, Thou seest the heavens, as troubled with man's act, Threatens his bloody stage.(Macbeth, Act 3, Scene 1)
By th' clock 'tis day, And yet dark night strangles the traveling lamp.(Macbeth, Act 3, Scene 2)
Is 't night's predominance or the day's shame That darkness does the face of earth entomb When living light should kiss it?(Macbeth, Act 3, Scene 3)
'Tis unnatural, Even like the deed that's done. On Tuesday last falcon, tow'ring in her pride of place, Was by a mousing owl hawked at and killed.(Macbeth, Act 3, Scene 4)
And Duncan's horses (a thing most strange and certain), Beauteous and swift, the minions of their race, Turned wild in nature, broke their stalls, flung out, Contending 'gainst obedience, as they would Make war with mankind.(Macbeth, Act 3, Scene 5)
'Tis said they eat each other.   They did so, to th' amazement of mine eyes That looked upon 't.(Macbeth, Act 3, Scene 6)
Here comes the good Macduff.-- How goes the world, sir, now?(Macbeth, Act 3, Scene 7)
Why, see you not?   Is 't known who did this more than bloody deed?(Macbeth, Act 3, Scene 8)
Those that Macbeth hath slain.  Alas the day, What good could they pretend?(Macbeth, Act 3, Scene 9)
They were suborned. Malcolm and Donalbain, the King's two sons, Are stol'n away and fled, which puts upon them Suspicion of the deed.(Macbeth, Act 3, Scene 10)
'Gainst nature still! Thriftless ambition, that will ravin up Thine own lives' means.(Macbeth, Act 3, Scene 11)
Then 'tis most like The sovereignty will fall upon Macbeth.(Macbeth, Act 3, Scene 12)
He is already named and gone to Scone To be invested.(Macbeth, Act 3, Scene 13)
Where is Duncan's body?  Carried to Colmekill, The sacred storehouse of his predecessors And guardian of their bones.(Macbeth, Act 3, Scene 14)
Will you to Scone?   No, cousin, I'll to Fife.  Well, will thither.(Macbeth, Act 3, Scene 15)
Well, may you see things well done there. Adieu, Lest our old robes sit easier than our new.(Macbeth, Act 3, Scene 16)
Farewell, father.   God's benison go with you and with those That would make good of bad and friends of foes.(Macbeth, Act 3, Scene 17)
We must not make a scarecrow of the law, Setting it up to fear the birds of prey, And let it keep one shape till custom make it Their perch and not their terror.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 0)
Ay, but yet Let us be keen and rather cut a little Than fall and bruise to death.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 1)
Alas, this gentleman Whom would save had a most noble father.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 2)
Let but your Honor know, Whom believe to be most strait in virtue, That, in the working of your own affections, Had time cohered with place, or place with wishing, Or that the resolute acting of your blood Could have attained th' effect of your own purpose, Whether you had not sometime in your life Erred in this point which now you censure him, And pulled the law upon you.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 3)
'Tis one thing to be tempted, Escalus, Another thing to fall.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 4)
not deny The jury passing on the prisoner's life May in the sworn twelve have a thief or two Guiltier than him they try.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 5)
What's open made to justice, That justice seizes.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 6)
What knows the laws That thieves do pass on thieves?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 7)
'Tis very pregnant, The jewel that we find, we stoop and take 't Because we see it; but what we do not see, We tread upon and never think of it.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 8)
You may not so extenuate his offense For have had such faults; but rather tell me, When that censure him do so offend, Let mine own judgment pattern out my death, And nothing come in partial.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 9)
Sir, he must die.      Be it as your wisdom will.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 10)
Where is the Provost?   Here, if it like your Honor.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 11)
See that Claudio Be executed by nine tomorrow morning.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 12)
Bring him his confessor, let him be prepared, For that's the utmost of his pilgrimage.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 13)
Well, heaven forgive him and forgive us all. Some rise by sin and some by virtue fall.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 14)
Some run from brakes of ice and answer none, And some condemned for a fault alone.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 15)
Come, bring them away. If these be good people in a commonweal that do nothing but use their abuses in common houses, know no law.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 16)
Bring them away.  How now, sir, what's your name?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 17)
And what's the matter?  If it please your Honor, am the poor duke's constable, and my name is Elbow.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 18)
do lean upon justice, sir, and do bring in here before your good Honor two notorious benefactors.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 19)
Benefactors? Well, what benefactors are they? Are they not malefactors?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 20)
If it please your Honor, know not well what they are, but precise villains they are, that am sure of, and void of all profanation in the world that good Christians ought to have.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 21)
This comes off well. Here's a wise officer.  Go to.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 22)
What quality are they of? Elbow is your name? Why dost thou not speak, Elbow?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 23)
He cannot, sir. He's out at elbow.  What are you, sir?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 24)
He, sir? tapster, sir, parcel bawd; one that serves a bad woman, whose house, sir, was, as they say, plucked down in the suburbs, and now she professes a hothouse, which think is a very ill house too.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 25)
How know you that?  My wife, sir, whom detest before heaven and your Honor--  How?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 26)
Thy wife?  Ay, sir, whom thank heaven is an honest woman--  Dost thou detest her therefore?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 27)
say, sir, will detest myself also, as well as she, that this house, if it be not a bawd's house, it is pity of her life, for it is a naughty house.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 28)
How dost thou know that, constable?  Marry, sir, by my wife, who, if she had been a woman cardinally given, might have been accused in fornication, adultery, and all uncleanliness there.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 29)
By the woman's means?  Ay, sir, by Mistress Overdone's means; but as she spit in his face, so she defied him.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 30)
Sir, if it please your Honor, this is not so.  Prove it before these varlets here, thou honorable man, prove it.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 31)
Do you hear how he misplaces?  Sir, she came in great with child, and longing, saving your Honor's reverence, for stewed prunes.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 32)
Sir, we had but two in the house, which at that very distant time stood, as it were, in a fruit dish, a dish of some threepence; your Honors have seen such dishes; they are not china dishes, but very good dishes--  Go to, go to.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 33)
No matter for the dish, sir.  No, indeed, sir, not of a pin; you are therein in the right.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 34)
But to the point: as say, this Mistress Elbow, being, as say, with child, and being great-bellied, and longing, as said, for prunes; and having but two in the dish, as said, Master Froth here, this very man, having eaten the rest, as said, and, as say, paying for them very honestly--for, as you know, Master Froth, could not give you threepence again--  No, indeed.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 35)
Very well. You being then, if you be remembered, cracking the stones of the foresaid prunes--  Ay, so did indeed.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 36)
Why, very well. telling you then, if you be remembered, that such a one and such a one were past cure of the thing you wot of, unless they kept very good diet, as told you--  All this is true.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 37)
Why, very well then--  Come, you are a tedious fool.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 38)
To the purpose: what was done to Elbow's wife that he hath cause to complain of?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 39)
Come me to what was done to her.  Sir, your Honor cannot come to that yet.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 40)
No, sir, nor mean it not.  Sir, but you shall come to it, by your Honor's leave.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 41)
And beseech you, look into Master Froth here, sir, a man of fourscore pound a year, whose father died at Hallowmas--was 't not at Hallowmas, Master Froth?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 42)
All-hallond Eve.  Why, very well. hope here be truths.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 43)
--He, sir, sitting, as say, in a lower chair, sir-- 'Twas in the Bunch of Grapes, where indeed you have a delight to sit, have you not?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 44)
have so, because it is an open room, and good for winter.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 45)
Why, very well then. hope here be truths.   This will last out a night in Russia When nights are longest there.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 46)
I'll take my leave, And leave you to the hearing of the cause, Hoping you'll find good cause to whip them all.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 47)
think no less. Good morrow to your Lordship  Now, sir, come on.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 48)
What was done to Elbow's wife, once more?  Once, sir?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 49)
There was nothing done to her once.  beseech you, sir, ask him what this man did to my wife.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 50)
beseech your Honor, ask me.  Well, sir, what did this gentleman to her?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 51)
beseech you, sir, look in this gentleman's face.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 52)
--Good Master Froth, look upon his Honor. 'Tis for a good purpose.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 53)
--Doth your Honor mark his face?  Ay, sir, very well.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 54)
Nay, beseech you, mark it well.  Well, do so.  Doth your Honor see any harm in his face?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 55)
Why, no.  I'll be supposed upon a book, his face is the worst thing about him.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 56)
Good, then, if his face be the worst thing about him, how could Master Froth do the Constable's wife any harm?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 57)
would know that of your Honor.  He's in the right, constable.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 58)
What say you to it?  First, an it like you, the house is a respected house; next, this is a respected fellow, and his mistress is a respected woman.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 59)
By this hand, sir, his wife is a more respected person than any of us all.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 60)
Varlet, thou liest; thou liest, wicked varlet! The time is yet to come that she was ever respected with man, woman, or child.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 61)
Sir, she was respected with him before he married with her.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 62)
Which is the wiser here, Justice or Iniquity? Is this true?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 63)
thou caitiff! thou varlet! thou wicked Hannibal!(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 64)
respected with her before was married to her?--If ever was respected with her, or she with me, let not your Worship think me the poor duke's officer.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 65)
--Prove this, thou wicked Hannibal, or I'll have mine action of batt'ry on thee.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 66)
If he took you a box o' th' ear, you might have your action of slander too.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 67)
Marry, thank your good Worship for it. What is 't your Worship's pleasure shall do with this wicked caitiff?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 68)
Truly, officer, because he hath some offenses in him that thou wouldst discover if thou couldst, let him continue in his courses till thou know'st what they are.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 69)
Marry, thank your Worship for it. Thou seest, thou wicked varlet, now, what's come upon thee.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 70)
Thou art to continue now, thou varlet, thou art to continue.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 71)
Where were you born, friend?  Here in Vienna, sir.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 72)
Are you of fourscore pounds a year?  Yes, an 't please you, sir.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 73)
So.  What trade are you of, sir?  tapster, a poor widow's tapster.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 74)
Your mistress' name?  Mistress Overdone.  Hath she had any more than one husband?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 75)
Nine, sir. Overdone by the last.  Nine?--Come hither to me, Master Froth.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 76)
Master Froth, would not have you acquainted with tapsters; they will draw you, Master Froth, and you will hang them.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 77)
Get you gone, and let me hear no more of you.  thank your Worship.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 78)
For mine own part, never come into any room in a taphouse but am drawn in.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 79)
Well, no more of it, Master Froth. Farewell.  Come you hither to me, Master Tapster.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 80)
What's your name, Master Tapster?  Pompey.  What else?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 81)
Bum, sir.  Troth, and your bum is the greatest thing about you, so that in the beastliest sense you are Pompey the Great.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 82)
Pompey, you are partly a bawd, Pompey, howsoever you color it in being a tapster, are you not?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 83)
Come, tell me true. It shall be the better for you.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 84)
Truly, sir, am a poor fellow that would live.  How would you live, Pompey?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 85)
By being a bawd? What do you think of the trade, Pompey?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 86)
Is it a lawful trade?  If the law would allow it, sir.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 87)
But the law will not allow it, Pompey, nor it shall not be allowed in Vienna.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 88)
Does your Worship mean to geld and splay all the youth of the city?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 89)
No, Pompey.  Truly, sir, in my poor opinion, they will to 't then.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 90)
If your Worship will take order for the drabs and the knaves, you need not to fear the bawds.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 91)
There is pretty orders beginning, can tell you. It is but heading and hanging.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 92)
If you head and hang all that offend that way but for ten year together, you'll be glad to give out a commission for more heads.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 93)
If this law hold in Vienna ten year, I'll rent the fairest house in it after threepence a bay.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 94)
If you live to see this come to pass, say Pompey told you so.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 95)
Thank you, good Pompey. And in requital of your prophecy, hark you: advise you let me not find you before me again upon any complaint whatsoever; no, not for dwelling where you do.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 96)
If do, Pompey, shall beat you to your tent and prove a shrewd Caesar to you.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 97)
In plain dealing, Pompey, shall have you whipped.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 98)
So, for this time, Pompey, fare you well.  thank your Worship for your good counsel.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 99)
But shall follow it as the flesh and fortune shall better determine.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 100)
Whip me? No, no, let carman whip his jade. The valiant heart's not whipped out of his trade.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 101)
Come hither to me, Master Elbow. Come hither, Master Constable.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 102)
How long have you been in this place of constable?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 103)
Seven year and a half, sir.  thought, by the readiness in the office, you had continued in it some time.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 104)
You say seven years together?  And a half, sir.  Alas, it hath been great pains to you.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 105)
They do you wrong to put you so oft upon 't. Are there not men in your ward sufficient to serve it?(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 106)
Faith, sir, few of any wit in such matters. As they are chosen, they are glad to choose me for them.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 107)
do it for some piece of money and go through with all.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 108)
Look you bring me in the names of some six or seven, the most sufficient of your parish.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 109)
To your Worship's house, sir?  To my house. Fare you well.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 110)
What's o'clock, think you?  Eleven, sir.  pray you home to dinner with me.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 111)
humbly thank you.   It grieves me for the death of Claudio, But there's no remedy.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 112)
Lord Angelo is severe.  It is but needful. Mercy is not itself that oft looks so.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 113)
Pardon is still the nurse of second woe. But yet, poor Claudio.(Measure for Measure, Act 0, Scene 114)
He's hearing of a cause. He will come straight.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 0)
I'll tell him of you.  Pray you do.  I'll know His pleasure.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 1)
Maybe he will relent. Alas, He hath but as offended in a dream.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 2)
All sects, all ages smack of this vice, and he To die for 't?(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 3)
Now, what's the matter, provost?   Is it your will Claudio shall die tomorrow?(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 4)
Did not tell thee yea? Hadst thou not order? Why dost thou ask again?(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 5)
Lest might be too rash. Under your good correction, have seen When, after execution, judgment hath Repented o'er his doom.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 6)
Go to. Let that be mine. Do you your office, or give up your place And you shall well be spared.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 7)
crave your Honor's pardon. What shall be done, sir, with the groaning Juliet?(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 8)
She's very near her hour.  Dispose of her To some more fitter place, and that with speed.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 9)
Here is the sister of the man condemned Desires access to you.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 10)
Hath he a sister?   Ay, my good lord, a very virtuous maid, And to be shortly of a sisterhood, If not already.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 11)
Well, let her be admitted.  See you the fornicatress be removed.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 12)
Let her have needful but not lavish means. There shall be order for 't.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 13)
Save your Honor.   Stay a little while.  You're welcome.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 14)
What's your will?   am a woeful suitor to your Honor, Please but your Honor hear me.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 15)
Well, what's your suit?   There is a vice that most do abhor, And most desire should meet the blow of justice, For which would not plead, but that must; For which must not plead, but that am At war 'twixt will and will not.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 16)
Well, the matter?   have a brother is condemned to die.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 17)
do beseech you let it be his fault And not my brother.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 18)
Heaven give thee moving graces.   Condemn the fault, and not the actor of it?(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 19)
Why, every fault's condemned ere it be done. Mine were the very cipher of a function To fine the faults whose fine stands in record And let go by the actor.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 20)
just but severe law! had a brother, then. Heaven keep your Honor.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 21)
Give 't not o'er so. To him again, entreat him, Kneel down before him, hang upon his gown.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 22)
You are too cold. If you should need a pin, You could not with more tame a tongue desire it.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 23)
To him, say.   Must he needs die?  Maiden, no remedy.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 24)
Yes, do think that you might pardon him, And neither heaven nor man grieve at the mercy.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 25)
will not do 't.  But can you if you would?   Look what will not, that cannot do.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 26)
But might you do 't and do the world no wrong If so your heart were touched with that remorse As mine is to him?(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 27)
He's sentenced. 'Tis too late.  You are too cold.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 28)
Too late? Why, no. that do speak a word May call it back again.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 29)
Well believe this: No ceremony that to great ones longs, Not the king's crown, nor the deputed sword, The marshal's truncheon, nor the judge's robe Become them with one half so good a grace As mercy does.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 30)
If he had been as you, and you as he, You would have slipped like him, but he like you Would not have been so stern.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 31)
Pray you begone.   would to heaven had your potency, And you were Isabel.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 32)
Should it then be thus? No. would tell what 'twere to be a judge And what a prisoner.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 33)
Ay, touch him; there's the vein.   Your brother is a forfeit of the law, And you but waste your words.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 34)
Alas, alas! Why all the souls that were were forfeit once, And He that might the vantage best have took Found out the remedy.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 35)
How would you be If He which is the top of judgment should But judge you as you are?(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 36)
think on that, And mercy then will breathe within your lips Like man new-made.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 37)
Be you content, fair maid. It is the law, not condemn your brother.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 38)
Were he my kinsman, brother, or my son, It should be thus with him.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 39)
He must die tomorrow.   Tomorrow? that's sudden! Spare him, spare him.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 40)
He's not prepared for death. Even for our kitchens We kill the fowl of season.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 41)
Shall we serve heaven With less respect than we do minister To our gross selves?(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 42)
Good, good my lord, bethink you. Who is it that hath died for this offense?(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 43)
There's many have committed it.  Ay, well said.   The law hath not been dead, though it hath slept.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 44)
Those many had not dared to do that evil If the first that did th' edict infringe Had answered for his deed.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 45)
Now 'tis awake, Takes note of what is done, and, like a prophet, Looks in a glass that shows what future evils-- Either now, or by remissness new-conceived, And so in progress to be hatched and born-- Are now to have no successive degrees But, ere they live, to end.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 46)
Yet show some pity.   show it most of all when show justice, For then pity those do not know, Which a dismissed offense would after gall, And do him right that, answering one foul wrong, Lives not to act another.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 47)
Be satisfied; Your brother dies tomorrow; be content.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 48)
So you must be the first that gives this sentence, And he that suffers.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 49)
it is excellent To have a giant's strength, but it is tyrannous To use it like a giant.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 50)
That's well said.  Could great men thunder As Jove himself does, Jove would never be quiet, For every pelting, petty officer Would use his heaven for thunder, Nothing but thunder.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 51)
Merciful heaven, Thou rather with thy sharp and sulphurous bolt Splits the unwedgeable and gnarled oak, Than the soft myrtle.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 52)
But man, proud man, Dressed in a little brief authority, Most ignorant of what he's most assured, His glassy essence, like an angry ape Plays such fantastic tricks before high heaven As makes the angels weep, who with our spleens Would all themselves laugh mortal.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 53)
to him, to him, wench. He will relent. He's coming.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 54)
perceive 't.  Pray heaven she win him.   We cannot weigh our brother with ourself.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 55)
Great men may jest with saints; 'tis wit in them, But in the less, foul profanation.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 56)
Thou 'rt i' th' right, girl. More o' that.   That in the captain's but a choleric word Which in the soldier is flat blasphemy.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 57)
Art avised o' that? More on 't.   Why do you put these sayings upon me?(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 58)
Because authority, though it err like others, Hath yet a kind of medicine in itself That skins the vice o' th' top.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 59)
Go to your bosom, Knock there, and ask your heart what it doth know That's like my brother's fault.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 60)
If it confess natural guiltiness such as is his, Let it not sound a thought upon your tongue Against my brother's life.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 61)
She speaks, and 'tis such sense That my sense breeds with it.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 62)
Fare you well.  Gentle my lord, turn back.   will bethink me.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 63)
Come again tomorrow.   Hark how I'll bribe you. Good my lord, turn back.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 64)
How? Bribe me?   Ay, with such gifts that heaven shall share with you.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 65)
You had marred all else.   Not with fond sicles of the tested gold, Or stones whose rate are either rich or poor As fancy values them, but with true prayers That shall be up at heaven and enter there Ere sunrise, prayers from preserved souls, From fasting maids whose minds are dedicate To nothing temporal.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 66)
Well, come to me tomorrow.  Go to, 'tis well; away.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 67)
Heaven keep your Honor safe.  Amen. For am that way going to temptation Where prayers cross.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 68)
At what hour tomorrow Shall attend your Lordship?(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 69)
At any time 'fore noon.  Save your Honor.   From thee, even from thy virtue.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 70)
What's this? What's this? Is this her fault or mine?(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 71)
The tempter or the tempted, who sins most, ha? Not she, nor doth she tempt; but it is That, lying by the violet in the sun, Do as the carrion does, not as the flower, Corrupt with virtuous season.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 72)
Can it be That modesty may more betray our sense Than woman's lightness?(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 73)
Having waste ground enough, Shall we desire to raze the sanctuary And pitch our evils there?(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 74)
fie, fie, fie! What dost thou, or what art thou, Angelo?(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 75)
Dost thou desire her foully for those things That make her good?(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 76)
let her brother live. Thieves for their robbery have authority When judges steal themselves.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 77)
What, do love her That desire to hear her speak again And feast upon her eyes?(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 78)
What is 't dream on? cunning enemy that, to catch a saint, With saints dost bait thy hook.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 79)
Most dangerous Is that temptation that doth goad us on To sin in loving virtue.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 80)
Never could the strumpet With all her double vigor, art and nature, Once stir my temper, but this virtuous maid Subdues me quite.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 81)
Ever till now When men were fond, smiled and wondered how.(Measure for Measure, Act 1, Scene 82)
Hail to you, provost, so think you are.   am the Provost.(Measure for Measure, Act 2, Scene 0)
What's your will, good friar?   Bound by my charity and my blest order, come to visit the afflicted spirits Here in the prison.(Measure for Measure, Act 2, Scene 1)
Do me the common right To let me see them, and to make me know The nature of their crimes, that may minister To them accordingly.(Measure for Measure, Act 2, Scene 2)
would do more than that if more were needful.    Look, here comes one, a gentlewoman of mine, Who, falling in the flaws of her own youth, Hath blistered her report.(Measure for Measure, Act 2, Scene 3)
She is with child, And he that got it, sentenced--a young man, More fit to do another such offense Than die for this.(Measure for Measure, Act 2, Scene 4)
When must he die?  As do think, tomorrow. have provided for you.(Measure for Measure, Act 2, Scene 5)
Stay awhile And you shall be conducted.   Repent you, fair one, of the sin you carry?(Measure for Measure, Act 2, Scene 6)
do; and bear the shame most patiently.   I'll teach you how you shall arraign your conscience, And try your penitence, if it be sound Or hollowly put on.(Measure for Measure, Act 2, Scene 7)
I'll gladly learn.  Love you the man that wronged you?(Measure for Measure, Act 2, Scene 8)
Yes, as love the woman that wronged him.   So then it seems your most offenseful act Was mutually committed?(Measure for Measure, Act 2, Scene 9)
Mutually.   Then was your sin of heavier kind than his.(Measure for Measure, Act 2, Scene 10)
do confess it and repent it, father.   'Tis meet so, daughter; but lest you do repent As that the sin hath brought you to this shame, Which sorrow is always toward ourselves, not heaven, Showing we would not spare heaven as we love it, But as we stand in fear--   do repent me as it is an evil, And take the shame with joy.(Measure for Measure, Act 2, Scene 11)
There rest. Your partner, as hear, must die tomorrow, And am going with instruction to him.(Measure for Measure, Act 2, Scene 12)
Grace go with you. Benedicite.   Must die tomorrow?(Measure for Measure, Act 2, Scene 13)
injurious love That respites me a life, whose very comfort Is still a dying horror.(Measure for Measure, Act 2, Scene 14)
2        When would pray and think, think and pray To several subjects.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 0)
Heaven hath my empty words, Whilst my invention, hearing not my tongue, Anchors on Isabel.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 1)
God in my mouth, As if did but only chew His name, And in my heart the strong and swelling evil Of my conception.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 2)
The state whereon studied Is, like a good thing being often read, Grown sere and tedious.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 3)
Yea, my gravity, Wherein--let no man hear me--I take pride, Could with boot change for an idle plume Which the air beats for vain.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 4)
place, form, How often dost thou with thy case, thy habit, Wrench awe from fools, and tie the wiser souls To thy false seeming!(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 5)
Blood, thou art blood. Let's write "good angel" on the devil's horn.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 6)
'Tis not the devil's crest.  How now, who's there?(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 7)
One Isabel, a sister, desires access to you.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 8)
Teach her the way.  heavens, Why does my blood thus muster to my heart, Making both it unable for itself And dispossessing all my other parts Of necessary fitness?(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 9)
So play the foolish throngs with one that swoons, Come all to help him, and so stop the air By which he should revive.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 10)
And even so The general subject to a well-wished king Quit their own part, and in obsequious fondness Crowd to his presence, where their untaught love Must needs appear offense.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 11)
How now, fair maid?  am come to know your pleasure.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 12)
That you might know it would much better please me Than to demand what 'tis.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 13)
Your brother cannot live.  Even so. Heaven keep your Honor.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 14)
Yet may he live a while. And it may be As long as you or Yet he must die.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 15)
Under your sentence?  Yea.   When, beseech you? That in his reprieve, Longer or shorter, he may be so fitted That his soul sicken not.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 16)
Ha! Fie, these filthy vices! It were as good To pardon him that hath from nature stolen man already made, as to remit Their saucy sweetness that do coin God's image In stamps that are forbid.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 17)
'Tis all as easy Falsely to take away a life true made As to put metal in restrained means To make a false one.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 18)
'Tis set down so in heaven, but not in Earth.   Say you so?(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 19)
Then shall pose you quickly: Which had you rather, that the most just law Now took your brother's life, or, to redeem him, Give up your body to such sweet uncleanness As she that he hath stained?(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 20)
Sir, believe this: had rather give my body than my soul.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 21)
talk not of your soul. Our compelled sins Stand more for number than for accompt.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 22)
How say you?   Nay, I'll not warrant that, for can speak Against the thing say.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 23)
Answer to this: now the voice of the recorded law, Pronounce a sentence on your brother's life.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 24)
Might there not be a charity in sin To save this brother's life?(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 25)
Please you to do 't, I'll take it as a peril to my soul, It is no sin at all, but charity.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 26)
Pleased you to do 't, at peril of your soul, Were equal poise of sin and charity.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 27)
That do beg his life, if it be sin Heaven let me bear it.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 28)
You granting of my suit, If that be sin, I'll make it my morn prayer To have it added to the faults of mine And nothing of your answer.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 29)
Nay, but hear me. Your sense pursues not mine. Either you are ignorant, Or seem so, crafty, and that's not good.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 30)
Let me be ignorant and in nothing good, But graciously to know am no better.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 31)
Thus wisdom wishes to appear most bright When it doth tax itself, as these black masks Proclaim an enshield beauty ten times louder Than beauty could, displayed.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 32)
But mark me. To be received plain, I'll speak more gross: Your brother is to die.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 33)
So.   And his offense is so, as it appears, Accountant to the law upon that pain.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 34)
True.   Admit no other way to save his life-- As subscribe not that, nor any other-- But, in the loss of question, that you, his sister, Finding yourself desired of such a person Whose credit with the judge, or own great place, Could fetch your brother from the manacles Of the all-binding law, and that there were No earthly mean to save him but that either You must lay down the treasures of your body To this supposed, or else to let him suffer, What would you do?(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 35)
As much for my poor brother as myself. That is, were under the terms of death, Th' impression of keen whips I'd wear as rubies And strip myself to death as to a bed That longing have been sick for, ere I'd yield My body up to shame.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 36)
Then must your brother die.  And 'twere the cheaper way.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 37)
Better it were a brother died at once Than that a sister, by redeeming him, Should die forever.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 38)
Were not you then as cruel as the sentence That you have slandered so?(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 39)
Ignomy in ransom and free pardon Are of two houses.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 40)
Lawful mercy Is nothing kin to foul redemption.   You seemed of late to make the law a tyrant, And rather proved the sliding of your brother merriment than a vice.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 41)
pardon me, my lord. It oft falls out, To have what we would have, we speak not what we mean.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 42)
something do excuse the thing hate For his advantage that dearly love.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 43)
We are all frail.  Else let my brother die, If not a fedary but only he Owe and succeed thy weakness.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 44)
Nay, women are frail too.   Ay, as the glasses where they view themselves, Which are as easy broke as they make forms.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 45)
Women--help, heaven--men their creation mar In profiting by them.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 46)
Nay, call us ten times frail, For we are soft as our complexions are, And credulous to false prints.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 47)
think it well. And from this testimony of your own sex, Since suppose we are made to be no stronger Than faults may shake our frames, let me be bold.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 48)
do arrest your words. Be that you are-- That is, a woman.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 49)
If you be more, you're none. If you be one, as you are well expressed By all external warrants, show it now By putting on the destined livery.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 50)
have no tongue but one. Gentle my lord, Let me entreat you speak the former language.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 51)
Plainly conceive love you.  My brother did love Juliet, And you tell me that he shall die for 't.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 52)
He shall not, Isabel, if you give me love.   know your virtue hath a license in 't Which seems a little fouler than it is To pluck on others.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 53)
Believe me, on mine honor, My words express my purpose.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 54)
Ha! Little honor to be much believed, And most pernicious purpose.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 55)
Seeming, seeming! will proclaim thee, Angelo, look for 't.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 56)
Sign me a present pardon for my brother Or with an outstretched throat I'll tell the world aloud What man thou art.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 57)
Who will believe thee, Isabel? My unsoiled name, th' austereness of my life, My vouch against you, and my place i' th' state Will so your accusation overweigh That you shall stifle in your own report And smell of calumny.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 58)
have begun, And now give my sensual race the rein.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 59)
Fit thy consent to my sharp appetite; Lay by all nicety and prolixious blushes That banish what they sue for.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 60)
Redeem thy brother By yielding up thy body to my will, Or else he must not only die the death, But thy unkindness shall his death draw out To ling'ring sufferance.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 61)
Answer me tomorrow, Or by the affection that now guides me most, I'll prove a tyrant to him.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 62)
As for you, Say what you can, my false o'erweighs your true.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 63)
To whom should complain? Did tell this, Who would believe me?(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 64)
perilous mouths, That bear in them one and the selfsame tongue, Either of condemnation or approof, Bidding the law make curtsy to their will, Hooking both right and wrong to th' appetite, To follow as it draws.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 65)
I'll to my brother. Though he hath fall'n by prompture of the blood, Yet hath he in him such a mind of honor That, had he twenty heads to tender down On twenty bloody blocks, he'd yield them up Before his sister should her body stoop To such abhorred pollution.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 66)
Then, Isabel, live chaste, and, brother, die. More than our brother is our chastity.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 67)
I'll tell him yet of Angelo's request, And fit his mind to death, for his soul's rest.(Measure for Measure, Act 3, Scene 68)
So then you hope of pardon from Lord Angelo?   The miserable have no other medicine But only hope.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 0)
have hope to live and am prepared to die.   Be absolute for death.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 1)
Either death or life Shall thereby be the sweeter.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 2)
Reason thus with life: If do lose thee, do lose a thing That none but fools would keep.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 3)
breath thou art, Servile to all the skyey influences That doth this habitation where thou keep'st Hourly afflict.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 4)
Merely, thou art death's fool, For him thou labor'st by thy flight to shun, And yet runn'st toward him still.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 5)
Thou art not noble, For all th' accommodations that thou bear'st Are nursed by baseness.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 6)
Thou 'rt by no means valiant, For thou dost fear the soft and tender fork Of a poor worm.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 7)
Thy best of rest is sleep, And that thou oft provok'st, yet grossly fear'st Thy death, which is no more.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 8)
Thou art not thyself, For thou exists on many a thousand grains That issue out of dust.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 9)
Happy thou art not, For what thou hast not, still thou striv'st to get, And what thou hast, forget'st.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 10)
Thou art not certain, For thy complexion shifts to strange effects After the moon.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 11)
If thou art rich, thou 'rt poor, For, like an ass whose back with ingots bows, Thou bear'st thy heavy riches but a journey, And death unloads thee.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 12)
Friend hast thou none, For thine own bowels which do call thee sire, The mere effusion of thy proper loins, Do curse the gout, serpigo, and the rheum For ending thee no sooner.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 13)
Thou hast nor youth nor age, But as it were an after-dinner's sleep Dreaming on both, for all thy blessed youth Becomes as aged and doth beg the alms Of palsied eld; and when thou art old and rich, Thou hast neither heat, affection, limb, nor beauty To make thy riches pleasant.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 14)
What's yet in this That bears the name of life? Yet in this life Lie hid more thousand deaths; yet death we fear, That makes these odds all even.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 15)
humbly thank you. To sue to live, find seek to die, And seeking death, find life.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 16)
Let it come on.   What ho! Peace here, grace, and good company.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 17)
Who's there? Come in. The wish deserves a welcome.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 18)
Dear sir, ere long I'll visit you again.  Most holy sir, thank you.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 19)
My business is a word or two with Claudio.   And very welcome.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 20)
--Look, signior, here's your sister.  Provost, a word with you.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 21)
As many as you please.   Bring me to hear them speak, where may be concealed.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 22)
Now, sister, what's the comfort?  Why, As all comforts are, most good, most good indeed.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 23)
Lord Angelo, having affairs to heaven, Intends you for his swift ambassador, Where you shall be an everlasting leiger; Therefore your best appointment make with speed.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 24)
Tomorrow you set on.  Is there no remedy?   None but such remedy as, to save a head, To cleave a heart in twain.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 25)
But is there any?  Yes, brother, you may live. There is a devilish mercy in the judge, If you'll implore it, that will free your life But fetter you till death.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 26)
Perpetual durance?   Ay, just; perpetual durance, a restraint, Though all the world's vastidity you had, To a determined scope.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 27)
But in what nature?   In such a one as, you consenting to 't, Would bark your honor from that trunk you bear And leave you naked.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 28)
Let me know the point.   do fear thee, Claudio, and quake Lest thou a feverous life shouldst entertain, And six or seven winters more respect Than a perpetual honor.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 29)
Dar'st thou die? The sense of death is most in apprehension, And the poor beetle that we tread upon In corporal sufferance finds a pang as great As when a giant dies.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 30)
Why give you me this shame? Think you can a resolution fetch From flowery tenderness?(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 31)
If must die, will encounter darkness as a bride, And hug it in mine arms.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 32)
There spake my brother! There my father's grave Did utter forth a voice.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 33)
Yes, thou must die. Thou art too noble to conserve a life In base appliances.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 34)
This outward-sainted deputy-- Whose settled visage and deliberate word Nips youth i' th' head, and follies doth enew As falcon doth the fowl--is yet a devil.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 35)
His filth within being cast, he would appear pond as deep as hell.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 36)
The prenzie Angelo?   'tis the cunning livery of hell The damned'st body to invest and cover In prenzie guards.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 37)
Dost thou think, Claudio, If would yield him my virginity Thou mightst be freed?(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 38)
heavens, it cannot be!   Yes, he would give 't thee; from this rank offense, So to offend him still.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 39)
This night's the time That should do what abhor to name, Or else thou diest tomorrow.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 40)
Thou shalt not do 't.  were it but my life, I'd throw it down for your deliverance As frankly as a pin.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 41)
Thanks, dear Isabel.   Be ready, Claudio, for your death tomorrow.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 42)
Yes. Has he affections in him That thus can make him bite the law by th' nose, When he would force it?(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 43)
Sure it is no sin, Or of the deadly seven it is the least.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 44)
Which is the least?   If it were damnable, he being so wise, Why would he for the momentary trick Be perdurably fined?(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 45)
Isabel--   What says my brother?  Death is a fearful thing.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 46)
And shamed life a hateful.   Ay, but to die, and go we know not where, To lie in cold obstruction and to rot, This sensible warm motion to become kneaded clod; and the delighted spirit To bathe in fiery floods, or to reside In thrilling region of thick-ribbed ice, To be imprisoned in the viewless winds And blown with restless violence round about The pendent world; or to be worse than worst Of those that lawless and incertain thought Imagine howling--'tis too horrible.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 47)
The weariest and most loathed worldly life That age, ache, penury, and imprisonment Can lay on nature is a paradise To what we fear of death.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 48)
Alas, alas!  Sweet sister, let me live. What sin you do to save a brother's life, Nature dispenses with the deed so far That it becomes a virtue.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 49)
you beast! faithless coward, dishonest wretch, Wilt thou be made a man out of my vice?(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 50)
Is 't not a kind of incest to take life From thine own sister's shame?(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 51)
What should think? Heaven shield my mother played my father fair, For such a warped slip of wilderness Ne'er issued from his blood.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 52)
Take my defiance; Die, perish. Might but my bending down Reprieve thee from thy fate, it should proceed.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 53)
I'll pray a thousand prayers for thy death, No word to save thee.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 54)
Nay, hear me, Isabel--  fie, fie, fie! Thy sin's not accidental, but a trade.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 55)
Mercy to thee would prove itself a bawd. 'Tis best that thou diest quickly.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 56)
hear me, Isabella--      Vouchsafe a word, young sister, but one word.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 57)
What is your will?  Might you dispense with your leisure, would by and by have some speech with you.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 58)
The satisfaction would require is likewise your own benefit.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 59)
have no superfluous leisure. My stay must be stolen out of other affairs, but will attend you awhile.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 60)
Son, have overheard what hath passed between you and your sister.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 61)
Angelo had never the purpose to corrupt her; only he hath made an assay of her virtue, to practice his judgment with the disposition of natures.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 62)
She, having the truth of honor in her, hath made him that gracious denial which he is most glad to receive.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 63)
am confessor to Angelo, and know this to be true.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 64)
Therefore prepare yourself to death. Do not satisfy your resolution with hopes that are fallible.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 65)
Tomorrow you must die. Go to your knees and make ready.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 66)
Let me ask my sister pardon. am so out of love with life that will sue to be rid of it.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 67)
Hold you there. Farewell.--Provost, a word with you.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 68)
What's your will, father?  That now you are come, you will be gone.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 69)
Leave me awhile with the maid. My mind promises with my habit no loss shall touch her by my company.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 70)
In good time.  The hand that hath made you fair hath made you good.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 71)
The goodness that is cheap in beauty makes beauty brief in goodness, but grace, being the soul of your complexion, shall keep the body of it ever fair.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 72)
The assault that Angelo hath made to you, fortune hath conveyed to my understanding; and but that frailty hath examples for his falling, should wonder at Angelo.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 73)
How will you do to content this substitute and to save your brother?(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 74)
am now going to resolve him. had rather my brother die by the law than my son should be unlawfully born.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 75)
But, how much is the good duke deceived in Angelo!(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 76)
If ever he return, and can speak to him, will open my lips in vain, or discover his government.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 77)
That shall not be much amiss. Yet, as the matter now stands, he will avoid your accusation: he made trial of you only.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 78)
Therefore, fasten your ear on my advisings. To the love have in doing good, a remedy presents itself.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 79)
do make myself believe that you may most uprighteously do a poor wronged lady a merited benefit, redeem your brother from the angry law, do no stain to your own gracious person, and much please the absent duke, if peradventure he shall ever return to have hearing of this business.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 80)
Let me hear you speak farther. have spirit to do anything that appears not foul in the truth of my spirit.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 81)
Virtue is bold, and goodness never fearful. Have you not heard speak of Mariana, the sister of Frederick, the great soldier who miscarried at sea?(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 82)
have heard of the lady, and good words went with her name.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 83)
She should this Angelo have married, was affianced to her oath, and the nuptial appointed.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 84)
Between which time of the contract and limit of the solemnity, her brother Frederick was wracked at sea, having in that perished vessel the dowry of his sister.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 85)
But mark how heavily this befell to the poor gentlewoman.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 86)
There she lost a noble and renowned brother, in his love toward her ever most kind and natural; with him, the portion and sinew of her fortune, her marriage dowry; with both, her combinate husband, this well-seeming Angelo.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 87)
Can this be so? Did Angelo so leave her?  Left her in her tears and dried not one of them with his comfort, swallowed his vows whole, pretending in her discoveries of dishonor; in few, bestowed her on her own lamentation, which she yet wears for his sake; and he, a marble to her tears, is washed with them but relents not.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 88)
What a merit were it in death to take this poor maid from the world!(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 89)
What corruption in this life, that it will let this man live!(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 90)
But how out of this can she avail?  It is a rupture that you may easily heal, and the cure of it not only saves your brother, but keeps you from dishonor in doing it.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 91)
Show me how, good father.  This forenamed maid hath yet in her the continuance of her first affection.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 92)
His unjust unkindness, that in all reason should have quenched her love, hath, like an impediment in the current, made it more violent and unruly.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 93)
Go you to Angelo, answer his requiring with a plausible obedience, agree with his demands to the point.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 94)
Only refer yourself to this advantage: first, that your stay with him may not be long, that the time may have all shadow and silence in it, and the place answer to convenience.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 95)
This being granted in course, and now follows all: we shall advise this wronged maid to stead up your appointment, go in your place.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 96)
If the encounter acknowledge itself hereafter, it may compel him to her recompense; and here, by this, is your brother saved, your honor untainted, the poor Mariana advantaged, and the corrupt deputy scaled.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 97)
The maid will frame and make fit for his attempt.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 98)
If you think well to carry this as you may, the doubleness of the benefit defends the deceit from reproof.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 99)
What think you of it?  The image of it gives me content already, and trust it will grow to a most prosperous perfection.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 100)
It lies much in your holding up. Haste you speedily to Angelo.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 101)
If for this night he entreat you to his bed, give him promise of satisfaction.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 102)
will presently to Saint Luke's. There at the moated grange resides this dejected Mariana.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 103)
At that place call upon me, and dispatch with Angelo that it may be quickly.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 104)
thank you for this comfort. Fare you well, good father.(Measure for Measure, Act 17, Scene 105)
Nay, if there be no remedy for it but that you will needs buy and sell men and women like beasts, we shall have all the world drink brown and white bastard.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 0)
heavens, what stuff is here?  'Twas never merry world since, of two usuries, the merriest was put down, and the worser allowed by order of law a furred gown to keep him warm, and furred with fox and lambskins too, to signify that craft, being richer than innocency, stands for the facing.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 1)
Come your way, sir.--Bless you, good father friar.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 2)
And you, good brother father. What offense hath this man made you, sir?(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 3)
Marry, sir, he hath offended the law; and, sir, we take him to be a thief too, sir, for we have found upon him, sir, a strange picklock, which we have sent to the Deputy.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 4)
Fie, sirrah, a bawd, a wicked bawd! The evil that thou causest to be done, That is thy means to live.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 5)
Do thou but think What 'tis to cram a maw or clothe a back From such a filthy vice; say to thyself, From their abominable and beastly touches drink, eat, array myself, and live.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 6)
Canst thou believe thy living is a life, So stinkingly depending?(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 7)
Go mend, go mend.  Indeed, it does stink in some sort, sir.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 8)
But yet, sir, would prove--   Nay, if the devil have given thee proofs for sin, Thou wilt prove his.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 9)
--Take him to prison, officer. Correction and instruction must both work Ere this rude beast will profit.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 10)
He must before the Deputy, sir; he has given him warning.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 11)
The Deputy cannot abide a whoremaster. If he be a whoremonger and comes before him, he were as good go a mile on his errand.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 12)
That we were all, as some would seem to be, From our faults, as faults from seeming, free.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 13)
His neck will come to your waist--a cord, sir.     spy comfort, cry bail.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 14)
Here's a gentleman and a friend of mine.  How now, noble Pompey?(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 15)
What, at the wheels of Caesar? Art thou led in triumph?(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 16)
What, is there none of Pygmalion's images, newly made woman, to be had now, for putting the hand in the pocket and extracting it clutched?(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 17)
What reply, ha? What sayst thou to this tune, matter, and method?(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 18)
Is 't not drowned i' th' last rain, ha? What sayst thou, trot?(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 19)
Is the world as it was, man? Which is the way? Is it sad and few words?(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 20)
Or how? The trick of it?  Still thus, and thus; still worse.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 21)
How doth my dear morsel, thy mistress? Procures she still, ha?(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 22)
Troth, sir, she hath eaten up all her beef, and she is herself in the tub.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 23)
Why, 'tis good. It is the right of it. It must be so.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 24)
Ever your fresh whore and your powdered bawd, an unshunned consequence; it must be so.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 25)
Art going to prison, Pompey?  Yes, faith, sir.  Why, 'tis not amiss, Pompey.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 26)
Farewell. Go say sent thee thither. For debt, Pompey?(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 27)
Or how?  For being a bawd, for being a bawd.  Well, then, imprison him.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 28)
If imprisonment be the due of a bawd, why, 'tis his right.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 29)
Bawd is he, doubtless, and of antiquity too. Bawd born.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 30)
-- Farewell, good Pompey. Commend me to the prison, Pompey.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 31)
You will turn good husband now, Pompey; you will keep the house.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 32)
hope, sir, your good Worship will be my bail.  No, indeed, will not, Pompey; it is not the wear.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 33)
will pray, Pompey, to increase your bondage. If you take it not patiently, why, your mettle is the more.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 34)
Adieu, trusty Pompey.--Bless you, friar.  And you.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 35)
Does Bridget paint still, Pompey, ha?  Come your ways, sir, come.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 36)
You will not bail me, then, sir?  Then, Pompey, nor now.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 37)
--What news abroad, friar? What news?  Come your ways, sir, come.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 38)
Go to kennel, Pompey, go.  What news, friar, of the Duke?(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 39)
know none. Can you tell me of any?  Some say he is with the Emperor of Russia; other some, he is in Rome.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 40)
But where is he, think you?  know not where, but wheresoever, wish him well.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 41)
It was a mad fantastical trick of him to steal from the state and usurp the beggary he was never born to.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 42)
Lord Angelo dukes it well in his absence. He puts transgression to 't.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 43)
He does well in 't.  little more lenity to lechery would do no harm in him.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 44)
Something too crabbed that way, friar.  It is too general a vice, and severity must cure it.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 45)
Yes, in good sooth, the vice is of a great kindred; it is well allied, but it is impossible to extirp it quite, friar, till eating and drinking be put down.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 46)
They say this Angelo was not made by man and woman after this downright way of creation.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 47)
Is it true, think you?  How should he be made, then?(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 48)
Some report a sea-maid spawned him; some, that he was begot between two stockfishes.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 49)
But it is certain that when he makes water, his urine is congealed ice; that know to be true.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 50)
And he is a motion generative, that's infallible.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 51)
You are pleasant, sir, and speak apace.  Why, what a ruthless thing is this in him, for the rebellion of a codpiece to take away the life of a man!(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 52)
Would the duke that is absent have done this? Ere he would have hanged a man for the getting a hundred bastards, he would have paid for the nursing a thousand.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 53)
He had some feeling of the sport, he knew the service, and that instructed him to mercy.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 54)
never heard the absent duke much detected for women.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 55)
He was not inclined that way.  sir, you are deceived.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 56)
'Tis not possible.  Who, not the Duke? Yes, your beggar of fifty; and his use was to put a ducat in her clack-dish.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 57)
The Duke had crotchets in him. He would be drunk too, that let me inform you.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 58)
You do him wrong, surely.  Sir, was an inward of his.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 59)
shy fellow was the Duke, and believe know the cause of his withdrawing.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 60)
What, prithee, might be the cause?  No, pardon. 'Tis a secret must be locked within the teeth and the lips.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 61)
But this can let you understand: the greater file of the subject held the Duke to be wise.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 62)
Wise? Why, no question but he was.  very superficial, ignorant, unweighing fellow.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 63)
Either this is envy in you, folly, or mistaking.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 64)
The very stream of his life and the business he hath helmed must, upon a warranted need, give him a better proclamation.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 65)
Let him be but testimonied in his own bringings-forth, and he shall appear to the envious a scholar, a statesman, and a soldier.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 66)
Therefore you speak unskillfully. Or, if your knowledge be more, it is much darkened in your malice.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 67)
Sir, know him, and love him.  Love talks with better knowledge, and knowledge with dearer love.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 68)
Come, sir, know what know.  can hardly believe that, since you know not what you speak.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 69)
But if ever the Duke return, as our prayers are he may, let me desire you to make your answer before him.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 70)
If it be honest you have spoke, you have courage to maintain it.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 71)
am bound to call upon you, and, pray you, your name?(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 72)
Sir, my name is Lucio, well known to the Duke.  He shall know you better, sir, if may live to report you.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 73)
fear you not.  you hope the Duke will return no more, or you imagine me too unhurtful an opposite.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 74)
But indeed can do you little harm; you'll forswear this again.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 75)
I'll be hanged first. Thou art deceived in me, friar.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 76)
But no more of this. Canst thou tell if Claudio die tomorrow or no?(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 77)
Why should he die, sir?  Why? For filling a bottle with a tundish.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 78)
would the Duke we talk of were returned again. This ungenitured agent will unpeople the province with continency.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 79)
Sparrows must not build in his house eaves, because they are lecherous.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 80)
The Duke yet would have dark deeds darkly answered.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 81)
He would never bring them to light Would he were returned.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 82)
Marry, this Claudio is condemned for untrussing. Farewell, good friar.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 83)
prithee pray for me. The Duke, say to thee again, would eat mutton on Fridays.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 84)
He's now past it, yet--and say to thee-- he would mouth with a beggar though she smelt brown bread and garlic.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 85)
Say that said so. Farewell.    No might nor greatness in mortality Can censure scape.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 86)
Back-wounding calumny The whitest virtue strikes.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 87)
What king so strong Can tie the gall up in the slanderous tongue?(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 88)
But who comes here?      Go, away with her to prison.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 89)
Good my lord, be good to me. Your Honor is accounted a merciful man, good my lord.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 90)
Double and treble admonition, and still forfeit in the same kind?(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 91)
This would make mercy swear and play the tyrant.  bawd of eleven years' continuance, may it please your Honor.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 92)
My lord, this is one Lucio's information against me.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 93)
Mistress Kate Keepdown was with child by him in the Duke's time; he promised her marriage.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 94)
His child is a year and a quarter old come Philip and Jacob.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 95)
have kept it myself, and see how he goes about to abuse me.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 96)
That fellow is a fellow of much license. Let him be called before us.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 97)
Away with her to prison.-- Go to, no more words. Provost, my brother Angelo will not be altered.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 98)
Claudio must die tomorrow. Let him be furnished with divines and have all charitable preparation.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 99)
If my brother wrought by my pity, it should not be so with him.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 100)
So please you, this friar hath been with him, and advised him for th' entertainment of death.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 101)
Good even, good father.  Bliss and goodness on you.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 102)
Of whence are you?   Not of this country, though my chance is now To use it for my time.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 103)
am a brother Of gracious order, late come from the See In special business from his Holiness.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 104)
What news abroad i' th' world?  None but that there is so great a fever on goodness that the dissolution of it must cure it.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 105)
Novelty is only in request, and it is as dangerous to be aged in any kind of course as it is virtuous to be constant in any undertaking.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 106)
There is scarce truth enough alive to make societies secure, but security enough to make fellowships accursed.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 107)
Much upon this riddle runs the wisdom of the world.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 108)
This news is old enough, yet it is every day's news.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 109)
