pray you, sir, of what disposition was the Duke?  One that, above all other strifes, contended especially to know himself.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 110)
What pleasure was he given to?  Rather rejoicing to see another merry than merry at anything which professed to make him rejoice--a gentleman of all temperance.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 111)
But leave we him to his events, with a prayer they may prove prosperous, and let me desire to know how you find Claudio prepared.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 112)
am made to understand that you have lent him visitation.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 113)
He professes to have received no sinister measure from his judge but most willingly humbles himself to the determination of justice.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 114)
Yet had he framed to himself, by the instruction of his frailty, many deceiving promises of life, which by my good leisure, have discredited to him, and now is he resolved to die.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 115)
You have paid the heavens your function and the prisoner the very debt of your calling.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 116)
have labored for the poor gentleman to the extremest shore of my modesty, but my brother justice have found so severe that he hath forced me to tell him he is indeed Justice.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 117)
If his own life answer the straitness of his proceeding, it shall become him well; wherein if he chance to fail, he hath sentenced himself.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 118)
am going to visit the prisoner. Fare you well.  Peace be with you.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 119)
He who the sword of heaven will bear Should be as holy as severe, Pattern in himself to know, Grace to stand, and virtue go; More nor less to others paying Than by self-offenses weighing.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 120)
Shame to him whose cruel striking Kills for faults of his own liking.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 121)
Twice treble shame on Angelo, To weed my vice, and let his grow.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 122)
what may man within him hide, Though angel on the outward side!(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 123)
How may likeness made in crimes, Making practice on the times, To draw with idle spiders' strings Most ponderous and substantial things.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 124)
Craft against vice must apply. With Angelo tonight shall lie His old betrothed but despised.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 125)
So disguise shall, by th' disguised, Pay with falsehood false exacting And perform an old contracting.(Measure for Measure, Act 18, Scene 126)
How now, spirit? Whither wander you?   Over hill, over dale, Thorough bush, thorough brier, Over park, over pale, Thorough flood, thorough fire; do wander everywhere, Swifter than the moon's sphere.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 0)
And serve the Fairy Queen, To dew her orbs upon the green.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 1)
The cowslips tall her pensioners be; In their gold coats spots you see; Those be rubies, fairy favors; In those freckles live their savors.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 2)
must go seek some dewdrops here And hang a pearl in every cowslip's ear.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 3)
Farewell, thou lob of spirits. I'll be gone. Our queen and all her elves come here anon.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 4)
The King doth keep his revels here tonight. Take heed the Queen come not within his sight, For Oberon is passing fell and wrath Because that she, as her attendant, hath lovely boy stolen from an Indian king; She never had so sweet a changeling.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 5)
And jealous Oberon would have the child Knight of his train, to trace the forests wild.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 6)
But she perforce withholds the loved boy, Crowns him with flowers and makes him all her joy.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 7)
And now they never meet in grove or green, By fountain clear or spangled starlight sheen, But they do square, that all their elves for fear Creep into acorn cups and hide them there.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 8)
Either mistake your shape and making quite, Or else you are that shrewd and knavish sprite Called Robin Goodfellow.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 9)
Are not you he That frights the maidens of the villagery, Skim milk, and sometimes labor in the quern And bootless make the breathless huswife churn, And sometime make the drink to bear no barm, Mislead night wanderers, laughing at their harm?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 10)
Those that "Hobgoblin" call you and "sweet Puck," You do their work, and they shall have good luck.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 11)
Are not you he?  Thou speakest aright. am that merry wanderer of the night.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 12)
jest to Oberon and make him smile When a fat and bean-fed horse beguile, Neighing in likeness of a filly foal.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 13)
And sometime lurk in a gossip's bowl In very likeness of a roasted crab, And, when she drinks, against her lips bob And on her withered dewlap pour the ale.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 14)
The wisest aunt, telling the saddest tale, Sometime for three-foot stool mistaketh me; Then slip from her bum, down topples she And "Tailor!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 15)
" cries and falls into a cough, And then the whole choir hold their hips and loffe And waxen in their mirth and neeze and swear merrier hour was never wasted there.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 16)
But room, fairy. Here comes Oberon.   And here my mistress.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 17)
Would that he were gone!       Ill met by moonlight, proud Titania.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 18)
What, jealous Oberon? Fairies, skip hence. have forsworn his bed and company.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 19)
Tarry, rash wanton. Am not thy lord?   Then must be thy lady.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 20)
But know When thou hast stolen away from Fairyland And in the shape of Corin sat all day Playing on pipes of corn and versing love To amorous Phillida.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 21)
Why art thou here, Come from the farthest steep of India, But that, forsooth, the bouncing Amazon, Your buskined mistress and your warrior love, To Theseus must be wedded, and you come To give their bed joy and prosperity?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 22)
How canst thou thus for shame, Titania, Glance at my credit with Hippolyta, Knowing know thy love to Theseus?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 23)
Didst not thou lead him through the glimmering night From Perigouna, whom he ravished, And make him with fair Aegles break his faith, With Ariadne and Antiopa?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 24)
These are the forgeries of jealousy; And never, since the middle summer's spring, Met we on hill, in dale, forest, or mead, By paved fountain or by rushy brook, Or in the beached margent of the sea, To dance our ringlets to the whistling wind, But with thy brawls thou hast disturbed our sport.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 25)
Therefore the winds, piping to us in vain, As in revenge have sucked up from the sea Contagious fogs, which, falling in the land, Hath every pelting river made so proud That they have overborne their continents.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 26)
The ox hath therefore stretched his yoke in vain, The plowman lost his sweat, and the green corn Hath rotted ere his youth attained a beard.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 27)
The fold stands empty in the drowned field, And crows are fatted with the murrain flock.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 28)
The nine-men's-morris is filled up with mud, And the quaint mazes in the wanton green, For lack of tread, are undistinguishable.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 29)
The human mortals want their winter here. No night is now with hymn or carol blessed.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 30)
Therefore the moon, the governess of floods, Pale in her anger, washes all the air, That rheumatic diseases do abound.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 31)
And thorough this distemperature we see The seasons alter: hoary-headed frosts Fall in the fresh lap of the crimson rose, And on old Hiems' thin and icy crown An odorous chaplet of sweet summer buds Is, as in mockery, set.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 32)
The spring, the summer, The childing autumn, angry winter, change Their wonted liveries, and the mazed world By their increase now knows not which is which.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 33)
And this same progeny of evils comes From our debate, from our dissension; We are their parents and original.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 34)
Do you amend it, then. It lies in you. Why should Titania cross her Oberon?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 35)
do but beg a little changeling boy To be my henchman.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 36)
Set your heart at rest: The Fairyland buys not the child of me.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 37)
His mother was a vot'ress of my order, And in the spiced Indian air by night Full often hath she gossiped by my side And sat with me on Neptune's yellow sands, Marking th' embarked traders on the flood, When we have laughed to see the sails conceive And grow big-bellied with the wanton wind; Which she, with pretty and with swimming gait, Following (her womb then rich with my young squire), Would imitate and sail upon the land To fetch me trifles and return again, As from a voyage, rich with merchandise.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 38)
But she, being mortal, of that boy did die, And for her sake do rear up her boy, And for her sake will not part with him.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 39)
How long within this wood intend you stay?   Perchance till after Theseus' wedding day.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 40)
If you will patiently dance in our round And see our moonlight revels, go with us.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 41)
If not, shun me, and will spare your haunts.   Give me that boy and will go with thee.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 42)
Not for thy fairy kingdom. Fairies, away. We shall chide downright if longer stay.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 43)
Well, go thy way. Thou shalt not from this grove Till torment thee for this injury.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 44)
-- My gentle Puck, come hither. Thou rememb'rest Since once sat upon a promontory And heard a mermaid on a dolphin's back Uttering such dulcet and harmonious breath That the rude sea grew civil at her song And certain stars shot madly from their spheres To hear the sea-maid's music.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 45)
remember.   That very time saw (but thou couldst not), Flying between the cold moon and the Earth, Cupid all armed.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 46)
certain aim he took At a fair vestal throned by the west, And loosed his love-shaft smartly from his bow As it should pierce a hundred thousand hearts.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 47)
But might see young Cupid's fiery shaft Quenched in the chaste beams of the wat'ry moon, And the imperial vot'ress passed on In maiden meditation, fancy-free.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 48)
Yet marked where the bolt of Cupid fell. It fell upon a little western flower, Before, milk-white, now purple with love's wound, And maidens call it "love-in-idleness.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 49)
" Fetch me that flower; the herb showed thee once.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 50)
The juice of it on sleeping eyelids laid Will make or man or woman madly dote Upon the next live creature that it sees.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 51)
Fetch me this herb, and be thou here again Ere the leviathan can swim a league.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 52)
I'll put a girdle round about the Earth In forty minutes.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 53)
Having once this juice, I'll watch Titania when she is asleep And drop the liquor of it in her eyes.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 54)
The next thing then she, waking, looks upon (Be it on lion, bear, or wolf, or bull, On meddling monkey, or on busy ape) She shall pursue it with the soul of love.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 55)
And ere take this charm from off her sight (As can take it with another herb), I'll make her render up her page to me.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 56)
But who comes here? am invisible, And will overhear their conference.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 57)
love thee not; therefore pursue me not. Where is Lysander and fair Hermia?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 58)
The one I'll stay; the other stayeth me. Thou told'st me they were stol'n unto this wood, And here am and wood within this wood Because cannot meet my Hermia.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 59)
Hence, get thee gone, and follow me no more.   You draw me, you hard-hearted adamant!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 60)
But yet you draw not iron, for my heart Is true as steel.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 61)
Leave you your power to draw, And shall have no power to follow you.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 62)
Do entice you? Do speak you fair? Or rather do not in plainest truth Tell you do not, nor cannot love you?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 63)
And even for that do love you the more. am your spaniel, and, Demetrius, The more you beat me will fawn on you.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 64)
Use me but as your spaniel: spurn me, strike me, Neglect me, lose me; only give me leave (Unworthy as am) to follow you.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 65)
What worser place can beg in your love (And yet a place of high respect with me) Than to be used as you use your dog?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 66)
Tempt not too much the hatred of my spirit, For am sick when do look on thee.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 67)
And am sick when look not on you.   You do impeach your modesty too much To leave the city and commit yourself Into the hands of one that loves you not, To trust the opportunity of night And the ill counsel of a desert place With the rich worth of your virginity.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 68)
Your virtue is my privilege. For that It is not night when do see your face, Therefore think am not in the night.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 69)
Nor doth this wood lack worlds of company, For you, in my respect, are all the world.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 70)
Then, how can it be said am alone When all the world is here to look on me?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 71)
I'll run from thee and hide me in the brakes And leave thee to the mercy of wild beasts.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 72)
The wildest hath not such a heart as you. Run when you will.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 73)
The story shall be changed: Apollo flies and Daphne holds the chase; The dove pursues the griffin; the mild hind Makes speed to catch the tiger.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 74)
Bootless speed When cowardice pursues and valor flies!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 75)
will not stay thy questions. Let me go, Or if thou follow me, do not believe But shall do thee mischief in the wood.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 76)
Ay, in the temple, in the town, the field, You do me mischief.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 77)
Fie, Demetrius! Your wrongs do set a scandal on my sex.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 78)
We cannot fight for love as men may do. We should be wooed and were not made to woo.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 79)
I'll follow thee and make a heaven of hell To die upon the hand love so well.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 80)
Fare thee well, nymph. Ere he do leave this grove, Thou shalt fly him, and he shall seek thy love.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 81)
Hast thou the flower there? Welcome, wanderer.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 82)
Ay, there it is.  pray thee give it me.  know a bank where the wild thyme blows, Where oxlips and the nodding violet grows, Quite overcanopied with luscious woodbine, With sweet muskroses, and with eglantine.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 83)
There sleeps Titania sometime of the night, Lulled in these flowers with dances and delight.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 84)
And there the snake throws her enameled skin, Weed wide enough to wrap a fairy in.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 85)
And with the juice of this I'll streak her eyes And make her full of hateful fantasies.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 86)
Take thou some of it, and seek through this grove.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 87)
sweet Athenian lady is in love With a disdainful youth.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 88)
Anoint his eyes, But do it when the next thing he espies May be the lady.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 89)
Thou shalt know the man By the Athenian garments he hath on.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 90)
Effect it with some care, that he may prove More fond on her than she upon her love.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 91)
And look thou meet me ere the first cock crow.   Fear not, my lord.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 0, Scene 92)
2        Come, now a roundel and a fairy song; Then, for the third part of a minute, hence-- Some to kill cankers in the muskrose buds, Some war with reremice for their leathern wings To make my small elves coats, and some keep back The clamorous owl that nightly hoots and wonders At our quaint spirits.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 0)
Sing me now asleep. Then to your offices and let me rest.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 1)
You spotted snakes with double tongue, Thorny hedgehogs, be not seen.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 2)
Newts and blindworms, do no wrong, Come not near our Fairy Queen.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 3)
Philomel, with melody Sing in our sweet lullaby.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 4)
Lulla, lulla, lullaby, lulla, lulla, lullaby. Never harm Nor spell nor charm Come our lovely lady nigh.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 5)
So good night, with lullaby.   Weaving spiders, come not here.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 6)
Hence, you long-legged spinners, hence. Beetles black, approach not near.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 7)
Worm nor snail, do no offence.   Philomel, with melody Sing in our sweet lullaby.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 8)
Lulla, lulla, lullaby, lulla, lulla, lullaby. Never harm Nor spell nor charm Come our lovely lady nigh.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 9)
So good night, with lullaby.    Hence, away! Now all is well.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 10)
One aloof stand sentinel.       What thou seest when thou dost wake Do it for thy true love take.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 11)
Love and languish for his sake. Be it ounce, or cat, or bear, Pard, or boar with bristled hair, In thy eye that shall appear When thou wak'st, it is thy dear.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 12)
Wake when some vile thing is near.      Fair love, you faint with wand'ring in the wood.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 13)
And, to speak troth, have forgot our way. We'll rest us, Hermia, if you think it good, And tarry for the comfort of the day.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 14)
Be it so, Lysander. Find you out a bed, For upon this bank will rest my head.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 15)
One turf shall serve as pillow for us both; One heart, one bed, two bosoms, and one troth.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 16)
Nay, good Lysander. For my sake, my dear, Lie further off yet.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 17)
Do not lie so near.   take the sense, sweet, of my innocence!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 18)
Love takes the meaning in love's conference. mean that my heart unto yours is knit, So that but one heart we can make of it; Two bosoms interchained with an oath-- So then two bosoms and a single troth.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 19)
Then by your side no bed-room me deny, For lying so, Hermia, do not lie.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 20)
Lysander riddles very prettily. Now much beshrew my manners and my pride If Hermia meant to say Lysander lied.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 21)
But, gentle friend, for love and courtesy, Lie further off in human modesty.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 22)
Such separation, as may well be said, Becomes a virtuous bachelor and a maid.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 23)
So far be distant; and good night, sweet friend. Thy love ne'er alter till thy sweet life end!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 24)
"Amen, amen" to that fair prayer, say And then end life when end loyalty!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 25)
Here is my bed. Sleep give thee all his rest!   With half that wish the wisher's eyes be pressed!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 26)
Through the forest have gone, But Athenian found none On whose eyes might approve This flower's force in stirring love.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 27)
Night and silence! Who is here? Weeds of Athens he doth wear.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 28)
This is he my master said Despised the Athenian maid.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 29)
And here the maiden, sleeping sound On the dank and dirty ground.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 30)
Pretty soul, she durst not lie Near this lack-love, this kill-courtesy.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 31)
-- Churl, upon thy eyes throw All the power this charm doth owe.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 32)
When thou wak'st, let love forbid Sleep his seat on thy eyelid.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 33)
So, awake when am gone, For must now to Oberon.      Stay, though thou kill me, sweet Demetrius.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 34)
charge thee, hence, and do not haunt me thus.   wilt thou darkling leave me?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 35)
Do not so.   Stay, on thy peril. alone will go.   am out of breath in this fond chase.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 36)
The more my prayer, the lesser is my grace. Happy is Hermia, wheresoe'er she lies, For she hath blessed and attractive eyes.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 37)
How came her eyes so bright? Not with salt tears.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 38)
If so, my eyes are oftener washed than hers. No, no, am as ugly as a bear, For beasts that meet me run away for fear.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 39)
Therefore no marvel though Demetrius Do as a monster fly my presence thus.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 40)
What wicked and dissembling glass of mine Made me compare with Hermia's sphery eyne?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 41)
But who is here? Lysander, on the ground! Dead or asleep?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 42)
see no blood, no wound.-- Lysander, if you live, good sir, awake.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 43)
And run through fire will for thy sweet sake. Transparent Helena!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 44)
Nature shows art, That through thy bosom makes me see thy heart.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 45)
Where is Demetrius? how fit a word Is that vile name to perish on my sword!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 46)
Do not say so. Lysander, say not so. What though he love your Hermia?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 47)
Lord, what though? Yet Hermia still loves you. Then be content.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 48)
Content with Hermia? No, do repent The tedious minutes with her have spent.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 49)
Not Hermia, but Helena love. Who will not change a raven for a dove?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 50)
The will of man is by his reason swayed, And reason says you are the worthier maid.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 51)
Things growing are not ripe until their season; So being young, till now ripe not to reason.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 52)
And touching now the point of human skill, Reason becomes the marshal to my will And leads me to your eyes, where o'erlook Love's stories written in love's richest book.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 53)
Wherefore was to this keen mockery born? When at your hands did deserve this scorn?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 54)
Is 't not enough, is 't not enough, young man, That did never, no, nor never can Deserve a sweet look from Demetrius' eye, But you must flout my insufficiency?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 55)
Good troth, you do me wrong, good sooth, you do, In such disdainful manner me to woo.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 56)
But fare you well. Perforce must confess thought you lord of more true gentleness.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 57)
that a lady of one man refused Should of another therefore be abused!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 58)
She sees not Hermia.--Hermia, sleep thou there, And never mayst thou come Lysander near.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 59)
For, as a surfeit of the sweetest things The deepest loathing to the stomach brings, Or as the heresies that men do leave Are hated most of those they did deceive, So thou, my surfeit and my heresy, Of all be hated, but the most of me!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 60)
And, all my powers, address your love and might To honor Helen and to be her knight.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 61)
Help me, Lysander, help me! Do thy best To pluck this crawling serpent from my breast.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 62)
Ay me, for pity! What a dream was here! Lysander, look how do quake with fear.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 63)
Methought a serpent ate my heart away, And you sat smiling at his cruel prey.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 64)
Lysander! What, removed? Lysander, lord! What, out of hearing?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 65)
Gone? No sound, no word? Alack, where are you? Speak, an if you hear.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 66)
Speak, of all loves! swoon almost with fear.-- No?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 67)
Then well perceive you are not nigh. Either death or you I'll find immediately.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 1, Scene 68)
Are we all met?  Pat, pat. And here's a marvels convenient place for our rehearsal.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 0)
This green plot shall be our stage, this hawthorn brake our tiring-house, and we will do it in action as we will do it before the Duke.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 1)
Peter Quince?  What sayest thou, bully Bottom?  There are things in this comedy of Pyramus and Thisbe that will never please.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 2)
First, Pyramus must draw a sword to kill himself, which the ladies cannot abide.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 3)
How answer you that?  By 'r lakin, a parlous fear.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 4)
believe we must leave the killing out, when all is done.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 5)
Not a whit! have a device to make all well. Write me a prologue, and let the prologue seem to say we will do no harm with our swords and that Pyramus is not killed indeed.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 6)
And, for the more better assurance, tell them that Pyramus, am not Pyramus, but Bottom the weaver.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 7)
This will put them out of fear.  Well, we will have such a prologue, and it shall be written in eight and six.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 8)
No, make it two more. Let it be written in eight and eight.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 9)
Will not the ladies be afeard of the lion?  fear it, promise you.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 10)
Masters, you ought to consider with yourself, to bring in (God shield us!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 11)
) a lion among ladies is a most dreadful thing. For there is not a more fearful wildfowl than your lion living, and we ought to look to 't.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 12)
Therefore another prologue must tell he is not a lion.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 13)
Nay, you must name his name, and half his face must be seen through the lion's neck, and he himself must speak through, saying thus, or to the same defect: "Ladies," or "Fair ladies, would wish you," or would request you," or would entreat you not to fear, not to tremble!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 14)
My life for yours. If you think come hither as a lion, it were pity of my life.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 15)
No, am no such thing. am a man as other men are." And there indeed let him name his name and tell them plainly he is Snug the joiner.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 16)
Well, it shall be so. But there is two hard things: that is, to bring the moonlight into a chamber, for you know Pyramus and Thisbe meet by moonlight.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 17)
Doth the moon shine that night we play our play?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 18)
calendar, a calendar! Look in the almanac. Find out moonshine, find out moonshine.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 19)
Yes, it doth shine that night.  Why, then, may you leave a casement of the great chamber window, where we play, open, and the moon may shine in at the casement.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 20)
Ay, or else one must come in with a bush of thorns and a lantern and say he comes to disfigure or to present the person of Moonshine.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 21)
Then there is another thing: we must have a wall in the great chamber, for Pyramus and Thisbe, says the story, did talk through the chink of a wall.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 22)
You can never bring in a wall. What say you, Bottom?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 23)
Some man or other must present Wall. And let him have some plaster, or some loam, or some roughcast about him to signify wall, or let him hold his fingers thus, and through that cranny shall Pyramus and Thisbe whisper.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 24)
If that may be, then all is well. Come, sit down, every mother's son, and rehearse your parts.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 25)
Pyramus, you begin. When you have spoken your speech, enter into that brake, and so everyone according to his cue.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 26)
What hempen homespuns have we swagg'ring here So near the cradle of the Fairy Queen?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 27)
What, a play toward? I'll be an auditor-- An actor too perhaps, if see cause.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 28)
Speak, Pyramus.--Thisbe, stand forth.   Thisbe, the flowers of odious savors sweet--  Odors, odors!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 29)
...odors savors sweet. So hath thy breath, my dearest Thisbe dear.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 30)
-- But hark, a voice! Stay thou but here awhile, And by and by will to thee appear.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 31)
stranger Pyramus than e'er played here.  Must speak now?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 32)
Ay, marry, must you, for you must understand he goes but to see a noise that he heard and is to come again.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 33)
Most radiant Pyramus, most lily-white of hue, Of color like the red rose on triumphant brier, Most brisky juvenal and eke most lovely Jew, As true as truest horse, that yet would never tire.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 34)
I'll meet thee, Pyramus, at Ninny's tomb.  "Ninus' tomb," man!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 35)
Why, you must not speak that yet. That you answer to Pyramus.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 36)
You speak all your part at once, cues and all.--Pyramus, enter.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 37)
Your cue is past. It is "never tire."   As true as truest horse, that yet would never tire.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 38)
If were fair, fair Thisbe, were only thine.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 39)
monstrous! strange! We are haunted. Pray, masters, fly, masters!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 40)
Help!    I'll follow you. I'll lead you about a round, Through bog, through bush, through brake, through brier.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 41)
Sometime a horse I'll be, sometime a hound, hog, a headless bear, sometime a fire, And neigh and bark and grunt and roar and burn, Like horse, hound, hog, bear, fire, at every turn.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 42)
Why do they run away? This is a knavery of them to make me afeard.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 43)
Bottom, thou art changed! What do see on thee?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 44)
What do you see? You see an ass-head of your own, do you?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 45)
Bless thee, Bottom, bless thee! Thou art translated!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 46)
see their knavery. This is to make an ass of me, to fright me, if they could.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 47)
But will not stir from this place, do what they can.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 48)
will walk up and down here, and will sing, that they shall hear am not afraid.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 49)
The ouzel cock, so black of hue, With orange-tawny bill, The throstle with his note so true, The wren with little quill--   What angel wakes me from my flow'ry bed?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 50)
The finch, the sparrow, and the lark, The plainsong cuckoo gray, Whose note full many a man doth mark And dares not answer "nay"-- for, indeed, who would set his wit to so foolish a bird?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 51)
Who would give a bird the lie though he cry "cuckoo" never so?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 52)
pray thee, gentle mortal, sing again. Mine ear is much enamored of thy note, So is mine eye enthralled to thy shape, And thy fair virtue's force perforce doth move me On the first view to say, to swear, love thee.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 53)
Methinks, mistress, you should have little reason for that.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 54)
And yet, to say the truth, reason and love keep little company together nowadays.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 55)
The more the pity that some honest neighbors will not make them friends.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 56)
Nay, can gleek upon occasion.   Thou art as wise as thou art beautiful.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 57)
Not so neither; but if had wit enough to get out of this wood, have enough to serve mine own turn.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 58)
Out of this wood do not desire to go. Thou shalt remain here whether thou wilt or no.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 59)
am a spirit of no common rate. The summer still doth tend upon my state, And do love thee.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 60)
Therefore go with me. I'll give thee fairies to attend on thee, And they shall fetch thee jewels from the deep And sing while thou on pressed flowers dost sleep.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 61)
And will purge thy mortal grossness so That thou shalt like an airy spirit go.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 62)
-- Peaseblossom, Cobweb, Mote, and Mustardseed!      Ready.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 63)
And  And  And  Where shall we go?   Be kind and courteous to this gentleman.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 64)
Hop in his walks and gambol in his eyes; Feed him with apricocks and dewberries, With purple grapes, green figs, and mulberries; The honey-bags steal from the humble-bees, And for night-tapers crop their waxen thighs And light them at the fiery glowworms' eyes To have my love to bed and to arise; And pluck the wings from painted butterflies To fan the moonbeams from his sleeping eyes.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 65)
Nod to him, elves, and do him courtesies.  Hail, mortal!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 66)
Hail!  Hail!  Hail!  cry your Worships mercy, heartily.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 67)
--I beseech your Worship's name.  Cobweb.  shall desire you of more acquaintance, good Master Cobweb.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 68)
If cut my finger, shall make bold with you.--Your name, honest gentleman?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 69)
Peaseblossom.  pray you, commend me to Mistress Squash, your mother, and to Master Peascod, your father.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 70)
Good Master Peaseblossom, shall desire you of more acquaintance too.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 71)
--Your name, beseech you, sir?  Mustardseed.  Good Master Mustardseed, know your patience well.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 72)
That same cowardly, giantlike ox-beef hath devoured many a gentleman of your house.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 73)
promise you, your kindred hath made my eyes water ere now.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 74)
desire you of more acquaintance, good Master Mustardseed.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 75)
Come, wait upon him. Lead him to my bower. The moon, methinks, looks with a wat'ry eye, And when she weeps, weeps every little flower, Lamenting some enforced chastity.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 9, Scene 76)
3        wonder if Titania be awaked; Then what it was that next came in her eye, Which she must dote on in extremity.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 0)
Here comes my messenger. How now, mad spirit? What night-rule now about this haunted grove?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 1)
My mistress with a monster is in love. Near to her close and consecrated bower, While she was in her dull and sleeping hour, crew of patches, rude mechanicals, That work for bread upon Athenian stalls, Were met together to rehearse a play Intended for great Theseus' nuptial day.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 2)
The shallowest thick-skin of that barren sort, Who Pyramus presented in their sport, Forsook his scene and entered in a brake.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 3)
When did him at this advantage take, An ass's noll fixed on his head.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 4)
Anon his Thisbe must be answered, And forth my mimic comes.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 5)
When they him spy, As wild geese that the creeping fowler eye, Or russet-pated choughs, many in sort, Rising and cawing at the gun's report, Sever themselves and madly sweep the sky, So at his sight away his fellows fly, And, at our stamp, here o'er and o'er one falls.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 6)
He "Murder" cries and help from Athens calls. Their sense thus weak, lost with their fears thus strong, Made senseless things begin to do them wrong; For briers and thorns at their apparel snatch, Some sleeves, some hats, from yielders all things catch.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 7)
led them on in this distracted fear And left sweet Pyramus translated there.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 8)
When in that moment, so it came to pass, Titania waked and straightway loved an ass.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 9)
This falls out better than could devise. But hast thou yet latched the Athenian's eyes With the love juice, as did bid thee do?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 10)
took him sleeping--that is finished, too-- And the Athenian woman by his side, That, when he waked, of force she must be eyed.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 11)
Stand close. This is the same Athenian.   This is the woman, but not this the man.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 12)
why rebuke you him that loves you so? Lay breath so bitter on your bitter foe!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 13)
Now but chide, but should use thee worse, For thou, fear, hast given me cause to curse.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 14)
If thou hast slain Lysander in his sleep, Being o'er shoes in blood, plunge in the deep And kill me too.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 15)
The sun was not so true unto the day As he to me.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 16)
Would he have stolen away From sleeping Hermia? I'll believe as soon This whole Earth may be bored, and that the moon May through the center creep and so displease Her brother's noontide with th' Antipodes.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 17)
It cannot be but thou hast murdered him. So should a murderer look, so dead, so grim.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 18)
So should the murdered look, and so should Pierced through the heart with your stern cruelty.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 19)
Yet you, the murderer, look as bright, as clear, As yonder Venus in her glimmering sphere.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 20)
What's this to my Lysander? Where is he? Ah, good Demetrius, wilt thou give him me?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 21)
had rather give his carcass to my hounds.   Out, dog!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 22)
Out, cur! Thou driv'st me past the bounds Of maiden's patience.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 23)
Hast thou slain him, then? Henceforth be never numbered among men.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 24)
once tell true! Tell true, even for my sake! Durst thou have looked upon him, being awake?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 25)
And hast thou killed him sleeping? brave touch! Could not a worm, an adder, do so much?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 26)
An adder did it, for with doubler tongue Than thine, thou serpent, never adder stung.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 27)
You spend your passion on a misprised mood. am not guilty of Lysander's blood, Nor is he dead, for aught that can tell.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 28)
pray thee, tell me then that he is well.   An if could, what should get therefor?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 29)
privilege never to see me more. And from thy hated presence part so.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 30)
See me no more, whether he be dead or no.    There is no following her in this fierce vein.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 31)
Here, therefore, for a while will remain. So sorrow's heaviness doth heavier grow For debt that bankrout sleep doth sorrow owe, Which now in some slight measure it will pay, If for his tender here make some stay.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 32)
What hast thou done? Thou hast mistaken quite And laid the love juice on some true-love's sight.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 33)
Of thy misprision must perforce ensue Some true-love turned, and not a false turned true.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 34)
Then fate o'errules, that, one man holding troth, million fail, confounding oath on oath.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 35)
About the wood go swifter than the wind, And Helena of Athens look thou find.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 36)
All fancy-sick she is and pale of cheer With sighs of love that costs the fresh blood dear.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 37)
By some illusion see thou bring her here. I'll charm his eyes against she do appear.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 38)
go, go, look how go, Swifter than arrow from the Tartar's bow.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 39)
Flower of this purple dye, Hit with Cupid's archery, Sink in apple of his eye.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 40)
When his love he doth espy, Let her shine as gloriously As the Venus of the sky.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 41)
-- When thou wak'st, if she be by, Beg of her for remedy.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 42)
Captain of our fairy band, Helena is here at hand, And the youth, mistook by me, Pleading for a lover's fee.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 43)
Shall we their fond pageant see? Lord, what fools these mortals be!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 44)
Stand aside. The noise they make Will cause Demetrius to awake.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 45)
Then will two at once woo one. That must needs be sport alone.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 46)
And those things do best please me That befall prepost'rously.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 47)
Why should you think that should woo in scorn?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 48)
Scorn and derision never come in tears. Look when vow, weep; and vows so born, In their nativity all truth appears.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 49)
How can these things in me seem scorn to you, Bearing the badge of faith to prove them true?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 50)
You do advance your cunning more and more. When truth kills truth, devilish holy fray!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 51)
These vows are Hermia's. Will you give her o'er? Weigh oath with oath and you will nothing weigh.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 52)
Your vows to her and me, put in two scales, Will even weigh, and both as light as tales.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 53)
had no judgment when to her swore.   Nor none, in my mind, now you give her o'er.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 54)
Demetrius loves her, and he loves not you.   Helen, goddess, nymph, perfect, divine!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 55)
To what, my love, shall compare thine eyne? Crystal is muddy.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 56)
how ripe in show Thy lips, those kissing cherries, tempting grow!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 57)
That pure congealed white, high Taurus' snow, Fanned with the eastern wind, turns to a crow When thou hold'st up thy hand.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 58)
let me kiss This princess of pure white, this seal of bliss!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 59)
spite! hell! see you all are bent To set against me for your merriment.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 60)
If you were civil and knew courtesy, You would not do me thus much injury.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 61)
Can you not hate me, as know you do, But you must join in souls to mock me too?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 62)
If you were men, as men you are in show, You would not use a gentle lady so, To vow and swear and superpraise my parts, When, am sure, you hate me with your hearts.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 63)
You both are rivals and love Hermia, And now both rivals to mock Helena.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 64)
trim exploit, a manly enterprise, To conjure tears up in a poor maid's eyes With your derision!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 65)
None of noble sort Would so offend a virgin and extort poor soul's patience, all to make you sport.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 66)
You are unkind, Demetrius. Be not so, For you love Hermia; this you know know.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 67)
And here with all goodwill, with all my heart, In Hermia's love yield you up my part.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 68)
And yours of Helena to me bequeath, Whom do love and will do till my death.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 69)
Never did mockers waste more idle breath.   Lysander, keep thy Hermia.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 70)
will none. If e'er loved her, all that love is gone.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 71)
My heart to her but as guest-wise sojourned, And now to Helen is it home returned, There to remain.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 72)
Helen, it is not so.   Disparage not the faith thou dost not know, Lest to thy peril thou aby it dear.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 73)
Look where thy love comes. Yonder is thy dear.      Dark night, that from the eye his function takes, The ear more quick of apprehension makes; Wherein it doth impair the seeing sense, It pays the hearing double recompense.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 74)
Thou art not by mine eye, Lysander, found; Mine ear, thank it, brought me to thy sound.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 75)
But why unkindly didst thou leave me so?   Why should he stay whom love doth press to go?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 76)
What love could press Lysander from my side?   Lysander's love, that would not let him bide, Fair Helena, who more engilds the night Than all yon fiery oes and eyes of light.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 77)
Why seek'st thou me? Could not this make thee know The hate bear thee made me leave thee so?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 78)
You speak not as you think. It cannot be.   Lo, she is one of this confederacy!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 79)
Now perceive they have conjoined all three To fashion this false sport in spite of me.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 80)
-- Injurious Hermia, most ungrateful maid, Have you conspired, have you with these contrived, To bait me with this foul derision?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 81)
Is all the counsel that we two have shared, The sisters' vows, the hours that we have spent When we have chid the hasty-footed time For parting us--O, is all forgot?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 82)
All schooldays' friendship, childhood innocence? We, Hermia, like two artificial gods, Have with our needles created both one flower, Both on one sampler, sitting on one cushion, Both warbling of one song, both in one key, As if our hands, our sides, voices, and minds Had been incorporate.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 83)
So we grew together Like to a double cherry, seeming parted, But yet an union in partition, Two lovely berries molded on one stem; So with two seeming bodies but one heart, Two of the first, like coats in heraldry, Due but to one, and crowned with one crest.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 84)
And will you rent our ancient love asunder, To join with men in scorning your poor friend?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 85)
It is not friendly; 'tis not maidenly. Our sex, as well as may chide you for it, Though alone do feel the injury.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 86)
am amazed at your words. scorn you not. It seems that you scorn me.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 87)
Have you not set Lysander, as in scorn, To follow me and praise my eyes and face, And made your other love, Demetrius, Who even but now did spurn me with his foot, To call me goddess, nymph, divine and rare, Precious, celestial?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 88)
Wherefore speaks he this To her he hates? And wherefore doth Lysander Deny your love (so rich within his soul) And tender me, forsooth, affection, But by your setting on, by your consent?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 89)
What though be not so in grace as you, So hung upon with love, so fortunate, But miserable most, to love unloved?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 90)
This you should pity rather than despise.   understand not what you mean by this.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 91)
Ay, do. Persever, counterfeit sad looks, Make mouths upon me when turn my back, Wink each at other, hold the sweet jest up.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 92)
This sport, well carried, shall be chronicled. If you have any pity, grace, or manners, You would not make me such an argument.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 93)
But fare you well. 'Tis partly my own fault, Which death or absence soon shall remedy.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 94)

excellent!   Sweet, do not scorn her so.   If she cannot entreat, can compel.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 96)

Ay, by my life, And never did desire to see thee more.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 115)

me!  You juggler, you cankerblossom, You thief of love!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 117)

Why so? Ay, that way goes the game. Now perceive that she hath made compare Between our statures; she hath urged her height, And with her personage, her tall personage, Her height, forsooth, she hath prevailed with him.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 122)
And are you grown so high in his esteem Because am so dwarfish and so low?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 123)

evermore did love you, Hermia, Did ever keep your counsels, never wronged you-- Save that, in love unto Demetrius, told him of your stealth unto this wood.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 130)

when she is angry, she is keen and shrewd. She was a vixen when she went to school, And though she be but little, she is fierce.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 137)

will not trust you, Nor longer stay in your curst company.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 146)
Your hands than mine are quicker for a fray. My legs are longer though, to run away.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 147)
am amazed and know not what to say.   This is thy negligence.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 148)
Still thou mistak'st, Or else committ'st thy knaveries willfully.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 149)
Believe me, king of shadows, mistook. Did not you tell me should know the man By the Athenian garments he had on?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 150)
And so far blameless proves my enterprise That have 'nointed an Athenian's eyes; And so far am glad it so did sort, As this their jangling esteem a sport.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 151)
Thou seest these lovers seek a place to fight. Hie, therefore, Robin, overcast the night; The starry welkin cover thou anon With drooping fog as black as Acheron, And lead these testy rivals so astray As one come not within another's way.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 152)
Like to Lysander sometime frame thy tongue; Then stir Demetrius up with bitter wrong.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 153)
And sometime rail thou like Demetrius. And from each other look thou lead them thus, Till o'er their brows death-counterfeiting sleep With leaden legs and batty wings doth creep.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 154)
Then crush this herb into Lysander's eye,  Whose liquor hath this virtuous property, To take from thence all error with his might And make his eyeballs roll with wonted sight.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 155)
When they next wake, all this derision Shall seem a dream and fruitless vision.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 156)
And back to Athens shall the lovers wend, With league whose date till death shall never end.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 157)
Whiles in this affair do thee employ, I'll to my queen and beg her Indian boy; And then will her charmed eye release From monster's view, and all things shall be peace.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 158)
My fairy lord, this must be done with haste, For night's swift dragons cut the clouds full fast, And yonder shines Aurora's harbinger, At whose approach, ghosts wand'ring here and there Troop home to churchyards.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 159)
Damned spirits all, That in crossways and floods have burial, Already to their wormy beds are gone.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 160)
For fear lest day should look their shames upon, They willfully themselves exile from light And must for aye consort with black-browed night.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 161)
But we are spirits of another sort. with the Morning's love have oft made sport And, like a forester, the groves may tread Even till the eastern gate, all fiery red, Opening on Neptune with fair blessed beams, Turns into yellow gold his salt-green streams.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 162)
But notwithstanding, haste! Make no delay. We may effect this business yet ere day.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 163)
Up and down, up and down, will lead them up and down.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 164)
am feared in field and town. Goblin, lead them up and down.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 165)
Here comes one.      Where art thou, proud Demetrius?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 166)
Speak thou now.   Here, villain, drawn and ready.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 167)
Where art thou?  will be with thee straight.  Follow me, then, to plainer ground.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 168)
Lysander, speak again. Thou runaway, thou coward, art thou fled?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 169)
Speak! In some bush? Where dost thou hide thy head?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 170)
Thou coward, art thou bragging to the stars, Telling the bushes that thou look'st for wars, And wilt not come?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 171)
Come, recreant! Come, thou child! I'll whip thee with a rod.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 172)
He is defiled That draws a sword on thee.  Yea, art thou there?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 173)
Follow my voice. We'll try no manhood here.       He goes before me and still dares me on.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 174)
When come where he calls, then he is gone. The villain is much lighter-heeled than followed fast, but faster he did fly, That fallen am in dark uneven way, And here will rest me.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 175)
Come, thou gentle day, For if but once thou show me thy gray light, I'll find Demetrius and revenge this spite.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 176)
Ho, ho, ho! Coward, why com'st thou not?   Abide me, if thou dar'st, for well wot Thou runn'st before me, shifting every place, And dar'st not stand nor look me in the face.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 177)
Where art thou now?   Come hither. am here.   Nay, then, thou mock'st me.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 178)
Thou shalt buy this dear If ever thy face by daylight see.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 179)
Now go thy way. Faintness constraineth me To measure out my length on this cold bed.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 180)
By day's approach look to be visited.       weary night, long and tedious night, Abate thy hours!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 181)
Shine, comforts, from the east, That may back to Athens by daylight From these that my poor company detest.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 182)
And sleep, that sometimes shuts up sorrow's eye, Steal me awhile from mine own company.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 183)
Yet but three? Come one more. Two of both kinds makes up four.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 184)
Here she comes, curst and sad. Cupid is a knavish lad Thus to make poor females mad.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 185)
Never so weary, never so in woe, Bedabbled with the dew and torn with briers, can no further crawl, no further go.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 186)
My legs can keep no pace with my desires. Here will rest me till the break of day.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 187)
Heavens shield Lysander if they mean a fray!    On the ground Sleep sound.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 188)
I'll apply To your eye, Gentle lover, remedy.    When thou wak'st, Thou tak'st True delight In the sight Of thy former lady's eye.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 189)
And the country proverb known, That every man should take his own, In your waking shall be shown.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 190)
Jack shall have Jill; Naught shall go ill; The man shall have his mare again, and all shall be well.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 10, Scene 191)
Titania, Queen of Fairies, and Bottom and Fairies, and Oberon, the King, behind them unseen by those     Come, sit thee down upon this flow'ry bed, While thy amiable cheeks do coy, And stick muskroses in thy sleek smooth head, And kiss thy fair large ears, my gentle joy.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 0)
Where's Peaseblossom?  Ready.  Scratch my head, Peaseblossom.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 1)
Where's Monsieur Cobweb?  Ready.  Monsieur Cobweb, good monsieur, get you your weapons in your hand and kill me a red-hipped humble-bee on the top of a thistle, and, good monsieur, bring me the honey-bag.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 2)
Do not fret yourself too much in the action, monsieur, and, good monsieur, have a care the honey-bag break not; would be loath to have you overflown with a honey-bag, signior.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 3)
Where's Monsieur Mustardseed?  Ready.  Give me your neaf, Monsieur Mustardseed.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 4)
Pray you, leave your courtesy, good monsieur.  What's your will?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 5)
Nothing, good monsieur, but to help Cavalery Cobweb to scratch.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 6)
must to the barber's, monsieur, for methinks am marvels hairy about the face.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 7)
And am such a tender ass, if my hair do but tickle me, must scratch.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 8)
What, wilt thou hear some music, my sweet love?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 9)
have a reasonable good ear in music. Let's have the tongs and the bones.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 10)
Or say, sweet love, what thou desirest to eat.  Truly, a peck of provender.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 11)
could munch your good dry oats. Methinks have a great desire to a bottle of hay.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 12)
Good hay, sweet hay, hath no fellow.   have a venturous fairy that shall seek The squirrel's hoard and fetch thee new nuts.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 13)
had rather have a handful or two of dried peas. But, pray you, let none of your people stir me; have an exposition of sleep come upon me.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 14)
Sleep thou, and will wind thee in my arms.-- Fairies, begone, and be all ways away.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 15)
So doth the woodbine the sweet honeysuckle Gently entwist; the female ivy so Enrings the barky fingers of the elm.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 16)
how love thee! How dote on thee!       Welcome, good Robin.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 17)
Seest thou this sweet sight? Her dotage now do begin to pity.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 18)
For, meeting her of late behind the wood, Seeking sweet favors for this hateful fool, did upbraid her and fall out with her.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 19)
For she his hairy temples then had rounded With coronet of fresh and fragrant flowers; And that same dew, which sometime on the buds Was wont to swell like round and orient pearls, Stood now within the pretty flouriets' eyes, Like tears that did their own disgrace bewail.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 20)
When had at my pleasure taunted her, And she in mild terms begged my patience, then did ask of her her changeling child, Which straight she gave me, and her fairy sent To bear him to my bower in Fairyland.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 21)
And now have the boy, will undo This hateful imperfection of her eyes.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 22)
And, gentle Puck, take this transformed scalp From off the head of this Athenian swain, That he, awaking when the other do, May all to Athens back again repair And think no more of this night's accidents But as the fierce vexation of a dream.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 23)
But first will release the Fairy Queen.  Be as thou wast wont to be.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 24)
See as thou wast wont to see. Dian's bud o'er Cupid's flower Hath such force and blessed power.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 25)
Now, my Titania, wake you, my sweet queen.   My Oberon, what visions have seen!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 26)
Methought was enamored of an ass.   There lies your love.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 27)
How came these things to pass? how mine eyes do loathe his visage now!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 28)
Silence awhile.--Robin, take off this head.-- Titania, music call; and strike more dead Than common sleep of all these five the sense.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 29)
Music, ho, music such as charmeth sleep!   Now, when thou wak'st, with thine own fool's eyes peep.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 30)
Sound music. Come, my queen, take hands with me, And rock the ground whereon these sleepers be.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 31)
Now thou and are new in amity, And will tomorrow midnight solemnly Dance in Duke Theseus' house triumphantly, And bless it to all fair prosperity.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 32)
There shall the pairs of faithful lovers be Wedded, with Theseus, all in jollity.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 33)
Fairy king, attend and mark. do hear the morning lark.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 34)
Then, my queen, in silence sad Trip we after night's shade.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 35)
We the globe can compass soon, Swifter than the wand'ring moon.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 36)
Come, my lord, and in our flight Tell me how it came this night That sleeping here was found With these mortals on the ground.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 37)
Go, one of you, find out the Forester. For now our observation is performed, And, since we have the vaward of the day, My love shall hear the music of my hounds.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 38)
Uncouple in the western valley; let them go. Dispatch, say, and find the Forester.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 39)
We will, fair queen, up to the mountain's top And mark the musical confusion Of hounds and echo in conjunction.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 40)
was with Hercules and Cadmus once, When in a wood of Crete they bayed the bear With hounds of Sparta.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 41)
Never did hear Such gallant chiding, for, besides the groves, The skies, the fountains, every region near Seemed all one mutual cry.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 42)
never heard So musical a discord, such sweet thunder.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 43)
My hounds are bred out of the Spartan kind, So flewed, so sanded; and their heads are hung With ears that sweep away the morning dew; Crook-kneed, and dewlapped like Thessalian bulls; Slow in pursuit, but matched in mouth like bells, Each under each.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 44)
cry more tunable Was never holloed to, nor cheered with horn, In Crete, in Sparta, nor in Thessaly.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 45)
Judge when you hear.--But soft! What nymphs are these?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 46)
My lord, this is my daughter here asleep, And this Lysander; this Demetrius is, This Helena, old Nedar's Helena.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 47)
wonder of their being here together.   No doubt they rose up early to observe The rite of May, and hearing our intent, Came here in grace of our solemnity.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 48)
But speak, Egeus. Is not this the day That Hermia should give answer of her choice?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 49)
It is, my lord.   Go, bid the huntsmen wake them with their horns.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 50)
Good morrow, friends. Saint Valentine is past.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 51)
Begin these woodbirds but to couple now?    Pardon, my lord.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 52)
pray you all, stand up.  know you two are rival enemies.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 53)
How comes this gentle concord in the world, That hatred is so far from jealousy To sleep by hate and fear no enmity?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 54)
My lord, shall reply amazedly, Half sleep, half waking.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 55)
But as yet, swear, cannot truly say how came here.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 56)
But, as think--for truly would speak, And now do bethink me, so it is: came with Hermia hither.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 57)
Our intent Was to be gone from Athens, where we might, Without the peril of the Athenian law--   Enough, enough!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 58)
--My lord, you have enough. beg the law, the law upon his head.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 59)
They would have stol'n away.--They would, Demetrius, Thereby to have defeated you and me: You of your wife and me of my consent, Of my consent that she should be your wife.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 60)
My lord, fair Helen told me of their stealth, Of this their purpose hither to this wood, And in fury hither followed them, Fair Helena in fancy following me.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 61)
But, my good lord, wot not by what power (But by some power it is) my love to Hermia, Melted as the snow, seems to me now As the remembrance of an idle gaud Which in my childhood did dote upon, And all the faith, the virtue of my heart, The object and the pleasure of mine eye, Is only Helena.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 62)
To her, my lord, Was betrothed ere saw Hermia. But like a sickness did loathe this food.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 63)
But, as in health, come to my natural taste, Now do wish it, love it, long for it, And will forevermore be true to it.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 64)
Fair lovers, you are fortunately met. Of this discourse we more will hear anon.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 65)
-- Egeus, will overbear your will, For in the temple by and by, with us, These couples shall eternally be knit.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 66)
-- And, for the morning now is something worn, Our purposed hunting shall be set aside.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 67)
Away with us to Athens. Three and three, We'll hold a feast in great solemnity.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 68)
Come, Hippolyta.     These things seem small and undistinguishable, Like far-off mountains turned into clouds.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 69)
Methinks see these things with parted eye, When everything seems double.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 70)
So methinks. And have found Demetrius like a jewel, Mine own and not mine own.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 71)
Are you sure That we are awake? It seems to me That yet we sleep, we dream.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 72)
Do not you think The Duke was here and bid us follow him?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 73)
Yea, and my father.  And Hippolyta.   And he did bid us follow to the temple.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 74)
Why, then, we are awake. Let's follow him, And by the way let us recount our dreams.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 75)
When my cue comes, call me, and will answer. My next is "Most fair Pyramus.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 76)
" Hey-ho! Peter Quince! Flute the bellows-mender! Snout the tinker!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 77)
Starveling! God's my life! Stolen hence and left me asleep!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 78)
have had a most rare vision. have had a dream past the wit of man to say what dream it was.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 79)
Man is but an ass if he go about to expound this dream.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 80)
Methought was--there is no man can tell what. Methought was and methought had--but man is but a patched fool if he will offer to say what methought had.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 81)
The eye of man hath not heard, the ear of man hath not seen, man's hand is not able to taste, his tongue to conceive, nor his heart to report what my dream was.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 82)
will get Peter Quince to write a ballad of this dream.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 83)
It shall be called "Bottom's Dream" because it hath no bottom; and will sing it in the latter end of a play, before the Duke.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 84)
Peradventure, to make it the more gracious, shall sing it at her death.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 18, Scene 85)
4       Have you sent to Bottom's house? Is he come home yet?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 0)
He cannot be heard of. Out of doubt he is transported.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 1)
If he come not, then the play is marred. It goes not forward, doth it?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 2)
It is not possible. You have not a man in all Athens able to discharge Pyramus but he.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 3)
No, he hath simply the best wit of any handicraftman in Athens.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 4)
Yea, and the best person too, and he is a very paramour for a sweet voice.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 5)
You must say "paragon." "paramour" is (God bless us) a thing of naught.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 6)
Masters, the Duke is coming from the temple, and there is two or three lords and ladies more married.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 7)
If our sport had gone forward, we had all been made men.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 8)
sweet bully Bottom! Thus hath he lost sixpence a day during his life.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 9)
He could not have 'scaped sixpence a day. An the Duke had not given him sixpence a day for playing Pyramus, I'll be hanged.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 10)
He would have deserved it. Sixpence a day in Pyramus, or nothing!(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 11)
Where are these lads? Where are these hearts?(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 12)
Bottom! most courageous day! most happy hour!  Masters, am to discourse wonders.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 13)
But ask me not what; for, if tell you, am not true Athenian.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 14)
will tell you everything right as it fell out.  Let us hear, sweet Bottom.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 15)
Not a word of me. All that will tell you is that the Duke hath dined.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 16)
Get your apparel together, good strings to your beards, new ribbons to your pumps.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 17)
Meet presently at the palace. Every man look o'er his part.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 18)
For the short and the long is, our play is preferred.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 19)
In any case, let Thisbe have clean linen, and let not him that plays the lion pare his nails, for they shall hang out for the lion's claws.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 20)
And, most dear actors, eat no onions nor garlic, for we are to utter sweet breath, and do not doubt but to hear them say it is a sweet comedy.(A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act 19, Scene 21)
white, and three or four followers accordingly, with     Mislike me not for my complexion, The shadowed livery of the burnished sun, To whom am a neighbor and near bred.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 0, Scene 0)
Bring me the fairest creature northward born, Where Phoebus' fire scarce thaws the icicles, And let us make incision for your love To prove whose blood is reddest, his or mine.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 0, Scene 1)
tell thee, lady, this aspect of mine Hath feared the valiant; by my love swear The best regarded virgins of our clime Have loved it too.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 0, Scene 2)
would not change this hue Except to steal your thoughts, my gentle queen.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 0, Scene 3)
In terms of choice am not solely led By nice direction of a maiden's eyes; Besides, the lott'ry of my destiny Bars me the right of voluntary choosing.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 0, Scene 4)
But if my father had not scanted me And hedged me by his wit to yield myself His wife who wins me by that means told you, Yourself, renowned prince, then stood as fair As any comer have looked on yet For my affection.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 0, Scene 5)
Even for that thank you. Therefore pray you lead me to the caskets To try my fortune.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 0, Scene 6)
By this scimitar That slew the Sophy and a Persian prince, That won three fields of Sultan Solyman, would o'erstare the sternest eyes that look, Outbrave the heart most daring on the Earth, Pluck the young sucking cubs from the she-bear, Yea, mock the lion when he roars for prey, To win thee, lady.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 0, Scene 7)
But, alas the while! If Hercules and Lychas play at dice Which is the better man, the greater throw May turn by fortune from the weaker hand; So is Alcides beaten by his page, And so may blind Fortune leading me, Miss that which one unworthier may attain, And die with grieving.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 0, Scene 8)
You must take your chance And either not attempt to choose at all Or swear before you choose, if you choose wrong Never to speak to lady afterward In way of marriage.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 0, Scene 9)
Therefore be advised.   Nor will not. Come, bring me unto my chance.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 0, Scene 10)
First, forward to the temple. After dinner Your hazard shall be made.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 0, Scene 11)
Good fortune then, To make me blest--or cursed'st among men!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 0, Scene 12)
Certainly my conscience will serve me to run from this Jew my master.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 0)
The fiend is at mine elbow and tempts me, saying to me "Gobbo, Lancelet Gobbo, good Lancelet," or "good Gobbo," or "good Lancelet Gobbo, use your legs, take the start, run away.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 1)
" My conscience says "No. Take heed, honest Lancelet, take heed, honest Gobbo," or, as aforesaid, "honest Lancelet Gobbo, do not run; scorn running with thy heels.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 2)
" Well, the most courageous fiend bids me pack. "Fia!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 3)
" says the fiend. "Away!" says the fiend. "For the heavens, rouse up a brave mind," says the fiend, "and run!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 4)
" Well, my conscience, hanging about the neck of my heart, says very wisely to me "My honest friend Lancelet, being an honest man's son"--or rather, an honest woman's son, for indeed my father did something smack, something grow to--he had a kind of taste--well, my conscience says "Lancelet, budge not.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 5)
" "Budge," says the fiend. "Budge not," says my conscience.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 6)
"Conscience," say "you counsel well." "Fiend," say "you counsel well.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 7)
" To be ruled by my conscience, should stay with the Jew my master, who (God bless the mark) is a kind of devil; and to run away from the Jew, should be ruled by the fiend, who (saving your reverence) is the devil himself.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 8)
