Certainly the Jew is the very devil incarnation, and, in my conscience, my conscience is but a kind of hard conscience to offer to counsel me to stay with the Jew.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 9)
The fiend gives the more friendly counsel. will run, fiend.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 10)
My heels are at your commandment. will run.     Master young man, you, pray you, which is the way to Master Jew's?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 11)
heavens, this is my true begotten father, who being more than sandblind, high gravelblind, knows me not.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 12)
will try confusions with him.  Master young gentleman, pray you, which is the way to Master Jew's?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 13)
Turn up on your right hand at the next turning, but at the next turning of all on your left; marry, at the very next turning, turn of no hand, but turn down indirectly to the Jew's house.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 14)
Be God's sonties, 'twill be a hard way to hit. Can you tell me whether one Lancelet, that dwells with him, dwell with him or no?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 15)
Talk you of young Master Lancelet? Mark me now, now will raise the waters.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 16)
--Talk you of young Master Lancelet?  No master, sir, but a poor man's son.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 17)
His father, though say 't, is an honest exceeding poor man and, God be thanked, well to live.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 18)
Well, let his father be what he will, we talk of young Master Lancelet.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 19)
Your Worship's friend, and Lancelet, sir.  But pray you, ergo, old man, ergo, beseech you, talk you of young Master Lancelet?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 20)
Of Lancelet, an 't please your mastership.  Ergo, Master Lancelet.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 21)
Talk not of Master Lancelet, father, for the young gentleman, according to Fates and Destinies, and such odd sayings, the Sisters Three, and such branches of learning, is indeed deceased, or, as you would say in plain terms, gone to heaven.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 22)
Marry, God forbid! The boy was the very staff of my age, my very prop.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 23)
Do look like a cudgel or a hovel-post, a staff or a prop?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 24)
--Do you know me, father?  Alack the day, know you not, young gentleman.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 25)
But pray you tell me, is my boy, God rest his soul, alive or dead?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 26)
Do you not know me, father?  Alack, sir, am sandblind.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 27)
know you not.  Nay, indeed, if you had your eyes, you might fail of the knowing me.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 28)
It is a wise father that knows his own child. Well, old man, will tell you news of your son.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 29)
Give me your blessing. Truth will come to light, murder cannot be hid long--a man's son may, but in the end, truth will out.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 30)
Pray you, sir, stand up! am sure you are not Lancelet my boy.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 31)
Pray you, let's have no more fooling about it, but give me your blessing.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 32)
am Lancelet, your boy that was, your son that is, your child that shall be.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 33)
cannot think you are my son.  know not what shall think of that; but am Lancelet, the Jew's man, and am sure Margery your wife is my mother.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 34)
Her name is Margery, indeed. I'll be sworn if thou be Lancelet, thou art mine own flesh and blood.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 35)
Lord worshiped might He be, what a beard hast thou got!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 36)
Thou hast got more hair on thy chin than Dobbin my fill-horse has on his tail.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 37)
It should seem, then, that Dobbin's tail grows backward.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 38)
am sure he had more hair of his tail than have of my face when last saw him.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 39)
Lord, how art thou changed! How dost thou and thy master agree?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 40)
have brought him a present. How 'gree you now?  Well, well.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 41)
But for mine own part, as have set up my rest to run away, so will not rest till have run some ground.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 42)
My master's a very Jew. Give him a present! Give him a halter.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 43)
am famished in his service. You may tell every finger have with my ribs.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 44)
Father, am glad you are come! Give me your present to one Master Bassanio, who indeed gives rare new liveries.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 45)
If serve not him, will run as far as God has any ground.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 46)
rare fortune, here comes the man! To him, father, for am a Jew if serve the Jew any longer.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 47)
You may do so, but let it be so hasted that supper be ready at the farthest by five of the clock.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 48)
See these letters delivered, put the liveries to making, and desire Gratiano to come anon to my lodging.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 49)
To him, father.  God bless your Worship.  Gramercy.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 50)
Wouldst thou aught with me?  Here's my son, sir, a poor boy--  Not a poor boy, sir, but the rich Jew's man, that would, sir, as my father shall specify--  He hath a great infection, sir, as one would say, to serve--  Indeed, the short and the long is, serve the Jew, and have a desire, as my father shall specify--  His master and he (saving your Worship's reverence) are scarce cater-cousins--  To be brief, the very truth is that the Jew, having done me wrong, doth cause me, as my father being, hope, an old man, shall frutify unto you--  have here a dish of doves that would bestow upon your Worship, and my suit is--  In very brief, the suit is impertinent to myself, as your Worship shall know by this honest old man, and though say it, though old man yet poor man, my father--  One speak for both.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 51)
What would you?  Serve you, sir.  That is the very defect of the matter, sir.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 52)
know thee well. Thou hast obtained thy suit. Shylock thy master spoke with me this day, And hath preferred thee, if it be preferment To leave a rich Jew's service, to become The follower of so poor a gentleman.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 53)
The old proverb is very well parted between my master Shylock and you, sir: you have "the grace of God," sir, and he hath "enough.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 54)
"   Thou speak'st it well.--Go, father, with thy son.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 55)
-- Take leave of thy old master, and inquire My lodging out.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 56)
Give him a livery More guarded than his fellows'.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 57)
See it done.   Father, in. cannot get a service, no!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 58)
have ne'er a tongue in my head! Well, if any man in Italy have a fairer table which doth offer to swear upon a book--I shall have good fortune, go to!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 59)
Here's a simple line of life. Here's a small trifle of wives--alas, fifteen wives is nothing; eleven widows and nine maids is a simple coming-in for one man--and then to 'scape drowning thrice, and to be in peril of my life with the edge of a featherbed!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 60)
Here are simple 'scapes. Well, if Fortune be a woman, she's a good wench for this gear.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 61)
Father, come. I'll take my leave of the Jew in the twinkling.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 62)
pray thee, good Leonardo, think on this.  These things being bought and orderly bestowed, Return in haste, for do feast tonight My best esteemed acquaintance.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 63)
Hie thee, go.   My best endeavors shall be done herein.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 64)
Where's your master?  Yonder, sir, he walks.  Signior Bassanio!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 65)
Gratiano!  have suit to you.  You have obtained it.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 66)
You must not deny me. must go with you to Belmont.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 67)
Why then you must. But hear thee, Gratiano, Thou art too wild, too rude and bold of voice-- Parts that become thee happily enough, And in such eyes as ours appear not faults.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 68)
But where thou art not known--why, there they show Something too liberal.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 69)
Pray thee take pain To allay with some cold drops of modesty Thy skipping spirit, lest through thy wild behavior be misconstered in the place go to, And lose my hopes.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 70)
Signior Bassanio, hear me. If do not put on a sober habit, Talk with respect, and swear but now and then, Wear prayer books in my pocket, look demurely, Nay more, while grace is saying, hood mine eyes Thus with my hat, and sigh and say "amen," Use all the observance of civility Like one well studied in a sad ostent To please his grandam, never trust me more.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 71)
Well, we shall see your bearing.   Nay, but bar tonight.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 72)
You shall not gauge me By what we do tonight.  No, that were pity.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 73)
would entreat you rather to put on Your boldest suit of mirth, for we have friends That purpose merriment.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 74)
But fare you well. have some business.   And must to Lorenzo and the rest.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 1, Scene 75)
2        am sorry thou wilt leave my father so. Our house is hell and thou, a merry devil, Didst rob it of some taste of tediousness.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 2, Scene 0)
But fare thee well. There is a ducat for thee, And, Lancelet, soon at supper shalt thou see Lorenzo, who is thy new master's guest.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 2, Scene 1)
Give him this letter, do it secretly, And so farewell.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 2, Scene 2)
would not have my father See me in talk with thee.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 2, Scene 3)
Adieu. Tears exhibit my tongue, most beautiful pagan, most sweet Jew.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 2, Scene 4)
If a Christian do not play the knave and get thee, am much deceived.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 2, Scene 5)
But adieu. These foolish drops do something drown my manly spirit.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 2, Scene 6)
Adieu.  Farewell, good Lancelet.  Alack, what heinous sin is it in me To be ashamed to be my father's child?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 2, Scene 7)
But though am a daughter to his blood, am not to his manners.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 2, Scene 8)
Lorenzo, If thou keep promise, shall end this strife, Become a Christian and thy loving wife.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 2, Scene 9)
Nay, we will slink away in supper time, Disguise us at my lodging, and return All in an hour.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 3, Scene 0)
We have not made good preparation.   We have not spoke us yet of torchbearers.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 3, Scene 1)
'Tis vile, unless it may be quaintly ordered, And better in my mind not undertook.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 3, Scene 2)
'Tis now but four o'clock. We have two hours To furnish us.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 3, Scene 3)
Friend Lancelet, what's the news?  An it shall please you to break up this, it shall seem to signify.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 3, Scene 4)
know the hand; in faith, 'tis a fair hand, And whiter than the paper it writ on Is the fair hand that writ.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 3, Scene 5)
Love news, in faith!  By your leave, sir.  Whither goest thou?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 3, Scene 6)
Marry, sir, to bid my old master the Jew to sup tonight with my new master the Christian.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 3, Scene 7)
Hold here, take this.  Tell gentle Jessica will not fail her.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 3, Scene 8)
Speak it privately.  Go, gentlemen, Will you prepare you for this masque tonight?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 3, Scene 9)
am provided of a torchbearer.   Ay, marry, I'll be gone about it straight.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 3, Scene 10)
And so will  Meet me and Gratiano At Gratiano's lodging some hour hence.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 3, Scene 11)
'Tis good we do so.    Was not that letter from fair Jessica?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 3, Scene 12)
must needs tell thee all. She hath directed How shall take her from her father's house, What gold and jewels she is furnished with, What page's suit she hath in readiness.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 3, Scene 13)
If e'er the Jew her father come to heaven, It will be for his gentle daughter's sake; And never dare misfortune cross her foot Unless she do it under this excuse, That she is issue to a faithless Jew.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 3, Scene 14)
Come, go with me. Peruse this as thou goest;  Fair Jessica shall be my torchbearer.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 3, Scene 15)
Well, thou shalt see, thy eyes shall be thy judge, The difference of old Shylock and Bassanio.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 0)
-- What, Jessica!--Thou shalt not gormandize As thou hast done with me--what, Jessica!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 1)
-- And sleep, and snore, and rend apparel out.-- Why, Jessica, say!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 2)
Why, Jessica!   Who bids thee call? do not bid thee call.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 3)
Your Worship was wont to tell me could do nothing without bidding.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 4)
Call you? What is your will?   am bid forth to supper, Jessica.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 5)
There are my keys.--But wherefore should go? am not bid for love.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 6)
They flatter me. But yet I'll go in hate, to feed upon The prodigal Christian.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 7)
--Jessica, my girl, Look to my house.--I am right loath to go.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 8)
There is some ill a-brewing towards my rest, For did dream of money bags tonight.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 9)
beseech you, sir, go. My young master doth expect your reproach.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 10)
So do his.  And they have conspired together--I will not say you shall see a masque, but if you do, then it was not for nothing that my nose fell a-bleeding on Black Monday last, at six o'clock i' th' morning, falling out that year on Ash Wednesday was four year in th' afternoon.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 11)
What, are there masques? Hear you me, Jessica, Lock up my doors, and when you hear the drum And the vile squealing of the wry-necked fife, Clamber not you up to the casements then, Nor thrust your head into the public street To gaze on Christian fools with varnished faces, But stop my house's ears mean my casements).(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 12)
Let not the sound of shallow fopp'ry enter My sober house.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 13)
By Jacob's staff swear have no mind of feasting forth tonight.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 14)
But will go.--Go you before me, sirrah. Say will come.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 15)
will go before, sir.  Mistress, look out at window for all this.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 16)
There will come a Christian by Will be worth a Jewess' eye.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 17)
What says that fool of Hagar's offspring, ha?   His words were "Farewell, mistress," nothing else.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 18)
The patch is kind enough, but a huge feeder, Snail-slow in profit, and he sleeps by day More than the wildcat.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 19)
Drones hive not with me, Therefore part with him, and part with him To one that would have him help to waste His borrowed purse.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 20)
Well, Jessica, go in. Perhaps will return immediately.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 21)
Do as bid you. Shut doors after you. Fast bind, fast find-- proverb never stale in thrifty mind.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 22)
Farewell, and if my fortune be not crossed, have a father, you a daughter, lost.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 4, Scene 23)
This is the penthouse under which Lorenzo Desired us to make stand.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 0)
His hour is almost past.   And it is marvel he outdwells his hour, For lovers ever run before the clock.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 1)
ten times faster Venus' pigeons fly To seal love's bonds new-made than they are wont To keep obliged faith unforfeited.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 2)
That ever holds. Who riseth from a feast With that keen appetite that he sits down?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 3)
Where is the horse that doth untread again His tedious measures with the unbated fire That he did pace them first?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 4)
All things that are, Are with more spirit chased than enjoyed.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 5)
How like a younger or a prodigal The scarfed bark puts from her native bay, Hugged and embraced by the strumpet wind; How like the prodigal doth she return With overweathered ribs and ragged sails, Lean, rent, and beggared by the strumpet wind!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 6)
Here comes Lorenzo. More of this hereafter.   Sweet friends, your patience for my long abode.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 7)
Not but my affairs have made you wait. When you shall please to play the thieves for wives, I'll watch as long for you then.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 8)
Approach. Here dwells my father Jew.--Ho! Who's within?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 9)
Who are you? Tell me for more certainty, Albeit I'll swear that do know your tongue.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 10)
Lorenzo, and thy love.   Lorenzo certain, and my love indeed, For who love so much?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 11)
And now who knows But you, Lorenzo, whether am yours?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 12)
Heaven and thy thoughts are witness that thou art.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 13)
Here, catch this casket; it is worth the pains.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 14)
am glad 'tis night, you do not look on me, For am much ashamed of my exchange.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 15)
But love is blind, and lovers cannot see The pretty follies that themselves commit, For if they could, Cupid himself would blush To see me thus transformed to a boy.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 16)
Descend, for you must be my torchbearer.   What, must hold a candle to my shames?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 17)
They in themselves, good sooth, are too too light.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 18)
Why, 'tis an office of discovery, love, And should be obscured.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 19)
So are you, sweet, Even in the lovely garnish of a boy.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 20)
But come at once, For the close night doth play the runaway, And we are stayed for at Bassanio's feast.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 21)
will make fast the doors and gild myself With some more ducats, and be with you straight.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 22)
Now, by my hood, a gentle and no Jew!   Beshrew me but love her heartily, For she is wise, if can judge of her, And fair she is, if that mine eyes be true, And true she is, as she hath proved herself.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 23)
And therefore, like herself, wise, fair, and true, Shall she be placed in my constant soul.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 24)
What, art thou come? On, gentleman, away! Our masquing mates by this time for us stay.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 25)
Who's there?  Signior Antonio?   Fie, fie, Gratiano, where are all the rest?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 26)
'Tis nine o'clock! Our friends all stay for you. No masque tonight; the wind is come about; Bassanio presently will go aboard.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 27)
have sent twenty out to seek for you.   am glad on 't.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 28)
desire no more delight Than to be under sail and gone tonight.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 5, Scene 29)
Go, draw aside the curtains and discover The several caskets to this noble prince.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 0)
Now make your choice.   This first, of gold, who this inscription bears, "Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire"; The second, silver, which this promise carries, "Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves"; This third, dull lead, with warning all as blunt, "Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 1)
" How shall know if do choose the right?   The one of them contains my picture, prince.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 2)
If you choose that, then am yours withal.   Some god direct my judgment!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 3)
Let me see. will survey th' inscriptions back again.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 4)
What says this leaden casket? "Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 5)
" Must give--for what? For lead? Hazard for lead? This casket threatens.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 6)
Men that hazard all Do it in hope of fair advantages.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 7)
golden mind stoops not to shows of dross. I'll then nor give nor hazard aught for lead.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 8)
What says the silver with her virgin hue? "Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 9)
" As much as he deserves--pause there, Morocco, And weigh thy value with an even hand.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 10)
If thou beest rated by thy estimation, Thou dost deserve enough; and yet enough May not extend so far as to the lady.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 11)
And yet to be afeard of my deserving Were but a weak disabling of myself.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 12)
As much as deserve--why, that's the lady! do in birth deserve her, and in fortunes, In graces, and in qualities of breeding, But more than these, in love do deserve.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 13)
What if strayed no farther, but chose here? Let's see once more this saying graved in gold: "Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 14)
" Why, that's the lady! All the world desires her.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 15)
From the four corners of the Earth they come To kiss this shrine, this mortal, breathing saint.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 16)
The Hyrcanian deserts and the vasty wilds Of wide Arabia are as throughfares now For princes to come view fair Portia.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 17)
The watery kingdom, whose ambitious head Spets in the face of heaven, is no bar To stop the foreign spirits, but they come As o'er a brook to see fair Portia.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 18)
One of these three contains her heavenly picture.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 19)
Is 't like that lead contains her? 'Twere damnation To think so base a thought.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 20)
It were too gross To rib her cerecloth in the obscure grave.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 21)
Or shall think in silver she's immured, Being ten times undervalued to tried gold?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 22)
sinful thought! Never so rich a gem Was set in worse than gold.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 23)
They have in England coin that bears the figure of an angel Stamped in gold, but that's insculped upon; But here an angel in a golden bed Lies all within.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 24)
--Deliver me the key. Here do choose, and thrive as may.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 25)
There, take it, prince.  And if my form lie there, Then am yours.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 26)
hell! What have we here? carrion death within whose empty eye There is a written scroll.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 27)
I'll read the writing: All that glisters is not gold-- Often have you heard that told.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 28)
Many a man his life hath sold But my outside to behold.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 29)
Gilded tombs do worms infold. Had you been as wise as bold, Young in limbs, in judgment old, Your answer had not been enscrolled.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 30)
Fare you well, your suit is cold. Cold indeed and labor lost!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 31)
Then, farewell, heat, and welcome, frost. Portia, adieu.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 32)
have too grieved a heart To take a tedious leave.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 33)
Thus losers part.    gentle riddance! Draw the curtains, go.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 6, Scene 34)
Why, man, saw Bassanio under sail; With him is Gratiano gone along; And in their ship am sure Lorenzo is not.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 7, Scene 0)
The villain Jew with outcries raised the Duke, Who went with him to search Bassanio's ship.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 7, Scene 1)
He came too late; the ship was under sail. But there the Duke was given to understand That in a gondola were seen together Lorenzo and his amorous Jessica.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 7, Scene 2)
Besides, Antonio certified the Duke They were not with Bassanio in his ship.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 7, Scene 3)
never heard a passion so confused, So strange, outrageous, and so variable As the dog Jew did utter in the streets.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 7, Scene 4)
"My daughter, my ducats, my daughter! Fled with a Christian!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 7, Scene 5)
my Christian ducats! Justice, the law, my ducats, and my daughter, sealed bag, two sealed bags of ducats, Of double ducats, stol'n from me by my daughter, And jewels--two stones, two rich and precious stones-- Stol'n by my daughter!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 7, Scene 6)
Justice! Find the girl! She hath the stones upon her, and the ducats.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 7, Scene 7)
"   Why, all the boys in Venice follow him, Crying "His stones, his daughter, and his ducats.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 7, Scene 8)
"   Let good Antonio look he keep his day, Or he shall pay for this.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 7, Scene 9)
Marry, well remembered. reasoned with a Frenchman yesterday Who told me, in the Narrow Seas that part The French and English, there miscarried vessel of our country richly fraught.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 7, Scene 10)
thought upon Antonio when he told me, And wished in silence that it were not his.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 7, Scene 11)
You were best to tell Antonio what you hear-- Yet do not suddenly, for it may grieve him.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 7, Scene 12)
kinder gentleman treads not the Earth. saw Bassanio and Antonio part.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 7, Scene 13)
Bassanio told him he would make some speed Of his return.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 7, Scene 14)
He answered "Do not so. Slubber not business for my sake, Bassanio, But stay the very riping of the time; And for the Jew's bond which he hath of me, Let it not enter in your mind of love.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 7, Scene 15)
Be merry, and employ your chiefest thoughts To courtship and such fair ostents of love As shall conveniently become you there.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 7, Scene 16)
" And even there, his eye being big with tears, Turning his face, he put his hand behind him, And with affection wondrous sensible He wrung Bassanio's hand--and so they parted.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 7, Scene 17)
think he only loves the world for him. pray thee, let us go and find him out And quicken his embraced heaviness With some delight or other.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 7, Scene 18)
Quick, quick, pray thee, draw the curtain straight.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 0)
The Prince of Arragon hath ta'en his oath And comes to his election presently.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 1)
Behold, there stand the caskets, noble prince.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 2)
If you choose that wherein am contained, Straight shall our nuptial rites be solemnized.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 3)
But if you fail, without more speech, my lord, You must be gone from hence immediately.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 4)
am enjoined by oath to observe three things: First, never to unfold to anyone Which casket 'twas chose; next, if fail Of the right casket, never in my life To woo a maid in way of marriage; Lastly, if do fail in fortune of my choice, Immediately to leave you, and be gone.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 5)
To these injunctions everyone doth swear That comes to hazard for my worthless self.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 6)
And so have addressed me. Fortune now To my heart's hope!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 7)
Gold, silver, and base lead. "Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 8)
" You shall look fairer ere give or hazard. What says the golden chest?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 9)
Ha, let me see: "Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 10)
" What many men desire--that "many" may be meant By the fool multitude that choose by show, Not learning more than the fond eye doth teach, Which pries not to th' interior, but like the martlet Builds in the weather on the outward wall, Even in the force and road of casualty.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 11)
will not choose what many men desire, Because will not jump with common spirits And rank me with the barbarous multitudes.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 12)
Why, then, to thee, thou silver treasure house. Tell me once more what title thou dost bear.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 13)
"Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 14)
" And well said, too; for who shall go about To cozen fortune and be honorable Without the stamp of merit?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 15)
Let none presume To wear an undeserved dignity. that estates, degrees, and offices Were not derived corruptly, and that clear honor Were purchased by the merit of the wearer!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 16)
How many then should cover that stand bare? How many be commanded that command?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 17)
How much low peasantry would then be gleaned From the true seed of honor?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 18)
And how much honor Picked from the chaff and ruin of the times, To be new varnished?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 19)
Well, but to my choice. "Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 20)
" will assume desert. Give me a key for this,  And instantly unlock my fortunes here.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 21)
Too long a pause for that which you find there.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 22)
What's here? The portrait of a blinking idiot Presenting me a schedule!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 23)
will read it.-- How much unlike art thou to Portia!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 24)
How much unlike my hopes and my deservings. "Who chooseth me shall have as much as he deserves"?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 25)
Did deserve no more than a fool's head? Is that my prize?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 26)
Are my deserts no better?   To offend and judge are distinct offices And of opposed natures.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 27)
What is here?   The fire seven times tried this; Seven times tried that judgment is That did never choose amiss.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 28)
Some there be that shadows kiss; Such have but a shadow's bliss.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 29)
There be fools alive, iwis, Silvered o'er--and so was this.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 30)
Take what wife you will to bed, will ever be your head.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 31)
So begone; you are sped. Still more fool shall appear By the time linger here.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 32)
With one fool's head came to woo, But go away with two.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 33)
Sweet, adieu. I'll keep my oath, Patiently to bear my wroth.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 34)
Thus hath the candle singed the moth. these deliberate fools, when they do choose, They have the wisdom by their wit to lose.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 35)
The ancient saying is no heresy: Hanging and wiving goes by destiny.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 36)
Come, draw the curtain, Nerissa.      Where is my lady?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 37)
Here. What would my lord?   Madam, there is alighted at your gate young Venetian, one that comes before To signify th' approaching of his lord, From whom he bringeth sensible regreets; To wit (besides commends and courteous breath), Gifts of rich value; yet have not seen So likely an ambassador of love.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 38)
day in April never came so sweet, To show how costly summer was at hand, As this fore-spurrer comes before his lord.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 39)
No more, pray thee. am half afeard Thou wilt say anon he is some kin to thee, Thou spend'st such high-day wit in praising him!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 40)
Come, come, Nerissa, for long to see Quick Cupid's post that comes so mannerly.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 8, Scene 41)
Now, what news on the Rialto?  Why, yet it lives there unchecked that Antonio hath a ship of rich lading wracked on the Narrow Seas--the Goodwins, think they call the place--a very dangerous flat, and fatal, where the carcasses of many a tall ship lie buried, as they say, if my gossip Report be an honest woman of her word.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 0)
would she were as lying a gossip in that as ever knapped ginger or made her neighbors believe she wept for the death of a third husband.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 1)
But it is true, without any slips of prolixity or crossing the plain highway of talk, that the good Antonio, the honest Antonio--O, that had a title good enough to keep his name company!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 2)
--  Come, the full stop.  Ha, what sayest thou? Why, the end is, he hath lost a ship.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 3)
would it might prove the end of his losses.  Let me say "amen" betimes, lest the devil cross my prayer, for here he comes in the likeness of a Jew.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 4)
How now, Shylock, what news among the merchants?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 5)
You knew, none so well, none so well as you, of my daughter's flight.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 6)
That's certain. for my part knew the tailor that made the wings she flew withal.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 7)
And Shylock for his own part knew the bird was fledge, and then it is the complexion of them all to leave the dam.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 8)
She is damned for it.  That's certain, if the devil may be her judge.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 9)
My own flesh and blood to rebel!  Out upon it, old carrion!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 10)
Rebels it at these years?  say my daughter is my flesh and my blood.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 11)
There is more difference between thy flesh and hers than between jet and ivory, more between your bloods than there is between red wine and Rhenish.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 12)
But tell us, do you hear whether Antonio have had any loss at sea or no?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 13)
There have another bad match! bankrout, a prodigal, who dare scarce show his head on the Rialto, a beggar that was used to come so smug upon the mart!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 14)
Let him look to his bond. He was wont to call me usurer; let him look to his bond.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 15)
He was wont to lend money for a Christian cur'sy; let him look to his bond.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 16)
Why, am sure if he forfeit, thou wilt not take his flesh!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 17)
What's that good for?  To bait fish withal; if it will feed nothing else, it will feed my revenge.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 18)
He hath disgraced me and hindered me half a million, laughed at my losses, mocked at my gains, scorned my nation, thwarted my bargains, cooled my friends, heated mine enemies-- and what's his reason?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 19)
am a Jew. Hath not a Jew eyes? Hath not a Jew hands, organs, dimensions, senses, affections, passions?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 20)
Fed with the same food, hurt with the same weapons, subject to the same diseases, healed by the same means, warmed and cooled by the same winter and summer as a Christian is?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 21)
If you prick us, do we not bleed? If you tickle us, do we not laugh?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 22)
If you poison us, do we not die? And if you wrong us, shall we not revenge?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 23)
If we are like you in the rest, we will resemble you in that.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 24)
If a Jew wrong a Christian, what is his humility?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 25)
Revenge. If a Christian wrong a Jew, what should his sufferance be by Christian example?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 26)
Why, revenge! The villainy you teach me will execute, and it shall go hard but will better the instruction.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 27)
Gentlemen, my master Antonio is at his house and desires to speak with you both.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 28)
We have been up and down to seek him.     Here comes another of the tribe; a third cannot be matched unless the devil himself turn Jew.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 29)
How now, Tubal, what news from Genoa? Hast thou found my daughter?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 30)
often came where did hear of her, but cannot find her.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 31)
Why, there, there, there, there! diamond gone cost me two thousand ducats in Frankfurt!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 32)
The curse never fell upon our nation till now, never felt it till now.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 33)
Two thousand ducats in that, and other precious, precious jewels!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 34)
would my daughter were dead at my foot and the jewels in her ear; would she were hearsed at my foot and the ducats in her coffin.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 35)
No news of them? Why so? And know not what's spent in the search!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 36)
Why, thou loss upon loss! The thief gone with so much, and so much to find the thief, and no satisfaction, no revenge, nor no ill luck stirring but what lights a' my shoulders, no sighs but a' my breathing, no tears but a' my shedding.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 37)
Yes, other men have ill luck, too. Antonio, as heard in Genoa--  What, what, what?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 38)
Ill luck, ill luck?  --hath an argosy cast away coming from Tripolis.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 39)
thank God, thank God! Is it true, is it true?  spoke with some of the sailors that escaped the wrack.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 40)
thank thee, good Tubal. Good news, good news! Ha, ha, heard in Genoa--  Your daughter spent in Genoa, as heard, one night fourscore ducats.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 41)
Thou stick'st a dagger in me. shall never see my gold again.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 42)
Fourscore ducats at a sitting, fourscore ducats!  There came divers of Antonio's creditors in my company to Venice that swear he cannot choose but break.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 43)
am very glad of it. I'll plague him, I'll torture him.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 44)
am glad of it.  One of them showed me a ring that he had of your daughter for a monkey.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 45)
Out upon her! Thou torturest me, Tubal. It was my turquoise!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 46)
had it of Leah when was a bachelor. would not have given it for a wilderness of monkeys.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 47)
But Antonio is certainly undone.  Nay, that's true, that's very true.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 48)
Go, Tubal, fee me an officer. Bespeak him a fortnight before.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 49)
will have the heart of him if he forfeit, for were he out of Venice can make what merchandise will.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 50)
Go, Tubal, and meet me at our synagogue. Go, good Tubal, at our synagogue, Tubal.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 20, Scene 51)
pray you tarry, pause a day or two Before you hazard, for in choosing wrong lose your company; therefore forbear a while.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 0)
There's something tells me (but it is not love) would not lose you, and you know yourself Hate counsels not in such a quality.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 1)
But lest you should not understand me well (And yet a maiden hath no tongue but thought) would detain you here some month or two Before you venture for me.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 2)
could teach you How to choose right, but then am forsworn.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 3)
So will never be. So may you miss me. But if you do, you'll make me wish a sin, That had been forsworn.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 4)
Beshrew your eyes, They have o'erlooked me and divided me.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 5)
One half of me is yours, the other half yours-- Mine own, would say--but if mine, then yours, And so all yours.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 6)
these naughty times Puts bars between the owners and their rights!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 7)
And so though yours, not yours. Prove it so, Let Fortune go to hell for it, not speak too long, but 'tis to peize the time, To eche it, and to draw it out in length, To stay you from election.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 8)
Let me choose, For as am, live upon the rack.   Upon the rack, Bassanio?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 9)
Then confess What treason there is mingled with your love.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 10)
None but that ugly treason of mistrust, Which makes me fear th' enjoying of my love.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 11)
There may as well be amity and life 'Tween snow and fire, as treason and my love.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 12)
Ay, but fear you speak upon the rack Where men enforced do speak anything.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 13)
Promise me life and I'll confess the truth.   Well, then, confess and live.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 14)
"Confess and love" Had been the very sum of my confession.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 15)
happy torment, when my torturer Doth teach me answers for deliverance!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 16)
But let me to my fortune and the caskets.   Away, then.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 17)
am locked in one of them. If you do love me, you will find me out.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 18)
-- Nerissa and the rest, stand all aloof. Let music sound while he doth make his choice.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 19)
Then if he lose he makes a swanlike end, Fading in music.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 20)
That the comparison May stand more proper, my eye shall be the stream And wat'ry deathbed for him.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 21)
He may win, And what is music then? Then music is Even as the flourish when true subjects bow To a new-crowned monarch.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 22)
Such it is As are those dulcet sounds in break of day That creep into the dreaming bridegroom's ear And summon him to marriage.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 23)
Now he goes, With no less presence but with much more love Than young Alcides when he did redeem The virgin tribute paid by howling Troy To the sea-monster.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 24)
stand for sacrifice; The rest aloof are the Dardanian wives, With bleared visages, come forth to view The issue of th' exploit.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 25)
Go, Hercules! Live thou, live. With much much more dismay view the fight than thou that mak'st the fray.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 26)
song the whilst Bassanio comments on     Tell me where is fancy bred, Or in the heart, or in the head?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 27)
How begot, how nourished? Reply, reply. It is engendered in the eye, With gazing fed, and fancy dies In the cradle where it lies.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 28)
Let us all ring fancy's knell. I'll begin it.--Ding, dong, bell.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 29)
Ding, dong, bell.   So may the outward shows be least themselves; The world is still deceived with ornament.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 30)
In law, what plea so tainted and corrupt But, being seasoned with a gracious voice, Obscures the show of evil?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 31)
In religion, What damned error but some sober brow Will bless it and approve it with a text, Hiding the grossness with fair ornament?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 32)
There is no vice so simple but assumes Some mark of virtue on his outward parts.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 33)
How many cowards whose hearts are all as false As stairs of sand, wear yet upon their chins The beards of Hercules and frowning Mars, Who inward searched have livers white as milk, And these assume but valor's excrement To render them redoubted.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 34)
Look on beauty, And you shall see 'tis purchased by the weight, Which therein works a miracle in nature, Making them lightest that wear most of it.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 35)
So are those crisped snaky golden locks, Which maketh such wanton gambols with the wind Upon supposed fairness, often known To be the dowry of a second head, The skull that bred them in the sepulcher.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 36)
Thus ornament is but the guiled shore To a most dangerous sea, the beauteous scarf Veiling an Indian beauty; in a word, The seeming truth which cunning times put on To entrap the wisest.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 37)
Therefore, then, thou gaudy gold, Hard food for Midas, will none of thee.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 38)
Nor none of thee, thou pale and common drudge 'Tween man and man.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 39)
But thou, thou meager lead, Which rather threaten'st than dost promise aught, Thy paleness moves me more than eloquence, And here choose Joy be the consequence!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 40)
How all the other passions fleet to air, As doubtful thoughts and rash embraced despair, And shudd'ring fear, and green-eyed jealousy!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 41)
love, be moderate, allay thy ecstasy, In measure rain thy joy, scant this excess!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 42)
feel too much thy blessing. Make it less, For fear surfeit.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 43)
What find here? Fair Portia's counterfeit! What demigod Hath come so near creation?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 44)
Move these eyes? Or whether, riding on the balls of mine, Seem they in motion?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 45)
Here are severed lips Parted with sugar breath; so sweet a bar Should sunder such sweet friends.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 46)
Here in her hairs The painter plays the spider, and hath woven golden mesh t' entrap the hearts of men Faster than gnats in cobwebs.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 47)
But her eyes! How could he see to do them? Having made one, Methinks it should have power to steal both his And leave itself unfurnished.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 48)
Yet look how far The substance of my praise doth wrong this shadow In underprizing it, so far this shadow Doth limp behind the substance.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 49)
Here's the scroll, The continent and summary of my fortune.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 50)
You that choose not by the view Chance as fair and choose as true.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 51)
Since this fortune falls to you, Be content and seek no new.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 52)
If you be well pleased with this And hold your fortune for your bliss, Turn you where your lady is, And claim her with a loving kiss.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 53)
gentle scroll! Fair lady, by your leave, come by note to give and to receive.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 54)
Like one of two contending in a prize That thinks he hath done well in people's eyes, Hearing applause and universal shout, Giddy in spirit, still gazing in a doubt Whether those peals of praise be his or no, So, thrice-fair lady, stand even so, As doubtful whether what see be true, Until confirmed, signed, ratified by you.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 55)
You see me, Lord Bassanio, where stand, Such as am.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 56)
Though for myself alone would not be ambitious in my wish To wish myself much better, yet for you would be trebled twenty times myself, thousand times more fair, ten thousand times More rich, that only to stand high in your account might in virtues, beauties, livings, friends, Exceed account.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 57)
But the full sum of me Is sum of something, which, to term in gross, Is an unlessoned girl, unschooled, unpracticed; Happy in this, she is not yet so old But she may learn; happier than this, She is not bred so dull but she can learn; Happiest of all, is that her gentle spirit Commits itself to yours to be directed As from her lord, her governor, her king.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 58)
Myself, and what is mine, to you and yours Is now converted.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 59)
But now was the lord Of this fair mansion, master of my servants, Queen o'er myself; and even now, but now, This house, these servants, and this same myself Are yours, my lord's.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 60)
give them with this ring,  Which, when you part from, lose, or give away, Let it presage the ruin of your love, And be my vantage to exclaim on you.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 61)
Madam, you have bereft me of all words. Only my blood speaks to you in my veins, And there is such confusion in my powers As after some oration fairly spoke By a beloved prince there doth appear Among the buzzing pleased multitude, Where every something being blent together Turns to a wild of nothing, save of joy Expressed and not expressed.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 62)
But when this ring Parts from this finger, then parts life from hence.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 63)
then be bold to say Bassanio's dead!   My lord and lady, it is now our time, That have stood by and seen our wishes prosper, To cry "Good joy, good joy, my lord and lady!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 64)
"   My Lord Bassanio, and my gentle lady, wish you all the joy that you can wish, For am sure you can wish none from me.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 65)
And when your honors mean to solemnize The bargain of your faith, do beseech you Even at that time may be married too.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 66)
With all my heart, so thou canst get a wife.   thank your Lordship, you have got me one.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 67)
My eyes, my lord, can look as swift as yours: You saw the mistress, beheld the maid.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 68)
You loved, loved; for intermission No more pertains to me, my lord, than you.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 69)
Your fortune stood upon the caskets there, And so did mine, too, as the matter falls.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 70)
For wooing here until sweat again, And swearing till my very roof was dry With oaths of love, at last (if promise last) got a promise of this fair one here To have her love, provided that your fortune Achieved her mistress.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 71)
Is this true, Nerissa?   Madam, it is, so you stand pleased withal.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 72)
And do you, Gratiano, mean good faith?  Yes, faith, my lord.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 73)
Our feast shall be much honored in your marriage.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 74)
We'll play with them the first boy for a thousand ducats.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 75)
What, and stake down?  No, we shall ne'er win at that sport and stake down.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 76)
But who comes here? Lorenzo and his infidel? What, and my old Venetian friend Salerio?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 77)
Lorenzo and Salerio, welcome hither-- If that the youth of my new int'rest here Have power to bid you welcome.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 78)
By your leave, bid my very friends and countrymen, Sweet Portia, welcome.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 79)
So do my lord. They are entirely welcome.   thank your Honor.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 80)
For my part, my lord, My purpose was not to have seen you here, But meeting with Salerio by the way, He did entreat me past all saying nay To come with him along.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 81)
did, my lord, And have reason for it. Signior Antonio Commends him to you.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 82)
Ere ope his letter, pray you tell me how my good friend doth.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 83)
Not sick, my lord, unless it be in mind, Nor well, unless in mind.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 84)
His letter there Will show you his estate.    Nerissa, cheer yond stranger, bid her welcome.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 85)
-- Your hand, Salerio. What's the news from Venice?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 86)
How doth that royal merchant, good Antonio? know he will be glad of our success.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 87)
We are the Jasons, we have won the Fleece.   would you had won the fleece that he hath lost.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 88)
There are some shrewd contents in yond same paper That steals the color from Bassanio's cheek.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 89)
Some dear friend dead, else nothing in the world Could turn so much the constitution Of any constant man.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 90)
What, worse and worse?-- With leave, Bassanio, am half yourself, And must freely have the half of anything That this same paper brings you.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 91)
sweet Portia, Here are a few of the unpleasant'st words That ever blotted paper.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 92)
Gentle lady, When did first impart my love to you, freely told you all the wealth had Ran in my veins: was a gentleman.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 93)
And then told you true; and yet, dear lady, Rating myself at nothing, you shall see How much was a braggart.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 94)
When told you My state was nothing, should then have told you That was worse than nothing; for indeed have engaged myself to a dear friend, Engaged my friend to his mere enemy To feed my means.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 95)
Here is a letter, lady, The paper as the body of my friend, And every word in it a gaping wound Issuing life blood.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 96)
--But is it true, Salerio? Hath all his ventures failed?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 97)
What, not one hit? From Tripolis, from Mexico and England, From Lisbon, Barbary, and India, And not one vessel 'scape the dreadful touch Of merchant-marring rocks?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 98)
Not one, my lord. Besides, it should appear that if he had The present money to discharge the Jew, He would not take it.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 99)
Never did know creature that did bear the shape of man So keen and greedy to confound a man.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 100)
He plies the Duke at morning and at night, And doth impeach the freedom of the state If they deny him justice.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 101)
Twenty merchants, The Duke himself, and the magnificoes Of greatest port have all persuaded with him, But none can drive him from the envious plea Of forfeiture, of justice, and his bond.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 102)
When was with him, have heard him swear To Tubal and to Chus, his countrymen, That he would rather have Antonio's flesh Than twenty times the value of the sum That he did owe him.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 103)
And know, my lord, If law, authority, and power deny not, It will go hard with poor Antonio.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 104)
Is it your dear friend that is thus in trouble?(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 105)
The dearest friend to me, the kindest man, The best conditioned and unwearied spirit In doing courtesies, and one in whom The ancient Roman honor more appears Than any that draws breath in Italy.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 106)
What sum owes he the Jew?   For me, three thousand ducats.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 107)
What, no more? Pay him six thousand and deface the bond.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 108)
Double six thousand and then treble that, Before a friend of this description Shall lose a hair through Bassanio's fault.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 109)
First go with me to church and call me wife, And then away to Venice to your friend!(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 110)
For never shall you lie by Portia's side With an unquiet soul.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 111)
You shall have gold To pay the petty debt twenty times over.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 112)
When it is paid, bring your true friend along. My maid Nerissa and myself meantime Will live as maids and widows.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 113)
Come, away, For you shall hence upon your wedding day.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 114)
Bid your friends welcome, show a merry cheer; Since you are dear bought, will love you dear.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 115)
But let me hear the letter of your friend.   Sweet Bassanio, my ships have all miscarried, my creditors grow cruel, my estate is very low, my bond to the Jew is forfeit, and since in paying it, it is impossible should live, all debts are cleared between you and if might but see you at my death.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 116)
Notwithstanding, use your pleasure. If your love do not persuade you to come, let not my letter.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 117)
love, dispatch all business and begone!   Since have your good leave to go away, will make haste.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 118)
But till come again, No bed shall e'er be guilty of my stay, Nor rest be interposer 'twixt us twain.(The Merchant of Venice, Act 21, Scene 119)
What from the cape can you discern at sea?   Nothing at all.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 0)
It is a high-wrought flood. cannot 'twixt the heaven and the main Descry a sail.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 1)
Methinks the wind hath spoke aloud at land. fuller blast ne'er shook our battlements.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 2)
If it hath ruffianed so upon the sea, What ribs of oak, when mountains melt on them, Can hold the mortise?(Othello, Act 0, Scene 3)
What shall we hear of this?   segregation of the Turkish fleet.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 4)
For do but stand upon the foaming shore, The chidden billow seems to pelt the clouds, The wind-shaked surge, with high and monstrous mane, Seems to cast water on the burning Bear And quench the guards of th' ever-fixed pole.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 5)
never did like molestation view On the enchafed flood.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 6)
If that the Turkish fleet Be not ensheltered and embayed, they are drowned.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 7)
It is impossible to bear it out.     News, lads! Our wars are done.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 8)
The desperate tempest hath so banged the Turks That their designment halts.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 9)
noble ship of Venice Hath seen a grievous wrack and sufferance On most part of their fleet.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 10)
How? Is this true?  The ship is here put in, Veronesa.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 11)
Michael Cassio, Lieutenant to the warlike Moor Othello, Is come on shore; the Moor himself at sea, And is in full commission here for Cyprus.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 12)
am glad on 't. 'Tis a worthy governor.   But this same Cassio, though he speak of comfort Touching the Turkish loss, yet he looks sadly And prays the Moor be safe, for they were parted With foul and violent tempest.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 13)
Pray heaven he be; For have served him, and the man commands Like a full soldier.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 14)
Let's to the seaside, ho! As well to see the vessel that's come in As to throw out our eyes for brave Othello, Even till we make the main and th' aerial blue An indistinct regard.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 15)
Come, let's do so; For every minute is expectancy Of more arrivance.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 16)
Thanks, you the valiant of this warlike isle, That so approve the Moor!(Othello, Act 0, Scene 17)
let the heavens Give him defense against the elements, For have lost him on a dangerous sea.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 18)
Is he well shipped?   His bark is stoutly timbered, and his pilot Of very expert and approved allowance; Therefore my hopes, not surfeited to death, Stand in bold cure.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 19)
What noise?   The town is empty; on the brow o' th' sea Stand ranks of people, and they cry sail!(Othello, Act 0, Scene 20)
"   My hopes do shape him for the Governor.    They do discharge their shot of courtesy.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 21)
Our friends, at least.  pray you, sir, go forth, And give us truth who 'tis that is arrived.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 22)
shall.   But, good lieutenant, is your general wived?(Othello, Act 0, Scene 23)
Most fortunately. He hath achieved a maid That paragons description and wild fame, One that excels the quirks of blazoning pens, And in th' essential vesture of creation Does tire the ingener.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 24)
How now? Who has put in?   'Tis one Iago, ancient to the General.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 25)
'Has had most favorable and happy speed! Tempests themselves, high seas, and howling winds, The guttered rocks and congregated sands (Traitors ensteeped to clog the guiltless keel), As having sense of beauty, do omit Their mortal natures, letting go safely by The divine Desdemona.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 26)
What is she?   She that spake of, our great captain's captain, Left in the conduct of the bold Iago, Whose footing here anticipates our thoughts sennight's speed.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 27)
Great Jove, Othello guard, And swell his sail with thine own powerful breath, That he may bless this bay with his tall ship, Make love's quick pants in Desdemona's arms, Give renewed fire to our extincted spirits, And bring all Cyprus comfort!(Othello, Act 0, Scene 28)
behold, The riches of the ship is come on shore!(Othello, Act 0, Scene 29)
You men of Cyprus, let her have your knees.  Hail to thee, lady, and the grace of heaven, Before, behind thee, and on every hand Enwheel thee round.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 30)
thank you, valiant Cassio. What tidings can you tell of my lord?(Othello, Act 0, Scene 31)
He is not yet arrived, nor know aught But that he's well and will be shortly here.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 32)
but fear--How lost you company?   The great contention of sea and skies Parted our fellowship.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 33)
But hark, a sail!   They give their greeting to the citadel.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 34)
This likewise is a friend.  See for the news.  Good ancient, you are welcome.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 35)
Welcome, mistress.  Let it not gall your patience, good Iago, That extend my manners.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 36)
'Tis my breeding That gives me this bold show of courtesy.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 37)
Sir, would she give you so much of her lips As of her tongue she oft bestows on me, You would have enough.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 38)
Alas, she has no speech!  In faith, too much. find it still when have list to sleep.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 39)
Marry, before your Ladyship, grant, She puts her tongue a little in her heart And chides with thinking.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 40)
You have little cause to say so.  Come on, come on!(Othello, Act 0, Scene 41)
You are pictures out of door, bells in your parlors, wildcats in your kitchens, saints in your injuries, devils being offended, players in your huswifery, and huswives in your beds.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 42)
Oh, fie upon thee, slanderer.   Nay, it is true, or else am a Turk.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 43)
You rise to play, and go to bed to work.   You shall not write my praise.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 44)
No, let me not.   What wouldst write of me if thou shouldst praise me?(Othello, Act 0, Scene 45)
gentle lady, do not put me to 't, For am nothing if not critical.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 46)
Come on, assay.--There's one gone to the harbor?(Othello, Act 0, Scene 47)
Ay, madam.   am not merry, but do beguile The thing am by seeming otherwise.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 48)
-- Come, how wouldst thou praise me?  am about it, but indeed my invention comes from my pate as birdlime does from frieze: it plucks out brains and all.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 49)
But my muse labors, and thus she is delivered: If she be fair and wise, fairness and wit, The one's for use, the other useth it.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 50)
Well praised! How if she be black and witty?   If she be black, and thereto have a wit, She'll find a white that shall her blackness hit.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 51)
Worse and worse.  How if fair and foolish?   She never yet was foolish that was fair, For even her folly helped her to an heir.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 52)
These are old fond paradoxes to make fools laugh i' th' alehouse.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 53)
What miserable praise hast thou for her that's foul and foolish?(Othello, Act 0, Scene 54)
There's none so foul and foolish thereunto, But does foul pranks which fair and wise ones do.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 55)
heavy ignorance! Thou praisest the worst best. But what praise couldst thou bestow on a deserving woman indeed, one that in the authority of her merit did justly put on the vouch of very malice itself?(Othello, Act 0, Scene 56)
She that was ever fair and never proud, Had tongue at will and yet was never loud, Never lacked gold and yet went never gay, Fled from her wish, and yet said "Now may," She that being angered, her revenge being nigh, Bade her wrong stay and her displeasure fly, She that in wisdom never was so frail To change the cod's head for the salmon's tail, She that could think and ne'er disclose her mind, See suitors following and not look behind, She was a wight, if ever such wight were--  To do what?(Othello, Act 0, Scene 57)
To suckle fools and chronicle small beer.  most lame and impotent conclusion!(Othello, Act 0, Scene 58)
--Do not learn of him, Emilia, though he be thy husband.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 59)
--How say you, Cassio? Is he not a most profane and liberal counselor?(Othello, Act 0, Scene 60)
He speaks home, madam. You may relish him more in the soldier than in the scholar.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 61)
He takes her by the palm. Ay, well said, whisper.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 62)
With as little a web as this will ensnare as great a fly as Cassio.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 63)
Ay, smile upon her, do. will gyve thee in thine own courtship.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 64)
You say true, 'tis so indeed. If such tricks as these strip you out of your lieutenantry, it had been better you had not kissed your three fingers so oft, which now again you are most apt to play the sir in.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 65)
Very good; well kissed; an excellent courtesy! 'Tis so, indeed.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 66)
Yet again your fingers to your lips? Would they were clyster pipes for your sake!(Othello, Act 0, Scene 67)
The Moor. know his trumpet.  'Tis truly so.  Let's meet him and receive him.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 68)
Lo, where he comes!      my fair warrior!  My dear Othello!(Othello, Act 0, Scene 69)
It gives me wonder great as my content To see you here before me.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 70)
my soul's joy! If after every tempest come such calms, May the winds blow till they have wakened death, And let the laboring bark climb hills of seas Olympus high, and duck again as low As hell's from heaven!(Othello, Act 0, Scene 71)
If it were now to die, 'Twere now to be most happy, for fear My soul hath her content so absolute That not another comfort like to this Succeeds in unknown fate.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 72)
The heavens forbid But that our loves and comforts should increase Even as our days do grow!(Othello, Act 0, Scene 73)
Amen to that, sweet powers! cannot speak enough of this content.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 74)
It stops me here; it is too much of joy. And this, and this, the greatest discords be That e'er our hearts shall make!(Othello, Act 0, Scene 75)
you are well tuned now, But I'll set down the pegs that make this music, As honest as am.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 76)
Come. Let us to the castle.-- News, friends! Our wars are done.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 77)
The Turks are drowned. How does my old acquaintance of this isle?(Othello, Act 0, Scene 78)
-- Honey, you shall be well desired in Cyprus. have found great love amongst them.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 79)
my sweet, prattle out of fashion, and dote In mine own comforts.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 80)
--I prithee, good Iago, Go to the bay and disembark my coffers.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 81)
Bring thou the master to the citadel. He is a good one, and his worthiness Does challenge much respect.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 82)
--Come, Desdemona. Once more, well met at Cyprus.   Do thou meet me presently at the harbor.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 83)
Come hither. If thou be'st valiant--as they say base men being in love have then a nobility in their natures more than is native to them--list me.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 84)
The Lieutenant tonight watches on the court of guard.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 85)
First, must tell thee this: Desdemona is directly in love with him.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 86)
With him? Why, 'tis not possible.  Lay thy finger thus, and let thy soul be instructed.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 87)
Mark me with what violence she first loved the Moor but for bragging and telling her fantastical lies.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 88)
And will she love him still for prating? Let not thy discreet heart think it.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 89)
Her eye must be fed. And what delight shall she have to look on the devil?(Othello, Act 0, Scene 90)
When the blood is made dull with the act of sport, there should be, again to inflame it and to give satiety a fresh appetite, loveliness in favor, sympathy in years, manners, and beauties, all which the Moor is defective in.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 91)
Now, for want of these required conveniences, her delicate tenderness will find itself abused, begin to heave the gorge, disrelish and abhor the Moor.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 92)
Very nature will instruct her in it and compel her to some second choice.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 93)
Now, sir, this granted--as it is a most pregnant and unforced position--who stands so eminent in the degree of this fortune as Cassio does?(Othello, Act 0, Scene 94)
knave very voluble, no further conscionable than in putting on the mere form of civil and humane seeming for the better compassing of his salt and most hidden loose affection.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 95)
Why, none, why, none! slipper and subtle knave, a finder-out of occasions, that has an eye can stamp and counterfeit advantages, though true advantage never present itself; a devilish knave!(Othello, Act 0, Scene 96)
Besides, the knave is handsome, young, and hath all those requisites in him that folly and green minds look after.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 97)
pestilent complete knave, and the woman hath found him already.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 98)
cannot believe that in her. She's full of most blessed condition.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 99)
Blessed fig's end! The wine she drinks is made of grapes.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 100)
If she had been blessed, she would never have loved the Moor.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 101)
Blessed pudding! Didst thou not see her paddle with the palm of his hand?(Othello, Act 0, Scene 102)
Didst not mark that?  Yes, that did. But that was but courtesy.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 103)
Lechery, by this hand! An index and obscure prologue to the history of lust and foul thoughts.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 104)
They met so near with their lips that their breaths embraced together.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 105)
Villainous thoughts, Roderigo! When these mutualities so marshal the way, hard at hand comes the master and main exercise, th' incorporate conclusion.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 106)
Pish! But, sir, be you ruled by me. have brought you from Venice.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 107)
Watch you tonight. For the command, I'll lay 't upon you.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 108)
Cassio knows you not. I'll not be far from you. Do you find some occasion to anger Cassio, either by speaking too loud, or tainting his discipline, or from what other course you please, which the time shall more favorably minister.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 109)
Well.  Sir, he's rash and very sudden in choler, and haply may strike at you.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 110)
Provoke him that he may, for even out of that will cause these of Cyprus to mutiny, whose qualification shall come into no true taste again but by the displanting of Cassio.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 111)
So shall you have a shorter journey to your desires by the means shall then have to prefer them, and the impediment most profitably removed, without the which there were no expectation of our prosperity.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 112)
will do this, if you can bring it to any opportunity.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 113)
warrant thee. Meet me by and by at the citadel. must fetch his necessaries ashore.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 114)
Farewell.  Adieu.   That Cassio loves her, do well believe 't.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 115)
That she loves him, 'tis apt and of great credit.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 116)
The Moor, howbeit that endure him not, Is of a constant, loving, noble nature, And dare think he'll prove to Desdemona most dear husband.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 117)
Now, do love her too, Not out of absolute lust (though peradventure stand accountant for as great a sin) But partly led to diet my revenge For that do suspect the lusty Moor Hath leaped into my seat--the thought whereof Doth, like a poisonous mineral, gnaw my inwards, And nothing can or shall content my soul Till am evened with him, wife for wife, Or, failing so, yet that put the Moor At least into a jealousy so strong That judgment cannot cure.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 118)
Which thing to do, If this poor trash of Venice, whom trace For his quick hunting, stand the putting on, I'll have our Michael Cassio on the hip, Abuse him to the Moor in the rank garb (For fear Cassio with my nightcap too), Make the Moor thank me, love me, and reward me For making him egregiously an ass And practicing upon his peace and quiet Even to madness.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 119)
'Tis here, but yet confused. Knavery's plain face is never seen till used.(Othello, Act 0, Scene 120)
It is Othello's pleasure, our noble and valiant general, that upon certain tidings now arrived, importing the mere perdition of the Turkish fleet, every man put himself into triumph: some to dance, some to make bonfires, each man to what sport and revels his addition leads him.(Othello, Act 1, Scene 0)
For besides these beneficial news, it is the celebration of his nuptial.(Othello, Act 1, Scene 1)
So much was his pleasure should be proclaimed All offices are open, and there is full liberty of feasting from this present hour of five till the bell have told eleven.(Othello, Act 1, Scene 2)
Heaven bless the isle of Cyprus and our noble general, Othello!(Othello, Act 1, Scene 3)
2        Good Michael, look you to the guard tonight.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 0)
Let's teach ourselves that honorable stop Not to outsport discretion.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 1)
Iago hath direction what to do, But notwithstanding, with my personal eye Will look to 't.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 2)
Iago is most honest. Michael, goodnight. Tomorrow with your earliest Let me have speech with you.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 3)
Come, my dear love, The purchase made, the fruits are to ensue; That profit's yet to come 'tween me and you.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 4)
-- Goodnight.       Welcome, Iago. We must to the watch.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 5)
Not this hour, lieutenant. 'Tis not yet ten o' th' clock.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 6)
Our general cast us thus early for the love of his Desdemona--who let us not therefore blame; he hath not yet made wanton the night with her, and she is sport for Jove.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 7)
She's a most exquisite lady.  And, I'll warrant her, full of game.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 8)
Indeed, she's a most fresh and delicate creature.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 9)
What an eye she has! Methinks it sounds a parley to provocation.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 10)
An inviting eye, and yet methinks right modest.  And when she speaks, is it not an alarum to love?(Othello, Act 2, Scene 11)
She is indeed perfection.  Well, happiness to their sheets!(Othello, Act 2, Scene 12)
Come, lieutenant, have a stoup of wine; and here without are a brace of Cyprus gallants that would fain have a measure to the health of black Othello.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 13)
Not tonight, good Iago. have very poor and unhappy brains for drinking.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 14)
could well wish courtesy would invent some other custom of entertainment.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 15)
they are our friends! But one cup; I'll drink for you.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 16)
have drunk but one cup tonight, and that was craftily qualified too, and behold what innovation it makes here.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 17)
am unfortunate in the infirmity and dare not task my weakness with any more.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 18)
What, man! 'Tis a night of revels. The gallants desire it.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 19)
Where are they?  Here at the door. pray you, call them in.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 20)
I'll do 't, but it dislikes me.   If can fasten but one cup upon him With that which he hath drunk tonight already, He'll be as full of quarrel and offense As my young mistress' dog.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 21)
Now my sick fool Roderigo, Whom love hath turned almost the wrong side out, To Desdemona hath tonight caroused Potations pottle-deep; and he's to watch.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 22)
Three else of Cyprus, noble swelling spirits That hold their honors in a wary distance, The very elements of this warlike isle, Have tonight flustered with flowing cups; And they watch too.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 23)
Now, 'mongst this flock of drunkards Am to put our Cassio in some action That may offend the isle.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 24)
