But here they come. If consequence do but approve my dream, My boat sails freely both with wind and stream.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 25)
'Fore God, they have given me a rouse already.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 26)
Good faith, a little one; not past a pint, as am a soldier.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 27)
Some wine, ho! And let me the cannikin clink, clink, And let me the cannikin clink.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 28)
soldier's a man, man's life's but a span, Why, then, let a soldier drink.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 29)
Some wine, boys!  'Fore God, an excellent song.  learned it in England, where indeed they are most potent in potting.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 30)
Your Dane, your German, and your swag-bellied Hollander--drink, ho!(Othello, Act 2, Scene 31)
--are nothing to your English.  Is your Englishman so exquisite in his drinking?(Othello, Act 2, Scene 32)
Why, he drinks you, with facility, your Dane dead drunk.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 33)
He sweats not to overthrow your Almain. He gives your Hollander a vomit ere the next pottle can be filled.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 34)
To the health of our general!  am for it, lieutenant, and I'll do you justice.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 35)
sweet England! King Stephen was and-a worthy peer, His breeches cost him but a crown; He held them sixpence all too dear; With that he called the tailor lown.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 36)
He was a wight of high renown, And thou art but of low degree; 'Tis pride that pulls the country down, Then take thy auld cloak about thee.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 37)
Some wine, ho!  'Fore God, this is a more exquisite song than the other!(Othello, Act 2, Scene 38)
Will you hear 't again?  No, for hold him to be unworthy of his place that does those things.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 39)
Well, God's above all; and there be souls must be saved, and there be souls must not be saved.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 40)
It's true, good lieutenant.  For mine own part--no offense to the General, nor any man of quality--I hope to be saved.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 41)
And so do too, lieutenant.  Ay, but, by your leave, not before me.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 42)
The Lieutenant is to be saved before the Ancient.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 43)
Let's have no more of this. Let's to our affairs.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 44)
God forgive us our sins! Gentlemen, let's look to our business.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 45)
Do not think, gentlemen, am drunk. This is my ancient, this is my right hand, and this is my left.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 46)
am not drunk now. can stand well enough, and speak well enough.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 47)
Excellent well.  Why, very well then. You must not think then that am drunk.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 48)
To th' platform, masters. Come, let's set the watch.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 49)
You see this fellow that is gone before? He's a soldier fit to stand by Caesar And give direction; and do but see his vice.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 50)
'Tis to his virtue a just equinox, The one as long as th' other.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 51)
'Tis pity of him. fear the trust Othello puts him in, On some odd time of his infirmity, Will shake this island.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 52)
But is he often thus?   'Tis evermore the prologue to his sleep.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 53)
He'll watch the horologe a double set If drink rock not his cradle.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 54)
It were well The General were put in mind of it.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 55)
Perhaps he sees it not, or his good nature Prizes the virtue that appears in Cassio And looks not on his evils.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 56)
Is not this true?     How now, Roderigo? pray you, after the Lieutenant, go.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 57)
And 'tis great pity that the noble Moor Should hazard such a place as his own second With one of an engraffed infirmity.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 58)
It were an honest action to say so To the Moor.  Not for this fair island.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 59)
do love Cassio well and would do much To cure him of this evil-- But hark!(Othello, Act 2, Scene 60)
What noise?     Zounds, you rogue, you rascal!  What's the matter, lieutenant?(Othello, Act 2, Scene 61)
knave teach me my duty? I'll beat the knave into a twiggen bottle.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 62)
Beat me?  Dost thou prate, rogue?  Nay, good lieutenant.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 63)
pray you, sir, hold your hand.  Let me go, sir, or I'll knock you o'er the mazard.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 64)
Come, come, you're drunk.  Drunk?    Away, say! Go out and cry a mutiny.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 65)
Nay, good lieutenant.--God's will, gentlemen!-- Help, ho!(Othello, Act 2, Scene 66)
Lieutenant--sir--Montano--sir-- Help, masters!--Here's a goodly watch indeed!(Othello, Act 2, Scene 67)
Who's that which rings the bell? Diablo, ho! The town will rise.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 68)
God's will, lieutenant, hold! You will be shamed forever.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 69)
What is the matter here?  Zounds, bleed still.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 70)
am hurt to th' death. He dies!  Hold, for your lives!(Othello, Act 2, Scene 71)
Hold, ho! Lieutenant--sir--Montano-- gentlemen-- Have you forgot all sense of place and duty?(Othello, Act 2, Scene 72)
Hold! The General speaks to you. Hold, for shame!(Othello, Act 2, Scene 73)
Why, how now, ho! From whence ariseth this? Are we turned Turks, and to ourselves do that Which heaven hath forbid the Ottomites?(Othello, Act 2, Scene 74)
For Christian shame, put by this barbarous brawl!(Othello, Act 2, Scene 75)
He that stirs next to carve for his own rage Holds his soul light; he dies upon his motion.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 76)
Silence that dreadful bell. It frights the isle From her propriety.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 77)
What is the matter, masters? Honest Iago, that looks dead with grieving, Speak.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 78)
Who began this? On thy love, charge thee.   do not know.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 79)
Friends all but now, even now, In quarter and in terms like bride and groom Divesting them for bed; and then but now, As if some planet had unwitted men, Swords out, and tilting one at other's breast, In opposition bloody.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 80)
cannot speak Any beginning to this peevish odds, And would in action glorious had lost Those legs that brought me to a part of it!(Othello, Act 2, Scene 81)
How comes it, Michael, you are thus forgot?   pray you pardon me; cannot speak.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 82)
Worthy Montano, you were wont be civil. The gravity and stillness of your youth The world hath noted.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 83)
And your name is great In mouths of wisest censure.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 84)
What's the matter That you unlace your reputation thus, And spend your rich opinion for the name Of a night-brawler?(Othello, Act 2, Scene 85)
Give me answer to it.   Worthy Othello, am hurt to danger.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 86)
Your officer Iago can inform you, While spare speech, which something now offends me, Of all that do know; nor know aught By me that's said or done amiss this night, Unless self-charity be sometimes a vice, And to defend ourselves it be a sin When violence assails us.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 87)
Now, by heaven, My blood begins my safer guides to rule, And passion, having my best judgment collied, Assays to lead the way.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 88)
Zounds, if stir, Or do but lift this arm, the best of you Shall sink in my rebuke.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 89)
Give me to know How this foul rout began, who set it on; And he that is approved in this offense, Though he had twinned with me, both at a birth, Shall lose me.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 90)
What, in a town of war Yet wild, the people's hearts brimful of fear, To manage private and domestic quarrel, In night, and on the court and guard of safety?(Othello, Act 2, Scene 91)
'Tis monstrous. Iago, who began 't?   If partially affined, or leagued in office, Thou dost deliver more or less than truth, Thou art no soldier.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 92)
Touch me not so near. had rather have this tongue cut from my mouth Than it should do offense to Michael Cassio.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 93)
Yet persuade myself, to speak the truth Shall nothing wrong him.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 94)
Thus it is, general: Montano and myself being in speech, There comes a fellow crying out for help, And Cassio following him with determined sword To execute upon him.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 95)
Sir, this gentleman  Steps in to Cassio and entreats his pause.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 96)
Myself the crying fellow did pursue, Lest by his clamor--as it so fell out-- The town might fall in fright.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 97)
He, swift of foot, Outran my purpose, and returned the rather For that heard the clink and fall of swords And Cassio high in oath, which till tonight ne'er might say before.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 98)
When came back-- For this was brief--I found them close together At blow and thrust, even as again they were When you yourself did part them.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 99)
More of this matter cannot report. But men are men; the best sometimes forget.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 100)
Though Cassio did some little wrong to him, As men in rage strike those that wish them best, Yet surely Cassio, believe, received From him that fled some strange indignity Which patience could not pass.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 101)
know, Iago, Thy honesty and love doth mince this matter, Making it light to Cassio.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 102)
--Cassio, love thee, But nevermore be officer of mine.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 103)
Look if my gentle love be not raised up! I'll make thee an example.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 104)
What is the matter, dear?  All's well now, sweeting.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 105)
Come away to bed.  Sir, for your hurts, Myself will be your surgeon.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 106)
--Lead him off.  Iago, look with care about the town And silence those whom this vile brawl distracted.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 107)
-- Come, Desdemona. 'Tis the soldier's life To have their balmy slumbers waked with strife.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 108)
What, are you hurt, lieutenant?  Ay, past all surgery.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 109)
Marry, God forbid!  Reputation, reputation, reputation!(Othello, Act 2, Scene 110)
have lost my reputation! have lost the immortal part of myself, and what remains is bestial.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 111)
My reputation, Iago, my reputation!  As am an honest man, thought you had received some bodily wound.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 112)
There is more sense in that than in reputation. Reputation is an idle and most false imposition, oft got without merit and lost without deserving.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 113)
You have lost no reputation at all, unless you repute yourself such a loser.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 114)
What, man, there are ways to recover the General again!(Othello, Act 2, Scene 115)
You are but now cast in his mood--a punishment more in policy than in malice, even so as one would beat his offenseless dog to affright an imperious lion.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 116)
Sue to him again and he's yours.  will rather sue to be despised than to deceive so good a commander with so slight, so drunken, and so indiscreet an officer.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 117)
Drunk? And speak parrot? And squabble? Swagger? Swear?(Othello, Act 2, Scene 118)
And discourse fustian with one's own shadow? thou invisible spirit of wine, if thou hast no name to be known by, let us call thee devil!(Othello, Act 2, Scene 119)
What was he that you followed with your sword? What had he done to you?(Othello, Act 2, Scene 120)
know not.  Is 't possible?  remember a mass of things, but nothing distinctly; a quarrel, but nothing wherefore.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 121)
God, that men should put an enemy in their mouths to steal away their brains!(Othello, Act 2, Scene 122)
That we should with joy, pleasance, revel, and applause transform ourselves into beasts!(Othello, Act 2, Scene 123)
Why, but you are now well enough. How came you thus recovered?(Othello, Act 2, Scene 124)
It hath pleased the devil drunkenness to give place to the devil wrath.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 125)
One unperfectness shows me another, to make me frankly despise myself.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 126)
Come, you are too severe a moraler. As the time, the place, and the condition of this country stands, could heartily wish this had not so befallen.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 127)
But since it is as it is, mend it for your own good.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 128)
will ask him for my place again; he shall tell me am a drunkard!(Othello, Act 2, Scene 129)
Had as many mouths as Hydra, such an answer would stop them all.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 130)
To be now a sensible man, by and by a fool, and presently a beast!(Othello, Act 2, Scene 131)
strange! Every inordinate cup is unblessed, and the ingredient is a devil.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 132)
Come, come, good wine is a good familiar creature, if it be well used.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 133)
Exclaim no more against it. And, good lieutenant, think you think love you.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 134)
have well approved it, sir.--I drunk!  You or any man living may be drunk at a time, man.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 135)
I'll tell you what you shall do. Our general's wife is now the general: may say so in this respect, for that he hath devoted and given up himself to the contemplation, mark, and denotement of her parts and graces.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 136)
Confess yourself freely to her. Importune her help to put you in your place again.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 137)
She is of so free, so kind, so apt, so blessed a disposition she holds it a vice in her goodness not to do more than she is requested.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 138)
This broken joint between you and her husband entreat her to splinter, and, my fortunes against any lay worth naming, this crack of your love shall grow stronger than it was before.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 139)
You advise me well.  protest, in the sincerity of love and honest kindness.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 140)
think it freely; and betimes in the morning will beseech the virtuous Desdemona to undertake for me.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 141)
am desperate of my fortunes if they check me here.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 142)
You are in the right. Good night, lieutenant. must to the watch.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 143)
Good night, honest Iago.   And what's he, then, that says play the villain, When this advice is free give and honest, Probal to thinking, and indeed the course To win the Moor again?(Othello, Act 2, Scene 144)
For 'tis most easy Th' inclining Desdemona to subdue In any honest suit.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 145)
She's framed as fruitful As the free elements. And then for her To win the Moor--were 't to renounce his baptism, All seals and symbols of redeemed sin-- His soul is so enfettered to her love That she may make, unmake, do what she list, Even as her appetite shall play the god With his weak function.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 146)
How am then a villain To counsel Cassio to this parallel course Directly to his good?(Othello, Act 2, Scene 147)
Divinity of hell! When devils will the blackest sins put on, They do suggest at first with heavenly shows, As do now.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 148)
For whiles this honest fool Plies Desdemona to repair his fortune, And she for him pleads strongly to the Moor, I'll pour this pestilence into his ear: That she repeals him for her body's lust; And by how much she strives to do him good, She shall undo her credit with the Moor.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 149)
So will turn her virtue into pitch, And out of her own goodness make the net That shall enmesh them all.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 150)
How now, Roderigo?  do follow here in the chase, not like a hound that hunts, but one that fills up the cry.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 151)
My money is almost spent, have been tonight exceedingly well cudgeled, and think the issue will be shall have so much experience for my pains, and so, with no money at all and a little more wit, return again to Venice.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 152)
How poor are they that have not patience! What wound did ever heal but by degrees?(Othello, Act 2, Scene 153)
Thou know'st we work by wit and not by witchcraft, And wit depends on dilatory time.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 154)
Does 't not go well? Cassio hath beaten thee, And thou, by that small hurt, hast cashiered Cassio.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 155)
Though other things grow fair against the sun, Yet fruits that blossom first will first be ripe.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 156)
Content thyself awhile. By th' Mass, 'tis morning!(Othello, Act 2, Scene 157)
Pleasure and action make the hours seem short. Retire thee; go where thou art billeted.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 158)
Away, say! Thou shalt know more hereafter. Nay, get thee gone.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 159)
Two things are to be done. My wife must move for Cassio to her mistress.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 160)
I'll set her on. Myself the while to draw the Moor apart And bring him jump when he may Cassio find Soliciting his wife.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 161)
Ay, that's the way. Dull not device by coldness and delay.(Othello, Act 2, Scene 162)
Yet cease your ire, you angry stars of heaven!(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 0)
Wind, rain, and thunder, remember earthly man Is but a substance that must yield to you, And as fits my nature, do obey you.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 1)
Alas, the seas hath cast me on the rocks, Washed me from shore to shore, and left my breath Nothing to think on but ensuing death.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 2)
Let it suffice the greatness of your powers To have bereft a prince of all his fortunes; And, having thrown him from your wat'ry grave, Here to have death in peace is all he'll crave.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 3)
What ho, Pilch!  Ha, come and bring away the nets!(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 4)
What, Patchbreech, say!  What say you, master?  Look how thou stirr'st now!(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 5)
Come away, or I'll fetch thee with a wanion.  Faith, master, am thinking of the poor men that were cast away before us even now.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 6)
Alas, poor souls, it grieved my heart to hear what pitiful cries they made to us to help them, when, welladay, we could scarce help ourselves!(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 7)
Nay, master, said not as much when saw the porpoise how he bounced and tumbled?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 8)
They say they're half fish, half flesh. plague on them!(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 9)
They ne'er come but look to be washed. Master, marvel how the fishes live in the sea.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 10)
Why, as men do a-land: the great ones eat up the little ones.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 11)
can compare our rich misers to nothing so fitly as to a whale: he plays and tumbles, driving the poor fry before him and at last devours them all at a mouthful.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 12)
Such whales have heard on a' the land, who never leave gaping till they swallowed the whole parish-- church, steeple, bells and all.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 13)
pretty moral.  But, master, if had been the sexton, would have been that day in the belfry.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 14)
Why, man?  Because he should have swallowed me too.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 15)
And when had been in his belly, would have kept such a jangling of the bells that he should never have left till he cast bells, steeple, church, and parish up again.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 16)
But if the good King Simonides were of my mind--  Simonides?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 17)
We would purge the land of these drones that rob the bee of her honey.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 18)
How from the finny subject of the sea These fishers tell the infirmities of men, And from their wat'ry empire recollect All that may men approve or men detect!(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 19)
-- Peace be at your labor, honest fishermen.  Honest good fellow, what's that?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 20)
If it be a day fits you, search out of the calendar, and nobody look after it!(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 21)
May see the sea hath cast upon your coast--  What a drunken knave was the sea to cast thee in our way!(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 22)
man whom both the waters and the wind In that vast tennis court hath made the ball For them to play upon entreats you pity him.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 23)
He asks of you that never used to beg.  No, friend, cannot you beg?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 24)
Here's them in our country of Greece gets more with begging than we can do with working.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 25)
Canst thou catch any fishes, then?  never practiced it.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 26)
Nay, then, thou wilt starve sure, for here's nothing to be got nowadays unless thou canst fish for 't.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 27)
What have been have forgot to know, But what am want teaches me to think on: man thronged up with cold.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 28)
My veins are chill And have no more of life than may suffice To give my tongue that heat to ask your help-- Which, if you shall refuse, when am dead, For that am a man, pray you see me buried.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 29)
Die, quotha? Now gods forbid 't, an have a gown.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 30)
Here, come, put it on; keep thee warm.  Now, afore me, a handsome fellow!(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 31)
Come, thou shalt go home, and we'll have flesh for holidays, fish for fasting days, and, moreo'er, puddings and flapjacks, and thou shalt be welcome.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 32)
thank you, sir.  Hark you, my friend. You said you could not beg?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 33)
did but crave.  But crave? Then I'll turn craver too, and so shall 'scape whipping.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 34)
Why, are your beggars whipped, then?  not all, my friend, not all; for if all your beggars were whipped, would wish no better office than to be beadle.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 35)
--But, master, I'll go draw up the net.   How well this honest mirth becomes their labor!(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 36)
Hark you, sir, do you know where you are?  Not well.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 37)
Why, I'll tell you. This is called Pentapolis, and our king the good Simonides.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 38)
"The good Simonides" do you call him?  Ay, sir, and he deserves so to be called for his peaceable reign and good government.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 39)
He is a happy king, since he gains from his subjects the name of "good" by his government.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 40)
How far is his court distant from this shore?  Marry, sir, half a day's journey.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 41)
And I'll tell you, he hath a fair daughter, and tomorrow is her birthday; and there are princes and knights come from all parts of the world to joust and tourney for her love.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 42)
Were my fortunes equal to my desires, could wish to make one there.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 43)
sir, things must be as they may; and what a man cannot get he may lawfully deal for his wife's soul.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 44)
Help, master, help! Here's a fish hangs in the net like a poor man's right in the law: 'twill hardly come out.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 45)
Ha! Bots on 't, 'tis come at last, and 'tis turned to a rusty armor.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 46)
An armor, friends? pray you let me see it.  Thanks, Fortune, yet, that after all thy crosses Thou givest me somewhat to repair myself; And though it was mine own, part of my heritage Which my dead father did bequeath to me With this strict charge even as he left his life, "Keep it, my Pericles; it hath been a shield 'Twixt me and death," and pointed to this brace, "For that it saved me, keep it.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 47)
In like necessity-- The which the gods protect thee from--may 't defend thee.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 48)
" It kept where kept, so dearly loved it, Till the rough seas, that spares not any man, Took it in rage, though calmed have given 't again.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 49)
thank thee for 't; my shipwrack now's no ill Since have here my father gave in his will.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 50)
What mean you, sir?   To beg of you, kind friends, this coat of worth, For it was sometime target to a king; know it by this mark.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 51)
He loved me dearly, And for his sake wish the having of it, And that you'd guide me to your sovereign's court, Where with it may appear a gentleman.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 52)
And if that ever my low fortune's better, I'll pay your bounties; till then, rest your debtor.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 53)
Why, wilt thou tourney for the lady?   I'll show the virtue have borne in arms.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 54)
Why, do 'ee take it, and the gods give thee good on 't.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 55)
Ay, but hark you, my friend, 'twas we that made up this garment through the rough seams of the waters.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 56)
There are certain condolements, certain vails. hope, sir, if you thrive, you'll remember from whence you had them.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 57)
Believe 't, will. By your furtherance am clothed in steel, And spite of all the rupture of the sea, This jewel holds his biding on my arm.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 58)
Unto thy value will mount myself Upon a courser, whose delightful steps Shall make the gazer joy to see him tread.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 59)
Only, my friend, yet am unprovided Of a pair of bases.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 60)
We'll sure provide. Thou shalt have my best gown to make thee a pair; and I'll bring thee to the court myself.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 61)
Then honor be but a goal to my will; This day I'll rise or else add ill to ill.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 0, Scene 62)
Are the knights ready to begin the triumph?  They are, my liege, And stay your coming to present themselves.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 0)
Return them we are ready, and our daughter here, In honor of whose birth these triumphs are, Sits here like Beauty's child, whom Nature gat For men to see and, seeing, wonder at.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 1)
It pleaseth you, my royal father, to express My commendations great, whose merit's less.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 2)
It's fit it should be so, for princes are model which heaven makes like to itself.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 3)
As jewels lose their glory if neglected, So princes their renowns if not respected.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 4)
'Tis now your honor, daughter, to entertain The labor of each knight in his device.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 5)
Which to preserve mine honor, I'll perform.        Who is the first that doth prefer himself?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 6)
knight of Sparta, my renowned father, And the device he bears upon his shield Is a black Ethiop reaching at the sun; The word: Lux tua vita mihi.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 7)
He loves you well that holds his life of you.      Who is the second that presents himself?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 8)
prince of Macedon, my royal father, And the device he bears upon his shield Is an armed knight that's conquered by a lady.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 9)
The motto thus, in Spanish: Pue per doleera kee per forsa.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 10)
And what's the third?  The third, of Antioch; And his device a wreath of chivalry; The word: Me pompae provexit apex.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 11)
What is the fourth?   burning torch that's turned upside down; The word: Qui me alit me extinguit.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 12)
Which shows that beauty hath his power and will, Which can as well inflame as it can kill.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 13)
The fifth, an hand environed with clouds, Holding out gold that's by the touchstone tried; The motto thus: Sic spectanda fides.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 14)
And what's the sixth and last, the which the knight himself With such a graceful courtesy delivered?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 15)
He seems to be a stranger; but his present is withered branch that's only green at top, The motto: In hac spe vivo.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 16)
pretty moral. From the dejected state wherein he is, He hopes by you his fortunes yet may flourish.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 17)
He had need mean better than his outward show Can any way speak in his just commend, For by his rusty outside he appears To have practiced more the whipstock than the lance.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 18)
He well may be a stranger, for he comes To an honored triumph strangely furnished.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 19)
And on set purpose let his armor rust Until this day, to scour it in the dust.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 20)
Opinion's but a fool that makes us scan The outward habit by the inward man.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 21)
But stay, the knights are coming. We will withdraw into the gallery.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 1, Scene 22)
Knights, To say you're welcome were superfluous.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 0)
To place upon the volume of your deeds, As in a title page, your worth in arms Were more than you expect or more than 's fit, Since every worth in show commends itself.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 1)
Prepare for mirth, for mirth becomes a feast. You are princes and my guests.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 2)
But you my knight and guest, To whom this wreath of victory give And crown you king of this day's happiness.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 3)
'Tis more by fortune, lady, than my merit.   Call it by what you will, the day is yours, And here, hope, is none that envies it.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 4)
In framing an artist, Art hath thus decreed, To make some good but others to exceed, And you are her labored scholar.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 5)
--Come, queen o' the feast, For, daughter, so you are; here, take your place.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 6)
-- Marshal, the rest as they deserve their grace.   We are honored much by good Simonides.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 7)
Your presence glads our days. Honor we love, For who hates honor hates the gods above.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 8)
Sir, yonder is your place.  Some other is more fit.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 9)
Contend not, sir, for we are gentlemen Have neither in our hearts nor outward eyes Envies the great, nor shall the low despise.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 10)
You are right courteous knights.  Sit, sir, sit.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 11)
By Jove wonder, that is king of thoughts, These cates resist me, he not thought upon.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 12)
By Juno, that is queen of marriage, All viands that eat do seem unsavory, Wishing him my meat.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 13)
--Sure, he's a gallant gentleman.   He's but a country gentleman; Has done no more than other knights have done; Has broken a staff or so.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 14)
So let it pass.   To me he seems like diamond to glass.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 15)
Yon king's to me like to my father's picture, Which tells in that glory once he was-- Had princes sit like stars about his throne, And he the sun for them to reverence.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 16)
None that beheld him but like lesser lights Did vail their crowns to his supremacy; Where now his son's like a glowworm in the night, The which hath fire in darkness, none in light; Whereby see that Time's the king of men.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 17)
He's both their parent, and he is their grave, And gives them what he will, not what they crave.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 18)
What, are you merry, knights?   Who can be other in this royal presence?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 19)
Here, with a cup that's stored unto the brim, As do you love, fill to your mistress' lips.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 20)
We drink this health to you.  We thank your Grace.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 21)
Yet pause awhile. Yon knight doth sit too melancholy, As if the entertainment in our court Had not a show might countervail his worth.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 22)
-- Note it not you, Thaisa?  What is 't to me, my father?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 23)
attend, my daughter. Princes in this Should live like gods above, who freely give To everyone that come to honor them.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 24)
And princes not doing so are like to gnats, Which make a sound but, killed, are wondered at.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 25)
Therefore, to make his entrance more sweet, Here, say we drink this standing-bowl of wine to him.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 26)
Alas, my father, it befits not me Unto a stranger knight to be so bold.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 27)
He may my proffer take for an offense, Since men take women's gifts for impudence.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 28)
How? Do as bid you, or you'll move me else.   Now, by the gods, he could not please me better.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 29)
And furthermore tell him we desire to know of him Of whence he is, his name and parentage.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 30)
The King, my father, sir, has drunk to you.  thank him.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 31)
Wishing it so much blood unto your life.   thank both him and you, and pledge him freely.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 32)
And further, he desires to know of you Of whence you are, your name and parentage.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 33)
gentleman of Tyre, my name Pericles. My education been in arts and arms, Who, looking for adventures in the world, Was by the rough seas reft of ships and men, And after shipwrack driven upon this shore.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 34)
He thanks your Grace; names himself Pericles, gentleman of Tyre, Who only by misfortune of the seas, Bereft of ships and men, cast on this shore.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 35)
Now, by the gods, pity his misfortune, And will awake him from his melancholy.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 36)
-- Come, gentlemen, we sit too long on trifles And waste the time which looks for other revels.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 37)
Even in your armors, as you are addressed, Will well become a soldiers' dance.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 38)
will not have excuse with saying this: "Loud music is too harsh for ladies' heads," Since they love men in arms as well as beds.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 39)
So, this was well asked, 'twas so well performed.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 40)
Come, sir. Here's a lady that wants breathing too, And have heard you knights of Tyre Are excellent in making ladies trip, And that their measures are as excellent.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 41)
In those that practice them they are, my lord.   that's as much as you would be denied Of your fair courtesy.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 42)
Unclasp, unclasp! Thanks, gentlemen, to all; all have done well; But you the best.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 43)
--Pages and lights, to conduct These knights unto their several lodgings.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 44)
Yours, sir, We have given order be next our own.  am at your Grace's pleasure.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 45)
Princes, it is too late to talk of love, And that's the mark know you level at.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 46)
Therefore each one betake him to his rest, Tomorrow all for speeding do their best.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 2, Scene 47)
2   2 Chorus      Here have you seen a mighty king His child, iwis, to incest bring; better prince and benign lord That will prove awful both in deed and word.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 0)
Be quiet, then, as men should be, Till he hath passed necessity.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 1)
I'll show you those in troubles reign, Losing a mite, a mountain gain.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 2)
The good in conversation, To whom give my benison, Is still at Tarsus, where each man Thinks all is Writ he speken can, And, to remember what he does, Build his statue to make him glorious.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 3)
But tidings to the contrary Are brought your eyes.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 4)
What need speak    Enter at one door Pericles talking with Cleon, all the train with them.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 5)
Enter at another door a Gentleman, with a letter to Pericles.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 6)
Pericles shows the letter to Cleon. Pericles gives the Messenger a reward and knights    Good Helicane, that stayed at home-- Not to eat honey like a drone From others' labors, for though he strive To killen bad, keep good alive, And to fulfill his prince' desire-- Sends word of all that haps in Tyre: How Thaliard came full bent with sin, And had intent to murder him; And that in Tarsus was not best Longer for him to make his rest.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 7)
He, doing so, put forth to seas, Where when men been there's seldom ease; For now the wind begins to blow; Thunder above and deeps below Makes such unquiet that the ship Should house him safe is wracked and split, And he, good prince, having all lost, By waves from coast to coast is tossed.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 8)
All perishen of man, of pelf, Ne aught escapend but himself; Till Fortune, tired with doing bad, Threw him ashore to give him glad.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 9)
And here he comes. What shall be next, Pardon old Gower--this 'longs the text.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 10)
No, Escanes, know this of me: Antiochus from incest lived not free, For which the most high gods not minding longer To withhold the vengeance that they had in store Due to this heinous capital offense, Even in the height and pride of all his glory, When he was seated in a chariot of An inestimable value, and his daughter with him, fire from heaven came and shriveled up Those bodies even to loathing, for they so stunk That all those eyes adored them, ere their fall, Scorn now their hand should give them burial.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 11)
'Twas very strange.   And yet but justice; for though this king were great, His greatness was no guard to bar heaven's shaft, But sin had his reward.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 12)
'Tis very true.      See, not a man in private conference Or counsel has respect with him but he.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 13)
It shall no longer grieve without reproof.   And cursed be he that will not second it.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 14)
Follow me, then.--Lord Helicane, a word.   With me?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 15)
And welcome. Happy day, my lords.   Know that our griefs are risen to the top, And now at length they overflow their banks.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 16)
Your griefs? For what? Wrong not your prince you love.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 17)
Wrong not yourself, then, noble Helicane. But if the Prince do live, let us salute him, Or know what ground's made happy by his breath.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 18)
If in the world he live, we'll seek him out; If in his grave he rest, we'll find him there, And be resolved he lives to govern us, Or dead, give 's cause to mourn his funeral And leave us to our free election.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 19)
Whose death's indeed the strongest in our censure; And knowing this kingdom is without a head-- Like goodly buildings left without a roof Soon fall to ruin--your noble self, That best know how to rule and how to reign, We thus submit unto, our sovereign.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 20)
Live, noble Helicane!   Try honor's cause; forbear your suffrages.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 21)
If that you love Prince Pericles, forbear. Take your wish, leap into the seas, Where's hourly trouble for a minute's ease.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 22)
twelve-month longer let me entreat you To forbear the absence of your king; If in which time expired, he not return, shall with aged patience bear your yoke.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 23)
But if cannot win you to this love, Go search like nobles, like noble subjects, And in your search spend your adventurous worth, Whom if you find and win unto return, You shall like diamonds sit about his crown.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 24)
To wisdom he's a fool that will not yield. And since Lord Helicane enjoineth us, We with our travels will endeavor.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 25)
Then you love us, we you, and we'll clasp hands.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 3, Scene 26)
Good morrow to the good Simonides.   Knights, from my daughter this let you know, That for this twelvemonth she'll not undertake married life.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 0)
Her reason to herself is only known, Which from her by no means can get.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 1)
May we not get access to her, my lord?   Faith, by no means; she hath so strictly tied her To her chamber that 'tis impossible.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 2)
One twelve moons more she'll wear Diana's livery.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 3)
This by the eye of Cynthia hath she vowed, And on her virgin honor will not break it.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 4)
Loath to bid farewell, we take our leaves.   So, They are well dispatched.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 5)
Now to my daughter's letter. She tells me here she'll wed the stranger knight Or never more to view nor day nor light.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 6)
'Tis well, mistress, your choice agrees with mine.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 7)
like that well. Nay, how absolute she's in 't, Not minding whether dislike or no!(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 8)
Well, do commend her choice, and will no longer Have it be delayed.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 9)
Soft, here he comes. must dissemble it.      All fortune to the good Simonides.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 10)
To you as much. Sir, am beholding to you For your sweet music this last night.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 11)
do Protest, my ears were never better fed With such delightful pleasing harmony.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 12)
It is your Grace's pleasure to commend, Not my desert.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 13)
Sir, you are music's master.   The worst of all her scholars, my good lord.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 14)
Let me ask you one thing: What do you think of my daughter, sir?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 15)
most virtuous princess.  And she is fair too, is she not?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 16)
As a fair day in summer, wondrous fair.   Sir, my daughter thinks very well of you, Ay, so well that you must be her master, And she will be your scholar.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 17)
Therefore, look to it.   am unworthy for her schoolmaster.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 18)
She thinks not so. Peruse this writing else.  What's here?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 19)
letter that she loves the knight of Tyre? 'Tis the King's subtlety to have my life.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 20)
-- seek not to entrap me, gracious lord, stranger and distressed gentleman That never aimed so high to love your daughter, But bent all offices to honor her.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 21)
Thou hast bewitched my daughter, and thou art villain.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 22)
By the gods, have not! Never did thought of mine levy offense; Nor never did my actions yet commence deed might gain her love or your displeasure.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 23)
Traitor, thou liest!  Traitor?  Ay, traitor.   Even in his throat, unless it be the King That calls me traitor, return the lie.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 24)
Now, by the gods, do applaud his courage.   My actions are as noble as my thoughts, That never relished of a base descent.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 25)
came unto your court for honor's cause, And not to be a rebel to her state, And he that otherwise accounts of me, This sword shall prove he's honor's enemy.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 26)
No? Here comes my daughter. She can witness it.      Then as you are as virtuous as fair, Resolve your angry father if my tongue Did e'er solicit or my hand subscribe To any syllable that made love to you.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 27)
Why, sir, say if you had, who takes offense At that would make me glad?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 28)
Yea, mistress, are you so peremptory? am glad on 't with all my heart.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 29)
-- I'll tame you! I'll bring you in subjection. Will you, not having my consent, Bestow your love and your affections Upon a stranger?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 30)
Who, for aught know, May be--nor can think the contrary-- As great in blood as myself.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 31)
-- Therefore, hear you, mistress: either frame Your will to mine--and you, sir, hear you: Either be ruled by me--or I'll make you Man and wife.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 32)
Nay, come, your hands and lips must seal it too. And being joined, I'll thus your hopes destroy.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 33)
And for further grief--God give you joy! What, are you both pleased?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 34)
Yes,  if you love me, sir.   Even as my life my blood that fosters it.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 35)
What, are you both agreed?  Yes, if 't please your Majesty.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 36)
It pleaseth me so well that will see you wed, And then with what haste you can, get you to bed.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 4, Scene 37)
The god of this great vast, rebuke these surges, Which wash both heaven and hell!(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 0)
And thou that hast Upon the winds command, bind them in brass, Having called them from the deep!(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 1)
still Thy deaf'ning dreadful thunders, gently quench Thy nimble sulfurous flashes.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 2)
--O, how, Lychorida, How does my queen?--Then, storm, venomously Wilt thou spit all thyself?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 3)
The seaman's whistle Is as a whisper in the ears of death, Unheard.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 4)
--Lychorida!--Lucina, Divinest patroness and midwife gentle To those that cry by night, convey thy deity Aboard our dancing boat, make swift the pangs Of my queen's travails!(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 5)
--Now, Lychorida!      Here is a thing too young for such a place, Who, if it had conceit, would die, as Am like to do.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 6)
Take in your arms this piece Of your dead queen.  How?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 7)
How, Lychorida?   Patience, good sir. Do not assist the storm.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 8)
Here's all that is left living of your queen, little daughter.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 9)
For the sake of it, Be manly and take comfort.  you gods!(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 10)
Why do you make us love your goodly gifts And snatch them straight away?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 11)
We here below Recall not what we give, and therein may Use honor with you.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 12)
Patience, good sir, Even for this charge.  Now mild may be thy life, For a more blusterous birth had never babe.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 13)
Quiet and gentle thy conditions, for Thou art the rudeliest welcome to this world That ever was prince's child.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 14)
Happy what follows! Thou hast as chiding a nativity As fire, air, water, earth, and heaven can make To herald thee from the womb.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 15)
Even at the first, thy loss is more than can Thy portage quit, with all thou canst find here.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 16)
Now the good gods throw their best eyes upon 't.     What courage, sir?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 17)
God save you.   Courage enough. do not fear the flaw.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 18)
It hath done to me the worst. Yet for the love Of this poor infant, this fresh new seafarer, would it would be quiet.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 19)
Slack the bowlines there!--Thou wilt not, wilt thou?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 20)
Blow, and split thyself!  But searoom, an the brine and cloudy billow kiss the moon, care not.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 21)
Sir, your queen must overboard. The sea works high, the wind is loud, and will not lie till the ship be cleared of the dead.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 22)
That's your superstition.  Pardon us, sir; with us at sea it hath been still observed, and we are strong in custom.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 23)
Therefore briefly yield 'er, for she must overboard straight.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 24)
As you think meet.--Most wretched queen!  Here she lies, sir.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 25)
terrible childbed hast thou had, my dear, No light, no fire.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 26)
Th' unfriendly elements Forgot thee utterly. Nor have time To give thee hallowed to thy grave, but straight Must cast thee, scarcely coffined, in the ooze, Where, for a monument upon thy bones And e'er-remaining lamps, the belching whale And humming water must o'erwhelm thy corpse, Lying with simple shells.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 27)
--O, Lychorida, Bid Nestor bring me spices, ink, and paper, My casket and my jewels; and bid Nicander Bring me the satin coffin.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 28)
Lay the babe Upon the pillow. Hie thee, whiles say priestly farewell to her.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 29)
Suddenly, woman!   Sir, we have a chest beneath the hatches, caulked and bitumed ready.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 30)
thank thee, mariner. Say, what coast is this?  We are near Tarsus.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 31)
Thither, gentle mariner. Alter thy course for Tyre.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 32)
When canst thou reach it?  By break of day if the wind cease.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 33)
make for Tarsus! There will visit Cleon, for the babe Cannot hold out to Tyrus.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 34)
There I'll leave it At careful nursing. Go thy ways, good mariner.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 22, Scene 35)
Philemon, ho!     Doth my lord call?  Get fire and meat for these poor men.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 0)
has been a turbulent and stormy night.    have been in many; but such a night as this, Till now, ne'er endured.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 1)
Your master will be dead ere you return. There's nothing can be ministered to nature That can recover him.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 2)
Give this to the 'pothecary, And tell me how it works.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 3)
Good morrow.  Good morrow to your Lordship.   Gentlemen, why do you stir so early?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 4)
Sir, Our lodgings, standing bleak upon the sea, Shook as the earth did quake.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 5)
The very principals did seem to rend And all to topple.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 6)
Pure surprise and fear Made me to quit the house.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 7)
That is the cause we trouble you so early. 'Tis not our husbandry.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 8)
you say well.   But much marvel that your Lordship, having Rich tire about you, should at these early hours Shake off the golden slumber of repose.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 9)
'Tis most strange Nature should be so conversant with pain, Being thereto not compelled.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 10)
hold it ever Virtue and cunning were endowments greater Than nobleness and riches.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 11)
Careless heirs May the two latter darken and expend, But immortality attends the former, Making a man a god.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 12)
'Tis known ever Have studied physic, through which secret art, By turning o'er authorities, have, Together with my practice, made familiar To me and to my aid the blessed infusions That dwells in vegetives, in metals, stones; And can speak of the disturbances That Nature works, and of her cures; which doth give me more content in course of true delight Than to be thirsty after tottering honor, Or tie my pleasure up in silken bags To please the fool and death.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 13)
Your Honor has through Ephesus poured forth Your charity, and hundreds call themselves Your creatures, who by you have been restored; And not your knowledge, your personal pain, but even Your purse, still open, hath built Lord Cerimon Such strong renown, as time shall never--      So, lift there.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 14)
What's that?  Sir, even now Did the sea toss up upon our shore this chest.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 15)
'Tis of some wrack.  Set 't down. Let's look upon 't.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 16)
'Tis like a coffin, sir.  What e'er it be, 'Tis wondrous heavy.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 17)
Wrench it open straight. If the sea's stomach be o'ercharged with gold, 'Tis a good constraint of Fortune it belches upon us.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 18)
'Tis so, my lord.  How close 'tis caulked and bitumed!(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 19)
Did the sea cast it up?   never saw so huge a billow, sir, As tossed it upon shore.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 20)
Wrench it open. Soft! It smells most sweetly in my sense.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 21)
delicate odor.   As ever hit my nostril. So, up with it.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 22)
you most potent gods! What's here? corse?  Most strange!(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 23)
Shrouded in cloth of state, balmed and entreasured With full bags of spices.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 24)
passport too! Apollo, perfect me in the characters.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 25)
Here give to understand, If e'er this coffin drives aland, King Pericles, have lost This queen, worth all our mundane cost.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 26)
Who finds her, give her burying. She was the daughter of a king.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 27)
Besides this treasure for a fee, The gods requite his charity.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 28)
If thou livest, Pericles, thou hast a heart That ever cracks for woe.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 29)
This chanced tonight.   Most likely, sir.  Nay, certainly tonight, For look how fresh she looks.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 30)
They were too rough That threw her in the sea.--Make a fire within; Fetch hither all my boxes in my closet.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 31)
Death may usurp on nature many hours, And yet the fire of life kindle again The o'erpressed spirits.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 32)
heard of an Egyptian That had nine hours lain dead, Who was by good appliance recovered.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 33)
Well said, well said! The fire and cloths. The rough and woeful music that we have, Cause it to sound, beseech you.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 34)
The viol once more! How thou stirr'st, thou block!(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 35)
The music there.  pray you, give her air. Gentlemen, This queen will live.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 36)
Nature awakes a warm breath Out of her. She hath not been entranced Above five hours.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 37)
See how she gins to blow Into life's flower again.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 38)
The heavens, through you, Increase our wonder, and sets up your fame Forever.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 39)
She is alive. Behold her eyelids-- Cases to those heavenly jewels which Pericles hath lost-- Begin to part their fringes of bright gold.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 40)
The diamonds of a most praised water doth Appear to make the world twice rich.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 41)
--Live, And make us weep to hear your fate, fair creature, Rare as you seem to be.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 42)
dear Diana, Where am Where's my lord? What world is this?(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 43)
Is not this strange?  Most rare!  Hush, my gentle neighbors!(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 44)
Lend me your hands. To the next chamber bear her.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 45)
Get linen. Now this matter must be looked to, For her relapse is mortal.(Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Act 23, Scene 46)
Will the King come, that may breathe my last In wholesome counsel to his unstaid youth?(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 0)
Vex not yourself nor strive not with your breath, For all in vain comes counsel to his ear.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 1)
but they say the tongues of dying men Enforce attention like deep harmony.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 2)
Where words are scarce, they are seldom spent in vain, For they breathe truth that breathe their words in pain.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 3)
He that no more must say is listened more Than they whom youth and ease have taught to gloze.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 4)
More are men's ends marked than their lives before.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 5)
The setting sun and music at the close, As the last taste of sweets, is sweetest last, Writ in remembrance more than things long past.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 6)
Though Richard my life's counsel would not hear, My death's sad tale may yet undeaf his ear.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 7)
No, it is stopped with other flattering sounds, As praises, of whose taste the wise are fond; Lascivious meters, to whose venom sound The open ear of youth doth always listen; Report of fashions in proud Italy, Whose manners still our tardy-apish nation Limps after in base imitation.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 8)
Where doth the world thrust forth a vanity-- So it be new, there's no respect how vile-- That is not quickly buzzed into his ears?(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 9)
Then all too late comes counsel to be heard Where will doth mutiny with wit's regard.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 10)
Direct not him whose way himself will choose. 'Tis breath thou lack'st, and that breath wilt thou lose.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 11)
Methinks am a prophet new inspired And thus expiring do foretell of him: His rash fierce blaze of riot cannot last, For violent fires soon burn out themselves; Small showers last long, but sudden storms are short; He tires betimes that spurs too fast betimes; With eager feeding food doth choke the feeder; Light vanity, insatiate cormorant, Consuming means, soon preys upon itself.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 12)
This royal throne of kings, this sceptered isle, This earth of majesty, this seat of Mars, This other Eden, demi-paradise, This fortress built by Nature for herself Against infection and the hand of war, This happy breed of men, this little world, This precious stone set in the silver sea, Which serves it in the office of a wall Or as a moat defensive to a house, Against the envy of less happier lands, This blessed plot, this earth, this realm, this England, This nurse, this teeming womb of royal kings, Feared by their breed and famous by their birth, Renowned for their deeds as far from home For Christian service and true chivalry As is the sepulcher in stubborn Jewry Of the world's ransom, blessed Mary's son, This land of such dear souls, this dear dear land, Dear for her reputation through the world, Is now leased out--I die pronouncing it-- Like to a tenement or pelting farm.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 13)
England, bound in with the triumphant sea, Whose rocky shore beats back the envious siege Of wat'ry Neptune, is now bound in with shame, With inky blots and rotten parchment bonds.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 14)
That England that was wont to conquer others Hath made a shameful conquest of itself.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 15)
Ah, would the scandal vanish with my life, How happy then were my ensuing death!(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 16)
The King is come. Deal mildly with his youth, For young hot colts being reined do rage the more.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 17)
How fares our noble uncle Lancaster?   What comfort, man?(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 18)
How is 't with aged Gaunt?   how that name befits my composition!(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 19)
Old Gaunt indeed and gaunt in being old. Within me grief hath kept a tedious fast, And who abstains from meat that is not gaunt?(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 20)
For sleeping England long time have watched; Watching breeds leanness, leanness is all gaunt.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 21)
The pleasure that some fathers feed upon Is my strict fast--I mean my children's looks-- And, therein fasting, hast thou made me gaunt.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 22)
Gaunt am for the grave, gaunt as a grave, Whose hollow womb inherits naught but bones.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 23)
Can sick men play so nicely with their names?   No, misery makes sport to mock itself.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 24)
Since thou dost seek to kill my name in me, mock my name, great king, to flatter thee.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 25)
Should dying men flatter with those that live?   No, no, men living flatter those that die.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 26)
Thou, now a-dying, sayest thou flatterest me.   no, thou diest, though the sicker be.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 27)
am in health, breathe, and see thee ill.   Now He that made me knows see thee ill, Ill in myself to see, and in thee, seeing ill.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 28)
Thy deathbed is no lesser than thy land, Wherein thou liest in reputation sick; And thou, too careless-patient as thou art, Commit'st thy anointed body to the cure Of those physicians that first wounded thee.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 29)
thousand flatterers sit within thy crown, Whose compass is no bigger than thy head, And yet encaged in so small a verge, The waste is no whit lesser than thy land.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 30)
had thy grandsire with a prophet's eye Seen how his son's son should destroy his sons, From forth thy reach he would have laid thy shame, Deposing thee before thou wert possessed, Which art possessed now to depose thyself.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 31)
Why, cousin, wert thou regent of the world, It were a shame to let this land by lease; But, for thy world enjoying but this land, Is it not more than shame to shame it so?(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 32)
Landlord of England art thou now, not king. Thy state of law is bondslave to the law, And thou--  lunatic lean-witted fool, Presuming on an ague's privilege, Darest with thy frozen admonition Make pale our cheek, chasing the royal blood With fury from his native residence.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 33)
Now, by my seat's right royal majesty, Wert thou not brother to great Edward's son, This tongue that runs so roundly in thy head Should run thy head from thy unreverent shoulders.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 34)
spare me not, my brother Edward's son, For that was his father Edward's son!(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 35)
That blood already, like the pelican, Hast thou tapped out and drunkenly caroused.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 36)
My brother Gloucester--plain, well-meaning soul, Whom fair befall in heaven 'mongst happy souls-- May be a precedent and witness good That thou respect'st not spilling Edward's blood.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 37)
Join with the present sickness that have, And thy unkindness be like crooked age To crop at once a too-long withered flower.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 38)
Live in thy shame, but die not shame with thee! These words hereafter thy tormentors be!(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 39)
-- Convey me to my bed, then to my grave. Love they to live that love and honor have.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 40)
And let them die that age and sullens have, For both hast thou, and both become the grave.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 41)
do beseech your Majesty, impute his words To wayward sickliness and age in him.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 42)
He loves you, on my life, and holds you dear As Harry, Duke of Hereford, were he here.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 43)
Right, you say true: as Hereford's love, so his; As theirs, so mine; and all be as it is.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 44)
My liege, old Gaunt commends him to your Majesty.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 45)
What says he?  Nay, nothing; all is said. His tongue is now a stringless instrument; Words, life, and all, old Lancaster hath spent.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 46)
Be York the next that must be bankrupt so! Though death be poor, it ends a mortal woe.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 47)
The ripest fruit first falls, and so doth he; His time is spent, our pilgrimage must be.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 48)
So much for that. Now for our Irish wars: We must supplant those rough rugheaded kern, Which live like venom where no venom else But only they have privilege to live.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 49)
And, for these great affairs do ask some charge, Towards our assistance we do seize to us The plate, coin, revenues, and movables Whereof our uncle Gaunt did stand possessed.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 50)
How long shall be patient? Ah, how long Shall tender duty make me suffer wrong?(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 51)
Not Gloucester's death, nor Hereford's banishment, Nor Gaunt's rebukes, nor England's private wrongs, Nor the prevention of poor Bolingbroke About his marriage, nor my own disgrace, Have ever made me sour my patient cheek Or bend one wrinkle on my sovereign's face.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 52)
am the last of noble Edward's sons, Of whom thy father, Prince of Wales, was first.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 53)
In war was never lion raged more fierce, In peace was never gentle lamb more mild, Than was that young and princely gentleman.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 54)
His face thou hast, for even so looked he, Accomplished with the number of thy hours; But when he frowned, it was against the French And not against his friends.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 55)
His noble hand Did win what he did spend, and spent not that Which his triumphant father's hand had won.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 56)
His hands were guilty of no kindred blood, But bloody with the enemies of his kin.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 57)
Richard! York is too far gone with grief, Or else he never would compare between.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 58)
Why, uncle, what's the matter?  my liege, Pardon me if you please.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 59)
If not, pleased Not to be pardoned, am content withal.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 60)
Seek you to seize and gripe into your hands The royalties and rights of banished Hereford?(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 61)
Is not Gaunt dead? And doth not Hereford live? Was not Gaunt just?(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 62)
And is not Harry true? Did not the one deserve to have an heir?(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 63)
Is not his heir a well-deserving son? Take Hereford's rights away, and take from time His charters and his customary rights; Let not tomorrow then ensue today; Be not thyself; for how art thou a king But by fair sequence and succession?(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 64)
Now afore God--God forbid say true!-- If you do wrongfully seize Hereford's rights, Call in the letters patents that he hath By his attorneys general to sue His livery, and deny his offered homage, You pluck a thousand dangers on your head, You lose a thousand well-disposed hearts, And prick my tender patience to those thoughts Which honor and allegiance cannot think.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 65)
Think what you will, we seize into our hands His plate, his goods, his money, and his lands.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 66)
I'll not be by the while. My liege, farewell. What will ensue hereof there's none can tell; But by bad courses may be understood That their events can never fall out good.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 67)
Go, Bushy, to the Earl of Wiltshire straight. Bid him repair to us to Ely House To see this business.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 68)
Tomorrow next We will for Ireland, and 'tis time, trow.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 69)
And we create, in absence of ourself, Our uncle York Lord Governor of England, For he is just and always loved us well.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 70)
-- Come on, our queen. Tomorrow must we part. Be merry, for our time of stay is short.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 71)
Well, lords, the Duke of Lancaster is dead.   And living too, for now his son is duke.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 72)
Barely in title, not in revenues.   Richly in both, if justice had her right.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 73)
My heart is great, but it must break with silence Ere 't be disburdened with a liberal tongue.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 74)
Nay, speak thy mind, and let him ne'er speak more That speaks thy words again to do thee harm!(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 75)
Tends that thou wouldst speak to the Duke of Hereford?(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 76)
If it be so, out with it boldly, man. Quick is mine ear to hear of good towards him.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 77)
No good at all that can do for him, Unless you call it good to pity him, Bereft and gelded of his patrimony.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 78)
Now, afore God, 'tis shame such wrongs are borne In him, a royal prince, and many more Of noble blood in this declining land.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 79)
The King is not himself, but basely led By flatterers; and what they will inform Merely in hate 'gainst any of us all, That will the King severely prosecute 'Gainst us, our lives, our children, and our heirs.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 80)
The commons hath he pilled with grievous taxes, And quite lost their hearts.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 81)
The nobles hath he fined For ancient quarrels, and quite lost their hearts.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 82)
And daily new exactions are devised, As blanks, benevolences, and wot not what.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 83)
But what i' God's name doth become of this?   Wars hath not wasted it, for warred he hath not, But basely yielded upon compromise That which his noble ancestors achieved with blows.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 84)
More hath he spent in peace than they in wars.   The Earl of Wiltshire hath the realm in farm.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 85)
The King grown bankrupt like a broken man.   Reproach and dissolution hangeth over him.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 86)
He hath not money for these Irish wars, His burdenous taxations notwithstanding, But by the robbing of the banished duke.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 87)
His noble kinsman. Most degenerate king! But, lords, we hear this fearful tempest sing, Yet seek no shelter to avoid the storm; We see the wind sit sore upon our sails, And yet we strike not, but securely perish.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 88)
We see the very wrack that we must suffer, And unavoided is the danger now For suffering so the causes of our wrack.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 89)
Not so. Even through the hollow eyes of death spy life peering; but dare not say How near the tidings of our comfort is.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 90)
Nay, let us share thy thoughts, as thou dost ours.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 91)
Be confident to speak, Northumberland. We three are but thyself, and speaking so Thy words are but as thoughts.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 92)
Therefore be bold.   Then thus: have from Le Port Blanc, bay in Brittany, received intelligence That Harry Duke of Hereford, Rainold Lord Cobham, That late broke from the Duke of Exeter, His brother, archbishop late of Canterbury, Sir Thomas Erpingham, Sir John Ramston, Sir John Norbery, Sir Robert Waterton, and Francis Coint-- All these well furnished by the Duke of Brittany With eight tall ships, three thousand men of war, Are making hither with all due expedience And shortly mean to touch our northern shore.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 93)
Perhaps they had ere this, but that they stay The first departing of the King for Ireland.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 94)
If then we shall shake off our slavish yoke, Imp out our drooping country's broken wing, Redeem from broking pawn the blemished crown, Wipe off the dust that hides our scepter's gilt, And make high majesty look like itself, Away with me in post to Ravenspurgh.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 95)
But if you faint, as fearing to do so, Stay and be secret, and myself will go.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 96)
To horse, to horse! Urge doubts to them that fear.(Richard II, Act 0, Scene 97)
Madam, your Majesty is too much sad. You promised, when you parted with the King, To lay aside life-harming heaviness And entertain a cheerful disposition.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 0)
To please the King did; to please myself cannot do it.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 1)
Yet know no cause Why should welcome such a guest as grief, Save bidding farewell to so sweet a guest As my sweet Richard.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 2)
Yet again methinks Some unborn sorrow ripe in Fortune's womb Is coming towards me, and my inward soul With nothing trembles.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 3)
At some thing it grieves More than with parting from my lord the King.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 4)
Each substance of a grief hath twenty shadows Which shows like grief itself but is not so; For sorrow's eyes, glazed with blinding tears, Divides one thing entire to many objects, Like perspectives, which rightly gazed upon Show nothing but confusion, eyed awry Distinguish form.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 5)
So your sweet Majesty, Looking awry upon your lord's departure, Find shapes of grief more than himself to wail, Which, looked on as it is, is naught but shadows Of what it is not.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 6)
Then, thrice-gracious queen, More than your lord's departure weep not.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 7)
More is not seen, Or if it be, 'tis with false sorrow's eye, Which for things true weeps things imaginary.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 8)
It may be so, but yet my inward soul Persuades me it is otherwise.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 9)
Howe'er it be, cannot but be sad--so heavy sad As thought, on thinking on no thought think, Makes me with heavy nothing faint and shrink.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 10)
'Tis nothing but conceit, my gracious lady.   'Tis nothing less.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 11)
Conceit is still derived From some forefather grief.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 12)
Mine is not so, For nothing hath begot my something grief-- Or something hath the nothing that grieve.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 13)
'Tis in reversion that do possess, But what it is that is not yet known what, cannot name.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 14)
'Tis nameless woe, wot.      God save your Majesty!(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 15)
--And well met, gentlemen. hope the King is not yet shipped for Ireland.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 16)
Why hopest thou so? 'Tis better hope he is, For his designs crave haste, his haste good hope.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 17)
Then wherefore dost thou hope he is not shipped?   That he, our hope, might have retired his power And driven into despair an enemy's hope, Who strongly hath set footing in this land.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 18)
The banished Bolingbroke repeals himself And with uplifted arms is safe arrived At Ravenspurgh.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 19)
Now God in heaven forbid!   Ah, madam, 'tis too true.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 20)
And that is worse, The Lord Northumberland, his son young Harry Percy, The Lords of Ross, Beaumont, and Willoughby, With all their powerful friends, are fled to him.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 21)
Why have you not proclaimed Northumberland And all the rest revolted faction traitors?(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 22)
We have; whereupon the Earl of Worcester Hath broken his staff, resigned his stewardship, And all the Household servants fled with him To Bolingbroke.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 23)
So, Green, thou art the midwife to my woe, And Bolingbroke my sorrow's dismal heir.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 24)
Now hath my soul brought forth her prodigy, And a gasping new-delivered mother, Have woe to woe, sorrow to sorrow joined.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 25)
Despair not, madam.  Who shall hinder me? will despair and be at enmity With cozening hope.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 26)
He is a flatterer, parasite, a keeper-back of death, Who gently would dissolve the bands of life Which false hope lingers in extremity.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 27)
Here comes the Duke of York.   With signs of war about his aged neck.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 28)
full of careful business are his looks!-- Uncle, for God's sake speak comfortable words.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 29)
Should do so, should belie my thoughts. Comfort's in heaven, and we are on the Earth, Where nothing lives but crosses, cares, and grief.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 30)
Your husband, he is gone to save far off Whilst others come to make him lose at home.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 31)
Here am left to underprop his land, Who, weak with age, cannot support myself.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 32)
Now comes the sick hour that his surfeit made; Now shall he try his friends that flattered him.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 33)
My lord, your son was gone before came.   He was?(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 34)
Why, so go all which way it will. The nobles they are fled; the commons they are cold And will, fear, revolt on Hereford's side.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 35)
Sirrah, get thee to Plashy, to my sister Gloucester; Bid her send me presently a thousand pound.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 36)
Hold, take my ring.   My lord, had forgot to tell your Lordship: Today as came by called there-- But shall grieve you to report the rest.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 37)
What is 't, knave?   An hour before came, the Duchess died.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 38)
God for His mercy, what a tide of woes Comes rushing on this woeful land at once!(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 39)
know not what to do. would to God, So my untruth had not provoked him to it, The King had cut off my head with my brother's!(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 40)
What, are there no posts dispatched for Ireland? How shall we do for money for these wars?(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 41)
-- Come, sister--cousin would say, pray pardon me.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 42)
-- Go, fellow, get thee home. Provide some carts And bring away the armor that is there.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 43)
Gentlemen, will you go muster men? If know how or which way to order these affairs Thus disorderly thrust into my hands, Never believe me.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 44)
