Both are my kinsmen. one is my sovereign, whom both my oath And duty bids defend; t' other again Is my kinsman, whom the King hath wronged, Whom conscience and my kindred bids to right.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 45)
Well, somewhat we must do.  Come, cousin, I'll dispose of you.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 46)
--Gentlemen, go muster up your men And meet me presently at Berkeley.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 47)
should to Plashy too, But time will not permit. All is uneven, And everything is left at six and seven.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 48)
The wind sits fair for news to go for Ireland, But none returns.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 49)
For us to levy power Proportionable to the enemy Is all unpossible.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 50)
Besides, our nearness to the King in love Is near the hate of those love not the King.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 51)
And that is the wavering commons, for their love Lies in their purses, and whoso empties them By so much fills their hearts with deadly hate.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 52)
Wherein the King stands generally condemned.   If judgment lie in them, then so do we, Because we ever have been near the King.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 53)
Well, will for refuge straight to Bristow Castle.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 54)
The Earl of Wiltshire is already there.   Thither will with you, for little office Will the hateful commons perform for us, Except like curs to tear us all to pieces.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 55)
-- Will you go along with us?   No, will to Ireland to his Majesty.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 56)
Farewell. If heart's presages be not vain, We three here part that ne'er shall meet again.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 57)
That's as York thrives to beat back Bolingbroke.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 58)
Alas, poor duke, the task he undertakes Is numb'ring sands and drinking oceans dry.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 59)
Where one on his side fights, thousands will fly.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 60)
Farewell at once, for once, for all, and ever.   Well, we may meet again.(Richard II, Act 1, Scene 61)
How far is it, my lord, to Berkeley now?  Believe me, noble lord, am a stranger here in Gloucestershire.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 0)
These high wild hills and rough uneven ways Draws out our miles and makes them wearisome.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 1)
And yet your fair discourse hath been as sugar, Making the hard way sweet and delectable.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 2)
But bethink me what a weary way From Ravenspurgh to Cotshall will be found In Ross and Willoughby, wanting your company, Which, protest, hath very much beguiled The tediousness and process of my travel.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 3)
But theirs is sweetened with the hope to have The present benefit which possess, And hope to joy is little less in joy Than hope enjoyed.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 4)
By this the weary lords Shall make their way seem short as mine hath done By sight of what have, your noble company.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 5)
Of much less value is my company Than your good words.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 6)
But who comes here?     It is my son, young Harry Percy, Sent from my brother Worcester whencesoever.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 7)
-- Harry, how fares your uncle?   had thought, my lord, to have learned his health of you.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 8)
Why, is he not with the Queen?   No, my good lord, he hath forsook the court, Broken his staff of office, and dispersed The Household of the King.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 9)
What was his reason? He was not so resolved When last we spake together.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 10)
Because your Lordship was proclaimed traitor. But he, my lord, is gone to Ravenspurgh To offer service to the Duke of Hereford, And sent me over by Berkeley to discover What power the Duke of York had levied there, Then with directions to repair to Ravenspurgh.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 11)
Have you forgot the Duke of Hereford, boy?   No, my good lord, for that is not forgot Which ne'er did remember.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 12)
To my knowledge never in my life did look on him.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 13)
Then learn to know him now. This is the Duke.   My gracious lord, tender you my service, Such as it is, being tender, raw, and young, Which elder days shall ripen and confirm To more approved service and desert.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 14)
thank thee, gentle Percy, and be sure count myself in nothing else so happy As in a soul rememb'ring my good friends; And as my fortune ripens with thy love, It shall be still thy true love's recompense.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 15)
My heart this covenant makes, my hand thus seals it.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 16)
How far is it to Berkeley, and what stir Keeps good old York there with his men of war?(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 17)
There stands the castle by yon tuft of trees, Manned with three hundred men, as have heard, And in it are the Lords of York, Berkeley, and Seymour, None else of name and noble estimate.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 18)
Here come the Lords of Ross and Willoughby, Bloody with spurring, fiery red with haste.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 19)
Welcome, my lords. wot your love pursues banished traitor.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 20)
All my treasury Is yet but unfelt thanks, which, more enriched, Shall be your love and labor's recompense.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 21)
Your presence makes us rich, most noble lord.   And far surmounts our labor to attain it.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 22)
Evermore thank's the exchequer of the poor, Which, till my infant fortune comes to years, Stands for my bounty.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 23)
But who comes here?      It is my Lord of Berkeley, as guess.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 24)
My Lord of Hereford, my message is to you.   My lord, my answer is--to "Lancaster"; And am come to seek that name in England.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 25)
And must find that title in your tongue Before make reply to aught you say.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 26)
Mistake me not, my lord, 'tis not my meaning To rase one title of your honor out.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 27)
To you, my lord, come, what lord you will, From the most gracious regent of this land, The Duke of York, to know what pricks you on To take advantage of the absent time, And fright our native peace with self-borne arms.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 28)
shall not need transport my words by you. Here comes his Grace in person.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 29)
My noble uncle.   Show me thy humble heart and not thy knee, Whose duty is deceivable and false.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 30)
My gracious uncle--  Tut, tut! Grace me no grace, nor uncle me no uncle.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 31)
am no traitor's uncle, and that word "grace" In an ungracious mouth is but profane.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 32)
Why have those banished and forbidden legs Dared once to touch a dust of England's ground?(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 33)
But then, more why: why have they dared to march So many miles upon her peaceful bosom, Frighting her pale-faced villages with war And ostentation of despised arms?(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 34)
Com'st thou because the anointed king is hence? Why, foolish boy, the King is left behind And in my loyal bosom lies his power.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 35)
Were but now lord of such hot youth As when brave Gaunt thy father and myself Rescued the Black Prince, that young Mars of men, From forth the ranks of many thousand French, then, how quickly should this arm of mine, Now prisoner to the palsy, chastise thee And minister correction to thy fault!(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 36)
My gracious uncle, let me know my fault. On what condition stands it and wherein?(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 37)
Even in condition of the worst degree, In gross rebellion and detested treason.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 38)
Thou art a banished man and here art come, Before the expiration of thy time, In braving arms against thy sovereign.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 39)
As was banished, was banished Hereford, But as come, come for Lancaster.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 40)
And, noble uncle, beseech your Grace Look on my wrongs with an indifferent eye.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 41)
You are my father, for methinks in you see old Gaunt alive.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 42)
then, my father, Will you permit that shall stand condemned wandering vagabond, my rights and royalties Plucked from my arms perforce and given away To upstart unthrifts?(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 43)
Wherefore was born? If that my cousin king be king in England, It must be granted am Duke of Lancaster.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 44)
You have a son, Aumerle, my noble cousin. Had you first died and he been thus trod down, He should have found his uncle Gaunt a father To rouse his wrongs and chase them to the bay.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 45)
am denied to sue my livery here, And yet my letters patents give me leave.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 46)
My father's goods are all distrained and sold, And these, and all, are all amiss employed.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 47)
What would you have me do? am a subject, And challenge law.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 48)
Attorneys are denied me, And therefore personally lay my claim To my inheritance of free descent.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 49)
The noble duke hath been too much abused.   It stands your Grace upon to do him right.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 50)
Base men by his endowments are made great.   My lords of England, let me tell you this: have had feeling of my cousin's wrongs And labored all could to do him right.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 51)
But in this kind to come, in braving arms, Be his own carver and cut out his way To find out right with wrong, it may not be.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 52)
And you that do abet him in this kind Cherish rebellion and are rebels all.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 53)
The noble duke hath sworn his coming is But for his own, and for the right of that We all have strongly sworn to give him aid.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 54)
And let him never see joy that breaks that oath.   Well, well.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 55)
see the issue of these arms. cannot mend it, must needs confess, Because my power is weak and all ill-left.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 56)
But if could, by Him that gave me life, would attach you all and make you stoop Unto the sovereign mercy of the King.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 57)
But since cannot, be it known unto you do remain as neuter.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 58)
So fare you well-- Unless you please to enter in the castle And there repose you for this night.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 59)
An offer, uncle, that we will accept. But we must win your Grace to go with us To Bristow Castle, which they say is held By Bushy, Bagot, and their complices, The caterpillars of the commonwealth, Which have sworn to weed and pluck away.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 60)
It may be will go with you; but yet I'll pause, For am loath to break our country's laws.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 61)
Nor friends nor foes, to me welcome you are. Things past redress are now with me past care.(Richard II, Act 2, Scene 62)
2        My Lord of Salisbury, we have stayed ten days And hardly kept our countrymen together, And yet we hear no tidings from the King.(Richard II, Act 3, Scene 0)
Therefore we will disperse ourselves. Farewell.   Stay yet another day, thou trusty Welshman.(Richard II, Act 3, Scene 1)
The King reposeth all his confidence in thee.   'Tis thought the King is dead.(Richard II, Act 3, Scene 2)
We will not stay. The bay trees in our country are all withered, And meteors fright the fixed stars of heaven; The pale-faced moon looks bloody on the Earth, And lean-looked prophets whisper fearful change; Rich men look sad, and ruffians dance and leap, The one in fear to lose what they enjoy, The other to enjoy by rage and war.(Richard II, Act 3, Scene 3)
These signs forerun the death or fall of kings. Farewell.(Richard II, Act 3, Scene 4)
Our countrymen are gone and fled, As well assured Richard their king is dead.(Richard II, Act 3, Scene 5)
Ah, Richard! With the eyes of heavy mind see thy glory like a shooting star Fall to the base earth from the firmament.(Richard II, Act 3, Scene 6)
Thy sun sets weeping in the lowly west, Witnessing storms to come, woe, and unrest.(Richard II, Act 3, Scene 7)
Thy friends are fled to wait upon thy foes, And crossly to thy good all fortune goes.(Richard II, Act 3, Scene 8)
Lord Marquess Dorset, Rivers, Hastings, Buckingham,     Why, so.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 0)
Now have done a good day's work. You peers, continue this united league.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 1)
every day expect an embassage From my Redeemer to redeem me hence, And more in peace my soul shall part to heaven Since have made my friends at peace on Earth.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 2)
Rivers and Hastings, take each other's hand. Dissemble not your hatred.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 3)
Swear your love.   By heaven, my soul is purged from grudging hate, And with my hand seal my true heart's love.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 4)
So thrive as truly swear the like.   Take heed you dally not before your king, Lest He that is the supreme King of kings Confound your hidden falsehood and award Either of you to be the other's end.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 5)
So prosper as swear perfect love.   And as love Hastings with my heart.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 6)
Madam, yourself is not exempt from this,-- Nor you, son Dorset,--Buckingham, nor you.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 7)
You have been factious one against the other.-- Wife, love Lord Hastings.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 8)
Let him kiss your hand, And what you do, do it unfeignedly.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 9)
There, Hastings, will never more remember Our former hatred, so thrive and mine.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 10)
Dorset, embrace him.--Hastings, love Lord Marquess.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 11)
This interchange of love, here protest, Upon my part shall be inviolable.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 12)
And so swear   Now, princely Buckingham, seal thou this league With thy embracements to my wife's allies And make me happy in your unity.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 13)
Whenever Buckingham doth turn his hate Upon your Grace, but with all duteous love Doth cherish you and yours, God punish me With hate in those where expect most love.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 14)
When have most need to employ a friend, And most assured that he is a friend, Deep, hollow, treacherous, and full of guile Be he unto me: this do beg of God, When am cold in love to you or yours.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 15)
pleasing cordial, princely Buckingham, Is this thy vow unto my sickly heart.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 16)
There wanteth now our brother Gloucester here To make the blessed period of this peace.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 17)
And in good time Here comes Sir Richard Ratcliffe and the Duke.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 18)
Good morrow to my sovereign king and queen, And, princely peers, a happy time of day.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 19)
Happy indeed, as we have spent the day. Gloucester, we have done deeds of charity, Made peace of enmity, fair love of hate, Between these swelling, wrong-incensed peers.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 20)
blessed labor, my most sovereign lord. Among this princely heap, if any here By false intelligence or wrong surmise Hold me a foe, If unwittingly, or in my rage, Have aught committed that is hardly borne By any in this presence, desire To reconcile me to his friendly peace.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 21)
'Tis death to me to be at enmity; hate it, and desire all good men's love.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 22)
First, madam, entreat true peace of you, Which will purchase with my duteous service;-- Of you, my noble cousin Buckingham, If ever any grudge were lodged between us;-- Of you and you, Lord Rivers and of Dorset, That all without desert have frowned on me;-- Of you, Lord Woodeville and Lord Scales;--of you, Dukes, earls, lords, gentlemen; indeed, of all.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 23)
do not know that Englishman alive With whom my soul is any jot at odds More than the infant that is born tonight.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 24)
thank my God for my humility.   holy day shall this be kept hereafter.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 25)
would to God all strifes were well compounded. My sovereign lord, do beseech your Highness To take our brother Clarence to your grace.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 26)
Why, madam, have offered love for this, To be so flouted in this royal presence?(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 27)
Who knows not that the gentle duke is dead?  You do him injury to scorn his corse.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 28)
Who knows not he is dead! Who knows he is?   All-seeing heaven, what a world is this!(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 29)
Look so pale, Lord Dorset, as the rest?   Ay, my good lord, and no man in the presence But his red color hath forsook his cheeks.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 30)
Is Clarence dead? The order was reversed.   But he, poor man, by your first order died, And that a winged Mercury did bear.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 31)
Some tardy cripple bare the countermand, That came too lag to see him buried.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 32)
God grant that some, less noble and less loyal, Nearer in bloody thoughts, and not in blood, Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did, And yet go current from suspicion.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 33)
boon, my sovereign, for my service done.   prithee, peace.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 34)
My soul is full of sorrow.   will not rise unless your Highness hear me.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 35)
Then say at once what is it thou requests.   The forfeit, sovereign, of my servant's life, Who slew today a riotous gentleman Lately attendant on the Duke of Norfolk.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 36)
Have a tongue to doom my brother's death, And shall that tongue give pardon to a slave?(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 37)
My brother killed no man; his fault was thought, And yet his punishment was bitter death.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 38)
Who sued to me for him? Who, in my wrath, Kneeled at my feet, and bade me be advised?(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 39)
Who spoke of brotherhood? Who spoke of love? Who told me how the poor soul did forsake The mighty Warwick and did fight for me?(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 40)
Who told me, in the field at Tewkesbury, When Oxford had me down, he rescued me, And said "Dear brother, live, and be a king"?(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 41)
Who told me, when we both lay in the field Frozen almost to death, how he did lap me Even in his garments and did give himself, All thin and naked, to the numb-cold night?(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 42)
All this from my remembrance brutish wrath Sinfully plucked, and not a man of you Had so much grace to put it in my mind.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 43)
But when your carters or your waiting vassals Have done a drunken slaughter and defaced The precious image of our dear Redeemer, You straight are on your knees for pardon, pardon, And unjustly too, must grant it you.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 44)
But for my brother, not a man would speak, Nor ungracious, speak unto myself For him, poor soul.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 45)
The proudest of you all Have been beholding to him in his life, Yet none of you would once beg for his life.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 46)
God, fear Thy justice will take hold On me and you, and mine and yours for this!(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 47)
-- Come, Hastings, help me to my closet.-- Ah, poor Clarence.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 48)
This is the fruits of rashness. Marked you not How that the guilty kindred of the Queen Looked pale when they did hear of Clarence' death?(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 49)
they did urge it still unto the King. God will revenge it.(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 50)
Come, lords, will you go To comfort Edward with our company?(Richard III, Act 0, Scene 51)
Good grandam, tell us, is our father dead?  No, boy.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 0)
Why do you weep so oft, and beat your breast, And cry Clarence, my unhappy son"?(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 1)
Why do you look on us and shake your head, And call us orphans, wretches, castaways, If that our noble father were alive?(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 2)
My pretty cousins, you mistake me both. do lament the sickness of the King, As loath to lose him, not your father's death.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 3)
It were lost sorrow to wail one that's lost.   Then, you conclude, my grandam, he is dead.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 4)
The King mine uncle is to blame for it. God will revenge it, whom will importune With earnest prayers, all to that effect.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 5)
And so will   Peace, children, peace. The King doth love you well.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 6)
Incapable and shallow innocents, You cannot guess who caused your father's death.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 7)
Grandam, we can, for my good uncle Gloucester Told me the King, provoked to it by the Queen, Devised impeachments to imprison him; And when my uncle told me so, he wept, And pitied me, and kindly kissed my cheek, Bade me rely on him as on my father, And he would love me dearly as a child.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 8)
Ah, that deceit should steal such gentle shape, And with a virtuous visor hide deep vice.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 9)
He is my son, ay, and therein my shame, Yet from my dugs he drew not this deceit.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 10)
Think you my uncle did dissemble, grandam?  Ay, boy.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 11)
cannot think it. Hark, what noise is this?       Ah, who shall hinder me to wail and weep, To chide my fortune and torment myself?(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 12)
I'll join with black despair against my soul And to myself become an enemy.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 13)
What means this scene of rude impatience?   To make an act of tragic violence.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 14)
Edward, my lord, thy son, our king, is dead. Why grow the branches when the root is gone?(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 15)
Why wither not the leaves that want their sap? If you will live, lament.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 16)
If die, be brief, That our swift-winged souls may catch the King's, Or, like obedient subjects, follow him To his new kingdom of ne'er-changing night.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 17)
Ah, so much interest have in thy sorrow As had title in thy noble husband.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 18)
have bewept a worthy husband's death And lived with looking on his images; But now two mirrors of his princely semblance Are cracked in pieces by malignant death, And for comfort, have but one false glass That grieves me when see my shame in him.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 19)
Thou art a widow, yet thou art a mother, And hast the comfort of thy children left, But death hath snatched my husband from mine arms And plucked two crutches from my feeble hands, Clarence and Edward.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 20)
what cause have Thine being but a moiety of my moan, To overgo thy woes and drown thy cries!(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 21)
Ah, aunt, you wept not for our father's death. How can we aid you with our kindred tears?(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 22)
Our fatherless distress was left unmoaned. Your widow-dolor likewise be unwept!(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 23)
Give me no help in lamentation. am not barren to bring forth complaints.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 24)
All springs reduce their currents to mine eyes, That being governed by the watery moon, May send forth plenteous tears to drown the world.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 25)
Ah, for my husband, for my dear lord Edward!   Ah, for our father, for our dear lord Clarence!(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 26)
Alas for both, both mine, Edward and Clarence!   What stay had but Edward?(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 27)
And he's gone.   What stay had we but Clarence? And he's gone.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 28)
What stays had but they? And they are gone.   Was never widow had so dear a loss.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 29)
Were never orphans had so dear a loss.   Was never mother had so dear a loss.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 30)
Alas, am the mother of these griefs. Their woes are parceled; mine is general.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 31)
She for an Edward weeps, and so do for a Clarence weep; so doth not she.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 32)
These babes for Clarence weep, and so do for an Edward weep; so do not they.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 33)
Alas, you three, on me, threefold distressed, Pour all your tears.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 34)
am your sorrow's nurse, And will pamper it with lamentation.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 35)
Comfort, dear mother. God is much displeased That you take with unthankfulness His doing.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 36)
In common worldly things, 'tis called ungrateful With dull unwillingness to repay a debt Which with a bounteous hand was kindly lent; Much more to be thus opposite with heaven, For it requires the royal debt it lent you.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 37)
Madam, bethink you, like a careful mother, Of the young prince your son.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 38)
Send straight for him. Let him be crowned. In him your comfort lives.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 39)
Drown desperate sorrow in dead Edward's grave And plant your joys in living Edward's throne.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 40)
Sister, have comfort. All of us have cause To wail the dimming of our shining star, But none can help our harms by wailing them.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 41)
-- Madam my mother, do cry you mercy; did not see your Grace.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 42)
Humbly on my knee crave your blessing.   God bless thee, and put meekness in thy breast, Love, charity, obedience, and true duty.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 43)
Amen.  And make me die a good old man! That is the butt end of a mother's blessing; marvel that her Grace did leave it out.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 44)
You cloudy princes and heart-sorrowing peers That bear this heavy mutual load of moan, Now cheer each other in each other's love.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 45)
Though we have spent our harvest of this king, We are to reap the harvest of his son.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 46)
The broken rancor of your high-swoll'n hates, But lately splintered, knit, and joined together, Must gently be preserved, cherished, and kept.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 47)
Meseemeth good that with some little train Forthwith from Ludlow the young prince be fet Hither to London, to be crowned our king.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 48)
Why "with some little train," my lord of Buckingham?(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 49)
Marry, my lord, lest by a multitude The new-healed wound of malice should break out, Which would be so much the more dangerous By how much the estate is green and yet ungoverned.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 50)
Where every horse bears his commanding rein And may direct his course as please himself, As well the fear of harm as harm apparent, In my opinion, ought to be prevented.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 51)
hope the King made peace with all of us; And the compact is firm and true in me.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 52)
And so in me, and so, think, in all. Yet since it is but green, it should be put To no apparent likelihood of breach, Which haply by much company might be urged.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 53)
Therefore say with noble Buckingham That it is meet so few should fetch the Prince.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 54)
And so say   Then be it so, and go we to determine Who they shall be that straight shall post to Ludlow.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 55)
-- Madam, and you, my sister, will you go To give your censures in this business?(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 56)
My lord, whoever journeys to the Prince, For God's sake let not us two stay at home.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 57)
For by the way I'll sort occasion, As index to the story we late talked of, To part the Queen's proud kindred from the Prince.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 58)
My other self, my council's consistory, My oracle, my prophet, my dear cousin, as a child, will go by thy direction.(Richard III, Act 1, Scene 59)
Good morrow, neighbor, whither away so fast?   promise you scarcely know myself.(Richard III, Act 2, Scene 0)
Hear you the news abroad?  Yes, that the King is dead.(Richard III, Act 2, Scene 1)
Ill news, by 'r Lady. Seldom comes the better. fear, fear, 'twill prove a giddy world.(Richard III, Act 2, Scene 2)
Neighbors, God speed.  Give you good morrow, sir.(Richard III, Act 2, Scene 3)
Doth the news hold of good King Edward's death?(Richard III, Act 2, Scene 4)
Ay, sir, it is too true, God help the while.   Then, masters, look to see a troublous world.(Richard III, Act 2, Scene 5)
No, no, by God's good grace, his son shall reign.(Richard III, Act 2, Scene 6)
Woe to that land that's governed by a child.   In him there is a hope of government, Which, in his nonage, council under him, And, in his full and ripened years, himself, No doubt shall then, and till then, govern well.(Richard III, Act 2, Scene 7)
So stood the state when Henry the Sixth Was crowned in Paris but at nine months old.(Richard III, Act 2, Scene 8)
Stood the state so? No, no, good friends, God wot, For then this land was famously enriched With politic grave counsel; then the King Had virtuous uncles to protect his Grace.(Richard III, Act 2, Scene 9)
Why, so hath this, both by his father and mother.(Richard III, Act 2, Scene 10)
Better it were they all came by his father, Or by his father there were none at all, For emulation who shall now be nearest Will touch us all too near if God prevent not.(Richard III, Act 2, Scene 11)
full of danger is the Duke of Gloucester, And the Queen's sons and brothers haught and proud, And were they to be ruled, and not to rule, This sickly land might solace as before.(Richard III, Act 2, Scene 12)
Come, come, we fear the worst. All will be well.(Richard III, Act 2, Scene 13)
When clouds are seen, wise men put on their cloaks; When great leaves fall, then winter is at hand; When the sun sets, who doth not look for night?(Richard III, Act 2, Scene 14)
Untimely storms makes men expect a dearth. All may be well; but if God sort it so, 'Tis more than we deserve or expect.(Richard III, Act 2, Scene 15)
Truly, the hearts of men are full of fear. You cannot reason almost with a man That looks not heavily and full of dread.(Richard III, Act 2, Scene 16)
Before the days of change, still is it so. By a divine instinct, men's minds mistrust Ensuing danger, as by proof we see The water swell before a boist'rous storm.(Richard III, Act 2, Scene 17)
But leave it all to God. Whither away?   Marry, we were sent for to the Justices.(Richard III, Act 2, Scene 18)
2         Last night, hear, they lay at Stony Stratford, And at Northampton they do rest tonight.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 0)
Tomorrow or next day they will be here.   long with all my heart to see the Prince.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 1)
hope he is much grown since last saw him.   But hear no; they say my son of York Has almost overta'en him in his growth.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 2)
Ay, mother, but would not have it so.   Why, my good cousin?(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 3)
It is good to grow.   Grandam, one night as we did sit at supper, My uncle Rivers talked how did grow More than my brother.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 4)
"Ay," quoth my uncle Gloucester, "Small herbs have grace; great weeds do grow apace.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 5)
" And since, methinks would not grow so fast Because sweet flowers are slow and weeds make haste.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 6)
Good faith, good faith, the saying did not hold In him that did object the same to thee!(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 7)
He was the wretched'st thing when he was young, So long a-growing and so leisurely, That if his rule were true, he should be gracious.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 8)
And so no doubt he is, my gracious madam.   hope he is, but yet let mothers doubt.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 9)
Now, by my troth, if had been remembered, could have given my uncle's Grace a flout To touch his growth nearer than he touched mine.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 10)
How, my young York? prithee let me hear it.   Marry, they say my uncle grew so fast That he could gnaw a crust at two hours old.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 11)
'Twas full two years ere could get a tooth. Grandam, this would have been a biting jest.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 12)
prithee, pretty York, who told thee this?  Grandam, his nurse.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 13)
His nurse? Why, she was dead ere thou wast born.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 14)
If 'twere not she, cannot tell who told me.   parlous boy!(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 15)
Go to, you are too shrewd.   Good madam, be not angry with the child.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 16)
Pitchers have ears.     Here comes a messenger.--What news?(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 17)
Such news, my lord, as grieves me to report.  How doth the Prince?(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 18)
Well, madam, and in health.  What is thy news?   Lord Rivers and Lord Grey are sent to Pomfret, And, with them, Sir Thomas Vaughan, prisoners.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 19)
Who hath committed them?   The mighty dukes, Gloucester and Buckingham.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 20)
For what offense?   The sum of all can, have disclosed.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 21)
Why, or for what, the nobles were committed Is all unknown to me, my gracious lord.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 22)
Ay me! see the ruin of my house. The tiger now hath seized the gentle hind.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 23)
Insulting tyranny begins to jut Upon the innocent and aweless throne.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 24)
Welcome, destruction, blood, and massacre. see, as in a map, the end of all.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 25)
Accursed and unquiet wrangling days, How many of you have mine eyes beheld?(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 26)
My husband lost his life to get the crown, And often up and down my sons were tossed For me to joy, and weep, their gain and loss.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 27)
And being seated, and domestic broils Clean overblown, themselves the conquerors Make war upon themselves, brother to brother, Blood to blood, self against self.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 28)
preposterous And frantic outrage, end thy damned spleen, Or let me die, to look on Earth no more.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 29)
Come, come, my boy. We will to sanctuary.-- Madam, farewell.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 30)
Stay, will go with you.   You have no cause.  My gracious lady, go, And thither bear your treasure and your goods.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 31)
For my part, I'll resign unto your Grace The seal keep; and so betide to me As well tender you and all of yours.(Richard III, Act 3, Scene 32)
Can go forward when my heart is here? Turn back, dull earth, and find thy center out.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 0, Scene 0)
Romeo, my cousin Romeo, Romeo!  He is wise And, on my life, hath stol'n him home to bed.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 0, Scene 1)
He ran this way and leapt this orchard wall. Call, good Mercutio.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 0, Scene 2)
Nay, I'll conjure too. Romeo! Humors! Madman! Passion!(Romeo and Juliet, Act 0, Scene 3)
Lover! Appear thou in the likeness of a sigh. Speak but one rhyme and am satisfied.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 0, Scene 4)
Cry but "Ay me," pronounce but "love" and "dove." Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word, One nickname for her purblind son and heir, Young Abraham Cupid, he that shot so trim When King Cophetua loved the beggar maid.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 0, Scene 5)
-- He heareth not, he stirreth not, he moveth not.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 0, Scene 6)
The ape is dead, and must conjure him.-- conjure thee by Rosaline's bright eyes, By her high forehead, and her scarlet lip, By her fine foot, straight leg, and quivering thigh, And the demesnes that there adjacent lie, That in thy likeness thou appear to us.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 0, Scene 7)
An if he hear thee, thou wilt anger him.   This cannot anger him.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 0, Scene 8)
'Twould anger him To raise a spirit in his mistress' circle Of some strange nature, letting it there stand Till she had laid it and conjured it down.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 0, Scene 9)
That were some spite. My invocation Is fair and honest.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 0, Scene 10)
In his mistress' name, conjure only but to raise up him.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 0, Scene 11)
Come, he hath hid himself among these trees To be consorted with the humorous night.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 0, Scene 12)
Blind is his love and best befits the dark.   If love be blind, love cannot hit the mark.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 0, Scene 13)
Now will he sit under a medlar tree And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit As maids call medlars when they laugh alone.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 0, Scene 14)
-- Romeo, that she were, that she were An open-arse, thou a pop'rin pear.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 0, Scene 15)
Romeo, good night. I'll to my truckle bed; This field-bed is too cold for me to sleep.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 0, Scene 16)
-- Come, shall we go?  Go, then, for 'tis in vain To seek him here that means not to be found.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 0, Scene 17)
He jests at scars that never felt a wound.    But soft, what light through yonder window breaks?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 0)
It is the East, and Juliet is the sun. Arise, fair sun, and kill the envious moon, Who is already sick and pale with grief That thou, her maid, art far more fair than she.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 1)
Be not her maid since she is envious. Her vestal livery is but sick and green, And none but fools do wear it.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 2)
Cast it off. It is my lady. it is my love! that she knew she were!(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 3)
She speaks, yet she says nothing. What of that? Her eye discourses; will answer it.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 4)
am too bold. 'Tis not to me she speaks. Two of the fairest stars in all the heaven, Having some business, do entreat her eyes To twinkle in their spheres till they return.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 5)
What if her eyes were there, they in her head? The brightness of her cheek would shame those stars As daylight doth a lamp; her eye in heaven Would through the airy region stream so bright That birds would sing and think it were not night.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 6)
See how she leans her cheek upon her hand. that were a glove upon that hand, That might touch that cheek!(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 7)
Ay me.  She speaks. speak again, bright angel, for thou art As glorious to this night, being o'er my head, As is a winged messenger of heaven Unto the white-upturned wond'ring eyes Of mortals that fall back to gaze on him When he bestrides the lazy puffing clouds And sails upon the bosom of the air.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 8)
Romeo, Romeo, wherefore art thou Romeo? Deny thy father and refuse thy name, Or, if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love, And I'll no longer be a Capulet.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 9)
Shall hear more, or shall speak at this?   'Tis but thy name that is my enemy.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 10)
Thou art thyself, though not a Montague. What's Montague?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 11)
It is nor hand, nor foot, Nor arm, nor face. be some other name Belonging to a man.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 12)
What's in a name? That which we call a rose By any other word would smell as sweet.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 13)
So Romeo would, were he not Romeo called, Retain that dear perfection which he owes Without that title.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 14)
Romeo, doff thy name, And, for thy name, which is no part of thee, Take all myself.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 15)
take thee at thy word. Call me but love, and I'll be new baptized.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 16)
Henceforth never will be Romeo.   What man art thou that, thus bescreened in night, So stumblest on my counsel?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 17)
By a name know not how to tell thee who am. My name, dear saint, is hateful to myself Because it is an enemy to thee.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 18)
Had it written, would tear the word.   My ears have yet not drunk a hundred words Of thy tongue's uttering, yet know the sound.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 19)
Art thou not Romeo, and a Montague?   Neither, fair maid, if either thee dislike.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 20)
How camest thou hither, tell me, and wherefore?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 21)
The orchard walls are high and hard to climb, And the place death, considering who thou art, If any of my kinsmen find thee here.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 22)
With love's light wings did o'erperch these walls, For stony limits cannot hold love out, And what love can do, that dares love attempt.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 23)
Therefore thy kinsmen are no stop to me.   If they do see thee, they will murder thee.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 24)
Alack, there lies more peril in thine eye Than twenty of their swords.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 25)
Look thou but sweet, And am proof against their enmity.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 26)
would not for the world they saw thee here.   have night's cloak to hide me from their eyes, And, but thou love me, let them find me here.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 27)
My life were better ended by their hate Than death prorogued, wanting of thy love.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 28)
By whose direction found'st thou out this place?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 29)
By love, that first did prompt me to inquire. He lent me counsel, and lent him eyes.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 30)
am no pilot; yet, wert thou as far As that vast shore washed with the farthest sea, should adventure for such merchandise.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 31)
Thou knowest the mask of night is on my face, Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek For that which thou hast heard me speak tonight.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 32)
Fain would dwell on form; fain, fain deny What have spoke.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 33)
But farewell compliment. Dost thou love me? know thou wilt say "Ay," And will take thy word.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 34)
Yet, if thou swear'st, Thou mayst prove false. At lovers' perjuries, They say, Jove laughs.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 35)
gentle Romeo, If thou dost love, pronounce it faithfully.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 36)
Or, if thou thinkest am too quickly won, I'll frown and be perverse and say thee nay, So thou wilt woo, but else not for the world.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 37)
In truth, fair Montague, am too fond, And therefore thou mayst think my havior light.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 38)
But trust me, gentleman, I'll prove more true Than those that have more coying to be strange.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 39)
should have been more strange, must confess, But that thou overheard'st ere was ware My true-love passion.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 40)
Therefore pardon me, And not impute this yielding to light love, Which the dark night hath so discovered.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 41)
Lady, by yonder blessed moon vow, That tips with silver all these fruit-tree tops--   swear not by the moon, th' inconstant moon, That monthly changes in her circled orb, Lest that thy love prove likewise variable.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 42)
What shall swear by?  Do not swear at all. Or, if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self, Which is the god of my idolatry, And I'll believe thee.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 43)
If my heart's dear love--   Well, do not swear. Although joy in thee, have no joy of this contract tonight.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 44)
It is too rash, too unadvised, too sudden, Too like the lightning, which doth cease to be Ere one can say "It lightens.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 45)
" Sweet, good night. This bud of love, by summer's ripening breath, May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 46)
Good night, good night. As sweet repose and rest Come to thy heart as that within my breast.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 47)
wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?   What satisfaction canst thou have tonight?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 48)
Th' exchange of thy love's faithful vow for mine.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 49)
gave thee mine before thou didst request it, And yet would it were to give again.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 50)
Wouldst thou withdraw it? For what purpose, love?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 51)
But to be frank and give it thee again. And yet wish but for the thing have.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 52)
My bounty is as boundless as the sea, My love as deep.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 53)
The more give to thee, The more have, for both are infinite.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 54)
hear some noise within. Dear love, adieu.-- Anon, good nurse.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 55)
--Sweet Montague, be true. Stay but a little; will come again.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 56)
blessed, blessed night! am afeard, Being in night, all this is but a dream, Too flattering sweet to be substantial.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 57)
Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 58)
If that thy bent of love be honorable, Thy purpose marriage, send me word tomorrow, By one that I'll procure to come to thee, Where and what time thou wilt perform the rite, And all my fortunes at thy foot I'll lay And follow thee my lord throughout the world.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 59)
Madam.   come anon.--But if thou meanest not well, do beseech thee--  Madam.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 60)
By and by, come.-- To cease thy strife and leave me to my grief.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 61)
Tomorrow will send.  So thrive my soul--  thousand times good night.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 62)
thousand times the worse to want thy light. Love goes toward love as schoolboys from their books, But love from love, toward school with heavy looks.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 63)
Hist, Romeo, hist! for a falc'ner's voice To lure this tassel-gentle back again!(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 64)
Bondage is hoarse and may not speak aloud, Else would tear the cave where Echo lies And make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine With repetition of "My Romeo!(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 65)
"   It is my soul that calls upon my name. How silver-sweet sound lovers' tongues by night, Like softest music to attending ears.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 66)
Romeo.  My dear.  What o'clock tomorrow Shall send to thee?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 67)
By the hour of nine.   will not fail. 'Tis twenty year till then.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 68)
have forgot why did call thee back.   Let me stand here till thou remember it.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 69)
shall forget, to have thee still stand there, Rememb'ring how love thy company.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 70)
And I'll still stay, to have thee still forget, Forgetting any other home but this.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 71)
'Tis almost morning. would have thee gone, And yet no farther than a wanton's bird, That lets it hop a little from his hand, Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves, And with a silken thread plucks it back again, So loving-jealous of his liberty.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 72)
would were thy bird.  Sweet, so would Yet should kill thee with much cherishing.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 73)
Good night, good night. Parting is such sweet sorrow That shall say "Good night" till it be morrow.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 74)
Sleep dwell upon thine eyes, peace in thy breast.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 75)
Would were sleep and peace so sweet to rest. Hence will to my ghostly friar's close cell, His help to crave, and my dear hap to tell.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 1, Scene 76)
The gray-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night, Check'ring the eastern clouds with streaks of light, And fleckled darkness like a drunkard reels From forth day's path and Titan's fiery wheels.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 0)
Now, ere the sun advance his burning eye, The day to cheer and night's dank dew to dry, must upfill this osier cage of ours With baleful weeds and precious-juiced flowers.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 1)
The Earth that's nature's mother is her tomb; What is her burying grave, that is her womb; And from her womb children of divers kind We sucking on her natural bosom find, Many for many virtues excellent, None but for some, and yet all different.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 2)
mickle is the powerful grace that lies In plants, herbs, stones, and their true qualities.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 3)
For naught so vile that on the Earth doth live But to the Earth some special good doth give; Nor aught so good but, strained from that fair use, Revolts from true birth, stumbling on abuse.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 4)
Virtue itself turns vice, being misapplied, And vice sometime by action dignified.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 5)
Within the infant rind of this weak flower Poison hath residence and medicine power: For this, being smelt, with that part cheers each part; Being tasted, stays all senses with the heart.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 6)
Two such opposed kings encamp them still In man as well as herbs--grace and rude will; And where the worser is predominant, Full soon the canker death eats up that plant.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 7)
Good morrow, father.  Benedicite. What early tongue so sweet saluteth me?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 8)
Young son, it argues a distempered head So soon to bid "Good morrow" to thy bed.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 9)
Care keeps his watch in every old man's eye, And, where care lodges, sleep will never lie; But where unbruised youth with unstuffed brain Doth couch his limbs, there golden sleep doth reign.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 10)
Therefore thy earliness doth me assure Thou art uproused with some distemp'rature, Or, if not so, then here hit it right: Our Romeo hath not been in bed tonight.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 11)
That last is true. The sweeter rest was mine.   God pardon sin!(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 12)
Wast thou with Rosaline?   With Rosaline, my ghostly father?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 13)
No. have forgot that name and that name's woe.   That's my good son.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 14)
But where hast thou been then?   I'll tell thee ere thou ask it me again.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 15)
have been feasting with mine enemy, Where on a sudden one hath wounded me That's by me wounded.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 16)
Both our remedies Within thy help and holy physic lies.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 17)
bear no hatred, blessed man, for, lo, My intercession likewise steads my foe.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 18)
Be plain, good son, and homely in thy drift. Riddling confession finds but riddling shrift.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 19)
Then plainly know my heart's dear love is set On the fair daughter of rich Capulet.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 20)
As mine on hers, so hers is set on mine, And all combined, save what thou must combine By holy marriage.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 21)
When and where and how We met, we wooed, and made exchange of vow I'll tell thee as we pass, but this pray, That thou consent to marry us today.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 22)
Holy Saint Francis, what a change is here! Is Rosaline, that thou didst love so dear, So soon forsaken?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 23)
Young men's love then lies Not truly in their hearts, but in their eyes.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 24)
Jesu Maria, what a deal of brine Hath washed thy sallow cheeks for Rosaline!(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 25)
How much salt water thrown away in waste To season love, that of it doth not taste!(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 26)
The sun not yet thy sighs from heaven clears, Thy old groans yet ringing in mine ancient ears.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 27)
Lo, here upon thy cheek the stain doth sit Of an old tear that is not washed off yet.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 28)
If e'er thou wast thyself, and these woes thine, Thou and these woes were all for Rosaline.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 29)
And art thou changed? Pronounce this sentence then: Women may fall when there's no strength in men.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 30)
Thou chid'st me oft for loving Rosaline.   For doting, not for loving, pupil mine.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 31)
And bad'st me bury love.  Not in a grave To lay one in, another out to have.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 32)
pray thee, chide me not. Her love now Doth grace for grace and love for love allow.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 33)
The other did not so.  she knew well Thy love did read by rote, that could not spell.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 34)
But come, young waverer, come, go with me. In one respect I'll thy assistant be, For this alliance may so happy prove To turn your households' rancor to pure love.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 35)
let us hence. stand on sudden haste.   Wisely and slow.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 2, Scene 36)
Where the devil should this Romeo be? Came he not home tonight?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 0)
Not to his father's. spoke with his man.   Why, that same pale hard-hearted wench, that Rosaline, Torments him so that he will sure run mad.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 1)
Tybalt, the kinsman to old Capulet, Hath sent a letter to his father's house.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 2)
challenge, on my life.  Romeo will answer it.  Any man that can write may answer a letter.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 3)
Nay, he will answer the letter's master, how he dares, being dared.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 4)
Alas, poor Romeo, he is already dead, stabbed with a white wench's black eye, run through the ear with a love-song, the very pin of his heart cleft with the blind bow-boy's butt shaft.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 5)
And is he a man to encounter Tybalt?  Why, what is Tybalt?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 6)
More than prince of cats. he's the courageous captain of compliments.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 7)
He fights as you sing prick-song, keeps time, distance, and proportion.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 8)
He rests his minim rests, one, two, and the third in your bosom--the very butcher of a silk button, a duelist, a duelist, a gentleman of the very first house of the first and second cause.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 9)
Ah, the immortal passado, the punto reverso, the hay!(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 10)
The what?  The pox of such antic, lisping, affecting phantasimes, these new tuners of accent: "By Jesu, a very good blade!(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 11)
very tall man! very good whore!" Why, is not this a lamentable thing, grandsire, that we should be thus afflicted with these strange flies, these fashion-mongers, these "pardon-me" 's, who stand so much on the new form that they cannot sit at ease on the old bench?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 12)
their bones, their bones!     Here comes Romeo, here comes Romeo.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 13)
Without his roe, like a dried herring. flesh, flesh, how art thou fishified!(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 14)
Now is he for the numbers that Petrarch flowed in.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 15)
Laura to his lady was a kitchen wench (marry, she had a better love to berhyme her), Dido a dowdy, Cleopatra a gypsy, Helen and Hero hildings and harlots, Thisbe a gray eye or so, but not to the purpose.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 16)
--Signior Romeo, bonjour. There's a French salutation to your French slop.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 17)
You gave us the counterfeit fairly last night.  Good morrow to you both.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 18)
What counterfeit did give you?  The slip, sir, the slip.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 19)
Can you not conceive?  Pardon, good Mercutio, my business was great, and in such a case as mine a man may strain courtesy.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 20)
That's as much as to say such a case as yours constrains a man to bow in the hams.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 21)
Meaning, to curtsy.  Thou hast most kindly hit it.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 22)
most courteous exposition.  Nay, am the very pink of courtesy.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 23)
"Pink" for flower.  Right.  Why, then is my pump well flowered.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 24)
Sure wit, follow me this jest now till thou hast worn out thy pump, that when the single sole of it is worn, the jest may remain, after the wearing, solely singular.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 25)
single-soled jest, solely singular for the singleness.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 26)
Come between us, good Benvolio. My wits faints.  Switch and spurs, switch and spurs, or I'll cry a match.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 27)
Nay, if our wits run the wild-goose chase, am done, for thou hast more of the wild goose in one of thy wits than, am sure, have in my whole five.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 28)
Was with you there for the goose?  Thou wast never with me for anything when thou wast not there for the goose.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 29)
will bite thee by the ear for that jest.  Nay, good goose, bite not.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 30)
Thy wit is a very bitter sweeting; it is a most sharp sauce.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 31)
And is it not, then, well served into a sweet goose?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 32)
here's a wit of cheveril that stretches from an inch narrow to an ell broad.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 33)
stretch it out for that word "broad," which added to the goose, proves thee far and wide a broad goose.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 34)
Why, is not this better now than groaning for love?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 35)
Now art thou sociable, now art thou Romeo, now art thou what thou art, by art as well as by nature.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 36)
For this driveling love is like a great natural that runs lolling up and down to hide his bauble in a hole.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 37)
Stop there, stop there.  Thou desirest me to stop in my tale against the hair.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 38)
Thou wouldst else have made thy tale large.  thou art deceived.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 39)
would have made it short, for was come to the whole depth of my tale and meant indeed to occupy the argument no longer.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 40)
Here's goodly gear. sail, a sail!  Two, two--a shirt and a smock.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 41)
Peter.  Anon.  My fan, Peter.  Good Peter, to hide her face, for her fan's the fairer face.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 42)
God you good morrow, gentlemen.  God you good e'en, fair gentlewoman.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 43)
Is it good e'en?  'Tis no less, tell you, for the bawdy hand of the dial is now upon the prick of noon.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 44)
Out upon you! What a man are you?  One, gentlewoman, that God hath made, himself to mar.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 45)
By my troth, it is well said: "for himself to mar," quoth he?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 46)
Gentlemen, can any of you tell me where may find the young Romeo?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 47)
can tell you, but young Romeo will be older when you have found him than he was when you sought him.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 48)
am the youngest of that name, for fault of a worse.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 49)
You say well.  Yea, is the worst well? Very well took, i' faith, wisely, wisely.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 50)
If you be he, sir, desire some confidence with you.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 51)
She will indite him to some supper.  bawd, a bawd, a bawd.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 52)
So ho!  What hast thou found?  No hare, sir, unless a hare, sir, in a Lenten pie that is something stale and hoar ere it be spent.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 53)
An old hare hoar, And an old hare hoar, Is very good meat in Lent.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 54)
But a hare that is hoar Is too much for a score When it hoars ere it be spent.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 55)
Romeo, will you come to your father's? We'll to dinner thither.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 56)
will follow you.  Farewell, ancient lady. Farewell, lady, lady, lady.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 57)
pray you, sir, what saucy merchant was this that was so full of his ropery?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 58)
gentleman, nurse, that loves to hear himself talk and will speak more in a minute than he will stand to in a month.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 59)
An he speak anything against me, I'll take him down, an he were lustier than he is, and twenty such jacks.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 60)
An if cannot, I'll find those that shall. Scurvy knave, am none of his flirt-gills; am none of his skains-mates.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 61)
And thou must stand by too and suffer every knave to use me at his pleasure.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 62)
saw no man use you at his pleasure. If had, my weapon should quickly have been out.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 63)
warrant you, dare draw as soon as another man, if see occasion in a good quarrel, and the law on my side.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 64)
Now, afore God, am so vexed that every part about me quivers.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 65)
Scurvy knave!  Pray you, sir, a word. And, as told you, my young lady bid me inquire you out.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 66)
What she bid me say, will keep to myself. But first let me tell you, if you should lead her in a fool's paradise, as they say, it were a very gross kind of behavior, as they say.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 67)
For the gentlewoman is young; and therefore, if you should deal double with her, truly it were an ill thing to be offered to any gentlewoman, and very weak dealing.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 68)
Nurse, commend me to thy lady and mistress. protest unto thee--  Good heart, and i' faith will tell her as much.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 69)
Lord, Lord, she will be a joyful woman.  What wilt thou tell her, nurse?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 70)
Thou dost not mark me.  will tell her, sir, that you do protest, which, as take it, is a gentlemanlike offer.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 71)
Bid her devise Some means to come to shrift this afternoon, And there she shall at Friar Lawrence' cell Be shrived and married.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 72)
Here is for thy pains.   No, truly, sir, not a penny.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 73)
Go to, say you shall.   This afternoon, sir? Well, she shall be there.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 74)
And stay, good nurse, behind the abbey wall. Within this hour my man shall be with thee And bring thee cords made like a tackled stair, Which to the high topgallant of my joy Must be my convoy in the secret night.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 75)
Farewell. Be trusty, and I'll quit thy pains. Farewell.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 76)
Commend me to thy mistress.   Now, God in heaven bless thee!(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 77)
Hark you, sir.  What sayst thou, my dear nurse?   Is your man secret?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 78)
Did you ne'er hear say "Two may keep counsel, putting one away"?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 79)
Warrant thee, my man's as true as steel.  Well, sir, my mistress is the sweetest lady.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 80)
Lord, Lord, when 'twas a little prating thing--O, there is a nobleman in town, one Paris, that would fain lay knife aboard, but she, good soul, had as lief see a toad, a very toad, as see him.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 81)
anger her sometimes and tell her that Paris is the properer man, but I'll warrant you, when say so, she looks as pale as any clout in the versal world.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 82)
Doth not rosemary and Romeo begin both with a letter?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 83)
Ay, nurse, what of that? Both with an  Ah, mocker, that's the dog's name.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 84)
is for the--No, know it begins with some other letter, and she hath the prettiest sententious of it, of you and rosemary, that it would do you good to hear it.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 85)
Commend me to thy lady.  Ay, a thousand times.--Peter.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 3, Scene 86)
2        Now old desire doth in his deathbed lie, And young affection gapes to be his heir.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 0)
That fair for which love groaned for and would die, With tender Juliet matched, is now not fair.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 1)
Now Romeo is beloved and loves again, Alike bewitched by the charm of looks, But to his foe supposed he must complain, And she steal love's sweet bait from fearful hooks.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 2)
Being held a foe, he may not have access To breathe such vows as lovers use to swear, And she as much in love, her means much less To meet her new beloved anywhere.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 3)
But passion lends them power, time means, to meet, Temp'ring extremities with extreme sweet.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 4)
The clock struck nine when did send the Nurse.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 5)
In half an hour she promised to return. Perchance she cannot meet him.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 6)
That's not so. she is lame! Love's heralds should be thoughts, Which ten times faster glides than the sun's beams, Driving back shadows over louring hills.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 7)
Therefore do nimble-pinioned doves draw Love, And therefore hath the wind-swift Cupid wings.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 8)
Now is the sun upon the highmost hill Of this day's journey, and from nine till twelve Is three long hours, yet she is not come.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 9)
Had she affections and warm youthful blood, She would be as swift in motion as a ball; My words would bandy her to my sweet love, And his to me.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 10)
But old folks, many feign as they were dead, Unwieldy, slow, heavy, and pale as lead.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 11)
God, she comes!--O, honey nurse, what news? Hast thou met with him?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 12)
Send thy man away.  Peter, stay at the gate.   Now, good sweet nurse--O Lord, why lookest thou sad?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 13)
Though news be sad, yet tell them merrily. If good, thou shamest the music of sweet news By playing it to me with so sour a face.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 14)
am aweary. Give me leave awhile. Fie, how my bones ache!(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 15)
What a jaunt have   would thou hadst my bones, and thy news.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 16)
Nay, come, pray thee, speak. Good, good nurse, speak.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 17)
Jesu, what haste! Can you not stay awhile? Do you not see that am out of breath?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 18)
How art thou out of breath, when thou hast breath To say to me that thou art out of breath?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 19)
The excuse that thou dost make in this delay Is longer than the tale thou dost excuse.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 20)
Is thy news good or bad? Answer to that. Say either, and I'll stay the circumstance.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 21)
Let me be satisfied; is 't good or bad?  Well, you have made a simple choice.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 22)
You know not how to choose a man. Romeo? No, not he.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 23)
Though his face be better than any man's, yet his leg excels all men's, and for a hand and a foot and a body, though they be not to be talked on, yet they are past compare.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 24)
He is not the flower of courtesy, but I'll warrant him as gentle as a lamb.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 25)
Go thy ways, wench. Serve God. What, have you dined at home?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 26)
No, no. But all this did know before. What says he of our marriage?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 27)
What of that?   Lord, how my head aches! What a head have It beats as it would fall in twenty pieces.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 28)
My back o' t' other side! Ah, my back, my back! Beshrew your heart for sending me about To catch my death with jaunting up and down.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 29)
faith, am sorry that thou art not well. Sweet, sweet, sweet nurse, tell me, what says my love?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 30)
Your love says, like an honest gentleman, and a courteous, and a kind, and a handsome, and, warrant, a virtuous--Where is your mother?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 31)
Where is my mother? Why, she is within. Where should she be?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 32)
How oddly thou repliest: "Your love says, like an honest gentleman, Where is your mother?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 33)
"  God's lady dear, Are you so hot? Marry, come up, trow.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 34)
Is this the poultice for my aching bones? Henceforward do your messages yourself.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 35)
Here's such a coil. Come, what says Romeo?   Have you got leave to go to shrift today?(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 36)
have.   Then hie you hence to Friar Lawrence' cell.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 37)
There stays a husband to make you a wife. Now comes the wanton blood up in your cheeks; They'll be in scarlet straight at any news.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 38)
Hie you to church. must another way, To fetch a ladder by the which your love Must climb a bird's nest soon when it is dark.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 39)
am the drudge and toil in your delight, But you shall bear the burden soon at night.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 40)
Go. I'll to dinner. Hie you to the cell.   Hie to high fortune!(Romeo and Juliet, Act 4, Scene 41)
So smile the heavens upon this holy act That after-hours with sorrow chide us not.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 5, Scene 0)
Amen, amen. But come what sorrow can, It cannot countervail the exchange of joy That one short minute gives me in her sight.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 5, Scene 1)
Do thou but close our hands with holy words, Then love-devouring death do what he dare, It is enough may but call her mine.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 5, Scene 2)
These violent delights have violent ends And in their triumph die, like fire and powder, Which, as they kiss, consume.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 5, Scene 3)
The sweetest honey Is loathsome in his own deliciousness And in the taste confounds the appetite.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 5, Scene 4)
Therefore love moderately. Long love doth so. Too swift arrives as tardy as too slow.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 5, Scene 5)
Here comes the lady. so light a foot Will ne'er wear out the everlasting flint.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 5, Scene 6)
lover may bestride the gossamers That idles in the wanton summer air, And yet not fall, so light is vanity.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 5, Scene 7)
Good even to my ghostly confessor.   Romeo shall thank thee, daughter, for us both.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 5, Scene 8)
As much to him, else is his thanks too much.   Ah, Juliet, if the measure of thy joy Be heaped like mine, and that thy skill be more To blazon it, then sweeten with thy breath This neighbor air, and let rich music's tongue Unfold the imagined happiness that both Receive in either by this dear encounter.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 5, Scene 9)
Conceit, more rich in matter than in words, Brags of his substance, not of ornament.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 5, Scene 10)
They are but beggars that can count their worth, But my true love is grown to such excess cannot sum up sum of half my wealth.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 5, Scene 11)
Come, come with me, and we will make short work, For, by your leaves, you shall not stay alone Till Holy Church incorporate two in one.(Romeo and Juliet, Act 5, Scene 12)
Good sister, wrong me not, nor wrong yourself, To make a bondmaid and a slave of me.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 0)
That disdain. But for these other goods-- Unbind my hands, I'll pull them off myself, Yea, all my raiment to my petticoat, Or what you will command me will do, So well know my duty to my elders.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 1)
Of all thy suitors here charge thee tell Whom thou lov'st best.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 2)
See thou dissemble not.   Believe me, sister, of all the men alive never yet beheld that special face Which could fancy more than any other.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 3)
Minion, thou liest. Is 't not Hortensio?   If you affect him, sister, here swear I'll plead for you myself, but you shall have him.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 4)
then belike you fancy riches more. You will have Gremio to keep you fair.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 5)
Is it for him you do envy me so? Nay, then, you jest, and now well perceive You have but jested with me all this while.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 6)
prithee, sister Kate, untie my hands.    If that be jest, then all the rest was so.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 7)
Why, how now, dame, whence grows this insolence?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 8)
-- Bianca, stand aside.--Poor girl, she weeps!  Go ply thy needle; meddle not with her.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 9)
For shame, thou hilding of a devilish spirit! Why dost thou wrong her that did ne'er wrong thee?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 10)
When did she cross thee with a bitter word?   Her silence flouts me, and I'll be revenged!(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 11)
What, in my sight?--Bianca, get thee in.    What, will you not suffer me?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 12)
Nay, now see She is your treasure, she must have a husband, must dance barefoot on her wedding day And, for your love to her, lead apes in hell.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 13)
Talk not to me. will go sit and weep Till can find occasion of revenge.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 14)
Was ever gentleman thus grieved as But who comes here?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 15)
in the habit of a mean man; Petruchio with Hortensio disguised as Litio; and Tranio disguised as Lucentio, with his boy, Biondello bearing a lute    Good morrow, neighbor Baptista.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 16)
Good morrow, neighbor Gremio.--God save you, gentlemen.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 17)
And you, good sir. Pray, have you not a daughter Called Katherina, fair and virtuous?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 18)
have a daughter, sir, called Katherina.   You are too blunt.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 19)
Go to it orderly.   You wrong me, Signior Gremio.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 20)
Give me leave.-- am a gentleman of Verona, sir, That hearing of her beauty and her wit, Her affability and bashful modesty, Her wondrous qualities and mild behavior, Am bold to show myself a forward guest Within your house, to make mine eye the witness Of that report which so oft have heard, And, for an entrance to my entertainment, do present you with a man of mine,  Cunning in music and the mathematics, To instruct her fully in those sciences, Whereof know she is not ignorant.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 21)
Accept of him, or else you do me wrong. His name is Litio, born in Mantua.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 22)
You're welcome, sir, and he for your good sake.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 23)
But for my daughter Katherine, this know, She is not for your turn, the more my grief.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 24)
see you do not mean to part with her, Or else you like not of my company.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 25)
Mistake me not. speak but as find. Whence are you, sir?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 26)
What may call your name?   Petruchio is my name, Antonio's son, man well known throughout all Italy.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 27)
know him well. You are welcome for his sake.   Saving your tale, Petruchio, pray Let us that are poor petitioners speak too!(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 28)
Bacare, you are marvelous forward.   pardon me, Signior Gremio, would fain be doing.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 29)
doubt it not, sir. But you will curse your wooing.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 30)
Neighbor, this is a gift very grateful, am sure of it.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 31)
To express the like kindness, myself, that have been more kindly beholding to you than any, freely give unto you this young scholar that hath been long studying at Rheims, as cunning in Greek, Latin, and other languages as the other in music and mathematics.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 32)
His name is Cambio. Pray accept his service.  thousand thanks, Signior Gremio.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 33)
--Welcome, good Cambio.  But, gentle sir, methinks you walk like a stranger.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 34)
May be so bold to know the cause of your coming?   Pardon me, sir, the boldness is mine own, That being a stranger in this city here Do make myself a suitor to your daughter, Unto Bianca, fair and virtuous.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 35)
Nor is your firm resolve unknown to me, In the preferment of the eldest sister.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 36)
This liberty is all that request, That, upon knowledge of my parentage, may have welcome 'mongst the rest that woo And free access and favor as the rest.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 37)
And toward the education of your daughters here bestow a simple instrument And this small packet of Greek and Latin books.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 38)
If you accept them, then their worth is great.   Lucentio is your name.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 39)
Of whence, pray?   Of Pisa, sir, son to Vincentio.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 40)
mighty man of Pisa. By report know him well. You are very welcome, sir.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 41)
Take you the lute, and you the set of books. You shall go see your pupils presently.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 42)
Holla, within!    Sirrah, lead these gentlemen To my daughters, and tell them both These are their tutors.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 43)
Bid them use them well.  We will go walk a little in the orchard, And then to dinner.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 44)
You are passing welcome, And so pray you all to think yourselves.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 45)
Signior Baptista, my business asketh haste, And every day cannot come to woo.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 46)
You knew my father well, and in him me, Left solely heir to all his lands and goods, Which have bettered rather than decreased.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 47)
Then tell me, if get your daughter's love, What dowry shall have with her to wife?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 48)
After my death, the one half of my lands, And, in possession, twenty thousand crowns.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 49)
And, for that dowry, I'll assure her of Her widowhood, be it that she survive me, In all my lands and leases whatsoever.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 50)
Let specialties be therefore drawn between us, That covenants may be kept on either hand.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 51)
Ay, when the special thing is well obtained, That is, her love, for that is all in all.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 52)
Why, that is nothing. For tell you, father, am as peremptory as she proud-minded; And where two raging fires meet together, They do consume the thing that feeds their fury.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 53)
Though little fire grows great with little wind, Yet extreme gusts will blow out fire and all.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 54)
So to her and so she yields to me, For am rough and woo not like a babe.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 55)
Well mayst thou woo, and happy be thy speed. But be thou armed for some unhappy words.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 56)
Ay, to the proof, as mountains are for winds, That shakes not, though they blow perpetually.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 57)
