How now, my friend, why dost thou look so pale?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 58)
For fear, promise you, if look pale.   What, will my daughter prove a good musician?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 59)
think she'll sooner prove a soldier! Iron may hold with her, but never lutes.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 60)
Why, then thou canst not break her to the lute?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 61)
Why, no, for she hath broke the lute to me. did but tell her she mistook her frets, And bowed her hand to teach her fingering, When, with a most impatient devilish spirit, " 'Frets' call you these?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 62)
" quoth she. "I'll fume with them!" And with that word she struck me on the head, And through the instrument my pate made way, And there stood amazed for a while, As on a pillory, looking through the lute, While she did call me "rascal fiddler," And "twangling Jack," with twenty such vile terms, As had she studied to misuse me so.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 63)
Now, by the world, it is a lusty wench. love her ten times more than ere did.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 64)
how long to have some chat with her!   Well, go with me, and be not so discomfited.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 65)
Proceed in practice with my younger daughter. She's apt to learn, and thankful for good turns.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 66)
-- Signior Petruchio, will you go with us, Or shall send my daughter Kate to you?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 67)
pray you do. I'll attend her here--  And woo her with some spirit when she comes!(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 68)
Say that she rail, why then I'll tell her plain She sings as sweetly as a nightingale.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 69)
Say that she frown, I'll say she looks as clear As morning roses newly washed with dew.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 70)
Say she be mute and will not speak a word, Then I'll commend her volubility And say she uttereth piercing eloquence.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 71)
If she do bid me pack, I'll give her thanks As though she bid me stay by her a week.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 72)
If she deny to wed, I'll crave the day When shall ask the banns, and when be married.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 73)
But here she comes--and now, Petruchio, speak.    Good morrow, Kate, for that's your name, hear.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 74)
Well have you heard, but something hard of hearing.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 75)
They call me Katherine that do talk of me.   You lie, in faith, for you are called plain Kate, And bonny Kate, and sometimes Kate the curst.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 76)
But Kate, the prettiest Kate in Christendom, Kate of Kate Hall, my super-dainty Kate (For dainties are all Kates)--and therefore, Kate, Take this of me, Kate of my consolation: Hearing thy mildness praised in every town, Thy virtues spoke of, and thy beauty sounded (Yet not so deeply as to thee belongs), Myself am moved to woo thee for my wife.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 77)
"Moved," in good time! Let him that moved you hither Remove you hence.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 78)
knew you at the first You were a movable.   Why, what's a movable?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 79)
joint stool.   Thou hast hit it. Come, sit on me.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 80)
Asses are made to bear, and so are you.   Women are made to bear, and so are you.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 81)
No such jade as you, if me you mean.   Alas, good Kate, will not burden thee, For knowing thee to be but young and light--   Too light for such a swain as you to catch, And yet as heavy as my weight should be.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 82)
"Should be"--should buzz!  Well ta'en, and like a buzzard.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 83)
slow-winged turtle, shall a buzzard take thee?   Ay, for a turtle, as he takes a buzzard.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 84)
Come, come, you wasp! faith, you are too angry.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 85)
If be waspish, best beware my sting.   My remedy is then to pluck it out.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 86)
Ay, if the fool could find it where it lies.   Who knows not where a wasp does wear his sting?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 87)
In his tail.  In his tongue.  Whose tongue?   Yours, if you talk of tales, and so farewell.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 88)
What, with my tongue in your tail? Nay, come again, good Kate.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 89)
am a gentleman--  That I'll try.   swear I'll cuff you if you strike again.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 90)
So may you lose your arms. If you strike me, you are no gentleman, And if no gentleman, why then no arms.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 91)
herald, Kate? put me in thy books.  What is your crest?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 92)
coxcomb?   combless cock, so Kate will be my hen.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 93)
No cock of mine. You crow too like a craven.   Nay, come, Kate, come.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 94)
You must not look so sour.   It is my fashion when see a crab.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 95)
Why, here's no crab, and therefore look not sour.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 96)
There is, there is.   Then show it me.  Had a glass, would.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 97)
What, you mean my face?  Well aimed of such a young one.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 98)
Now, by Saint George, am too young for you.   Yet you are withered.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 99)
'Tis with cares.  care not.   Nay, hear you, Kate--in sooth, you 'scape not so.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 100)
chafe you if tarry. Let me go.   No, not a whit.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 101)
find you passing gentle. 'Twas told me you were rough, and coy, and sullen, And now find report a very liar.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 102)
For thou art pleasant, gamesome, passing courteous, But slow in speech, yet sweet as springtime flowers.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 103)
Thou canst not frown, thou canst not look askance, Nor bite the lip as angry wenches will, Nor hast thou pleasure to be cross in talk.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 104)
But thou with mildness entertain'st thy wooers, With gentle conference, soft, and affable.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 105)
Why does the world report that Kate doth limp? sland'rous world!(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 106)
Kate like the hazel twig Is straight, and slender, and as brown in hue As hazelnuts, and sweeter than the kernels.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 107)
let me see thee walk! Thou dost not halt.   Go, fool, and whom thou keep'st command.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 108)
Did ever Dian so become a grove As Kate this chamber with her princely gait?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 109)
be thou Dian and let her be Kate, And then let Kate be chaste and Dian sportful.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 110)
Where did you study all this goodly speech?   It is extempore, from my mother wit.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 111)
witty mother, witless else her son.  Am not wise?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 112)
Yes, keep you warm.   Marry, so mean, sweet Katherine, in thy bed.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 113)
And therefore, setting all this chat aside, Thus in plain terms: your father hath consented That you shall be my wife, your dowry 'greed on, And, will you, nill you, will marry you.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 114)
Now, Kate, am a husband for your turn, For by this light, whereby see thy beauty, Thy beauty that doth make me like thee well, Thou must be married to no man but me.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 115)
For am he am born to tame you, Kate, And bring you from a wild Kate to a Kate Conformable as other household Kates.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 116)
Here comes your father. Never make denial. must and will have Katherine to my wife.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 117)
Now, Signior Petruchio, how speed you with my daughter?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 118)
How but well, sir? How but well? It were impossible should speed amiss.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 119)
Why, how now, daughter Katherine? In your dumps?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 120)
Call you me daughter? Now promise you You have showed a tender fatherly regard, To wish me wed to one half lunatic, madcap ruffian and a swearing Jack, That thinks with oaths to face the matter out.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 121)
Father, 'tis thus: yourself and all the world That talked of her have talked amiss of her.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 122)
If she be curst, it is for policy, For she's not froward, but modest as the dove; She is not hot, but temperate as the morn.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 123)
For patience she will prove a second Grissel, And Roman Lucrece for her chastity.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 124)
And to conclude, we have 'greed so well together That upon Sunday is the wedding day.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 125)
I'll see thee hanged on Sunday first.  Hark, Petruchio, she says she'll see thee hanged first.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 126)
Is this your speeding? Nay, then, goodnight our part.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 127)
Be patient, gentlemen. choose her for myself. If she and be pleased, what's that to you?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 128)
'Tis bargained 'twixt us twain, being alone, That she shall still be curst in company.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 129)
tell you, 'tis incredible to believe How much she loves me.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 130)
the kindest Kate! She hung about my neck, and kiss on kiss She vied so fast, protesting oath on oath, That in a twink she won me to her love.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 131)
you are novices! 'Tis a world to see How tame, when men and women are alone, meacock wretch can make the curstest shrew.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 132)
-- Give me thy hand, Kate. will unto Venice To buy apparel 'gainst the wedding day.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 133)
-- Provide the feast, father, and bid the guests. will be sure my Katherine shall be fine.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 134)
know not what to say, but give me your hands. God send you joy, Petruchio.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 135)
'Tis a match.  and Amen, say we. We will be witnesses.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 136)
Father, and wife, and gentlemen, adieu. will to Venice.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 137)
Sunday comes apace. We will have rings, and things, and fine array, And kiss me, Kate.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 138)
We will be married o' Sunday.     Was ever match clapped up so suddenly?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 139)
Faith, gentlemen, now play a merchant's part And venture madly on a desperate mart.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 140)
'Twas a commodity lay fretting by you. 'Twill bring you gain, or perish on the seas.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 141)
The gain seek, is quiet in the match.   No doubt but he hath got a quiet catch.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 142)
But now, Baptista, to your younger daughter. Now is the day we long have looked for.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 143)
am your neighbor and was suitor first.   And am one that love Bianca more Than words can witness or your thoughts can guess.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 144)
Youngling, thou canst not love so dear as   Graybeard, thy love doth freeze.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 145)
But thine doth fry! Skipper, stand back. 'Tis age that nourisheth.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 146)
But youth in ladies' eyes that flourisheth.   Content you, gentlemen.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 147)
will compound this strife. 'Tis deeds must win the prize, and he of both That can assure my daughter greatest dower Shall have my Bianca's love.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 148)
Say, Signior Gremio, what can you assure her?   First, as you know, my house within the city Is richly furnished with plate and gold, Basins and ewers to lave her dainty hands; My hangings all of Tyrian tapestry; In ivory coffers have stuffed my crowns, In cypress chests my arras counterpoints, Costly apparel, tents, and canopies, Fine linen, Turkey cushions bossed with pearl, Valance of Venice gold in needlework, Pewter and brass, and all things that belongs To house or housekeeping.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 149)
Then, at my farm have a hundred milch-kine to the pail, Six score fat oxen standing in my stalls, And all things answerable to this portion.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 150)
Myself am struck in years, must confess, And if die tomorrow this is hers, If whilst live she will be only mine.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 151)
That "only" came well in.  Sir, list to me: am my father's heir and only son.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 152)
If may have your daughter to my wife, I'll leave her houses three or four as good, Within rich Pisa walls, as any one Old Signior Gremio has in Padua, Besides two thousand ducats by the year Of fruitful land, all which shall be her jointure.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 153)
-- What, have pinched you, Signior Gremio?   Two thousand ducats by the year of land?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 154)
My land amounts not to so much in all.-- That she shall have, besides an argosy That now is lying in Marcellus' road.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 155)
What, have choked you with an argosy?   Gremio, 'tis known my father hath no less Than three great argosies, besides two galliasses And twelve tight galleys.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 156)
These will assure her, And twice as much whate'er thou off'rest next.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 157)
Nay, have offered all. have no more, And she can have no more than all have.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 158)
If you like me, she shall have me and mine.   Why, then, the maid is mine from all the world, By your firm promise.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 159)
Gremio is outvied.   must confess your offer is the best, And, let your father make her the assurance, She is your own; else, you must pardon me.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 160)
If you should die before him, where's her dower?   That's but a cavil.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 161)
He is old, young.   And may not young men die as well as old?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 162)
Well, gentlemen, am thus resolved: On Sunday next, you know My daughter Katherine is to be married.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 163)
Now, on the Sunday following, shall Bianca Be bride to you, if you make this assurance.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 164)
If not, to Signior Gremio. And so take my leave, and thank you both.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 165)
Adieu, good neighbor. Now fear thee not. Sirrah young gamester, your father were a fool To give thee all and in his waning age Set foot under thy table.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 166)
Tut, a toy! An old Italian fox is not so kind, my boy.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 167)
vengeance on your crafty withered hide!-- Yet have faced it with a card of ten.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 168)
'Tis in my head to do my master good. see no reason but supposed Lucentio Must get a father, called "supposed Vincentio"-- And that's a wonder.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 169)
Fathers commonly Do get their children. But in this case of wooing, child shall get a sire, if fail not of my cunning.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 0, Scene 170)
3         Fiddler, forbear. You grow too forward, sir.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 0)
Have you so soon forgot the entertainment Her sister Katherine welcomed you withal?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 1)
But, wrangling pedant, this is The patroness of heavenly harmony.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 2)
Then give me leave to have prerogative, And when in music we have spent an hour, Your lecture shall have leisure for as much.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 3)
Preposterous ass, that never read so far To know the cause why music was ordained.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 4)
Was it not to refresh the mind of man After his studies or his usual pain?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 5)
Then give me leave to read philosophy, And, while pause, serve in your harmony.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 6)
Sirrah, will not bear these braves of thine.   Why, gentlemen, you do me double wrong To strive for that which resteth in my choice.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 7)
am no breeching scholar in the schools. I'll not be tied to hours, nor 'pointed times, But learn my lessons as please myself.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 8)
And, to cut off all strife, here sit we down. Take you your instrument, play you the whiles; His lecture will be done ere you have tuned.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 9)
You'll leave his lecture when am in tune?   That will be never.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 10)
Tune your instrument.  Where left we last?  Here, madam:  Hic ibat Simois, hic est Sigeia tellus, Hic steterat Priami regia celsa senis.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 11)
Conster them.  Hic ibat, as told you before, Simois, am Lucentio, hic est, son unto Vincentio of Pisa, Sigeia tellus, disguised thus to get your love, Hic steterat, and that "Lucentio" that comes a-wooing, Priami, is my man Tranio, regia, bearing my port, celsa senis, that we might beguile the old pantaloon.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 12)
Madam, my instrument's in tune.  Let's hear.  Oh fie, the treble jars!(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 13)
Spit in the hole, man, and tune again.  Now let me see if can conster it.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 14)
Hic ibat Simois, know you not; hic est Sigeia tellus, trust you not; Hic steterat Priami, take heed he hear us not; regia, presume not; celsa senis, despair not.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 15)
Madam, 'tis now in tune.  All but the bass.   The bass is right.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 16)
'Tis the base knave that jars. How fiery and forward our pedant is.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 17)
Now for my life the knave doth court my love! Pedascule, I'll watch you better yet.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 18)
In time may believe, yet mistrust.   Mistrust it not, for sure Aeacides Was Ajax, called so from his grandfather.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 19)
must believe my master; else, promise you, should be arguing still upon that doubt.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 20)
But let it rest.--Now, Litio, to you. Good master, take it not unkindly, pray, That have been thus pleasant with you both.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 21)
You may go walk, and give me leave awhile. My lessons make no music in three parts.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 22)
Are you so formal, sir? Well, must wait And watch withal, for, but be deceived, Our fine musician groweth amorous.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 23)
Madam, before you touch the instrument, To learn the order of my fingering must begin with rudiments of art, To teach you gamut in a briefer sort, More pleasant, pithy, and effectual Than hath been taught by any of my trade.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 24)
And there it is in writing fairly drawn.   Why, am past my gamut long ago.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 25)
Yet read the gamut of Hortensio.    "Gamut am, the ground of all accord: re, to plead Hortensio's passion; mi, Bianca, take him for thy lord, fa ut, that loves with all affection; sol re, one clef, two notes have la mi, show pity or die.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 26)
" Call you this "gamut"? Tut, like it not. Old fashions please me best.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 27)
am not so nice To change true rules for odd inventions.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 28)
Mistress, your father prays you leave your books And help to dress your sister's chamber up.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 29)
You know tomorrow is the wedding day.   Farewell, sweet masters both.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 30)
must be gone.   Faith, mistress, then have no cause to stay.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 31)
But have cause to pry into this pedant. Methinks he looks as though he were in love.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 32)
Yet if thy thoughts, Bianca, be so humble To cast thy wand'ring eyes on every stale, Seize thee that list!(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 33)
If once find thee ranging, Hortensio will be quit with thee by changing.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 14, Scene 34)
Signior Lucentio, this is the 'pointed day That Katherine and Petruchio should be married, And yet we hear not of our son-in-law.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 0)
What will be said? What mockery will it be, To want the bridegroom when the priest attends To speak the ceremonial rites of marriage?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 1)
What says Lucentio to this shame of ours?   No shame but mine.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 2)
must, forsooth, be forced To give my hand, opposed against my heart, Unto a mad-brain rudesby, full of spleen, Who wooed in haste and means to wed at leisure.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 3)
told you, he was a frantic fool, Hiding his bitter jests in blunt behavior, And, to be noted for a merry man, He'll woo a thousand, 'point the day of marriage, Make friends, invite, and proclaim the banns, Yet never means to wed where he hath wooed.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 4)
Now must the world point at poor Katherine And say "Lo, there is mad Petruchio's wife, If it would please him come and marry her.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 5)
"   Patience, good Katherine, and Baptista too. Upon my life, Petruchio means but well, Whatever fortune stays him from his word.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 6)
Though he be blunt, know him passing wise; Though he be merry, yet withal he's honest.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 7)
Would Katherine had never seen him, though!    Go, girl.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 8)
cannot blame thee now to weep, For such an injury would vex a very saint, Much more a shrew of thy impatient humor.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 9)
Master, master, news! And such old news as you never heard of!(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 10)
Is it new and old too? How may that be?  Why, is it not news to hear of Petruchio's coming?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 11)
Is he come?  Why, no, sir.   What then?  He is coming.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 12)
When will he be here?   When he stands where am, and sees you there.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 13)
But say, what to thine old news?  Why, Petruchio is coming in a new hat and an old jerkin, a pair of old breeches thrice turned, a pair of boots that have been candle-cases, one buckled, another laced; an old rusty sword ta'en out of the town armory, with a broken hilt, and chapeless; with two broken points; his horse hipped, with an old mothy saddle and stirrups of no kindred, besides possessed with the glanders and like to mose in the chine, troubled with the lampass, infected with the fashions, full of windgalls, sped with spavins, rayed with the yellows, past cure of the fives, stark spoiled with the staggers, begnawn with the bots, swayed in the back and shoulder-shotten, near-legged before, and with a half-checked bit and a headstall of sheep's leather, which, being restrained to keep him from stumbling, hath been often burst, and now repaired with knots; one girth six times pieced, and a woman's crupper of velour, which hath two letters for her name fairly set down in studs, and here and there pieced with packthread.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 14)
Who comes with him?  Oh, sir, his lackey, for all the world caparisoned like the horse: with a linen stock on one leg and a kersey boot-hose on the other, gartered with a red and blue list; an old hat, and the humor of forty fancies pricked in 't for a feather.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 15)
monster, a very monster in apparel, and not like a Christian footboy or a gentleman's lackey.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 16)
'Tis some odd humor pricks him to this fashion, Yet oftentimes he goes but mean-appareled.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 17)
am glad he's come, howsoe'er he comes.  Why, sir, he comes not.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 18)
Didst thou not say he comes?  Who? That Petruchio came?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 19)
Ay, that Petruchio came!  No, sir, say his horse comes with him on his back.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 20)
Why, that's all one.   Nay, by Saint Jamy. hold you a penny, horse and a man Is more than one, And yet not many.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 21)
Come, where be these gallants? Who's at home?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 22)
You are welcome, sir.  And yet come not well.  And yet you halt not.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 23)
Not so well appareled as wish you were.   Were it better should rush in thus-- But where is Kate?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 24)
Where is my lovely bride? How does my father? Gentles, methinks you frown.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 25)
And wherefore gaze this goodly company As if they saw some wondrous monument, Some comet or unusual prodigy?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 26)
Why, sir, you know this is your wedding day. First were we sad, fearing you would not come, Now sadder that you come so unprovided.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 27)
Fie, doff this habit, shame to your estate, An eyesore to our solemn festival.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 28)
And tell us what occasion of import Hath all so long detained you from your wife And sent you hither so unlike yourself.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 29)
Tedious it were to tell, and harsh to hear. Sufficeth am come to keep my word, Though in some part enforced to digress, Which at more leisure will so excuse As you shall well be satisfied with all.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 30)
But where is Kate? stay too long from her. The morning wears.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 31)
'Tis time we were at church.   See not your bride in these unreverent robes.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 32)
Go to my chamber, put on clothes of mine.   Not believe me.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 33)
Thus I'll visit her.   But thus, trust, you will not marry her.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 34)
Good sooth, even thus. Therefore, ha' done with words.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 35)
To me she's married, not unto my clothes. Could repair what she will wear in me, As can change these poor accoutrements, 'Twere well for Kate and better for myself.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 36)
But what a fool am to chat with you When should bid good morrow to my bride And seal the title with a lovely kiss!(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 37)
He hath some meaning in his mad attire. We will persuade him, be it possible, To put on better ere he go to church.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 38)
I'll after him, and see the event of this.    But, sir, to love concerneth us to add Her father's liking, which to bring to pass, As before imparted to your Worship, am to get a man (whate'er he be It skills not much, we'll fit him to our turn), And he shall be "Vincentio of Pisa," And make assurance here in Padua Of greater sums than have promised.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 39)
So shall you quietly enjoy your hope And marry sweet Bianca with consent.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 40)
Were it not that my fellow schoolmaster Doth watch Bianca's steps so narrowly, 'Twere good, methinks, to steal our marriage, Which, once performed, let all the world say no, I'll keep mine own despite of all the world.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 41)
That by degrees we mean to look into, And watch our vantage in this business.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 42)
We'll overreach the graybeard, Gremio, The narrow prying father, Minola, The quaint musician, amorous Litio, All for my master's sake, Lucentio.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 43)
Signior Gremio, came you from the church?   As willingly as e'er came from school.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 44)
And is the bride and bridegroom coming home?   bridegroom, say you?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 45)
'Tis a groom indeed, grumbling groom, and that the girl shall find.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 46)
Curster than she? Why, 'tis impossible.   Why, he's a devil, a devil, a very fiend.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 47)
Why, she's a devil, a devil, the devil's dam.   Tut, she's a lamb, a dove, a fool to him.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 48)
I'll tell you, Sir Lucentio: when the priest Should ask if Katherine should be his wife, "Ay, by gog's wouns!(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 49)
" quoth he, and swore so loud That, all amazed, the priest let fall the book, And as he stooped again to take it up, This mad-brained bridegroom took him such a cuff That down fell priest and book, and book and priest.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 50)
"Now, take them up," quoth he, "if any list."   What said the wench when he rose again?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 51)
Trembled and shook, for why he stamped and swore As if the vicar meant to cozen him.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 52)
But after many ceremonies done, He calls for wine.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 53)
health!" quoth he, as if He had been aboard, carousing to his mates After a storm; quaffed off the muscatel And threw the sops all in the sexton's face, Having no other reason But that his beard grew thin and hungerly, And seemed to ask him sops as he was drinking.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 54)
This done, he took the bride about the neck And kissed her lips with such a clamorous smack That at the parting all the church did echo.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 55)
And seeing this, came thence for very shame, And after me know the rout is coming.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 56)
Such a mad marriage never was before! Hark, hark, hear the minstrels play.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 57)
Gentlemen and friends, thank you for your pains.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 58)
know you think to dine with me today And have prepared great store of wedding cheer, But so it is, my haste doth call me hence, And therefore here mean to take my leave.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 59)
Is 't possible you will away tonight?   must away today, before night come.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 60)
Make it no wonder. If you knew my business, You would entreat me rather go than stay.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 61)
And, honest company, thank you all, That have beheld me give away myself To this most patient, sweet, and virtuous wife.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 62)
Dine with my father, drink a health to me, For must hence, and farewell to you all.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 63)
Let us entreat you stay till after dinner.  It may not be.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 64)
Let me entreat you.  It cannot be.  Let me entreat you.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 65)
am content.  Are you content to stay?   am content you shall entreat me stay, But yet not stay, entreat me how you can.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 66)
Now, if you love me, stay.  Grumio, my horse.  Ay, sir, they be ready; the oats have eaten the horses.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 67)
Nay, then, Do what thou canst, will not go today, No, nor tomorrow, not till please myself.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 68)
The door is open, sir. There lies your way. You may be jogging whiles your boots are green.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 69)
For me, I'll not be gone till please myself. 'Tis like you'll prove a jolly surly groom, That take it on you at the first so roundly.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 70)
Kate, content thee. Prithee, be not angry.   will be angry.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 71)
What hast thou to do?-- Father, be quiet. He shall stay my leisure.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 72)
Ay, marry, sir, now it begins to work.   Gentlemen, forward to the bridal dinner.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 73)
see a woman may be made a fool If she had not a spirit to resist.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 74)
They shall go forward, Kate, at thy command.-- Obey the bride, you that attend on her.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 75)
Go to the feast, revel and domineer, Carouse full measure to her maidenhead, Be mad and merry, or go hang yourselves.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 76)
But for my bonny Kate, she must with me. Nay, look not big, nor stamp, nor stare, nor fret; will be master of what is mine own.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 77)
She is my goods, my chattels; she is my house, My household stuff, my field, my barn, My horse, my ox, my ass, my anything.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 78)
And here she stands, touch her whoever dare. I'll bring mine action on the proudest he That stops my way in Padua.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 79)
--Grumio, Draw forth thy weapon. We are beset with thieves.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 80)
Rescue thy mistress if thou be a man!-- Fear not, sweet wench, they shall not touch thee, Kate.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 81)
I'll buckler thee against a million.    Nay, let them go.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 82)
couple of quiet ones!   Went they not quickly, should die with laughing.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 83)
Of all mad matches never was the like.   Mistress, what's your opinion of your sister?(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 84)
That being mad herself, she's madly mated.   warrant him, Petruchio is Kated.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 85)
Neighbors and friends, though bride and bridegroom wants For to supply the places at the table, You know there wants no junkets at the feast.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 86)

Shall sweet Bianca practice how to bride it?   She shall, Lucentio.(The Taming of the Shrew, Act 15, Scene 88)
Sir, your glove.  Not mine. My gloves are on.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 0)
Why, then, this may be yours, for this is but one.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 1)
Ha? Let me see. Ay, give it me, it's mine. Sweet ornament that decks a thing divine!(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 2)
Ah, Sylvia, Sylvia!  Madam Sylvia! Madam Sylvia!  How now, sirrah?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 3)
She is not within hearing, sir.  Why, sir, who bade you call her?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 4)
Your Worship, sir, or else mistook.  Well, you'll still be too forward.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 5)
And yet was last chidden for being too slow.  Go to, sir.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 6)
Tell me, do you know Madam Sylvia?  She that your Worship loves?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 7)
Why, how know you that am in love?  Marry, by these special marks: first, you have learned, like Sir Proteus, to wreathe your arms like a malcontent; to relish a love song like a robin redbreast; to walk alone like one that had the pestilence; to sigh like a schoolboy that had lost his to weep like a young wench that had buried her grandam; to fast like one that takes diet; to watch like one that fears robbing; to speak puling like a beggar at Hallowmas.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 8)
You were wont, when you laughed, to crow like a cock; when you walked, to walk like one of the lions.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 9)
When you fasted, it was presently after dinner; when you looked sadly, it was for want of money.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 10)
And now you are metamorphosed with a mistress, that when look on you, can hardly think you my master.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 11)
Are all these things perceived in me?  They are all perceived without you.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 12)
Without me? They cannot.  Without you? Nay, that's certain, for without you were so simple, none else would.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 13)
But you are so without these follies, that these follies are within you and shine through you like the water in an urinal, that not an eye that sees you but is a physician to comment on your malady.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 14)
But tell me, dost thou know my Lady Sylvia?  She that you gaze on so as she sits at supper?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 15)
Hast thou observed that? Even she mean.  Why, sir, know her not.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 16)
Dost thou know her by my gazing on her and yet know'st her not?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 17)
Is she not hard-favored, sir?  Not so fair, boy, as well-favored.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 18)
Sir, know that well enough.  What dost thou know?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 19)
That she is not so fair as, of you, well-favored.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 20)
mean that her beauty is exquisite but her favor infinite.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 21)
That's because the one is painted, and the other out of all count.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 22)
How painted? And how out of count?  Marry, sir, so painted to make her fair, that no man counts of her beauty.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 23)
How esteem'st thou me? account of her beauty.  You never saw her since she was deformed.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 24)
How long hath she been deformed?  Ever since you loved her.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 25)
have loved her ever since saw her, and still see her beautiful.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 26)
If you love her, you cannot see her.  Why?  Because love is blind.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 27)
that you had mine eyes, or your own eyes had the lights they were wont to have when you chid at Sir Proteus for going ungartered!(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 28)
What should see then?  Your own present folly and her passing deformity; for he, being in love, could not see to garter his hose, and you, being in love, cannot see to put on your hose.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 29)
Belike, boy, then you are in love, for last morning you could not see to wipe my shoes.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 30)
True, sir, was in love with my bed. thank you, you swinged me for my love, which makes me the bolder to chide you for yours.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 31)
In conclusion, stand affected to her.  would you were set, so your affection would cease.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 32)
Last night she enjoined me to write some lines to one she loves.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 33)
And have you?  have.  Are they not lamely writ?  No, boy, but as well as can do them.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 34)
Peace, here she comes.     excellent motion! exceeding puppet!(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 35)
Now will he interpret to her.  Madam and mistress, a thousand good-morrows.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 36)
give ye good ev'n! Here's a million of manners.  Sir Valentine, and servant, to you two thousand.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 37)
He should give her interest, and she gives it him.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 38)
As you enjoined me, have writ your letter Unto the secret, nameless friend of yours, Which was much unwilling to proceed in But for my duty to your Ladyship.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 39)
thank you, gentle servant, 'tis very clerkly done.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 40)
Now trust me, madam, it came hardly off, For, being ignorant to whom it goes, writ at random, very doubtfully.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 41)
Perchance you think too much of so much pains?   No, madam.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 42)
So it stead you, will write, Please you command, a thousand times as much, And yet--   pretty period.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 43)
Well, guess the sequel; And yet will not name it And yet care not.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 44)
And yet take this again. And yet thank you, Meaning henceforth to trouble you no more.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 45)
And yet you will; and yet another "yet."   What means your Ladyship?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 46)
Do you not like it?   Yes, yes, the lines are very quaintly writ, But, since unwillingly, take them again.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 47)
Nay, take them.  Madam, they are for you.   Ay, ay.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 48)
You writ them, sir, at my request, But will none of them.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 49)
They are for you. would have had them writ more movingly.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 50)
Please you, I'll write your Ladyship another.   And when it's writ, for my sake read it over, And if it please you, so; if not, why, so.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 51)
If it please me, madam? What then?   Why, if it please you, take it for your labor.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 52)
And so good-morrow, servant.   jest unseen, inscrutable, invisible As a nose on a man's face, or a weathercock on a steeple!(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 53)
My master sues to her, and she hath taught her suitor, He being her pupil, to become her tutor.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 54)
excellent device! Was there ever heard a better? That my master, being scribe, to himself should write the letter?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 55)
How now, sir? What, are you reasoning with yourself?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 56)
Nay, was rhyming. 'Tis you that have the reason.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 57)
To do what?  To be a spokesman from Madam Sylvia.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 58)
To whom?  To yourself. Why, she woos you by a figure.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 59)
What figure?  By a letter, should say.  Why, she hath not writ to me!(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 60)
What need she when she hath made you write to yourself?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 61)
Why, do you not perceive the jest?  No, believe me.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 62)
No believing you indeed, sir. But did you perceive her earnest?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 63)
She gave me none, except an angry word.  Why, she hath given you a letter.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 64)
That's the letter writ to her friend.  And that letter hath she delivered, and there an end.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 65)
would it were no worse.  I'll warrant you, 'tis as well.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 66)
For often have you writ to her, and she, in modesty Or else for want of idle time, could not again reply, Or fearing else some messenger that might her mind discover, Herself hath taught her love himself to write unto her lover.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 67)
All this speak in print, for in print found it. Why muse you, sir?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 68)
'Tis dinnertime.  have dined.  Ay, but hearken, sir, though the chameleon love can feed on the air, am one that am nourished by my victuals and would fain have meat.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 69)
Have patience, gentle Julia.  must where is no remedy.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 1, Scene 0)
When possibly can, will return.   If you turn not, you will return the sooner.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 1, Scene 1)
Keep this remembrance for thy Julia's sake.    Why, then we'll make exchange.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 1, Scene 2)
Here, take you this.   And seal the bargain with a holy kiss.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 1, Scene 3)
Here is my hand for my true constancy. And when that hour o'erslips me in the day Wherein sigh not, Julia, for thy sake, The next ensuing hour some foul mischance Torment me for my love's forgetfulness.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 1, Scene 4)
My father stays my coming. Answer not. The tide is now--nay, not thy tide of tears; That tide will stay me longer than should.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 1, Scene 5)
Julia, farewell. What, gone without a word? Ay, so true love should do.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 1, Scene 6)
It cannot speak, For truth hath better deeds than words to grace it.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 1, Scene 7)
Sir Proteus, you are stayed for.  Go. come, come.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 1, Scene 8)
2       Nay,'twill be this hour ere have done weeping.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 0)
All the kind of the Lances have this very fault. have received my proportion like the Prodigious Son and am going with Sir Proteus to the Imperial's court.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 1)
think Crab my dog be the sourest-natured dog that lives: my mother weeping, my father wailing, my sister crying, our maid howling, our cat wringing her hands, and all our house in a great perplexity, yet did not this cruel-hearted cur shed one tear.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 2)
He is a stone, a very pibble stone, and has no more pity in him than a dog.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 3)
Jew would have wept to have seen our parting. Why, my grandam, having no eyes, look you, wept herself blind at my parting.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 4)
Nay, I'll show you the manner of it. This shoe is my father.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 5)
No, this left shoe is my father; no, no, this left shoe is my mother.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 6)
Nay, that cannot be so neither. Yes, it is so, it is so; it hath the worser sole.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 7)
This shoe with the hole in it is my mother; and this my father.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 8)
vengeance on 't, there 'tis! Now sir, this staff is my sister, for, look you, she is as white as a lily and as small as a wand.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 9)
This hat is Nan, our maid. am the dog. No, the dog is himself, and am the dog.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 10)
the dog is me, and am myself. Ay, so, so. Now come to my father: "Father, your blessing.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 11)
" Now should not the shoe speak a word for weeping.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 12)
Now should kiss my father.  Well, he weeps on. Now come to my mother.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 13)
that she could speak now like a wold woman! Well, kiss her.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 14)
Why, there 'tis; here's my mother's breath up and down.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 15)
Now come to my sister. Mark the moan she makes! Now the dog all this while sheds not a tear nor speaks a word.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 16)
But see how lay the dust with my tears.     Lance, away, away!(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 17)
Aboard. Thy master is shipped, and thou art to post after with oars.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 18)
What's the matter? Why weep'st thou, man? Away, ass.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 19)
You'll lose the tide if you tarry any longer.  It is no matter if the tied were lost, for it is the unkindest tied that ever any man tied.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 20)
What's the unkindest tide?  Why, he that's tied here, Crab my dog.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 21)
Tut, man. mean thou 'lt lose the flood and, in losing the flood, lose thy voyage and, in losing thy voyage, lose thy master and, in losing thy master, lose thy service and, in losing thy service-- Why dost thou stop my mouth?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 22)
For fear thou shouldst lose thy tongue.  Where should lose my tongue?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 23)
In thy tale.  In thy tail!  Lose the tide, and the voyage, and the master, and the service, and the tied.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 24)
Why, man, if the river were dry, am able to fill it with my tears; if the wind were down, could drive the boat with my sighs.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 25)
Come. Come away, man. was sent to call thee.  Sir, call me what thou dar'st.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 2, Scene 26)
Servant!  Mistress?  Master, Sir Thurio frowns on you.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 0)
Ay, boy, it's for love.  Not of you.  Of my mistress, then.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 1)
'Twere good you knocked him.  Servant, you are sad.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 2)
Indeed, madam, seem so.  Seem you that you are not?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 3)
Haply do.  So do counterfeits.  So do you.  What seem that am not?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 4)
Wise.  What instance of the contrary?  Your folly.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 5)
And how quote you my folly?  quote it in your jerkin.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 6)
My "jerkin" is a doublet.  Well, then, I'll double your folly.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 7)
How!  What, angry, Sir Thurio? Do you change color?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 8)
Give him leave, madam. He is a kind of chameleon.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 9)
That hath more mind to feed on your blood than live in your air.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 10)
You have said, sir.  Ay, sir, and done too for this time.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 11)
know it well, sir. You always end ere you begin.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 12)
fine volley of words, gentlemen, and quickly shot off.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 13)
'Tis indeed, madam. We thank the giver.  Who is that, servant?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 14)
Yourself, sweet lady, for you gave the fire. Sir Thurio borrows his wit from your Ladyship's looks and spends what he borrows kindly in your company.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 15)
Sir, if you spend word for word with me, shall make your wit bankrupt.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 16)
know it well, sir. You have an exchequer of words and, think, no other treasure to give your followers, for it appears by their bare liveries that they live by your bare words.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 17)
No more, gentlemen, no more. Here comes my father.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 18)
Now, daughter Sylvia, you are hard beset.-- Sir Valentine, your father is in good health.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 19)
What say you to a letter from your friends Of much good news?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 20)
My lord, will be thankful To any happy messenger from thence.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 21)
Know you Don Antonio, your countryman?   Ay, my good lord, know the gentleman To be of worth and worthy estimation, And not without desert so well reputed.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 22)
Hath he not a son?   Ay, my good lord, a son that well deserves The honor and regard of such a father.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 23)
You know him well?   knew him as myself, for from our infancy We have conversed and spent our hours together, And though myself have been an idle truant, Omitting the sweet benefit of time To clothe mine age with angel-like perfection, Yet hath Sir Proteus--for that's his name-- Made use and fair advantage of his days: His years but young, but his experience old; His head unmellowed, but his judgment ripe; And in a word--for far behind his worth Comes all the praises that now bestow-- He is complete in feature and in mind, With all good grace to grace a gentleman.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 24)
Beshrew me, sir, but if he make this good, He is as worthy for an empress' love, As meet to be an emperor's counselor.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 25)
Well, sir, this gentleman is come to me With commendation from great potentates, And here he means to spend his time awhile.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 26)
think 'tis no unwelcome news to you.   Should have wished a thing, it had been he.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 27)
Welcome him then according to his worth. Sylvia, speak to you--and you, Sir Thurio.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 28)
For Valentine, need not cite him to it. will send him hither to you presently.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 29)
This is the gentleman told your Ladyship Had come along with me but that his mistress Did hold his eyes locked in her crystal looks.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 30)
Belike that now she hath enfranchised them Upon some other pawn for fealty.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 31)
Nay, sure, think she holds them prisoners still.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 32)
Nay, then, he should be blind, and being blind How could he see his way to seek out you?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 33)
Why, lady, love hath twenty pair of eyes.   They say that Love hath not an eye at all.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 34)
To see such lovers, Thurio, as yourself. Upon a homely object, Love can wink.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 35)
Have done, have done. Here comes the gentleman.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 36)
Welcome, dear Proteus.--Mistress, beseech you Confirm his welcome with some special favor.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 37)
His worth is warrant for his welcome hither, If this be he you oft have wished to hear from.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 38)
Mistress, it is. Sweet lady, entertain him To be my fellow-servant to your Ladyship.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 39)
Too low a mistress for so high a servant.   Not so, sweet lady, but too mean a servant To have a look of such a worthy mistress.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 40)
Leave off discourse of disability. Sweet lady, entertain him for your servant.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 41)
My duty will boast of, nothing else.   And duty never yet did want his meed.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 42)
Servant, you are welcome to a worthless mistress.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 43)
I'll die on him that says so but yourself.  That you are welcome?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 44)
That you are worthless.      Madam, my lord your father would speak with you.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 45)
wait upon his pleasure.  Come, Sir Thurio, Go with me.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 46)
--Once more, new servant, welcome. I'll leave you to confer of home affairs.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 47)
When you have done, we look to hear from you.   We'll both attend upon your Ladyship.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 48)
Now tell me, how do all from whence you came?   Your friends are well and have them much commended.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 49)
And how do yours?  left them all in health.   How does your lady?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 50)
And how thrives your love?   My tales of love were wont to weary you.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 51)
know you joy not in a love discourse.   Ay, Proteus, but that life is altered now.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 52)
have done penance for contemning Love, Whose high imperious thoughts have punished me With bitter fasts, with penitential groans, With nightly tears, and daily heartsore sighs, For in revenge of my contempt of love, Love hath chased sleep from my enthralled eyes And made them watchers of mine own heart's sorrow.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 53)
gentle Proteus, Love's a mighty lord And hath so humbled me as confess There is no woe to his correction, Nor, to his service, no such joy on Earth.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 54)
Now, no discourse except it be of love. Now can break my fast, dine, sup, and sleep Upon the very naked name of Love.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 55)
Enough; read your fortune in your eye. Was this the idol that you worship so?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 56)
Even she. And is she not a heavenly saint?   No, but she is an earthly paragon.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 57)
Call her divine.  will not flatter her.   flatter me, for love delights in praises.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 58)
When was sick, you gave me bitter pills, And must minister the like to you.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 59)
Then speak the truth by her; if not divine, Yet let her be a principality, Sovereign to all the creatures on the Earth.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 60)
Except my mistress.  Sweet, except not any, Except thou wilt except against my love.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 61)
Have not reason to prefer mine own?   And will help thee to prefer her too: She shall be dignified with this high honor-- To bear my lady's train, lest the base earth Should from her vesture chance to steal a kiss And, of so great a favor growing proud, Disdain to root the summer-swelling flower And make rough winter everlastingly.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 62)
Why, Valentine, what braggartism is this?   Pardon me, Proteus, all can is nothing To her whose worth makes other worthies nothing.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 63)
She is alone--  Then let her alone.   Not for the world!(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 64)
Why, man, she is mine own, And as rich in having such a jewel As twenty seas if all their sand were pearl, The water nectar, and the rocks pure gold.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 65)
Forgive me that do not dream on thee, Because thou seest me dote upon my love.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 66)
My foolish rival, that her father likes Only for his possessions are so huge, Is gone with her along, and must after, For love, thou know'st, is full of jealousy.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 67)
But she loves you?   Ay, and we are betrothed; nay more, our marriage hour, With all the cunning manner of our flight Determined of: how must climb her window, The ladder made of cords, and all the means Plotted and 'greed on for my happiness.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 68)
Good Proteus, go with me to my chamber, In these affairs to aid me with thy counsel.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 69)
Go on before. shall inquire you forth. must unto the road to disembark Some necessaries that needs must use, And then I'll presently attend you.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 70)
Will you make haste?  will. Even as one heat another heat expels, Or as one nail by strength drives out another, So the remembrance of my former love Is by a newer object quite forgotten.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 71)
Is it mine eye, or Valentine's praise, Her true perfection, or my false transgression, That makes me reasonless to reason thus?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 72)
She is fair, and so is Julia that love-- That did love, for now my love is thawed, Which like a waxen image 'gainst a fire Bears no impression of the thing it was.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 73)
Methinks my zeal to Valentine is cold, And that love him not as was wont.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 74)
but love his lady too too much, And that's the reason love him so little.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 75)
How shall dote on her with more advice That thus without advice begin to love her?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 76)
'Tis but her picture have yet beheld, And that hath dazzled my reason's light; But when look on her perfections, There is no reason but shall be blind.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 77)
If can check my erring love, will; If not, to compass her I'll use my skill.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 3, Scene 78)
Lance, by mine honesty, welcome to Padua.  Forswear not thyself, sweet youth, for am not welcome.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 0)
reckon this always: that a man is never undone till he be hanged, nor never welcome to a place till some certain shot be paid and the Hostess say welcome.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 1)
Come on, you madcap. I'll to the alehouse with you presently, where, for one shot of five pence, thou shalt have five thousand welcomes.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 2)
But, sirrah, how did thy master part with Madam Julia?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 3)
Marry, after they closed in earnest, they parted very fairly in jest.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 4)
But shall she marry him?  No.  How then? Shall he marry her?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 5)
No, neither.  What, are they broken?  No, they are both as whole as a fish.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 6)
Why then, how stands the matter with them?  Marry, thus: when it stands well with him, it stands well with her.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 7)
What an ass art thou! understand thee not.  What a block art thou that thou canst not!(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 8)
My staff understands me.  What thou sayst?  Ay, and what do too.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 9)
Look thee, I'll but lean, and my staff understands me.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 10)
It stands under thee indeed.  Why, "stand under" and "understand" is all one.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 11)
But tell me true, will 't be a match?  Ask my dog.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 12)
If he say "Ay," it will; if he say "No," it will; if he shake his tail and say nothing, it will.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 13)
The conclusion is, then, that it will.  Thou shalt never get such a secret from me but by a parable.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 14)
'Tis well that get it so. But, Lance, how sayst thou that my master is become a notable lover?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 15)
never knew him otherwise.  Than how?  notable lubber, as thou reportest him to be.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 16)
Why, thou whoreson ass, thou mistak'st me.  Why, fool, meant not thee; meant thy master.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 17)
tell thee, my master is become a hot lover.  Why, tell thee, care not though he burn himself in love.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 18)
If thou wilt, go with me to the alehouse; if not, thou art an Hebrew, a Jew, and not worth the name of a Christian.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 19)
Why?  Because thou hast not so much charity in thee as to go to the ale with a Christian.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 4, Scene 20)
To leave my Julia, shall be forsworn. To love fair Sylvia, shall be forsworn.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 5, Scene 0)
To wrong my friend, shall be much forsworn. And ev'n that power which gave me first my oath Provokes me to this threefold perjury.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 5, Scene 1)
Love bade me swear, and love bids me forswear. sweet-suggesting Love, if thou hast sinned, Teach me, thy tempted subject, to excuse it.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 5, Scene 2)
At first did adore a twinkling star, But now worship a celestial sun; Unheedful vows may heedfully be broken, And he wants wit that wants resolved will To learn his wit t' exchange the bad for better.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 5, Scene 3)
Fie, fie, unreverend tongue, to call her bad Whose sovereignty so oft thou hast preferred With twenty thousand soul-confirming oaths.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 5, Scene 4)
cannot leave to love, and yet do. But there leave to love where should love.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 5, Scene 5)
Julia lose, and Valentine lose; If keep them, needs must lose myself; If lose them, thus find by their loss: For Valentine, myself; for Julia, Sylvia.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 5, Scene 6)
to myself am dearer than a friend, For love is still most precious in itself, And Sylvia--witness heaven that made her fair-- Shows Julia but a swarthy Ethiope.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 5, Scene 7)
will forget that Julia is alive, Rememb'ring that my love to her is dead; And Valentine I'll hold an enemy, Aiming at Sylvia as a sweeter friend.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 5, Scene 8)
cannot now prove constant to myself Without some treachery used to Valentine.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 5, Scene 9)
This night he meaneth with a corded ladder To climb celestial Sylvia's chamber window, Myself in counsel his competitor.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 5, Scene 10)
Now presently I'll give her father notice Of their disguising and pretended flight, Who, all enraged, will banish Valentine, For Thurio he intends shall wed his daughter.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 5, Scene 11)
But Valentine being gone, I'll quickly cross By some sly trick blunt Thurio's dull proceeding.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 5, Scene 12)
Love, lend me wings to make my purpose swift, As thou hast lent me wit to plot this drift.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 5, Scene 13)
Counsel, Lucetta. Gentle girl, assist me; And ev'n in kind love do conjure thee-- Who art the table wherein all my thoughts Are visibly charactered and engraved-- To lesson me and tell me some good mean How with my honor may undertake journey to my loving Proteus.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 0)
Alas, the way is wearisome and long.   true-devoted pilgrim is not weary To measure kingdoms with his feeble steps; Much less shall she that hath Love's wings to fly, And when the flight is made to one so dear, Of such divine perfection, as Sir Proteus.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 1)
Better forbear till Proteus make return.   know'st thou not his looks are my soul's food?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 2)
Pity the dearth that have pined in By longing for that food so long a time.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 3)
Didst thou but know the inly touch of love, Thou wouldst as soon go kindle fire with snow As seek to quench the fire of love with words.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 4)
do not seek to quench your love's hot fire, But qualify the fire's extreme rage, Lest it should burn above the bounds of reason.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 5)
The more thou damm'st it up, the more it burns.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 6)
The current that with gentle murmur glides, Thou know'st, being stopped, impatiently doth rage, But when his fair course is not hindered, He makes sweet music with th' enameled stones, Giving a gentle kiss to every sedge He overtaketh in his pilgrimage; And so by many winding nooks he strays With willing sport to the wild ocean.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 7)
Then let me go and hinder not my course. I'll be as patient as a gentle stream And make a pastime of each weary step Till the last step have brought me to my love, And there I'll rest as after much turmoil blessed soul doth in Elysium.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 8)
But in what habit will you go along?   Not like a woman, for would prevent The loose encounters of lascivious men.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 9)
Gentle Lucetta, fit me with such weeds As may beseem some well-reputed page.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 10)
Why, then, your Ladyship must cut your hair.   No, girl, I'll knit it up in silken strings With twenty odd-conceited true-love knots.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 11)
To be fantastic may become a youth Of greater time than shall show to be.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 12)
What fashion, madam, shall make your breeches?   That fits as well as "Tell me, good my lord, What compass will you wear your farthingale?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 13)
" Why, ev'n what fashion thou best likes, Lucetta.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 14)
You must needs have them with a codpiece, madam.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 15)
Out, out, Lucetta. That will be ill-favored.   round hose, madam, now's not worth a pin Unless you have a codpiece to stick pins on.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 16)
Lucetta, as thou lov'st me, let me have What thou think'st meet and is most mannerly.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 17)
But tell me, wench, how will the world repute me For undertaking so unstaid a journey?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 18)
fear me it will make me scandalized.   If you think so, then stay at home and go not.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 19)
Nay, that will not.   Then never dream on infamy, but go.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 20)
If Proteus like your journey when you come, No matter who's displeased when you are gone.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 21)
fear me he will scarce be pleased withal.   That is the least, Lucetta, of my fear.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 22)
thousand oaths, an ocean of his tears, And instances of infinite of love Warrant me welcome to my Proteus.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 23)
All these are servants to deceitful men.   Base men that use them to so base effect!(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 24)
But truer stars did govern Proteus' birth. His words are bonds, his oaths are oracles, His love sincere, his thoughts immaculate, His tears pure messengers sent from his heart, His heart as far from fraud as heaven from Earth.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 25)
Pray heav'n he prove so when you come to him.   Now, as thou lov'st me, do him not that wrong To bear a hard opinion of his truth.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 26)
Only deserve my love by loving him. And presently go with me to my chamber To take a note of what stand in need of To furnish me upon my longing journey.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 27)
All that is mine leave at thy dispose, My goods, my lands, my reputation.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 28)
Only, in lieu thereof, dispatch me hence. Come, answer not, but to it presently.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 6, Scene 29)
Sir Thurio, give us leave, pray, awhile; We have some secrets to confer about.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 0)
Now tell me, Proteus, what's your will with me?   My gracious lord, that which would discover The law of friendship bids me to conceal, But when call to mind your gracious favors Done to me, undeserving as am, My duty pricks me on to utter that Which else no worldly good should draw from me.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 1)
Know, worthy prince, Sir Valentine my friend This night intends to steal away your daughter; Myself am one made privy to the plot.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 2)
know you have determined to bestow her On Thurio, whom your gentle daughter hates, And should she thus be stol'n away from you, It would be much vexation to your age.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 3)
Thus, for my duty's sake, rather chose To cross my friend in his intended drift Than, by concealing it, heap on your head pack of sorrows which would press you down, Being unprevented, to your timeless grave.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 4)
Proteus, thank thee for thine honest care, Which to requite command me while live.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 5)
This love of theirs myself have often seen, Haply when they have judged me fast asleep, And oftentimes have purposed to forbid Sir Valentine her company and my court.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 6)
But fearing lest my jealous aim might err And so, unworthily, disgrace the man-- rashness that ever yet have shunned-- gave him gentle looks, thereby to find That which thyself hast now disclosed to me.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 7)
And that thou mayst perceive my fear of this, Knowing that tender youth is soon suggested, nightly lodge her in an upper tower, The key whereof myself have ever kept, And thence she cannot be conveyed away.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 8)
Know, noble lord, they have devised a mean How he her chamber-window will ascend And with a corded ladder fetch her down; For which the youthful lover now is gone, And this way comes he with it presently, Where, if it please you, you may intercept him.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 9)
But, good my lord, do it so cunningly That my discovery be not aimed at; For love of you, not hate unto my friend, Hath made me publisher of this pretense.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 10)
Upon mine honor, he shall never know That had any light from thee of this.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 11)
Adieu, my lord. Sir Valentine is coming.       Sir Valentine, whither away so fast?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 12)
Please it your Grace, there is a messenger That stays to bear my letters to my friends, And am going to deliver them.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 13)
Be they of much import?   The tenor of them doth but signify My health and happy being at your court.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 14)
Nay then, no matter. Stay with me awhile; am to break with thee of some affairs That touch me near, wherein thou must be secret.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 15)
'Tis not unknown to thee that have sought To match my friend Sir Thurio to my daughter.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 16)
know it well, my lord, and sure the match Were rich and honorable.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 17)
Besides, the gentleman Is full of virtue, bounty, worth, and qualities Beseeming such a wife as your fair daughter.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 18)
Cannot your Grace win her to fancy him?   No. Trust me, she is peevish, sullen, froward, Proud, disobedient, stubborn, lacking duty, Neither regarding that she is my child Nor fearing me as if were her father; And may say to thee, this pride of hers, Upon advice, hath drawn my love from her, And where thought the remnant of mine age Should have been cherished by her childlike duty, now am full resolved to take a wife And turn her out to who will take her in.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 19)
Then let her beauty be her wedding dower, For me and my possessions she esteems not.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 20)
What would your Grace have me to do in this?   There is a lady in Verona here Whom affect; but she is nice, and coy, And nought esteems my aged eloquence.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 21)
Now therefore would have thee to my tutor-- For long agone have forgot to court; Besides, the fashion of the time is changed-- How and which way may bestow myself To be regarded in her sun-bright eye.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 22)
Win her with gifts if she respect not words; Dumb jewels often in their silent kind More than quick words do move a woman's mind.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 23)
But she did scorn a present that sent her.   woman sometime scorns what best contents her.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 24)
Send her another; never give her o'er, For scorn at first makes after-love the more.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 25)
If she do frown, 'tis not in hate of you, But rather to beget more love in you.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 26)
If she do chide, 'tis not to have you gone, Forwhy the fools are mad if left alone.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 27)
Take no repulse, whatever she doth say; For "get you gone" she doth not mean "away.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 28)
" Flatter and praise, commend, extol their graces; Though ne'er so black, say they have angels' faces.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 29)
That man that hath a tongue, say, is no man If with his tongue he cannot win a woman.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 30)
But she mean is promised by her friends Unto a youthful gentleman of worth And kept severely from resort of men, That no man hath access by day to her.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 31)
Why, then, would resort to her by night.   Ay, but the doors be locked and keys kept safe, That no man hath recourse to her by night.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 32)
What lets but one may enter at her window?   Her chamber is aloft, far from the ground, And built so shelving that one cannot climb it Without apparent hazard of his life.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 33)
Why, then a ladder quaintly made of cords To cast up, with a pair of anchoring hooks, Would serve to scale another Hero's tower, So bold Leander would adventure it.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 34)
Now, as thou art a gentleman of blood, Advise me where may have such a ladder.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 35)
When would you use it? Pray sir, tell me that.   This very night; for love is like a child That longs for everything that he can come by.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 36)
By seven o'clock I'll get you such a ladder.   But hark thee: will go to her alone; How shall best convey the ladder thither?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 37)
It will be light, my lord, that you may bear it Under a cloak that is of any length.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 38)
cloak as long as thine will serve the turn?   Ay, my good lord.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 39)
Then let me see thy cloak; I'll get me one of such another length.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 40)
Why, any cloak will serve the turn, my lord.   How shall fashion me to wear a cloak?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 41)
pray thee, let me feel thy cloak upon me.   What letter is this same?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 42)
What's here?  To Sylvia. And here an engine fit for my proceeding.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 43)
I'll be so bold to break the seal for once.  My thoughts do harbor with my Sylvia nightly, And slaves they are to me that send them flying.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 44)
could their master come and go as lightly, Himself would lodge where, senseless, they are lying.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 45)
