My herald thoughts in thy pure bosom rest them, While their king, that thither them importune, Do curse the grace that with such grace hath blest them, Because myself do want my servants' fortune.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 46)
curse myself, for they are sent by me, That they should harbor where their lord should be.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 47)
What's here? Sylvia, this night will enfranchise thee.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 48)
'Tis so. And here's the ladder for the purpose. Why, Phaeton--for thou art Merops' son-- Wilt thou aspire to guide the heavenly car And with thy daring folly burn the world?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 49)
Wilt thou reach stars because they shine on thee?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 50)
Go, base intruder, overweening slave, Bestow thy fawning smiles on equal mates And think my patience, more than thy desert, Is privilege for thy departure hence.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 51)
Thank me for this more than for all the favors Which all too much have bestowed on thee.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 52)
But if thou linger in my territories Longer than swiftest expedition Will give thee time to leave our royal court, By heaven, my wrath shall far exceed the love ever bore my daughter or thyself.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 53)
Begone. will not hear thy vain excuse, But, as thou lov'st thy life, make speed from hence.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 54)
And why not death, rather than living torment?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 55)
To die is to be banished from myself, And Sylvia is myself; banished from her Is self from self--a deadly banishment.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 56)
What light is light if Sylvia be not seen? What joy is joy if Sylvia be not by-- Unless it be to think that she is by And feed upon the shadow of perfection?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 57)
Except be by Sylvia in the night, There is no music in the nightingale.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 58)
Unless look on Sylvia in the day, There is no day for me to look upon.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 59)
She is my essence, and leave to be If be not by her fair influence Fostered, illumined, cherished, kept alive.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 60)
fly not death, to fly his deadly doom; Tarry here, but attend on death, But fly hence, fly away from life.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 61)
Run, boy, run, run, and seek him out.  So-ho, so-ho!(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 62)
What seest thou?  Him we go to find. There's not a hair on 's head but 'tis a Valentine.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 63)
Valentine?  No.  Who then? His spirit?  Neither.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 64)
What then?  Nothing.  Can nothing speak? Master, shall strike?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 65)
Who wouldst thou strike?  Nothing.  Villain, forbear.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 66)
Why, sir, I'll strike nothing. pray you--   Sirrah, say forbear.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 67)
--Friend Valentine, a word.   My ears are stopped and cannot hear good news, So much of bad already hath possessed them.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 68)
Then in dumb silence will bury mine, For they are harsh, untunable, and bad.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 69)
Is Sylvia dead?  No, Valentine.   No Valentine indeed for sacred Sylvia.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 70)
Hath she forsworn me?  No, Valentine.   No Valentine if Sylvia have forsworn me.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 71)
What is your news?  Sir, there is a proclamation that you are vanished.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 72)
That thou art banished--O, that's the news-- From hence, from Sylvia, and from me thy friend.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 73)
have fed upon this woe already, And now excess of it will make me surfeit.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 74)
Doth Sylvia know that am banished?   Ay, ay, and she hath offered to the doom-- Which unreversed stands in effectual force-- sea of melting pearl, which some call tears; Those at her father's churlish feet she tendered, With them, upon her knees, her humble self, Wringing her hands, whose whiteness so became them As if but now they waxed pale for woe.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 75)
But neither bended knees, pure hands held up, Sad sighs, deep groans, nor silver-shedding tears Could penetrate her uncompassionate sire; But Valentine, if he be ta'en, must die.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 76)
Besides, her intercession chafed him so, When she for thy repeal was suppliant, That to close prison he commanded her With many bitter threats of biding there.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 77)
No more, unless the next word that thou speak'st Have some malignant power upon my life.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 78)
If so, pray thee breathe it in mine ear As ending anthem of my endless dolor.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 79)
Cease to lament for that thou canst not help, And study help for that which thou lament'st.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 80)
Time is the nurse and breeder of all good. Here, if thou stay, thou canst not see thy love; Besides, thy staying will abridge thy life.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 81)
Hope is a lover's staff; walk hence with that And manage it against despairing thoughts.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 82)
Thy letters may be here, though thou art hence, Which, being writ to me, shall be delivered Even in the milk-white bosom of thy love.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 83)
The time now serves not to expostulate. Come, I'll convey thee through the city gate And, ere part with thee, confer at large Of all that may concern thy love affairs.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 84)
As thou lov'st Sylvia, though not for thyself, Regard thy danger, and along with me.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 85)
pray thee, Lance, an if thou seest my boy, Bid him make haste and meet me at the North Gate.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 86)
Go, sirrah, find him out.--Come, Valentine.   my dear Sylvia!(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 87)
Hapless Valentine!   am but a fool, look you, and yet have the wit to think my master is a kind of a knave, but that's all one if he be but one knave.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 88)
He lives not now that knows me to be in love, yet am in love, but a team of horse shall not pluck that from me, nor who 'tis love; and yet 'tis a woman, but what woman will not tell myself; and yet 'tis a milk-maid; yet 'tis not a maid, for she hath had gossips; yet 'tis a maid, for she is her master's maid and serves for wages.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 89)
She hath more qualities than a water spaniel, which is much in a bare Christian.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 90)
Here is the catalog of her condition. Imprimis, She can fetch and carry.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 91)
Why, a horse can do no more; nay, a horse cannot fetch but only carry; therefore is she better than a jade.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 92)
Item, She can milk. Look you, a sweet virtue in a maid with clean hands.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 93)
How now, Signior Lance? What news with your Mastership?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 94)
With my master's ship? Why, it is at sea.  Well, your old vice still: mistake the word.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 95)
What news, then, in your paper?  The black'st news that ever thou heard'st.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 96)
Why, man? How black?  Why, as black as ink.  Let me read them.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 97)
Fie on thee, jolt-head, thou canst not read.  Thou liest.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 98)
can.  will try thee. Tell me this, who begot thee?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 99)
Marry, the son of my grandfather.  illiterate loiterer, it was the son of thy grandmother.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 100)
This proves that thou canst not read.  Come, fool, come.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 101)
Try me in thy paper.  There, and Saint Nicholas be thy speed.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 102)
Imprimis, She can milk.  Ay, that she can.  Item, She brews good ale.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 103)
And thereof comes the proverb: "Blessing of your heart, you brew good ale.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 104)
"  Item, She can sew.  That's as much as to say "Can she so?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 105)
"  Item, She can knit.  What need a man care for a stock with a wench, when she can knit him a stock?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 106)
Item, She can wash and scour.  special virtue, for then she need not be washed and scoured.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 107)
Item, She can spin.  Then may set the world on wheels, when she can spin for her living.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 108)
Item, She hath many nameless virtues.  That's as much as to say "bastard virtues," that indeed know not their fathers and therefore have no names.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 109)
Here follow her vices.  Close at the heels of her virtues.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 110)
Item, She is not to be kissed fasting in respect of her breath.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 111)
Well, that fault may be mended with a breakfast.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 112)
Read on.  Item, She hath a sweet mouth.  That makes amends for her sour breath.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 113)
Item, She doth talk in her sleep.  It's no matter for that, so she sleep not in her talk.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 114)
Item, She is slow in words.  villain, that set this down among her vices!(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 115)
To be slow in words is a woman's only virtue. pray thee, out with 't, and place it for her chief virtue.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 116)
Item, She is proud.  Out with that too; it was Eve's legacy and cannot be ta'en from her.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 117)
Item, She hath no teeth.  care not for that neither, because love crusts.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 118)
Item, She is curst.  Well, the best is, she hath no teeth to bite.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 119)
Item, She will often praise her liquor.  If her liquor be good, she shall; if she will not, will, for good things should be praised.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 120)
Item, She is too liberal.  Of her tongue she cannot, for that's writ down she is slow of; of her purse she shall not, for that I'll keep shut; now, of another thing she may, and that cannot help.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 121)
Well, proceed.  Item, She hath more hair than wit, and more faults than hairs, and more wealth than faults.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 122)
Stop there. I'll have her. She was mine and not mine twice or thrice in that last article.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 123)
Rehearse that once more.  Item, She hath more hair than wit.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 124)
"More hair than wit"? It may be; I'll prove it: the cover of the salt hides the salt, and therefore it is more than the salt; the hair that covers the wit is more than the wit, for the greater hides the less.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 125)
What's next?  And more faults than hairs.  That's monstrous!(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 126)
that that were out!  And more wealth than faults.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 127)
Why, that word makes the faults gracious. Well, I'll have her, and if it be a match, as nothing is impossible--  What then?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 128)
Why, then will tell thee that thy master stays for thee at the North Gate.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 129)
For me?  For thee? Ay, who art thou? He hath stayed for a better man than thee.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 130)
And must go to him?  Thou must run to him, for thou hast stayed so long that going will scarce serve the turn.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 131)
Why didst not tell me sooner? Pox of your love letters!(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 132)
Now will he be swinged for reading my letter; an unmannerly slave, that will thrust himself into secrets.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 133)
Sir Thurio, fear not but that she will love you Now Valentine is banished from her sight.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 0)
Since his exile she hath despised me most, Forsworn my company and railed at me, That am desperate of obtaining her.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 1)
This weak impress of love is as a figure Trenched in ice, which with an hour's heat Dissolves to water and doth lose his form.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 2)
little time will melt her frozen thoughts, And worthless Valentine shall be forgot.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 3)
How now, Sir Proteus? Is your countryman, According to our proclamation, gone?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 4)
Gone, my good lord.   My daughter takes his going grievously.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 5)
little time, my lord, will kill that grief.   So believe, but Thurio thinks not so.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 6)
Proteus, the good conceit hold of thee, For thou hast shown some sign of good desert, Makes me the better to confer with thee.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 7)
Longer than prove loyal to your Grace Let me not live to look upon your Grace.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 8)
Thou know'st how willingly would effect The match between Sir Thurio and my daughter?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 9)
do, my lord.   And also, think, thou art not ignorant How she opposes her against my will?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 10)
She did, my lord, when Valentine was here.   Ay, and perversely she persevers so.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 11)
What might we do to make the girl forget The love of Valentine, and love Sir Thurio?(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 12)
The best way is to slander Valentine With falsehood, cowardice, and poor descent, Three things that women highly hold in hate.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 13)
Ay, but she'll think that it is spoke in hate.   Ay, if his enemy deliver it.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 14)
Therefore it must with circumstance be spoken By one whom she esteemeth as his friend.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 15)
Then you must undertake to slander him.   And that, my lord, shall be loath to do.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 16)
'Tis an ill office for a gentleman, Especially against his very friend.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 17)
Where your good word cannot advantage him, Your slander never can endamage him; Therefore the office is indifferent, Being entreated to it by your friend.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 18)
You have prevailed, my lord. If can do it By aught that can speak in his dispraise, She shall not long continue love to him.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 19)
But say this weed her love from Valentine, It follows not that she will love Sir Thurio.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 20)
Therefore, as you unwind her love from him, Lest it should ravel and be good to none, You must provide to bottom it on me, Which must be done by praising me as much As you in worth dispraise Sir Valentine.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 21)
And, Proteus, we dare trust you in this kind Because we know, on Valentine's report, You are already Love's firm votary And cannot soon revolt and change your mind.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 22)
Upon this warrant shall you have access Where you with Sylvia may confer at large-- For she is lumpish, heavy, melancholy, And, for your friend's sake, will be glad of you-- Where you may temper her by your persuasion To hate young Valentine and love my friend.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 23)
As much as can do will effect.-- But you, Sir Thurio, are not sharp enough.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 24)
You must lay lime to tangle her desires By wailful sonnets, whose composed rhymes Should be full-fraught with serviceable vows.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 25)
Ay, much is the force of heaven-bred poesy.   Say that upon the altar of her beauty You sacrifice your tears, your sighs, your heart.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 26)
Write till your ink be dry, and with your tears Moist it again, and frame some feeling line That may discover such integrity.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 27)
For Orpheus' lute was strung with poets' sinews, Whose golden touch could soften steel and stones, Make tigers tame, and huge leviathans Forsake unsounded deeps to dance on sands.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 28)
After your dire-lamenting elegies, Visit by night your lady's chamber window With some sweet consort; to their instruments Tune a deploring dump; the night's dead silence Will well become such sweet complaining grievance.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 29)
This, or else nothing, will inherit her.   This discipline shows thou hast been in love.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 30)
And thy advice this night I'll put in practice.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 31)
Therefore, sweet Proteus, my direction-giver, Let us into the city presently To sort some gentlemen well-skilled in music.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 32)
have a sonnet that will serve the turn To give the onset to thy good advice.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 33)
About it, gentlemen.   We'll wait upon your Grace till after supper And afterward determine our proceedings.(The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 21, Scene 34)
And late five thousand. To Varro and to Isidore He owes nine thousand, besides my former sum, Which makes it five-and-twenty.(Timon of Athens, Act 0, Scene 0)
Still in motion Of raging waste! It cannot hold; it will not.(Timon of Athens, Act 0, Scene 1)
If want gold, steal but a beggar's dog And give it Timon, why, the dog coins gold.(Timon of Athens, Act 0, Scene 2)
If would sell my horse and buy twenty more Better than he, why, give my horse to Timon-- Ask nothing; give it him--it foals me straight, And able horses.(Timon of Athens, Act 0, Scene 3)
No porter at his gate But rather one that smiles and still invites All that pass by.(Timon of Athens, Act 0, Scene 4)
It cannot hold. No reason Can sound his state in safety.(Timon of Athens, Act 0, Scene 5)
--Caphis, ho! Caphis, say!     Here, sir. What is your pleasure?(Timon of Athens, Act 0, Scene 6)
Get on your cloak and haste you to Lord Timon. Importune him for my moneys.(Timon of Athens, Act 0, Scene 7)
Be not ceased With slight denial, nor then silenced when "Commend me to your master" and the cap Plays in the right hand thus; but tell him My uses cry to me.(Timon of Athens, Act 0, Scene 8)
must serve my turn Out of mine own. His days and times are past, And my reliances on his fracted dates Have smit my credit.(Timon of Athens, Act 0, Scene 9)
love and honor him But must not break my back to heal his finger.(Timon of Athens, Act 0, Scene 10)
Immediate are my needs, and my relief Must not be tossed and turned to me in words But find supply immediate.(Timon of Athens, Act 0, Scene 11)
Get you gone. Put on a most importunate aspect, visage of demand, for do fear When every feather sticks in his own wing Lord Timon will be left a naked gull, Which flashes now a phoenix.(Timon of Athens, Act 0, Scene 12)
Get you gone.  go, sir.   go, sir"? Take the bonds along with you And have the dates in.(Timon of Athens, Act 0, Scene 13)
2        No care, no stop, so senseless of expense That he will neither know how to maintain it Nor cease his flow of riot.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 0)
Takes no account How things go from him nor resumes no care Of what is to continue.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 1)
Never mind Was to be so unwise to be so kind. What shall be done?(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 2)
He will not hear till feel. must be round with him, now he comes from hunting.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 3)
Fie, fie, fie, fie!      Good even, Varro. What, you come for money?(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 4)
Is 't not your business too?  It is. And yours too, Isidore?(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 5)
It is so.  Would we were all discharged!  fear it.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 6)
Here comes the lord.      So soon as dinner's done we'll forth again, My Alcibiades.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 7)
With me? What is your will?   My lord, here is a note of certain dues.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 8)
Dues? Whence are you?  Of Athens here, my lord.  Go to my steward.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 9)
Please it your Lordship, he hath put me off To the succession of new days this month.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 10)
My master is awaked by great occasion To call upon his own and humbly prays you That with your other noble parts you'll suit In giving him his right.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 11)
Mine honest friend, prithee but repair to me next morning.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 12)
Nay, good my lord--  Contain thyself, good friend.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 13)
One Varro's servant, my good lord--   From Isidore.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 14)
He humbly prays your speedy payment.   If you did know, my lord, my master's wants--   'Twas due on forfeiture, my lord, six weeks and past.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 15)
Your steward puts me off, my lord, and Am sent expressly to your Lordship.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 16)
Give me breath.-- do beseech you, good my lords, keep on.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 17)
I'll wait upon you instantly.  Come hither. Pray you, How goes the world that am thus encountered With clamorous demands of debt, broken bonds, And the detention of long-since-due debts Against my honor?(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 18)
Please you, gentlemen, The time is unagreeable to this business.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 19)
Your importunacy cease till after dinner, That may make his Lordship understand Wherefore you are not paid.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 20)
Do so, my friends.-- See them well entertained.  Pray, draw near.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 21)
Stay, stay, here comes the Fool with Apemantus.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 22)
Let's ha' some sport with 'em.  Hang him! He'll abuse us.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 23)
plague upon him, dog!  How dost, Fool?  Dost dialogue with thy shadow?(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 24)
speak not to thee.  No, 'tis to thyself.  Come away.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 25)
There's the fool hangs on your back already.  No, thou stand'st single; thou 'rt not on him yet.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 26)
Where's the fool now?  He last asked the question.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 27)
Poor rogues and usurers' men, bawds between gold and want.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 28)
What are we, Apemantus?  Asses.  Why?  That you ask me what you are, and do not know yourselves.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 29)
--Speak to 'em, Fool.  How do you, gentlemen?  Gramercies, good Fool.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 30)
How does your mistress?  She's e'en setting on water to scald such chickens as you are.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 31)
Would we could see you at Corinth!  Good. Gramercy.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 32)
Look you, here comes my master's page.  Why, how now, captain?(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 33)
What do you in this wise company?--How dost thou, Apemantus?(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 34)
Would had a rod in my mouth that might answer thee profitably.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 35)
Prithee, Apemantus, read me the superscription of these letters.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 36)
know not which is which.   Canst not read?  No.  There will little learning die, then, that day thou art hanged.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 37)
This is to Lord Timon, this to Alcibiades. Go. Thou wast born a bastard, and thou 'lt die a bawd.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 38)
Thou wast whelped a dog, and thou shalt famish a dog's death.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 39)
Answer not. am gone.  E'en so thou outrunn'st grace.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 40)
--Fool, will go with you to Lord Timon's.  Will you leave me there?(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 41)
If Timon stay at home.--You three serve three usurers?(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 42)
Ay. Would they served us!  So would I--as good a trick as ever hangman served thief.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 43)
Are you three usurers' men?  Ay, fool.  think no usurer but has a fool to his servant.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 44)
My mistress is one, and am her Fool. When men come to borrow of your masters, they approach sadly and go away merry, but they enter my master's house merrily and go away sadly.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 45)
The reason of this?  could render one.  Do it then, that we may account thee a whoremaster and a knave, which notwithstanding, thou shalt be no less esteemed.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 46)
What is a whoremaster, fool?  fool in good clothes, and something like thee.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 47)
'Tis a spirit; sometime 't appears like a lord, sometime like a lawyer, sometime like a philosopher, with two stones more than 's artificial one.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 48)
He is very often like a knight, and generally in all shapes that man goes up and down in from fourscore to thirteen, this spirit walks in.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 49)
Thou art not altogether a Fool.  Nor thou altogether a wise man.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 50)
As much foolery as have, so much wit thou lack'st.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 51)
That answer might have become Apemantus.  Aside, aside!(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 52)
Here comes Lord Timon.     Come with me, fool, come.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 53)
do not always follow lover, elder brother, and woman; sometime the philosopher.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 54)
Pray you, walk near. I'll speak with you anon.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 55)
You make me marvel wherefore ere this time Had you not fully laid my state before me, That might so have rated my expense As had leave of means.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 56)
You would not hear me. At many leisures proposed--  Go to.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 57)
Perchance some single vantages you took When my indisposition put you back, And that unaptness made your minister Thus to excuse yourself.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 58)
my good lord, At many times brought in my accounts, Laid them before you.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 59)
You would throw them off And say you found them in mine honesty.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 60)
When for some trifling present you have bid me Return so much, have shook my head and wept-- Yea, 'gainst th' authority of manners prayed you To hold your hand more close.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 61)
did endure Not seldom nor no slight checks when have Prompted you in the ebb of your estate And your great flow of debts.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 62)
My loved lord, Though you hear now too late, yet now's a time.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 63)
The greatest of your having lacks a half To pay your present debts.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 64)
Let all my land be sold.   'Tis all engaged, some forfeited and gone, And what remains will hardly stop the mouth Of present dues.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 65)
The future comes apace. What shall defend the interim?(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 66)
And at length How goes our reck'ning?   To Lacedaemon did my land extend.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 67)
my good lord, the world is but a word. Were it all yours to give it in a breath, How quickly were it gone!(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 68)
You tell me true.   If you suspect my husbandry of falsehood, Call me before th' exactest auditors, And set me on the proof.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 69)
So the gods bless me, When all our offices have been oppressed With riotous feeders, when our vaults have wept With drunken spilth of wine, when every room Hath blazed with lights and brayed with minstrelsy, have retired me to a wasteful cock And set mine eyes at flow.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 70)
Prithee, no more.   Heavens, have said, the bounty of this lord!(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 71)
How many prodigal bits have slaves and peasants This night englutted.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 72)
Who is not Timon's? What heart, head, sword, force, means, but is Lord Timon's?(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 73)
Great Timon, noble, worthy, royal Timon! Ah, when the means are gone that buy this praise, The breath is gone whereof this praise is made.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 74)
Feast-won, fast-lost. One cloud of winter showers, These flies are couched.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 75)
Come, sermon me no further. No villainous bounty yet hath passed my heart; Unwisely, not ignobly, have given.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 76)
Why dost thou weep? Canst thou the conscience lack To think shall lack friends?(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 77)
Secure thy heart. If would broach the vessels of my love And try the argument of hearts by borrowing, Men and men's fortunes could frankly use As can bid thee speak.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 78)
Assurance bless your thoughts!   And in some sort these wants of mine are crowned, That account them blessings.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 79)
For by these Shall try friends. You shall perceive how you Mistake my fortunes.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 80)
am wealthy in my friends.-- Within there! Flaminius!(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 81)
--Servilius!     My lord, my lord.  will dispatch you severally.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 82)
You to Lord Lucius,  to Lord Lucullus you--I hunted with his Honor today; you to Sempronius.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 83)
Commend me to their loves, and am proud, say, that my occasions have found time to use 'em toward a supply of money.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 84)
Let the request be fifty talents.  As you have said, my lord.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 85)
Lord Lucius and Lucullus? Humh!  Go you, sir, to the Senators, Of whom, even to the state's best health, have Deserved this hearing.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 86)
Bid 'em send o' th' instant thousand talents to me.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 87)
have been bold-- For that knew it the most general way-- To them to use your signet and your name, But they do shake their heads, and am here No richer in return.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 88)
Is 't true? Can 't be?   They answer in a joint and corporate voice That now they are at fall, want treasure, cannot Do what they would, are sorry.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 89)
You are honorable, But yet they could have wished--they know not-- Something hath been amiss--a noble nature May catch a wrench--would all were well--'tis pity.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 90)
And so, intending other serious matters, After distasteful looks and these hard fractions, With certain half-caps and cold-moving nods They froze me into silence.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 91)
You gods, reward them! Prithee, man, look cheerly.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 92)
These old fellows Have their ingratitude in them hereditary.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 93)
Their blood is caked, 'tis cold, it seldom flows; 'Tis lack of kindly warmth they are not kind; And nature, as it grows again toward earth, Is fashioned for the journey, dull and heavy.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 94)
Go to Ventidius. Prithee, be not sad. Thou art true and honest--ingeniously speak-- No blame belongs to thee.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 95)
Ventidius lately Buried his father, by whose death he's stepped Into a great estate.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 96)
When he was poor, Imprisoned, and in scarcity of friends, cleared him with five talents.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 97)
Greet him from me. Bid him suppose some good necessity Touches his friend, which craves to be remembered With those five talents.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 98)
That had, give 't these fellows To whom 'tis instant due.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 99)
Ne'er speak or think That Timon's fortunes 'mong his friends can sink.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 100)
would could not think it. That thought is bounty's foe; Being free itself, it thinks all others so.(Timon of Athens, Act 1, Scene 101)
2      Now climbeth Tamora Olympus' top, Safe out of Fortune's shot, and sits aloft, Secure of thunder's crack or lightning flash, Advanced above pale Envy's threat'ning reach.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 0)
As when the golden sun salutes the morn And, having gilt the ocean with his beams, Gallops the zodiac in his glistering coach And overlooks the highest-peering hills, So Tamora.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 1)
Upon her wit doth earthly honor wait, And virtue stoops and trembles at her frown.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 2)
Then, Aaron, arm thy heart and fit thy thoughts To mount aloft with thy imperial mistress, And mount her pitch whom thou in triumph long Hast prisoner held, fettered in amorous chains And faster bound to Aaron's charming eyes Than is Prometheus tied to Caucasus.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 3)
Away with slavish weeds and servile thoughts! will be bright, and shine in pearl and gold To wait upon this new-made emperess.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 4)
To wait, said To wanton with this queen, This goddess, this Semiramis, this nymph, This siren that will charm Rome's Saturnine And see his shipwrack and his commonweal's.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 5)
Holla! What storm is this?      Chiron, thy years wants wit, thy wits wants edge And manners, to intrude where am graced, And may, for aught thou knowest, affected be.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 6)
Demetrius, thou dost overween in all, And so in this, to bear me down with braves.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 7)
'Tis not the difference of a year or two Makes me less gracious or thee more fortunate.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 8)
am as able and as fit as thou To serve and to deserve my mistress' grace, And that my sword upon thee shall approve And plead my passions for Lavinia's love.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 9)
Clubs, clubs! These lovers will not keep the peace.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 10)
Why, boy, although our mother, unadvised, Gave you a dancing rapier by your side, Are you so desperate grown to threat your friends?(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 11)
Go to. Have your lath glued within your sheath Till you know better how to handle it.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 12)
Meanwhile, sir, with the little skill have, Full well shalt thou perceive how much dare.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 13)
Ay, boy, grow you so brave?  Why, how now, lords?(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 14)
So near the Emperor's palace dare you draw And maintain such a quarrel openly?(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 15)
Full well wot the ground of all this grudge. would not for a million of gold The cause were known to them it most concerns, Nor would your noble mother for much more Be so dishonored in the court of Rome.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 16)
For shame, put up.  Not till have sheathed My rapier in his bosom, and withal Thrust those reproachful speeches down his throat That he hath breathed in my dishonor here.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 17)
For that am prepared and full resolved, Foul-spoken coward, that thund'rest with thy tongue And with thy weapon nothing dar'st perform.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 18)
Away, say! Now by the gods that warlike Goths adore, This petty brabble will undo us all.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 19)
Why, lords, and think you not how dangerous It is to jet upon a prince's right?(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 20)
What, is Lavinia then become so loose Or Bassianus so degenerate That for her love such quarrels may be broached Without controlment, justice, or revenge?(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 21)
Young lords, beware! And should the Empress know This discord's ground, the music would not please.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 22)
care not, knew she and all the world. love Lavinia more than all the world.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 23)
Youngling, learn thou to make some meaner choice.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 24)
Lavinia is thine elder brother's hope.   Why, are you mad?(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 25)
Or know you not in Rome How furious and impatient they be, And cannot brook competitors in love?(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 26)
tell you, lords, you do but plot your deaths By this device.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 27)
Aaron, a thousand deaths Would propose to achieve her whom love.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 28)
To achieve her how?  Why makes thou it so strange?(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 29)
She is a woman, therefore may be wooed; She is a woman, therefore may be won; She is Lavinia, therefore must be loved.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 30)
What, man, more water glideth by the mill Than wots the miller of, and easy it is Of a cut loaf to steal a shive, we know.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 31)
Though Bassianus be the Emperor's brother, Better than he have worn Vulcan's badge.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 32)
Ay, and as good as Saturninus may.   Then why should he despair that knows to court it With words, fair looks, and liberality?(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 33)
What, hast not thou full often struck a doe And borne her cleanly by the keeper's nose?(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 34)
Why, then, it seems some certain snatch or so Would serve your turns.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 35)
Ay, so the turn were served.  Aaron, thou hast hit it.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 36)
Would you had hit it too! Then should not we be tired with this ado.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 37)
Why, hark you, hark you! And are you such fools To square for this?(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 38)
Would it offend you then That both should speed?   Faith, not me.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 39)
Nor me, so were one.   For shame, be friends, and join for that you jar.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 40)
'Tis policy and stratagem must do That you affect, and so must you resolve That what you cannot as you would achieve, You must perforce accomplish as you may.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 41)
Take this of me: Lucrece was not more chaste Than this Lavinia, Bassianus' love.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 42)
speedier course than ling'ring languishment Must we pursue, and have found the path.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 43)
My lords, a solemn hunting is in hand; There will the lovely Roman ladies troop.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 44)
The forest walks are wide and spacious, And many unfrequented plots there are, Fitted by kind for rape and villainy.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 45)
Single you thither then this dainty doe, And strike her home by force, if not by words.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 46)
This way, or not at all, stand you in hope. Come, come, our empress, with her sacred wit To villainy and vengeance consecrate, Will we acquaint withal what we intend, And she shall file our engines with advice That will not suffer you to square yourselves, But to your wishes' height advance you both.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 47)
The Emperor's court is like the house of Fame, The palace full of tongues, of eyes, and ears; The woods are ruthless, dreadful, deaf, and dull.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 48)
There speak and strike, brave boys, and take your turns.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 49)
There serve your lust, shadowed from heaven's eye, And revel in Lavinia's treasury.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 50)
Thy counsel, lad, smells of no cowardice.   Sit fas aut nefas, till find the stream To cool this heat, a charm to calm these fits, Per Stygia, per manes vehor.(Titus Andronicus, Act 0, Scene 51)
The hunt is up, the moon is bright and gray, The fields are fragrant, and the woods are green.(Titus Andronicus, Act 1, Scene 0)
Uncouple here, and let us make a bay And wake the Emperor and his lovely bride, And rouse the Prince, and ring a hunter's peal, That all the court may echo with the noise.(Titus Andronicus, Act 1, Scene 1)
Sons, let it be your charge, as it is ours, To attend the Emperor's person carefully.(Titus Andronicus, Act 1, Scene 2)
have been troubled in my sleep this night, But dawning day new comfort hath inspired.(Titus Andronicus, Act 1, Scene 3)
enter Saturninus, Tamora, Bassianus, Lavinia, Chiron,     Many good morrows to your Majesty;-- Madam, to you as many, and as good.(Titus Andronicus, Act 1, Scene 4)
-- promised your Grace a hunter's peal.   And you have rung it lustily, my lords-- Somewhat too early for new-married ladies.(Titus Andronicus, Act 1, Scene 5)
Lavinia, how say you?  say no. have been broad awake two hours and more.(Titus Andronicus, Act 1, Scene 6)
Come on, then. Horse and chariots let us have, And to our sport.(Titus Andronicus, Act 1, Scene 7)
Madam, now shall you see Our Roman hunting.  have dogs, my lord, Will rouse the proudest panther in the chase And climb the highest promontory top.(Titus Andronicus, Act 1, Scene 8)
And have horse will follow where the game Makes way and runs like swallows o'er the plain.(Titus Andronicus, Act 1, Scene 9)
Chiron, we hunt not, we, with horse nor hound, But hope to pluck a dainty doe to ground.(Titus Andronicus, Act 1, Scene 10)
He that had wit would think that had none, To bury so much gold under a tree And never after to inherit it.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 0)
Let him that thinks of me so abjectly Know that this gold must coin a stratagem Which, cunningly effected, will beget very excellent piece of villainy.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 1)
And so repose, sweet gold, for their unrest That have their alms out of the Empress' chest.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 2)
My lovely Aaron, wherefore look'st thou sad, When everything doth make a gleeful boast?(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 3)
The birds chant melody on every bush, The snakes lies rolled in the cheerful sun, The green leaves quiver with the cooling wind And make a checkered shadow on the ground.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 4)
Under their sweet shade, Aaron, let us sit, And whilst the babbling echo mocks the hounds, Replying shrilly to the well-tuned horns, As if a double hunt were heard at once, Let us sit down and mark their yellowing noise.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 5)
And after conflict such as was supposed The wand'ring prince and Dido once enjoyed When with a happy storm they were surprised, And curtained with a counsel-keeping cave, We may, each wreathed in the other's arms, Our pastimes done, possess a golden slumber, Whiles hounds and horns and sweet melodious birds Be unto us as is a nurse's song Of lullaby to bring her babe asleep.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 6)
Madam, though Venus govern your desires, Saturn is dominator over mine.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 7)
What signifies my deadly standing eye, My silence, and my cloudy melancholy, My fleece of woolly hair that now uncurls Even as an adder when she doth unroll To do some fatal execution?(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 8)
No, madam, these are no venereal signs. Vengeance is in my heart, death in my hand, Blood and revenge are hammering in my head.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 9)
Hark, Tamora, the empress of my soul, Which never hopes more heaven than rests in thee, This is the day of doom for Bassianus.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 10)
His Philomel must lose her tongue today, Thy sons make pillage of her chastity And wash their hands in Bassianus' blood.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 11)
Seest thou this letter? Take it up, pray thee, And give the King this fatal-plotted scroll.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 12)
Now, question me no more. We are espied. Here comes a parcel of our hopeful booty, Which dreads not yet their lives' destruction.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 13)
Ah, my sweet Moor, sweeter to me than life!   No more, great empress.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 14)
Bassianus comes. Be cross with him, and I'll go fetch thy sons To back thy quarrels, whatsoe'er they be.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 15)
Who have we here? Rome's royal empress, Unfurnished of her well-beseeming troop?(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 16)
Or is it Dian, habited like her, Who hath abandoned her holy groves To see the general hunting in this forest?(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 17)
Saucy controller of my private steps, Had the power that some say Dian had, Thy temples should be planted presently With horns, as was Acteon's, and the hounds Should drive upon thy new-transformed limbs, Unmannerly intruder as thou art.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 18)
Under your patience, gentle empress, 'Tis thought you have a goodly gift in horning, And to be doubted that your Moor and you Are singled forth to try experiments.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 19)
Jove shield your husband from his hounds today! 'Tis pity they should take him for a stag.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 20)
Believe me, queen, your swarthy Cimmerian Doth make your honor of his body's hue, Spotted, detested, and abominable.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 21)
Why are you sequestered from all your train, Dismounted from your snow-white goodly steed, And wandered hither to an obscure plot, Accompanied but with a barbarous Moor, If foul desire had not conducted you?(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 22)
And being intercepted in your sport, Great reason that my noble lord be rated For sauciness.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 23)
--I pray you, let us hence, And let her joy her raven-colored love.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 24)
This valley fits the purpose passing well.   The King my brother shall have notice of this.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 25)
Ay, for these slips have made him noted long. Good king to be so mightily abused!(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 26)
Why, have patience to endure all this.      How now, dear sovereign and our gracious mother, Why doth your Highness look so pale and wan?(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 27)
Have not reason, think you, to look pale? These two have ticed me hither to this place, barren, detested vale you see it is; The trees, though summer, yet forlorn and lean, Overcome with moss and baleful mistletoe.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 28)
Here never shines the sun, here nothing breeds, Unless the nightly owl or fatal raven.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 29)
And when they showed me this abhorred pit, They told me, here at dead time of the night thousand fiends, a thousand hissing snakes, Ten thousand swelling toads, as many urchins, Would make such fearful and confused cries As any mortal body hearing it Should straight fall mad, or else die suddenly.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 30)
No sooner had they told this hellish tale But straight they told me they would bind me here Unto the body of a dismal yew And leave me to this miserable death.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 31)
And then they called me foul adulteress, Lascivious Goth, and all the bitterest terms That ever ear did hear to such effect.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 32)
And had you not by wondrous fortune come, This vengeance on me had they executed.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 33)
Revenge it as you love your mother's life, Or be you not henceforth called my children.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 34)
This is a witness that am thy son.   And this for me, struck home to show my strength.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 35)
Ay, come, Semiramis, nay, barbarous Tamora, For no name fits thy nature but thy own!(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 36)
Give me the poniard! You shall know, my boys, Your mother's hand shall right your mother's wrong.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 37)
Stay, madam, here is more belongs to her. First thrash the corn, then after burn the straw.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 38)
This minion stood upon her chastity, Upon her nuptial vow, her loyalty, And with that painted hope braves your mightiness; And shall she carry this unto her grave?(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 39)
And if she do, would were an eunuch! Drag hence her husband to some secret hole, And make his dead trunk pillow to our lust.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 40)
But when you have the honey you desire, Let not this wasp outlive, us both to sting.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 41)
warrant you, madam, we will make that sure.-- Come, mistress, now perforce we will enjoy That nice-preserved honesty of yours.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 42)
Tamora, thou bearest a woman's face--   will not hear her speak.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 43)
Away with her.   Sweet lords, entreat her hear me but a word.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 44)
Listen, fair madam. Let it be your glory To see her tears, but be your heart to them As unrelenting flint to drops of rain.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 45)
When did the tiger's young ones teach the dam? do not learn her wrath; she taught it thee.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 46)
The milk thou suck'st from her did turn to marble.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 47)
Even at thy teat thou hadst thy tyranny. Yet every mother breeds not sons alike.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 48)
Do thou entreat her show a woman's pity.   What, wouldst thou have me prove myself a bastard?(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 49)
'Tis true; the raven doth not hatch a lark. Yet have heard--O, could find it now!(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 50)
-- The lion, moved with pity, did endure To have his princely paws pared all away.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 51)
Some say that ravens foster forlorn children, The whilst their own birds famish in their nests.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 52)
be to me, though thy hard heart say no, Nothing so kind, but something pitiful.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 53)
know not what it means.--Away with her.   let me teach thee!(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 54)
For my father's sake, That gave thee life when well he might have slain thee, Be not obdurate; open thy deaf ears.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 55)
Hadst thou in person ne'er offended me, Even for his sake am pitiless.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 56)
-- Remember, boys, poured forth tears in vain To save your brother from the sacrifice, But fierce Andronicus would not relent.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 57)
Therefore away with her, and use her as you will; The worse to her, the better loved of me.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 58)
Tamora, be called a gentle queen, And with thine own hands kill me in this place!(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 59)
For 'tis not life that have begged so long; Poor was slain when Bassianus died.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 60)
What begg'st thou, then? Fond woman, let me go!(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 61)
'Tis present death beg, and one thing more That womanhood denies my tongue to tell.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 62)
keep me from their worse-than-killing lust, And tumble me into some loathsome pit Where never man's eye may behold my body.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 63)
Do this, and be a charitable murderer.   So should rob my sweet sons of their fee.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 64)
No, let them satisfy their lust on thee.   Away, for thou hast stayed us here too long!(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 65)
No grace, no womanhood? Ah, beastly creature, The blot and enemy to our general name, Confusion fall--   Nay, then, I'll stop your mouth.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 66)
--Bring thou her husband. This is the hole where Aaron bid us hide him.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 67)
Farewell, my sons. See that you make her sure.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 68)
Ne'er let my heart know merry cheer indeed Till all the Andronici be made away.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 69)
Now will hence to seek my lovely Moor, And let my spleenful sons this trull deflower.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 70)
Come on, my lords, the better foot before.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 71)
Straight will bring you to the loathsome pit Where espied the panther fast asleep.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 72)
My sight is very dull, whate'er it bodes.   And mine, promise you.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 73)
Were it not for shame, Well could leave our sport to sleep awhile.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 74)
What, art thou fallen? What subtle hole is this, Whose mouth is covered with rude-growing briers Upon whose leaves are drops of new-shed blood As fresh as morning dew distilled on flowers?(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 75)
very fatal place it seems to me. Speak, brother! Hast thou hurt thee with the fall?(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 76)
brother, with the dismal'st object hurt That ever eye with sight made heart lament!(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 77)
Now will fetch the King to find them here, That he thereby may have a likely guess How these were they that made away his brother.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 78)
Why dost not comfort me and help me out From this unhallowed and bloodstained hole?(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 79)
am surprised with an uncouth fear. chilling sweat o'erruns my trembling joints.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 80)
My heart suspects more than mine eye can see.   To prove thou hast a true-divining heart, Aaron and thou look down into this den And see a fearful sight of blood and death.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 81)
Aaron is gone, and my compassionate heart Will not permit mine eyes once to behold The thing whereat it trembles by surmise.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 82)
tell me who it is, for ne'er till now Was a child to fear know not what.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 83)
Lord Bassianus lies berayed in blood, All on a heap, like to a slaughtered lamb, In this detested, dark, blood-drinking pit.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 84)
If it be dark, how dost thou know 'tis he?   Upon his bloody finger he doth wear precious ring that lightens all this hole, Which like a taper in some monument Doth shine upon the dead man's earthy cheeks And shows the ragged entrails of this pit.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 85)
So pale did shine the moon on Pyramus When he by night lay bathed in maiden blood.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 86)
brother, help me with thy fainting hand-- If fear hath made thee faint as me it hath-- Out of this fell devouring receptacle, As hateful as Cocytus' misty mouth.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 87)
Reach me thy hand, that may help thee out, Or, wanting strength to do thee so much good, may be plucked into the swallowing womb Of this deep pit, poor Bassianus' grave.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 88)
have no strength to pluck thee to the brink.   Nor no strength to climb without thy help.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 89)
Thy hand once more. will not loose again Till thou art here aloft or below.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 90)
Thou canst not come to me. come to thee.        Along with me!(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 91)
I'll see what hole is here And what he is that now is leapt into it.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 92)
-- Say, who art thou that lately didst descend Into this gaping hollow of the earth?(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 93)
The unhappy sons of old Andronicus, Brought hither in a most unlucky hour To find thy brother Bassianus dead.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 94)
My brother dead! know thou dost but jest. He and his lady both are at the lodge Upon the north side of this pleasant chase.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 95)
'Tis not an hour since left them there.   We know not where you left them all alive, But, out alas, here have we found him dead.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 96)
Where is my lord the King?   Here, Tamora, though grieved with killing grief.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 97)
Where is thy brother Bassianus?   Now to the bottom dost thou search my wound.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 98)
Poor Bassianus here lies murdered.   Then all too late bring this fatal writ, The complot of this timeless tragedy, And wonder greatly that man's face can fold In pleasing smiles such murderous tyranny.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 99)
An if we miss to meet him handsomely, Sweet huntsman--Bassianus 'tis we mean-- Do thou so much as dig the grave for him; Thou know'st our meaning.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 100)
Look for thy reward Among the nettles at the elder tree Which overshades the mouth of that same pit Where we decreed to bury Bassianus.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 101)
Do this, and purchase us thy lasting friends. Tamora, was ever heard the like?(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 102)
This is the pit, and this the elder tree.-- Look, sirs, if you can find the huntsman out That should have murdered Bassianus here.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 103)
My gracious lord, here is the bag of gold.   Two of thy whelps, fell curs of bloody kind, Have here bereft my brother of his life.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 104)
-- Sirs, drag them from the pit unto the prison. There let them bide until we have devised Some never-heard-of torturing pain for them.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 105)
What, are they in this pit? wondrous thing! How easily murder is discovered.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 106)
High Emperor, upon my feeble knee beg this boon with tears not lightly shed, That this fell fault of my accursed sons-- Accursed if the faults be proved in them--   If it be proved!(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 107)
You see it is apparent. Who found this letter? Tamora, was it you?(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 108)
Andronicus himself did take it up.   did, my lord, yet let me be their bail, For by my father's reverend tomb vow They shall be ready at your Highness' will To answer their suspicion with their lives.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 109)
Thou shalt not bail them. See thou follow me.-- Some bring the murdered body, some the murderers.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 110)
Let them not speak a word. The guilt is plain. For, by my soul, were there worse end than death, That end upon them should be executed.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 111)
Andronicus, will entreat the King. Fear not thy sons; they shall do well enough.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 112)
Come, Lucius, come. Stay not to talk with them.(Titus Andronicus, Act 2, Scene 113)
with Lavinia, her hands cut off, and her tongue cut out,     So, now go tell, an if thy tongue can speak, Who 'twas that cut thy tongue and ravished thee.(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 0)
Write down thy mind; bewray thy meaning so, An if thy stumps will let thee play the scribe.(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 1)
See how with signs and tokens she can scrowl.   Go home.(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 2)
Call for sweet water; wash thy hands.   She hath no tongue to call, nor hands to wash; And so let's leave her to her silent walks.(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 3)
An 'twere my cause, should go hang myself.   If thou hadst hands to help thee knit the cord.(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 4)
Who is this? My niece, that flies away so fast?(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 5)
-- Cousin, a word. Where is your husband? If do dream, would all my wealth would wake me.(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 6)
If do wake, some planet strike me down That may slumber an eternal sleep.(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 7)
Speak, gentle niece. What stern ungentle hands Hath lopped and hewed and made thy body bare Of her two branches, those sweet ornaments Whose circling shadows kings have sought to sleep in, And might not gain so great a happiness As half thy love?(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 8)
Why dost not speak to me? Alas, a crimson river of warm blood, Like to a bubbling fountain stirred with wind, Doth rise and fall between thy rosed lips, Coming and going with thy honey breath.(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 9)
But sure some Tereus hath deflowered thee, And lest thou shouldst detect him cut thy tongue.(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 10)
Ah, now thou turn'st away thy face for shame, And notwithstanding all this loss of blood, As from a conduit with three issuing spouts, Yet do thy cheeks look red as Titan's face, Blushing to be encountered with a cloud.(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 11)
Shall speak for thee, shall say 'tis so? that knew thy heart, and knew the beast, That might rail at him to ease my mind.(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 12)
Sorrow concealed, like an oven stopped, Doth burn the heart to cinders where it is.(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 13)
Fair Philomela, why she but lost her tongue, And in a tedious sampler sewed her mind; But, lovely niece, that mean is cut from thee.(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 14)
craftier Tereus, cousin, hast thou met, And he hath cut those pretty fingers off That could have better sewed than Philomel.(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 15)
had the monster seen those lily hands Tremble like aspen leaves upon a lute And make the silken strings delight to kiss them, He would not then have touched them for his life.(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 16)
Or had he heard the heavenly harmony Which that sweet tongue hath made, He would have dropped his knife and fell asleep, As Cerberus at the Thracian poet's feet.(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 17)
Come, let us go and make thy father blind, For such a sight will blind a father's eye.(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 18)
One hour's storm will drown the fragrant meads; What will whole months of tears thy father's eyes?(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 19)
Do not draw back, for we will mourn with thee. could our mourning ease thy misery!(Titus Andronicus, Act 3, Scene 20)
(Quintus and Martius) bound, passing on the stage to     Hear me, grave fathers; noble tribunes, stay.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 0)
For pity of mine age, whose youth was spent In dangerous wars whilst you securely slept; For all my blood in Rome's great quarrel shed, For all the frosty nights that have watched, And for these bitter tears which now you see, Filling the aged wrinkles in my cheeks, Be pitiful to my condemned sons, Whose souls is not corrupted as 'tis thought.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 1)
For two-and-twenty sons never wept Because they died in honor's lofty bed.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 2)
For these, tribunes, in the dust write My heart's deep languor and my soul's sad tears.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 3)
Let my tears stanch the earth's dry appetite. My sons' sweet blood will make it shame and blush.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 4)
Earth, will befriend thee more with rain That shall distil from these two ancient ruins Than youthful April shall with all his showers.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 5)
In summer's drought I'll drop upon thee still; In winter with warm tears I'll melt the snow And keep eternal springtime on thy face, So thou refuse to drink my dear sons' blood.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 6)
reverend tribunes, gentle aged men, Unbind my sons, reverse the doom of death, And let me say, that never wept before, My tears are now prevailing orators.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 7)
noble father, you lament in vain. The Tribunes hear you not; no man is by, And you recount your sorrows to a stone.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 8)
Ah, Lucius, for thy brothers let me plead.-- Grave tribunes, once more entreat of you--   My gracious lord, no tribune hears you speak.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 9)
Why, 'tis no matter, man. If they did hear, They would not mark me; if they did mark, They would not pity me.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 10)
Yet plead must, And bootless unto them. Therefore tell my sorrows to the stones, Who, though they cannot answer my distress, Yet in some sort they are better than the Tribunes, For that they will not intercept my tale.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 11)
When do weep, they humbly at my feet Receive my tears and seem to weep with me, And were they but attired in grave weeds, Rome could afford no tribunes like to these.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 12)
stone is soft as wax, tribunes more hard than stones; stone is silent and offendeth not, And tribunes with their tongues doom men to death.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 13)
But wherefore stand'st thou with thy weapon drawn?(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 14)
To rescue my two brothers from their death, For which attempt the Judges have pronounced My everlasting doom of banishment.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 15)
happy man, they have befriended thee! Why, foolish Lucius, dost thou not perceive That Rome is but a wilderness of tigers?(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 16)
Tigers must prey, and Rome affords no prey But me and mine.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 17)
How happy art thou then From these devourers to be banished.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 18)
But who comes with our brother Marcus here?      Titus, prepare thy aged eyes to weep, Or, if not so, thy noble heart to break.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 19)
bring consuming sorrow to thine age.   Will it consume me?(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 20)
Let me see it, then.   This was thy daughter.  Why, Marcus, so she is.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 21)
Ay me, this object kills me!   Faint-hearted boy, arise and look upon her.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 22)
-- Speak, Lavinia. What accursed hand Hath made thee handless in thy father's sight?(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 23)
What fool hath added water to the sea Or brought a faggot to bright-burning Troy?(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 24)
My grief was at the height before thou cam'st, And now like Nilus it disdaineth bounds.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 25)
-- Give me a sword. I'll chop off my hands too, For they have fought for Rome and all in vain; And they have nursed this woe in feeding life; In bootless prayer have they been held up, And they have served me to effectless use.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 26)
Now all the service require of them Is that the one will help to cut the other.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 27)
-- 'Tis well, Lavinia, that thou hast no hands, For hands to do Rome service is but vain.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 28)
Speak, gentle sister. Who hath martyred thee?   that delightful engine of her thoughts, That blabbed them with such pleasing eloquence, Is torn from forth that pretty hollow cage Where, like a sweet melodious bird, it sung Sweet varied notes, enchanting every ear.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 29)
say thou for her who hath done this deed!   thus found her straying in the park, Seeking to hide herself as doth the deer That hath received some unrecuring wound.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 30)
It was my dear, and he that wounded her Hath hurt me more than had he killed me dead.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 31)
For now stand as one upon a rock, Environed with a wilderness of sea, Who marks the waxing tide grow wave by wave, Expecting ever when some envious surge Will in his brinish bowels swallow him.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 32)
This way to death my wretched sons are gone; Here stands my other son a banished man, And here my brother, weeping at my woes.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 33)
But that which gives my soul the greatest spurn Is dear Lavinia, dearer than my soul.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 34)
Had but seen thy picture in this plight It would have madded me.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 35)
What shall do, Now behold thy lively body so? Thou hast no hands to wipe away thy tears, Nor tongue to tell me who hath martyred thee.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 36)
Thy husband he is dead, and for his death Thy brothers are condemned, and dead by this.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 37)
-- Look, Marcus!--Ah, son Lucius, look on her! When did name her brothers, then fresh tears Stood on her cheeks as doth the honeydew Upon a gathered lily almost withered.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 38)
Perchance she weeps because they killed her husband, Perchance because she knows them innocent.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 39)
If they did kill thy husband, then be joyful, Because the law hath ta'en revenge on them.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 40)
-- No, no, they would not do so foul a deed. Witness the sorrow that their sister makes.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 41)
-- Gentle Lavinia, let me kiss thy lips, Or make some sign how may do thee ease.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 42)
Shall thy good uncle and thy brother Lucius And thou and sit round about some fountain, Looking all downwards to behold our cheeks, How they are stained like meadows yet not dry With miry slime left on them by a flood?(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 43)
And in the fountain shall we gaze so long Till the fresh taste be taken from that clearness And made a brine pit with our bitter tears?(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 44)
Or shall we cut away our hands like thine? Or shall we bite our tongues and in dumb shows Pass the remainder of our hateful days?(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 45)
What shall we do? Let us that have our tongues Plot some device of further misery To make us wondered at in time to come.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 46)
Sweet father, cease your tears, for at your grief See how my wretched sister sobs and weeps.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 47)
Patience, dear niece.--Good Titus, dry thine eyes.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 48)
Ah, Marcus, Marcus! Brother, well wot Thy napkin cannot drink a tear of mine, For thou, poor man, hast drowned it with thine own.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 49)
Ah, my Lavinia, will wipe thy cheeks.   Mark, Marcus, mark.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 50)
understand her signs. Had she a tongue to speak, now would she say That to her brother which said to thee.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 51)
His napkin, with his true tears all bewet, Can do no service on her sorrowful cheeks.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 52)
what a sympathy of woe is this, As far from help as limbo is from bliss.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 53)
Titus Andronicus, my lord the Emperor Sends thee this word, that if thou love thy sons, Let Marcus, Lucius, or thyself, old Titus, Or any one of you, chop off your hand And send it to the King; he for the same Will send thee hither both thy sons alive, And that shall be the ransom for their fault.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 54)
gracious emperor! gentle Aaron! Did ever raven sing so like a lark, That gives sweet tidings of the sun's uprise?(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 55)
With all my heart I'll send the Emperor my hand. Good Aaron, wilt thou help to chop it off?(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 56)
Stay, father, for that noble hand of thine, That hath thrown down so many enemies, Shall not be sent.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 57)
My hand will serve the turn. My youth can better spare my blood than you, And therefore mine shall save my brothers' lives.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 58)
Which of your hands hath not defended Rome And reared aloft the bloody battleax, Writing destruction on the enemy's castle?(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 59)
none of both but are of high desert. My hand hath been but idle; let it serve To ransom my two nephews from their death.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 60)
Then have kept it to a worthy end.   Nay, come, agree whose hand shall go along, For fear they die before their pardon come.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 61)
My hand shall go.  By heaven, it shall not go!   Sirs, strive no more.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 62)
Such withered herbs as these Are meet for plucking up, and therefore mine.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 63)
Sweet father, if shall be thought thy son, Let me redeem my brothers both from death.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 64)
And for our father's sake and mother's care, Now let me show a brother's love to thee.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 65)
Agree between you. will spare my hand.  Then I'll go fetch an ax.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 66)
But will use the ax.   Come hither, Aaron. I'll deceive them both.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 67)
Lend me thy hand, and will give thee mine.   If that be called deceit, will be honest And never whilst live deceive men so.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 68)
But I'll deceive you in another sort, And that you'll say ere half an hour pass.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 69)
Now stay your strife. What shall be is dispatched.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 70)
-- Good Aaron, give his Majesty my hand. Tell him it was a hand that warded him From thousand dangers.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 71)
Bid him bury it. More hath it merited; that let it have.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 72)
As for my sons, say account of them As jewels purchased at an easy price, And yet dear, too, because bought mine own.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 73)
go, Andronicus, and for thy hand Look by and by to have thy sons with thee.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 74)
Their heads, mean. how this villainy Doth fat me with the very thoughts of it!(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 75)
Let fools do good and fair men call for grace; Aaron will have his soul black like his face.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 76)
here lift this one hand up to heaven, And bow this feeble ruin to the earth.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 77)
If any power pities wretched tears, To that call.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 78)
What, wouldst thou kneel with me? Do, then, dear heart, for heaven shall hear our prayers, Or with our sighs we'll breathe the welkin dim And stain the sun with fog, as sometime clouds When they do hug him in their melting bosoms.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 79)
brother, speak with possibility, And do not break into these deep extremes.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 80)
Is not my sorrow deep, having no bottom? Then be my passions bottomless with them.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 81)
But yet let reason govern thy lament.   If there were reason for these miseries, Then into limits could bind my woes.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 82)
When heaven doth weep, doth not the Earth o'erflow?(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 83)
If the winds rage, doth not the sea wax mad, Threat'ning the welkin with his big-swoll'n face?(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 84)
And wilt thou have a reason for this coil? am the sea.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 85)
Hark how her sighs doth flow! She is the weeping welkin, the Earth.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 86)
Then must my sea be moved with her sighs; Then must my Earth with her continual tears Become a deluge, overflowed and drowned, Forwhy my bowels cannot hide her woes But like a drunkard must vomit them.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 87)
Then give me leave, for losers will have leave To ease their stomachs with their bitter tongues.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 88)
Worthy Andronicus, ill art thou repaid For that good hand thou sent'st the Emperor.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 89)
Here are the heads of thy two noble sons, And here's thy hand in scorn to thee sent back.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 90)
Thy grief their sports, thy resolution mocked, That woe is me to think upon thy woes More than remembrance of my father's death.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 91)
Now let hot Etna cool in Sicily, And be my heart an everburning hell!(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 92)
These miseries are more than may be borne. To weep with them that weep doth ease some deal, But sorrow flouted at is double death.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 93)
Ah, that this sight should make so deep a wound And yet detested life not shrink thereat!(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 94)
That ever death should let life bear his name, Where life hath no more interest but to breathe.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 95)
Alas, poor heart, that kiss is comfortless As frozen water to a starved snake.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 96)
When will this fearful slumber have an end?   Now farewell, flatt'ry; die, Andronicus.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 97)
Thou dost not slumber. See thy two sons' heads, Thy warlike hand, thy mangled daughter here, Thy other banished son with this dear sight Struck pale and bloodless; and thy brother, Even like a stony image cold and numb.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 98)
Ah, now no more will control thy griefs. Rent off thy silver hair, thy other hand, Gnawing with thy teeth, and be this dismal sight The closing up of our most wretched eyes.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 99)
Now is a time to storm. Why art thou still?  Ha, ha, ha!(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 100)
Why dost thou laugh? It fits not with this hour.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 101)
Why, have not another tear to shed. Besides, this sorrow is an enemy And would usurp upon my wat'ry eyes And make them blind with tributary tears.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 102)
Then which way shall find Revenge's cave? For these two heads do seem to speak to me And threat me shall never come to bliss Till all these mischiefs be returned again Even in their throats that hath committed them.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 103)
Come, let me see what task have to do. You heavy people, circle me about That may turn me to each one of you And swear unto my soul to right your wrongs.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 104)
The vow is made. Come, brother, take a head, And in this hand the other will bear.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 105)
-- And, Lavinia, thou shalt be employed in these arms.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 106)
Bear thou my hand, sweet wench, between thy teeth.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 107)
-- As for thee, boy, go get thee from my sight. Thou art an exile, and thou must not stay.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 108)
Hie to the Goths and raise an army there. And if you love me, as think you do, Let's kiss and part, for we have much to do.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 109)
Farewell, Andronicus, my noble father, The woefull'st man that ever lived in Rome.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 110)
Farewell, proud Rome, till Lucius come again. He loves his pledges dearer than his life.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 111)
Farewell, Lavinia, my noble sister. would thou wert as thou tofore hast been!(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 112)
But now nor Lucius nor Lavinia lives But in oblivion and hateful griefs.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 113)
If Lucius live he will requite your wrongs And make proud Saturnine and his empress Beg at the gates like Tarquin and his queen.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 114)
Now will to the Goths and raise a power To be revenged on Rome and Saturnine.(Titus Andronicus, Act 14, Scene 115)
banquet. Enter Titus Andronicus, Marcus, Lavinia,     So, so.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 0)
Now sit, and look you eat no more Than will preserve just so much strength in us As will revenge these bitter woes of ours.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 1)
Marcus, unknit that sorrow-wreathen knot. Thy niece and poor creatures, want our hands And cannot passionate our tenfold grief With folded arms.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 2)
This poor right hand of mine Is left to tyrannize upon my breast, Who, when my heart, all mad with misery, Beats in this hollow prison of my flesh, Then thus thump it down.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 3)
