-- Thou map of woe, that thus dost talk in signs, When thy poor heart beats with outrageous beating, Thou canst not strike it thus to make it still.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 4)
Wound it with sighing, girl, kill it with groans; Or get some little knife between thy teeth And just against thy heart make thou a hole, That all the tears that thy poor eyes let fall May run into that sink and, soaking in, Drown the lamenting fool in sea-salt tears.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 5)
Fie, brother, fie! Teach her not thus to lay Such violent hands upon her tender life.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 6)
How now! Has sorrow made thee dote already? Why, Marcus, no man should be mad but What violent hands can she lay on her life?(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 7)
Ah, wherefore dost thou urge the name of hands, To bid Aeneas tell the tale twice o'er How Troy was burnt and he made miserable?(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 8)
handle not the theme, to talk of hands, Lest we remember still that we have none.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 9)
-- Fie, fie, how franticly square my talk, As if we should forget we had no hands If Marcus did not name the word of hands!(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 10)
Come, let's fall to, and, gentle girl, eat this. Here is no drink!(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 11)
--Hark, Marcus, what she says. can interpret all her martyred signs.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 12)
She says she drinks no other drink but tears Brewed with her sorrow, mashed upon her cheeks.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 13)
-- Speechless complainer, will learn thy thought. In thy dumb action will be as perfect As begging hermits in their holy prayers.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 14)
Thou shalt not sigh, nor hold thy stumps to heaven, Nor wink, nor nod, nor kneel, nor make a sign, But of these will wrest an alphabet And by still practice learn to know thy meaning.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 15)
Good grandsire, leave these bitter deep laments.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 16)
Make my aunt merry with some pleasing tale.   Alas, the tender boy, in passion moved, Doth weep to see his grandsire's heaviness.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 17)
Peace, tender sapling. Thou art made of tears, And tears will quickly melt thy life away.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 18)
What dost thou strike at, Marcus, with thy knife?(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 19)
At that that have killed, my lord, a fly.   Out on thee, murderer!(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 20)
Thou kill'st my heart. Mine eyes are cloyed with view of tyranny; deed of death done on the innocent Becomes not Titus' brother.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 21)
Get thee gone. see thou art not for my company.   Alas, my lord, have but killed a fly.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 22)
"But"? How if that fly had a father and mother?(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 23)
How would he hang his slender gilded wings And buzz lamenting doings in the air!(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 24)
Poor harmless fly, That, with his pretty buzzing melody, Came here to make us merry!(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 25)
And thou hast killed him.   Pardon me, sir. It was a black, ill-favored fly, Like to the Empress' Moor.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 26)
Therefore killed him.   Then pardon me for reprehending thee, For thou hast done a charitable deed.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 27)
Give me thy knife. will insult on him, Flattering myself as if it were the Moor Come hither purposely to poison me.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 28)
There's for thyself, and that's for Tamora. Ah, sirrah!(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 29)
Yet think we are not brought so low But that between us we can kill a fly That comes in likeness of a coal-black Moor.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 30)
Alas, poor man, grief has so wrought on him He takes false shadows for true substances.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 31)
Come, take away.--Lavinia, go with me. I'll to thy closet and go read with thee Sad stories chanced in the times of old.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 32)
-- Come, boy, and go with me. Thy sight is young, And thou shalt read when mine begin to dazzle.(Titus Andronicus, Act 15, Scene 33)
Beseech you, sir, be merry. You have cause-- So have we all--of joy, for our escape Is much beyond our loss.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 0)
Our hint of woe Is common; every day some sailor's wife, The masters of some merchant, and the merchant Have just our theme of woe.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 1)
But for the miracle-- mean our preservation--few in millions Can speak like us.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 2)
Then wisely, good sir, weigh Our sorrow with our comfort.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 3)
Prithee, peace.  He receives comfort like cold porridge.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 4)
The visitor will not give him o'er so.  Look, he's winding up the watch of his wit.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 5)
By and by it will strike.  Sir--  One. Tell.  When every grief is entertained that's offered, comes to th' entertainer--  dollar.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 6)
Dolor comes to him indeed. You have spoken truer than you purposed.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 7)
You have taken it wiselier than meant you should.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 8)
Therefore, my lord--  Fie, what a spendthrift is he of his tongue.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 9)
prithee, spare.  Well, have done. But yet--  He will be talking.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 10)
Which, of he or Adrian, for a good wager, first begins to crow?(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 11)
The old cock.  The cockerel.  Done. The wager?  laughter.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 12)
match!  Though this island seem to be desert--  Ha, ha, ha.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 13)
So. You're paid.  Uninhabitable and almost inaccessible--  Yet--  Yet--  He could not miss 't.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 14)
It must needs be of subtle, tender, and delicate temperance.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 15)
Temperance was a delicate wench.  Ay, and a subtle, as he most learnedly delivered.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 16)
The air breathes upon us here most sweetly.  As if it had lungs, and rotten ones.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 17)
Or as 'twere perfumed by a fen.  Here is everything advantageous to life.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 18)
True, save means to live.  Of that there's none, or little.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 19)
How lush and lusty the grass looks! How green!  The ground indeed is tawny.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 20)
With an eye of green in 't.  He misses not much.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 21)
No, he doth but mistake the truth totally.  But the rarity of it is, which is indeed almost beyond credit--  As many vouched rarities are.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 22)
That our garments, being, as they were, drenched in the sea, hold notwithstanding their freshness and gloss, being rather new-dyed than stained with salt water.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 23)
If but one of his pockets could speak, would it not say he lies?(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 24)
Ay, or very falsely pocket up his report.  Methinks our garments are now as fresh as when we put them on first in Afric, at the marriage of the King's fair daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 25)
'Twas a sweet marriage, and we prosper well in our return.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 26)
Tunis was never graced before with such a paragon to their queen.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 27)
Not since widow Dido's time.  Widow? pox o' that!(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 28)
How came that "widow" in? Widow Dido!  What if he had said "widower Aeneas" too?(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 29)
Good Lord, how you take it!  "Widow Dido," said you?(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 30)
You make me study of that. She was of Carthage, not of Tunis.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 31)
This Tunis, sir, was Carthage.  Carthage?  assure you, Carthage.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 32)
His word is more than the miraculous harp.  He hath raised the wall, and houses too.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 33)
What impossible matter will he make easy next?  think he will carry this island home in his pocket and give it his son for an apple.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 34)
And sowing the kernels of it in the sea, bring forth more islands.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 35)
Ay.  Why, in good time.  Sir, we were talking that our garments seem now as fresh as when we were at Tunis at the marriage of your daughter, who is now queen.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 36)
And the rarest that e'er came there.  Bate, beseech you, widow Dido.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 37)
widow Dido? Ay, widow Dido.  Is not, sir, my doublet as fresh as the first day wore it?(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 38)
mean, in a sort.  That "sort" was well fished for.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 39)
When wore it at your daughter's marriage.   You cram these words into mine ears against The stomach of my sense.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 40)
Would had never Married my daughter there, for coming thence My son is lost, and, in my rate, she too, Who is so far from Italy removed ne'er again shall see her.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 41)
--O, thou mine heir Of Naples and of Milan, what strange fish Hath made his meal on thee?(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 42)
Sir, he may live. saw him beat the surges under him And ride upon their backs.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 43)
He trod the water, Whose enmity he flung aside, and breasted The surge most swoll'n that met him.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 44)
His bold head 'Bove the contentious waves he kept, and oared Himself with his good arms in lusty stroke To th' shore, that o'er his wave-worn basis bowed, As stooping to relieve him.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 45)
not doubt He came alive to land.  No, no, he's gone.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 46)
Sir, you may thank yourself for this great loss, That would not bless our Europe with your daughter, But rather lose her to an African, Where she at least is banished from your eye, Who hath cause to wet the grief on 't.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 47)
Prithee, peace.   You were kneeled to and importuned otherwise By all of us; and the fair soul herself Weighed between loathness and obedience at Which end o' th' beam should bow.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 48)
We have lost your son, fear, forever. Milan and Naples have More widows in them of this business' making Than we bring men to comfort them.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 49)
The fault's your own.  So is the dear'st o' th' loss.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 50)
My lord Sebastian, The truth you speak doth lack some gentleness And time to speak it in.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 51)
You rub the sore When you should bring the plaster.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 52)
Very well.  And most chirurgeonly.   It is foul weather in us all, good sir, When you are cloudy.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 53)
Foul weather?  Very foul.   Had plantation of this isle, my lord--   He'd sow 't with nettle seed.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 54)
Or docks, or mallows.   And were the king on 't, what would do?(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 55)
Scape being drunk, for want of wine.   th' commonwealth would by contraries Execute all things, for no kind of traffic Would admit; no name of magistrate; Letters should not be known; riches, poverty, And use of service, none; contract, succession, Bourn, bound of land, tilth, vineyard, none; No use of metal, corn, or wine, or oil; No occupation; all men idle, all, And women too, but innocent and pure; No sovereignty--  Yet he would be king on 't.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 56)
The latter end of his commonwealth forgets the beginning.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 57)
All things in common nature should produce Without sweat or endeavor; treason, felony, Sword, pike, knife, gun, or need of any engine Would not have; but nature should bring forth Of its own kind all foison, all abundance, To feed my innocent people.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 58)
No marrying 'mong his subjects?  None, man, all idle: whores and knaves.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 59)
would with such perfection govern, sir, excel the Golden Age.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 60)
'Save his Majesty!   Long live Gonzalo!  And do you mark me, sir?(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 61)
Prithee, no more. Thou dost talk nothing to me.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 62)
do well believe your Highness, and did it to minister occasion to these gentlemen, who are of such sensible and nimble lungs that they always use to laugh at nothing.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 63)
'Twas you we laughed at.  Who in this kind of merry fooling am nothing to you.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 64)
So you may continue, and laugh at nothing still.  What a blow was there given!(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 65)
An it had not fallen flatlong.  You are gentlemen of brave mettle.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 66)
You would lift the moon out of her sphere if she would continue in it five weeks without changing.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 67)
We would so, and then go a-batfowling.  Nay, good my lord, be not angry.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 68)
No, warrant you, will not adventure my discretion so weakly.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 69)
Will you laugh me asleep? For am very heavy.  Go sleep, and hear us.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 70)
What, all so soon asleep? wish mine eyes Would, with themselves, shut up my thoughts.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 71)
find They are inclined to do so.  Please you, sir, Do not omit the heavy offer of it.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 72)
It seldom visits sorrow; when it doth, It is a comforter.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 73)
We two, my lord, Will guard your person while you take your rest, And watch your safety.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 74)
Thank you. Wondrous heavy.    What a strange drowsiness possesses them!(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 75)
It is the quality o' th' climate.  Why Doth it not then our eyelids sink?(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 76)
find Not myself disposed to sleep.  Nor My spirits are nimble.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 77)
They fell together all, as by consent. They dropped as by a thunderstroke.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 78)
What might, Worthy Sebastian, what might--? No more.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 79)
And yet methinks see it in thy face What thou shouldst be.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 80)
Th' occasion speaks thee, and My strong imagination sees a crown Dropping upon thy head.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 81)
What, art thou waking?   Do you not hear me speak?(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 82)
do, and surely It is a sleepy language, and thou speak'st Out of thy sleep.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 83)
What is it thou didst say? This is a strange repose, to be asleep With eyes wide open--standing, speaking, moving-- And yet so fast asleep.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 84)
Noble Sebastian, Thou let'st thy fortune sleep, die rather, wink'st Whiles thou art waking.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 85)
Thou dost snore distinctly. There's meaning in thy snores.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 86)
am more serious than my custom. You Must be so too, if heed me; which to do Trebles thee o'er.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 87)
Well, am standing water.   I'll teach you how to flow.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 88)
Do so. To ebb Hereditary sloth instructs me.   If you but knew how you the purpose cherish Whiles thus you mock it, how in stripping it You more invest it.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 89)
Ebbing men indeed Most often do so near the bottom run By their own fear or sloth.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 90)
Prithee, say on. The setting of thine eye and cheek proclaim matter from thee, and a birth indeed Which throes thee much to yield.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 91)
Thus, sir: Although this lord of weak remembrance--this, Who shall be of as little memory When he is earthed--hath here almost persuaded-- For he's a spirit of persuasion, only Professes to persuade--the King his son's alive, 'Tis as impossible that he's undrowned As he that sleeps here swims.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 92)
have no hope That he's undrowned.  out of that no hope What great hope have you!(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 93)
No hope that way is Another way so high a hope that even Ambition cannot pierce a wink beyond, But doubt discovery there.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 94)
Will you grant with me That Ferdinand is drowned?(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 95)
He's gone.  Then tell me, Who's the next heir of Naples?(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 96)
Claribel.   She that is Queen of Tunis; she that dwells Ten leagues beyond man's life; she that from Naples Can have no note, unless the sun were post-- The man i' th' moon's too slow--till newborn chins Be rough and razorable; she that from whom We all were sea-swallowed, though some cast again, And by that destiny to perform an act Whereof what's past is prologue, what to come In yours and my discharge.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 97)
What stuff is this? How say you? 'Tis true my brother's daughter's Queen of Tunis, So is she heir of Naples, 'twixt which regions There is some space.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 98)
space whose ev'ry cubit Seems to cry out "How shall that Claribel Measure us back to Naples?(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 99)
Keep in Tunis And let Sebastian wake." Say this were death That now hath seized them, why, they were no worse Than now they are.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 100)
There be that can rule Naples As well as he that sleeps, lords that can prate As amply and unnecessarily As this Gonzalo.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 101)
myself could make chough of as deep chat. that you bore The mind that do, what a sleep were this For your advancement!(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 102)
Do you understand me?   Methinks do.  And how does your content Tender your own good fortune?(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 103)
remember You did supplant your brother Prospero.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 104)
True, And look how well my garments sit upon me, Much feater than before.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 105)
My brother's servants Were then my fellows; now they are my men.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 106)
But, for your conscience?   Ay, sir, where lies that?(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 107)
If 'twere a kibe, 'Twould put me to my slipper, but feel not This deity in my bosom.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 108)
Twenty consciences That stand 'twixt me and Milan, candied be they And melt ere they molest!(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 109)
Here lies your brother, No better than the earth he lies upon.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 110)
If he were that which now he's like--that's dead-- Whom with this obedient steel, three inches of it, Can lay to bed forever; whiles you, doing thus, To the perpetual wink for aye might put This ancient morsel, this Sir Prudence, who Should not upbraid our course.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 111)
For all the rest, They'll take suggestion as a cat laps milk.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 112)
They'll tell the clock to any business that We say befits the hour.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 113)
Thy case, dear friend, Shall be my precedent: as thou got'st Milan, I'll come by Naples.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 114)
Draw thy sword. One stroke Shall free thee from the tribute which thou payest, And the King shall love thee.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 115)
Draw together, And when rear my hand, do you the like To fall it on Gonzalo.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 116)
but one word.       My master through his art foresees the danger That you, his friend, are in, and sends me forth-- For else his project dies--to keep them living.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 117)
While you here do snoring lie, Open-eyed conspiracy His time doth take.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 118)
If of life you keep a care, Shake off slumber and beware.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 119)
Awake, awake!  Then let us both be sudden.  Now, good angels preserve the King!(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 120)
Why, how now, ho! Awake? Why are you drawn? Wherefore this ghastly looking?(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 121)
What's the matter?   Whiles we stood here securing your repose, Even now, we heard a hollow burst of bellowing Like bulls, or rather lions.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 122)
Did 't not wake you? It struck mine ear most terribly.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 123)
heard nothing.   'twas a din to fright a monster's ear, To make an earthquake.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 124)
Sure, it was the roar Of a whole herd of lions.  Heard you this, Gonzalo?(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 125)
Upon mine honor, sir, heard a humming, And that a strange one too, which did awake me.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 126)
shaked you, sir, and cried. As mine eyes opened, saw their weapons drawn.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 127)
There was a noise, That's verily. 'Tis best we stand upon our guard, Or that we quit this place.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 128)
Let's draw our weapons.   Lead off this ground, and let's make further search For my poor son.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 129)
Heavens keep him from these beasts, For he is, sure, i' th' island.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 130)
Lead away.   Prospero my lord shall know what have done.(The Tempest, Act 0, Scene 131)
2         All the infections that the sun sucks up From bogs, fens, flats, on Prosper fall and make him By inchmeal a disease!(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 0)
His spirits hear me, And yet needs must curse. But they'll nor pinch, Fright me with urchin-shows, pitch me i' th' mire, Nor lead me like a firebrand in the dark Out of my way, unless he bid 'em.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 1)
But For every trifle are they set upon me, Sometimes like apes, that mow and chatter at me And after bite me; then like hedgehogs, which Lie tumbling in my barefoot way and mount Their pricks at my footfall.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 2)
Sometime am All wound with adders, who with cloven tongues Do hiss me into madness.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 3)
Lo, now, lo! Here comes a spirit of his, and to torment me For bringing wood in slowly.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 4)
I'll fall flat. Perchance he will not mind me.      Here's neither bush nor shrub to bear off any weather at all.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 5)
And another storm brewing; hear it sing i' th' wind.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 6)
Yond same black cloud, yond huge one, looks like a foul bombard that would shed his liquor.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 7)
If it should thunder as it did before, know not where to hide my head.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 8)
Yond same cloud cannot choose but fall by pailfuls.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 9)
What have we here, a man or a fish? Dead or alive?(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 10)
fish, he smells like a fish--a very ancient and fishlike smell, a kind of not-of-the-newest poor-John.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 11)
strange fish. Were in England now, as once was, and had but this fish painted, not a holiday fool there but would give a piece of silver.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 12)
There would this monster make a man. Any strange beast there makes a man.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 13)
When they will not give a doit to relieve a lame beggar, they will lay out ten to see a dead Indian.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 14)
Legged like a man, and his fins like arms! Warm, o' my troth!(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 15)
do now let loose my opinion, hold it no longer: this is no fish, but an islander that hath lately suffered by a thunderbolt.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 16)
Alas, the storm is come again. My best way is to creep under his gaberdine.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 17)
There is no other shelter hereabout. Misery acquaints a man with strange bedfellows.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 18)
will here shroud till the dregs of the storm be past.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 19)
shall no more to sea, to sea. Here shall die ashore-- This is a very scurvy tune to sing at a man's funeral.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 20)
Well, here's my comfort.   The master, the swabber, the boatswain, and The gunner and his mate, Loved Mall, Meg, and Marian, and Margery, But none of us cared for Kate.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 21)
For she had a tongue with a tang, Would cry to a sailor "Go hang!(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 22)
" She loved not the savor of tar nor of pitch, Yet a tailor might scratch her where'er she did itch.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 23)
Then to sea, boys, and let her go hang! This is a scurvy tune too.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 24)
But here's my comfort.   Do not torment me!  What's the matter?(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 25)
Have we devils here? Do you put tricks upon 's with savages and men of Ind?(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 26)
Ha? have not scaped drowning to be afeard now of your four legs, for it hath been said "As proper a man as ever went on four legs cannot make him give ground," and it shall be said so again while Stephano breathes at' nostrils.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 27)
The spirit torments me.  This is some monster of the isle with four legs, who hath got, as take it, an ague.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 28)
Where the devil should he learn our language? will give him some relief, if it be but for that.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 29)
If can recover him and keep him tame and get to Naples with him, he's a present for any emperor that ever trod on neat's leather.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 30)
Do not torment me, prithee. I'll bring my wood home faster.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 31)
He's in his fit now, and does not talk after the wisest.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 32)
He shall taste of my bottle. If he have never drunk wine afore, it will go near to remove his fit.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 33)
If can recover him and keep him tame, will not take too much for him.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 34)
He shall pay for him that hath him, and that soundly.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 35)
Thou dost me yet but little hurt. Thou wilt anon; know it by thy trembling.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 36)
Now Prosper works upon thee.  Come on your ways. Open your mouth.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 37)
Here is that which will give language to you, cat.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 38)
Open your mouth. This will shake your shaking, can tell you, and that soundly.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 39)
You cannot tell who's your friend. Open your chaps again.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 40)
should know that voice. It should be--but he is drowned, and these are devils.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 41)
defend me!  Four legs and two voices--a most delicate monster!(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 42)
His forward voice now is to speak well of his friend.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 43)
His backward voice is to utter foul speeches and to detract.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 44)
If all the wine in my bottle will recover him, will help his ague.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 45)
Come. Amen! will pour some in thy other mouth.  Stephano!(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 46)
Doth thy other mouth call me? Mercy, mercy, this is a devil, and no monster!(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 47)
will leave him; have no long spoon.  Stephano! If thou be'st Stephano, touch me and speak to me, for am Trinculo--be not afeard--thy good friend Trinculo.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 48)
If thou be'st Trinculo, come forth. I'll pull thee by the lesser legs.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 49)
If any be Trinculo's legs, these are they. Thou art very Trinculo indeed.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 50)
How cam'st thou to be the siege of this mooncalf?(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 51)
Can he vent Trinculos?  took him to be killed with a thunderstroke.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 52)
But art thou not drowned, Stephano? hope now thou art not drowned.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 53)
Is the storm overblown? hid me under the dead mooncalf's gaberdine for fear of the storm.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 54)
And art thou living, Stephano? Stephano, two Neapolitans scaped!(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 55)
Prithee, do not turn me about. My stomach is not constant.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 56)
These be fine things, an if they be not sprites.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 57)
That's a brave god and bears celestial liquor. will kneel to him.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 58)
How didst thou scape? How cam'st thou hither? Swear by this bottle how thou cam'st hither--I escaped upon a butt of sack, which the sailors heaved o'erboard--by this bottle, which made of the bark of a tree with mine own hands, since was cast ashore.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 59)
I'll swear upon that bottle to be thy true subject, for the liquor is not earthly.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 60)
Here. Swear then how thou escapedst.  Swum ashore, man, like a duck.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 61)
can swim like a duck, I'll be sworn.  Here, kiss the book.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 62)
Though thou canst swim like a duck, thou art made like a goose.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 63)
Stephano, hast any more of this?  The whole butt, man.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 64)
My cellar is in a rock by th' seaside, where my wine is hid.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 65)
--How now, mooncalf, how does thine ague?  Hast thou not dropped from heaven?(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 66)
Out o' th' moon, do assure thee. was the man i' th' moon when time was.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 67)
have seen thee in her, and do adore thee. My mistress showed me thee, and thy dog, and thy bush.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 68)
Come, swear to that. Kiss the book. will furnish it anon with new contents.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 69)
Swear.   By this good light, this is a very shallow monster.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 70)
afeard of him? very weak monster. The man i' th' moon?(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 71)
most poor, credulous monster! --Well drawn, monster, in good sooth!(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 72)
I'll show thee every fertile inch o' th' island, and will kiss thy foot.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 73)
prithee, be my god.  By this light, a most perfidious and drunken monster.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 74)
When 's god's asleep, he'll rob his bottle.  I'll kiss thy foot.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 75)
I'll swear myself thy subject.  Come on, then. Down, and swear.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 76)
shall laugh myself to death at this puppy-headed monster.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 77)
most scurvy monster. could find in my heart to beat him--  Come, kiss.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 78)
--but that the poor monster's in drink. An abominable monster.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 79)
I'll show thee the best springs. I'll pluck thee berries.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 80)
I'll fish for thee and get thee wood enough. plague upon the tyrant that serve.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 81)
I'll bear him no more sticks, but follow thee, Thou wondrous man.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 82)
most ridiculous monster, to make a wonder of a poor drunkard.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 83)
prithee, let me bring thee where crabs grow, And with my long nails will dig thee pignuts, Show thee a jay's nest, and instruct thee how To snare the nimble marmoset.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 84)
I'll bring thee To clustering filberts, and sometimes I'll get thee Young scamels from the rock.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 85)
Wilt thou go with me?  prithee now, lead the way without any more talking.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 86)
--Trinculo, the King and all our company else being drowned, we will inherit here.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 87)
--Here, bear my bottle.--Fellow Trinculo, we'll fill him by and by again.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 88)
Farewell, master, farewell, farewell.  howling monster, a drunken monster.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 89)
No more dams I'll make for fish, Nor fetch in firing At requiring, Nor scrape trenchering, nor wash dish.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 90)
'Ban, 'ban, Ca-caliban Has a new master. Get a new man.(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 91)
Freedom, high-day! High-day, freedom! Freedom, high-day, freedom!(The Tempest, Act 1, Scene 92)
There be some sports are painful, and their labor Delight in them sets off; some kinds of baseness Are nobly undergone; and most poor matters Point to rich ends.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 0)
This my mean task Would be as heavy to me as odious, but The mistress which serve quickens what's dead And makes my labors pleasures.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 1)
she is Ten times more gentle than her father's crabbed, And he's composed of harshness.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 2)
must remove Some thousands of these logs and pile them up, Upon a sore injunction.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 3)
My sweet mistress Weeps when she sees me work, and says such baseness Had never like executor.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 4)
forget; But these sweet thoughts do even refresh my labors, Most busiest when do it.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 5)
Alas now, pray you, Work not so hard. would the lightning had Burnt up those logs that you are enjoined to pile.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 6)
Pray, set it down and rest you. When this burns 'Twill weep for having wearied you.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 7)
My father Is hard at study. Pray now, rest yourself.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 8)
He's safe for these three hours.  most dear mistress, The sun will set before shall discharge What must strive to do.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 9)
If you'll sit down, I'll bear your logs the while.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 10)
Pray, give me that. I'll carry it to the pile.  No, precious creature, had rather crack my sinews, break my back, Than you should such dishonor undergo While sit lazy by.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 11)
It would become me As well as it does you, and should do it With much more ease, for my good will is to it, And yours it is against.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 12)
Poor worm, thou art infected. This visitation shows it.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 13)
You look wearily.  No, noble mistress, 'tis fresh morning with me When you are by at night.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 14)
do beseech you, Chiefly that might set it in my prayers, What is your name?(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 15)
Miranda.--O my father, have broke your hest to say so!(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 16)
Admired Miranda! Indeed the top of admiration, worth What's dearest to the world!(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 17)
Full many a lady have eyed with best regard, and many a time Th' harmony of their tongues hath into bondage Brought my too diligent ear.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 18)
For several virtues Have liked several women, never any With so full soul but some defect in her Did quarrel with the noblest grace she owed, And put it to the foil.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 19)
But you, you, So perfect and so peerless, are created Of every creature's best.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 20)
do not know One of my sex, no woman's face remember, Save, from my glass, mine own.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 21)
Nor have seen More that may call men than you, good friend, And my dear father.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 22)
How features are abroad am skilless of, but by my modesty, The jewel in my dower, would not wish Any companion in the world but you, Nor can imagination form a shape Besides yourself to like of.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 23)
But prattle Something too wildly, and my father's precepts therein do forget.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 24)
am in my condition prince, Miranda; do think a king-- would, not so!(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 25)
--and would no more endure This wooden slavery than to suffer The flesh-fly blow my mouth.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 26)
Hear my soul speak: The very instant that saw you did My heart fly to your service, there resides To make me slave to it, and for your sake Am this patient log-man.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 27)
Do you love me?   heaven, Earth, bear witness to this sound, And crown what profess with kind event If speak true; if hollowly, invert What best is boded me to mischief.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 28)
Beyond all limit of what else i' th' world, Do love, prize, honor you.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 29)
am a fool To weep at what am glad of.  Fair encounter Of two most rare affections.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 30)
Heavens rain grace On that which breeds between 'em!(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 31)
Wherefore weep you?   At mine unworthiness, that dare not offer What desire to give, and much less take What shall die to want.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 32)
But this is trifling, And all the more it seeks to hide itself, The bigger bulk it shows.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 33)
Hence, bashful cunning, And prompt me, plain and holy innocence.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 34)
am your wife if you will marry me. If not, I'll die your maid.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 35)
To be your fellow You may deny me, but I'll be your servant Whether you will or no.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 36)
My mistress, dearest, and thus humble ever.   My husband, then?(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 37)
Ay, with a heart as willing As bondage e'er of freedom.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 38)
Here's my hand.   And mine, with my heart in 't. And now farewell Till half an hour hence.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 39)
thousand thousand.    So glad of this as they cannot be, Who are surprised withal; but my rejoicing At nothing can be more.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 40)
I'll to my book, For yet ere suppertime must perform Much business appertaining.(The Tempest, Act 9, Scene 41)
3       Tell not me. When the butt is out, we will drink water; not a drop before.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 0)
Therefore bear up and board 'em.--Servant monster, drink to me.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 1)
Servant monster? The folly of this island! They say there's but five upon this isle; we are three of them.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 2)
If th' other two be brained like us, the state totters.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 3)
Drink, servant monster, when bid thee. Thy eyes are almost set in thy head.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 4)
Where should they be set else? He were a brave monster indeed if they were set in his tail.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 5)
My man-monster hath drowned his tongue in sack. For my part, the sea cannot drown me.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 6)
swam, ere could recover the shore, five-and-thirty leagues off and on, by this light.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 7)
--Thou shalt be my lieutenant, monster, or my standard.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 8)
Your lieutenant, if you list. He's no standard.  We'll not run, Monsieur Monster.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 9)
Nor go neither. But you'll lie like dogs, and yet say nothing neither.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 10)
Mooncalf, speak once in thy life, if thou be'st a good mooncalf.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 11)
How does thy Honor? Let me lick thy shoe. I'll not serve him; he is not valiant.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 12)
Thou liest, most ignorant monster. am in case to justle a constable.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 13)
Why, thou debauched fish, thou! Was there ever man a coward that hath drunk so much sack as today?(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 14)
Wilt thou tell a monstrous lie, being but half a fish and half a monster?(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 15)
Lo, how he mocks me! Wilt thou let him, my lord?(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 16)
"Lord," quoth he? That a monster should be such a natural!(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 17)
Lo, lo again! Bite him to death, prithee.  Trinculo, keep a good tongue in your head.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 18)
If you prove a mutineer, the next tree. The poor monster's my subject, and he shall not suffer indignity.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 19)
thank my noble lord. Wilt thou be pleased to harken once again to the suit made to thee?(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 20)
Marry, will Kneel and repeat it. will stand, and so shall Trinculo.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 21)
As told thee before, am subject to a tyrant, a sorcerer, that by his cunning hath cheated me of the island.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 22)
Thou liest.  Thou liest, thou jesting monkey, thou.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 23)
would my valiant master would destroy thee. do not lie.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 24)
Trinculo, if you trouble him any more in 's tale, by this hand, will supplant some of your teeth.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 25)
Why, said nothing.  Mum then, and no more. Proceed.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 26)
say by sorcery he got this isle; From me he got it.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 27)
If thy Greatness will, Revenge it on him, for know thou dar'st, But this thing dare not.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 28)
That's most certain.   Thou shalt be lord of it, and I'll serve thee.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 29)
How now shall this be compassed? Canst thou bring me to the party?(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 30)
Yea, yea, my lord. I'll yield him thee asleep, Where thou mayst knock a nail into his head.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 31)
Thou liest. Thou canst not.   What a pied ninny's this!(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 32)
--Thou scurvy patch!-- do beseech thy Greatness, give him blows And take his bottle from him.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 33)
When that's gone, He shall drink naught but brine, for I'll not show him Where the quick freshes are.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 34)
Trinculo, run into no further danger. Interrupt the monster one word further, and by this hand, I'll turn my mercy out o' doors and make a stockfish of thee.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 35)
Why, what did did nothing. I'll go farther off.  Didst thou not say he lied?(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 36)
Thou liest.  Do so? Take thou that. As you like this, give me the lie another time.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 37)
did not give the lie! Out o' your wits and hearing too?(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 38)
pox o' your bottle! This can sack and drinking do.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 39)
murrain on your monster, and the devil take your fingers!(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 40)
Ha, ha, ha!  Now forward with your tale. Prithee, stand further off.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 41)
Beat him enough. After a little time I'll beat him too.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 42)
Stand farther. Come, proceed.   Why, as told thee, 'tis a custom with him th' afternoon to sleep.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 43)
There thou mayst brain him, Having first seized his books, or with a log Batter his skull, or paunch him with a stake, Or cut his weasand with thy knife.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 44)
Remember First to possess his books, for without them He's but a sot, as am, nor hath not One spirit to command.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 45)
They all do hate him As rootedly as Burn but his books.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 46)
He has brave utensils--for so he calls them-- Which, when he has a house, he'll deck withal.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 47)
And that most deeply to consider is The beauty of his daughter.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 48)
He himself Calls her a nonpareil. never saw a woman But only Sycorax my dam and she; But she as far surpasseth Sycorax As great'st does least.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 49)
Is it so brave a lass?   Ay, lord, she will become thy bed, warrant, And bring thee forth brave brood.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 50)
Monster, will kill this man. His daughter and will be king and queen--save our Graces!(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 51)
-- and Trinculo and thyself shall be viceroys.--Dost thou like the plot, Trinculo?(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 52)
Excellent.  Give me thy hand. am sorry beat thee.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 53)
But while thou liv'st, keep a good tongue in thy head.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 54)
Within this half hour will he be asleep. Wilt thou destroy him then?(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 55)
Ay, on mine honor.  This will tell my master.   Thou mak'st me merry.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 56)
am full of pleasure. Let us be jocund. Will you troll the catch You taught me but whilere?(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 57)
At thy request, monster, will do reason, any reason.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 58)
--Come on, Trinculo, let us sing.  Flout 'em and cout 'em And scout 'em and flout 'em!(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 59)
Thought is free.  That's not the tune.   What is this same?(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 60)
This is the tune of our catch played by the picture of Nobody.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 61)
If thou be'st a man, show thyself in thy likeness.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 62)
If thou be'st a devil, take 't as thou list.  forgive me my sins!(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 63)
He that dies pays all debts.--I defy thee!-- Mercy upon us!(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 64)
Art thou afeard?  No, monster, not   Be not afeard.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 65)
The isle is full of noises, Sounds and sweet airs that give delight and hurt not.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 66)
Sometimes a thousand twangling instruments Will hum about mine ears, and sometimes voices That, if then had waked after long sleep, Will make me sleep again; and then, in dreaming, The clouds methought would open, and show riches Ready to drop upon me, that when waked cried to dream again.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 67)
This will prove a brave kingdom to me, where shall have my music for nothing.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 68)
When Prospero is destroyed.  That shall be by and by.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 69)
remember the story.  The sound is going away. Let's follow it, and after do our work.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 70)
Lead, monster. We'll follow.--I would could see this taborer.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 71)
He lays it on. Wilt come?  I'll follow, Stephano.(The Tempest, Act 10, Scene 72)
Will you stay no longer? Nor will you not that go with you?(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 0)
By your patience, no. My stars shine darkly over me.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 1)
The malignancy of my fate might perhaps distemper yours.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 2)
Therefore shall crave of you your leave that may bear my evils alone.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 3)
It were a bad recompense for your love to lay any of them on you.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 4)
Let me yet know of you whither you are bound.  No, sooth, sir.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 5)
My determinate voyage is mere extravagancy. But perceive in you so excellent a touch of modesty that you will not extort from me what am willing to keep in.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 6)
Therefore it charges me in manners the rather to express myself.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 7)
You must know of me, then, Antonio, my name is Sebastian, which called Roderigo.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 8)
My father was that Sebastian of Messaline whom know you have heard of.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 9)
He left behind him myself and a sister, both born in an hour.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 10)
If the heavens had been pleased, would we had so ended!(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 11)
But you, sir, altered that, for some hour before you took me from the breach of the sea was my sister drowned.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 12)
Alas the day!  lady, sir, though it was said she much resembled me, was yet of many accounted beautiful.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 13)
But though could not with such estimable wonder overfar believe that, yet thus far will boldly publish her: she bore a mind that envy could not but call fair.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 14)
She is drowned already, sir, with salt water, though seem to drown her remembrance again with more.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 15)
Pardon me, sir, your bad entertainment.  good Antonio, forgive me your trouble.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 16)
If you will not murder me for my love, let me be your servant.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 17)
If you will not undo what you have done-- that is, kill him whom you have recovered--desire it not.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 18)
Fare you well at once. My bosom is full of kindness, and am yet so near the manners of my mother that, upon the least occasion more, mine eyes will tell tales of me.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 19)
am bound to the Count Orsino's court. Farewell.   The gentleness of all the gods go with thee!(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 20)
have many enemies in Orsino's court, Else would very shortly see thee there.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 21)
But come what may, do adore thee so That danger shall seem sport, and will go.(Twelfth Night, Act 0, Scene 22)
Were not you even now with the Countess Olivia?(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 0)
Even now, sir. On a moderate pace have since arrived but hither.(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 1)
She returns this ring to you, sir. You might have saved me my pains to have taken it away yourself.(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 2)
She adds, moreover, that you should put your lord into a desperate assurance she will none of him.(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 3)
And one thing more, that you be never so hardy to come again in his affairs unless it be to report your lord's taking of this.(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 4)
Receive it so.  She took the ring of me. I'll none of it.(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 5)
Come, sir, you peevishly threw it to her, and her will is it should be so returned.(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 6)
If it be worth stooping for, there it lies in your eye; if not, be it his that finds it.(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 7)
left no ring with her. What means this lady?  Fortune forbid my outside have not charmed her!(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 8)
She made good view of me, indeed so much That methought her eyes had lost her tongue, For she did speak in starts distractedly.(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 9)
She loves me, sure! The cunning of her passion Invites me in this churlish messenger.(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 10)
None of my lord's ring? Why, he sent her none! am the man.(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 11)
If it be so, as 'tis, Poor lady, she were better love a dream.(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 12)
Disguise, see thou art a wickedness Wherein the pregnant enemy does much.(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 13)
How easy is it for the proper false In women's waxen hearts to set their forms!(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 14)
Alas, our frailty is the cause, not we, For such as we are made of, such we be.(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 15)
How will this fadge? My master loves her dearly, And poor monster, fond as much on him, And she, mistaken, seems to dote on me.(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 16)
What will become of this? As am man, My state is desperate for my master's love.(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 17)
As am woman (now, alas the day!), What thriftless sighs shall poor Olivia breathe!(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 18)
Time, thou must untangle this, not It is too hard a knot for me t' untie.(Twelfth Night, Act 1, Scene 19)
Approach, Sir Andrew. Not to be abed after midnight is to be up betimes, and "diluculo surgere," thou know'st--  Nay, by my troth, know not.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 0)
But know to be up late is to be up late.  false conclusion.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 1)
hate it as an unfilled can. To be up after midnight and to go to bed then, is early, so that to go to bed after midnight is to go to bed betimes.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 2)
Does not our lives consist of the four elements?  Faith, so they say, but think it rather consists of eating and drinking.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 3)
Thou 'rt a scholar. Let us therefore eat and drink.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 4)
Marian, say, a stoup of wine!     Here comes the Fool, i' faith.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 5)
How now, my hearts? Did you never see the picture of "We Three"?(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 6)
Welcome, ass! Now let's have a catch.  By my troth, the Fool has an excellent breast.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 7)
had rather than forty shillings had such a leg, and so sweet a breath to sing, as the Fool has.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 8)
--In sooth, thou wast in very gracious fooling last night when thou spok'st of Pigrogromitus of the Vapians passing the equinoctial of Queubus.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 9)
'Twas very good, i' faith. sent thee sixpence for thy leman.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 10)
Hadst it?  did impeticos thy gratillity, for Malvolio's nose is no whipstock, my lady has a white hand, and the Myrmidons are no bottle-ale houses.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 11)
Excellent! Why, this is the best fooling when all is done.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 12)
Now, a song!  Come on, there is sixpence for you.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 13)
Let's have a song.  There's a testril of me, too.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 14)
If one knight give a--  Would you have a love song or a song of good life?(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 15)
love song, a love song.  Ay, ay, care not for good life.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 16)
mistress mine, where are you roaming? stay and hear!(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 17)
Your truelove's coming, That can sing both high and low.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 18)
Trip no further, pretty sweeting. Journeys end in lovers meeting, Every wise man's son doth know.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 19)
Excellent good, i' faith!  Good, good.   What is love?(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 20)
'Tis not hereafter. Present mirth hath present laughter.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 21)
What's to come is still unsure. In delay there lies no plenty, Then come kiss me, sweet and twenty.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 22)
Youth's a stuff will not endure.  mellifluous voice, as am true knight.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 23)
contagious breath.  Very sweet and contagious, i' faith.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 24)
To hear by the nose, it is dulcet in contagion. But shall we make the welkin dance indeed?(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 25)
Shall we rouse the night owl in a catch that will draw three souls out of one weaver?(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 26)
Shall we do that?  An you love me, let's do 't. am dog at a catch.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 27)
By 'r Lady, sir, and some dogs will catch well.  Most certain.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 28)
Let our catch be "Thou Knave."  "Hold thy peace, thou knave," knight?(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 29)
shall be constrained in 't to call thee "knave," knight.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 30)
'Tis not the first time have constrained one to call me "knave.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 31)
" Begin, Fool. It begins "Hold thy peace."  shall never begin if hold my peace.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 32)
Good, i' faith. Come, begin.     What a caterwauling do you keep here!(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 33)
If my lady have not called up her steward Malvolio and bid him turn you out of doors, never trust me.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 34)
My lady's a Cataian, we are politicians, Malvolio's a Peg-a-Ramsey, and  Three merry men be we.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 35)
Am not consanguineous? Am not of her blood? Tillyvally!(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 36)
"Lady"!  There dwelt a man in Babylon, lady, lady.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 37)
Beshrew me, the knight's in admirable fooling.  Ay, he does well enough if he be disposed, and so do too.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 38)
He does it with a better grace, but do it more natural.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 39)
the twelfth day of December--  For the love o' God, peace!(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 40)
My masters, are you mad? Or what are you? Have you no wit, manners, nor honesty but to gabble like tinkers at this time of night?(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 41)
Do you make an ale-house of my lady's house, that you squeak out your coziers' catches without any mitigation or remorse of voice?(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 42)
Is there no respect of place, persons, nor time in you?(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 43)
We did keep time, sir, in our catches. Sneck up!(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 44)
Sir Toby, must be round with you. My lady bade me tell you that, though she harbors you as her kinsman, she's nothing allied to your disorders.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 45)
If you can separate yourself and your misdemeanors, you are welcome to the house; if not, an it would please you to take leave of her, she is very willing to bid you farewell.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 46)
Farewell, dear heart, since must needs be gone.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 47)
Nay, good Sir Toby.   His eyes do show his days are almost done.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 48)
Is 't even so?   But will never die.   Sir Toby, there you lie.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 49)
This is much credit to you.   Shall bid him go?   What an if you do?(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 50)
Shall bid him go, and spare not?   no, no, no, no, you dare not.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 51)
Out o' tune, sir? You lie. Art any more than a steward?(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 52)
Dost thou think, because thou art virtuous, there shall be no more cakes and ale?(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 53)
Yes, by Saint Anne, and ginger shall be hot i' th' mouth, too.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 54)
Thou 'rt i' th' right.--Go, sir, rub your chain with crumbs.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 55)
--A stoup of wine, Maria!  Mistress Mary, if you prized my lady's favor at anything more than contempt, you would not give means for this uncivil rule.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 56)
She shall know of it, by this hand.  Go shake your ears!(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 57)
'Twere as good a deed as to drink when a man's a-hungry, to challenge him the field and then to break promise with him and make a fool of him.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 58)
Do 't, knight. I'll write thee a challenge. Or I'll deliver thy indignation to him by word of mouth.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 59)
Sweet Sir Toby, be patient for tonight. Since the youth of the Count's was today with my lady, she is much out of quiet.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 60)
For Monsieur Malvolio, let me alone with him. If do not gull him into a nayword and make him a common recreation, do not think have wit enough to lie straight in my bed.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 61)
know can do it.  Possess us, possess us, tell us something of him.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 62)
Marry, sir, sometimes he is a kind of puritan.  if thought that, I'd beat him like a dog!(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 63)
What, for being a puritan? Thy exquisite reason, dear knight?(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 64)
have no exquisite reason for 't, but have reason good enough.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 65)
The devil a puritan that he is, or anything constantly but a time-pleaser; an affectioned ass that cons state without book and utters it by great swaths; the best persuaded of himself, so crammed, as he thinks, with excellencies, that it is his grounds of faith that all that look on him love him.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 66)
And on that vice in him will my revenge find notable cause to work.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 67)
What wilt thou do?  will drop in his way some obscure epistles of love, wherein by the color of his beard, the shape of his leg, the manner of his gait, the expressure of his eye, forehead, and complexion, he shall find himself most feelingly personated.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 68)
can write very like my lady your niece; on a forgotten matter, we can hardly make distinction of our hands.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 69)
Excellent! smell a device.  have 't in my nose, too.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 70)
He shall think, by the letters that thou wilt drop, that they come from my niece, and that she's in love with him.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 71)
My purpose is indeed a horse of that color.  And your horse now would make him an ass.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 72)
Ass, doubt not.  'twill be admirable!  Sport royal, warrant you.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 73)
know my physic will work with him. will plant you two, and let the Fool make a third, where he shall find the letter.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 74)
Observe his construction of it. For this night, to bed, and dream on the event.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 75)
Farewell.  Good night, Penthesilea.  Before me, she's a good wench.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 76)
She's a beagle true bred, and one that adores me.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 77)
What o' that?  was adored once, too.  Let's to bed, knight.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 78)
Thou hadst need send for more money.  If cannot recover your niece, am a foul way out.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 79)
Send for money, knight. If thou hast her not i' th' end, call me "Cut.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 80)
"  If do not, never trust me, take it how you will.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 81)
Come, come, I'll go burn some sack. 'Tis too late to go to bed now.(Twelfth Night, Act 2, Scene 82)
Give me some music.  Now, good morrow, friends.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 0)
-- Now, good Cesario, but that piece of song, That old and antique song we heard last night.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 1)
Methought it did relieve my passion much, More than light airs and recollected terms Of these most brisk and giddy-paced times.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 2)
Come, but one verse.  He is not here, so please your Lordship, that should sing it.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 3)
Who was it?  Feste the jester, my lord, a Fool that the Lady Olivia's father took much delight in.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 4)
He is about the house.   Seek him out  and play the tune the while.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 5)
Come hither, boy. If ever thou shalt love, In the sweet pangs of it remember me, For such as am, all true lovers are, Unstaid and skittish in all motions else Save in the constant image of the creature That is beloved.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 6)
How dost thou like this tune?   It gives a very echo to the seat Where love is throned.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 7)
Thou dost speak masterly. My life upon 't, young though thou art, thine eye Hath stayed upon some favor that it loves.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 8)
Hath it not, boy?  little, by your favor.   What kind of woman is 't?(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 9)
Of your complexion.   She is not worth thee, then.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 10)
What years, i' faith?  About your years, my lord.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 11)
Too old, by heaven. Let still the woman take An elder than herself.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 12)
So wears she to him; So sways she level in her husband's heart.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 13)
For, boy, however we do praise ourselves, Our fancies are more giddy and unfirm, More longing, wavering, sooner lost and worn, Than women's are.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 14)
think it well, my lord.   Then let thy love be younger than thyself, Or thy affection cannot hold the bent.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 15)
For women are as roses, whose fair flower, Being once displayed, doth fall that very hour.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 16)
And so they are. Alas, that they are so, To die even when they to perfection grow!(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 17)
fellow, come, the song we had last night.-- Mark it, Cesario.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 18)
It is old and plain; The spinsters and the knitters in the sun And the free maids that weave their thread with bones Do use to chant it.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 19)
It is silly sooth, And dallies with the innocence of love Like the old age.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 20)
Are you ready, sir?  Ay, prithee, sing. The Song.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 21)
Come away, come away, death, And in sad cypress let me be laid.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 22)
Fly away, fly away, breath, am slain by a fair cruel maid.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 23)
My shroud of white, stuck all with yew, prepare it!(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 24)
My part of death, no one so true Did share it.  Not a flower, not a flower sweet On my black coffin let there be strown; Not a friend, not a friend greet My poor corpse where my bones shall be thrown.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 25)
thousand thousand sighs to save, Lay me, where Sad true lover never find my grave To weep there.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 26)
There's for thy pains.  No pains, sir. take pleasure in singing, sir.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 27)
I'll pay thy pleasure, then.  Truly sir, and pleasure will be paid, one time or another.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 28)
Give me now leave to leave thee.  Now the melancholy god protect thee and the tailor make thy doublet of changeable taffeta, for thy mind is a very opal.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 29)
would have men of such constancy put to sea, that their business might be everything and their intent everywhere, for that's it that always makes a good voyage of nothing.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 30)
Farewell.   Let all the rest give place.  Once more, Cesario, Get thee to yond same sovereign cruelty.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 31)
Tell her my love, more noble than the world, Prizes not quantity of dirty lands.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 32)
The parts that Fortune hath bestowed upon her, Tell her, hold as giddily as Fortune.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 33)
But 'tis that miracle and queen of gems That nature pranks her in attracts my soul.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 34)
But if she cannot love you, sir--   cannot be so answered.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 35)
Sooth, but you must. Say that some lady, as perhaps there is, Hath for your love as great a pang of heart As you have for Olivia.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 36)
You cannot love her; You tell her so. Must she not then be answered?(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 37)
There is no woman's sides Can bide the beating of so strong a passion As love doth give my heart; no woman's heart So big, to hold so much; they lack retention.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 38)
Alas, their love may be called appetite, No motion of the liver but the palate, That suffer surfeit, cloyment, and revolt; But mine is all as hungry as the sea, And can digest as much.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 39)
Make no compare Between that love a woman can bear me And that owe Olivia.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 40)
Ay, but know--  What dost thou know?   Too well what love women to men may owe.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 41)
In faith, they are as true of heart as we. My father had a daughter loved a man As it might be, perhaps, were a woman, should your Lordship.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 42)
And what's her history?   blank, my lord. She never told her love, But let concealment, like a worm i' th' bud, Feed on her damask cheek.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 43)
She pined in thought, And with a green and yellow melancholy She sat like Patience on a monument, Smiling at grief.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 44)
Was not this love indeed? We men may say more, swear more, but indeed Our shows are more than will; for still we prove Much in our vows but little in our love.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 45)
But died thy sister of her love, my boy?   am all the daughters of my father's house, And all the brothers, too--and yet know not.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 46)
Sir, shall to this lady?  Ay, that's the theme. To her in haste.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 47)
Give her this jewel. Say My love can give no place, bide no denay.(Twelfth Night, Act 3, Scene 48)
2       Come thy ways, Signior Fabian.  Nay, I'll come.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 0)
If lose a scruple of this sport, let me be boiled to death with melancholy.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 1)
Wouldst thou not be glad to have the niggardly rascally sheep-biter come by some notable shame?(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 2)
would exult, man. You know he brought me out o' favor with my lady about a bearbaiting here.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 3)
To anger him, we'll have the bear again, and we will fool him black and blue, shall we not, Sir Andrew?(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 4)
An we do not, it is pity of our lives.     Here comes the little villain.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 5)
--How now, my metal of India?  Get you all three into the boxtree.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 6)
Malvolio's coming down this walk. He has been yonder i' the sun practicing behavior to his own shadow this half hour.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 7)
Observe him, for the love of mockery, for know this letter will make a contemplative idiot of him.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 8)
Close, in the name of jesting!  Lie thou there  for here comes the trout that must be caught with tickling.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 9)
'Tis but fortune, all is fortune. Maria once told me she did affect me, and have heard herself come thus near, that should she fancy, it should be one of my complexion.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 10)
Besides, she uses me with a more exalted respect than anyone else that follows her.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 11)
What should think on 't?  Here's an overweening rogue.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 12)
peace! Contemplation makes a rare turkeycock of him.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 13)
How he jets under his advanced plumes!  'Slight, could so beat the rogue!(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 14)
Peace, say.  To be Count Malvolio.  Ah, rogue!  Pistol him, pistol him!(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 15)
Peace, peace!  There is example for 't. The lady of the Strachy married the yeoman of the wardrobe.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 16)
Fie on him, Jezebel!  peace, now he's deeply in.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 17)
Look how imagination blows him.  Having been three months married to her, sitting in my state--  for a stone-bow, to hit him in the eye!(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 18)
Calling my officers about me, in my branched velvet gown, having come from a daybed where have left Olivia sleeping--  Fire and brimstone!(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 19)
peace, peace!  And then to have the humor of state; and after a demure travel of regard, telling them know my place, as would they should do theirs, to ask for my kinsman Toby--  Bolts and shackles!(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 20)
peace, peace, peace! Now, now.  Seven of my people, with an obedient start, make out for him.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 21)
frown the while, and perchance wind up my watch, or play with my--some rich jewel.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 22)
Toby approaches; curtsies there to me--  Shall this fellow live?(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 23)
Though our silence be drawn from us with cars, yet peace!(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 24)
extend my hand to him thus, quenching my familiar smile with an austere regard of control--  And does not Toby take you a blow o' the lips then?(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 25)
Saying, "Cousin Toby, my fortunes, having cast me on your niece, give me this prerogative of speech--"  What, what?(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 26)
"You must amend your drunkenness."  Out, scab!  Nay, patience, or we break the sinews of our plot!(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 27)
"Besides, you waste the treasure of your time with a foolish knight--"  That's me, warrant you.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 28)
"One Sir Andrew."  knew 'twas for many do call me fool.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 29)
What employment have we here?  Now is the woodcock near the gin.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 30)
peace, and the spirit of humors intimate reading aloud to him.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 31)
By my life, this is my lady's hand! These be her very c's, her u's, and her t's, and thus she makes her great P's.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 32)
It is in contempt of question her hand.  Her c's, her u's, and her t's.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 33)
Why that?  To the unknown beloved, this, and my good wishes--Her very phrases!(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 34)
By your leave, wax. Soft. And the impressure her Lucrece, with which she uses to seal--'tis my lady!(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 35)
To whom should this be?  This wins him, liver and all.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 36)
Jove knows love, But who? Lips, do not move; No man must know.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 37)
"No man must know." What follows? The numbers altered.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 38)
"No man must know." If this should be thee, Malvolio!(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 39)
Marry, hang thee, brock!   may command where adore, But silence, like a Lucrece knife, With bloodless stroke my heart doth gore; doth sway my life.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 40)
fustian riddle!  Excellent wench, say  doth sway my life.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 41)
" Nay, but first let me see, let me see, let me see.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 42)
What dish o' poison has she dressed him!  And with what wing the staniel checks at it!(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 43)
may command where adore." Why, she may command me; serve her; she is my lady.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 44)
Why, this is evident to any formal capacity. There is no obstruction in this.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 45)
And the end--what should that alphabetical position portend?(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 46)
If could make that resemble something in me! Softly!(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 47)
ay, make up that.--He is now at a cold scent.  Sowter will cry upon 't for all this, though it be as rank as a fox.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 48)
"M"--Malvolio. "M"--why, that begins my name!  Did not say he would work it out?(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 49)
The cur is excellent at faults.  But then there is no consonancy in the sequel that suffers under probation.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 50)
should follow, but does.  And shall end, hope.  Ay, or I'll cudgel him and make him cry   And then comes behind.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 51)
Ay, an you had any eye behind you, you might see more detraction at your heels than fortunes before you.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 52)
This simulation is not as the former, and yet to crush this a little, it would bow to me, for every one of these letters are in my name.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 53)
Soft, here follows prose. If this fall into thy hand, revolve.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 54)
In my stars am above thee, but be not afraid of greatness.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 55)
Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon 'em.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 56)
Thy fates open their hands. Let thy blood and spirit embrace them.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 57)
And, to inure thyself to what thou art like to be, cast thy humble slough and appear fresh.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 58)
Be opposite with a kinsman, surly with servants. Let thy tongue tang arguments of state.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 59)
Put thyself into the trick of singularity. She thus advises thee that sighs for thee.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 60)
Remember who commended thy yellow stockings and wished to see thee ever cross-gartered.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 61)
say, remember. Go to, thou art made, if thou desir'st to be so.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 62)
If not, let me see thee a steward still, the fellow of servants, and not worthy to touch Fortune's fingers.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 63)
Farewell. She that would alter services with thee, The Fortunate-Unhappy.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 64)
Daylight and champian discovers not more! This is open.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 65)
will be proud, will read politic authors, will baffle Sir Toby, will wash off gross acquaintance, will be point-devise the very man.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 66)
do not now fool myself, to let imagination jade me; for every reason excites to this, that my lady loves me.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 67)
She did commend my yellow stockings of late, she did praise my leg being cross-gartered, and in this she manifests herself to my love and, with a kind of injunction, drives me to these habits of her liking.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 68)
thank my stars, am happy. will be strange, stout, in yellow stockings, and cross-gartered, even with the swiftness of putting on.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 69)
Jove and my stars be praised! Here is yet a postscript.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 70)
Thou canst not choose but know who am. If thou entertain'st my love, let it appear in thy smiling; thy smiles become thee well.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 71)
Therefore in my presence still smile, dear my sweet, prithee.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 72)
Jove, thank thee! will smile. will do everything that thou wilt have me.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 73)
will not give my part of this sport for a pension of thousands to be paid from the Sophy.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 74)
could marry this wench for this device.  So could too.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 75)
And ask no other dowry with her but such another jest.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 76)
Nor neither.     Here comes my noble gull-catcher.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 77)
Wilt thou set thy foot o' my neck?  Or o' mine either?(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 78)
Shall play my freedom at tray-trip and become thy bondslave?(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 79)
faith, or either?  Why, thou hast put him in such a dream that when the image of it leaves him he must run mad.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 80)
Nay, but say true, does it work upon him?  Like aqua vitae with a midwife.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 81)
If you will then see the fruits of the sport, mark his first approach before my lady.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 82)
He will come to her in yellow stockings, and 'tis a color she abhors, and cross-gartered, a fashion she detests; and he will smile upon her, which will now be so unsuitable to her disposition, being addicted to a melancholy as she is, that it cannot but turn him into a notable contempt.(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 83)
If you will see it, follow me.  To the gates of Tartar, thou most excellent devil of wit!(Twelfth Night, Act 4, Scene 84)
may depart with little while live; something may cast to you, not much.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 0)
Alas, the prison keep, though it be for great ones, yet they seldom come; before one salmon you shall take a number of minnows.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 1)
am given out to be better lined than it can appear to me report is a true speaker.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 2)
would were really that am delivered to be. Marry, what have, be it what it will, will assure upon my daughter at the day of my death.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 3)
Sir, demand no more than your own offer, and will estate your daughter in what have promised.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 4)
Well, we will talk more of this when the solemnity is past.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 5)
But have you a full promise of her? When that shall be seen, tender my consent.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 6)
have sir. Here she comes.  Your friend and have chanced to name you here, upon the old business.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 7)
But no more of that now; so soon as the court hurry is over, we will have an end of it.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 8)
th' meantime, look tenderly to the two prisoners.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 9)
can tell you they are princes.  These strewings are for their chamber.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 10)
'Tis pity they are in prison, and 'twere pity they should be out.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 11)
do think they have patience to make any adversity ashamed.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 12)
The prison itself is proud of 'em, and they have all the world in their chamber.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 13)
They are famed to be a pair of absolute men.  By my troth, think fame but stammers 'em.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 14)
They stand a grise above the reach of report.  heard them reported in the battle to be the only doers.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 15)
Nay, most likely, for they are noble suff'rers. marvel how they would have looked had they been victors, that with such a constant nobility enforce a freedom out of bondage, making misery their mirth and affliction a toy to jest at.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 16)
Do they so?  It seems to me they have no more sense of their captivity than of ruling Athens.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 17)
They eat well, look merrily, discourse of many things, but nothing of their own restraint and disasters.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 18)
Yet sometimes a divided sigh, martyred as 'twere i' th' deliverance, will break from one of them--when the other presently gives it so sweet a rebuke that could wish myself a sigh to be so chid, or at least a sigher to be comforted.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 19)
never saw 'em.  The Duke himself came privately in the night, and so did they.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 20)
What the reason of it is, know not. Look, yonder they are; that's Arcite looks out.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 21)
No, sir, no, that's Palamon. Arcite is the lower of the twain; you may perceive a part of him.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 22)
Go to, leave your pointing; they would not make us their object.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 23)
Out of their sight.  It is a holiday to look on them.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 0, Scene 24)
