How do you, noble cousin?  How do you, sir?   Why, strong enough to laugh at misery And bear the chance of war; yet we are prisoners fear forever, cousin.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 0)
believe it, And to that destiny have patiently Laid up my hour to come.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 1)
cousin Arcite, Where is Thebes now? Where is our noble country?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 2)
Where are our friends and kindreds? Never more Must we behold those comforts, never see The hardy youths strive for the games of honor, Hung with the painted favors of their ladies, Like tall ships under sail; then start amongst 'em And as an east wind leave 'em all behind us, Like lazy clouds, whilst Palamon and Arcite, Even in the wagging of a wanton leg, Outstripped the people's praises, won the garlands Ere they have time to wish 'em ours.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 3)
never Shall we two exercise, like twins of honor, Our arms again, and feel our fiery horses Like proud seas under us.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 4)
Our good swords now-- Better the red-eyed god of war ne'er wore-- Ravished our sides, like age must run to rust And deck the temples of those gods that hate us; These hands shall never draw 'em out like lightning To blast whole armies more.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 5)
No, Palamon, Those hopes are prisoners with us. Here we are And here the graces of our youths must wither Like a too-timely spring.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 6)
Here age must find us And--which is heaviest, Palamon--unmarried.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 7)
The sweet embraces of a loving wife, Loaden with kisses, armed with thousand Cupids, Shall never clasp our necks; no issue know us-- No figures of ourselves shall we e'er see, To glad our age, and like young eagles teach 'em Boldly to gaze against bright arms and say "Remember what your fathers were, and conquer!(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 8)
" The fair-eyed maids shall weep our banishments And in their songs curse ever-blinded Fortune Till she for shame see what a wrong she has done To youth and nature.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 9)
This is all our world. We shall know nothing here but one another, Hear nothing but the clock that tells our woes.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 10)
The vine shall grow, but we shall never see it; Summer shall come, and with her all delights, But dead-cold winter must inhabit here still.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 11)
'Tis too true, Arcite. To our Theban hounds That shook the aged forest with their echoes No more now must we halloo; no more shake Our pointed javelins whilst the angry swine Flies like a Parthian quiver from our rages, Struck with our well-steeled darts.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 12)
All valiant uses, The food and nourishment of noble minds, In us two here shall perish; we shall die, Which is the curse of honor, lastly, Children of grief and ignorance.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 13)
Yet, cousin, Even from the bottom of these miseries, From all that fortune can inflict upon us, see two comforts rising, two mere blessings, If the gods please: to hold here a brave patience, And the enjoying of our griefs together.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 14)
Whilst Palamon is with me, let me perish If think this our prison!(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 15)
Certainly 'Tis a main goodness, cousin, that our fortunes Were twined together.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 16)
'Tis most true, two souls Put in two noble bodies, let 'em suffer The gall of hazard, so they grow together, Will never sink; they must not, say they could.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 17)
willing man dies sleeping and all's done.   Shall we make worthy uses of this place That all men hate so much?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 18)
How, gentle cousin?   Let's think this prison holy sanctuary To keep us from corruption of worse men.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 19)
We are young and yet desire the ways of honor That liberty and common conversation, The poison of pure spirits, might like women Woo us to wander from.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 20)
What worthy blessing Can be but our imaginations May make it ours?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 21)
And here being thus together, We are an endless mine to one another; We are one another's wife, ever begetting New births of love; we are father, friends, acquaintance; We are, in one another, families; am your heir, and you are mine.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 22)
This place Is our inheritance; no hard oppressor Dare take this from us; here with a little patience We shall live long and loving.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 23)
No surfeits seek us; The hand of war hurts none here, nor the seas Swallow their youth.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 24)
Were we at liberty, wife might part us lawfully, or business; Quarrels consume us; envy of ill men Crave our acquaintance.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 25)
might sicken, cousin, Where you should never know it, and so perish Without your noble hand to close mine eyes, Or prayers to the gods.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 26)
thousand chances, Were we from hence, would sever us.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 27)
You have made me-- thank you, cousin Arcite--almost wanton With my captivity.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 28)
What a misery It is to live abroad and everywhere!(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 29)
'Tis like a beast, methinks. find the court here, am sure, a more content; and all those pleasures That woo the wills of men to vanity see through now, and am sufficient To tell the world 'tis but a gaudy shadow That old Time as he passes by takes with him.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 30)
What had we been, old in the court of Creon, Where sin is justice, lust and ignorance The virtues of the great ones?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 31)
Cousin Arcite, Had not the loving gods found this place for us, We had died as they do, ill old men, unwept, And had their epitaphs, the people's curses.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 32)
Shall say more?  would hear you still.  You shall.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 33)
Is there record of any two that loved Better than we do, Arcite?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 34)
Sure there cannot.   do not think it possible our friendship Should ever leave us.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 35)
Till our deaths it cannot.    And after death our spirits shall be led To those that love eternally.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 36)
Speak on, sir.   This garden has a world of pleasures in 't.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 37)
What flower is this?  'Tis called narcissus, madam.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 38)
That was a fair boy certain, but a fool To love himself.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 39)
Were there not maids enough?   Pray, forward.  Yes.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 40)
Or were they all hard-hearted?   They could not be to one so fair.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 41)
Thou wouldst not.   think should not, madam.  That's a good wench.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 42)
But take heed to your kindness, though.  Why, madam?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 43)
Men are mad things.  Will you go forward, cousin?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 44)
Canst not thou work such flowers in silk, wench?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 45)
Yes.   I'll have a gown full of 'em, and of these.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 46)
This is pretty color. Will 't not do Rarely upon a skirt, wench?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 47)
Dainty, madam.   Cousin, cousin! How do you, sir?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 48)
Why, Palamon!   Never till now was in prison, Arcite.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 49)
Why, what's the matter, man?  Behold, and wonder!(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 50)
By heaven, she is a goddess.  Ha!  Do reverence. She is a goddess, Arcite.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 51)
Of all flowers Methinks a rose is best.  Why, gentle madam?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 52)
It is the very emblem of a maid. For when the west wind courts her gently, How modestly she blows and paints the sun With her chaste blushes!(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 53)
When the north comes near her, Rude and impatient, then, like chastity, She locks her beauties in her bud again, And leaves him to base briers.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 54)
Yet, good madam, Sometimes her modesty will blow so far She falls for 't.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 55)
maid, If she have any honor, would be loath To take example by her.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 56)
Thou art wanton!   She is wondrous fair.  She is all the beauty extant.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 57)
The sun grows high. Let's walk in. Keep these flowers.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 58)
We'll see how near art can come near their colors.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 59)
am wondrous merry-hearted. could laugh now.   could lie down, am sure.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 60)
And take one with you?   That's as we bargain, madam.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 61)
Well, agree then.    What think you of this beauty?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 62)
'Tis a rare one.   Is 't but a rare one?  Yes, a matchless beauty.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 63)
Might not a man well lose himself and love her?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 64)
cannot tell what you have done; have, Beshrew mine eyes for 't!(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 65)
Now feel my shackles.   You love her, then?  Who would not?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 66)
And desire her?   Before my liberty.  saw her first.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 67)
That's nothing.  But it shall be.  saw her, too.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 68)
Yes, but you must not love her.   will not, as you do, to worship her As she is heavenly and a blessed goddess.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 69)
love her as a woman, to enjoy her. So both may love.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 70)
You shall not love at all.  Not love at all! Who shall deny me?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 71)
that first saw her; that took possession First with mine eye of all those beauties In her revealed to mankind.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 72)
If thou lov'st her, Or entertain'st a hope to blast my wishes, Thou art a traitor, Arcite, and a fellow False as thy title to her.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 73)
Friendship, blood, And all the ties between us disclaim If thou once think upon her.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 74)
Yes, love her, And, if the lives of all my name lay on it, must do so.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 75)
love her with my soul. If that will lose you, farewell, Palamon.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 76)
say again, love, and in loving her maintain am as worthy and as free a lover And have as just a title to her beauty As any Palamon or any living That is a man's son.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 77)
Have called thee friend?   Yes, and have found me so.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 78)
Why are you moved thus? Let me deal coldly with you: am not Part of your blood, part of your soul?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 79)
You have told me That was Palamon and you were Arcite.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 80)
Yes.  Am not liable to those affections, Those joys, griefs, angers, fears, my friend shall suffer?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 81)
You may be.  Why then would you deal so cunningly, So strangely, so unlike a noble kinsman, To love alone?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 82)
Speak truly, do you think me Unworthy of her sight?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 83)
No, but unjust If thou pursue that sight.  Because another First sees the enemy, shall stand still And let mine honor down, and never charge?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 84)
Yes, if he be but one.  But say that one Had rather combat me?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 85)
Let that one say so, And use thy freedom. Else, if thou pursuest her, Be as that cursed man that hates his country, branded villain.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 86)
You are mad.  must be. Till thou art worthy, Arcite, it concerns me.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 87)
And in this madness if hazard thee And take thy life, deal but truly.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 88)
Fie, sir! You play the child extremely. will love her; must, ought to do so, and dare, And all this justly.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 89)
that now, that now, Thy false self and thy friend had but this fortune To be one hour at liberty, and grasp Our good swords in our hands, would quickly teach thee What 'twere to filch affection from another.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 90)
Thou art baser in it than a cutpurse. Put but thy head out of this window more And, as have a soul, I'll nail thy life to 't.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 91)
Thou dar'st not, fool; thou canst not; thou art feeble.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 92)
Put my head out? I'll throw my body out And leap the garden when see her next, And pitch between her arms to anger thee.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 93)
No more; the keeper's coming. shall live To knock thy brains out with my shackles.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 94)
Do!   By your leave, gentlemen.  Now, honest keeper?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 95)
Lord Arcite, you must presently to th' Duke; The cause know not yet.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 96)
am ready, keeper.   Prince Palamon, must awhile bereave you Of your fair cousin's company.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 97)
And me too, Even when you please, of life.--Why is he sent for?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 98)
It may be he shall marry her; he's goodly, And like enough the Duke hath taken notice Both of his blood and body.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 99)
But his falsehood! Why should a friend be treacherous?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 100)
If that Get him a wife so noble and so fair, Let honest men ne'er love again.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 101)
Once more would but see this fair one. Blessed garden And fruit and flowers more blessed that still blossom As her bright eyes shine on you, would were, For all the fortune of my life hereafter, Yon little tree, yon blooming apricock!(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 102)
How would spread and fling my wanton arms In at her window; would bring her fruit Fit for the gods to feed on; youth and pleasure Still as she tasted should be doubled on her; And, if she be not heavenly, would make her So near the gods in nature, they should fear her.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 103)
And then am sure she would love me.--How now, keeper, Where's Arcite?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 104)
Banished. Prince Pirithous Obtained his liberty, but never more Upon his oath and life must he set foot Upon this kingdom.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 105)
He's a blessed man. He shall see Thebes again, and call to arms The bold young men that, when he bids 'em charge, Fall on like fire.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 106)
Arcite shall have a fortune, If he dare make himself a worthy lover, Yet in the field to strike a battle for her, And, if he lose her then, he's a cold coward.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 107)
How bravely may he bear himself to win her If he be noble Arcite--thousand ways!(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 108)
Were at liberty, would do things Of such a virtuous greatness that this lady, This blushing virgin, should take manhood to her And seek to ravish me.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 109)
My lord, for you have this charge to--  To discharge my life?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 110)
No, but from this place to remove your Lordship; The windows are too open.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 111)
Devils take 'em That are so envious to me! Prithee, kill me.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 112)
And hang for 't afterward!  By this good light, Had a sword would kill thee.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 113)
Why, my lord?   Thou bringst such pelting, scurvy news continually, Thou art not worthy life.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 114)
will not go.   Indeed you must, my lord.  May see the garden?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 115)
No.  Then am resolved, will not go.   must constrain you then; and, for you are dangerous, I'll clap more irons on you.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 116)
Do, good keeper. I'll shake 'em so, you shall not sleep; I'll make you a new morris.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 117)
Must go?   There is no remedy.  Farewell, kind window.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 118)
May rude wind never hurt thee. my lady, If ever thou hast felt what sorrow was, Dream how suffer.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 1, Scene 119)
Banished the kingdom? 'Tis a benefit, mercy must thank 'em for; but banished The free enjoying of that face die for, 'twas a studied punishment, a death Beyond imagination--such a vengeance That, were old and wicked, all my sins Could never pluck upon me.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 0)
Palamon, Thou hast the start now; thou shalt stay and see Her bright eyes break each morning 'gainst thy window And let in life into thee; thou shalt feed Upon the sweetness of a noble beauty That nature ne'er exceeded nor ne'er shall.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 1)
Good gods, what happiness has Palamon! Twenty to one he'll come to speak to her, And if she be as gentle as she's fair, know she's his.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 2)
He has a tongue will tame Tempests and make the wild rocks wanton.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 3)
Come what can come, The worst is death. will not leave the kingdom.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 4)
know mine own is but a heap of ruins, And no redress there.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 5)
If go, he has her. am resolved another shape shall make me Or end my fortunes.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 6)
Either way am happy. I'll see her and be near her, or no more.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 7)
My masters, I'll be there, that's certain.  And I'll be there.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 8)
And  Why, then, have with you, boys. 'Tis but a chiding.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 9)
Let the plough play today; I'll tickle 't out of the jades' tails tomorrow.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 10)
am sure to have my wife as jealous as a turkey, but that's all one.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 11)
I'll go through; let her mumble.  Clap her aboard tomorrow night and stow her, and all's made up again.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 12)
Ay, do but put a fescue in her fist and you shall see her take a new lesson out and be a good wench.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 13)
Do we all hold against the Maying?  Hold? What should ail us?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 14)
Arcas will be there.  And Sennois and Rycas; and three better lads ne'er danced under green tree.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 15)
And you know what wenches, ha! But will the dainty domine, the Schoolmaster, keep touch, do you think?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 16)
For he does all, you know.  He'll eat a hornbook ere he fail.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 17)
Go to, the matter's too far driven between him and the tanner's daughter to let slip now; and she must see the Duke, and she must dance too.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 18)
Shall we be lusty?  All the boys in Athens blow wind i' th' breech on 's.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 19)
And here I'll be and there I'll be, for our town, and here again, and there again.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 20)
Ha, boys, hey for the weavers!  This must be done i' th' woods.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 21)
pardon me.  By any means; our thing of learning says so--where he himself will edify the Duke most parlously in our behalfs.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 22)
He's excellent i' th' woods; bring him to th' plains, his learning makes no cry.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 23)
We'll see the sports, then every man to 's tackle.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 24)
And, sweet companions, let's rehearse, by any means, before the ladies see us, and do sweetly, and God knows what may come on 't.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 25)
Content. The sports once ended, we'll perform. Away, boys, and hold.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 26)
By your leaves, honest friends: pray you, whither go you?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 27)
Whither? Why, what a question's that?  Yes, 'tis a question To me that know not.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 28)
To the games, my friend.   Where were you bred, you know it not?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 29)
Not far, sir. Are there such games today?  Yes, marry, are there, And such as you never saw.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 30)
The Duke himself Will be in person there.  What pastimes are they?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 31)
Wrestling and running.--'Tis a pretty fellow.   Thou wilt not go along?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 32)
Not yet, sir.  Well, sir, Take your own time.--Come, boys.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 33)
My mind misgives me. This fellow has a vengeance trick o' th' hip.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 34)
Mark how his body's made for 't.  I'll be hanged, though, if he dare venture.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 35)
Hang him, plum porridge! He wrestle? He roast eggs!(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 36)
Come, let's be gone, lads.   This is an offered opportunity durst not wish for.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 37)
Well could have wrestled-- The best men called it excellent--and run Swifter than wind upon a field of corn, Curling the wealthy ears, never flew.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 38)
I'll venture, And in some poor disguise be there.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 39)
Who knows Whether my brows may not be girt with garlands, And happiness prefer me to a place Where may ever dwell in sight of her?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 2, Scene 40)
Why should love this gentleman? 'Tis odds He never will affect me.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 3, Scene 0)
am base, My father the mean keeper of his prison, And he a prince.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 3, Scene 1)
To marry him is hopeless; To be his whore is witless.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 3, Scene 2)
Out upon 't! What pushes are we wenches driven to When fifteen once has found us!(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 3, Scene 3)
First, saw him; seeing, thought he was a goodly man; He has as much to please a woman in him, If he please to bestow it so, as ever These eyes yet looked on.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 3, Scene 4)
Next, pitied him, And so would any young wench, o' my conscience, That ever dreamed, or vowed her maidenhead To a young handsome man.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 3, Scene 5)
Then loved him, Extremely loved him, infinitely loved him!(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 3, Scene 6)
And yet he had a cousin, fair as he too. But in my heart was Palamon, and there, Lord, what a coil he keeps!(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 3, Scene 7)
To hear him Sing in an evening, what a heaven it is!(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 3, Scene 8)
And yet his songs are sad ones. Fairer spoken Was never gentleman.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 3, Scene 9)
When come in To bring him water in a morning, first He bows his noble body, then salutes me thus: "Fair, gentle maid, good morrow.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 3, Scene 10)
May thy goodness Get thee a happy husband." Once he kissed me; loved my lips the better ten days after.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 3, Scene 11)
Would he would do so ev'ry day! He grieves much-- And me as much to see his misery.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 3, Scene 12)
What should do to make him know love him? For would fain enjoy him.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 3, Scene 13)
Say ventured To set him free? What says the law then?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 3, Scene 14)
Thus much for law or kindred! will do it, And this night, or tomorrow, he shall love me.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 3, Scene 15)
2     Enter Theseus, Hippolyta, Pirithous, Emilia, Arcite     You have done worthily.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 0)
have not seen, Since Hercules, a man of tougher sinews.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 1)
Whate'er you are, you run the best and wrestle That these times can allow.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 2)
am proud to please you.   What country bred you?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 3)
This; but far off, prince.   Are you a gentleman?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 4)
My father said so, And to those gentle uses gave me life.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 5)
Are you his heir?  His youngest, sir.  Your father, Sure, is a happy sire, then.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 6)
What proves you?   little of all noble qualities.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 7)
could have kept a hawk and well have hallowed To a deep cry of dogs.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 8)
dare not praise My feat in horsemanship, yet they that knew me Would say it was my best piece.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 9)
Last, and greatest, would be thought a soldier.  You are perfect.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 10)
Upon my soul, a proper man.  He is so.   How do you like him, lady?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 11)
admire him. have not seen so young a man so noble, If he say true, of his sort.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 12)
Believe, His mother was a wondrous handsome woman; His face, methinks, goes that way.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 13)
But his body And fiery mind illustrate a brave father.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 14)
Mark how his virtue, like a hidden sun, Breaks through his baser garments.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 15)
He's well got, sure.   What made you seek this place, sir?(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 16)
Noble Theseus, To purchase name and do my ablest service To such a well-found wonder as thy worth; For only in thy court, of all the world, Dwells fair-eyed Honor.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 17)
All his words are worthy.   Sir, we are much indebted to your travel, Nor shall you lose your wish.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 18)
--Pirithous, Dispose of this fair gentleman.  Thanks, Theseus.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 19)
-- Whate'er you are, you're mine, and shall give you To a most noble service: to this lady, This bright young virgin.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 20)
Pray observe her goodness; You have honored her fair birthday with your virtues, And, as your due, you're hers.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 21)
Kiss her fair hand, sir.   Sir, you're a noble giver.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 22)
--Dearest beauty, Thus let me seal my vowed faith.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 23)
When your servant, Your most unworthy creature, but offends you, Command him die, he shall.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 24)
That were too cruel. If you deserve well, sir, shall soon see 't.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 25)
You're mine, and somewhat better than your rank I'll use you.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 26)
I'll see you furnished, and because you say You are a horseman, must needs entreat you This afternoon to ride--but 'tis a rough one.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 27)
like him better, prince; shall not then Freeze in my saddle.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 28)
Sweet, you must be ready,-- And you, Emilia,--and you, friend,--and all, Tomorrow by the sun, to do observance To flowery May in Dian's wood.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 29)
--Wait well, sir, Upon your mistress.--Emily, hope He shall not go afoot.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 30)
That were a shame, sir, While have horses.--Take your choice, and what You want at any time, let me but know it.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 31)
If you serve faithfully, dare assure you You'll find a loving mistress.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 32)
If do not, Let me find that my father ever hated, Disgrace and blows.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 33)
Go lead the way; you have won it. It shall be so; you shall receive all dues Fit for the honor you have won.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 34)
'Twere wrong else.-- Sister, beshrew my heart, you have a servant That, if were a woman, would be master; But you are wise.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 4, Scene 35)
Let all the dukes and all the devils roar! He is at liberty.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 5, Scene 0)
have ventured for him, And out have brought him; to a little wood mile hence have sent him, where a cedar Higher than all the rest spreads like a plane Fast by a brook, and there he shall keep close Till provide him files and food, for yet His iron bracelets are not off.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 5, Scene 1)
Love, What a stout-hearted child thou art! My father Durst better have endured cold iron than done it.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 5, Scene 2)
love him beyond love and beyond reason Or wit or safety.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 5, Scene 3)
have made him know it; care not, am desperate. If the law Find me and then condemn me for 't, some wenches, Some honest-hearted maids, will sing my dirge And tell to memory my death was noble, Dying almost a martyr.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 5, Scene 4)
That way he takes purpose is my way too. Sure he cannot Be so unmanly as to leave me here.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 5, Scene 5)
If he do, maids will not so easily Trust men again.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 5, Scene 6)
And yet he has not thanked me For what have done; no, not so much as kissed me, And that, methinks, is not so well; nor scarcely Could persuade him to become a free man, He made such scruples of the wrong he did To me and to my father.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 5, Scene 7)
Yet hope, When he considers more, this love of mine Will take more root within him.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 5, Scene 8)
Let him do What he will with me, so he use me kindly; For use me so he shall, or I'll proclaim him, And to his face, no man.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 5, Scene 9)
I'll presently Provide him necessaries and pack my clothes up, And where there is a path of ground I'll venture, So he be with me.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 5, Scene 10)
By him like a shadow I'll ever dwell. Within this hour the hubbub Will be all o'er the prison.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 5, Scene 11)
am then Kissing the man they look for. Farewell, father!(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 5, Scene 12)
Get many more such prisoners and such daughters, And shortly you may keep yourself.(The Two Noble Kinsmen, Act 5, Scene 13)
Thersites!  Agamemnon--how if he had boils, full, all over, generally?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 0)
Thersites!  And those boils did run? Say so. Did not the general run, then?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 1)
Were not that a botchy core?  Dog!  Then there would come some matter from him.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 2)
see none now.  Thou bitchwolf's son, canst thou not hear?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 3)
Feel, then.  The plague of Greece upon thee, thou mongrel beef-witted lord!(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 4)
Speak, then, thou unsalted leaven, speak. will beat thee into handsomeness.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 5)
shall sooner rail thee into wit and holiness, but think thy horse will sooner con an oration than thou learn a prayer without book.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 6)
Thou canst strike, canst thou? red murrain o' thy jade's tricks.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 7)
Toadstool, learn me the proclamation.  Dost thou think have no sense, thou strikest me thus?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 8)
The proclamation!  Thou art proclaimed a fool, think.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 9)
Do not, porpentine, do not. My fingers itch.  would thou didst itch from head to foot, and had the scratching of thee; would make thee the loathsomest scab in Greece.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 10)
When thou art forth in the incursions, thou strikest as slow as another.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 11)
say, the proclamation!  Thou grumblest and railest every hour on Achilles, and thou art as full of envy at his greatness as Cerberus is at Proserpina's beauty, ay, that thou bark'st at him.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 12)
Mistress Thersites!  Thou shouldst strike him--  Cobloaf!(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 13)
He would pound thee into shivers with his fist as a sailor breaks a biscuit.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 14)
You whoreson cur!  Do, do.  Thou stool for a witch!(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 15)
Ay, do, do, thou sodden-witted lord. Thou hast no more brain than have in mine elbows; an asinego may tutor thee, thou scurvy-valiant ass.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 16)
Thou art here but to thrash Trojans, and thou art bought and sold among those of any wit, like a barbarian slave.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 17)
If thou use to beat me, will begin at thy heel and tell what thou art by inches, thou thing of no bowels, thou.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 18)
You dog!  You scurvy lord!  You cur!  Mars his idiot!(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 19)
Do, rudeness, do, camel, do, do.     Why, how now, Ajax?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 20)
Wherefore do you thus?--How now, Thersites? What's the matter, man?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 21)
You see him there, do you?  Ay, what's the matter?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 22)
Nay, look upon him.  So do. What's the matter?  Nay, but regard him well.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 23)
Well, why, so do.  But yet you look not well upon him, for whosomever you take him to be, he is Ajax.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 24)
know that, fool.  Ay, but that fool knows not himself.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 25)
Therefore beat thee.  Lo, lo, lo, lo, what modicums of wit he utters!(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 26)
His evasions have ears thus long. have bobbed his brain more than he has beat my bones.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 27)
will buy nine sparrows for a penny, and his pia mater is not worth the ninth part of a sparrow.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 28)
This lord, Achilles--Ajax, who wears his wit in his belly, and his guts in his head--I'll tell you what say of him.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 29)
What?  say, this Ajax--  Nay, good Ajax.  Has not so much wit--  Nay, must hold you.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 30)
As will stop the eye of Helen's needle, for whom he comes to fight.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 31)
Peace, fool!  would have peace and quietness, but the fool will not--he there, that he.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 32)
Look you there.  thou damned cur, shall--  Will you set your wit to a fool's?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 33)
No, warrant you. The fool's will shame it.  Good words, Thersites.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 34)
What's the quarrel?  bade the vile owl go learn me the tenor of the proclamation, and he rails upon me.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 35)
serve thee not.  Well, go to, go to.  serve here voluntary.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 36)
Your last service was suff'rance; 'twas not voluntary.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 37)
No man is beaten voluntary. Ajax was here the voluntary, and you as under an impress.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 38)
E'en so. great deal of your wit, too, lies in your sinews, or else there be liars.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 39)
Hector shall have a great catch an he knock out either of your brains; he were as good crack a fusty nut with no kernel.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 40)
What, with me too, Thersites?  There's Ulysses and old Nestor--whose wit was moldy ere your grandsires had nails on their toes--yoke you like draft-oxen and make you plow up the wars.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 41)
What? What?  Yes, good sooth. To, Achilles! To, Ajax!(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 42)
To--  shall cut out your tongue.  'Tis no matter.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 43)
shall speak as much as thou afterwards.  No more words, Thersites.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 44)
Peace.  will hold my peace when Achilles' brach bids me, shall  There's for you, Patroclus.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 45)
will see you hanged like clodpolls ere come any more to your tents.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 46)
will keep where there is wit stirring and leave the faction of fools.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 47)
good riddance.   Marry, this, sir, is proclaimed through all our host: That Hector, by the fifth hour of the sun, Will with a trumpet 'twixt our tents and Troy Tomorrow morning call some knight to arms That hath a stomach, and such a one that dare Maintain--I know not what; 'tis trash.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 48)
Farewell.  Farewell. Who shall answer him?   know not.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 49)
'Tis put to lott'ry. Otherwise, He knew his man.  meaning you?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 0, Scene 50)
After so many hours, lives, speeches spent, Thus once again says Nestor from the Greeks: "Deliver Helen, and all damage else-- As honor, loss of time, travel, expense, Wounds, friends, and what else dear that is consumed In hot digestion of this cormorant war-- Shall be struck off.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 0)
"--Hector, what say you to 't?   Though no man lesser fears the Greeks than As far as toucheth my particular, Yet, dread Priam, There is no lady of more softer bowels, More spongy to suck in the sense of fear, More ready to cry out "Who knows what follows?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 1)
" Than Hector is. The wound of peace is surety, Surety secure; but modest doubt is called The beacon of the wise, the tent that searches To th' bottom of the worst.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 2)
Let Helen go. Since the first sword was drawn about this question, Every tithe soul, 'mongst many thousand dismes, Hath been as dear as Helen; mean, of ours.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 3)
If we have lost so many tenths of ours To guard a thing not ours--nor worth to us, Had it our name, the value of one ten-- What merit's in that reason which denies The yielding of her up?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 4)
Fie, fie, my brother, Weigh you the worth and honor of a king So great as our dread father's in a scale Of common ounces?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 5)
Will you with counters sum The past-proportion of his infinite, And buckle in a waist most fathomless With spans and inches so diminutive As fears and reasons?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 6)
Fie, for godly shame!   No marvel though you bite so sharp at reasons, You are so empty of them.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 7)
Should not our father Bear the great sway of his affairs with reason, Because your speech hath none that tell him so?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 8)
You are for dreams and slumbers, brother priest.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 9)
You fur your gloves with reason. Here are your reasons: You know an enemy intends you harm; You know a sword employed is perilous, And reason flies the object of all harm.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 10)
Who marvels, then, when Helenus beholds Grecian and his sword, if he do set The very wings of reason to his heels And fly like chidden Mercury from Jove Or like a star disorbed?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 11)
Nay, if we talk of reason, Let's shut our gates and sleep.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 12)
Manhood and honor Should have hare hearts, would they but fat their thoughts With this crammed reason.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 13)
Reason and respect Make livers pale and lustihood deject.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 14)
Brother, she is not worth what she doth cost The keeping.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 15)
What's aught but as 'tis valued?   But value dwells not in particular will; It holds his estimate and dignity As well wherein 'tis precious of itself As in the prizer.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 16)
'Tis mad idolatry To make the service greater than the god; And the will dotes that is attributive To what infectiously itself affects Without some image of th' affected merit.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 17)
take today a wife, and my election Is led on in the conduct of my will-- My will enkindled by mine eyes and ears, Two traded pilots 'twixt the dangerous shores Of will and judgment.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 18)
How may avoid, Although my will distaste what it elected, The wife choose?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 19)
There can be no evasion To blench from this and to stand firm by honor.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 20)
We turn not back the silks upon the merchant When we have soiled them, nor the remainder viands We do not throw in unrespective sieve Because we now are full.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 21)
It was thought meet Paris should do some vengeance on the Greeks.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 22)
Your breath with full consent bellied his sails; The seas and winds, old wranglers, took a truce And did him service.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 23)
He touched the ports desired, And for an old aunt whom the Greeks held captive, He brought a Grecian queen, whose youth and freshness Wrinkles Apollo's and makes pale the morning.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 24)
Why keep we her? The Grecians keep our aunt. Is she worth keeping?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 25)
Why, she is a pearl Whose price hath launched above a thousand ships And turned crowned kings to merchants.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 26)
If you'll avouch 'twas wisdom Paris went-- As you must needs, for you all cried "Go, go"-- If you'll confess he brought home worthy prize-- As you must needs, for you all clapped your hands And cried "Inestimable"--why do you now The issue of your proper wisdoms rate And do a deed that never Fortune did, Beggar the estimation which you prized Richer than sea and land?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 27)
theft most base, That we have stol'n what we do fear to keep!(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 28)
But thieves unworthy of a thing so stol'n, That in their country did them that disgrace We fear to warrant in our native place.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 29)
Cry, Trojans, cry!  What noise? What shriek is this?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 30)
'Tis our mad sister. do know her voice.  Cry, Trojans!(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 31)
It is Cassandra.      Cry, Trojans, cry! Lend me ten thousand eyes, And will fill them with prophetic tears.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 32)
Peace, sister, peace!   Virgins and boys, mid-age and wrinkled elders, Soft infancy, that nothing canst but cry, Add to my clamors.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 33)
Let us pay betimes moiety of that mass of moan to come.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 34)
Cry, Trojans, cry! Practice your eyes with tears.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 35)
Troy must not be, nor goodly Ilium stand. Our firebrand brother Paris burns us all.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 36)
Cry, Trojans, cry! Helen and a woe! Cry, cry! Troy burns, or else let Helen go.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 37)
Now, youthful Troilus, do not these high strains Of divination in our sister work Some touches of remorse?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 38)
Or is your blood So madly hot that no discourse of reason Nor fear of bad success in a bad cause Can qualify the same?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 39)
Why, brother Hector, We may not think the justness of each act Such and no other than event doth form it, Nor once deject the courage of our minds Because Cassandra's mad.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 40)
Her brainsick raptures Cannot distaste the goodness of a quarrel Which hath our several honors all engaged To make it gracious.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 41)
For my private part, am no more touched than all Priam's sons; And Jove forbid there should be done amongst us Such things as might offend the weakest spleen To fight for and maintain!(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 42)
Else might the world convince of levity As well my undertakings as your counsels.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 43)
But attest the gods, your full consent Gave wings to my propension and cut off All fears attending on so dire a project.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 44)
For what, alas, can these my single arms? What propugnation is in one man's valor To stand the push and enmity of those This quarrel would excite?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 45)
Yet, protest, Were alone to pass the difficulties And had as ample power as have will, Paris should ne'er retract what he hath done Nor faint in the pursuit.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 46)
Paris, you speak Like one besotted on your sweet delights.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 47)
You have the honey still, but these the gall. So to be valiant is no praise at all.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 48)
Sir, propose not merely to myself The pleasures such a beauty brings with it, But would have the soil of her fair rape Wiped off in honorable keeping her.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 49)
What treason were it to the ransacked queen, Disgrace to your great worths, and shame to me, Now to deliver her possession up On terms of base compulsion?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 50)
Can it be That so degenerate a strain as this Should once set footing in your generous bosoms?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 51)
There's not the meanest spirit on our party Without a heart to dare or sword to draw When Helen is defended, nor none so noble Whose life were ill bestowed or death unfamed Where Helen is the subject.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 52)
Then say, Well may we fight for her whom, we know well, The world's large spaces cannot parallel.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 53)
Paris and Troilus, you have both said well, And on the cause and question now in hand Have glozed--but superficially, not much Unlike young men, whom Aristotle thought Unfit to hear moral philosophy.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 54)
The reasons you allege do more conduce To the hot passion of distempered blood Than to make up a free determination 'Twixt right and wrong, for pleasure and revenge Have ears more deaf than adders to the voice Of any true decision.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 55)
Nature craves All dues be rendered to their owners.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 56)
Now, What nearer debt in all humanity Than wife is to the husband?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 57)
If this law Of nature be corrupted through affection, And that great minds, of partial indulgence To their benumbed wills, resist the same, There is a law in each well-ordered nation To curb those raging appetites that are Most disobedient and refractory.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 58)
If Helen, then, be wife to Sparta's king, As it is known she is, these moral laws Of nature and of nations speak aloud To have her back returned.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 59)
Thus to persist In doing wrong extenuates not wrong, But makes it much more heavy.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 60)
Hector's opinion Is this in way of truth; yet, ne'ertheless, My sprightly brethren, propend to you In resolution to keep Helen still, For 'tis a cause that hath no mean dependence Upon our joint and several dignities.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 61)
Why, there you touched the life of our design! Were it not glory that we more affected Than the performance of our heaving spleens, would not wish a drop of Trojan blood Spent more in her defense.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 62)
But, worthy Hector, She is a theme of honor and renown, spur to valiant and magnanimous deeds, Whose present courage may beat down our foes, And fame in time to come canonize us; For presume brave Hector would not lose So rich advantage of a promised glory As smiles upon the forehead of this action For the wide world's revenue.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 63)
am yours, You valiant offspring of great Priamus.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 64)
have a roisting challenge sent amongst The dull and factious nobles of the Greeks Will strike amazement to their drowsy spirits.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 65)
was advertised their great general slept, Whilst emulation in the army crept.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 1, Scene 66)
2       How now, Thersites? What, lost in the labyrinth of thy fury?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 0)
Shall the elephant Ajax carry it thus? He beats me, and rail at him.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 1)
worthy satisfaction! Would it were otherwise, that could beat him whilst he railed at me.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 2)
'Sfoot, I'll learn to conjure and raise devils but I'll see some issue of my spiteful execrations.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 3)
Then there's Achilles, a rare enginer! If Troy be not taken till these two undermine it, the walls will stand till they fall of themselves.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 4)
thou great thunder-darter of Olympus, forget that thou art Jove, the king of gods; and, Mercury, lose all the serpentine craft of thy caduceus, if you take not that little, little, less than little wit from them that they have, which short-armed ignorance itself knows is so abundant scarce it will not in circumvention deliver a fly from a spider without drawing their massy irons and cutting the web.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 5)
After this, the vengeance on the whole camp! Or rather, the Neapolitan bone-ache!(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 6)
For that, methinks, is the curse depending on those that war for a placket.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 7)
have said my prayers, and devil Envy say "Amen."--What ho, my lord Achilles!(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 8)
Who's there? Thersites? Good Thersites, come in and rail.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 9)
If could 'a remembered a gilt counterfeit, thou couldst not have slipped out of my contemplation.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 10)
But it is no matter. Thyself upon thyself! The common curse of mankind, folly and ignorance, be thine in great revenue!(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 11)
Heaven bless thee from a tutor, and discipline come not near thee!(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 12)
Let thy blood be thy direction till thy death; then if she that lays thee out says thou art a fair corse, I'll be sworn and sworn upon 't she never shrouded any but lazars.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 13)
Amen.    Where's Achilles?  What, art thou devout?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 14)
Wast thou in prayer?  Ay. The heavens hear me!  Amen.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 15)
Who's there?  Thersites, my lord.  Where? Where?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 16)
where?    Art thou come? Why, my cheese, my digestion, why hast thou not served thyself in to my table so many meals?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 17)
Come, what's Agamemnon?  Thy commander, Achilles.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 18)
--Then, tell me, Patroclus, what's Achilles?  Thy lord, Thersites.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 19)
Then, tell me, pray thee, what's Thersites?  Thy knower, Patroclus.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 20)
Then, tell me, Patroclus, what art thou?  Thou must tell that knowest.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 21)
tell, tell.  I'll decline the whole question. Agamemnon commands Achilles, Achilles is my lord, am Patroclus' knower, and Patroclus is a fool.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 22)
You rascal!  Peace, fool. have not done.  He is a privileged man.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 23)
--Proceed, Thersites.  Agamemnon is a fool, Achilles is a fool, Thersites is a fool, and, as aforesaid, Patroclus is a fool.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 24)
Derive this. Come.  Agamemnon is a fool to offer to command Achilles, Achilles is a fool to be commanded of Agamemnon, Thersites is a fool to serve such a fool, and this Patroclus is a fool positive.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 25)
Why am a fool?  Make that demand of the creator.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 26)
It suffices me thou art.     Look you, who comes here?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 27)
Patroclus, I'll speak with nobody.--Come in with me, Thersites.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 28)
Here is such patchery, such juggling, and such knavery.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 29)
All the argument is a whore and a cuckold, a good quarrel to draw emulous factions and bleed to death upon.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 30)
Now the dry serpigo on the subject, and war and lechery confound all!(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 31)
Where is Achilles?   Within his tent, but ill-disposed, my lord.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 32)
Let it be known to him that we are here. He shent our messengers, and we lay by Our appertainments, visiting of him.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 33)
Let him be told so, lest perchance he think We dare not move the question of our place Or know not what we are.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 34)
shall say so to him.   We saw him at the opening of his tent.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 35)
He is not sick.  Yes, lion-sick, sick of proud heart.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 36)
You may call it melancholy if you will favor the man, but, by my head, 'tis pride.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 37)
But, why, why? Let him show us a cause.--A word, my lord.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 38)
What moves Ajax thus to bay at him?  Achilles hath inveigled his fool from him.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 39)
Who, Thersites?  He.  Then will Ajax lack matter, if he have lost his argument.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 40)
No. You see, he is his argument that has his argument: Achilles.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 41)
All the better. Their fraction is more our wish than their faction.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 42)
But it was a strong composure a fool could disunite.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 43)
The amity that wisdom knits not, folly may easily untie.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 44)
Here comes Patroclus.  No Achilles with him.  The elephant hath joints, but none for courtesy; his legs are legs for necessity, not for flexure.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 45)
Achilles bids me say he is much sorry If anything more than your sport and pleasure Did move your greatness and this noble state To call upon him.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 46)
He hopes it is no other But for your health and your digestion sake, An after-dinner's breath.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 47)
Hear you, Patroclus: We are too well acquainted with these answers, But his evasion, winged thus swift with scorn, Cannot outfly our apprehensions.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 48)
Much attribute he hath, and much the reason Why we ascribe it to him.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 49)
Yet all his virtues, Not virtuously on his own part beheld, Do in our eyes begin to lose their gloss, Yea, and like fair fruit in an unwholesome dish, Are like to rot untasted.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 50)
Go and tell him We come to speak with him; and you shall not sin If you do say we think him overproud And underhonest, in self-assumption greater Than in the note of judgment; and worthier than himself Here tend the savage strangeness he puts on, Disguise the holy strength of their command, And underwrite in an observing kind His humorous predominance--yea, watch His course and time, his ebbs and flows, as if The passage and whole carriage of this action Rode on his tide.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 51)
Go tell him this, and add That, if he overhold his price so much, We'll none of him.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 52)
But let him, like an engine Not portable, lie under this report: "Bring action hither; this cannot go to war.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 53)
" stirring dwarf we do allowance give Before a sleeping giant.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 54)
Tell him so.   shall, and bring his answer presently.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 55)
In second voice we'll not be satisfied; We come to speak with him.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 56)
--Ulysses, enter you.   What is he more than another?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 57)
No more than what he thinks he is.  Is he so much?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 58)
Do you not think he thinks himself a better man than am?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 59)
No question.  Will you subscribe his thought and say he is?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 60)
No, noble Ajax. You are as strong, as valiant, as wise, no less noble, much more gentle, and altogether more tractable.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 61)
Why should a man be proud? How doth pride grow? know not what pride is.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 62)
Your mind is the clearer, Ajax, and your virtues the fairer.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 63)
He that is proud eats up himself. Pride is his own glass, his own trumpet, his own chronicle; and whatever praises itself but in the deed devours the deed in the praise.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 64)
do hate a proud man as hate the engendering of toads.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 65)
And yet he loves himself. Is 't not strange?      Achilles will not to the field tomorrow.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 66)
What's his excuse?  He doth rely on none, But carries on the stream of his dispose, Without observance or respect of any, In will peculiar and in self-admission.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 67)
Why, will he not, upon our fair request, Untent his person and share th' air with us?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 68)
Things small as nothing, for request's sake only, He makes important.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 69)
Possessed he is with greatness And speaks not to himself but with a pride That quarrels at self-breath.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 70)
Imagined worth Holds in his blood such swoll'n and hot discourse That 'twixt his mental and his active parts Kingdomed Achilles in commotion rages And batters down himself.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 71)
What should say? He is so plaguy proud that the death-tokens of it Cry "No recovery.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 72)
"  Let Ajax go to him.-- Dear lord, go you and greet him in his tent.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 73)
'Tis said he holds you well and will be led At your request a little from himself.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 74)
Agamemnon, let it not be so! We'll consecrate the steps that Ajax makes When they go from Achilles.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 75)
Shall the proud lord That bastes his arrogance with his own seam And never suffers matter of the world Enter his thoughts, save such as doth revolve And ruminate himself--shall he be worshipped Of that we hold an idol more than he?(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 76)
No. This thrice-worthy and right valiant lord Shall not so stale his palm, nobly acquired, Nor, by my will, assubjugate his merit, As amply titled as Achilles is, By going to Achilles.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 77)
That were to enlard his fat-already pride And add more coals to Cancer when he burns With entertaining great Hyperion.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 78)
This lord go to him? Jupiter forbid And say in thunder "Achilles, go to him.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 79)
"   this is well; he rubs the vein of him.   And how his silence drinks up this applause!(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 80)
If go to him, with my armed fist I'll pash him o'er the face.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 81)
no, you shall not go.   An he be proud with me, I'll feeze his pride.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 82)
Let me go to him.   Not for the worth that hangs upon our quarrel.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 83)
paltry, insolent fellow.  How he describes himself!(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 84)
Can he not be sociable?  The raven chides blackness.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 85)
I'll let his humorous blood.  He will be the physician that should be the patient.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 86)
An all men were of my mind--  Wit would be out of fashion.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 87)
--he should not bear it so; he should eat swords first.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 88)
Shall pride carry it?  An 'twould, you'd carry half.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 89)
He would have ten shares.  will knead him; I'll make him supple.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 90)
He's not yet through warm. Force him with praises.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 91)
Pour in, pour in; his ambition is dry.   My lord, you feed too much on this dislike.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 92)
Our noble general, do not do so.   You must prepare to fight without Achilles.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 93)
Why, 'tis this naming of him does him harm. Here is a man--but 'tis before his face; will be silent.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 94)
Wherefore should you so? He is not emulous, as Achilles is.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 95)
Know the whole world, he is as valiant--  whoreson dog, that shall palter with us thus!(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 96)
Would he were a Trojan!  What a vice were it in Ajax now--  If he were proud--  Or covetous of praise--  Ay, or surly borne--  Or strange, or self-affected--   Thank the heavens, lord, thou art of sweet composure.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 97)
Praise him that gat thee, she that gave thee suck; Famed be thy tutor, and thy parts of nature Thrice famed beyond, beyond thy erudition; But he that disciplined thine arms to fight, Let Mars divide eternity in twain And give him half; and for thy vigor, Bull-bearing Milo his addition yield To sinewy Ajax.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 98)
will not praise thy wisdom, Which like a bourn, a pale, a shore confines Thy spacious and dilated parts.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 99)
Here's Nestor, Instructed by the antiquary times; He must, he is, he cannot but be wise.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 100)
-- But pardon, father Nestor, were your days As green as Ajax' and your brain so tempered, You should not have the eminence of him, But be as Ajax.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 101)
Shall call you father?   Ay, my good son.  Be ruled by him, Lord Ajax.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 102)
There is no tarrying here; the hart Achilles Keeps thicket.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 103)
Please it our great general To call together all his state of war.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 104)
Fresh kings are come to Troy. Tomorrow We must with all our main of power stand fast.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 105)
And here's a lord--come knights from east to west And cull their flower, Ajax shall cope the best.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 106)
Go we to council. Let Achilles sleep. Light boats sail swift, though greater hulks draw deep.(Troilus and Cressida, Act 2, Scene 107)
What, have 'scaped love letters in the holiday time of my beauty, and am now a subject for them?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 0)
Let me see.  Ask me no reason why love you, for though Love use Reason for his precisian, he admits him not for his counselor.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 1)
You are not young; no more am Go to, then, there's sympathy.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 2)
You are merry; so am Ha, ha, then, there's more sympathy.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 3)
You love sack, and so do Would you desire better sympathy?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 4)
Let it suffice thee, Mistress Page--at the least, if the love of soldier can suffice--that love thee.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 5)
will not say pity me--'tis not a soldier-like phrase--but say love me.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 6)
By me, Thine own true knight, By day or night, Or any kind of light, With all his might For thee to fight, John Falstaff.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 7)
What a Herod of Jewry is this! wicked, wicked world!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 8)
One that is well-nigh worn to pieces with age, to show himself a young gallant!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 9)
What an unweighed behavior hath this Flemish drunkard picked--with the devil's name!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 10)
--out of my conversation, that he dares in this manner assay me?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 11)
Why, he hath not been thrice in my company! What should say to him?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 12)
was then frugal of my mirth. Heaven forgive me! Why, I'll exhibit a bill in the Parliament for the putting down of men.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 13)
How shall be revenged on him? For revenged will be, as sure as his guts are made of puddings.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 14)
Mistress Page! Trust me, was going to your house.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 15)
And, trust me, was coming to you. You look very ill.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 16)
Nay, I'll ne'er believe that. have to show to the contrary.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 17)
Faith, but you do, in my mind.  Well, do, then. Yet say could show you to the contrary.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 18)
Mistress Page, give me some counsel.  What's the matter, woman?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 19)
woman, if it were not for one trifling respect, could come to such honor!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 20)
Hang the trifle, woman; take the honor. What is it?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 21)
Dispense with trifles. What is it?  If would but go to hell for an eternal moment or so, could be knighted.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 22)
What, thou liest! Sir Alice Ford? These knights will hack, and so thou shouldst not alter the article of thy gentry.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 23)
We burn daylight. Here, read, read. Perceive how might be knighted.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 24)
shall think the worse of fat men as long as have an eye to make difference of men's liking.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 25)
And yet he would not swear; praised women's modesty; and gave such orderly and well-behaved reproof to all uncomeliness that would have sworn his disposition would have gone to the truth of his words.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 26)
But they do no more adhere and keep place together than the Hundredth Psalm to the tune of "Greensleeves.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 27)
" What tempest, trow, threw this whale, with so many tuns of oil in his belly, ashore at Windsor?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 28)
How shall be revenged on him? think the best way were to entertain him with hope till the wicked fire of lust have melted him in his own grease.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 29)
Did you ever hear the like?  Letter for letter, but that the name of Page and Ford differs!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 30)
To thy great comfort in this mystery of ill opinions, here's the twin brother of thy letter.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 31)
But let thine inherit first, for protest mine never shall.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 32)
warrant he hath a thousand of these letters writ with blank space for different names--sure, more--and these are of the second edition.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 33)
He will print them, out of doubt; for he cares not what he puts into the press, when he would put us two.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 34)
had rather be a giantess and lie under Mount Pelion.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 35)
Well, will find you twenty lascivious turtles ere one chaste man.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 36)
Why, this is the very same--the very hand, the very words.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 37)
What doth he think of us?  Nay, know not. It makes me almost ready to wrangle with mine own honesty.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 38)
I'll entertain myself like one that am not acquainted withal; for, sure, unless he know some strain in me that know not myself, he would never have boarded me in this fury.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 39)
"Boarding" call you it? I'll be sure to keep him above deck.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 40)
So will If he come under my hatches, I'll never to sea again.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 41)
Let's be revenged on him. Let's appoint him a meeting, give him a show of comfort in his suit, and lead him on with a fine-baited delay till he hath pawned his horses to mine Host of the Garter.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 42)
Nay, will consent to act any villainy against him that may not sully the chariness of our honesty.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 43)
that my husband saw this letter! It would give eternal food to his jealousy.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 44)
Why, look where he comes, and my good man too. He's as far from jealousy as am from giving him cause, and that, hope, is an unmeasurable distance.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 45)
You are the happier woman.  Let's consult together against this greasy knight.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 46)
Come hither.     Well, hope it be not so.   Hope is a curtal dog in some affairs.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 47)
Sir John affects thy wife.  Why, sir, my wife is not young.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 48)
He woos both high and low, both rich and poor, Both young and old, one with another, Ford.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 49)
He loves the gallimaufry. Ford, perpend.  Love my wife?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 50)
With liver burning hot. Prevent, Or go thou like Sir Acteon, he, With Ringwood at thy heels.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 51)
odious is the name!  What name, sir?  The horn, say.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 52)
Farewell. Take heed, have open eye, for thieves do foot by night.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 53)
Take heed, ere summer comes or cuckoo birds do sing.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 54)
-- Away, Sir Corporal Nym.--Believe it, Page. He speaks sense.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 55)
will be patient. will find out this.  And this is true.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 56)
like not the humor of lying. He hath wronged me in some humors.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 57)
should have borne the humored letter to her; but have a sword, and it shall bite upon my necessity.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 58)
He loves your wife; there's the short and the long.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 59)
My name is Corporal Nym. speak and avouch. 'Tis true.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 60)
My name is Nym, and Falstaff loves your wife. Adieu.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 61)
love not the humor of bread and cheese. Adieu.  "The humor of it," quoth he?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 62)
Here's a fellow frights English out of his wits.  will seek out Falstaff.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 63)
never heard such a drawling, affecting rogue.  If do find it--well.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 64)
will not believe such a Cataian, though the priest o' th' town commended him for a true man.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 65)
'Twas a good sensible fellow--well.      How now, Meg?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 66)
