--Will you go, Mistress Page?  Have with you.--You'll come to dinner, George?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 70)
Look who comes yonder.    She shall be our messenger to this paltry knight.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 71)
Trust me, thought on her. She'll fit it.  You are come to see my daughter Anne?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 72)
Ay, forsooth. And, pray, how does good Mistress Anne?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 73)
Go in with us and see. We have an hour's talk with you.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 74)
How now, Master Ford?  You heard what this knave told me, did you not?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 75)
Yes, and you heard what the other told me?  Do you think there is truth in them?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 76)
Hang 'em, slaves! do not think the knight would offer it.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 77)
But these that accuse him in his intent towards our wives are a yoke of his discarded men, very rogues, now they be out of service.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 78)
Were they his men?  Marry, were they.  like it never the better for that.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 79)
Does he lie at the Garter?  Ay, marry, does he. If he should intend this voyage toward my wife, would turn her loose to him; and what he gets more of her than sharp words, let it lie on my head.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 80)
do not misdoubt my wife, but would be loath to turn them together.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 81)
man may be too confident. would have nothing lie on my head.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 82)
cannot be thus satisfied.     Look where my ranting Host of the Garter comes.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 83)
There is either liquor in his pate or money in his purse when he looks so merrily.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 84)
--How now, mine Host?  How now, bullyrook? Thou 'rt a gentleman.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 85)
-- Cavaleiro Justice, say!     follow, mine Host, follow.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 86)
--Good even and twenty, good Master Page. Master Page, will you go with us?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 87)
We have sport in hand.  Tell him, Cavaleiro Justice; tell him, bullyrook.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 88)
Sir, there is a fray to be fought between Sir Hugh the Welsh priest and Caius the French doctor.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 89)
Good mine Host o' th' Garter, a word with you.  What say'st thou, my bullyrook?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 90)
Will you go with us to behold it? My merry Host hath had the measuring of their weapons and, think, hath appointed them contrary places; for, believe me, hear the parson is no jester.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 91)
Hark, will tell you what our sport shall be.   Hast thou no suit against my knight, my guest cavalier?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 92)
None, protest. But I'll give you a pottle of burnt sack to give me recourse to him, and tell him my name is Brook--only for a jest.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 93)
My hand, bully. Thou shalt have egress and regress--said well?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 94)
--and thy name shall be Brook. It is a merry knight.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 95)
Will you go, ameers?  Have with you, mine Host.  have heard the Frenchman hath good skill in his rapier.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 96)
Tut, sir, could have told you more. In these times you stand on distance--your passes, stoccados, and know not what.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 97)
'Tis the heart, Master Page; 'tis here, 'tis here.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 98)
have seen the time, with my long sword would have made you four tall fellows skip like rats.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 99)
Here, boys, here, here! Shall we wag?  Have with you.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 100)
had rather hear them scold than fight.  Though Page be a secure fool and stands so firmly on his wife's frailty, yet cannot put off my opinion so easily.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 101)
She was in his company at Page's house, and what they made there know not.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 102)
Well, will look further into 't, and have a disguise to sound Falstaff.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 103)
If find her honest, lose not my labor. If she be otherwise, 'tis labor well bestowed.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 0, Scene 104)
will not lend thee a penny.  Why then, the world's mine oyster, which with sword will open.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 0)
Not a penny. have been content, sir, you should lay my countenance to pawn.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 1)
have grated upon my good friends for three reprieves for you and your coach-fellow Nym, or else you had looked through the grate like a gemini of baboons.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 2)
am damned in hell for swearing to gentlemen my friends you were good soldiers and tall fellows.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 3)
And when Mistress Bridget lost the handle of her fan, took 't upon mine honor thou hadst it not.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 4)
Didst not thou share? Hadst thou not fifteen pence?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 5)
Reason, you rogue, reason. Think'st thou I'll endanger my soul gratis?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 6)
At a word, hang no more about me. am no gibbet for you.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 7)
Go--a short knife and a throng--to your manor of Pickt-hatch, go.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 8)
You'll not bear a letter for me, you rogue? You stand upon your honor?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 9)
Why, thou unconfinable baseness, it is as much as can do to keep the terms of my honor precise.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 10)
Ay, ay, myself sometimes, leaving the fear of God on the left hand and hiding mine honor in my necessity, am fain to shuffle, to hedge, and to lurch; and yet you, rogue, will ensconce your rags, your cat-a-mountain looks, your red-lattice phrases, and your bold beating oaths under the shelter of your honor!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 11)
You will not do it? You?  do relent. What would thou more of man?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 12)
Sir, here's a woman would speak with you.  Let her approach.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 13)
Give your Worship good morrow.  Good morrow, goodwife.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 14)
Not so, an 't please your Worship.  Good maid, then.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 15)
I'll be sworn--as my mother was, the first hour was born.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 16)
do believe the swearer. What with me?  Shall vouchsafe your Worship a word or two?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 17)
Two thousand, fair woman, and I'll vouchsafe thee the hearing.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 18)
There is one Mistress Ford, sir--I pray, come a little nearer this ways.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 19)
myself dwell with Master Doctor Caius.  Well, on.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 20)
"Mistress Ford," you say--  Your Worship says very true.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 21)
pray your Worship, come a little nearer this ways.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 22)
warrant thee, nobody hears. Mine own people, mine own people.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 23)
Are they so? God bless them and make them His servants!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 24)
Well, "Mistress Ford"--what of her?  Why, sir, she's a good creature.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 25)
Lord, Lord, your Worship's a wanton! Well, heaven forgive you and all of us, pray!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 26)
"Mistress Ford"--come, "Mistress Ford"--  Marry, this is the short and the long of it: you have brought her into such a canaries as 'tis wonderful.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 27)
The best courtier of them all, when the court lay at Windsor, could never have brought her to such a canary.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 28)
Yet there has been knights, and lords, and gentlemen, with their coaches, warrant you, coach after coach, letter after letter, gift after gift, smelling so sweetly--all musk--and so rushling, warrant you, in silk and gold, and in such alligant terms, and in such wine and sugar of the best and the fairest, that would have won any woman's heart; and, warrant you, they could never get an eye-wink of her.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 29)
had myself twenty angels given me this morning, but defy all angels in any such sort, as they say, but in the way of honesty.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 30)
And, warrant you, they could never get her so much as sip on a cup with the proudest of them all.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 31)
And yet there has been earls--nay, which is more, pensioners--but, warrant you, all is one with her.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 32)
But what says she to me? Be brief, my good she-Mercury.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 33)
Marry, she hath received your letter, for the which she thanks you a thousand times, and she gives you to notify that her husband will be absence from his house between ten and eleven.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 34)
Ten and eleven?  Ay, forsooth; and then you may come and see the picture, she says, that you wot of.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 35)
Master Ford, her husband, will be from home. Alas, the sweet woman leads an ill life with him.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 36)
He's a very jealousy man. She leads a very frampold life with him, good heart.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 37)
Ten and eleven. Woman, commend me to her. will not fail her.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 38)
Why, you say well. But have another messenger to your Worship.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 39)
Mistress Page hath her hearty commendations to you too; and, let me tell you in your ear, she's as fartuous a civil modest wife, and one, tell you, that will not miss you morning nor evening prayer, as any is in Windsor, whoe'er be the other.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 40)
And she bade me tell your Worship that her husband is seldom from home, but she hopes there will come a time.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 41)
never knew a woman so dote upon a man. Surely, think you have charms, la!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 42)
Yes, in truth.  Not assure thee. Setting the attraction of my good parts aside, have no other charms.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 43)
Blessing on your heart for 't!  But pray thee, tell me this: has Ford's wife and Page's wife acquainted each other how they love me?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 44)
That were a jest indeed! They have not so little grace, hope.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 45)
That were a trick indeed! But Mistress Page would desire you to send her your little page, of all loves.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 46)
Her husband has a marvelous infection to the little page; and, truly, Master Page is an honest man.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 47)
Never a wife in Windsor leads a better life than she does.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 48)
Do what she will, say what she will, take all, pay all, go to bed when she list, rise when she list--all is as she will.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 49)
And, truly, she deserves it, for if there be a kind woman in Windsor, she is one.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 50)
You must send her your page, no remedy.  Why, will.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 51)
Nay, but do so then, and, look you, he may come and go between you both.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 52)
And in any case have a nayword, that you may know one another's mind, and the boy never need to understand anything; for 'tis not good that children should know any wickedness.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 53)
Old folks, you know, have discretion, as they say, and know the world.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 54)
Fare thee well. Commend me to them both. There's my purse.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 55)
am yet thy debtor.--Boy, go along with this woman.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 56)
This news distracts me.   This punk is one of Cupid's carriers.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 57)
Clap on more sails, pursue; up with your fights; Give fire!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 58)
She is my prize, or ocean whelm them all!   Sayst thou so, old Jack?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 59)
Go thy ways. I'll make more of thy old body than have done.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 60)
Will they yet look after thee? Wilt thou, after the expense of so much money, be now a gainer?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 61)
Good body, thank thee. Let them say 'tis grossly done; so it be fairly done, no matter.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 62)
Sir John, there's one Master Brook below would fain speak with you and be acquainted with you, and hath sent your Worship a morning's draught of sack.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 63)
Brook is his name?  Ay, sir.  Call him in. Such Brooks are welcome to me that o'erflows such liquor.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 64)
Ah ha, Mistress Ford and Mistress Page, have encompassed you?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 65)
Go to. Via!     God bless you, sir.  And you, sir.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 66)
Would you speak with me?  make bold to press with so little preparation upon you.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 67)
You're welcome. What's your will?--Give us leave, drawer.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 68)
Sir, am a gentleman that have spent much. My name is Brook.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 69)
Good Master Brook, desire more acquaintance of you.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 70)
Good Sir John, sue for yours--not to charge you, for must let you understand think myself in better plight for a lender than you are, the which hath something emboldened me to this unseasoned intrusion; for they say, if money go before, all ways do lie open.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 71)
Money is a good soldier, sir, and will on.  Troth, and have a bag of money here troubles me.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 72)
If you will help to bear it, Sir John, take all, or half, for easing me of the carriage.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 73)
Sir, know not how may deserve to be your porter.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 74)
will tell you, sir, if you will give me the hearing.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 75)
Speak, good Master Brook. shall be glad to be your servant.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 76)
Sir, hear you are a scholar--I will be brief with you--and you have been a man long known to me, though had never so good means as desire to make myself acquainted with you.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 77)
shall discover a thing to you wherein must very much lay open mine own imperfection.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 78)
But, good Sir John, as you have one eye upon my follies, as you hear them unfolded, turn another into the register of your own, that may pass with a reproof the easier, sith you yourself know how easy it is to be such an offender.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 79)
Very well, sir. Proceed.  There is a gentlewoman in this town--her husband's name is Ford.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 80)
Well, sir.  have long loved her and, protest to you, bestowed much on her, followed her with a doting observance, engrossed opportunities to meet her, fee'd every slight occasion that could but niggardly give me sight of her, not only bought many presents to give her, but have given largely to many to know what she would have given.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 81)
Briefly, have pursued her as love hath pursued me, which hath been on the wing of all occasions.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 82)
But whatsoever have merited, either in my mind or in my means, meed am sure have received none, unless experience be a jewel.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 83)
That have purchased at an infinite rate, and that hath taught me to say this: "Love like a shadow flies when substance love pursues, Pursuing that that flies, and flying what pursues.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 84)
"  Have you received no promise of satisfaction at her hands?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 85)
Never.  Have you importuned her to such a purpose?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 86)
Never.  Of what quality was your love, then?  Like a fair house built on another man's ground, so that have lost my edifice by mistaking the place where erected it.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 87)
To what purpose have you unfolded this to me?  When have told you that, have told you all.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 88)
Some say that though she appear honest to me, yet in other places she enlargeth her mirth so far that there is shrewd construction made of her.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 89)
Now, Sir John, here is the heart of my purpose: you are a gentleman of excellent breeding, admirable discourse, of great admittance, authentic in your place and person, generally allowed for your many warlike, courtlike, and learned preparations.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 90)
sir!  Believe it, for you know it. There is money.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 91)
Spend it, spend it, spend more; spend all have. Only give me so much of your time in exchange of it as to lay an amiable siege to the honesty of this Ford's wife.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 92)
Use your art of wooing; win her to consent to you.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 93)
If any man may, you may as soon as any.  Would it apply well to the vehemency of your affection that should win what you would enjoy?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 94)
Methinks you prescribe to yourself very preposterously.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 95)
understand my drift. She dwells so securely on the excellency of her honor that the folly of my soul dares not present itself; she is too bright to be looked against.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 96)
Now, could come to her with any detection in my hand, my desires had instance and argument to commend themselves.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 97)
could drive her then from the ward of her purity, her reputation, her marriage vow, and a thousand other her defenses, which now are too too strongly embattled against me.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 98)
What say you to 't, Sir John?  Master Brook, will first make bold with your money; next, give me your hand; and, last, as am a gentleman, you shall, if you will, enjoy Ford's wife.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 99)
good sir!  say you shall.  Want no money, Sir John; you shall want none.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 100)
Want no Mistress Ford, Master Brook; you shall want none.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 101)
shall be with her, may tell you, by her own appointment.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 102)
Even as you came in to me, her assistant or go-between parted from me.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 103)
say shall be with her between ten and eleven, for at that time the jealous, rascally knave her husband will be forth.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 104)
Come you to me at night. You shall know how speed.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 105)
am blessed in your acquaintance. Do you know Ford, sir?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 106)
Hang him, poor cuckoldly knave! know him not. Yet wrong him to call him poor.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 107)
They say the jealous wittolly knave hath masses of money, for the which his wife seems to me well-favored.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 108)
will use her as the key of the cuckoldly rogue's coffer, and there's my harvest home.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 109)
would you knew Ford, sir, that you might avoid him if you saw him.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 110)
Hang him, mechanical salt-butter rogue! will stare him out of his wits.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 111)
will awe him with my cudgel; it shall hang like a meteor o'er the cuckold's horns.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 112)
Master Brook, thou shalt know will predominate over the peasant, and thou shalt lie with his wife.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 113)
Come to me soon at night. Ford's a knave, and will aggravate his style.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 114)
Thou, Master Brook, shalt know him for knave and cuckold.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 115)
Come to me soon at night.  What a damned epicurean rascal is this!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 116)
My heart is ready to crack with impatience. Who says this is improvident jealousy?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 117)
My wife hath sent to him, the hour is fixed, the match is made.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 118)
Would any man have thought this? See the hell of having a false woman: my bed shall be abused, my coffers ransacked, my reputation gnawn at.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 119)
And shall not only receive this villainous wrong but stand under the adoption of abominable terms, and by him that does me this wrong.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 120)
Terms, names! "Amaimon" sounds well, "Lucifer" well, "Barbason" well; yet they are devils' additions, the names of fiends.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 121)
But "Cuckold," "Wittoll," "Cuckold"! The devil himself hath not such a name.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 122)
Page is an ass, a secure ass. He will trust his wife, he will not be jealous.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 123)
will rather trust a Fleming with my butter, Parson Hugh the Welshman with my cheese, an Irishman with my aquavitae bottle, or a thief to walk my ambling gelding, than my wife with herself.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 124)
Then she plots, then she ruminates, then she devises; and what they think in their hearts they may effect, they will break their hearts but they will effect.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 125)
God be praised for my jealousy! Eleven o'clock the hour.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 126)
will prevent this, detect my wife, be revenged on Falstaff, and laugh at Page.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 127)
will about it. Better three hours too soon than a minute too late.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 1, Scene 128)
Jack Rugby.  Sir?  Vat is the clock, Jack?  'Tis past the hour, sir, that Sir Hugh promised to meet.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 0)
By gar, he has save his soul dat he is no come. He has pray his Pible well dat he is no come.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 1)
By gar, Jack Rugby, he is dead already if he be come.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 2)
He is wise, sir. He knew your Worship would kill him if he came.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 3)
By gar, de herring is no dead so as vill kill him.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 4)
Take your rapier, Jack. vill tell you how vill kill him.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 5)
Alas, sir, cannot fence.  Villainy, take your rapier.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 6)
Forbear. Here's company.     God bless thee, bully doctor!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 7)
God save you, Master Doctor Caius!  Now, good Master Doctor!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 8)
Give you good morrow, sir.  Vat be all you, one, two, tree, four, come for?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 9)
To see thee fight, to see thee foin, to see thee traverse; to see thee here, to see thee there; to see thy pass, thy puncto, thy stock, thy reverse, thy distance, thy montant.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 10)
Is he dead, my Ethiopian? Is he dead, my Francisco?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 11)
Ha, bully? What says my Aesculapius, my Galien, my heart of elder, ha?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 12)
Is he dead, bully stale? Is he dead?  By gar, he is de coward jack-priest of de vorld.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 13)
He is not show his face.  Thou art a Castalion King Urinal Hector of Greece, my boy!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 14)
pray you, bear witness that me have stay six or seven, two, tree hours for him, and he is no come.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 15)
He is the wiser man, Master Doctor. He is a curer of souls, and you a curer of bodies.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 16)
If you should fight, you go against the hair of your professions.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 17)
-- Is it not true, Master Page?  Master Shallow, you have yourself been a great fighter, though now a man of peace.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 18)
Bodykins, Master Page, though now be old and of the peace, if see a sword out, my finger itches to make one.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 19)
Though we are justices and doctors and churchmen, Master Page, we have some salt of our youth in us.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 20)
We are the sons of women, Master Page.  'Tis true, Master Shallow.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 21)
It will be found so, Master Page.--Master Doctor Caius, am come to fetch you home.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 22)
am sworn of the peace. You have showed yourself a wise physician, and Sir Hugh hath shown himself a wise and patient churchman.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 23)
You must go with me, Master Doctor.  Pardon, guest Justice.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 24)
word, Monsieur Mockwater.  "Mockvater"? Vat is dat?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 25)
"Mockwater," in our English tongue, is "valor," bully.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 26)
By gar, then have as much mockvater as de Englishman.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 27)
Scurvy jack-dog priest! By gar, me vill cut his ears.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 28)
He will clapper-claw thee tightly, bully.  "Clapper-de-claw"?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 29)
Vat is dat?  That is, he will make thee amends.  By gar, me do look he shall clapper-de-claw me, for, by gar, me vill have it.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 30)
And will provoke him to 't, or let him wag.  Me tank you for dat.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 31)
And moreover, bully-- But first, Master guest, and Master Page, and eke Cavaleiro Slender, go you through the town to Frogmore.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 32)
Sir Hugh is there, is he?  He is there. See what humor he is in; and will bring the doctor about by the fields.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 33)
Will it do well?  We will do it.  and Adieu, good Master Doctor.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 34)
By gar, me vill kill de priest, for he speak for a jackanape to Anne Page.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 35)
Let him die. Sheathe thy impatience; throw cold water on thy choler.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 36)
Go about the fields with me through Frogmore. will bring thee where Mistress Anne Page is, at a farmhouse a-feasting, and thou shalt woo her.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 37)
Cried game! Said well?  By gar, me dank you vor dat.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 38)
By gar, love you, and shall procure-a you de good guest: de earl, de knight, de lords, de gentlemen, my patients.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 39)
For the which will be thy adversary toward Anne Page.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 40)
Said well?  By gar, 'tis good. Vell said.  Let us wag, then.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 2, Scene 41)
pray you now, good Master Slender's servingman and friend Simple by your name, which way have you looked for Master Caius, that calls himself doctor of physic?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 0)
Marry, sir, the Petty-ward, the Park-ward, every way; Old Windsor way, and every way but the town way.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 1)
most fehemently desire you, you will also look that way.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 2)
will, sir.  Pless my soul, how full of cholers am, and trempling of mind!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 3)
shall be glad if he have deceived me. How melancholies am!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 4)
will knog his urinals about his knave's costard when have good opportunities for the 'ork.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 5)
Pless my soul!  To shallow rivers, to whose falls Melodious birds sings madrigals.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 6)
There will we make our peds of roses And a thousand fragrant posies.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 7)
To shallow-- Mercy on me, have a great dispositions to cry.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 8)
Melodious birds sing madrigals-- Whenas sat in Pabylon-- And a thousand vagram posies.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 9)
To shallow rivers, to whose falls Melodious birds sings madrigals.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 10)
Yonder he is, coming this way, Sir Hugh.  He's welcome.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 11)
To shallow rivers, to whose falls-- Heaven prosper the right!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 12)
What weapons is he?  No weapons, sir. There comes my master, Master Shallow, and another gentleman, from Frogmore, over the stile, this way.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 13)
Pray you, give me my gown--or else keep it in your arms.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 14)
How now, Master Parson? Good morrow, good Sir Hugh.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 15)
Keep a gamester from the dice, and a good student from his book, and it is wonderful.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 16)
Ah, sweet Anne Page!  God save you, good Sir Hugh!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 17)
God pless you from His mercy sake, all of you!  What, the sword and the word?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 18)
Do you study them both, Master Parson?  And youthful still--in your doublet and hose this raw rheumatic day?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 19)
There is reasons and causes for it.  We are come to you to do a good office, Master Parson.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 20)
Fery well. What is it?  Yonder is a most reverend gentleman who, belike having received wrong by some person, is at most odds with his own gravity and patience that ever you saw.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 21)
have lived fourscore years and upward. never heard a man of his place, gravity, and learning so wide of his own respect.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 22)
What is he?  think you know him: Master Doctor Caius, the renowned French physician.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 23)
Got's will and His passion of my heart! had as lief you would tell me of a mess of porridge.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 24)
Why?  He has no more knowledge in Hibbocrates and Galen--and he is a knave besides, a cowardly knave as you would desires to be acquainted withal.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 25)
warrant you, he's the man should fight with him.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 26)
sweet Anne Page!  It appears so by his weapons. Keep them asunder.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 27)
Here comes Doctor Caius.      Nay, good Master Parson, keep in your weapon.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 28)
So do you, good Master Doctor.  Disarm them, and let them question.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 29)
Let them keep their limbs whole and hack our English.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 30)
pray you, let-a me speak a word with your ear. Verefore vill you not meet-a me?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 31)
Pray you, use your patience. In good time.  By gar, you are de coward, de Jack dog, John ape.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 32)
Pray you, let us not be laughing-stocks to other men's humors.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 33)
desire you in friendship, and will one way or other make you amends.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 34)
By Jeshu, will knog your urinal about your knave's cogscomb.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 35)
Diable! Jack Rugby, mine Host de Jarteer, have not stay for him to kill him?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 36)
Have not, at de place did appoint?  As am a Christians soul, now look you, this is the place appointed.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 37)
I'll be judgment by mine Host of the Garter.  Peace, say, Gallia and Gaul, French and Welsh, soul-curer and body-curer!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 38)
Ay, dat is very good, excellent.  Peace, say! Hear mine Host of the Garter.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 39)
Am politic? Am subtle? Am a Machiavel? Shall lose my doctor?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 40)
No, he gives me the potions and the motions. Shall lose my parson, my priest, my Sir Hugh?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 41)
No, he gives me the proverbs and the no-verbs.  Give me thy hand, terrestrial; so.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 42)
Give me thy hand, celestial; so. Boys of art, have deceived you both.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 43)
have directed you to wrong places. Your hearts are mighty, your skins are whole, and let burnt sack be the issue.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 44)
Come, lay their swords to pawn.  Follow me, lads of peace, follow, follow, follow.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 45)
Afore God, a mad Host. Follow, gentlemen, follow.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 46)
sweet Anne Page!   Ha, do perceive dat? Have you make-a de sot of us, ha, ha?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 47)
This is well! He has made us his vloutingstog. desire you that we may be friends, and let us knog our prains together to be revenge on this same scall, scurvy, cogging companion, the Host of the Garter.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 48)
By gar, with all my heart. He promise to bring me where is Anne Page.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 49)
By gar, he deceive me too.  Well, will smite his noddles.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 50)
Nay, keep your way, little gallant. You were wont to be a follower, but now you are a leader.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 0)
Whether had you rather--lead mine eyes, or eye your master's heels?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 1)
had rather, forsooth, go before you like a man than follow him like a dwarf.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 2)
you are a flattering boy! Now see you'll be a courtier.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 3)
Well met, Mistress Page. Whither go you?  Truly, sir, to see your wife.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 4)
Is she at home?  Ay, and as idle as she may hang together, for want of company.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 5)
think if your husbands were dead, you two would marry.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 6)
Be sure of that--two other husbands.  Where had you this pretty weathercock?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 7)
cannot tell what the dickens his name is my husband had him of.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 8)
--What do you call your knight's name, sirrah?  Sir John Falstaff.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 9)
Sir John Falstaff!  He, he. can never hit on 's name.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 10)
There is such a league between my goodman and he.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 11)
Is your wife at home indeed?  Indeed, she is.  By your leave, sir.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 12)
am sick till see her.  Has Page any brains? Hath he any eyes?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 13)
Hath he any thinking? Sure they sleep; he hath no use of them.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 14)
Why, this boy will carry a letter twenty mile as easy as a cannon will shoot point-blank twelve score.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 15)
He pieces out his wife's inclination. He gives her folly motion and advantage.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 16)
And now she's going to my wife, and Falstaff's boy with her.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 17)
man may hear this shower sing in the wind. And Falstaff's boy with her!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 18)
Good plots they are laid, and our revolted wives share damnation together.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 19)
Well, will take him, then torture my wife, pluck the borrowed veil of modesty from the so-seeming Mistress Page, divulge Page himself for a secure and willful Acteon, and to these violent proceedings all my neighbors shall cry aim.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 20)
clock The clock gives me my cue, and my assurance bids me search.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 21)
There shall find Falstaff. shall be rather praised for this than mocked, for it is as positive as the earth is firm that Falstaff is there.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 22)
will go.      Well met, Master Ford.  Trust me, a good knot.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 23)
have good cheer at home, and pray you all go with me.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 24)
must excuse myself, Master Ford.  And so must sir.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 25)
We have appointed to dine with Mistress Anne, and would not break with her for more money than I'll speak of.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 26)
We have lingered about a match between Anne Page and my cousin Slender, and this day we shall have our answer.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 27)
hope have your good will, Father Page.  You have, Master Slender.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 28)
stand wholly for you.--But my wife, Master Doctor, is for you altogether.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 29)
Ay, be-gar, and de maid is love-a me! My nursh-a Quickly tell me so mush.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 30)
What say you to young Master Fenton? He capers, he dances, he has eyes of youth, he writes verses, he speaks holiday, he smells April and May.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 31)
He will carry 't, he will carry 't. 'Tis in his buttons he will carry 't.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 32)
Not by my consent, promise you. The gentleman is of no having.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 33)
He kept company with the wild Prince and Poins. He is of too high a region; he knows too much.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 34)
No, he shall not knit a knot in his fortunes with the finger of my substance.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 35)
If he take her, let him take her simply. The wealth have waits on my consent, and my consent goes not that way.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 36)
beseech you heartily, some of you go home with me to dinner.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 37)
Besides your cheer, you shall have sport: will show you a monster.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 38)
Master Doctor, you shall go.--So shall you, Master Page.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 39)
-- And you, Sir Hugh.  Well, fare you well. We shall have the freer wooing at Master Page's.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 40)
Go home, John Rugby. come anon.   Farewell, my hearts.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 41)
will to my honest knight Falstaff, and drink canary with him.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 42)
think shall drink in pipe-wine first with him; I'll make him dance.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 43)
--Will you go, gentles?  and Have with you to see this monster.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 24, Scene 44)
3       What, John! What, Robert!  Quickly, quickly!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 0)
Is the buck-basket--  warrant.--What, Robert, say!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 1)
Come, come, come.  Here, set it down.  Give your men the charge.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 2)
We must be brief.  Marry, as told you before, John and Robert, be ready here hard by in the brewhouse, and when suddenly call you, come forth, and without any pause or staggering take this basket on your shoulders.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 3)
That done, trudge with it in all haste, and carry it among the whitsters in Datchet Mead, and there empty it in the muddy ditch close by the Thames side.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 4)
You will do it?  ha' told them over and over. They lack no direction.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 5)
--Be gone, and come when you are called.  Here comes little Robin.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 6)
How now, my eyas-musket? What news with you?  My master, Sir John, is come in at your back door, Mistress Ford, and requests your company.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 7)
You little Jack-a-Lent, have you been true to us?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 8)
Ay, I'll be sworn. My master knows not of your being here and hath threatened to put me into everlasting liberty if tell you of it, for he swears he'll turn me away.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 9)
Thou 'rt a good boy. This secrecy of thine shall be a tailor to thee and shall make thee a new doublet and hose.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 10)
--I'll go hide me.  Do so.--Go tell thy master am alone.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 11)
Mistress Page, remember you your cue.  warrant thee.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 12)
If do not act it, hiss me.  Go to, then. We'll use this unwholesome humidity, this gross-wat'ry pumpion.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 13)
We'll teach him to know turtles from jays.     "Have caught thee, my heavenly jewel?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 14)
" Why, now let me die, for have lived long enough.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 15)
This is the period of my ambition. this blessed hour!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 16)
sweet Sir John!  Mistress Ford, cannot cog. cannot prate, Mistress Ford.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 17)
Now shall sin in my wish: would thy husband were dead.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 18)
I'll speak it before the best lord: would make thee my lady.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 19)
your lady, Sir John? Alas, should be a pitiful lady.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 20)
Let the court of France show me such another. see how thine eye would emulate the diamond.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 21)
Thou hast the right arched beauty of the brow that becomes the ship-tire, the tire-valiant, or any tire of Venetian admittance.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 22)
plain kerchief, Sir John. My brows become nothing else, nor that well neither.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 23)
Thou art a tyrant to say so. Thou wouldst make an absolute courtier, and the firm fixture of thy foot would give an excellent motion to thy gait in a semicircled farthingale.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 24)
see what thou wert, if Fortune thy foe were not, Nature thy friend.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 25)
Come, thou canst not hide it.  Believe me, there's no such thing in me.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 26)
What made me love thee? Let that persuade thee. There's something extraordinary in thee.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 27)
Come, cannot cog and say thou art this and that like a many of these lisping hawthorn buds that come like women in men's apparel and smell like Bucklersbury in simple time.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 28)
cannot. But love thee, none but thee; and thou deserv'st it.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 29)
Do not betray me, sir. fear you love Mistress Page.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 30)
Thou mightst as well say love to walk by the Counter gate, which is as hateful to me as the reek of a lime-kiln.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 31)
Well, heaven knows how love you, and you shall one day find it.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 32)
Keep in that mind. I'll deserve it.  Nay, must tell you, so you do, or else could not be in that mind.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 33)
Mistress Ford, Mistress Ford! Here's Mistress Page at the door, sweating and blowing and looking wildly, and would needs speak with you presently.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 34)
She shall not see me. will ensconce me behind the arras.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 35)
Pray you, do so. She's a very tattling woman.    What's the matter?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 36)
How now?  Mistress Ford, what have you done? You're shamed, you're overthrown, you're undone forever!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 37)
What's the matter, good Mistress Page?  well-a-day, Mistress Ford, having an honest man to your husband, to give him such cause of suspicion!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 38)
What cause of suspicion?  What cause of suspicion?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 39)
Out upon you! How am mistook in you!  Why, alas, what's the matter?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 40)
Your husband's coming hither, woman, with all the officers in Windsor, to search for a gentleman that he says is here now in the house, by your consent, to take an ill advantage of his absence.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 41)
You are undone.  'Tis not so, hope.  Pray heaven it be not so, that you have such a man here!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 42)
But 'tis most certain your husband's coming, with half Windsor at his heels, to search for such a one.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 43)
come before to tell you. If you know yourself clear, why, am glad of it.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 44)
But if you have a friend here, convey, convey him out.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 45)
Be not amazed! Call all your senses to you; defend your reputation, or bid farewell to your good life forever.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 46)
What shall do? There is a gentleman, my dear friend; and fear not mine own shame so much as his peril.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 47)
had rather than a thousand pound he were out of the house.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 48)
For shame! Never stand "you had rather" and "you had rather.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 49)
" Your husband's here at hand. Bethink you of some conveyance.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 50)
In the house you cannot hide him. how have you deceived me!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 51)
Look, here is a basket. If he be of any reasonable stature, he may creep in here; and throw foul linen upon him, as if it were going to bucking.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 52)
Or--it is whiting time--send him by your two men to Datchet Mead.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 53)
He's too big to go in there. What shall do?  Let me see 't, let me see 't!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 54)
let me see 't! I'll in, I'll in. Follow your friend's counsel.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 55)
I'll in.  What, Sir John Falstaff? Are these your letters, knight?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 56)
love thee. Help me away. Let me creep in here. I'll never--       Help to cover your master, boy.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 57)
--Call your men, Mistress Ford.--You dissembling knight!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 58)
What, John! Robert! John!    Go, take up these clothes here quickly.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 59)
Where's the cowlstaff? Look how you drumble! Carry them to the laundress in Datchet Mead.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 60)
Quickly! Come.      Pray you, come near. If suspect without cause, why then make sport at me.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 61)
Then let me be your jest; deserve it.--How now? Whither bear you this?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 62)
and To the laundress, forsooth.  Why, what have you to do whither they bear it?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 63)
You were best meddle with buck-washing!  Buck? would could wash myself of the buck.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 64)
Buck, buck, buck! Ay, buck! warrant you, buck, and of the season too, it shall appear.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 65)
Gentlemen, have dreamed tonight; I'll tell you my dream.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 66)
Here, here, here be my keys. Ascend my chambers. Search, seek, find out.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 67)
I'll warrant we'll unkennel the fox. Let me stop this way first.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 68)
So, now uncape.  Good Master Ford, be contented. You wrong yourself too much.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 69)
True, Master Page.--Up, gentlemen. You shall see sport anon.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 70)
Follow me, gentlemen.  This is fery fantastical humors and jealousies.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 71)
By gar, 'tis no the fashion of France. It is not jealous in France.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 72)
Nay, follow him, gentlemen. See the issue of his search.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 73)
Is there not a double excellency in this?  know not which pleases me better-- that my husband is deceived, or Sir John.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 74)
What a taking was he in when your husband asked who was in the basket!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 75)
am half afraid he will have need of washing, so throwing him into the water will do him a benefit.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 76)
Hang him, dishonest rascal! would all of the same strain were in the same distress.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 77)
think my husband hath some special suspicion of Falstaff's being here, for never saw him so gross in his jealousy till now.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 78)
will lay a plot to try that, and we will yet have more tricks with Falstaff.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 79)
His dissolute disease will scarce obey this medicine.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 80)
Shall we send that foolish carrion Mistress Quickly to him, and excuse his throwing into the water, and give him another hope, to betray him to another punishment?(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 81)
We will do it. Let him be sent for tomorrow eight o'clock to have amends.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 82)
cannot find him. Maybe the knave bragged of that he could not compass.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 83)

Ay, do so.  Heaven make you better than your thoughts!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 85)
Amen!  You do yourself mighty wrong, Master Ford.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 86)

would not ha' your distemper in this kind for the wealth of Windsor Castle.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 90)

Your wife is as honest a 'omans as will desires among five thousand, and five hundred too.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 92)

After, we'll a-birding together; have a fine hawk for the bush.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 99)
Shall it be so?  Anything.  If there is one, shall make two in the company.(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 100)
