Dat is good, by gar, with all my heart.  lousy knave, to have his gibes and his mockeries!(The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 25, Scene 103)
Take the boy to you. He so troubles me 'Tis past enduring.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 0)
Come, my gracious lord, Shall be your playfellow?(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 1)
No, I'll none of you.  Why, my sweet lord?   You'll kiss me hard and speak to me as if were a baby still.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 2)
--I love you better.   And why so, my lord?  Not for because Your brows are blacker--yet black brows, they say, Become some women best, so that there be not Too much hair there, but in a semicircle, Or a half-moon made with a pen.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 3)
Who taught this?   learned it out of women's faces.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 4)
--Pray now, What color are your eyebrows?  Blue, my lord.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 5)
Nay, that's a mock. have seen a lady's nose That has been blue, but not her eyebrows.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 6)
Hark ye, The Queen your mother rounds apace. We shall Present our services to a fine new prince One of these days, and then you'd wanton with us If we would have you.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 7)
She is spread of late Into a goodly bulk. Good time encounter her!(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 8)
What wisdom stirs amongst you?--Come, sir, now am for you again.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 9)
Pray you sit by us, And tell 's a tale.  Merry or sad shall 't be?(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 10)
As merry as you will.   sad tale's best for winter.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 11)
have one Of sprites and goblins.  Let's have that, good sir.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 12)
Come on, sit down. Come on, and do your best To fright me with your sprites.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 13)
You're powerful at it.   There was a man--  Nay, come sit down, then on.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 14)
Dwelt by a churchyard. will tell it softly, Yond crickets shall not hear it.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 15)
Come on then, and give 't me in mine ear.        Was he met there?(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 16)
His train? Camillo with him?   Behind the tuft of pines met them.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 17)
Never Saw men scour so on their way. eyed them Even to their ships.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 18)
How blest am In my just censure, in my true opinion!(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 19)
Alack, for lesser knowledge! How accursed In being so blest!(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 20)
There may be in the cup spider steeped, and one may drink, depart, And yet partake no venom, for his knowledge Is not infected; but if one present Th' abhorred ingredient to his eye, make known How he hath drunk, he cracks his gorge, his sides, With violent hefts.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 21)
have drunk, and seen the spider. Camillo was his help in this, his pander.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 22)
There is a plot against my life, my crown. All's true that is mistrusted.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 23)
That false villain Whom employed was pre-employed by him.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 24)
He has discovered my design, and Remain a pinched thing, yea, a very trick For them to play at will.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 25)
How came the posterns So easily open?  By his great authority, Which often hath no less prevailed than so On your command.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 26)
know 't too well. Give me the boy. am glad you did not nurse him.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 27)
Though he does bear some signs of me, yet you Have too much blood in him.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 28)
What is this? Sport?   Bear the boy hence. He shall not come about her.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 29)
Away with him, and let her sport herself With that she's big with,  for 'tis Polixenes Has made thee swell thus.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 30)
But I'd say he had not, And I'll be sworn you would believe my saying, Howe'er you lean to th' nayward.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 31)
You, my lords, Look on her, mark her well. Be but about To say "She is a goodly lady," and The justice of your hearts will thereto add "'Tis pity she's not honest, honorable.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 32)
" Praise her but for this her without-door form, Which on my faith deserves high speech, and straight The shrug, the "hum," or "ha," these petty brands That calumny doth use--O, am out, That mercy does, for calumny will sear Virtue itself--these shrugs, these "hum"s and "ha"s, When you have said she's goodly, come between Ere you can say she's honest.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 33)
But be 't known, From him that has most cause to grieve it should be, She's an adult'ress.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 34)
Should a villain say so, The most replenished villain in the world, He were as much more villain.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 35)
You, my lord, Do but mistake.  You have mistook, my lady, Polixenes for Leontes.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 36)
thou thing, Which I'll not call a creature of thy place Lest barbarism, making me the precedent, Should a like language use to all degrees, And mannerly distinguishment leave out Betwixt the prince and beggar.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 37)
--I have said She's an adult'ress; have said with whom.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 38)
More, she's a traitor, and Camillo is federary with her, and one that knows What she should shame to know herself But with her most vile principal: that she's bed-swerver, even as bad as those That vulgars give bold'st titles; ay, and privy To this their late escape.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 39)
No, by my life, Privy to none of this. How will this grieve you, When you shall come to clearer knowledge, that You thus have published me!(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 40)
Gentle my lord, You scarce can right me throughly then to say You did mistake.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 41)
No. If mistake In those foundations which build upon, The center is not big enough to bear schoolboy's top.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 42)
--Away with her to prison. He who shall speak for her is afar off guilty But that he speaks.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 43)
There's some ill planet reigns. must be patient till the heavens look With an aspect more favorable.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 44)
Good my lords, am not prone to weeping, as our sex Commonly are, the want of which vain dew Perchance shall dry your pities.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 45)
But have That honorable grief lodged here which burns Worse than tears drown.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 46)
Beseech you all, my lords, With thoughts so qualified as your charities Shall best instruct you, measure me; and so The King's will be performed.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 47)
Shall be heard?   Who is 't that goes with me? Beseech your Highness My women may be with me, for you see My plight requires it.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 48)
--Do not weep, good fools; There is no cause. When you shall know your mistress Has deserved prison, then abound in tears As come out.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 49)
This action now go on Is for my better grace.--Adieu, my lord.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 50)
never wished to see you sorry; now trust shall.--My women, come; you have leave.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 51)
Go, do our bidding. Hence!    Beseech your Highness, call the Queen again.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 52)
Be certain what you do, sir, lest your justice Prove violence, in the which three great ones suffer: Yourself, your queen, your son.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 53)
For her, my lord, dare my life lay down--and will do 't, sir, Please you t' accept it--that the Queen is spotless th' eyes of heaven, and to you--I mean In this which you accuse her.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 54)
If it prove She's otherwise, I'll keep my stables where lodge my wife.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 55)
I'll go in couples with her; Than when feel and see her, no farther trust her.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 56)
For every inch of woman in the world, Ay, every dram of woman's flesh, is false, If she be.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 57)
Hold your peaces.  Good my lord--   It is for you we speak, not for ourselves.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 58)
You are abused, and by some putter-on That will be damned for 't.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 59)
Would knew the villain! would land-damn him. Be she honor-flawed, have three daughters--the eldest is eleven; The second and the third, nine and some five; If this prove true, they'll pay for 't.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 60)
By mine honor, I'll geld 'em all; fourteen they shall not see To bring false generations.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 61)
They are co-heirs, And had rather glib myself than they Should not produce fair issue.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 62)
Cease. No more. You smell this business with a sense as cold As is a dead man's nose.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 63)
But do see 't and feel 't, As you feel doing thus, and see withal The instruments that feel.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 64)
If it be so, We need no grave to bury honesty. There's not a grain of it the face to sweeten Of the whole dungy Earth.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 65)
What? Lack credit?   had rather you did lack than my lord, Upon this ground.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 66)
And more it would content me To have her honor true than your suspicion, Be blamed for 't how you might.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 67)
Why, what need we Commune with you of this, but rather follow Our forceful instigation?(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 68)
Our prerogative Calls not your counsels, but our natural goodness Imparts this, which if you--or stupefied Or seeming so in skill--cannot or will not Relish a truth like us, inform yourselves We need no more of your advice.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 69)
The matter, The loss, the gain, the ord'ring on 't is all Properly ours.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 70)
And wish, my liege, You had only in your silent judgment tried it, Without more overture.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 71)
How could that be? Either thou art most ignorant by age, Or thou wert born a fool.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 72)
Camillo's flight, Added to their familiarity-- Which was as gross as ever touched conjecture, That lacked sight only, naught for approbation But only seeing, all other circumstances Made up to th' deed--doth push on this proceeding.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 73)
Yet, for a greater confirmation-- For in an act of this importance 'twere Most piteous to be wild--I have dispatched in post To sacred Delphos, to Apollo's temple, Cleomenes and Dion, whom you know Of stuffed sufficiency.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 74)
Now from the oracle They will bring all, whose spiritual counsel had Shall stop or spur me.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 75)
Have done well?  Well done, my lord.   Though am satisfied and need no more Than what know, yet shall the oracle Give rest to th' minds of others, such as he Whose ignorant credulity will not Come up to th' truth.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 76)
So have we thought it good From our free person she should be confined, Lest that the treachery of the two fled hence Be left her to perform.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 77)
Come, follow us. We are to speak in public, for this business Will raise us all.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 78)
To laughter, as take it, If the good truth were known.(The Winter's Tale, Act 0, Scene 79)
2        The keeper of the prison, call to him. Let him have knowledge who am.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 0)
Good lady, No court in Europe is too good for thee.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 1)
What dost thou then in prison?    Now, good sir, You know me, do you not?(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 2)
For a worthy lady And one who much honor.  Pray you then, Conduct me to the Queen.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 3)
may not, madam. To the contrary have express commandment.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 4)
Here's ado, to lock up honesty and honor from Th' access of gentle visitors.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 5)
Is 't lawful, pray you, To see her women? Any of them?(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 6)
Emilia?  So please you, madam, To put apart these your attendants, Shall bring Emilia forth.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 7)
pray now, call her.-- Withdraw yourselves.    And, madam, must be present at your conference.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 8)
Well, be 't so, prithee. Here's such ado to make no stain a stain As passes coloring.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 9)
Dear gentlewoman, How fares our gracious lady?(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 10)
As well as one so great and so forlorn May hold together.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 11)
On her frights and griefs, Which never tender lady hath borne greater, She is something before her time delivered.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 12)
boy?  daughter, and a goodly babe, Lusty and like to live.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 13)
The Queen receives Much comfort in 't, says "My poor prisoner, am innocent as you.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 14)
"  dare be sworn. These dangerous unsafe lunes i' th' King, beshrew them!(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 15)
He must be told on 't, and he shall. The office Becomes a woman best.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 16)
I'll take 't upon me. If prove honey-mouthed, let my tongue blister And never to my red-looked anger be The trumpet anymore.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 17)
Pray you, Emilia, Commend my best obedience to the Queen.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 18)
If she dares trust me with her little babe, I'll show 't the King and undertake to be Her advocate to th' loud'st We do not know How he may soften at the sight o' th' child.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 19)
The silence often of pure innocence Persuades when speaking fails.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 20)
Most worthy madam, Your honor and your goodness is so evident That your free undertaking cannot miss thriving issue.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 21)
There is no lady living So meet for this great errand.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 22)
Please your Ladyship To visit the next room, I'll presently Acquaint the Queen of your most noble offer, Who but today hammered of this design, But durst not tempt a minister of honor Lest she should be denied.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 23)
Tell her, Emilia, I'll use that tongue have. If wit flow from 't As boldness from my bosom, let 't not be doubted shall do good.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 24)
Now be you blest for it! I'll to the Queen. Please you come something nearer.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 25)
Madam, if 't please the Queen to send the babe, know not what shall incur to pass it, Having no warrant.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 26)
You need not fear it, sir. This child was prisoner to the womb, and is By law and process of great nature thence Freed and enfranchised, not a party to The anger of the King, nor guilty of, If any be, the trespass of the Queen.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 27)
do believe it.   Do not you fear. Upon mine honor, Will stand betwixt you and danger.(The Winter's Tale, Act 1, Scene 28)
Nor night nor day no rest. It is but weakness To bear the matter thus, mere weakness.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 0)
If The cause were not in being--part o' th' cause, She th' adult'ress, for the harlot king Is quite beyond mine arm, out of the blank And level of my brain, plot-proof.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 1)
But she can hook to me. Say that she were gone, Given to the fire, a moiety of my rest Might come to me again.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 2)
--Who's there?     My lord.  How does the boy?  He took good rest tonight.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 3)
'Tis hoped His sickness is discharged.  To see his nobleness, Conceiving the dishonor of his mother.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 4)
He straight declined, drooped, took it deeply, Fastened and fixed the shame on 't in himself, Threw off his spirit, his appetite, his sleep, And downright languished.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 5)
Leave me solely. Go, See how he fares. Fie, fie, no thought of him.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 6)
The very thought of my revenges that way Recoil upon me--in himself too mighty, And in his parties, his alliance.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 7)
Let him be Until a time may serve. For present vengeance, Take it on her.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 8)
Camillo and Polixenes Laugh at me, make their pastime at my sorrow.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 9)
They should not laugh if could reach them, nor Shall she within my power.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 10)
You must not enter.   Nay, rather, good my lords, be second to me.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 11)
Fear you his tyrannous passion more, alas, Than the Queen's life?(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 12)
gracious innocent soul, More free than he is jealous.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 13)
That's enough.   Madam, he hath not slept tonight, commanded None should come at him.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 14)
Not so hot, good sir. come to bring him sleep. 'Tis such as you That creep like shadows by him and do sigh At each his needless heavings, such as you Nourish the cause of his awaking.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 15)
Do come with words as medicinal as true, Honest as either, to purge him of that humor That presses him from sleep.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 16)
What noise there, ho?   No noise, my lord, but needful conference About some gossips for your Highness.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 17)
How?-- Away with that audacious lady. Antigonus, charged thee that she should not come about me.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 18)
knew she would.  told her so, my lord, On your displeasure's peril and on mine, She should not visit you.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 19)
What, canst not rule her?   From all dishonesty he can.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 20)
In this, Unless he take the course that you have done-- Commit me for committing honor--trust it, He shall not rule me.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 21)
La you now, you hear. When she will take the rein let her run, But she'll not stumble.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 22)
Good my liege, come-- And beseech you hear me, who professes Myself your loyal servant, your physician, Your most obedient counselor, yet that dares Less appear so in comforting your evils Than such as most seem yours--I say come From your good queen.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 23)
Good queen?   Good queen, my lord, good queen, say "good queen," And would by combat make her good, so were man, the worst about you.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 24)
Force her hence.   Let him that makes but trifles of his eyes First hand me.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 25)
On mine own accord I'll off, But first I'll do my errand.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 26)
--The good queen, For she is good, hath brought you forth a daughter-- Here 'tis--commends it to your blessing.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 27)
Out! mankind witch! Hence with her, out o' door.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 28)
most intelligencing bawd.  Not so. am as ignorant in that as you In so entitling me, and no less honest Than you are mad--which is enough, I'll warrant, As this world goes, to pass for honest.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 29)
Traitors, Will you not push her out?  Give her the bastard, Thou dotard; thou art woman-tired, unroosted By thy Dame Partlet here.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 30)
Take up the bastard, Take 't up, say. Give 't to thy crone.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 31)
Forever Unvenerable be thy hands if thou Tak'st up the Princess by that forced baseness Which he has put upon 't.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 32)
He dreads his wife.   So would you did. Then 'twere past all doubt You'd call your children yours.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 33)
nest of traitors!   am none, by this good light.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 34)
Nor nor any But one that's here, and that's himself.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 35)
For he The sacred honor of himself, his queen's, His hopeful son's, his babe's, betrays to slander, Whose sting is sharper than the sword's; and will not-- For, as the case now stands, it is a curse He cannot be compelled to 't--once remove The root of his opinion, which is rotten As ever oak or stone was sound.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 36)
callet Of boundless tongue, who late hath beat her husband And now baits me!(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 37)
This brat is none of mine. It is the issue of Polixenes.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 38)
Hence with it, and together with the dam Commit them to the fire.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 39)
It is yours, And, might we lay th' old proverb to your charge, So like you 'tis the worse.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 40)
--Behold, my lords, Although the print be little, the whole matter And copy of the father--eye, nose, lip, The trick of 's frown, his forehead, nay, the valley, The pretty dimples of his chin and cheek, his smiles, The very mold and frame of hand, nail, finger.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 41)
And thou, good goddess Nature, which hast made it So like to him that got it, if thou hast The ordering of the mind too, 'mongst all colors No yellow in 't, lest she suspect, as he does, Her children not her husband's.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 42)
gross hag!-- And, losel, thou art worthy to be hanged That wilt not stay her tongue.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 43)
Hang all the husbands That cannot do that feat, you'll leave yourself Hardly one subject.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 44)
Once more, take her hence.   most unworthy and unnatural lord Can do no more.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 45)
I'll ha' thee burnt.  care not. It is an heretic that makes the fire, Not she which burns in 't.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 46)
I'll not call you tyrant; But this most cruel usage of your queen, Not able to produce more accusation Than your own weak-hinged fancy, something savors Of tyranny, and will ignoble make you, Yea, scandalous to the world.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 47)
On your allegiance, Out of the chamber with her!(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 48)
Were a tyrant, Where were her life? She durst not call me so If she did know me one.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 49)
Away with her!   pray you do not push me; I'll be gone.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 50)
-- Look to your babe, my lord; 'tis yours. Jove send her better guiding spirit.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 51)
--What needs these hands? You that are thus so tender o'er his follies Will never do him good, not one of you.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 52)
So, so. Farewell, we are gone.   Thou, traitor, hast set on thy wife to this.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 53)
My child? Away with 't! Even thou, that hast heart so tender o'er it, take it hence, And see it instantly consumed with fire.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 54)
Even thou, and none but thou. Take it up straight.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 55)
Within this hour bring me word 'tis done, And by good testimony, or I'll seize thy life, With what thou else call'st thine.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 56)
If thou refuse And wilt encounter with my wrath, say so.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 57)
The bastard brains with these my proper hands Shall dash out.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 58)
Go, take it to the fire, For thou sett'st on thy wife.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 59)
did not, sir. These lords, my noble fellows, if they please, Can clear me in 't.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 60)
We can, my royal liege. He is not guilty of her coming hither.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 61)
You're liars all.   Beseech your Highness, give us better credit.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 62)
We have always truly served you, and beseech So to esteem of us.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 63)
And on our knees we beg, As recompense of our dear services Past and to come, that you do change this purpose, Which being so horrible, so bloody, must Lead on to some foul issue.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 64)
We all kneel.   am a feather for each wind that blows.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 65)
Shall live on to see this bastard kneel And call me father?(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 66)
Better burn it now Than curse it then. But be it; let it live.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 67)
It shall not neither.  You, sir, come you hither, You that have been so tenderly officious With Lady Margery, your midwife there, To save this bastard's life--for 'tis a bastard, So sure as this beard's gray.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 68)
What will you adventure To save this brat's life?(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 69)
Anything, my lord, That my ability may undergo And nobleness impose.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 70)
At least thus much: I'll pawn the little blood which have left To save the innocent.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 71)
Anything possible.   It shall be possible. Swear by this sword Thou wilt perform my bidding.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 72)
will, my lord.   Mark, and perform it, seest thou; for the fail Of any point in 't shall not only be Death to thyself but to thy lewd-tongued wife, Whom for this time we pardon.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 73)
We enjoin thee, As thou art liegeman to us, that thou carry This female bastard hence, and that thou bear it To some remote and desert place quite out Of our dominions, and that there thou leave it, Without more mercy, to it own protection And favor of the climate.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 74)
As by strange fortune It came to us, do in justice charge thee, On thy soul's peril and thy body's torture, That thou commend it strangely to some place Where chance may nurse or end it.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 75)
Take it up.   swear to do this, though a present death Had been more merciful.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 76)
--Come on, poor babe.  Some powerful spirit instruct the kites and ravens To be thy nurses!(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 77)
Wolves and bears, they say, Casting their savageness aside, have done Like offices of pity.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 78)
Sir, be prosperous In more than this deed does require.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 79)
--And blessing Against this cruelty fight on thy side, Poor thing, condemned to loss.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 80)
No, I'll not rear Another's issue.     Please your Highness, posts From those you sent to th' oracle are come An hour since.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 81)
Cleomenes and Dion, Being well arrived from Delphos, are both landed, Hasting to th' court.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 82)
So please you, sir, their speed Hath been beyond account.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 83)
Twenty-three days They have been absent. 'Tis good speed, foretells The great Apollo suddenly will have The truth of this appear.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 84)
Prepare you, lords. Summon a session, that we may arraign Our most disloyal lady; for, as she hath Been publicly accused, so shall she have just and open trial.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 85)
While she lives, My heart will be a burden to me.(The Winter's Tale, Act 2, Scene 86)
The climate's delicate, the air most sweet, Fertile the isle, the temple much surpassing The common praise it bears.(The Winter's Tale, Act 15, Scene 0)
shall report, For most it caught me, the celestial habits-- Methinks so should term them--and the reverence Of the grave wearers.(The Winter's Tale, Act 15, Scene 1)
the sacrifice, How ceremonious, solemn, and unearthly It was i' th' off'ring!(The Winter's Tale, Act 15, Scene 2)
But of all, the burst And the ear-deaf'ning voice o' th' oracle, Kin to Jove's thunder, so surprised my sense That was nothing.(The Winter's Tale, Act 15, Scene 3)
If th' event o' th' journey Prove as successful to the Queen--O, be 't so!(The Winter's Tale, Act 15, Scene 4)
-- As it hath been to us rare, pleasant, speedy, The time is worth the use on 't.(The Winter's Tale, Act 15, Scene 5)
Great Apollo Turn all to th' best! These proclamations, So forcing faults upon Hermione, little like.(The Winter's Tale, Act 15, Scene 6)
The violent carriage of it Will clear or end the business when the oracle, Thus by Apollo's great divine sealed up, Shall the contents discover.(The Winter's Tale, Act 15, Scene 7)
Something rare Even then will rush to knowledge. Go.(The Winter's Tale, Act 15, Scene 8)
This sessions, to our great grief we pronounce, Even pushes 'gainst our heart: the party tried The daughter of a king, our wife, and one Of us too much beloved.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 0)
Let us be cleared Of being tyrannous, since we so openly Proceed in justice, which shall have due course Even to the guilt or the purgation.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 1)
Produce the prisoner.   It is his Highness' pleasure that the Queen Appear in person here in court.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 2)
Silence!  Read the indictment.  Hermione, queen to the worthy Leontes, King of Sicilia, thou art here accused and arraigned of high treason, in committing adultery with Polixenes, King of Bohemia, and conspiring with Camillo to take away the life of our sovereign lord the King, thy royal husband; the pretense whereof being by circumstances partly laid open, thou, Hermione, contrary to the faith and allegiance of a true subject, didst counsel and aid them, for their better safety, to fly away by night.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 3)
Since what am to say must be but that Which contradicts my accusation, and The testimony on my part no other But what comes from myself, it shall scarce boot me To say "Not guilty.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 4)
" Mine integrity, Being counted falsehood, shall, as express it, Be so received.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 5)
But thus: if powers divine Behold our human actions, as they do, doubt not then but innocence shall make False accusation blush and tyranny Tremble at patience.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 6)
You, my lord, best know, Whom least will seem to do so, my past life Hath been as continent, as chaste, as true, As am now unhappy; which is more Than history can pattern, though devised And played to take spectators.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 7)
For behold me, fellow of the royal bed, which owe moiety of the throne, a great king's daughter, The mother to a hopeful prince, here standing To prate and talk for life and honor fore Who please to come and hear.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 8)
For life, prize it As weigh grief, which would spare.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 9)
For honor, 'Tis a derivative from me to mine, And only that stand for.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 10)
appeal To your own conscience, sir, before Polixenes Came to your court, how was in your grace, How merited to be so; since he came, With what encounter so uncurrent Have strained t' appear thus; if one jot beyond The bound of honor, or in act or will That way inclining, hardened be the hearts Of all that hear me, and my near'st of kin Cry fie upon my grave.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 11)
ne'er heard yet That any of these bolder vices wanted Less impudence to gainsay what they did Than to perform it first.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 12)
That's true enough, Though 'tis a saying, sir, not due to me.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 13)
You will not own it.  More than mistress of Which comes to me in name of fault, must not At all acknowledge.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 14)
For Polixenes, With whom am accused, do confess loved him as in honor he required, With such a kind of love as might become lady like me, with a love even such, So and no other, as yourself commanded, Which not to have done, think, had been in me Both disobedience and ingratitude To you and toward your friend, whose love had spoke, Even since it could speak, from an infant, freely That it was yours.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 15)
Now, for conspiracy, know not how it tastes, though it be dished For me to try how.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 16)
All know of it Is that Camillo was an honest man; And why he left your court, the gods themselves, Wotting no more than are ignorant.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 17)
You knew of his departure, as you know What you have underta'en to do in 's absence.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 18)
Sir, You speak a language that understand not. My life stands in the level of your dreams, Which I'll lay down.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 19)
Your actions are my dreams. You had a bastard by Polixenes, And but dreamed it.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 20)
As you were past all shame-- Those of your fact are so--so past all truth, Which to deny concerns more than avails; for as Thy brat hath been cast out, like to itself, No father owning it--which is indeed More criminal in thee than it--so thou Shalt feel our justice, in whose easiest passage Look for no less than death.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 21)
Sir, spare your threats. The bug which you would fright me with seek.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 22)
To me can life be no commodity. The crown and comfort of my life, your favor, do give lost, for do feel it gone, But know not how it went.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 23)
My second joy And first fruits of my body, from his presence am barred like one infectious.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 24)
My third comfort, Starred most unluckily, is from my breast, The innocent milk in it most innocent mouth, Haled out to murder; myself on every post Proclaimed a strumpet; with immodest hatred The childbed privilege denied, which longs To women of all fashion; lastly, hurried Here to this place, i' th' open air, before have got strength of limit.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 25)
Now, my liege, Tell me what blessings have here alive, That should fear to die?(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 26)
Therefore proceed. But yet hear this (mistake me not: no life, prize it not a straw, but for mine honor, Which would free), if shall be condemned Upon surmises, all proofs sleeping else But what your jealousies awake, tell you 'Tis rigor, and not law.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 27)
Your Honors all, do refer me to the oracle. Apollo be my judge.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 28)
This your request Is altogether just. Therefore bring forth, And in Apollo's name, his oracle.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 29)
The Emperor of Russia was my father. that he were alive and here beholding His daughter's trial, that he did but see The flatness of my misery, yet with eyes Of pity, not revenge.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 30)
You here shall swear upon this sword of justice That you, Cleomenes and Dion, have Been both at Delphos, and from thence have brought This sealed-up oracle, by the hand delivered Of great Apollo's priest, and that since then You have not dared to break the holy seal Nor read the secrets in 't.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 31)
All this we swear.  Break up the seals and read.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 32)
Hermione is chaste, Polixenes blameless, Camillo a true subject, Leontes a jealous tyrant, his innocent babe truly begotten; and the King shall live without an heir if that which is lost be not found.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 33)
Now blessed be the great Apollo!  Praised!  Hast thou read truth?(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 34)
Ay, my lord, even so as it is here set down.   There is no truth at all i' th' oracle.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 35)
The sessions shall proceed. This is mere falsehood.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 36)
My lord the King, the King!  What is the business?(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 37)
sir, shall be hated to report it. The Prince your son, with mere conceit and fear Of the Queen's speed, is gone.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 38)
How? Gone?  Is dead.   Apollo's angry, and the heavens themselves Do strike at my injustice.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 39)
How now there?   This news is mortal to the Queen.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 40)
Look down And see what death is doing.  Take her hence.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 41)
Her heart is but o'ercharged. She will recover. have too much believed mine own suspicion.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 42)
Beseech you, tenderly apply to her Some remedies for life.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 43)
Apollo, pardon My great profaneness 'gainst thine oracle.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 44)
I'll reconcile me to Polixenes, New woo my queen, recall the good Camillo, Whom proclaim a man of truth, of mercy; For, being transported by my jealousies To bloody thoughts and to revenge, chose Camillo for the minister to poison My friend Polixenes, which had been done But that the good mind of Camillo tardied My swift command, though with death and with Reward did threaten and encourage him, Not doing it and being done.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 45)
He, most humane And filled with honor, to my kingly guest Unclasped my practice, quit his fortunes here, Which you knew great, and to the hazard Of all incertainties himself commended, No richer than his honor.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 46)
How he glisters Through my rust, and how his piety Does my deeds make the blacker!(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 47)
Woe the while! cut my lace, lest my heart, cracking it, Break too!(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 48)
What fit is this, good lady?   What studied torments, tyrant, hast for me?(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 49)
What wheels, racks, fires? What flaying? Boiling In leads or oils?(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 50)
What old or newer torture Must receive, whose every word deserves To taste of thy most worst?(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 51)
Thy tyranny, Together working with thy jealousies, Fancies too weak for boys, too green and idle For girls of nine, think what they have done, And then run mad indeed, stark mad, for all Thy bygone fooleries were but spices of it.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 52)
That thou betrayedst Polixenes, 'twas nothing; That did but show thee of a fool, inconstant And damnable ingrateful.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 53)
Nor was 't much Thou wouldst have poisoned good Camillo's honor, To have him kill a king: poor trespasses, More monstrous standing by, whereof reckon The casting forth to crows thy baby daughter To be or none or little, though a devil Would have shed water out of fire ere done 't.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 54)
Nor is 't directly laid to thee the death Of the young prince, whose honorable thoughts, Thoughts high for one so tender, cleft the heart That could conceive a gross and foolish sire Blemished his gracious dam.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 55)
This is not, no, Laid to thy answer. But the last--O lords, When have said, cry woe!(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 56)
--the Queen, the Queen, The sweet'st, dear'st creature's dead, and vengeance for 't Not dropped down yet.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 57)
The higher powers forbid!   say she's dead. I'll swear 't.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 58)
If word nor oath Prevail not, go and see. If you can bring Tincture or luster in her lip, her eye, Heat outwardly or breath within, I'll serve you As would do the gods.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 59)
--But, thou tyrant, Do not repent these things, for they are heavier Than all thy woes can stir.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 60)
Therefore betake thee To nothing but despair. thousand knees Ten thousand years together, naked, fasting, Upon a barren mountain, and still winter In storm perpetual, could not move the gods To look that way thou wert.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 61)
Go on, go on. Thou canst not speak too much. have deserved All tongues to talk their bitt'rest.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 62)
Say no more. Howe'er the business goes, you have made fault th' boldness of your speech.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 63)
am sorry for 't. All faults make, when shall come to know them, do repent.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 64)
Alas, have showed too much The rashness of a woman.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 65)
He is touched To th' noble heart.--What's gone and what's past help Should be past grief.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 66)
Do not receive affliction At my petition. beseech you, rather Let me be punished, that have minded you Of what you should forget.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 67)
Now, good my liege, Sir, royal sir, forgive a foolish woman.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 68)
The love bore your queen--lo, fool again!-- I'll speak of her no more, nor of your children.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 69)
I'll not remember you of my own lord, Who is lost too.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 70)
Take your patience to you, And I'll say nothing.  Thou didst speak but well When most the truth, which receive much better Than to be pitied of thee.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 71)
Prithee, bring me To the dead bodies of my queen and son.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 72)
One grave shall be for both. Upon them shall The causes of their death appear, unto Our shame perpetual.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 73)
Once a day I'll visit The chapel where they lie, and tears shed there Shall be my recreation.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 74)
So long as nature Will bear up with this exercise, so long daily vow to use it.(The Winter's Tale, Act 16, Scene 75)
